And then I thought, well, it was cold too, February, if a wave hit get me hypothermia, would I have to do something? So I decided to try to crawl on my hands and knees up to the hole. When we got back to the States, I took a roll call and they found that they were short eight people.

Herman Bell speaks of Bird Fairclough.

He first went to Africa and he told me, walk most of the way around the shoreline of Africa, then to Sicily and from Sicily he want to Anzio. And he laid on that beach for 63 days without a bath or anything. And then he went further into Italy and was sent up on a hill to clean out some some nest gunness up there. And Finally was shot through the arm and he went down into one of those cellar like things. And I just they just shot in there with their machine guns and the bullets were going everywhere. But then he said they didn't hit him with had his helmet on and held up pretty bad. And they said the next morning somebody said, anybody in there better come out because we're going to blow it up. And he said it was an American's voice. And he said, boy, don't I'm in here. And so they came in and got him and took him down and had his arm treated. And they said they were going to shipping out. And I said, no way, you're going to ship me out. He said, I know every one of those places, I'm going back up. So he cleaned out several places up there. So that made it safer. And he went a lot of medals and he earned every one of them.

Paul Christie speaks of Al Kongslie.

North African campaign al Kongslie landed with the troops to the south of Casablanca when the ships landed there and you marched all the way across North Africa to Tunisia. And even he fought for ground support for Patton. His orders and now as one of the troops that ambushed the German Hakone. And I was came in as ground support for Al and went all the way through the African campaign, And Cicilia came around and was in the Landingham DayDay and all of the war always Hartmut. Hitler and Tojo had to be stopped

Dud Lemke.

We had a cause because we knew the person we were fighting what his intent was.

Continue to the mural of fourteen hundred and fifty two buildings.

stops.significance: Tulelake-Butte Valley Fairgrounds Museum Segregation Center Indoor Exhibit
stops.directionsToNextStop: Next, locate the pickle jar display.
stops.audioTranscript:
Stand briefly in the footsteps. You are atop the peninsula overlooking the Tulelake Relocation Center at Newell, located just eight miles south of here. 
Step over to the wooden cross.

This is a part of the original wooden cross placed on top of the peninsula or Castle Rock in 1942 by Japanese Americans who signed their names to the wooden plaque.

In 1943 the camp became a segregation's center. Its population peaked in September 1944 at eighteen thousand six hundred interned Japanese Americans.

The notice came back in two weeks that you have to leave. Then reality set in that we have to all leave. And that's all we had averaged two weeks time to actually dispose of our personal property, whatever it may be. And then fall into camp, but going to camp was OK. But then again, this is what you can take what you can carry. That it, no more. Tulelake the camp itself is kind of unique. When 1943 July, all the directors got together and decided that Tulelake would be a segregation center because there were more dissidents at Tulelake. And then the camp itself is one and a quarter mile square and had twenty eight guard towers around us. The farm had eleven guard towers around us. In total thirty two miles of fence actually in the fence from Tulelake to Klamath Falls, which is encompassed over 100 miles of barbed wire was strung around us. Eighteen thousand eight hundred inmates. But with twelve hundred full time soldiers on standby.

What I would be doing if I was back home, you know, comparing it to camp. And it was really the first time that I had been exposed to so many Japanese people from all over and everywhere there were all blackheads and I'm going I don't know how I would tell my friends apart.

What the produce we raised all the quality produce we pack four million pounds a year out of the warehouse, out the siding there, and talk to the other camp people that said they received some from Tulelake, but a lot of it was sent out on the road. So the destination unknown. And one day they were just dumping barrels of fish, to different messhalls, Every messhall got two barrels of fish. Then they went back and looked at the balance. This fish must be pretty old. They look at the barrel packed in 1934 by WP labor. The Army quartermaster would say what we're eating. They said, we're getting fresh fish. And that's how the Chronicle put it up there, and they said, we've been pampered. Ladies will go out there and spend all day long just digging for seashells in this nice seashells, and they'll make beads and birds and different ornaments out of it. Meantime, the men folks will sit out there, be smoking, playing cards, and they see all these seagulls coming there. They were catch these birds draw these stars and stripes and so forth. And so who could do the best designed birds. In the meantime, the birds would go back to the coastline and the game wardens says, where are these birds coming from, where all the insignias and painting on the bottom and birds and finally traced it back to Tulelake and the game warden put a stop there, painted the seagulls because they're protected birds.

The camp remained in operation longer than any other war relocation center closing March 20th, 1946.

Next, locate the pickle jar display.

stops.significance: Tulelake-Butte Valley Fairgrounds Museum - Final Indoor Exhibit
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the gift shop by using the straight aisle on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
As Tulelake receded in 1917, farm units for homesteading were made available after World War Two. The last groups of homesteaders were drawn in lotteries from 1946 to 1949.

The pickle jar became the choice for homestead lotteries after the fish bowl became too small. The 1946 drawing held at the armory in Klamath Falls included one thousand three hundred and five names typed on the slips of paper, put into capsules and placed into this three gallon pickle jar. Only 86 names were drawn.

This pickle jar was filled for the last time in 1949 in the American Legion Hall in Tulelake. Eighty six out of five thousand names were drawn.

With these drawings they had to have drawings for them because there were so many more applications than there was plots of land available. In the halls was always full. There is always there full of people who are sitting in a desk, people, a lot of them on the edge of the seat, hoping that their name would be the next one drawn out. But the ones that were there, why, they let out a good yell. The tension was there and everybody was just waiting to because they knew it was an opportunity there. They were getting an opportunity for new life in a new community. And it was really something to see.

When we got down there where we had guys that came next to us were navy. 'Course we were all army men, two Navy.

The morning at the we went to move out on our site, when it snowd, and when I got out there close to it, I put the car in second gear and opened it wide open and headed out. And when I hit the yellow post-it, mark my land the phone to the right of it out on the land, And where it got stuck, that was home.

We spent some time in the tent. The wind blew and mercifully that spring and that poor old tent, what kind of rock and it wasn't real, real comfortable. The dirt came in, of course, and we had our grain stored, our seed grain stored in the tent so it wouldn't get wet.

Move on to the Korean War display.

Members of our community served under the command of General MacArthur to help protect South Korea from conquest by North Korea, when war broke out in 1950.

When I got to Korea, they put us in some high walled camps for a while. Then they were building the Quonset hut barracks after a fashion. We were being woken up at night, sometimes with the small aircraft flying over the runway, dropping hand grenades, which they call bed check Charlie. I never did figure out why they didn't go after that guy, but they just let him do it night after night, probably a couple of nights every week.

Between August 5th, 1964, and April 30th, 1975, three point four million military personnel served in the Vietnam War.

The minute that door opened and you started walking towards the tarmac, the heat was just beyond anything, I'd and I'm a Phenix, Arizona boy, and this was a heat like I've never experienced, the humidity was up 105 percent, was probably 108 degrees, and it was eight o'clock at night.

I think there was one period of over three months that we weren't without any fresh meat or fresh vegetables. A typical breakfast was one spoonful of eggs. What are sort of green dehydrate would have been reconstituted out of powdered eggs at one spoonful of square dehydrated potatoes and possibly two little small Vienna sausages and one piece of bread without any butter or jam.

Rarely ever did you get to see the bad guy because his whole mission in life was to just Pick at you and run. They said we lost the war. We didn't lose the war. We fought it the best way we could. We were just as proud and dedicated to our own brothers as they were. We were just dealt a different kind of card.

The official end of America's direct involvement in Vietnam was April 30th, 1975.

Step over to the farming and ranching display.

Just as the United States is a melting pot of people from all parts of the world, so is this region. Sharing of education's travel experiences, agricultural knowledge and skills have created these diverse communities. 
Where have you found Nettles growing? You knew it was the finest soil. And as you know, we have lots of wild metals in this country, and it was also an indicator of water.

I had my first job when I was seven and Ray was nine. We delivered papers in the morning and milk in the afternoon and we got along fine. But I always wanted to ever do was be a cowboy.

The tractors gradually came in and replaced the horses in our area has a beautiful soil. Some of the best soil actually in the world.

You should now be standing in front of our current issues. This concludes the indoor segment of your audio tour. Feel free to visit the theater and research room behind you and spend time in the current issues section. When you are ready, return to the gift shop by using the straight aisle on your left.

stops.significance: Tulelake-Butte Valley Fairgrounds Museum - Segregation Center Outdoor Exhibit
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome back to the gift shop. Please proceed through the door to your right marked outdoor displays. Walk straight ahead to the tall guard tower.

The guard tower to see the pictures is straight up and down there. One of the 1943 after segregation, the one with the spread footing was the original old guard tower when the original camp was built. The guard towers, when you look at it, there's a flat door. As the guard goes up the towers, they get up the trapdoor. Then when they shut that, once they get up, shut the trap door and there's a hatch and lock it. So no one from the bottom comes from the same trap door. The soldiers protect themselves from people intruding from the bottom up. But still, the guard towers were outside of the fence. There's no way we can get through the guard tower anyway. That's how they were all built.

Now walk to the large black tar paper building.

Peer into the two windows, closest the museum building to see a Japanese American family. This is the living space they were given during their time at the Tulelake camp.

The barracks for Tule Lake and other campsall had staggerd 20 by 100 barracks. Tule Lake average barracks were five units apiece, 20 by 20 for five people. 20 by 16, it was four for four people.

So as far as that privacy and the girls didn't have any doors on the stalls there. And in fact, it was open for a while until they start putting separations between the bowls so that we had some privacy and then we would have our friends, hey, I got to go. You be my screen. You know, the dust and the sandstone is just terrible. You know, we'd open the window and then, of course, the flooring was too solid. So every time the sandstorm here comes in Rosharon and close the window and then but then the sand would come up between the wood on the floor and then all the sand would be on the blanket and table, what have you.

Now move to the next window. Inside, you will see bachelor living quarters.

So the bachelors were living in the twenty by sixteen, four bachelors that moved in. They didn't know each other, so if they couldn't get along with each other, they had a hard time. I know they would ask me to sneak some material in there that will get a 16 foot by six foot rope will put a wall in between them. So the only eight foot by twenty two people was just a narrow slit like. Some people really was ingenious how they made the prove what they did. They would go to the canteen and buy rice and take the mess. They have the cook for them, but they could very well put it in the barracks or what they did. They cook the whole the floor and they put the little basement like a mini basement barracks and put two or three barrels down there and put the rice down there and start fermenting the rice and put the lid on it so nobody can see it. That can smell like the smell of the outside. But still there were there out of sight, out of mind type of deal. And eventually they'll make the saki.

Continue to the third window. A homesteaders wife prepares a meal.

After the camp closed in 1946, many barracks were cut in half and hauled to newly allotted homesteads. This barrack is that half sized.

Barracks became homes for veterans trying to earn the right to own the land. The battle to keep dirt and cold out of the shack like buildings was a challenge for the homesteaders, just as it had been for the Japanese Americans who preceded them.

Continue to the last window.

Little by little, improvements were made to the buildings to make them more comfortable. Today, as you travel through the basin, you may notice remodeled barracks in use as homes.

This barracks had moved in. It was vertex inside and underneath the floor and had boards just for the one  by twelve, for the boards on the floor. I covered it with tarpaper and put the tongue and groove and down and had a better floor.

I think it was a lot harder on wives than it was on the man in general. And we'd get out, you know, work. wives are in the barrackswith little kids. When we got our barracks, they were given to us. And they were 100 hundred feet long, and we had to saw by my hand. They cut the electricity off the cap and then jack them up. Our house movers to move on our homesteads.

I find that I did a lot of things like my mother did when we were young kids because we had no electricity when I was real young.
This concludes the tour of our Museum of Local History.

We invite you to continue viewing the outdoor displays within this fenced area.

Thank you for your interest in our history. Your generous donations and support will help us continue to share the rich history of our basin. Please come again.

images.title: Inside Museum
images.altText: Inside Museum
images.caption: Inside Museum

data.title: Mystery of the Dunes
data.description: This self-guided interpretive tour takes you on a sensory experience of the Dune Life Nature trail.

stops.significance: Welcome to White Sands National Park’s Dune Life Nature Trail! You are looking at the oldest dunes in the park. This is the scene for our mystery – how does anything survive out here? We’ll be following along with Katie the Kit Fox and the blue trail markers to immerse our senses into the dunefield and what makes it, and the plants and animals, so unique. Let’s solve a mystery!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue straight on the desert trail and up the first dune. At the first trail sign about “Who Eats What,” follow the trail markers to the left for our next stop at the sign “Meat-eating mice?”
stops.audioTranscript: Welcome to White Sands National Park’s Dune Life Nature Trail! You are looking at the oldest dunes in the park. This is the scene for our mystery – how does anything survive out here? We’ll be following along with Katie the Kit Fox and the blue trail markers to immerse our senses into the dunefield and what makes it, and the plants and animals, so unique. Let’s solve a mystery!

stops.significance:
Grab a handful of sand and let it run through your fingers. Now dig down a few inches, does the feeling of the sand change? The dunes are full of water. When it rains, the dunes hold onto the fresh water and store it for the plants to use. The relationship between gypsum sand and water creates the foundation for life to adapt to an otherwise harsh environment.
Touch was the first of our senses, but what’s next? Let’s move to the next stop and engage a primary sense the animals use: smell.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the trail, following the blue trail markers, to the interpretive sign “Get Down and Come Eat”
stops.audioTranscript:
Grab a handful of sand and let it run through your fingers. Now dig down a few inches, does the feeling of the sand change? The dunes are full of water. When it rains, the dunes hold onto the fresh water and store it for the plants to use. The relationship between gypsum sand and water creates the foundation for life to adapt to an otherwise harsh environment.
Touch was the first of our senses, but what’s next? Let’s move to the next stop and engage a primary sense the animals use: smell.

stops.significance:
To fully appreciate your surroundings, close your eyes and focus on what you can smell. Does the dunefield have a distinct smell? What about the plants? Look to your left; this plant is a Hoary rosemary mint bush. Gently, without pulling them off, press some of the small leaves between your fingers. Smell your fingers. This sometimes minty, sometimes rosemary smelling plant is an important source of food for the pollinators that live in the dunes.
Now that we’ve taken in the scents of the dunefield, let’s move to our next stop and find out a little bit about the sounds that you could hear!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the trail, following the blue trail markers through the desert brush, to the interpretive sign “Hoo’s down in that hole?”
stops.audioTranscript:
To fully appreciate your surroundings, close your eyes and focus on what you can smell. Does the dunefield have a distinct smell? What about the plants? Look to your left; this plant is a Hoary rosemary mint bush. Gently, without pulling them off, press some of the small leaves between your fingers. Smell your fingers. This sometimes minty, sometimes rosemary smelling plant is an important source of food for the pollinators that live in the dunes.
Now that we’ve taken in the scents of the dunefield, let’s move to our next stop and find out a little bit about the sounds that you could hear!

stops.significance:
Close your eyes again. Listen. Identify two sounds you can hear – are they natural?  Are you hearing the wind? The cottonwood leaves? A distant thunderstorm? Now listen to some sounds that you might hear at night. How are they different?  Lots of the animals come out at night to hunt and avoid the searing mid-day heat.
With sound, we may not see what we can hear. Let’s move to the next stop to take in the sights of the dunefield.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on trail, following the blue trail markers up the big dune, to the interpretive sign “Jackrabbit for dinner…again?”
stops.audioTranscript:
Close your eyes again. Listen. Identify two sounds you can hear – are they natural?  Are you hearing the wind? The cottonwood leaves? A distant thunderstorm? Now listen to some sounds that you might hear at night.  [group of coyotes yipping] [spadefoot toad croaking] [thunder] [leaves rustling] How are they different?  Lots of the animals come out at night to hunt and avoid the searing mid-day heat.
With sound, we may not see what we can hear. Let’s move to the next stop to take in the sights of the dunefield.

stops.significance:
Take in your surroundings; what do you see? 

In the distance, two mountain ranges stand tall, surrounding this basin. The dunes meet the Chihuahuan Desert, and plants spring up between the dunes. The many environments of the park - the dunes, the desert, the playas, and between the dunes - all coexist and support the plants and animals of the park. Like an island in a ocean, the dunefield is an isolated environment; many of the species that live here can only live here!

With all your senses engaged, let’s go find out if we’ve solved the mystery!
stops.assetName: Eye Spy with My Little Eye
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on trail, following the blue trail markers, back to where you came up the dune and the trail splits.
stops.audioTranscript:
Take in your surroundings; what do you see? 
In the distance, two mountain ranges stand tall, surrounding this basin. The dunes meet the Chihuahuan Desert, and plants spring up between the dunes. The many environments of the park - the dunes, the desert, the playas, and between the dunes - all coexist and support the plants and animals of the park. Like an island in a ocean, the dunefield is an isolated environment; many of the species that live here can only live here!
With all your senses engaged, let’s go find out if we’ve solved the mystery!

stops.significance:
Now that we’ve explored the dunefield with our senses, how do you think the plants and animals survive? Animals and plants have used adaptations for thousands of years to find a home in this unique place.
	You may have noticed we still have one sense to go – taste! This one is super important; pull out your water bottle and take a big drink. Your adaptation for survival out here is your body’s ability to sweat and cool down. If you don’t hydrate, your body can’t cool itself down.
	Thank you for coming along with us to solve the dunefield mystery! Enjoy the rest of your trip and stay safe!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the parking lot by following the blue trail markers back down the dune and through the desert scrub.
stops.audioTranscript:
Now that we’ve explored the dunefield with our senses, how do you think the plants and animals survive? Animals and plants have used adaptations for thousands of years to find a home in this unique place.
	You may have noticed we still have one sense to go – taste! This one is super important; pull out your water bottle and take a big drink. Your adaptation for survival out here is your body’s ability to sweat and cool down. If you don’t hydrate, your body can’t cool itself down.
	Thank you for coming along with us to solve the dunefield mystery! Enjoy the rest of your trip and stay safe!

images.title: Aerial Shot of Dune Life Trailhead
images.altText: Aerial photo of white dunes meeting brown desert with a parking lot in the bottom right corner.
images.caption: The dunefield stretches for miles and miles, but it has to end somewhere!

data.title: National Mall Half-Day Tour
data.description: This walking route starts at the Smithsonian Metro and takes you on an efficient walking route through all the major memorials on the National Mall.

stops.significance: At the National Mall exit from Smithsonian Metro, this information kiosk is your first spot to get park information.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed west on the path toward the Washington Monument.

stops.significance: The Washington Monument Lodge is your one-stop shop for national parks passport stamps. Tickets for the Washington Monument are given out at the window in the rear of the building on a first-come, first-served basis. You may want to inquire about tickets later in the day and return to the monument at your assigned time. However, the tour inside the Washington Monument can be a time-consuming venture and it is not accounted for in this 2-4 hour tour of the landmarks.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed on the circular path around the Washington Monument.

stops.significance: Completed in 1884, the Washington Monument was the tallest building in the world at the time, a dizzying 555 feet, 5-1/8 inches. The monument was built to honor the first president of the United States, George Washington, for whom the city is also named. Looking up, you can see the windows on the observation deck, 500' in the sky.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the circular path around the Washington Monument and cross at the crosswalk on 17th Street for the World War II Memorial. You may go around the Washington Monument in either direction; the White House is visible if you take the circle counterclockwise.

stops.significance: The World War II memorial honors the service and sacrifice of Americans on the homefront and the warfront. Columns represent each of the U.S. states and territories at the time of the war, and a wall of stars represents the servicemembers who gave their lives in the conflict. Additional features include bas reliefs of different scenes from the war, quotes from notable figures, and two "victory pavilions" with bronze sculptures of eagles laying a laurel wreath above the Victory Medal. Visit the nearby information kiosk to access the WWII memorial database of servicemembers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go north along 17th street.

stops.significance: Where Constitution Ave., a busy thoroughfare now runs, there was once a canal that provided access into the city from the Potomac River. The house is now an information station for park visitors.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go west along Constitution Ave, or follow the elm walk along the Reflecting Pool.

stops.assetName: 56 Signers of the Declaration of Independence Memorial

images.credit: Carol M. Highsmith's America, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division.
images.title: Washington Monument and Reflecting Pool
images.altText: The Washington Monument at night reflected in the still water of the Reflecting Pool.
images.caption: The Washington Monument, World War II Memorial, and Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool.

data.title: Native American Heritage Walking Tour
data.description: For thousands of years, Native peoples have lived, raised families, and created culture in the Cuyahoga Valley. This flat, unpaved walk is a little over two miles out and back on the Towpath Trail. It explores the remnants these peoples left on the land. Be aware: at times, nearby Canal Road can be noisy.

stops.significance: Do you know who was here before you? What peoples walked this land before we did? How do we know about them? Take a walk north on the Towpath Trail to explore the lives of Indigenous peoples who were here for thousands of years. Watch for the Cuyahoga River to the west (left). Along the way, consider what has changed over many generations. What sounds would Native Americans have heard? What would the land look like? How has it changed? What will future generations know about us from what we leave behind?
stops.directionsToNextStop:
You may wish to explore the Canal Exploration Center, which has some stories of Native Americans and the canal. The Center is open seasonally. Afterward, learn more history on this flat, 2-mile roundtrip hike.

To start, turn north (away from Blossom the mule) and walk the Towpath Trail. Carefully cross Hillside Road. In ½ mile, stop at the wayside exhibit to your left to learn about Native Americans’ reliance on the Cuyahoga River.

stops.significance: The Cuyahoga River was a vital lifeline for Native Americans. It provided both food and transportation. What do you think might have been for dinner if you lived along the river 500 years ago? Imagine paddling this river in a wooden dugout canoe to seek beaver for trade. How do we know what Native Americans ate? Like us today, they left trash behind. What would your dinner trash reveal about you?
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue north 0.4 miles on the Towpath Trail, watching for bikes and other trail users. Stop at the next wayside exhibit for an “unknown” village site, Pilgerruh.

stops.significance: During the 1600s and 1700s, Native Americans found themselves pushed westward as Europeans crowded the eastern seaboard. At these western edges, conflict was ongoing. Native Americans found themselves pawns in a war an ocean away in Europe, but the struggle was also in their villages. Tribes and communities often fought or fled together. Learn about one such group, fleeing the violence of massacre, who rested here for almost a year. Owing to changes in the river and land, archeologists are unsure exactly where their village was. What would make you leave your home?
stops.directionsToNextStop: At first contact with Europeans, vast cities and farming communities could be found in North America. To learn about a large farming community, continue 0.2 miles north, crossing a paved path, the old Stone Road, to the final two signs.

stops.significance:
Past peoples lived at the South Park site for hundreds of years, building big villages and farming complexes. Sometimes they occupied, left, and re-occupied areas. We don’t know what these people called themselves, so we have given them a name. What these peoples left behind gives us a foggy peek into their lives. Check out both the Ohio Historical Marker and the park wayside exhibit. What do you think these peoples’ lives were like?

After reading the exhibits, you have three choices. You can continue north another ½ mile to Rockside Station and then double back. You can turn back a short distance and turn right to follow the 1½-mile roundtrip Hemlock Creek Trail. Or you can return directly to Canal Exploration Center. As you walk back the way you came, consider the many generations of Native Americans who lived, loved, raised families, shared stories, and passed on. What will future peoples be wondering about us?

images.title: South Park Village Illustration
images.altText: A sepia drawing of a prehistoric village of 7 loaf shaped buildings, surrounded by a circular fence.
images.caption: An illustration of South Park, a Whittlesey village near Stone Road.

data.title: Natural Bridges Scenic Drive
data.description: Everything Natural Bridges has to offer is accessed via the scenic drive. Cruise the 9-mile driving loop, stopping for short walks to viewpoints of the bridges, archeological sites, and more. This tour will guide you through the monument, providing helpful directions and must-know facts.

stops.significance: Stop at the park visitor center first. Here you can pay your park entry fee or show your pass, pick up a map, browse the bookstore, and more! Exhibits and the 10-minute park film will introduce the area and the monument’s history. The visitor center is also a great place to fill up on water and use restroom facilities.
stops.directionsToNextStop: To start the scenic driving loop, exit the visitor center parking lot in your vehicle. At the stop sign, turn right and continue on the road. Once you reach the start of the driving loop, the road is one lane and one-way. Continue on the one-way scenic loop drive to the Sipapu Bridge Viewpoint parking area. Park and walk along the paved path to the viewpoint (581 feet / 177 meters roundtrip).

stops.significance: Sipapu is the largest bridge in the park and named after the Hopi term for the opening between worlds. The viewpoint gives sweeping views of the bridge and the canyon landscape it spans. The viewpoint is particularly great for geology, with desert varnish streaking down the canyon walls and pot holes on the canyon rim. Below, you can see where an ancient river flowed through the canyon and carved out the bridge.
stops.directionsToNextStop: After you finish marveling at Sipapu Bridge, retrace your steps back to your vehicle and continue driving along the scenic drive until you reach the parking area for Horse Collar Ruin Overlook. Park and take the short, unpaved hike to the overlook, about 0.6 mile or 1 kilometer roundtrip. If short on time or unable to hike far, skip this stop and head to Kachina Bridge Viewpoint.

stops.significance: Natural Bridges is more than a geology monument! This special place was also home to the ancestral Pueblo peoples who once lived throughout the Four Corners area. Horse Collar Ruin is well preserved and easily seen from the overlook.
stops.directionsToNextStop: After studying Horse Collar Ruin, retrace your steps back to your vehicle. Continue driving along the scenic drive until you reach the parking area for Kachina Bridge (combined viewpoint and trailhead parking). Park and walk along the paved path to the Kachina Bridge Viewpoint, 0.26 mile or 0.42 kilometer roundtrip.

stops.significance: Kachina is the thickest bridge in the park at a whopping 44-foot width. From the viewpoint, you get a bird’s eye view of this massive sandstone bridge and the canyons below. The winding paved path is dotted with desert plant life, including yucca, juniper, and pinyon pine.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps back to your vehicle and continue driving the scenic drive until you reach the parking area for Owachomo Bridge (combined viewpoint and trailhead parking). Park and walk along the paved path to the Owachomo Bridge Viewpoint, 519 feet or 158 meters roundtrip.

stops.significance: Owachomo is the thinnest, and perhaps oldest, natural bridge in the park. From the viewpoint, you can see Owachomo’s span against the canyon country backdrop. The viewpoint also allows for views of sweeping biological soil crust, a living crust that gives life to this arid environment.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps back to your vehicle and continue driving along the scenic drive until you reach a small parking area with waysides and views of Bears Ears buttes. Park and walk to the waysides for views of the surrounding Cedar Mesa and Bears Ears National Monument.

stops.significance: Bears Ears Buttes and surrounding area are sacred lands to many local peoples, who come to visit, gather, and perform ceremonies. Although not within the monument boundaries, Bears Ears are an iconic landmark visible from many places in the Four Corners area. One of the best views of these buttes is this wayside here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to your vehicle and continue driving the scenic drive. This drive will loop back to the start, where you can take the loop again or turn right back to the visitor center and out of the monument.

images.title: Kachina Viewpoint and Trailhead sign
images.altText: A stone sign marking the parking area for Kachina Bridge along a road in canyon country
images.caption: The 9-mile scenic drive provides access to all three natural bridges, beautiful views, and more!

data.title: Natural Sounds Audio Tour
data.description: All recorded sounds were recorded by Dr. Nathan Wolek the 2020 artist-in-resident. The National Park Service Natural Sounds and Night Skies Division and Atlantic Center for the Arts are partnering for this environmental arts program. Close your eyes and listen to the sounds of Canaveral National Seashore. Multiple locations are recorded throughout the park including Apollo Beach, Playalinda Beach and Seminole Rest.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Drive to Turtle Mound. Follow the boardwalk to the top of the Mound.
stops.audioTranscript: Clicking sounds of underwater life.

stops.directionsToNextStop: From this middle platform head left or right to another platform.
stops.audioTranscript: Sounds of waves cicadas, crickets and a plane flying over head.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Go back down the boardwalk to the middle platform that is sheltered by the two Turtle Mound peaks.
stops.audioTranscript: Sounds of waves crashing.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Drive south to Eldora parking lot 8.
stops.audioTranscript: Birds chirp, cicadas call, and waves crash.

images.title: Soundwalk Wolek Beach
images.altText: Two feet and a sound recorder on the beach.
images.caption: Listen to the sounds of the seashore.

data.title: Nisqually Vista Nature Tour
data.description: Season: Summer The Nisqually Vista Nature Trail is open year-round and is a popular snowshoeing route in winter, but this self-guided tour is designed for the summer season when the trail is snow-free. In spring and fall, there may be patches of snow covering sections of trail. Please stay on trails, even if it means crossing snow, to avoid trampling delicate meadow plants. The Nisqually Vista Nature Trail provides an opportunity to learn about some of the forces that have shaped the Paradise landscape.

stops.significance: This year-round creek is the first indicator of some of the forces that shape Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Deadhorse Creek
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail uphill for 450 feet (about 2 minutes). The next stop is a boulder on the right with a large hollow center.

stops.significance: A boulder and its distinct features provide clues to the formation of Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: The Hollow Rock
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail for 440 ft (about 1 minute). The next stop is a small stream crossing just before the trail junction.

stops.significance: Take a closer look at the meadows that make Mount Rainier a true “Paradise”.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Meadow Life
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail for 250 feet (about 1 minute). The next stop is a small pool on the right side of the trail.

stops.significance: This tiny pond is a Paradise landmark, demonstrating the unique ecosystem of the subalpine zone.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Fairy Pool
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail for 0.2 miles (about 4 minutes). The next stop is the first of a series of overlooks on the right side of the trail, with a large wooden boundary.

stops.significance: The first of three fantastic views exposes evidence of the dynamic history of Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Mountain Passages
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the right for 170 feet (about 1 minute). The next stop is the second overlook on the right with a small wooden boundary.

stops.significance: Eruptions aren’t the only major events to change the surface of Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Valley of Water and Ice
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the right for 180 feet (about 1 minute). The next stop is the third overlook on the right with a wooden boundary on three sides.

stops.significance: The surface of the mountain is constantly being carved by glaciers, creating unique features and formations.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Sculpting the Mountain
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the right for 100 feet (less than 1 minute). The next stop is the final and largest overlook – the Nisqually Vista – on the right with a stone and wooden boundary and exhibit panel.

stops.significance: Take in the full vista of Mount Rainier and one of its most prominent and famous glaciers.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Nisqually Vista
stops.directionsToNextStop: View the exhibit panel at this overlook. Use the next stop in the app for written and audio description of the exhibit panel. Otherwise continue to “Mountains Upon Mountains”.

stops.significance: Learn more about the features and movement of glaciers. Use this stop in the app for written and audio description of the exhibit panel.
stops.assetName: Paradise Meadows: Nisqually Vista Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the right for 390 feet (about 2 minutes). The next stop is along a downhill section with a clearing in the trees on the right and views of a mountain range.

stops.significance: The ancient rocks of the Tatoosh Range tell the story of a time before Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Mountains Upon Mountains
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail for 375 feet (about 2 minutes). The next stop is just before the trail switchback with a large cluster of trees on the right.

stops.significance: A stand of trees signals the adaptations plants use to survive through extreme winters and short summers.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Tree Clusters
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail uphill along the switchbacks for 0.1 mile (about 3 minutes). The next stop is just before the trail junction with meadows and boulders in the immediate surroundings.

stops.significance: The locations of boulders throughout the Paradise valley illustrate the massive forces of mudflows.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: Well-traveled Rocks
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the trail to the right to head back to the trailhead. The final stop is in 0.2 mile (about 5 minutes) at the bench just before the stone steps of the trailhead.

stops.significance: Take in one final view of the mountain on this trail and ponder the past and future of Mount Rainier.
stops.assetName: Nisqually Vista Walking Tour: A Changing Mountain
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go down the steps to the trailhead, which leads to the Paradise lower parking lot. Taking the Deadhorse Creek Trail at the junction will connect to other Paradise area trails.

images.title: Nisqually Vista Nature Trail
images.altText: Nisqually Vista Nature Trail begins with a short flight of stairs and an informational sign.
images.caption: Nisqually Vista Nature Trail

data.title: North Bridge Self-Guided Tour
data.description: The fight at Concord's North Bridge occurred around 9:30 a.m., April 19, 1775. It was here that Colonial soldiers were first ordered to fire upon British Regulars. It was here the first British soldiers died. This self-guided tour will help you explore the significant sites, structures and landscapes associated with the battle at Concord's North Bridge and the events of April 19, 1775. Most of the sites are accessible by foot within half a mile of each other.

stops.significance: This is the best place to park and begin the tour. North Bridge Visitor Center features a short video and exhibits about the North Bridge fight. It is generally open April through October. Parking is available year round.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the front door of North Bridge Visitor Center and walk back toward the parking area. Follow the sidewalk to the right. You will see a large, yellow colonial house across the street. This is the Major John Buttrick House.

stops.significance: Major John Buttrick led the Colonial advance to North Bridge and gave the order to fire. The bodies of Isaac Davis and Abner Hosmer, who were killed at the North Bridge, were brought to the house.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back towards North Bridge Visitor Center. From the front door, walk straight, past the exposed cellar holes, to the stone wall beside Liberty Street. The Muster Field is on the opposite side in front of you.

stops.significance: The minute man and militia companies gathered here and formed their column just prior to advancing to the North Bridge.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around and walk a few paces back toward North Bridge Visitor Center. You will see a wide, dirt/sand path. Follow this to your right down the hill. This is the old Groton Road.

stops.significance: The Groton Road dates back to the late 1600s. On April 19, 1775 the minute and militia companies marched along this road as they advanced to the North Bridge and against the British soldiers posted there.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking down the Groton Road. As the road turns to your left, you will see an exhibit panel. Walk across the grass to your right towards a wood-rail fence where you will see another exhibit panel near the stone wall by the modern road.
stops.audioTranscript:
Today, when you walk from North Bridge Visitor Center to the North Bridge battle site you are actually walking on a colonial road that is over three centuries old! This is the same route taken by the colonial soldiers during the battle at North Bridge on April 19, 1775.

The area today occupied by the North Bridge unit of Minute Man National Historical Park was once an Indigenous settlement known as Musketaquid. In 1635 the land was purchased by the English from the indigenous inhabitants and incorporated into the town of Concord. The area beyond the river became known as the North Quarter.

In 1654 the town laid out a road from the main village out to the North Quarter and constructed a bridge across Concord River. The route of this road follows much of modern-day Monument Street until you get to the entrance to the North Bridge site. At this point Monument Street continues straight north while the old road (now closed to vehicles) turns west to the North Bridge.

At this same time the town constructed a gravel and stone causeway which led west from the bridge for 400 feet along the riverbank. The purpose of the causeway was to improve passage across the wet land beside the river.
In 1699 the farm road beyond the causeway was extended and improved. The new road followed the causeway west from the bridge then turned north and east “up ye hill” (towards the current-day North Bridge Visitor Center) then turned west. This westerly turn is located at the top of the hill as you approach North Bridge Visitor Center.

There was also a west branch that split off at the western end of the causeway just before the east branch made the turn “up ye hill." The west branch followed the river past the Brown family house lot. Both the east and west branch rejoined further west and continued passed the Barrett Farm to Groton.

In 1750 the town to build a new causeway and also paid for the construction of a low stone wall along the northern edge to separate it off from Buttrick’s property.
In 1760 the North Bridge was rebuilt. This was the bridge in use at the time of the battle on April 19, 1775.

On April 19, 1775, the British arrived in Concord around 7:30 a.m. Approximately 225 British soldiers crossed the North Bridge. They left 96 men behind to guard the bridge and the road. The rest continued along the west branch of the Groton Road to Colonel Barrett’s farm to search for arms and supplies. The colonial soldiers, whose numbers grew to over 400 men watched and waited on high ground northwest of the bridge at a place now known as the Muster Field.

Sometime around 9:30 a.m. the colonial soldiers noticed smoke rising from Concord center. Colonel Barrett issued the order to march but not to fire first. The colonial soldiers marched down the east branch of the Groton Road, then onto the causeway leading to the North Bridge. As they approached, the British soldiers retreated across the bridge and prepared for action.

In the ensuing fight the minute men and militia were constrained by the narrowness of the old causeway. Their column was hemmed in by the river on their right and a stone wall on their left, beyond which was a wet meadow. A veteran of Captain David Brown’s Company, Amos Barrett, wrote that “we then was all ordered to fire and not kill our own men.” Thus constrained they could not form a proper line of battle. They remained in column, elevated their muskets and fired over each other’s heads and shoulders. 

In 1793 the town of Concord moved the river crossing to its present location, further north on current-day Monument Street. At this same time a new road was constructed which is today Liberty Street. The old Groton Road, river crossing and causeway, which played such a key role in the battle on April 19, 1775 were abandoned and reverted to pasture and meadow.

In 1836 a granite obelisk was erected at the battle site on the east bank where the British soldiers stood. In 1874 a bridge was built on the site of the old North Bridge. A year later the Minute Man statue by Daniel Chester French was dedicated on the 100th anniversary of the battle. However, the land west of the North Bridge beyond the Minute Man statue remained privately owned and access blocked by an iron fence.

In 1959 the old Concord battleground became part of Minute Man National Historical Park. Eventually, the land west of the North Bridge, which had been closed off, was reopened. Historical research and archaeology were done to determine the route of the long-vanished roads. Parts of the causeway and the route of the eastern branch of the Groton Road were excavated. The route of the western branch was also studied. The eastern branch was then reopened as a walking trail from North Bridge Visitor Center to the North Bridge. Reopening the Groton Road allows you to more fully explore the North Bridge battle site and better understand its context within the historic landscape. As you do so you are walking in the footsteps of history!

stops.significance: Captain David Brown lived here with his family. He led his men into battle on April 19, 1775 just yards from his home. The property had been in his family since the 1640s.
stops.assetName: The Captain David Brown House Site
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Groton Road walking path and continue walking for about 150 yards toward the North Bridge.

stops.significance: The first time colonial soldiers were ordered to fire upon British soldiers happened here on April 19, 1775. The first British soldiers died on the east bank, along with two minute men from Acton upon the west bank.
stops.directionsToNextStop: While at Concord's North Bridge, you will see the Minute Man Statue on the west bank of the river.

stops.significance: This statue, representing a minute man of 1775, was created by sculptor Daniel Chester French and unveiled for the centennial celebration of the battle. on April 19, 1875.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk across the North Bridge to the east bank of the river. The 1836 Battle Monument is directly ahead of you.

stops.significance: Standing twenty-five feet tall, the 1836 Battle Monument was the first monument erected at the famous North Bridge battlefield in Concord Massachusetts. Although the monument towers over the bridge today, it’s construction and legacy remain fraught with controversy.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Standing on the east side of the 1836 Battle Monument, where the plaque is, the Grave of British Soldiers is set within the stone wall to your left.

stops.significance: This gravesite marks the final resting place of the first British soldiers to die during the American Revolution, on April 19, 1775.
stops.assetName: Grave of British Soldiers at the North Bridge
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the wide path that runs between the double row of trees towards Monument Street. Take a right onto the sidewalk at Monument Street and walk about 100 yards. The Elisha Jones House is across the street on your left.

stops.significance: This house still bears a scar of the battle. A retreating British soldier fired into it. It was later the home of prominent Concord resident John Shepard Keyes.

images.title: Concord's North Bridge
images.altText: An arched wooden bridge spans a small river. Trees display autumn color against an overcast sky.
images.caption: Concord's North Bridge, site of the "shot heard round the world."

data.title: North District Driving Tour
data.description: Enjoy this driving tour of the highlights of the North District of Cape Cod National Seashore (Truro and Provincetown areas). Stop by the visitor center to plan your trip or follow along on this short, 1-2 hour tour!

stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit Highland Light Road and turn right onto Route 6 towards Provincetown. Follow Route 6 for 2 miles. Turn right onto Pilgrim Heights Road. Trail entrance is adjacent to gazebo in first parking lot.

Exit Pilgrim Heights Road and turn right onto Route 6 towards Provincetown. Follow Route 6 for 4.7 miles and turn right at the stop light onto Race Point Road. Stay on Race Point Road for 1 mile. Follow signs and turn left into the Beech Forest parking area. Trailhead is at the end of the first parking area.

Exit the Beech Forest parking area and turn left onto Race Point Road. Follow the road for 1.5 miles. Follow signs to the Race Point Beach parking lot. The Old Harbor Life-Saving Station is on the right side of the parking area.

images.title: Old Harbor Life-Saving Station
images.altText: Ramp leads down to garage of Old Harbor Life-Saving Station. House against dunes and gray sky.
images.caption: Old Harbor Life-Saving Station in present day.

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Day in the Life During the Manhattan Project
data.description: Step back in time in downtown Oak Ridge as you discover the same shopping districts, lodging, recreation, and houses of worship that Manhattan Project workers and visitors would have enjoyed long ago.

stops.significance: Jackson Square, originally called Town Center No.1, opened in 1943 and was often considered the primary shopping and entertainment hub in Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. Residents could find 24-hour grocery shopping at over a dozen stores, several restaurants, a bowling alley, a pharmacy, a movie theater, and dance hall among many other attractions. It was here that many Oak Ridgers gathered to celebrate the end of World War II.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head southwest along Broadway Ave. and in a short distance the Guest House will loom large on a hill in front of you.

stops.significance: The Guest House (now the Alexander Inn assisted-living facility) was the primary hotel for official visitors during the Manhattan Project. Constructed in 1943, several Manhattan Project luminaries stayed here over the duration of the war including J. Robert Oppenheimer, General Leslie Groves, and Secretary of War Henry Stimson. Room rates for all guests was $2 per night for a room with a private bath, or $1.50 per night with a communal bathroom.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk north along E. Madison Rd. directly behind the Guest House and the Chapel on the Hill will quickly come into view.

stops.significance: Built in 1943, this standard military 700-series chapel was one of three military chapels constructed at Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. The chapel received its name during a prayer of dedication on September 30, 1943. 22 different congregations worshiped here during the Manhattan Project, with worshipers being segregated by both denomination and race. The United Church purchased the chapel in 1955 and continues to hold services to this day.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the chapel, head south back to Broadway Ave., cross over Broadway Ave. to Tennessee Ave., and the tennis courts will appear on the right.

stops.significance: One of several locations throughout Oak Ridge constructed for Manhattan Project workers to exercise, the community tennis courts became popular for a reason other than tennis. On pleasant evenings these courts hosted outdoor dances for workers and residents. The first dance was held here on July 22, 1944, and soon became a weekly event during the war. Today, Oak Ridgers use the courts for recreation and the National Park Service and community partners occasionally host throwback dances here.

images.title: Jackson Square, 1945
images.altText: Elevated 1945 photo of a strip mall with parking lot at center and people walking throughout
images.caption: Jackson Square, 1945

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Day in the Life During the Manhattan Project (Part 2)
data.description: Step back in time as you discover more places in Oak Ridge that Manhattan Project workers and residents would have visited for shopping, entertainment, and recreation long ago.

stops.significance: Grove Center, along with Jackson Square and Jefferson Square, was a primary shopping and entertainment district in Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. The center included a grocery store, clothing store, and shoe store among many other businesses. Grove Center's main attraction was the Grove Theater, a state-of-the-art concert hall that held approximately 1,000 people. As you explore the area today, take time to see what events are occurring at the theater.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk or drive across Robertsville Rd. and the community swimming pool will be directly across the street from Grove Center.

stops.significance: The community swimming pool, a spring-fed pool constructed in 1945, was a popular location for workers and residents to cool off on hot summer days during the Manhattan Project. Prior to the pool's construction, the site was home to a small pond called Cross Pond. This watering hole provided respite for people and livestock as they migrated toward middle Tennessee during the 19th century. The swimming pool remains a popular feature of the Oak Ridge community to this day.

images.title: Oak Ridge Swimming Pool
images.altText: Black and white photo of several young people in swimsuits gathered on a wooden platform at a pool
images.caption: The Community Swimming Pool was a popular gathering place during the Manhattan Project.

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Walk Through Wheat
data.description: Explore the area that was once the Wheat community, a small rural community that existed for decades prior to the displacement of its citizens to make way for the Manhattan Project, specifically the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant.

stops.significance: This Baptist church, constructed in 1901, is the last surviving structure of the Wheat community. Officially named in 1881 by local postmaster Henry Franklin Wheat, the Wheat community boasted a post office, several schools, a Masonic lodge, a service station, three churches, a small school and several residences and farms. In 1942, the federal government selected 59,000 acres of land in East Tennessee to develop what would become Oak Ridge. Manhattan Project administrators offered residents of Wheat and nearby communities between $35-45 dollars per acre to give up the land with no relocation expenses provided; many were told to vacate within two weeks.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Travel southwest from the Wheat Church towards Blair Rd. In your vehicle, turn left from the gravel parking lot onto Blair Rd (.3 mi or .48 km) and then right onto SR-58. Turn right into the ETTP complex (1 mi or 1.6 km) and follow signs for the K-25 History Center.

stops.significance: The K-25 History Center is a free museum located within the remnants of the K-25 complex (now ETTP). The center tells the remarkable story of the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant, a uranium-enrichment facility that was the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project. It was on this massive site that the majority of the Wheat community existed. Multiple homes, businesses, and farms were destroyed and many residents were displaced to make way for this revolutionary scientific undertaking.

images.title: Wheat Church, 1948
images.altText: A black and white photograph of a small church and graveyard on a wooded hillside.
images.caption: Wheat Church, 1948

data.title: Oak Ridge: For Kids
data.description: The City of Oak Ridge has something for kids of all ages to enjoy. From world-class museums to outdoor activities and attractions, every member of your family will enjoy a day in the secret city.

stops.significance: The Children's Museum of Oak Ridge, opened in 1974, holds a wide array of exhibits, including hands-on learning opportunities in art, science, environmental studies, history, geography, and world cultures. In addition, the museum is home to the Manhattan Project Oak Ridge Visitor Center. Park rangers are on hand to answer any questions you may have about the wealth of historic sites throughout  the city.
stops.directionsToNextStop: By car- Turn right on W. Outer Drive and right onto Highland Avenue. Turn left onto Robertsville Road and left onto Oak Ridge Turnpike. A.K. Bissell Park will appear on your right.

stops.significance: A.K. Bissell Park has something for both kids and adults to enjoy. This 38-acre park offers you the chance to picnic, walk, jog, play on the playground, or just relax on a nice day. The park is home to the International Friendship Bell, a massive bronze bell symbolizing peace and unity between the United States and Japan. Be sure to ring the bell during your visit. Also, the Secret City Commemorative Walk is located in the park. Take this short walk to learn more about the founding of Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project.
stops.directionsToNextStop: By car- Turn right onto Oak Ridge Turnpike and turn right at the stoplight onto S. Tulane Avenue. Turn left onto Wilson Street and turn right onto E. Main Street. The museum will appear on the left at the end of the strip mall.

stops.significance: The American Museum of Science and Energy is an Oak Ridge institution. Here you will find countless interactive scientific exhibits from the Manhattan Project to the present day. Children of all ages will enjoy the hands-on learning opportunities found within the museum.
stops.directionsToNextStop: By car- From the American Museum of Science & Energy, turn left onto S. Rutgers Ave. Turn left onto Vermont Ave. Turn left onto Pennsylvania Ave. and take a slight left onto Providence Rd. The pool will appear on the left.

stops.significance: The Oak Ridge Community Swimming Pool, constructed in 1945 as a place for Manhattan Project workers to enjoy on hot summer days, has been a staple of the community ever since. The pool holds approximately 2.2 million gallons (8 million liters) of water, making it one of the largest spring-fed pools in the United States. Located across from Grove Center, the pool is open during summer months.

images.title: A Child Receives a Security Badge, 1945.
images.altText: Black and white photo of child with two policemen
images.caption: A child receives a security clearance badge, 1945.

data.title: Oak Ridge: Visit K-25
data.description: Walk in the footsteps of thousands of Manhattan Project employees as you imagine what it was like working in secrecy in the largest building in the world at the time.

stops.significance: The Turnpike Gatehouse, one of many positioned throughout the secret city during and after the Manhattan Project, controlled access to K-25. Armed guards stood watch here 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The interior of the gatehouse is closed to the public, excepting special events. Hiking trails begin in the parking lot and lead through the now-abandoned Wheat community, one of several rural communities that existed before the Manhattan Project.
stops.directionsToNextStop: By car- Turn right onto SR-58 for a few minutes until you reach ETTP on the right. Turn right onto Heritage Center Blvd. and left onto Enrichment St. The K-25 History Center is on your right just past the fire station.

stops.significance: The K-25 History Center tells the remarkable story of the K-25 complex from the Manhattan Project through the Cold War. Here you will find hundreds of exhibits on the revolutionary science that led to the development of the atomic bomb, as well as artifacts and information pertaining to the thousands of workers who called this complex home. Admission is free. Directly behind the museum sits a massive empty field. This was the site of the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant, the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project.
stops.directionsToNextStop: By car- Turn left on Enrichment St. right onto Heritage Center Blvd., and right onto SR-58 as you exit ETTP. Take an immediate left into the parking lot of the K-25 Overlook and Visitor Center.

stops.significance: The K-25 Overlook and Visitor Center is located on the site of Happy Valley, the construction and workers’ community that sprung up during the Manhattan Project. As you explore the visitor center, you will find more information on Happy Valley, K-25, and the Manhattan Project as a whole. Standing in the parking lot and looking across SR-58 will give you a panoramic view of the now-demolished K-25 complex.

images.title: K-25, 1947
images.altText: Aerial photo of large industrial complex in wooded valley.
images.caption: The K-25 plant was the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project.

data.title: Oakland Plantation Self-Guided Walking Tours
data.description: Explore the grounds of Oakland Plantation through a self-guided walking tour. The tour explores a wide range of buildings and people who lived on the plantation. Maps available at the Oakland entrance pavilion. A cell phone tour is also available.

park.fullName: Cane River Creole National Historical Park
park.name: Cane River Creole

tags: Cane River Creole National Historical Park

stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Oakland Plantation, a part of the Cane River Creole National Historical Park. You are about to enter one of the most intact Creole Plantations in existence. Creole can mean different things to different people. Here in the Cane River area, Creoles are descended from Louisiana’s colonial settlers. This can be any combination of colonial French, Spanish, African, or Native American descent. The term Creole can also be used to label the contributions of the Creole Culture, including their language, food, and architecture.

Oakland Plantation was a thriving agricultural community for nearly 200 years. The workforce was originally comprised of enslaved laborers. Following emancipation, sharecroppers and tenant farmers worked the fields. Along with the people who worked the fields, you also had doctors, blacksmiths, carpenters, laundresses, and store clerks. All these people played key roles in ensuring the success of the plantation. Founded by Jean Pierre Emanuel Prud’homme around 1785, Oakland would remain in the family for the next two centuries. During that time span the family would endure the Civil War, outbreaks of the boll weevil, and the great depression. 

As you tour the plantation today, you will gain an understanding of life on a cotton plantation and come away with a new appreciation for the contributions of the diverse group of people who lived and worked on this land.

The North Slave/Tenant Cabin is one of two that remains at Oakland and is a remnant of a larger community, which extended for a quarter-mile to the south along the river. These buildings were home to generations of workers at Oakland Plantation--first enslaved families and later tenant farming families. Many of those later families and individuals were formerly enslaved or descendants of enslaved people, who continued to toil in the fields where their ancestors had labored.

Sharecropper and tenant farmer families lived in these quarters as late as the 1960s. The interior is historically furnished to the tenant farming era. Tenant farmers and sharecroppers did not own their own farms, and to work the land they had to turn over a share of the crop to the landowner. These people would shop for goods at the plantation store on a credit system. When the crop came in, they had to settle their debt with the landowner and the plantation store, and whatever was left over was their net profit. If it was a bad growing season, or if the boll weevil invaded the crop, the sharecroppers might be in debt at the end of the year. It was extremely difficult to get ahead under this labor system, so many farm workers from the south began migrating to large northern cities to find better jobs.

This building was the home of the plantation overseer. The overseer was employed by the Prud’homme family as a manager of the farm. He made sure the cotton was planted, chopped, picked, ginned, and pressed. The overseer was responsible for management of the laborers. Delegating labor to repair buildings, mend fences, and tend to livestock.

Built of bousillage around 1860, it served as a home for overseers until the 1960s. The first overseer to occupy this home was Seneca Pace. Pace kept a journal of his activities at Oakland. His journal provides readers with a record of the planting cycle and numerous other labor activities. One of Pace’s most frequent topics was the weather, which of course was one factor that could make or break a growing season.

During the first half of the twentieth century this building was the home of the Metoyer family. Leo Metoyer lived here with his parents, wife, and three children. Leo was the yardman at Oakland. He tended to the animals and the yard in front of the main house.

The Corn Crib or Square Crib was built by enslaved people in the 1820s of hand-hewn cypress logs with carved Roman numerals. It was a storage place for corn grown on the plantation. Cotton was the plantation’s main crop, but they grew several other fruits and vegetables, chief among them being corn. Corn was an essential part of the diet of the enslaved worker and used as feed for livestock. Today on Cane River, corn has surpassed cotton as the main agricultural product.

Beside the corn crib, sits a brick cistern. The groundwater in this region was un-suitable for drinking, so the people built cisterns to collect rainwater. Cisterns can be made from brick and buried underground, or they can be constructed from wood and placed above ground or in attics. The brick cistern adjacent to the corn crib was sixteen feet deep and held almost 5,000 gallons of water.

For much of its history, Oakland Plantation was a thriving, self-sufficient farm community. Everything the Prud’homme family and the laborers needed was here on the plantation, including their own doctor. Various doctors would occupy this building throughout its history.

Large plantations had hospitals to provide medical treatment for their enslaved laborers. Quite often doctors would make rounds to area plantations treating the ill. In some cases, like Oakland, a doctor resided on the property. It is likely that the hospital at Oakland stood in the field beside the Cottage. The ailments of the enslaved were numerous. Due to their strenuous work schedule and environment, along with a poor diet, the enslaved fell victim to a variety of illnesses. 

After a succession of doctors, this building became home to various members of the Prud’homme family. Today, the Doctor’s Cottage serves as a park administration building.

stops.assetName: Oakland Mule Barn, Carpenter Shop and Pigeonnier
stops.audioTranscript:
The Mule Barn started out as a smokehouse. When the original mule barn was destroyed by a lightning storm, this building was converted to be the new mule barn. This building is a great example of the resourcefulness and ability to adapt, exhibited by the Prud’homme family.

The Carpenter’s Shop is constructed of hand-hewn cypress logs. At the corners of this structure, you can see the notching that held the logs in place. The building is covered with a coat of lime wash. Lime was the main ingredient in any recipe for lime wash, but recipes could vary from region to region. Lime wash is another example of the Creole ability to make practical use of readily available materials.

Pigeonniers or dovecotes were common on French Creole plantations. The Prud’homme family housed pigeons in these buildings, which they would harvest for pigeon pie or squab on toast. They would also eat the eggs and use the pigeon waste as fertilizer.

The store was constructed after the Civil War and quickly became a focal point of the community. In the words of historian Ann Malone, “the postbellum rural merchant was all things to his community…His store was the hub of the local universe. It was the marketplace, banking and credit source, recreational center, public forum, and news exchange.” Oakland’s store also served as a post office on and off during its existence, further enhancing its importance in the community.

The plantation store could also prove to be a financial burden to the sharecroppers. Quite often sharecroppers could not get out from under the mountain of debt that they accumulated at the stores. Historian Carol Breedlove noted, “Perhaps the Prud’hommes could have done more, or been more generous [with the sharecroppers]. On the other hand, they could certainly, in their environment and historical period, have done less, been less supportive and more selfish.” As the numbers of sharecroppers dwindled, so did the importance of the plantation stores. The Prud’hommes closed their store for good in 1982.

The Oakland Plantation Store is the park's main visitor contact station. Inside the store you will find historic exhibits, NPS passport stamps, Junior Ranger books, and a gift shop.

The live oaks lining the entrance to the main house at Oakland are especially magnificent. These trees are believed to have been planted in the early 19th century. The allée that they form was intended to act as a “breeze way” to keep the Main House cooler by funneling breezes off Cane River. The river which sits approximately 100 yards in front of the house served as a transportation artery, food source, and recreational outlet for the communities situated on its banks.

The Bottle Garden in front of the Main House was originally laid out as a boxwood-lined parterre garden sometime between the late 1810s and the late 1820s. Parterre gardens, with their low plantings and geometric patterns, were designed to be seen from the gallery of the raised house and were common to French landscape design. After a blight killed the boxwood hedges, the Prud’homme family used bottles from the wine cellar below the house to line the planting beds. The family maintained this tradition until the NPS acquired the property, replacing broken bottles with new ones or older ones from the wine cellar.

Today, the roughly rectangular Bottle Garden contains beds in geometric shapes: rectangles, diamonds, hearts, waves, circles, clovers, and stars, laid out with sense of symmetry. The bottle edging includes wine bottles from Taylor Wine Company, ale and stout beer bottles, salt-glazed stoneware bottles, Anheuser-Busch beer bottles, mineral water bottles, soda water bottles, and bitters bottles. The oldest bottles date to around 1790, while the newest bottle dates to the late 1990s. The Bottle Garden is one of the more unique features at Oakland.

As Europeans began settling along the Gulf Coast and Mississippi Valley, they incorporated old world architectural styles to suit their new climate. Built by enslaved workers, the Main House at Oakland retains the pitched or sloping roof that is characteristic in French structures from Normandy to Quebec, but it also shows characteristics brought to North America from the West Indian Creoles including the elevated first floor, spacious porch, and multiple double doors. All these innovations helped cool the house during the humid summer months. One regional component of the main house and other structures along Cane River is bousillage. Bousillage is mud from the river mixed with Spanish moss or straw creating a brick like substance which is prevalent in the interior walls of the house.

The 1821 house consisted of only four rooms on the main level and has seen several additions through the years. Below the house, the ground floor has a room for an enslaved nanny, who accessed the bedrooms on the upper floor through a staircase and trapdoor in floor. Also below the house are a wine cellar, several storage rooms, and "museum" that was used by the Prud'homme family in the mid-20th century to display various objects to visitors.

Oakland’s Main House stands as an excellent example of French Creole architecture that utilizes old world and new world concepts mixed with regional techniques. The Main House is open to the public on weekends from 10 AM to 2 PM.

This building originally sat closer to the Main House and served as the Cook’s House. During the difficult times of the Great Depression, the Prud’hommes moved this building to its current location and turned it into a cabin for recreational fishermen. To meet the needs of the fishermen the Prud’hommes also had boats for rent and bait for sale. Plantation workers made extra cash cleaning and cooking fish. During the Great Depression, the price of cotton dipped below the cost of production, making the income generated by the fishing camp especially important.

This building today, stands as an example of the ability to successfully adapt to and eventually overcome a difficult economic situation. In addition, the building is one of the best examples of bousillage on the plantation.

stops.assetName: Oakland Setting Pen, Fattening Pen and Wash House
stops.audioTranscript:
These buildings behind the Main House are further examples of the self-sufficiency of Oakland Plantation. The setting pen was used to house nesting chickens; the fattening pen was for chickens they planned to eat. The wash house was where laundry was done.

Chickens were a common site on plantations. In historian, John Michael Vlach’s book Back of the Big House he cited the following advantages to raising chickens: “they provided both meat and eggs; they could be maintained on very small amounts of feed; and they could be killed on short notice, thus reducing the risk of spoilage.”

Laundry was originally done by enslaved workers, and then by paid domestics. Louisiana lore contends that on laundry day, people would eat red beans and rice, since that meal required little attention giving folks time to concentrate on doing the laundry.

images.title: Trail sign at Oakland Plantation
images.altText: Brown trail sign with Oakland Overseer's House in background.
images.caption: Trail signs mark the path of the self-guided tour route at both plantations.

data.title: Obscure Memorials of the National Mall
data.description: Come visit the National Mall and see some of the more obscure memorials like the Arts of War and Peace, John Paul Jones, 56 Signers Island, the newly reopened Lockkeepers House and more! Walk the path less taken.

stops.significance: This memorial commemorates American Revolutionary War sea captain and “Father of the US Navy” John Paul Jones. His maritime exploits during the war terrified the British and boosted the morale of the American people. This memorial was dedicated by President William Howard Taft on April 16, 1912 the day after the steamship Titanic sank.

The Japanese lantern is in the grove where the first cherry trees from Japan were planted. The lantern is a symbol of the friendship between the people of  the United States and Japan. It was one of a pair of lanterns carved in 1651 in Nagasaki as a tribute to the recently passed Tokugawa Iemitsu, Second Shogun of the Tokugawa Dynasty. This lantern stood in Tokyo’s famous Ueno Park until 1954 when it was given to the National Mall. It is lit just once a year during the Cherry Blossom Festival.

In 1931 President Herbert Hoover dedicated the District of Columbia War Memorial to the music of a John Phillip Sousa led US Army Band. It honors all the citizens of the District of Columbia who served in the First World War. The names of the four hundred and ninety-nine District of Columbia citizens who died in the conflict are engraved on the memorial’s marble base. Today it is a popular spot for weddings on the National Mall.

The John Ericsson Memorial honors the Swedish-American inventor who advanced the building of early railroads, invented the screw propeller and designed the innovative Civil War warship Monitor which saved the Union Blockade. It was jointly dedicated in 1926 by both US President Calvin Coolidge and the Crown Prince of Sweden Gustaf Adolf.
