The Arts of War and Peace are a set of four massive bronze gold leaf covered equestrian statues that guard the entrances to the Arlington Memorial Bridge and Rock Creek Parkway. Designed by American Sculptors James Earle Fraser and Leo Friedlander just before the Second World War, the project was abandoned by the US government during the war years. In 1950 the statues were cast in Italian foundries by the Italian Government as a gift for our assistance helping them rebuild postwar.

stops.assetName: Arts of Peace: Music and Harvest

stops.significance: The Vietnam Women’s Memorial was added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in 1993. It honors all the American women who served in the Vietnam War. Since all eight of the women listed on the Vietnam Wall were either U.S. Army or U.S. Air Force nurses it was decided to make the memorial a bronze statue of three nurses aiding a wounded soldier. It was created by the American Sculptor Glenna Goodacre the same artist who created the US Sacajawea dollar coin.

Beginning in World War I, the government maintained "temporary" office buildings on this site for use by the United States Navy and the Munitions Department. Nicknamed "Tempos," these structures remained until the 1970s when President Richard M. Nixon ordered their removal. The buildings were demolished in 1971 after they were no longer in use by the Navy. President Nixon then directed that a park be laid out on the land, leading to the creation of Constitution Gardens.

The Gardens were dedicated in May of 1976 as an American Revolution Bicentennial tribute. It has become an important water feature of the National Mall.

On July 2nd, 1984 Signer’s Island was added to Constitution Gardens on the two hundred and eighth anniversary of the unanimous vote for independence by the Continental Congress. The vote for independence was made July 2nd but its wording was not approved and ratified until July 4th, 1776, Independence Day. The signatures of each of the fifty-six signers of the Declaration of Independence are recreated carved in red granite on this unique memorial.
stops.assetName: 56 Signers of the Declaration of Independence Memorial

stops.significance: From 1815 till 1871 what is now Constitution Avenue was the western entrance to the Washington City Canal. The canal was then bricked over and reutilized as part of the city sewer system, but a visible reminder remains. Built in 1837 the Lockkeeper’s House housed the Lockkeeper and his family who operated the canal entrance and collected its tolls. One of the oldest structures on the National Mall, it was recently restored in 2018 and reopened to the public.

In 1683, the first German settlement in America at Germantown, northwest of Philadelphia was founded. Four hundred years later a visit by the Chancellor of Germany, Helmut Kohl, to President Ronald Reagan at the White House resulted in the creation of a garden on the National Mall. The garden celebrated four centuries of friendship between the American and German people. Four years later both leaders would dedicate a garden filled with trees and plants common to both nations.

President Thomas Jefferson wanted American cartographers to draw the longitudinal Prime Meridian thru the new capital of Washington DC. In 1804, a meridian wooden marker was placed directly south of the White House on what would later become the Washington Monument grounds. The original wooden marker was replaced with a larger stone marker in 1889. This site is also close to the original intended location for the Washington Monument.

images.title: John Paul Jones Memorial
images.altText: A monument featuring a dark bronze , standing figure atop an ornate stone base.
images.caption: John Paul Jones Memorial

data.title: Ocracoke Village Tour
data.description: Take a tour of the beautiful historic Village.

stops.significance: Ocracoke Visitor Center is a great place to start a visit to this historic island village.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed behind the visitor center to the black stone marker on the shoreline.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Cape Hatteras National Seashore, a part of the National Park System, where the rich natural and cultural resources of the Outer Banks of North Carolina are preserved and protected.

At the southern end of the seashore, the Ocracoke Lighthouse signals ships that a safe harbor can be found in Silver Lake Harbor within the nearby village of Ocracoke. This 1.8-mile tour starts at the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center, then ends at the Ocracoke Lighthouse. Allow at least 45 minutes to visit the sites on the tour and to return directly from the lighthouse grounds to the visitor center. Any side trips will take additional time.

For those who want to continue on through the village, this tour will end with suggested ways back through the charming village. Enjoy your visit!

Starting at the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center gives you a chance to orient yourself with the village, the island, and the rest of Cape Hatteras National Seashore. It also gives you a chance to ask a National Park Service ranger any questions you might have, pick up permits for off-road vehicle use or for beach fires, shop in the gift store, or make use of the restroom facilities.

stops.significance: Silver Lake, at the core of Ocracoke Village, provides a picturesque view of the area.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the Harbor road away from the visitor center to the Ocracoke Working Watermen's Exhibit.
stops.audioTranscript: Using caution as you walk across the street, take a walk along the Silver Lake Harbor Docks. Silver Lake Harbor played a pivotal role in the development of the village. With the threat of German U-boats just offshore during World War II, the US Navy expanded and deepened Silver Lake Harbor, which later provided a means for tourism to flourish by allowing large ferry boats to access the village directly, as well as a wide variety of private boats.

stops.significance: A great exhibit detailing the life and means of the people who have worked the waters for a living.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down Cemetery Road to the  British Cemetery.

stops.significance: Cemetery containing the remains of members of the British Navy killed during World War II off the coast of Ocracoke Island.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed back to Silver Lake, and follow the road east.  Make a right on Lighthouse Road and proceed to the Ocracoke Light Station on the right side of the road.

stops.significance: Site of the second oldest lighthouse in the United States, and oldest functioning lighthouse in North Carolina.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed back down Lighthouse Road to return to Silver Lake and the Ocracoke Visitor Center.
stops.audioTranscript:
Take a stroll around Silver Lake Harbor to Creek Road, which connects with Lighthouse Road. A short walk down Lighthouse Road takes you to the boardwalk of the Ocracoke Lighthouse. It is a pleasant 9/10-mile walk from the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center, and a great way to experience the village.

Walk along the boardwalk to the base of the Ocracoke Lighthouse and take in your surroundings. Have you noticed where the lighthouse keepers lived? If you have visited Bodie Island or Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, what differences can you see from those lighthouses and this one? Why do you think this is the case? Explore the Ocracoke Lighthouse site within this app to learn how this lighthouse is different.

As you move toward the base of the lighthouse, you might notice a couple of small buildings located near the lighthouse. What do you think they might have been used for? The answers can be found within this app.

After visiting the lighthouse grounds, you can wander back to the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center by following a variety of different routes. You may continue on down Lighthouse Road, which turns into Loop Road (and loops back around to the Lighthouse Road.) This will allow you to visit The North Carolina Coastal Land Trust’s Springer’s Point Preserve where a nature trail loops around to Ocracoke Inlet. Heading back down Lighthouse Road toward North Carolina-12, gives you a chance to stroll down Howard Street, the oldest street in the village. Be sure to use care crossing North Carolina-12. The end of Howard Street merges back with North Carolina-12, which you can follow back to the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center. Along the way you might be interested in detours to visit the Working Waterman’s Exhibit, the British cemetery, or the Ocracoke Preservation Society Museum.

We hope you enjoyed this tour and discovered something new along the way.

images.title: Ocracoke Lighthouse
images.altText: Ocracoke Lighthouse

data.title: Off the Beaten Path: Billings Gap Overlook Route
data.description: This hike takes you to a great viewpoint of the Billings Gap area between Blue Mesa and the landform to the east. The route follows the steep edge of Blue Mesa and offers views of badlands to the east and the broad grassy valleys to the north and south. The badlands’ blues, purples, grays, and whites seem to shift throughout the day and with the seasons. The summer monsoon adds a touch of green vegetation and wildflowers.

stops.assetName: Off the Beaten Path Billings Gap Overlook Route Stop 1
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back to the beginning of the pullout to the right of the wayside exhibit.

stops.assetName: Off the Beaten Path Billings Gap Overlook Route Stop 2
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the edge of the mesa in a clockwise direction.

stops.assetName: Off the Beaten Path Billings Gap Overlook Route Stop 3
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the edge of the mesa in a clockwise direction.

stops.assetName: Off the Beaten Path Billings Gap Overlook Route Stop 4
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the edge of the mesa in a clockwise direction.

stops.assetName: Off the Beaten Path Billings Gap Overlook Route Stop 5
