data.title: Ohanapecosh Hot Springs Walking Tour
data.description: As you walk along this loop trail, look for the travertine mineral deposits, evidence of human history, and the interconnection of living things. Be advised pets are not allowed on this a 0.6-mile walking tour trail that ends in the Ohanapecosh Campground at Loop B. While it might be tempting, bathing is not permitted, and drinking is not advised as the water temperature is not hot enough to kill bacteria. Please Leave No Trace by staying on the trail to help us preserve and protect this place.

stops.significance: Your adventure begins behind the Ohanapecosh visitor center, near a massive tree slice.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along this tour by taking the trail to the right. Do not cross the small stream here that leads to the campground loop, but take the trail that runs parallel to it to the right. The next stop is where the trail crosses a short wooden boardwalk in approximately 225 feet. Look around you between stops; this is the wettest section of forest along this trail. As you walk consider: where does your water come from?

stops.significance: The plants that grow in wet conditions are adapted to their environment.
stops.directionsToNextStop: A series of boulders to the right of the trail marks the next stop in 300 feet. As you walk further away from the stream look for changes in the vegetation.

stops.significance: Different plants grow in different parts of the forest depending on the resources available.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is in 200 feet where the trail turns to the left and a large stump is visible to the right.

stops.significance: Is it bad when a tree dies? Or does it provide a benefit to the forest?
stops.directionsToNextStop: You are leaving the 'hemlock forest' and entering an area kept moist by the flow from the hot springs. The next stop is in 200 feet at the beginning of a short wooden boardwalk.

stops.significance: The Ohanapecosh hot springs were once a health resort. The water temperature is not hot enough to kill bacteria. Bathing is not permitted, and drinking is not advised.
stops.directionsToNextStop: In 200 feet the trail forms a T-intersection. Keep left to continue the tour; the next stop will be at a section of trail with a raised boardwalk approximately 350 feet after this turn. The trail to the right of the T-intersection leads to Silver Falls. The walk from Ohanapecosh Campground to Silver Falls and back is about 3 miles round trip, with an elevation gain of 300 feet.

stops.significance: The hot springs deposit colorful minerals at this location.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is near a low rock wall on the right side of the trail in 250 feet.

stops.significance: The Ohanapecosh river is important to this area.
stops.directionsToNextStop: As the trail moves out of the forest and back into the campground, keep to the right side of the road and be aware of traffic. The final stop will discuss the buildings to the left in 400 feet.

stops.significance: We return to the campground and observe the human infrastructure of the park.
stops.directionsToNextStop: We hope you enjoyed your experience in the lowland forests and hot springs of Ohanapecosh on this walking tour. To learn more, visit the Ohanapecosh Visitor Center located to the left along the road in front of you. For another look at the Ohanapecosh River, take a right for a scenic view from the bridge.

images.title: Ohanapecosh Hot Spring pools
images.altText: Water forms in a small muddy pool.
images.caption: Ohanapecosh Hot Spring

data.title: Old Dune Walking Tour
data.description: This tour takes you through the dunes of Sandy Hook. You'll also learn a bit about the historic life saving station. The tour is .7 miles.

stops.significance: Beginning of tour. Look around at for the osprey platform
stops.audioTranscript: Before you start on the trail, look around you. Across from the parking lot is an osprey next on a platform, which was built by park staff. Ospreys, also called seahawks, like to nest in high places, including electric or telephone poles. you may see a diamondback terrapin crossing the road from May to July, when females lay their eggs. Watch out for them when you drive!

A crew of 8 men worked at U.S. Life-Saving Service Station #2 at Spermacetti Cover, built in 1894. When ships wrecked, the life-saving crew usually rowed a surfboat to the shipwreck to rescue people. When a storm was too strong, they fired a small line-throwing cannon from the shore to the ship to make connection with the stranded crew. One to two people could fit into a breeches buoy, a pair of canvas pants that hung from the line. If many people were aboard the shipwreck a "lifecar", or small metal boat that held up to six passengers, could pull people to safety. This photo shows the last two crewmen of the Edmund J. Phinney being rescued in a breeches buoy at the North Beach area in December 1907 during a powerful winter storm.

Sand is terrible for growing plants. It does not hold water, has few nutrients, and can get hotter than 100 degrees Fahrenheit in the summer. The Eastern red cedar, or red juniper, gets around this by producing evergreen leaves that take less energy to grow. Despite this, the red cedar still struggles in the environment here because it cannot tolerate salt. When Hurricane Sandy flooded this area, it killed many cedar trees that you will see on the trail. Even then, dead trees are useful because they provide food and habitat for wildlife.

This forest of American holly is the largest stand or group of American holly trees on the East Coast. Along with Eastern red cedar and wild black cherry trees, the American hollies create a unique maritime forest on Sandy Hook. One tree in this forest dates from the 1830s. Female trees produce flowers which produce red berries.

Stop for a moment and be silent. What do you hear? Morning is the best time to hear birdcalls. Try to differentiate between the different calls.

What is a prickly pear cactus doing in New Jersey? It's actually a native plant on our beaches. Before Europeans arrive here, the Lenni Lenape, a Native American tribe that lived in what is now New Jersey, ate the fresh fruits or dried them for later use. Today, box turtles and Eastern cottontail rabbits eat the cactus for food and water. In the winter, rabbits feed on bark and twigs.

The first winged or dwarf sumac and wild black cherry seeds may have been dropped here by birds, which ate the berries and deposited the seeds. Do you hear or see any birds in the area looking for berries? Take a close look at the black cherry tree. Those parallel rows of holes were drilled by the yellow-bellied sapsucker, a type of woodpecker, as it looked for bugs to eat. Downy and hairy woodpeckers also like this area. Look for black and white birds with red patches on the backs of their heads.

Each spring and fall, millions of birds look for food and water along the Atlantic Flyway as they migrate thousands of miles. Fresh water is a rarity along the Eastern seacoast, so this pond is a welcome sight. This pond was enhanced by the Army, but natural ponds form as well between a beach and dunes in a low-lying swale where water is able to accumulate. These natural brackish ponds, which combine fresh water with sea water, host a diverse number of plants. Look for phragmites, a grass five to 10 feet high. This opportunistic plant loves to grow in highly disturbed areas.

Some plants dominate certain beach areas, such as the golden heather. This plant releases a toxin into the ground that slows the growth of other plants, giving it plenty of room to grow. Its complex root system helps anchor the sand, but trampling by humans can easily damage the roots. This plant is commonly found around beach plums, a shrub whose fruit ripens in late summer to fall. The Lenape people used these fruits in their diet. A neighbor to these plants is the seaside goldenrod. This blooms into large, bright yellow flowerheads in the fall.

Sandy Hook doesn't stand still. The wind and waves constantly shift the Hook's dunes and shorelines. Without rooted plants, there would be no sand dunes at all. Just ahead of us lies the primary dune, held together by the roots of beach grass. Dunes are primary shock absorbers for severe storms. 

Walk south on the beach back to the Life-Saving Station. If part of the beach is closed to protect nests of threatened bird species, then observe the rules posted on the signs. You can help the National Park Service to protect endangered and threatened birds and plant. 

Walking south along the beach, you may see ghost crabs, a variety of gulls, sanderlings, American oystercatchers, or piping plovers. Give these creatures plenty of space. This is their home.

images.title: Osprey on the  Sand
images.altText: Osprey on the sand
images.caption: Osprey at the Beach

data.title: Old Faithful and the Upper Geyser Basin
data.description: Old Faithful Geyser is just one of many hydrothermal wonders to be experienced along this loop tour. Travel along a mixture of boardwalks and paved trails, though be aware there are some stairs or steep grades are along the way.

stops.directionsToNextStop: From the north side of the Old Faithful Visitor Education Center, head north to the crescent-shaped viewing platform the curves around Old Faithful Geyser.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Upper Geyser Basin—the location of the largest concentration of geysers in the world. This tour will take you by dozens of hydrothermal features, from dazzling hot springs to steaming—and potentially erupting—geysers.

Because of the dynamic nature of the features along this tour, you may complete this tour in as little as an hour or choose to spend several hours in the Upper Geyser Basin. Before heading out, here are a few safety notes: Be sure to take water. Bring along any other weather-related items: sunscreen, raincoats, gloves, etc. It can be windy, so cinch your hats and secure your items. Stop by the restroom before heading out. The only restroom available in the basin is a vault toilet near Morning Glory Pool. Stay on the boardwalks and established trails at all times. Superheated water flows just below a thin crust throughout the basin. Besides the high chance of breaking through the crust and causing bodily injury or death, leaving the trail can damage hydrothermal features—ruining the experience for everyone. Boardwalks can be slippery when wet or covered in snow. Watch for wildlife and maintain the minimum safe distance of 25 yards (23 meters or 2 bus-lengths) from any wildlife—and 100 yards (91 meters or 8 bus-lengths) from bears or wolves.

Ready? Head on to the next stop: the Old Faithful Geyser viewing platform.

stops.significance: World-famous geyser that has a fairly predictable eruption sequence.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Following the crescent-shaped viewing platform east and north until to reach a wide trail. Continue to the north side of Old Faithful Geyser until a trail branches off to the north into the woods and down to the Firehole River. Follow that trail.
stops.audioTranscript: Old Faithful Geyser may be the world’s most famous geyser, and with good reason. At roughly 90–minute intervals, this predictable geyser shoots a majestic plume of water and steam up to 180 feet into the air over the course of 1-½ to 5 minutes. Eruption heights and durations vary, so each eruption provides a unique experience. Boardwalks and trails encircle Old Faithful Geyser, so you can watch from any side and get a different experience. Four characteristics set geysers apart from the other hydrothermal features—mudpots, fumaroles, and hot springs. While heading on to the next stop, observe Old Faithful’s activity to see if you can discern what those components are.

For a moment, slow down and take in the sights, sounds, and smells while crossing the bridge of the Firehole River. This is one of those beautiful moments where you can feel like you’ve left the throngs of visitors and the human development behind. 

The Firehole River begins at Madison Lake, a small lake near the Continental Divide west of Shoshone Lake. It flows nearly 21 miles, passing by Lone Star Geyser and through the Upper, Midway, and Lower geyser basins on its way to the confluence with the Gibbon River, where the rivers combine to form the Madison River near Madison Junction. Because so many hydrothermal features drain into the Firehole River, its water is warmer and has a higher concentration of dissolved minerals than other rivers. The Firehole River is a favored fly-fishing river due to its being home to several species of trout.

Here is your first opportunity to take a side-adventure from this tour. This relatively short yet steep ascent takes you up to areas that provide nice views of Old Faithful Geyser and the Old Faithful Inn from above. Be sure to have bear spray handy, as bears are known to frequent the area.

Welcome to Geyser Hill, home to more than 50 geysers—the 4th largest geyser field on Earth. The boardwalk takes a loop around the entire hill, though this tour follows just the southern part of the loop. If you want to explore the rest of the loop, pause the tour and resume it back up once you return to the opposite side of the hill near the Lion Geyser Complex.

Anemone Geysers are the second (and third) geysers along the tour. The pair that showcases how different even adjacent hydrothermal features can be. These geysers erupt on a much smaller scale than Old Faithful, and these eruptions occur at varied intervals. As the name suggests, this geyser pair has some fascinating formations of geyserite around its opening. Geyserite is the silica-based mineral deposited out on the water and onto the surrounding area in bulbous or cauliflower-like shapes. 

This is a good place to watch an entire geyser cycle. Pay particular attention to the sound these geysers make. Sound familiar? 

Now that you’ve seen a couple of geysers, what do you think are the ingredients needed to make a geyser? If you were thinking water, heat, pressure, and a constriction, you’d be correct. We’ll explore each of these four ingredients as we continue along the tour. We’ll start with water. As you move on to the next stop, pay attention to the other hydrothermal features around you.

Beehive Geyser is unpredictable, though, if you’re lucky, you may get a chance to see this cone geyser erupt and feel the spray of its water. Just be cautious if you do, since the water also contains silica minerals that will fuse to your glasses and camera lenses if allowed to dry on them. 

As the name implies, Beehive Geyser is named after the beehive-like cone that it has built itself over time. With each eruption, a thin layer of silica-rich minerals found within the water is deposited as geyserite. Geysers come in two main types: fountain geysers and cone geysers. Beehive Geyser is a cone geyser. The difference is apparent in both the shape of the eruption column and the shape of the opening. You will get a chance to see a fountain geyser later on the tour. 

Where do you think all the water that circulates through all these features comes from? A little hint: these hot springs and geysers are active year-round, and for the most part do not vary in size or frequency throughout the year.

Take a moment and look all around you. While it may be hard to imagine, glaciers covered this landscape 12,000 years ago. As they melted away, they left behind all the earth and rock (called sediment) they excavated from the surrounding mountains. This sediment is very porous (full of holes), which makes it ideal for holding a large volume of water. Though rainwater and snowmelt ultimately feed the system, it can take hundreds of years for the raindrops falling on the landscape today to make their way into the superheated groundwater and resurface in the pool of a hot spring or in the erupted water of a geyser.

Heart Spring is a colorful pool that gives you a clear view of the hydrothermal water moving through the hundreds of features in the Upper Geyser Basin. The water is hot (close to the boiling point of water—about 199°F or 93°C at this elevation) with a blue appearance. This rich blue color is a result of the water scattering the blue wavelength of sunlight more than the other colors. 

Look around at how much water you can see coming out of the ground in the spring, or as steam, or as active eruptions. Now think about how much super-heated water must be right under the surface of the ground all around you.

Geysers can be solitary features, like Old Faithful, or they can be interconnected groups. The Lion Geyser Complex is actually a collection of seven geysers. The largest of the group is Lion Geyser. While none of the geysers in the complex are considered predictable, there is a cyclic nature to Lion Geyser’s eruptions. The start of Lion Geyser’s cycle is an initial eruption of about 6 minutes, with the eruption plume averaging 60 feet in height. After that eruption, two to four subsequent eruptions that are shorter in duration and height occur every 90 minutes or so. The cycle repeats from 4-1/2 to 19 hours later. Watch all the different parts of this complex to see what activity you can notice.

In 2018, Ear Spring erupted. While it is not uncommon for hot springs to become eruptively active, what made Ear Spring’s eruption more unique was that it also ended up ejecting litter: a cement block, cans, coins, and even a baby pacifier. This litter serves as a good reminder to never toss anything into the precious features. The good news? Most of the litter was rather old, some items dating back to the 1930s, meaning that visitors had not been littering in the spring recently.

Here the boardwalk passes through the edge of a lodgepole pine forest, the most common tree in Yellowstone. You can recognize lodgepole pines by their needles, which grow in groups of two. Lodgepole pines are shade intolerant. Any branches left in the shade will be self-pruned by the tree. Lodgepole pines prefer slightly acidic soil, and grow quickly in mineral soils disturbed by fire. 

Looking down around the boardwalk, you can see seeps and wetland plants growing among the trees. These wetland areas are essential to the plant and animal diversity in the park. About 38% of all plant species growing in Yellowstone are found in wetlands, and wetlands provide essential habitat for rare plants, thermal species, reptiles, amphibians, insects, birds, and fish.

Along this stretch are a series of hot springs of varying color. These colors, like most of the colors around Yellowstone’s hydrothermal features, come from the organisms that live in the hot water. Known as thermophiles, these organisms from every branch of life thrive in these conditions we normally consider inhospitable. 

Observe the relatively quiet nature of these hydrothermal features compared to the activity of Geyser Hill. These springs were not always so calm, for some of these features were known to have erupted before the 1959 earthquake, and even on the night of the earthquake.

Spasmodic Geyser is a good study of the transition from hot spring to geyser. Any hot spring could have been, or might be in the future, a geyser. All it takes is a constriction that causes pressure to build up until it is released in an eruption. Constrictions and pressure—two of the four main ingredients of a geyser—always go together. 

Spasmodic Geyser has the appearance of a hot spring, yet it is still a geyser. Spasmodic’s frequent activity suggests the constriction is less than those of the geysers you have seen previously on the tour. With less of a constriction, less pressure can build up. With less pressure building up, the eruptions tend to be smaller and more frequent.

Sawmill Geyser reveals the dynamic nature of Yellowstone. Up until January 29, 2017, Sawmill Geyser was a frequently active geyser. Then, without any sign of change above-ground, Sawmill Geyser stopped erupting and has not erupted since. Before this shift, it was documented through the years that Sawmill Geyser and the other geysers in the vicinity—Spasmodic, Tardy, Penta, and Churn—would cycle through different periods of activity. 

At this point of the tour, you can either continue north to the next stop, Grand Geyser, or, if pressed for time, bypass several stops and take the boardwalk heading west to cut over to the Crested Pool stop.

Grand Geyser is a splendid example of a fountain geyser, sending water up to 200 feet into the air. Like other fountain geysers, Grand Geyser erupts out of a pool of water rather than from a built-up cone like Beehive Geyser. 

Grand Geyser is one of the six geysers with predictable eruptions. What makes for a predictable geyser? A fairly regular interval of eruptions that proves to be considerably accurate. However, as Sawmill Geyser demonstrates, Yellowstone is a dynamic place, and Grand Geyser has periods when the predictions are less accurate.

Beauty Pool and the nearby Chromatic Pool highlight how interconnected some of these thermal features can be. Historically, the main flow of water went to Chromatic Pool, with shorter periods when the underground flow shifted to Beauty Pool. The pool actively receiving the majority of hot-water flow is fuller, hotter, and has more vibrant growth of thermophiles. These days, the exchange happens several times over the year. When Beauty Pool is receiving the hot water, it grows dramatically, sometimes reaching the edges of the boardwalk.

In 1871, the Hayden expedition set out to survey the sources of the Missouri and Yellowstone rivers, the area that would become the nation's first national park. Thomas Moran joined as artist on the team, and during the forty days he spent in the area, Moran documented more than 30 different sites and their geologic features. The stunning Giant Geyser and the rest of the Upper Geyser Basin composed one of those sites. His sketches, along with William Henry Jackson's photographs, captured the nation's attention and proved essential in convincing the United States Congress to establish Yellowstone as a national park.

Geyserite build-up is on full display at Grotto Geyser. Geyserite, the silica-rich material left behind by the water issuing from hydrothermal features, has built up an unusually shaped cone around Grotto’s vent. It is speculated that geyserite coated the trunks of trees that once grew here.

Riverside Geyser illustrates how water systems can be entirely separated, even when situated right next to each other. In this case, Riverside Geyser vents right next to, and into, the Firehole River. However, the superheated water that erupts out of Riverside Geyser does not come from the Firehole River. 

This separation, including separation from other hydrothermal features, might be why Riverside Geyser is so regular, making it one of Yellowstone’s predictable geysers.

Change happens all the time in Yellowstone. Morning Glory Pool was once one of the most-visited features in the park, with a unique pale-blue pool. 

However, the change that occurred to this feature was a result of poor visitor behavior. People threw objects—coins, logs, bottles, cans, and clothing—into the pool, which clogged the vent. This clogging caused the temperature of the pool to drop. The temperature drop altered the thermophilic community and color of the pool. Thousands of objects have been removed from the pool, yet the damage remains. This is one type of change we can all help prevent by not littering in other wonders in Yellowstone and elsewhere.

Daisy Geyser is another of the predictable geysers, though its predictability has become less than it has been in the past. As with most of the features in the park, Daisy Geyser has gone through periods of dormancy, with the last period going through the 1960s. Daisy, and the other nine geysers in its complex, show the nature of how water flow can change throughout a whole system. Some geysers become more active during a when water flow increases, and then becoming less active when the water shifts to a different part of the system.

Heat is the engine that drives all hydrothermal features. Without the intense heat, there would be no geysers, hot springs, mudpots, or fumaroles. And without those hydrothermal features, no thermophiles would be around because they wouldn’t have a suitable habitat. 

The heat is on full display at Crested Pool, where frequent “super-boils” bubble through the deep pool like an angry cauldron. Amazingly, the heat source is far below ground and heats the water to temperatures exceeding 400°F (204°C). The water remains in liquid form, even though it is nearly twice the boiling point, due to the intense pressure from the surrounding rock and overlying water. This super-heated water can be found just below the surface throughout the park’s geyser basins, where the surface can be just a thin crust that can give way when stepped on.

Take some time at Castle Geyser to observe all of the features of a geyser. The massive cone of geyserite displays the building process of cone geysers, while recent scientific research on the geyserite suggests periods of inactivity in the geyser’s past that allowed trees to grow in the area, and then later be coated in geyserite, much like what is thought to have happened at Grotto Geyser. 

Castle Geyser is also a predictable geyser, yet its eruption frequency, duration, and volume have changed over the years. Even during the intervals between eruptions, Castle Geyser shows off the underlying heat, with steam rising from vents and the sound of water churning in its depths. 

Also on display here is the separation of water systems in adjacent features. At the base of Castle Geyser’s cone is Tortoise Shell Spring. There appears to be no connection between the two features, as Castle Geyser’s eruptions have no noticeable effect on this spring. 

Castle Geyser is prominently on display in one of Thomas Moran’s sketches from the 1871 Hayden expedition. Moran depicts the otherworldliness of Yellowstone that intrigued people and led to the creation of the first national park.

With Yellowstone established as a national park in 1872 and people’s curiosity piqued by the unique hydrothermal wonders here, development to support tourism soon followed. The Old Faithful Inn was not the first hotel built in the area, but it remains the oldest hotel in the Old Faithful area and the largest log hotel in the world. The design of the hotel was also influential in the rustic design of other structures across the National Park Service. 

Hotels were important to the early development of Yellowstone, as most visitors had to travel a great distance, often a journey of several days, to reach the park. 

Making the natural and cultural wonders accessible to visitors has always been a priority of the National Park Service. Visitors are an integral part of national parks. The act that created the National Park Service states that the purpose of the agency is: 

… to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wild life therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations. 

We hope you enjoyed experiencing the most hydrothermally active place on Earth and found many reasons to preserve and protect the resources of this park and this planet—from the geysers of Yellowstone to the wildlife near your home.

images.title: Crested Pool
images.altText: Steam rises from a circular, blue pool of water rimmed in white and orange.
images.caption: Steam rises from Crested Pool

data.title: Old Slater Mill: The Beginnings of American Industry
data.description: Explore the grounds at Old Slater Mill National Historic Landmark and learn more about the beginnings of the America's industrial age. See three historic buildings, the Blackstone River, a dam, and a waterfall. Read the interpretive panels that dot the landscape and listen to this self-guided audio tour to learn more about the dramatic changes that began at this site.

park.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
park.name: Blackstone River Valley

stops.significance: Old Slater Mill is considered the birthplace of the American Industrial Revolution.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From where you are standing, turn around to face the small red building opposite the pathway from Old Slater Mill.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Old Slater Mill National Historic Landmark. There are three historic buildings on this site, and countless stories to investigate. Join me in exploring this place--and the people--who changed the social fabric of this nation. 

In front of you is Old Slater Mill. Originally constructed in 1793, this was the first successful water-powered cotton spinning mill in North America. On this site, children worked machines that ran on waterpower to make thread. This location was ideal for running such a mill, though it took human engineering and plenty of hard work to turn this into a place for industry.  

Let’s start by talking about some of those workers who ushered in the American age of industry. Moses Brown, a Providence merchant invested the capital to finance this venture. David Wilkinson and Sylvanus Brown, two local skilled craftsmen, provided the machine-making-know-how. Samuel Slater, an English immigrant, provided the knowledge of how English textile machines worked. John Bucklins, a free African-American man living in this area was among the carpenters who constructed this building. It was a small mill by modern standards – 43 feet long, 29 feet wide and 2 ½ stories tall. Nonetheless, the mill probably seemed quite large to children like 10-year-old Anne Arnold, who came here to work.  

You see the mill today much as it was in 1832, the first year the trademark belltower was added to the structure. This place tells the stories of people –like Ann, and John, and others -- at work in a changing world. After more than four decades of work in factories, Samuel Slater declared, “I gave out the psalm and they have been singing to the tune ever since.” As we explore this site, let us consider how that tune has changed, and how work has changed our lives, in this continually evolving world.

stops.significance: The Sylvanus Brown House is one of 3 historic building located at the Old Slater Mill complex. Built in 1758, it is a great example of what life in colonial America was like.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If facing the Brown House, turn left and walk towards the large stone building in front of you. Stand in a place where you can appreciate the size and scale of this mill.
stops.audioTranscript:
Want to step back in time to an age before industry? The Sylvanus Brown House offers an illustrative portal to the past. Look through the windows. What do you see? Inside, there is a spinning wheel, a handloom, and18th-century furniture.  

This house once belonged to Sylvanus Brown, a local mechanic who lived in the small village of Pawtucket. Originally built around 1758, the home was moved from its original location to this complex in the 1960s.  

Before the Industrial Revolution, many objects were made by hand or with simple tools. In the colonial period, before the American Revolution, people like Sylvanus Brown grew a lot of their own food in gardens such as the one you see adjacent to the home. Brown was also part of a village, and many of his neighbors were craftspeople, skilled at their own trades. People in this area were part of a worldwide trade network, including the Atlantic Slave Trade and the China Trade. However, manufacturing on a large scale tended to happen out of sight, and far away from home. 

The rise of factories such as Slater’s was a disruption in this way of life. These cottage-based processes would not change overnight, but as industrialization gained more traction throughout the nineteenth century, more objects began to be massed produced in factories and people’s lives began to change dramatically. At Slater’s mill, people experienced a new type of work. They were not paid for what they produced or even their skill but for their time.  

From his home, Sylvanus Brown was witness to these changes, and his own skills were put to use in making some of these life-changing machines.

stops.significance: The Wilkinson Mill is a National Engineering Landmark. Built in 1810, it is a beautiful example of rubble-stone construction, and it demonstrates the ingenuity and enterprise that launched the American Industrial Revolution.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If facing the Wilkinson Mill, turn left and walk over the small bridge to the edge of the river. Stand along the railing in a good place where you can see the Slater Dam (the waterfall in front of you).
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1810, stone masons and other skilled craftsman completed this rubble-stone mill for David Wilkinson. It still stands as a testament to the skill of those who built it.  

In the lowest level of the mill was the wheel pit. Peek through the lowest row of windows, and you might catch a glimpse of the wooden waterwheel. This wheel powered a machine shop on the first floor, and cotton-spinning and weaving on the second and third floors.  

In the machine shop, David Wilkinson and his employees built and repaired machines. A great example of one of the machines Wilkinson invented was the screw-cutting lathe. Prior to this invention in 1798, all screws were hand-cut. With this invention, screws could now be massed produced with speed and precision. This allowed for screws to be used interchangeably. A huge step in making machine building and repair much faster and easier.  

The Wilkinsons and this mill are great examples of the ingenuity and enterprise that launched the American Industrial Revolution. 

But how were these mills powered? At first it was the Blackstone River that provided the power that brought these mills to life.

stops.significance: Built in 1792, the Slater Dam is an important part of the historical and cultural landscape. This dam created the reservoir of water, known as a mill pond, that held the water which powered these mills.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If standing facing the Slater Dam, turn right and walk down the brick path. When you reach the end of the brick path (about 50 yards down) look to your left. You will see the Pawtucket Falls. For a more impressive view of the falls, walk up the stairs to the street and stand on the Main Street bridge looking down at the falls.
stops.audioTranscript:
This is not a natural waterfall, but a human-made dam. Constructed in 1792, this dam has undergone several restorations over its life, but it remains, much like the buildings we have seen, an important element of the historical and cultural landscape of this site. 

This dam compounded a series of natural drops in the river to one single drop. This backed up a reservoir of water, known as a mill pond. Ideally, the mill pond was deep enough and contained enough water to still power the mills in times of drought and freezing. Water diverted from the mill pond went through a human-dug channel, called a raceway, just before it fell on the waterwheel. The weight of water pushed down on the wheel spinning it to motion. Then, this spinning motion was transferred to the multiple floors of these mills through a series of gears and driveshafts. On each floor, a series of wheels and belts would connect the machines to the drive shaft. This applied the spinning motion of the waterwheel to individual machines, allowing them to do work. Finally, water would continue to move through a second human-dug channel called the tailrace, which diverted the water back into the river. 

Take a moment to use some of your senses. What are you seeing or hearing?  

Consider the workers who were in these buildings 200 years ago. They spent long hours listening to the roar of the river and the clatter of machines and belts. Have you ever worked or lived around loud, heavy machinery? Does water power anything in your life?   

As you make your way to the final stop, consider some of the changes that have occurred to the landscape around this dam.

stops.significance: The Pawtucket Falls has been an important gathering point for centuries. It was the potential power of water at this site that attracted a community of skilled craftsmen. These craftsmen and the potential water attracted the attention of Moses Brown, who financed the cotton-spinning operations here which launched the American Industrial Revolution
stops.audioTranscript:
Unlike the Slater Dam, this waterfall is natural. This is the Pawtucket Falls. The second largest waterfall on the Blackstone River, this site has seen dramatic changes over the years. Thousands of years ago, it was covered by the massive glacier that created the Blackstone Valley during the last Ice Age. Once the ice melted, this site provided the only crossing point of Narragansett Bay that could be done on foot. As a result, it was used as a major trade route for the Narragansett and Wampanoag peoples for centuries.  

English colonizers made this area a center of early industry. Among the first English inhabitants was the Jencks family who set up their iron forging operation here. Just over a century later, Moses Brown chose this site for his experiment, for replicating an English textile mill.  

As industrialization took hold, the crossing point that became a small village evolved into a booming mill city. Both sides of the river were cluttered with mill buildings, storage houses, shops, dye houses, and other industrial buildings. Eventually entire families moved to industrial communities called Mill Villages. In many industrial communities, workers often earned steady wages, and enjoyed a sense of community, but they lived under the constant control and manipulation of their employers. 

Then by the twentieth century, the landscape started to change again. Old Slater Mill was purchased by the Old Slater Mill Association in 1921. Thus, began the process of turning the building into a museum. Over the next several decades, almost all the buildings which once stood here were demolished. Gone was the industrial landscape that Old Slater Mill had existed within for 150 years.  

Today, this landscape is owned by the American people through the care and stewardship of the National Park Service. We invite you to continue to explore this historical landscape and contemplate how the fabric of this nation was woven, frayed, and mended.

images.title: Old Slater Mill and Dam, historic view
images.altText: Old Slater Mill with belltower on the banks of the Blackstone River with Slater Dam
images.caption: Old Slater Mill and Dam, Historic View

data.title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour
data.description: This walking tour will allow you to experience the assault on Orchard Knob, the first engagement of the Battles for Chattanooga, that took place on November 23, 1863. Please be aware that you will need to walk to the top of Orchard Knob for the majority of this tour. The route is paved, but we encourage you to watch your footing.
tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

stops.significance: Orchard Knob is a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit your car. Taking the sidewalk, make your way toward Orchard Knob Avenue and the iron entrance gate. You should now be standing, facing the main entrance gate near the corner of Orchard Knob Avenue and Ivey Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Orchard Knob, one of six units preserved as part of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park. You should currently be parked on Ivey Street, near the intersection of Ivey Street and Orchard Knob Avenue. The land on which you are about to visit was added to the park between 1892 and 1893. All that remains preserved of this 1863 engagement is what you see within the confines of the rock walls protected by the National Park Service.  

This walking tour will cover the attack on Orchard Knob, which took place on November 23, 1863, as well as the subsequent attack on Missionary Ridge two days later. Throughout this tour, you will see a number of monuments and plaques. Blue plaques mark Union troop positions, while gray plaques mark Confederate troop positions. Bronze plaques you may encounter along the way mark positions of Ohio troops during the engagement. Many of these plaques date to the early to mid-1890s. If you have the time, we encourage you to stop and read the plaques to gain a more wholistic understanding of what occurred here. While visiting Orchard Knob, please avoid climbing on the cannon and walking over the fortifications, as they are historic and can easily be damaged. Please refrain from disturbing the natural and cultural landscape by removing plants, animals, or historic items from park grounds.  As a final note, there are no trash cans in this portion of the park. We ask that you remove any trash you brought with you to preserve the battlefield for other visitors.

stops.significance: Orchard Knob is a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park.
stops.assetName: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 1: Iron Entrance Gate to Orchard Knob
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the entrance gate, make your way up the paved walkway and stand at the wayside entitled “The Struggle Begins.” Look up from the wayside. You are now facing west.
stops.audioTranscript: If you look to your left, down Orchard Knob Avenue, you will see part of a blue plaque to US General William Hazen's Brigade. Directly across the avenue from this plaque, once stood a plaque to the 28th Alabama’s position. On November 23, 1863, the 28th Alabama was stationed, on picket duty, at that location, while the 24th Alabama picketed the top and front of Orchard Knob. The Confederate lines stretched past the knob to the left and right and were a few yards in front of this once-timbered hill. These soldiers also constructed shallow rifle pits on the knob to provide cover from enemy fire.

stops.significance: Orchard Knob is a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park.
stops.assetName: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 2: The Fight for the Gateway Begins - Orchard Knob
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to your right and continue up the path until you reach the large Illinois Monument at the knob’s summit. Pass behind the monument and find the blue plaque to Bridges’ Illinois Battery. Walk over to one of the cannon, being mindful not to walk over the fortifications in front of the cannon. Face in the direction to which the cannon is pointed. You are now facing Missionary Ridge.
stops.audioTranscript:
On November 22, Confederate deserters informed US General Ulysses S. Grant that it seemed Confederate General Braxton Bragg would soon withdraw his forces from the surrounding heights of Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge. Grant and his subordinates had reason to believe the deserters as the US high command received reports of large numbers of Confederates leaving the siege lines that encircled the city. However, these forces, under command of General James Longstreet, were being dispatched to retake the Union-held city of Knoxville, Tennessee. Grant decided to undertake a “reconnaissance in force” to test Bragg and the strength of his army by attacking Confederate-held Orchard Knob from Fort Wood, the location of which is marked on this wayside. 

On November 23, early in the afternoon, Confederates were aroused by the cacophony of bugles, the thundering beats of drums, and the general commotion which resulted from men being formed into line of battle. They watched as thousands of US soldiers poured from Fort Wood. A soldier in the 93rd Ohio recalled that the Union lines stretched “from the mouth of Chattanooga Creek, across the valley, to the woods that skirt Missionary Ridge.'' Another observer, watching from Fort Wood, noted, “Flags were flying, the quick earnest steps of thousands beat time. The sharp commands of hundreds of company officers, the sound of the drums, the ringing notes of the bugle, companies wheeling and countermarching, and regiments getting into line, the bright sun lighting up ten thousand polished bayonets till they glistened and flashed like...a shower of electric spirits – all looked like preparations for a peaceful pageant, rather than for the bloody work of death.” As the long blue lines lurched forward, the gray-clad men readied themselves to hold their ground.  
 
Newton Davis, colonel of the 24th Alabama, realized the few hundred yards that separated his command and Lieutenant Colonel William Butler’s 28th Alabama was virtually impossible to hold against the overwhelming numbers which made up the blue wave surging toward them. Consequently, Davis joined his men as they raced back the 1,200 yards to the fortified Confederate line at Missionary Ridge’s base. On the other hand, Butler received word to hold his position, at all hazards, and that support was on its way. He had no idea that the 24th Alabama had vanished from his right flank atop Orchard Knob. General Hazen stated the Confederate positions were “carried at the point of the bayonet.” The Alabamians tried to hold on, but it was useless, and 146 of Butler’s men surrendered, while the regiment’s survivors dashed toward Missionary Ridge, following in the footsteps of their 24th Alabama comrades. Within an hour of the first forward movement by US soldiers, the assault was over. The two Alabama regiments suffered 186 casualties out of the original 634 who were present-for-duty that morning. Additionally, the 28th Alabama suffered the stinging loss of its colors, which had been presented to them by the ladies of Selma.   

That evening Union troops fashioned breastworks and fortifications atop and around Orchard Knob – now facing Missionary Ridge. Milton Barnes, Lieutenant Colonel of the 97th Ohio stated that his unit advanced 250 yards in front of Orchard Knob and picketed that evening. US General Gordon Granger wrote that Orchard knob was “a strong and important position” that “afforded points of observation upon movements that the enemy might make through the valley toward the scene of Major General Sherman’s operations.”  

With the loss of Orchard Knob, the Confederates lost an important point from which to observe the US troops in and around Chattanooga.

stops.significance: Orchard Knob is a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park.
stops.assetName: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 3: Forward Observation Post - Grant Watches the Miracle at Missionary Ridge
stops.directionsToNextStop: When you leave, please take the paved path back down to the gate and exit from there. You may notice, there are monuments dotting the perimeter of Orchard Knob as well. We invite you to walk to your right, around the corner, and back onto Ivey Street. One beautifully crafted example is the 1st Michigan Engineers’ monument, which is located near the corner of Ivey and Hawthorne Streets.
stops.audioTranscript:
After Orchard Knob fell to US forces, General Grant and other commanders, such as General George Thomas, used Orchard Knob as an observation post to monitor attacks on November 24 and 25.  On November 24, Grant’s plan called for General William T. Sherman to attack the Confederate right flank on the north end of Missionary Ridge, while General Joseph Hooker conducted a demonstration, or distraction, against Lookout Mountain. This plan failed due to Sherman advancing on Billy Goat Hill, a separated hill north of Missionary Ridge. However, Generals Hooker and John Geary were successful in capturing Lookout Mountain during what would later be coined, “The Battle Above the Clouds.” The next day, November 25, Grant watched as the troops stationed near Orchard knob formed battle lines for the coming assault. The plan of attack was for Sherman to move against the Confederate right flank on Missionary Ridge and for Hooker to leave Lookout Mountain, march through Chattanooga Valley, and attack the Confederate left flank on the southern end of Missionary Ridge, near Rossville, Georgia. Thomas’ US troops were ordered to be a distraction by attacking Missionary Ridge’s center, hoping to draw Confederate focus away from their flanks. The men were to advance only to the first of three successive lines of Confederate rifle pits and halt. While the men of US General Philip Sheridan's and US General Thomas J. Wood’s divisions moved into line, General Granger focused on getting Bridges’ Battery ready atop Orchard Knob. This is the battery position at which you currently stand. The battery was unlimbered at midnight on November 23, and they were tasked to be the signal and support for the men assailing the base of the Missionary Ridge. While Sherman had trouble breaking through Confederate General Patrick Cleburne's lines on Tunnel Hill, at the north end of the ridge, Bridges’ guns fired six shots in rapid succession, signaling the start of the charge. At 4 pm, 35,000 US soldiers stretching along the valley, advanced toward the base of Missionary Ridge. They overpowered the Southerners in the first line of rifle pits at the ridge’s base. However, the veterans did not stop there, and they continued up the steep slopes, yelling “Chickamauga, Chickamauga!” At first, Grant was furious and asked Thomas and Granger if they ordered the continued assault. Both men denied any involvement, but Granger said, “When those fellows get started, all hell can't stop them.” The once defeated, demoralized, and besieged US soldiers proved that Chickamauga was not their undoing, but that they were still a force to be reckoned with in a fight. These men, overpowering the Confederates, took the remaining rifle pits as the dispirited Confederates fled Missionary Ridge. Once the smoke of battle cleared, the blue-clad soldiers solidly held Missionary Ridge and the “Gateway to the Confederacy” - Chattanooga. As one Confederate put it so succinctly after the war, “This was the death knell of the Confederacy.”  

We encourage you to spend some time atop Orchard Knob, contemplating what you have heard about the importance of this place to the overall success of the US forces during the Battles for Chattanooga. When you leave, please take the paved path back down to the gate and exit from there. You may notice, there are monuments dotting the perimeter of Orchard Knob as well. We invite you to walk to your right, around the corner, and back onto Ivey Street. Look at these amazingly carved monuments on this side and the western side of Orchard Knob. Veterans erected these regimental monuments specifically to organizations engaged in the Chattanooga Campaign, yet operated in areas where the national military park was unable to preserve land. One beautifully crafted example is the 1st Michigan Engineers’ monument, which is located near the corner of Ivey and Hawthorne Streets.

stops.significance: Orchard Knob is a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park.
stops.assetName: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 4: 1st Michigan Engineers Monument
stops.directionsToNextStop: This concludes our tour of Orchard Knob, a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park. Thank you for visiting.
stops.audioTranscript: The 1st Michigan was the only engineering regiment assigned to the US Army of the Cumberland, only numbering approximately 300 men during the campaign. These men were primarily tasked with building and repairing bridges and railroads. At Chattanooga, a portion of the regiment helped open the much-needed supply line, later dubbed “The Cracker Line” by preparing the needed materials and constructing the pontoon bridges across the Tennessee River at Brown’s Ferry, which was completed in an astounding 8 hours, and at South Chickamauga Creek, near the north end of Missionary Ridge. The amazingly intricate bronze relief on the monument’s face depicts the laying of a pontoon bridge across the river. At the same time, other members of the regiment were engaged in working along the railroad from Chattanooga to Murfreesboro, Tennessee.

images.title: A Ranger-led Tour of Orchard Knob
images.altText: A park ranger leads a tour of Orchard KNob
images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour of Orchard Knob

data.title: Oregon Trail Pathway Audio Tour
data.description: Learn more about how emigrants travelled the emigrant trail through Scotts Bluff National Monument on this 1 mile long (round-trip) hike of the Oregon Trail Pathway. While some sections of the trail are paved, others have a natural surface. Be aware of uneven and slippery surfaces.

stops.significance: This is the start of the Oregon Trail Pathway. The trail is 1 mile (1.6 kilometers) round-trip and is rated as moderate in difficulty. There is an elevation change of 85 feet (26 meters). Most of the trail is asphalt paved. However, the mid-section of the trail features a segment of the Oregon/California Trails that was travelled by emigrants starting in 1851. This section of trail is naturally surfaced and can be slippery with uneven surfaces.
stops.directionsToNextStop: To get to the next stop on the tour, carefully cross the Summit Road at the marked crosswalk. follow the sidewalk that bears to the left. Look for the interpretive wayside labeled "Choices."
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Oregon Trail Pathway.  This easy walk will take you past our replica wagons onto a segment of the Oregon Trail and concludes at the William Henry Jackson campsite.  Round trip hike is roughly one mile.  The trail is paved with the exception of a section of the original Oregon Trail.  

Trail conditions will vary depending on what season you are visiting Scotts Bluff National Monument.  Spring on the prairie tends to be wet which can make the unpaved section of this trail a muddy mess.  Sturdy shoes are recommended.  Summer brings sunshine, high temperatures and rattlesnake activity to the prairie.  Please be sure to wear sunscreen, carry and drink water, and stay on the trail.  If you do encounter a rattlesnake give it plenty of room and do not attempt to move it.  If you like, you may return to the visit center and request a ranger to relocate the snake.  In the winter the trail may become icy or covered by drifting snow.  Strong winds frequent the prairie and Mitchell Pass so dress accordingly.        

Have a great hike and proceed to the next stop where you will learn about the replica wagons stationed along the trail.

stops.significance: From this stop you should be able to see Mitchell Pass off to the west. Mitchell Pass became the preferred route for emigrants to bypass Scotts Bluff starting in 1851. You will also see a few emigrant wagons.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue west on the paved trail until you reach the Murphy wagon. If is is summertime, the wagon will be the second one you encounter as you head west. If it is winter, it will be the first wagon you encounter.
stops.audioTranscript:
The predominant landscape, which is Scotts Bluff National Monument, guided emigrants of all walks of life westward across the plains to what they hoped was a better life in Oregon, California or Utah.  Mitchell Pass, located just beyond the replica wagons, represented the completion of 1/3 of their four to six month journey.  Today it takes 33 hours at 60 miles per hour to travel the 2,000 mile trail the emigrants walked.  Mitchell Pass often experienced bottleneck traffic as wagons funneled through the narrow passage.  Much like our replica wagons are lined up, wagons along the trail would have to wait their turn to continue west.  You may want to pick up the Wagons of the Overland Trails brochure located in the brochure rack for additional information.

If you’re here between Memorial Day and Labor Day you will see a Mormon handcart.  The Mormon handcart was used by recently converted Mormons just arriving to the United States who had little to no funds to purchase a wagon.  Most Mormons traveled from places like Council Bluffs but some traveled from St. Joseph or Kansas City.  Mormons generally used the Mormon Trail when heading to Utah, which was located north of the North Platte River.  If they happen to start their journey west on the south side of the river they tended to stay on that side following the Oregon Trail.  The Mormon handcart movement took place between 1856 and 1860.  These handcarts were significantly smaller than a wagon therefore the Mormon Church set restrictions on what converts were allowed to pack.

A little further ahead, you will have a better view of the Studebaker and Murphy wagons.

stops.significance: From this stop, different types of wagons that were used by emigrants and freight-hauling outfits can be seen.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue west on the trail until the paved surface ends and the trail is surfaced with gravel. The next stop is at a wayside panel titled "A Transportation Corridor."
stops.audioTranscript:
Between the early 1840s and late 1860s upwards of half a million people made the trek west to places like Oregon, California and Utah.  Many of these people were families hoping to make a better life in the West.  The wagons you see before you carried their livelihoods and their hopes and dreams across the country.  

The Studebaker wagon is blue while the Murphy has is stained a natural color.  Many emigrant families painted their wagons along with the canvas.  The Murphy is slightly larger of the two.  The Studebaker was mass produced by the Studebaker family who would eventually become leaders in the automotive industry.  

Generally speaking emigrant wagons were roughly 11 feet long by 4 feet wide and 10 feet tall.  They weighed about 1,300 pounds empty and 1,800 to 2,000 pounds loaded.  Oxen were the livestock of choice used to pull the wagons.  They were usually less expensive then mules and endured the long arduous journey better.  Contrary to Hollywood myth horses were seldom used to pull wagons.  Usually a wagon the size of the Murphy required four to six oxen. 
 
The last wagon you seen is the Conestoga wagon, the semi tractor trailer of the trails.  This wagon is considerably larger than either of the family wagons.  It measures 17 feet long by 8 feet wide and 20 feet tall!  Depending on the load as few as ten oxen could be used but sometimes as many as 24 were needed.  Conestoga wagons supplied the western outposts with goods and supplies of all kinds. People traveling and living west of the Missouri River relied on freighters to haul a little of home and civilization to the frontier.  
When looking at these wagons you might think to yourself, “Traveling 2,000 miles wouldn’t be so bad if I was riding in that.”  The sick, injured and infants rode in the wagon, everyone else walked.  There simply wasn’t room and this helped ease the burden on the livestock.  

Proceed to the next stop to learn about a major landmark on the trail and where you can walk in an authentic section of the Oregon Trail.

stops.significance: At this point on the tour, you will traverse a short section of the actual Oregon Trail. Here, at Mitchell Pass, wagon trains that had spread out across the prairie, were forced to funnel into the narrow pass, just wide enough for one wagon.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue by walking the gravel section of trail. The next stop is at the point where the trail becomes an asphalt paved section again.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1843 Scotts Bluff witnessed its first mass migration as emigrant families went west in search of better lives.  In the early years there were few guide books or accurate maps available.  Emigrants used landmarks such as the rock formations Eagle and Sentinel Rocks you see towering above you.   These rocks frame Mitchell Pass and guided emigrants westward.  

Here at the start of Mitchell Pass families lined up to take their turn through the bottleneck pass.  To the south is Sentinel Rock and to the North is Eagle Rock.   Prior to 1851, Robidoux Pass, located about eight miles to the South was favored.  Emigrants likely knew of Mitchell Pass, but found it rough and unimproved until approximately 1851.  It’s thought that soldiers from nearby Fort Laramie made improvements to Mitchell Pass the short their supply route.      

As you continue hiking you will notice the sidewalk has ended and the trail is now dirt.  The dirt section represents an original segment of the historic trails.  Besides the Oregon Trail, three other trails converged along what many historians refer to as the Great Platte River Road.  These are the California, Mormon, and the Pony Express trails.  Depending on the weather you may experience this segment much like an emigrant traveler did, under oppressive heat from the sun, against winds you must lean into to keep upright, or in ankle deep mud that threatens to engulf your shoes.  

In this segment many people expect to find two track wagon ruts.  You won’t see ruts at Scotts Bluff National Monument, but rather a swale, which is a large bowl shaped indention in the ground.  Here the trails were carved through sand and silt stone which erodes easily against wind and rain.  This bowl shape is wide at the beginning of this segment and narrows as you continue through the pass.  

Continue along the trail to your next stop, the distance between these two stops is a little longer than what you have experienced along the trail so far.  When the trail surface becomes paved again you are just about to your next stop where you will be paralleling the historic trails.

stops.significance: Wide depressions left by wagon traffic, called swales, can be seen from this point.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue west on the paved trail to the point where the trail ends. This will be the last stop on your audio tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
On the last portion of your hike you walked a segment of the original Oregon Trail.  Hopefully the weather was kind to you today and you didn’t have to fight strong winds, lighting, or heavy rains as the emigrants sometimes did.  Can you imagine how difficult navigating a wagon through the pass would be in such conditions?

Take a rest here and enjoy the view of Mitchell Pass behind you.  
Emigrant travelers would now begin making their way back towards the banks of the North Platte River.  You might be asking yourself, “Why didn’t they just stay along the river to begin with?”  They were avoiding the geologic badlands formation found along the south side of the river which made travel along the banks impassable.  

As you continue along this trail look to your left, next to the paved trail in the grass you will see a shallow ditch.  Here the wagon trail curves to the left.  In the shallow ditch and you may be able to make out the remnants of two wagon wheel ruts.  If you are interested in viewing some of the deepest and best preserved ruts you may want to visit the Oregon Trail Ruts State Historic Site and National Historic Landmark located near Guernsey, Wyoming.  Though Scotts Bluff once had remarkable ruts they have all but eroded as the surrounding geology is primarily sand and silt stone, this is why we see the swale, the bowl shape indention you walked through at stop ten more often.

Continue along the trail to stop twelve where we will discuss a treasured trail character.

stops.significance: This site is the location of artist and photographer William Henry Jackson's 1866 campsite.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop on the Oregon Trail Pathway audio tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
At this location the famed 19th Century artist and photographer William Henry Jackson camped here in 1866 along with the freighting company he worked.  Earlier that year Jackson found himself in Nebraska City, Nebraska Territory – a jumping off point for freighting caravans headed west. Despite lacking any experience handling oxen or hauling freight, Jackson signed on as bullwhacker for an outfit bound for Montana. 

Along the trail he sketched the sites he saw and the people he met.  Jackson was a gifted artist and found that his journey west was filled with new inspiration.   Jackson left the freight caravan near South Pass in present day Wyoming and headed south for Salt Lake City and eventually California.  His experiences in the West struck a chord in him, and he realized that documenting the settling of the frontier might become his life’s work.

It is through Jackson’s images of the frontier coupled with the first hand experiences found in emigrant dairies that we have the opportunity to gain a better understanding of what life truly was like along the Oregon Trail.  

If you would like to learn more about William Henry Jackson and his works please visit the park’s museum and tour the William Henry Jackson Room where you will find reprints of some of his watercolors and photographs.  

From here the historic trails make their way north returning to the banks of the North Platte River and westward to the mountains.  We hope that you have enjoyed your walk and tour, and that we have given you a better understanding of the Oregon Trail and the people who traveled it.

images.title: Audio Tour
images.altText: A woman stands on a paved trail and uses her smart phone to listen to an audio tour.
images.caption: The cell phone tour is now part of the NPS app.

data.title: Oregon Trail across Oregon & Washington
data.description: Traveling with this mobile tour is like having a ranger in your pocket! Find trail sites to visit in Oregon and Washington and learn as you explore! This Auto Tour will start you on the eastern side of Oregon, near the border with Idaho. Guiding you to travel west, mostly following Interstate 84, you will end your tour in Oregon City, Oregon. You can also return to the menu and select "Trail Sites to Visit in Oregon" and "Trail Sites to Visit in Washington" to explore individual sites near you.

stops.significance: Keeney Pass was named for the early western pioneer, Jonathan Keeney. In 1831, at the age of 19, Keeney left Missouri to explore the Rocky Mountains. He joined Jim Bridger of the American Fur Company and spent his life trapping and trading throughout the west. Thousands of emigrants on the Oregon Trail used this pass to reach the fertile farmlands that laid further west. The countryside of Keeney Pass has largely been unchanged since this time.

Farewell Bend State Recreation Area is named after Farewell Bend, the last location where emigrants camped and watered along the banks of the Snake River after following the river for over 300 miles. The next morning they would turn northwest and head into the desolate Burnt River country. Restored cover wagons and exhibits at an Oregon Trail kiosk tell the story.

Birch Creek Trail Site is a Bureau of Land Management site where the actual path made by emigrants, livestock, and wagons traveling the Oregon Trail is still a hiking path. Visitors are welcome to hike this quarter mile long section of the Oregon Trail across the sagebrush plains as it heads toward the Snake River. The hiking part of this path ends at a barbed wire fence, which divides grazing allotments on public lands. Oregon Trail ruts then continue for a short distance from the fence before disappearing in the grass.

The National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center is a 500 acre site managed by the Bureau of Land Management. The large interpretive center building contains exhibits that tell the compelling story of the Oregon Trail and the emigrant experience. In addition, the center contains a theater that hosts films, lectures, and dramatic presentations. On the grounds of the site are four miles of interpretive hiking trails, an amphitheater, a wagon encampment for living history demonstrations, and scenic views of the surrounding area. Oregon Trail ruts are visible from the center and can be visited. The site offers activities for all ages, for school groups, and for group tours. This is a particularly fine stop for families with children.
stops.assetName: National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center

stops.significance: The National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center is located at the top of Flagstaff Hill. The Oregon Trail reached this hill by going through the small valley, known as Virtue Flat, that lies just south of the center. Traveling through this valley was no easy task. Emigrants had to fight their way through shoulder-tall sagebrush just after spending four or five difficult days ascending Burnt River. The trek across Virtue Flats created 13 miles of still visible Oregon Trail ruts. Approximately one mile of these ruts lies on the interpretive center's grounds. The ruts can be reached by following hiking trails from the interpretive center or by driving a half-mile west of the center's entrance on Highway 86 to a turnout.
stops.assetName: National Historic Oregon Trail Center- Trail Ruts

stops.significance: The Grande Ronde Valley Oregon Trail Kiosk is located in the Charles Reynolds Rest Area off of Interstate 84. The kiosk's interpretive exhibits tell of the emigrant experience in the Grande Ronde Valley and their peaceful encounters with the valley's American Indians. Look back to the southeast (left side of the freeway when facing the westbound lanes of I-84) to see white posts marking the "powerful rockey" 1,300-foot descent of Ladd Hill to the Grande Ronde Valley.
stops.assetName: Grande Ronde Valley Oregon Trail Kiosk

stops.significance: For emigrants on the Oregon Trail, Ladd Marsh was another obstacle they had to overcome in order to reach the fertile lands of the Willamette Valley. After traveling through Ladd Canyon and descending Ladd Hill, the flat lands of Grande Ronde Valley at first were a welcome reprieve from hard travel. But that changed upon entering the marsh. The narrow-wheeled wagons become mired in the wet, muddy ground, exhausting already weary travelers. It was not until 1868, 25 years after the first wagons rolled through the marsh, that a new route was established that avoided the wet ground.

For emigrants, today's Birnie Park was more than just a place along the Oregon Trail. It was also an important camping and staging area. In order to leave Grande Ronde Valley and continue on the Trail, emigrants faced a nearly 1000 ft. climb up steep valley walls. Teams of oxen had to be combined in order to pull the wagons up this rise. The area now known as Birnie Park provided a perfect location to do this.

Oregon Trail Interpretive Park at Blue Mountain Crossing is where the Oregon Trail passed through the rugged Blue Mountains. Knowing that this was the last mountain range they would cross must have helped emigrants find the strength to climb the Blue Mountains. Trail swales and scars on stately Ponderosa pines made by passing wagons reveal the struggle emigrants faced in this rugged, and beautiful, mountain range.
stops.assetName: Oregon Trail Interpretive Park at Blue Mountain Crossing

stops.significance: "Tamástslikt" (pronounced "tuh-MUST-slickt") is from the Walla Walla Indian language, meaning "interpreting our own story." This museum and research facility is the only American Indian owned and operated interpretive center on the Oregon Trail. Its permanent exhibits explore the past, present, and future of the Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla people (the Confederated Tribes) and tell the Oregon Trail story from their perspective. This is a chance to see the pioneers through the eyes of Indian people.

Whitman Mission National Historic Site was established to preserve and share the story of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman's religious mission to the Cayuse Nation in the early nineteenth century, along with its lasting impacts and continuing relevancy. The Whitman's established their religious mission at Waiilatpu on the Columbia Plateau in 1836. During the 1840s, the mission also served as a way-stop on the Oregon Trail, providing emigrants with food, medicine, and, if needed, a place to stay during the winter. The Whitmans were killed in an attack on November 29, 1847.
stops.assetName: Whitman Mission National Historic Site, the Oregon Trail

stops.significance: The primary route of the Oregon Trail passed through Echo Meadows from 1847-1860. Just four miles from the Umatilla River crossing, emigrants did not stop or camp here, but they left signs of their passing nonetheless. Deep wagon swales were created as the emigrants passed through the meadows, which remain to this day.

Crossing the Deschutes River, near Deschutes River State Park , was difficult for emigrants. They frequently camped at the mouth of this large tributary of the Columbia River before crossing. In order to cross, some emigrant parties used the rocky islands near the river's mouth as stepping stones, while wagons were floated across and stock animals swam. Others forded the river using rafts. The lure of the nearby rich and fertile Willamette valley drove them ahead.
stops.assetName: Deschutes River State Park Oregon Trail Kiosk

stops.significance: Celilo Park is located along a stretch of the Columbia River where American Indians have been fishing for at least 10,000 years. In the past, they netted salmon migrating up the rapids and over Celilo Falls for food and trade. This important fishery became the hub of a vast Indian trade network that one writer called "the Wall Street of the West."

Columbia Gorge Discovery Center & Museum is located on a 54-acre point of land adjacent to the Columbia River and is the interpretive center for the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area. This area includes one of the oldest continuously occupied places in North America (over 11,000 years) and parts of the Lewis and Clark and Oregon Trails.

Obtained as a gift from Mark Mayer in 1924, the Rowena Crest Viewpoint is a paved overlook located near the top of the high bluffs on the south side of the Columbia River. It offers magnificent views of the Columbia River Gorge, interpretive exhibits, and hiking trails through a nature preserve. When the spring wildflowers are in bloom, this is one of the most stunning vistas in the Gorge.

Fort Vancouver was a supply depot and the headquarters for the Columbia District of the Hudson's Bay Company (HBC), a British corporation that monopolized the fur trade. Although HBC hoped to secure the Oregon Country for Britain, the post's humane and generous chief factor, Dr. John McLoughlin, often came to the rescue of American emigrants who arrived on his doorstep half-starved and penniless. He is regarded by many as a hero of the emigration era.
stops.assetName: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site, the Oregon Trail

stops.significance: This is where visitors register for a tour of the McLoughlin House.

McLoughlin House is named after John McLoughlin, the Chief Factor of Fort Vancouver. Pressured into retirement by Hudson's Bay Company because of his generosity toward American emigrants, John McLoughlin moved his family from the fort to this home in 1846. During his retirement, he became a U.S. citizen (in 1851), founded Oregon City, established several businesses there, and donated land for schools and churches.

The End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center contains a wealth of displays about the history of the Oregon Trail and the town of Oregon City. Before heading into the center, explore the outside grounds and gardens. Here, interpretive signs tell the stories of the Trail, the Tumwater Chinook and Clackamas Indian people, and the settlement of the Willamette Valley. Follow the sidewalk to reach the garden that contains the designated end of the Oregon Trail, which is marked by two monuments.
stops.assetName: End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center

data.description: This tour will begin at the Historic Entrance Gate. From there you will be able to explore the historic structures of Moton Field.

data.title: Outpost on the Missouri Self-Guided Tour
data.description: Outpost on the Missouri Self-Guided Tour takes visitors through the reconstructed historic site. This roughly 1/3 mile tour utilizes a cement walkway, packed gravel, and prairie grass for travel paths and includes one elevation rise (hill) of approximately 20 feet.

Follow cement path to Fort site. At Bastion turn right, follow riverbank to continue on rock path past Front Gate to Riverboat Landing Wayside.
Follow cement path to Fort site. At Bastion turn right, follow riverbank to continue on rock path past Front Gate to Riverboat Landing Wayside.
Enter the Fort through the Front Gate, pass the Trade House entrance, once inside the Courtyard turn left to view the Bourgeois House Wayside.
Follow the wooden sidewalk past the Clerks Office. Continue on dirt path past the Blacksmith Shop, continue up the grey staircase to Bastion Wayside.
Return to Clerks Office, turn north (facing Bourgeois House) and follow rectangle beans on ground outline to the Dwelling Range Wayside.
Cross the Courtyard towards the other wooden rectangles to the Store Range Wayside.
Follow wooden rectangles on ground north to the back of the Bourgeois House. Turn left between the back of the Bourgeois House and wall, walk past the kitchen to the Rear Courtyard Wayside.
Return to Courtyard, exit Fort through Rear Gates by walking past Bourgeois house and turning right. From the Rear Gate, move straight to The Prairie" Wayside.
This ends the Waysides Tour - we hope you enjoyed touring Fort Union!

data.title: Pa'rus Guided Hike
data.description: Learn about Zion’s diverse plant and animal life, geology, and human history while following the Virgin River on the Pa’rus Trail starting at the Zion Canyon Visitor Center. The paved trail connects the Zion Canyon Visitor Center and Canyon Junction in 3.5 miles roundtrip. It is a paved trail accessible for wheelchairs, pets on leashes, and bicycles. Due to limited service, save Zion for offline use on the NPS app to access these tour stops on the trail.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk along the sidewalk, follow the bridge to the left over the river and cross the road towards the South Campground. Follow the paved Pa’rus Trail to the Living Canyon wayside.
Continue walking on the Pa'rus Trail to the Footprints in Time wayside.
Continue walking on the Pa'rus Trail to the Creation for Destruction wayside.
Continue on the Pa'rus Trail to the Changing Landscapes wayside.
Continue on the Pa'rus Trail to the Virgin River wayside.
Continue on the Pa'rus Trail to the Diversion Dam wayside.
Continue on the Pa'rus Trail to the Master Sculptor wayside.
Continue on the Pa'rus Trail to Canyon Junction to complete the hike.
