data.title: Passage to the Gates of Lodore
data.description: Gates of Lodore is located on the northern tip of Dinosaur National Monument. It is a long drive to the area and the wild, remote country adds to its sense of isolation. Here, the Green River, after winding across the broad valley known as Browns Park, turns toward the south and makes a direct path into the mountains in front of it. The Green enters into deep canyons filled with rapids that challenged Major John Wesley Powell who passed through here in 1869 on his voyage down the Green and Colorado Rivers.

stops.significance:
Many canyons can be seen only distantly from their rims, or entered via long and strenuous hikes. Here, an easy walk takes you to the threshold of Dinosaur National Monument's canyon country for a look into its history and habitats. 

This tour is keyed to numbered points of interest along the trail as you approach the Gates of Lodore. Wear comfortable, sturdy shoes. Carry water and snacks. The elevation here is 5,500 feet (1,700 meters) above sea level so remember to pace yourself. Seek shelter immediately if thunder is heard or lightning is visible.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Start up the hill from the trailhead to trail marker 1

stops.significance:
From its origin high in the mountains of the Wind River Range in Wyoming, the Green River rushes through steep-walled canyons and traverses sage-covered valleys. After emerging from the Flaming Gorge Dam, the river wanders placidly through an open valley beginning 30 miles upstream from here. Early trappers and traders to the area named this valley Browns Hole after Baptiste Brown, a French-Canadian trapper. He choose this area to settle because of its mild winters and plentiful beaver pelts.

Travelers that passed through the area later included John Wesley Powell on his historic float through the Grand Canyon. Powell gave the area its current name of Browns Park. However, most local cattle ranchers still referred to the valley as Browns Hole until a spirited young Elizabeth Bassett convinced them to adopt what she termed the much more “eloquent” name of Browns Park.
stops.audioTranscript:
From its origin high in the mountains of the Wind River Range in Wyoming, the Green River rushes through steep-walled canyons and traverses sage-covered valleys. After emerging from the Flaming Gorge Dam, the river wanders placidly through an open valley beginning 30 miles upstream from here. Early trappers and traders to the area named this valley Browns Hole after Baptiste Brown, a French-Canadian trapper. He choose this area to settle because of its mild winters and plentiful beaver pelts.

Travelers that passed through the area later included John Wesley Powell on his historic float through the Grand Canyon. Powell gave the area its current name of Browns Park. However, most local cattle ranchers still referred to the valley as Browns Hole until a spirited young Elizabeth Bassett convinced them to adopt what she termed the much more “eloquent” name of Browns Park. Because of its isolation, Browns Park served as home to not only ranchers but also outlaws including Butch Cassidy, Matt Warner, and the notorious bounty hunter Tom Horn. Today, Browns Park remains sparsely populated by people, but it provides critical habitat for a variety of wildlife.

stops.significance: Browns Park is an isolated area, but it is not immune to change. Beginning in the 1870s, early settlers altered the landscape to suit their needs. Great cattle herds once roamed the range. Unlike native animals, cattle grazed on native grasses faster than they could reproduce and new invasive plants took their place. Cheat grass is one of the most common of these species. Originally introduced in grain shipments from the Mediterranean, it spread rapidly across the American west. Not only does it provide poor forage for native animals, but its seeds have the ability to hitchhike to new destinations by catching in fur or on your socks.
stops.audioTranscript: Browns Park is an isolated area, but it is not immune to change. Beginning in the 1870s, early settlers altered the landscape to suit their needs. Great cattle herds once roamed the range. Unlike native animals, cattle grazed on native grasses faster than they could reproduce and new invasive plants took their place. Cheat grass is one of the most common of these species. Originally introduced in grain shipments from the Mediterranean, it spread rapidly across the American west. Not only does it provide poor forage for native animals, but its seeds have the ability to hitchhike to new destinations by catching in fur or on your socks.

stops.significance: In contrast to cheat grass, lichens have been here a long time. The colorful patches on the rocks at your feet are alive. They are made of fungi whose filaments can cling to smooth rock and secrete acids that release minerals and algae which take shelter in the fungi and manufacture food for them both. Lichen help to create new habitat by breaking down rock and by naturally decaying themselves, creating a layer of soil where new plants can take hold.
stops.audioTranscript: In contrast to cheat grass, lichens have been here a long time. The colorful patches on the rocks at your feet are alive. They are made of fungi whose filaments can cling to smooth rock and secrete acids that release minerals and algae which take shelter in the fungi and manufacture food for them both. Lichen help to create new habitat by breaking down rock and by naturally decaying themselves, creating a layer of soil where new plants can take hold.

stops.significance: The Green River is affected by events that take place far upstream of here. During spring runoff or after heavy rains, the water may be brown, gray or red with silt from nearby tributaries such as Vermilion Creek. In drier weather, the river may live up to its name, flowing cold and green all the way from Flaming Gorge Dam, which traps most of its sediments. The dam’s greatest affect is not the river’s color, but its flow. After its completion in 1969, the great spring floods of former years are now trapped behind the dam. This altered the habitat downstream and made it more difficult for native fish to survive. In response, dam operators release extra water in the spring to simulate natural flooding and create conditions for the fish to spawn successfully. For the rest of the year, gradual releases from the dam keep the flow at a relatively constant level.

In drier weather, the river may live up to its name, flowing cold and green all the way from Flaming Gorge Dam, which traps most of its sediments. The dam’s greatest affect is not the river’s color, but its flow. After its completion in 1969, the great spring floods of former years are now trapped behind the dam. This altered the habitat downstream and made it more difficult for native fish to survive. In response, dam operators release extra water in the spring to simulate natural flooding and create conditions for the fish to spawn successfully. For the rest of the year, gradual releases from the dam keep the flow at a relatively constant level.

stops.significance: Across the river you can see some of the oldest rocks in Dinosaur National Monument, far more ancient than the dinosaur fossils. Perhaps as much as a billion years ago, this area lay near sea level and was being slowly buried by pebbles, sand, and mud washed down from mountains. Partly due to the weight of these sediments, the land gradually sank and the sediments piled up, reaching a thickness of over 24,000 feet. Tremendous pressure and cementing action of dissolved minerals solidified the sediments into the conglomerates, sandstones and shales that today we call the Uinta Mountain Group.
stops.audioTranscript: Across the river you can see some of the oldest rocks in Dinosaur National Monument, far more ancient than the dinosaur fossils. Perhaps as much as a billion years ago, this area lay near sea level and was being slowly buried by pebbles, sand, and mud washed down from mountains. Partly due to the weight of these sediments, the land gradually sank and the sediments piled up, reaching a thickness of over 24,000 feet. Tremendous pressure and cementing action of dissolved minerals solidified the sediments into the conglomerates, sandstones and shales that today we call the Uinta Mountain Group.

stops.significance: The Uinta Mountains, a spur of the Rocky Mountains, were formed by compression of the Earth’s crust. Once level layers, they then buckled upward into a broad arch. The range is highest in north-central Utah and gradually flattens out east of here. This uplifting probably began about the time the dinosaurs went extinct, and most likely continued a little at a time over millions of years. Even as the land rose, it was being worn down by erosion. Many of the younger rock layers have been stripped off to reveal these ancient rocks that were once at the very core of the mountains.

The range is highest in north-central Utah and gradually flattens out east of here. This uplifting probably began about the time the dinosaurs went extinct, and most likely continued a little at a time over millions of years. Even as the land rose, it was being worn down by erosion. Many of the younger rock layers have been stripped off to reveal these ancient rocks that were once at the very core of the mountains.

stops.significance:
If you have traveled from a moister climate, you might not think of this area as forested. The Utah juniper, however, manages to cover much of this arid country. What it lacks in stature, the juniper makes up for in toughness, longevity, the fragrance of its wood, and the beauty of its often gnarled, twisted trunks. Also, from a more utilitarian viewpoint, junipers have fueled many a campfire since prehistoric times, supported miles of fences and perhaps right now are providing you with a bit of welcome shade.

The junipers’ companion in much of the canyon country forests is the pinyon (piñon) pine. Though you might think of pines as growing best on snow-capped mountains, many species, especially the pinyon group are well adapted to lower, drier areas. All leaves have pores through which plants breathe but in pine needles these are sunk in deep pits. Along with a waxy coating the needles help to reduce the amount of moisture lost through evaporation.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you have traveled from a moister climate, you might not think of this area as forested. The Utah juniper, however, manages to cover much of this arid country. What it lacks in stature, the juniper makes up for in toughness, longevity, the fragrance of its wood, and the beauty of its often gnarled, twisted trunks. Also, from a more utilitarian viewpoint, junipers have fueled many a campfire since prehistoric times, supported miles of fences and perhaps right now are providing you with a bit of welcome shade.

The junipers’ companion in much of the canyon country forests is the pinyon (piñon) pine. Though you might think of pines as growing best on snow-capped mountains, many species, especially the pinyon group are well adapted to lower, drier areas. All leaves have pores through which plants breathe but in pine needles these are sunk in deep pits. Along with a waxy coating the needles help to reduce the amount of moisture lost through evaporation. Also, in many pines a type of root fungus helps draw water from the soil, since the fine strands of the fungus can penetrate into more nooks and crannies than relatively coarse roots. Perhaps you’ve seen or tasted the “pine nuts” sold throughout the Southwest. These are the seeds of the pinyon pine, borne in small cones which ripen in the fall. Harvesting them is a fall tradition for many native cultures. Additionally, pinyon seeds are a staple food for wildlife including the Clarks Nutcracker, Golden Mantled Ground Squirrel and the Juniper Titmouse.

stops.significance: You might expect to see cacti in this semi desert, but unless they are in bloom, you may have to look closely to find them. Dinosaur National Monument is a “cold” desert, where temperatures can top 100°F in summer, but may plunge well below zero in the winter. Since cacti survive by storing water in their fleshy stems, they are vulnerable to subfreezing temperatures. Only a few low-growing varieties, likely to be insulated by a blanket of snow during the coldest weather, live here. In spring they show off bright yellow, pink, and red blossoms, but in other seasons watch your step because you might feel one before you see it!

Since cacti survive by storing water in their fleshy stems, they are vulnerable to subfreezing temperatures. Only a few low-growing varieties, likely to be insulated by a blanket of snow during the coldest weather, live here. In spring they show off bright yellow, pink, and red blossoms, but in other seasons watch your step because you might feel one before you see it!

stops.significance: Like cacti, most of the plants here must conserve water in order to survive. Feel the leaves of this black greasewood. Their waxy surface helps to hold in moisture, just as waxed paper keeps food fresh. Both greasewood and its smaller cousin, shadscale saltbush, can absorb and store quantities of salt in alkaline soil that would kill many other plants.
stops.audioTranscript: Like cacti, most of the plants here must conserve water in order to survive. Feel the leaves of this black greasewood. Their waxy surface helps to hold in moisture, just as waxed paper keeps food fresh. Both greasewood and its smaller cousin, shadscale saltbush, can absorb and store quantities of salt in alkaline soil that would kill many other plants.

stops.significance: Rounding out the three most common shrubs here is the one that is probably the best known, sagebrush. Its grayish color readily distinguishes it from the greener greasewood and its spicy aroma clinches its identity. Although sagebrush is less tolerant of alkaline soils than saltbush and greasewood, several different species cover vast areas of the Intermountain West.
stops.audioTranscript: Rounding out the three most common shrubs here is the one that is probably the best known, sagebrush. Its grayish color readily distinguishes it from the greener greasewood and its spicy aroma clinches its identity. Although sagebrush is less tolerant of alkaline soils than saltbush and greasewood, several different species cover vast areas of the Intermountain West.

stops.significance: Greasewood, shadscale, and sagebrush dominate a surprisingly complex habitat sometimes referred to as sagebrush steppe. Look around for signs of wildlife. Some species, such as sage grouse, are completely dependent on this habitat. Others like elk and mule deer come and go with the seasons. An abundance of wildflowers creates a patchwork of color every spring.

stops.significance:
“Soon I see a bright star that appears to rest on the very verge of the cliff overhead to the east. Slowly it seems to float from its resting place on the rock over the canyon. At first it appears like a jewel set on the brink of the cliff, but as it moves out from the rock I almost wonder that it does not fall.”
-John Wesley Powell

Dinosaur National Monument is one of the darkest places remaining in the contiguous United States. Because there is minimal impact from artificial lights, you can still see the stars of our Milky Way galaxy with startling clarity. The majority of residents of the United States live in places where the Milky Way is no longer visible, even on a moonless night. Night skies are a vanishing resource and increasing development, even in many rural areas, expands the impact of light pollution. The skies above the monument are an important resource to enjoy and protect just like the fossils, stunning scenery, and wild rivers.
stops.audioTranscript:
“Soon I see a bright star that appears to rest on the very verge of the cliff overhead to the east. Slowly it seems to float from its resting place on the rock over the canyon. At first it appears like a jewel set on the brink of the cliff, but as it moves out from the rock I almost wonder that it does not fall.”
-John Wesley Powell

Dinosaur National Monument is one of the darkest places remaining in the contiguous United States. Because there is minimal impact from artificial lights, you can still see the stars of our Milky Way galaxy with startling clarity. The majority of residents of the United States live in places where the Milky Way is no longer visible, even on a moonless night. Night skies are a vanishing resource and increasing development, even in many rural areas, expands the impact of light pollution.

The skies above the monument are an important resource to enjoy and protect just like the fossils, stunning scenery, and wild rivers. Natural night skies also provide an important environment for animals and plants that require darkness. Due to isolation, night skies at Gates of Lodore still look similar to those that native peoples and early explorers experienced. When you gaze at the stars, whether with the naked eye or a telescope, not only are you looking into the distance, but also into the past.

stops.significance: The Green River, after meandering calmly through Browns Park, turns southward and cuts directly across the Uinta Mountains, which rise 3,000 feet above the valley floor. No one knows for sure why this is the case, but one theory suggests that a few million years ago the river flowed eastward, away from the mountains. When that route was blocked by uplift along the present continental divide, drainage in this area was stagnated. Browns Park gradually filled to the brim with sediments. Meandering along on top of that fill, the Green River eventually spilled over the buried crest of the mountains and down their southern slope. This gave it the energy to begin down cutting once more and as it washed out most of the recent sediments, it also rasped its way into the older rocks to carve the Canyon of Lodore.

No one knows for sure why this is the case, but one theory suggests that a few million years ago the river flowed eastward, away from the mountains. When that route was blocked by uplift along the present continental divide, drainage in this area was stagnated. Browns Park gradually filled to the brim with sediments. Meandering along on top of that fill, the Green River eventually spilled over the buried crest of the mountains and down their southern slope. This gave it the energy to begin down cutting once more and as it washed out most of the recent sediments, it also rasped its way into the older rocks to carve the Canyon of Lodore.

stops.significance: Today, the rugged walls along the Green River are a haunt of the bighorn sheep. These sure footed climbers were probably abundant here in the past based on the number of images of them that appear in the thousand year old rock art of the Fremont People. As the west became more settled with the arrival of Europeans, the bighorn sheep began to die out from a combination of over hunting, disease, and competition from domestic livestock. The last native bighorn sheep seen in Dinosaur was reported in 1944. In 1952 a new herd of animals from elsewhere in Colorado were transplanted into the area. Their population has increased significantly to the point where bighorn sheep are now a common sight along the river corridors. Due to their unique padded hooves, bighorn are able to climb the steep, rocky canyon walls with speed and agility, making them well adapted to life in Dinosaur.

As the west became more settled with the arrival of Europeans, the bighorn sheep began to die out from a combination of over hunting, disease, and competition from domestic livestock. The last native bighorn sheep seen in Dinosaur was reported in 1944. In 1952 a new herd of animals from elsewhere in Colorado were transplanted into the area. Their population has increased significantly to the point where bighorn sheep are now a common sight along the river corridors. stops.significance: “At noon the sun shines in splendor on vermilion walls… and the canyon opens, like a beautiful portal, to a region of glory. This evening, as I write, the sun is going down and the shadows are settling in the canyon… and now it is a dark portal to a region of gloom, the gateway through which we are to enter on our voyage of exploration tomorrow, what shall we find?” John Wesley Powell wrote these words as he camped near here on June 7, 1869, expressing the combination of excitement and fear he and his companions often felt as they made the first full length expedition down the Green River. Since most of this canyon country was still literally a blank spot on the map, Powell and his men had the opportunity to fill in the blanks with new names. Andy Hall, the youngster of the group, suggested the name of this canyon after recalling “The Cataract of Lodore” by the English poet Robert Southey: “All at once and all o’er, with a mighty uproar and this way the water comes down at Lodore.”
stops.audioTranscript:
“At noon the sun shines in splendor on vermilion walls… and the canyon opens, like a beautiful portal, to a region of glory. This evening, as I write, the sun is going down and the shadows are settling in the canyon… and now it is a dark portal to a region of gloom, the gateway through which we are to enter on our voyage of exploration tomorrow, what shall we find?”
 
John Wesley Powell wrote these words as he camped near here on June 7, 1869, expressing the combination of excitement and fear he and his companions often felt as they made the first full length expedition down the Green River. Since most of this canyon country was still literally a blank spot on the map, Powell and his men had the opportunity to fill in the blanks with new names. Andy Hall, the youngster of the group, suggested the name of this canyon after recalling “The Cataract of Lodore” by the English poet Robert Southey: “All at once and all o’er, with a mighty uproar and this way the water comes down at Lodore.”

These lines soon proved to be appropriate, for the first large rapid below here wrecked one of the party’s four wooden boats and earned itself the name Disaster Falls. The crew salvaged what they could, and approached the later rapids more cautiously. Powell ultimately floated all the way down the Green and Colorado Rivers through the Grand Canyon.

stops.significance: What Powell had called “the great unknown” is now explored by thousands of people every year in rafts and kayaks. River running is very popular in Dinosaur National Monument. The monument uses a permit system both for boater safety and to reduce the impact of too many people concentrated in narrow canyons. To some, imposition of such regulations is contradictory to the freedom of wilderness travel; to others, some control necessary to preserve the wilderness itself. How we protect our public lands, while also allowing for their use, is a continual debate. Rafters may not have been able to enjoy these wild rivers if proposed dams had been constructed within the monument boundaries. The Echo Park Dam would have flooded the entire Canyon of Lodore and also that of the Yampa River, the Green’s major tributary. Protestors of the dam pointed out that Dinosaur National Monument had been enlarged to protect these canyons in their natural state, not as artificial reservoirs.
stops.audioTranscript:
What Powell had called “the great unknown” is now explored by thousands of people every year in rafts and kayaks. River running is very popular in Dinosaur National Monument. The monument uses a permit system both for boater safety and to reduce the impact of too many people concentrated in narrow canyons. To some, imposition of such regulations is contradictory to the freedom of wilderness travel; to others, some control necessary to preserve the wilderness itself. How we protect our public lands, while also allowing for their use, is a continual debate.

Rafters may not have been able to enjoy these wild rivers if proposed dams had been constructed within the monument boundaries. The Echo Park Dam would have flooded the entire Canyon of Lodore and also that of the Yampa River, the Green’s major tributary. Protestors of the dam pointed out that Dinosaur National Monument had been enlarged to protect these canyons in their natural state, not as artificial reservoirs. After years of contentious debate in the 1950s and 60s, the decision was made to not build a dam within the monument boundaries.

Though the water that passes through the Gates of Lodore today is not quite the wild and unknown torrent that Powell saw, it is still a flowing river. The current still gnaws inch by inch into ancient rock; beaver still burrow and feed along the banks; bighorn still find footholds on the canyon walls; and modern explorers thrilled by the sights, the roar of a rapid and the song of a canyon wren can attest that this river is a rare and valuable resource.

stops.significance: “How does the water Come down at Lodore?” My little boy asked me thus, once on a time; and moreover he tasked me to tell him in rhyme. Anon, at the word, there first came one daughter, and then came another, to second and third the request of their brother, and to hear how the water comes down at Lodore, with its rush and its roar, as many a time they had seen it before. So I told them in rhyme, for of rhymes I had store; and ‘twas in my vocation for their recreation that so I should sing; because I was laureate to them and the king. From its sources which well In the tarn on the fell; from its fountains In the mountains, its rills and its gills; through moss and through brake, it runs and it creeps for a while, till it sleeps in its own little lake. And thence at departing, awakening and starting, it runs through the reeds, and away it proceeds, through meadow and glade, in sun and in shade, and through the wood-shelter, among crags in its flurry, helter-skelter, hurry-skurry.
stops.audioTranscript:
“How does the water Come down at Lodore?” My little boy asked me thus, once on a time; and moreover he tasked me to tell him in rhyme. Anon, at the word, there first came one daughter, and then came another, to second and third the request of their brother, and to hear how the water comes down at Lodore, with its rush and its roar, as many a time they had seen it before. So I told them in rhyme, for of rhymes I had store; and ‘twas in my vocation for their recreation that so I should sing; because I was laureate to them and the king. From its sources which well In the tarn on the fell; from its fountains In the mountains, its rills and its gills; through moss and through brake, it runs and it creeps for a while, till it sleeps in its own little lake. And thence at departing, awakening and starting, it runs through the reeds, and away it proceeds, through meadow and glade, in sun and in shade, and through the wood-shelter, among crags in its flurry, helter-skelter, hurry-skurry. Here it comes sparkling, and there it lies darkling; now smoking and frothing Its tumult and wrath in, till, in this rapid race on which it is bent, it reaches the place of its steep descent.”

Excerpt from “ The Catarct of Lodore” by Robert Southey

data.title: Places of Salem Maritime
data.description: Following the American Revolution, Salem was one of the most prosperous communities of the early republic. Daring and skilled maritime merchants traveled the globe, controlling valuable trade markets with the West Indies, Europe, Asia, and Indonesia. In 1938, Salem Maritime became the first ever National Historic Site incorporated into the National Park Service. On this walking tour, we’ll visit historic buildings and structures that span over 300 years of history.

stops.significance: Once a headquarters and training facility for the Second Corps of Cadets, the visitor center offers exhibits, maps, brochures, films, and a traditional park store.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the front door of the visitor center, turn to your right and proceed up Essex Street. Take a right on Herbert Street. At the end of the road, take a left on Derby Street. Waite & Peirce will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the Salem Armory Visitor Center, National Park Service staff and volunteers can provide you information on historic sites and other places of interest throughout the Essex National Heritage Area.  

Before you set out, make sure you are prepared—restrooms are available at limited locations. Pets are welcome to tour with you, but are not allowed in any historic buildings and should not be left unattended.

stops.significance: Serving as a park store, Waite & Peirce is named after the owners of the original FRIENDSHIP. Aaron Waite and Jerathmiel Peirce sent their ships to bring back exotic spices and other treasures to Salem during the Golden Age of American Maritime history.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk up Derby Street until you reach an open, grassy field on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
Named for the owners of the original FRIENDSHIP, Aaron Waite and Jerathmiel Peirce, the Waite & Peirce firm conducted business in Salem for nearly 50 years. They dealt in the city’s major trade commodities, sending ships across the world to the West Indies, the East Indies, Europe, and Russia.  

In 1974, the City of Salem uncovered two early 19th century warehouses on nearby Front Street. The National Park Service purchased both for one dollar and moved the buildings to Salem Maritime. One warehouse was later destroyed by a fire, but today, the other serves as our park store and commemorates the Salem partners, Waite & Peirce.

stops.significance: During the Golden Age of Sail, Derby Wharf was the center of Salem’s maritime trade lined with warehouses, stores, and business.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the gravel path to your right. A large wood warehouse will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript: Captain Richard Derby and his son Elias Hasket began building Derby Wharf in 1762. Richard Derby was a successful merchant, building a fortune through trade with the West Indies and his involvement in the Atlantic slave economy. His son, Elias Hasket Derby, continued this practice. As the Derby family's trade expanded over the years, they extended the wharf. In 1806, the Derby family lengthened the wharf to over two thousand feet. By 1812, it was lined with 15 large, wooden warehouses and home to thirty-five stores and businesses.

stops.significance: The Pedrick Store House is a reminder of the warehouses that used to crowd the wharf. It was built in Marblehead by Thomas Pedrick, a successful member of the merchant community in pre-Revolutionary War Marblehead.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the gravel path. A large sailing vessel is docked behind the Pedrick Store House.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Pedrick Store House was built in Marblehead, just across the harbor from Salem, in 1770 by Thomas Pedrick, a successful member of the merchant community in pre-Revolutionary War Marblehead. A warehouse was an important part of a merchant’s property, as it was where goods and equipment for the vessels were stored, repair work could be done for vessels, and the merchant often had his “counting house” or business office. During the Revolution, Pedrick commissioned privateers to capture British merchant vessels, storing captured cargo in his store house. 

In 1809, the warehouse was purchased by Captain William Story, a relative of Thomas Pedrick. Unfortunately, he was not as successful in his mercantile efforts as Pedrick had been, and was forced to sell the warehouse and wharf in 1820. The building went through several owners until the National Park Service accepted it in 2003 and began several years of conservation on the original 18th century timbers.

stops.significance: In port cities like Salem, the vessels sitting in the harbor were the pride of the community. Friendship of Salem is a replica of the 1797 Salem-built vessel Friendship.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel path. It will take you just over 2000 feet into Salem Harbor.
stops.audioTranscript:
The original FRIENDSHIP was a two-decked, three-masted, square-rigged ship, built on Salem’s South River by shipwright Enos Briggs in 1796. FRIENDSHIP was known as an East Indiaman, a vessel typically employed in the East Indies trade. In addition, FRIENDSHIP traded in the West Indies, South America, northern Europe, and the Mediterranean, making at least fifteen voyages.

FRIENDSHIP left for its eighth voyage in June of 1802, on the way to Sumatra and then China. It returned twenty six months later, in August of 1804, with cargo including silk, coffee, tea, pepper, and china. The customs duties collected amounted to over 31 thousand dollars. During this voyage, Thomas Russell, the second mate, and Mr. Odell, the ship carpenter, constructed a large model of FRIENDSHIP. 

On September 5th of 1812, when it was about two thirds of the way across the Atlantic, FRIENDSHIP was captured as a prize of war by the British vessel ROSAMOND. Unfortunately, little is known about its life afterwards.  

Today, the replica FRIENDSHIP OF SALEM, is berthed at Derby Wharf. The hull construction and rig are based on Thomas Russell’s 1804 model, displayed today at the Peabody Essex Museum. The National Park Service used modern materials and construction methods while retaining the original appearance of this iconic, Salem ship.

stops.significance: One of four lighthouses used to navigate Salem Sound, the Derby Wharf Light Station is the wharf’s only surviving structure.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Reverse direction and take the path back to Derby Street. Cross the street and you'll be standing in front of the Custom House.
stops.audioTranscript:
In July of 1870, the US Congress authorized the building of a light station at the end of Derby Wharf as part of a plan to, “mark the main channel leading into this anchorage, with the view of its becoming a harbor of refuge.” Eventually, as Derby Wharf continued to deteriorate from lack of use, the light station too became less significant and was dimmed in the 1930s.  

The National Park Service acquired ownership of the light station from the Coast Guard in 1979. With the help of the volunteer organization, the Friends of Salem Maritime, the National Park Service restored the structure and the Derby Wharf Light was relit on October 4th of 1983.  

Today, the solar powered light flashes red at six second intervals. Although Salem’s harbor has witnessed major changes in the types of craft frequenting its waters, the Derby Light Station continues to serve the maritime community as it did over 100 years ago.

stops.significance: The Custom House served as the headquarters for the U.S. Customs Service in Salem from 1819 to 1936. This property became part of Salem Maritime National Historic Site in 1938. It was temporarily occupied by the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the front of the Custom House, turn to your right, then left, following the brick sidewalk around to the back of the building. Walk through the opening in the fence on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The property was purchased for use by the U.S. Treasury in 1818 for five thousand dollars and served as headquarters for the U.S. Customs Service in Salem. It was vital that government officials be stationed at the center of Salem’s maritime trade. This location, across from the busy and bustling Derby Wharf, was ideal. Here, customs officials collected duties on incoming cargo, documented vessels in Salem’s harbor, and maintained records of crews and passengers. 

As you stand in front of the building, notice the federal style architecture, the 12 granite steps leading to the tall double doors, the white columns and large windows, and the golden eagle proudly perched above. The Custom House symbolized the Federal Government’s presence in Salem. Architects designed an impressive structure to represent the government’s strength and stability.  

Salem’s Customs Service used this building as headquarters until 1936. In 1937, the U.S. Treasury Department transferred thousands of objects from the Custom House to the US Department of the Interior, including documents, ledgers, work tools, and furniture.

stops.significance: The Public Stores was built at the same time as the Custom House in 1819 however, the two are not connected by any interior doors. The space served as a bonded warehouse, where the US Customs Service stored goods until duties and storage fees could be paid by merchants.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the walkway at the back of the building. At the rear of the yard is a small brick building.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1790, the Derby owned ships LIGHT HORSE and ASTREA returned to Salem carrying a large cargo of tea from China. The newly established U.S. Customs Service assessed their value and determined 25 thousand dollars in import duties were due. Unable to pay cash upfront and unwilling to flood the market with an over-supply of tea, Derby petitioned Congress to establish a bonded warehouse system.  

This new system allowed goods to be stored in a Customs Service warehouse for an extended period of time, until duties and storage fees could be paid. Derby’s concept proved popular, allowing merchants to store their cargo for a fee as they waited for market values to increase.  

At one time, Salem’s bonded warehouses would have held luxury and exotic trade goods from all around the world. Goods may be sold to local shops, shipped to other American destinations, or re-exported to other countries. Today, the Public Stores is filled with reproductions of trade goods such as tea chests, textiles, pepper, and china.

stops.significance: The Scale House was built in 1829 and used by the Customs Service until 1937. It housed scales and gauges used to measure imported goods arriving in Salem.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Reverse direction and follow the walkway through the fence and out of the Custom House yard. Cross the cobblestone driveway and the Hawkes House will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
When vessels arrived in Salem, the Custom House yard bustled with activity. Customs officials loaded up portable scales and gauges and headed down Orange Street. Scales were assembled on the wharf right next to an incoming ship where Customs officials got busy with the measuring and counting of imported goods. Depending upon the ship’s cargo, it may have taken Customs officials up to two weeks to measure and assess duties. 

Between 1819 and 1829, the Customs Service stored their scales in a small coach house left behind on this property. When the building burned down in 1829, new funds allowed for the construction of the scale house standing here today.

stops.significance: Elias Hasket Derby commissioned Samuel McIntire to build this wooden, three story mansion in 1781. However, construction was never completed. It’s possible Derby used it as a warehouse until his death in 1799.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the Hawkes House on your right, continue down the brick sidewalk and follow it to the left. You will pass a garden on your right. Go through the fence until you reach a house at the end.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1781, while living in the little brick house next door, Elias Hasket Derby commissioned Samuel McIntire to begin construction on a new mansion. Two years later, the Derby family relocated to a different mansion and construction on the Hawkes house was suspended.   

After Derby’s death, Benjamin Hawkes, for whom the house is named, purchased the property. He significantly altered the structure and interior of the building, removing over fifteen feet along the eastern edge, and reducing the building’s size by about one third.  

Following a period of financial difficulties, Hawkes lost the property to the bank in 1830. In 1937, the National Park Service acquired the property from the City of Salem. The historic mansion and surrounding grounds had fallen into disrepair. Landscape architect Norman Newton designed a landscape plan for Salem Maritime in the Colonial Revival style with the intention to give the area an elegant feel reminiscent of the cosmopolitan peak of Salem. 

Workers erected fences, laid the cobblestone driveway and brick paths, and planted trees. The plan also called for the removal of numerous buildings in the area between Orange Street and Palfrey Court, including several homes, garages, and stores. Including the Hawkes House, only five buildings escaped demolition.

stops.significance: Today this house offers us the unique opportunity to study the lives of working class families over a period of nearly 300 years and to see how the fruits of international trade reached all residents, not just the wealthy, in historic Salem.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Reverse directions and follow the sidewalk back towards Derby Street. Once at Derby Street, turn left. A large brick house will be on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
Thomas Ives purchased this property in 1670 and later built a half-house, two rooms stacked on top of each other, with a chimney and steeply pitched gable roof. This popular home design allowed the building to grow over time as demand for space increased.  

Over the years, the home housed several families and underwent various additions and renovations. The Narbonne family, for whom the house is named, occupied the home from 1820 to 1905. Sarah Narbonne and her daughter Mary supported themselves by running a “cent shop” out of the home. The National Park Service bought the property in 1964. 

Before municipal trash removal, residents threw garbage in the backyard or down privies. In the 1970s, archaeologists excavated the property. In the backyard, they discovered a wealth of social history, almost 160 thousand artifacts.  

In addition to common ceramics, typical of working class-families, an abundance of fine china pieces were discovered. Residents of the home were not wealthy, and it’s unlikely their counterparts further inland would have owned similar sets of fine china. But because they lived in Salem, where ships regularly brought luxury goods from around the world, residents of the Narbonne house had ready access to such items.

stops.significance: Constructed in 1761, this building is the earliest surviving brick house in Salem. It is recognized as an excellent example of 18th-century domestic Georgian architecture.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the sidewalk and you will see a blue building on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Derby House was constructed for prominent Salem merchant Richard Derby in 1761 as a wedding gift for his son, Elias Hasket Derby. Elias Hasket and his family spent most of the Revolutionary War in this house. 

In 1782, after twenty years in the home with his wife, seven children, and at least two enslaved people, Hasket moved the family to a home nearly twice as large on Washington Street. Through the next century, the little brick house was home to various residents, eventually split up into apartments, and finally fell into disrepair.  

In 1927, the Society for Preservation of New England Antiquities began restoring the house intending to bring it back to its original appearance. The National Park Service acquired the property in 1937 and began its own restoration efforts the following year. Today, the Derby House is furnished to reflect the lifestyle of a rising merchant in the 1770s. Maritime trade is demonstrated by imported dishes, maps, and goods like shells and ceramics, brought back as gifts from sailing voyages around the world.

stops.significance: From 1837 to 1851, Salem directories listed a West India Goods Store on this property. It may have served as a retail store for exotic, luxury goods from the West Indies. Over the years, the building has housed various tenants and businesses.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross Palfrey Court and you will be standing in front a large brick building with window displays.
stops.audioTranscript:
Not many documents remain to offer insight into the history of this property. Records indicate that Captain Henry Prince, one-time owner of the Derby House, purchased a lot adjacent to his property in 1801. Fourteen years later, records show Prince paying taxes on his house and a store. It is unclear whether this refers to a warehouse or a retail store.  

From 1837 to 1851, after Prince had vacated his home, Salem directories listed a West India Goods Store on the property. Imports from the West Indies included molasses, sugar, coffee, and indigo. Salem stores would have sold exotic luxury items, in addition to local produce and products.  

Additional records indicate that over the years this building housed numerous businesses and various tenants. At one point, the building was even moved from the southeast corner to the southwest corner of the lot. After the National Park Service acquired the property in 1937, the building was moved back to its original location.

stops.significance: The St. Joseph Society built this three-story brick structure for Polish immigrants and their children helping to create a shared sense of ethnic and community identity.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Fraternal Society of St. Joseph was founded in 1897 to offer various forms of assistance to Polish immigrants. When the society was twelve years old, members built this three-story brick structure as a permanent meeting place. St. Joseph Hall quickly became a center of Polish-American activities in Salem.   

The hall provided a space for meetings and social events like balls, banquets, concerts, and weddings. The society offered life insurance and health benefits to members, in addition to sponsoring sports teams, parades and various cultural and political activities.  

The St. Joseph Society helped create a shared sense of ethnic and community identity for Polish immigrants and their children. The hall on Derby Street played a major role in helping the society’s members adjust to life in America.  

By the 1980s, the neighborhood was no longer a primarily Polish community, and with a dwindling number of members, the society found it difficult to maintain the building. At the same time, the National Park Service was seeking new stories to include at Salem Maritime, to better reflect the city’s rich and diverse history. St. Joseph Hall was purchased by the park in 1988.

images.caption: Explore the first National Historic Site in the United States.

data.title: Places of Saugus Iron Works
data.description: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site, or Hammersmith as it was called, represents North America’s 17th century transformation from stone to iron tool manufacturing. In a venture intended to make the Massachusetts Bay Colony more self-reliant, English investors financed the creation of the Company of Undertakers for the iron works in New England. These workmen would help Massachusetts achieve its goals. Use this walking tour to get acquainted with the grounds, buildings and history at the iron works.

park.fullName: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
park.name: Saugus Iron Works

stops.significance: The Iron Works House is the oldest building at the site and is an excellent example of first period architecture.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the front door of the house, turn right and follow the path. You will make a sharp left turn, reversing your direction. Continue on and you will have the house to your left and museum to your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
The iron works house is located in the center of the upper lawn area and is the sole remaining 17th century structure on the site, though it is probably unrelated to the iron works operation. The first known occupant, Samuel Appleton, lived in the house from 1681-1688, a dozen or more years after the industrial site had closed. Appleton was a member of the Puritan gentry and this grand house reflected his privileged position in society.  

By the early 20th century, the house had been gravely altered from its original state. It was rescued and restored by antiquarian Wallace Nutting who became famous for his reproduction colonial furniture, books on colonial homes, and photographs. Nutting bought the house in 1915 and restored it to its original appearance.

stops.significance: In the 1950s, this clapboarded building was converted into a museum to house thousands of artifacts unearthed during the archeological investigations at the time.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn left down the path after exiting the building. At the next split, take the path to your left. Following the path north takes you to the oak planked charging bridge of the blast furnace.
stops.audioTranscript:
Wallace Nutting’s restoration of the Iron Works House inspired efforts to restore the iron works site. Local citizens formed the first iron works association in 1943. With funds for the American Iron and Steel Institute, archeologist Roland Wells Robbins began digging in 1948. Over the next few years, he and his team unearthed outlines of the principle structures and the remains of the blast furnace, a 500-pound hammer head, a large section of a waterwheel and thousands of other artifacts.  

By 1951, a reconstruction project was under way. Workers, from civil engineers to leather craftsmen, relied on Robbins archeological finds, colonial documents and 17th century English descriptions of iron works to recreate the Saugus Iron Works. The site was open to the public in 1954 and transferred to the National Park Service in 1968.

stops.significance: This square-based stone structure processed charcoal, bog ore and gabbro to make iron.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the charging bridge behind you, take a left down the path until you reach the granite stairway. Descend the stairs, turning right at the bottom. Follow the path down and take a left at the split. Continue to follow it around and you will enter a shed.
stops.audioTranscript:
The ironmaking operation began with fillers dumping basketful after basketful of raw materials, gathered from nearby marshes, woods and coastal areas, into the furnace’s deep charging hole. The initial charging operation, which included drying out the sandstone lining of the furnace, could take as long as a week to be completed. 

A calcium rich flux, usually limestone or seashells, was needed to drive impurities out of the iron. At Saugus, it was determined that gabbro, an igneous rock found on the shoreline of the nearby Nahant peninsula, could be used as a flux. Founders carefully managed proportions of charcoal, bog ore, gabbro and air to separate the iron from its impurities.  

As molten iron and slag were tapped separately from the base of the furnace, more material was fed into the charge hole at the top. While in blast, the furnace was attended around the clock from 30-40 weeks until maintenance was needed.

stops.significance: Patterns were pressed into the sand floor to make iron molds.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk through the shed until you reach the path on the other side. With the retaining wall on your left, cross the wooden bridge until you reach a wide wooden ramp with steep pitch. At the top of the ramp, two large wooden doors welcome you to the forge.
stops.audioTranscript:
Wooden patterns were pressed into the sand to make molds for some of the iron parts needed at the furnace, such as the cams, and for the forge, hammer heads and the large counterbalance and pivot for the hammer called the hurst.  

Cast iron products such as pots, salt pans and anvils were in great demand by the inhabitants of the new Massachusetts Bay Colony. To fill the need, potters were employed to produce clay molds which were buried beneath the sand floor of the casting shed. A clay plug was knocked out of a dam at the bottom of the furnace, allowing molten iron to flow into a large ladle. The fiery liquid was then poured through a long hollow tube into the buried mold.  

Workers would carefully create a series of connected trenches in the sand, that when iron was tapped into these gutters, it froze into cast iron ingots, or sows. The sows were taken to the forge, where they were reworked into wrought iron.

stops.significance: Forge workers produced wrought iron merchant bars, the primary product of the iron works.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the forge walking down a steep path and turn left at the split. Proceed across a wood bridge and corduroy road made from logs laid parallel to one another. Take the path to your left until you come to the large barn door of the rolling and slitting mill.
stops.audioTranscript:
In late 1650, the local workforce was augmented by a group of 61 Scottish prisoners of war who arrived in Lynn as forced indentured workers. This created new tensions between the iron works and the local community. These men had been captured at the Battle of Dunbar Scotland,  marched over 100 miles to Newcastle, then shipped across the Atlantic to ease the chronic shortage and high price of labor at the iron works. Many Scottish prisoners were trained at Saugus and they soon replaced local workers as carpenters, farmers, wood cutters and miners, with some becoming iron workers and blacksmiths. 

These skilled iron workers brought specialized metallurgical knowledge to Saugus. The hammermen squeezed excess slag from the loop and forged the iron into merchant bars, the major product of the Saugus Iron Works. The long internal fibers of the bar made it less brittle than cast iron, making it ideal for horseshoes, shovels and other tools. Imported steel could be welded onto wrought iron axes and chisels to add a more durable cutting edge.

stops.significance: In this building, merchant bars were further worked to create other semi-finished products that blacksmiths could use.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps down the path and turn right across the wooden deck and bridge. The warehouse and dock are on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the rolling and slitting mill, merchant bars were heated and passed through rollers to flatten them. This reshaped the bars into flat stock, or flats. Some of the rolled pieces were shipped as they were to be used, among other things, as iron tires for wagon wheels, axes or sawblades. 

While many flats were sold as they were, others were reheated and put through the slitters. When a heated flat is forced through the slitters, it breaks into many smaller rods of iron. The iron rods provided blacksmiths and farmers the means to make nails, which were in great demand.

stops.significance: The iron works was situated at a place along the Saugus River where the Atlantic tide reaches its highest point allowing shallow draft boats to transport raw materials in and finished products out.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the warehouse on your right, turn left and cross the wooden bridge. Follow the path first to your right, then to your left until you reach a shallow dip in the pathway. Just south is the archaeological site of the Joseph Jenks blacksmith shop.
stops.audioTranscript:
Riverways were the most practical places to build a transportation system in the 17th century. Boatman sailed single-masted boats with a shallow draft to carry gabbro from Nahant or iron bars or castings to other coastal communities. The warehouse or iron house was typically locked to secure valuable iron goods in anticipation of the voyage to market. Markets ranged from local blacksmiths to English merchants and even entrepreneurs in Barbados.  

Just past the warehouse, the wood dock projects in the river. Red wing blackbirds, black crown night herons, ducks, Canada geese, kingfishers and goldfinches are among the more than 40 species of birds making a living along the waterfront.  

Despite successful iron production, the iron works was plagued by financial difficulties beginning in the 1650s, resulting in bankruptcy. This caused a dispersal of iron workers throughout southern New England, and as far south as New Jersey, helping to spread iron making technology throughout the colonies.

stops.significance: In 1646, Jenks obtained a patent from the Massachusetts General Court which gave him exclusive right to build water mills for making scythes and other edge tools.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1646, the iron works permitted Joseph Jenks to establish a blacksmith shop on the tailrace of the blast furnace so he could use the water to power a small hammer and grindstones. Using iron and steel he forged scythes, sawblades and axes to meet the needs of the local inhabitants. Jenks also made the long, heavy sawblades needed to cut timber in New England's water powered sawmills. 

The Jenks Blacksmith Shop was located near the slag pile, and used water from the tailrace of the blast furnace to run its water wheel. This building was not reconstructed and the area where it was is currently marsh habitat.

images.title: Places of Saugus Iron Works
images.altText: three people follow a path around the back of a house to a wood-sided museum with bright red door
images.caption: Explore the grounds and structures of Saugus Iron Works.

data.title: Poetry of Places
data.description: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's poetry touches on universal themes, but in many instances it is specifically located through references, imagery, and inspiration to his Cambridge neighborhood.

park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance: "To A Child," published in The Belfry of Bruges and Other Poems, 1845.
stops.audioTranscript:
Selection from "To A Child"

Through these once solitary halls
Thy pattering footstep falls.
The sound of thy merry voice
Makes the old walls
Jubilant, and they rejoice
With the joy of thy young heart,
O'er the light of whose gladness
No shadows of sadness
From the sombre background of memory start. 

Once, ah, once, within these walls,
One whom memory oft recalls,
The Father of his Country, dwelt.
And yonder meadows broad and damp
The fires of the besieging camp
Encircled with a burning belt.
Up and down these echoing stairs,
Heavy with the weight of cares,
Sounded his majestic tread;
Yes, within this very room
Sat he in those hours of gloom,
Weary both in heart and head.

stops.significance: "The Herons of Elmwood," published in Keramos and Other Poems, 1878.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Herons of Elmwood

Warm and still is the summer night,
  As here by the river's brink I wander;
White overhead are the stars, and white
  The glimmering lamps on the hillside yonder. 

Silent are all the sounds of day;
  Nothing I hear but the chirp of crickets,
And the cry of the herons winging their way
  O'er the poet's house in the Elmwood thickets. 

Call to him, herons, as slowly you pass
  To your roosts in the haunts of the exiled thrushes,
Sing him the song of the green morass;
  And the tides that water the reeds and rushes. 

Sing him the mystical Song of the Hern,
  And the secret that baffles our utmost seeking;
For only a sound of lament we discern,
  And cannot interpret the words you are speaking. 

Sing of the air, and the wild delight
  Of wings that uplift and winds that uphold you,
The joy of freedom, the rapture of flight
  Through the drift of the floating mists that infold you. 

Of the landscape lying so far below,
  With its towns and rivers and desert places;
And the splendor of light above, and the glow
  Of the limitless, blue, ethereal spaces. 

Ask him if songs of the Troubadours,
  Or of Minnesingers in old black-letter,
Sound in his ears more sweet than yours,
  And if yours are not sweeter and wilder and better. 

Sing to him, say to him, here at his gate,
  Where the boughs of the stately elms are meeting,
Some one hath lingered to meditate,
  And send him unseen this friendly greeting; 

That many another hath done the same,
  Though not by a sound was the silence broken;
The surest pledge of a deathless name
  Is the silent homage of thoughts unspoken.

stops.significance: In "To the River Charles," published in Ballads and Other Poems, 1842, Longfellow directly addresses the river, which was part of the viewshed from his rooms at the Craigie house.  In the eighth stanza, he alludes to "three friends, all true and tried" who share the river's name. These friends are identified as Charles Sumner, Charles Folsom, and Charles Amory.
stops.audioTranscript:
To the River Charles

River! that in silence windest
Through the meadows, bright and free,
Till at length thy rest thou findest
In the bosom of the sea! 
Four long years of mingled feeling,
Half in rest, and half in strife,
I have seen thy waters stealing
Onward, like the stream of life. 
Thou hast taught me, Silent River!
  Many a lesson, deep and long;
Thou hast been a generous giver;
  I can give thee but a song. 
Oft in sadness and in illness,
  I have watched thy current glide,
Till the beauty of its stillness
  Overflowed me, like a tide. 
And in better hours and brighter,
  When I saw thy waters gleam,
I have felt my heart beat lighter,
  And leap onward with thy stream. 
Not for this alone I love thee,
  Nor because thy waves of blue
From celestial seas above thee
  Take their own celestial hue. 
Where yon shadowy woodlands hide thee,
  And thy waters disappear,
Friends I love have dwelt beside thee,
  And have made thy margin dear. 
More than this;--thy name reminds me
  Of three friends, all true and tried;
And that name, like magic, binds me
  Closer, closer to thy side. 
Friends my soul with joy remembers!
  How like quivering flames they start,
When I fan the living embers
  On the hearth-stone of my heart! 
'T is for this, thou Silent River!
  That my spirit leans to thee;
Thou hast been a generous giver,
  Take this idle song from me.

stops.significance: When Longfellow worked at Harvard, he would walk down the street and pass this house and adjacent blacksmith shop on his way to work. Here lived Dexter Pratt, the blacksmith who provided some of the inspiration for Longfellow's poem "The Village Blacksmith."
stops.audioTranscript:
The Village Blacksmith

Under a spreading chestnut-tree
The village smithy stands;
The smith, a mighty man is he,
With large and sinewy hands;
And the muscles of his brawny arms
Are strong as iron bands. 

His hair is crisp, and black, and long,
His face is like the tan;
His brow is wet with honest sweat,
He earns whate'er he can,
And looks the whole world in the face,
For he owes not any man. 

Week in, week out, from morn till night,
You can hear his bellows blow;
You can hear him swing his heavy sledge,
With measured beat and slow,
Like a sexton ringing the village bell,
When the evening sun is low. 

And children coming home from school
Look in at the open door;
They love to see the flaming forge,
And hear the bellows roar,
And catch the burning sparks that fly
Like chaff from a threshing-floor. 

He goes on Sunday to the church,
And sits among his boys;
He hears the parson pray and preach,
He hears his daughter's voice,
Singing in the village choir,
And it makes his heart rejoice. 

It sounds to him like her mother's voice,
Singing in Paradise!
He needs must think of her once more,
How in the grave she lies;
And with his hard, rough hand he wipes
A tear out of his eyes. 

Toiling,--rejoicing,--sorrowing,
Onward through life he goes;
Each morning sees some task begin,
Each evening sees it close
Something attempted, something done,
Has earned a night's repose. 

Thanks, thanks to thee, my worthy friend,
For the lesson thou hast taught!
Thus at the flaming forge of life
Our fortunes must be wrought;
Thus on its sounding anvil shaped
Each burning deed and thought.

stops.significance: "In the Churchyard at Cambridge," published in Birds of Passage, 1858; "The Burial of the Poet"
stops.audioTranscript:
"In the Churchyard at Cambridge"

In the village churchyard she lies,
Dust is in her beautiful eyes,
  No more she breathes, nor feels, nor stirs;
At her feet and at her head
Lies a slave to attend the dead,
  But their dust is white as hers. 

Was she a lady of high degree,
So much in love with the vanity
  And foolish pomp of this world of ours?
Or was it Christian charity,
And lowliness and humility,
  The richest and rarest of all dowers? 

Who shall tell us?  No one speaks;
No color shoots into those cheeks,
  Either of anger or of pride,
At the rude question we have asked;
Nor will the mystery be unmasked
  By those who are sleeping at her side. 

Hereafter?--And do you think to look
On the terrible pages of that Book
  To find her failings, faults, and errors?
Ah, you will then have other cares,
In your own short-comings and despairs,
  In your own secret sins and terrors!

stops.significance: Longfellow wrote "The Bridge," published in The Belfry of Bruges and Other Poems, 1845, about the current bridge's predecessor, the West Boston Bridge.  It was that wooden bridge that he often crossed on foot from his home in Cambridge to visit both his publisher and his unrequited love, Fanny Appleton.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Bridge

I stood on the bridge at midnight,
  As the clocks were striking the hour,
And the moon rose o'er the city,
  Behind the dark church-tower. 

I saw her bright reflection
  In the waters under me,
Like a golden goblet falling
  And sinking into the sea. 

And far in the hazy distance
  Of that lovely night in June,
The blaze of the flaming furnace
  Gleamed redder than the moon. 

Among the long, black rafters
  The wavering shadows lay,
And the current that came from the ocean
  Seemed to lift and bear them away; 

As, sweeping and eddying through them,
Rose the belated tide,
And, streaming into the moonlight,
  The seaweed floated wide. 

And like those waters rushing
  Among the wooden piers,
A flood of thoughts came o'er me
  That filled my eyes with tears. 

How often, oh, how often,
  In the days that had gone by,
I had stood on that bridge at midnight
  And gazed on that wave and sky! 

How often, oh, how often,
  I had wished that the ebbing tide
Would bear me away on its bosom
  O'er the ocean wild and wide! 

For my heart was hot and restless,
  And my life was full of care,
And the burden laid upon me
  Seemed greater than I could bear. 

But now it has fallen from me,
  It is buried in the sea;
And only the sorrow of others
  Throws its shadow over me. 

Yet whenever I cross the river
  On its bridge with wooden piers,
Like the odor of brine from the ocean
  Comes the thought of other years. 

And I think how many thousands
  Of care-encumbered men,
Each bearing his burden of sorrow,
  Have crossed the bridge since then. 

I see the long procession
  Still passing to and fro,
The young heart hot and restless,
  And the old subdued and slow! 

And forever and forever,
  As long as the river flows,
As long as the heart has passions,
  As long as life has woes; 

The moon and its broken reflection
  And its shadows shall appear,
As the symbol of love in heaven,
  And its wavering image here.

data.title: Point Park Walking Tour
data.description: Point Park, part of Lookout Mountain Battlefield, has six points of interested located inside. There is an entrance fee to Point Park.
tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

stops.assetName: Lookout Mountain Battlefield - Point Park Introduction
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk across the street to the large Army Corps of Engineer's entrance gate, shaped like a castle.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #1 - Entrance Gate
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk through the entrance gate. Please remember that Point Park is a fee area. Walker down the rock path to the large black cannon, slightly to the right.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #2 - Parrott Gun Overlook
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the steps to the paved carriage walk and turn left. Continue on this path until you reach the two bronze Napoleon cannon signifying Garrity's Alabama Battery.
Continue to your left, passing the path to the Ochs Museum on your right and Corput's Battery on your right. Stop at the large rock overlook on the western side of the mountain.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #4 - Western Overlook & Wauhatchie
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to your right and walk the few yards to the two bronze Napoleon cannon for Corput's Georgia Battery.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #5 - Corput's Battery
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to the Ochs Museum pathway on your left. Turn left and walk down the path to the "Y" intersection. Take the path to your left, which takes you to the Ochs Museum and Observatory.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #6 - Ochs Museum and Observatory
stops.directionsToNextStop: When leaving the Ochs Museum and Observatory, take the path to your right, which will take you opposite the route as you came down. You will make your way to the top of the stairs, back to the carriage walk. Walk to your left on the carriage walk to the large monument in the park's center, the New York Peace Monument.

stops.assetName: Point Park Tour Stop #7 - The New York Peace Monument
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to the exit by taking the path back to the paved carriage walk or by using the stone walkway back to the park entrance gate.
