images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour inside Point Park, part of Lookout Mountain Battlefield.

data.title: Political Education of Harry S Truman
data.description: Welcome to The Political Education of Harry Truman self-guided tour. The Independence Town Square is where Harry Truman began his political career. This tour focuses on his early political life when he was developing his skills and making political associations.

park.fullName: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
park.name: Harry S Truman

tags: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
harry s truman historic district national historic landmark

stops.significance: Bronze statue of Harry S Truman.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is Clinton's which is across the street on the corner of W Maple and N Main Street.
stops.audioTranscript: Right now, you ought to be standing in front of Harry Truman’s statue.  There’s nothing unusual about towns erecting statues to their favorite sons and Independence is no exception.  It usually happens after they’re dead.  Harry Truman said, “A statesman is a politician who’s been dead 10 or 15 years.”  It must be tough being a politician.  No matter what they do, somebody’s not going to like it.  With all the criticism they get, you’d think that, sooner or later, they must ask themselves if it’s really all worth it.  That question—Is it worth it? —is a question everyone has to ask themselves once in a while.  At what point to we realize a price is too high to pay in order to get something we want?  Whatever we gain comes at a price, whether it’s the price of a new car, or how much time we’re willing to commit to getting an education.  Or, sometimes, the question is about an exchange of personal standards for what we consider to be a greater good.  That’s a tricky one.   This is the question Harry Truman had to ask himself when he decided to get into politics.  The 1920s and ‘30s, when Truman got into the job, were a time when machine bosses-controlled politics in all large cities.  In Jackson County, which included both Independence and Kansas City, Boss Tom Pendergast ran the Democratic machine, and one had to be associated with his organization in order to be in politics at all.  Harry Truman needed to be able to work with a corrupt machine without being corrupted by it himself.  Anybody hoping to do that was going to have to be both politically astute and realistic about human nature.  Harry Truman seemed to be both, and he showed a willingness to work within certain parameters in order to accomplish what he considered to be a greater good.  It is possible that Harry Truman’s success was due to his ability to balance an idealistic nature with pragmatic common sense.  Whatever it was, Harry Truman received a political education here in Independence that, when combined with his temperament and personality, and the right circumstances, of course, was enough to get him to the White House.  Fortunately, for those who are interested, there is tangible evidence of that education still in existence.  Although the uses have changed, almost all the buildings where important events happened are still standing, and this tour will take you to some of them.  Let’s start with the place where Harry Truman had his first job, the first place he learned his first lesson about politics.  It’s right across the street on the corner of Maple and Main.

stops.significance: Harry Truman had his first job at Clinton's Drugstore.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go south on Main Street to the next stop on the corner of N Main St and E Lexington Ave.
stops.audioTranscript: This is Clinton’s Soda Fountain, at 100 West Maple Street.  Originally, this was Clinton’s Drugstore.  This is where Harry had his first job and it’s the place where he learned his first lesson about human nature.  This building is about growing up and wising up.  Harry worked here for a few months when he was about 14 years old. That would have been in 1898.  This is how Harry later described the place and his job:  My first paying job was opening up a drugstore in Independence for Mr. Jim Clinton at six-thirty in the morning, mopping the floors, sweeping the sidewalk, and having everything shipshape when Mr. Clinton came in.  When everything was in order, there were bottles to wipe off and shelves to dust.  There must have been a thousand bottles to dust and yards and yards of patent-medicine cases and shelves to clean.  At least it seemed that way, because I never finished the bottles and shelves by school time and had to start the next morning where I’d left off the day before.  By the time I got around them all, it was time to start over.  How I hated Latin-covered prescription bottles and patent-medicine shelves!  Now here’s the important part.  He wrote:  In a little closet under the prescription case, which faced the front and shut off the view of the back end of the store, was an assortment of whisky bottles.  Early in the morning, sometimes before Mr. Clinton arrived, the good church members and Anti-Saloon Leaguers would come in for their early-morning drink behind the prescription case at ten cents an ounce.  They would wipe their mouths, peep through the observation hole in the front of the case and depart.  This procedure gave a fourteen-year-old boy quite a viewpoint on the public front of leading citizens.  There were saloons aplenty around the square in Independence, and many leading men in town made no bones about going into them and buying a drink.  I learned to think more highly of them than I did of the prescription-counter drinkers. The lesson he learned:  Some people are not as honest as they would like you to think they are, but that doesn’t mean one has to be like them.  So, like most normal people, Truman gravitated towards friends who he believed shared his values and experiences.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman played poker in the Farmers and Merchants Bank Building.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take W Lexington Ave west, past the Courthouse, and turn right on N Liberty Street.  The next stop is at 204 N Liberty Street.
stops.audioTranscript: Politics is all about who you know, and the more people you know and the better they like you, the easier it is to succeed in politics.  This building at 101 North Main Street is the old Farmers and Merchants Bank Building.  And this building is all about who you know.  This is where the Harpie Club met.  The Harpie Club was Harry Truman’s poker playing club.  It was formed around 1924 by him and some of his friends.  Most of them were veterans of World War I.  There were usually about 16 to 18 members, and they played every Monday night.  Its name, the Harpie Club, had something to do with a harmonica playing contest and was called the Harmonica Club for a time. The name gradually changed into the Harpie Club partly because they found out that sometimes the harmonica is called a French Harp.  That may have been something they picked up on during the time they spent in France during World War I.  Anyway, the club met here in this building in a back room on the third floor.  These were good-natured poker games. Harry Truman really loved poker, but he didn’t seem to take the game too seriously.   And it doesn’t sound like he was much of a bluffer, either—he was a pretty straightforward guy.  One of his friends recalled. "You can tell when he's winning, because there's a kind of smile on his face."  These men, Truman’s friends, were prominent men in the community—business owners, public officials, government employees—and it was these friends that assisted Harry Truman in his political career.  So, Harry learned it’s good to have friends.  Before he settled completely into politics, though, Harry tried to be a businessman and chose friends of his for his business partners.  None of these business ventures worked out, but it wasn’t always his fault.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman was a part of a company called Community Savings and Loan and their main office was located here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk north on N Liberty Street and your next stop will be on the right at Trinity Episcopal Church of Independence.
stops.audioTranscript: Harry Truman wrote in his high school notebook that, to be successful in modern politics (this would have been in the late 1890s), a man must be loyal to his party, even if they are all thieves and saloon keepers.  Harry Truman was loyal to a fault, but the fact is that sometimes he was loyal to people who didn’t always deserve it.   This building, at 204 North Liberty Street, is where Harry Truman learned that, just because someone says they’re your friend, doesn’t always mean you can trust them.  And that was a hard lesson for him to learn.  In 1925, Harry Truman became involved in a company called Community Savings and Loan, the main office of which was located in this shop front.  He had two business partners, Spencer Salisbury and Arthur Metzger. Metzger was a member of the Harpie Club and Truman had known Salisbury in World War I.  His involvement with Salisbury was a sign that Harry was not always the best judge of character when it came to his friends.  Salisbury belonged to an old, well-to-do Independence family.  He was lively and talkative, but people also sometimes called him “a little slick.”  Lots of people called him “Snake-eye” Salisbury.  Even his own sister said he was “kind of a cold bird.”  Asked long afterward why Harry ever associated himself with the man, Edgar Hinde, another member of the Harpie Club replied, “Anybody who’s ever been a friend of his...they’ve got to hit him right in the face before he’ll drop them.”  It turned out that Salisbury was cheating Truman in the Savings and Loan business.  "My private business has gone to pot," Truman wrote.  "I'll be worse than a pauper when I'm done."  So, Harry got out, and he ended up making an enemy out of Salisbury.  Privately Truman wrote that Salisbury “used me for his own ends, robbed me, and laughed at me.  It nearly makes me a pessimist.”  And to top it all off, even though Truman never said anything publicly against Salisbury, Salisbury spoke critically of Truman both privately and in public.  So Truman was loyal, which was a good thing, because he would have to be loyal—and partisan—if he was going to make it with the Pendergast machine, but he also learned that loyalty had its risks.  The other thing he got from the Savings and Loan venture was a taste of what it’s like to have somebody talking bad about you.  Everybody hears rumors and stories about politicians.  Some are true and some aren’t, but the stories do get back to family members, and that had to bother Truman, because he didn’t want those, he cared about to be embarrassed by him in any way.  And there was no one he cared about more than his wife.  For this next stop, if you’re standing in front of the former Community Savings and Loan shop, look north on Liberty Street towards the Trinity Episcopal Church.  It’s 2 ½ blocks north on the east side of the street.  You can walk up there is you want, but you don’t have to, because you can see it from here.  If you look up there, you’ll notice a real tall, pointed steeple – that’s the Catholic Church.  The Episcopal Church is between you and the Catholic Church.  It’s a one-story church with the smaller steeple that has a little belfry tower at the peak.  See the water tower?  Look straight down from the water tower and you should see it.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman married Bess Wallace Truman at Trinity Episcopal Church of Independence.
stops.audioTranscript: The Trinity Episcopal Church was built back in 1881 and that’s where Harry and Bess got married in 1919.  This building is about trying to be the kind of person that you know you ought to be.  Here’s the situation:  Harry Truman was a decent man who wanted to stay that way, but who decided to get involved with politics, along with all its moral challenges and temptations.  To really understand Truman’s commitment to do the right thing, it’s really important to know how much he wanted to look good to Bess.  The best evidence for this is in the letters he wrote to her over the years.  These are some of the things he wrote to her.  I’m horribly anxious for you to suffer from an excessively good opinion of me! Since I can’t rescue you from any monster or carry you from a burning building or save you from a sinking ship – simply because I’d be afraid of the monsters, couldn’t carry you, and can’t swim – I’ll have to go to work and make money enough to pay my debts and then get you to take me for what I am; just a common everyday man whose instincts are to be ornery, who’s anxious to be right. I’ve wanted so badly to make good…so you and my sweet baby [Margaret] wouldn’t be ashamed of me. I’ve never cared for social position or rank for myself except to see that those dear to me were not made to suffer for my shortcomings. Harry Truman spent his life trying to be the type of man he thought his wife deserved.  Independence was a small town, and everyone knew each other.  And also, everybody knew what was going on over in Kansas City; people knew who Pendergast was and people knew the type of people who associated with Pendergast.  So, what Truman learned here was, if he was to retain his good reputation and not embarrass his family, and yet succeed in a career as a politician, he would have to walk a fine line.  And the place where that political career began is only a couple of blocks from here.

stops.significance: Mike Pendergast announced Harry S Truman as the candidate for Eastern District County Judge in the Slack Grocery building.
stops.audioTranscript: This is the old Slack Grocery Building at 211 West Lexington.  The part of the building we’re interested in is down at the far end, where the drug store is. Upstairs above the drug store.  This upstairs section was where the Rural Jackson County Democratic Club used to meet.  It was here, in this building, in early 1922, that Mike Pendergast, who was Boss Tom’s brother, introduced Harry Truman and announced that Truman was the organization’s candidate for Eastern District Jackson County Judge. This was the first time Harry Truman’s name was mentioned in connection with a political office.  It was also when Harry Truman first started learning about the inner workings of a political machine.  Here’s how all this happened:  In late 1921, Harry Truman was running a clothing store—a haberdashery—over in Kansas City, which wasn’t doing too well.  In fact, they were going out of business.  A fellow named Jim Pendergast, who was an army buddy of Harry’s and the nephew of Boss Tom, brought his father, Mike Pendergast, into the haberdashery and asked Truman if he would be interested in running for Eastern District County judge.  The way the county was set up at the time was there three judges, who were really commissioners rather than judges in the judicial sense.  There was a presiding judge who was elected at large, and then there was an eastern district and a western district judge, each elected from their part of the county.  Tom Pendergast had control of the western part of the county, and he already had his men in place as the presiding judge and the western district judge.  But Tom didn’t control the whole county.  That’s because the Democratic party was split into two factions.  Tom ran the western faction, but the eastern faction was run by a guy named Joe Shannon, and Pendergast usually had to share the political spoils with him.  So, it’d be a real coup for Boss Tom to get a Pendergast man in office as the Eastern District judge, too, since that would give Pendergast control of the whole county.  The problem was these judges held a lot of power and once in a while, after they were in office, they’d try to take over Pendergast’s operation.  So, Pendergast needed a man who was a) from the east part of the county, b) who could be elected honestly (which was always easier than trying to rig the election), and c) who would be loyal to the machine after he was in office.  Harry Truman was perfect for the job.   Plus, Harry was a war hero, he had been a farmer so folks in the rural part of the county knew and liked him, he came from a good family and his father had been friends with Mike Pendergast…, and Harry needed a job anyway since the haberdashery was going out of business.  So, everybody got something out of this.  And it all started right here, upstairs at 211 West Maple Street.  After his nomination, he still had to campaign to get elected.  He set up campaign headquarters about a block to the east, right up Maple Street.  The address, though, 111 West Maple Street, is a little hard to find.  It would be between 109 and 113 West Maple.  Walk on up there and see what you find.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman had his 1922 campaign headquarters for Eastern District County Judge here.
stops.audioTranscript: If you’re in the right place, you’re looking at an empty lot.  Out of all the buildings related to Truman’s early political years, this is the only one that’s gone now.  This vacant lot is where Truman's headquarters was during his 1922 campaign for eastern district judge.  This would have been the first political campaign he ever ran.  The building was torn down around 1973, and it’s really too bad, too, because this is where Harry Truman started on the path that led him to the White House.  Edgar Hinde, a member of the Harpie Club and later postmaster of Independence, recalled Harry Truman coming to him one day with kind of a little grin on his face, asking what Hinde would think if Truman decided to run for county judge.  Hinde told him he would think he was crazy.  “Well,” Truman responded, “I got to eat.”  See, Edgar Hinde knew what politics were like in Jackson County.  When Harry got involved in politics, he was worried about his reputation, but there was a lot more than his reputation in danger sometimes.  Politics in Kansas City during the 1920s could be a violent business.  Out in Independence, things weren’t so bad, but Kansas City was rough.  We’re talking about things like unlicensed cars filled with armed thugs cruising the streets looking for opposition targets.  One election day, a pack of hoodlums jumped an opposition candidate for city council, and his bodyguard, and a Kansas City Star reporter, and they beat all of them up.  The reporter got away and there was a big car chase all the way back to the front door of the newspaper building.  Another gang came in a voting place, apparently looking to beat up one of the election judges; another judge whipped out a revolver, so they shot and killed him instead.  Other thugs set out to kill a deputy sheriff who was on the other side.  There was a shootout, the deputy and one of the mobsters were mortally wounded, and an innocent bystander was killed instantly.  And, even though most of this was going on in over in Kansas City, Harry Truman and his family were sometimes personally in danger, too.  For example, when Margaret was in first grade, there was a kidnapping attempt on her.  The next day was election day, and Harry had Margaret and Bess locked up in a hotel room over in Kansas City with a couple of armed guards at the door.  In 1933, Harry wrote to Bess, “Please be careful about eating anything that comes in the mail.”  Not really sure what that was all about, but it sounds like he was worried someone might try to poison them.  This was a dangerous time to be in politics, and Truman knew that when he went into it.  But professionally, he had finally found his niche.  He found the kind of job that he was really good at.  He was 38 years old.  He didn’t know it then, but he was going to end up doing this for the rest of his life.  This kind of stuff was just the price that he had to pay.  Once he was elected, he moved into an office in the county courthouse.  Walk across the street to the south entrance door.  That’s the one directly across the street that’s facing Lexington Street.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman began his political career at the courthouse as a county judge.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go inside the courthouse, turn right and walk down the hallway, your next stop at Harry Truman's office will be on the right.
stops.audioTranscript: Take a look at the plaque to the right of the courthouse entrance. You can see the names of all the county judge's names who were in office every time the courthouse was remodeled. There’s been seven county courthouses in Independence, the last six of which have stood on this site.  But this one you’re standing in front of now, this is the building where Harry Truman’s political education was first put to practical use. He ended up serving ten years on the county court, two of them as the Eastern District Judge, and eight of them as the Presiding Judge. Doctor Andrew Dunar, in his book The Truman Scandals, talks about three main political lessons Truman learned during that time. Number one: Truman came to recognize corruption and he learned to dealt with it in a way that left him his reputation. But he also came to understand that there would always be people who would seek public positions for private gain. For instance, there was a guy named Barr, who Truman picked for eastern judge, only to find out Barr was no good.  Here’s what Truman wrote about Barr:“I picked a West Pointer, a son of an honorable father, a man who should have had Washington, Lee, Jackson, Gustavus Adolphus, for his ideals, to associate with me in carrying out a program and I got—a dud, a weakling, no ideals, no nothing. He’s use his office for his own enrichment, he’s not true to his wife (and a man not honorable in his marital relations is not usually honorable in any other). He’d sell me or anyone else he’s associated with out for his own gain.” Yet Truman also believed that one could survive in the midst of corruption, and sometimes, even stop some of it. So, Lesson number two: Truman learned to avoid corruption by working around people who were responsible for it. For instance, he was able to work around the other two judges on the court. He remembered, “When I wanted something done, I’d let Barr and Vrooman start a crap game and then introduce a long and technical order. Neither of them would have time to read it and over it would go. I got a lot of good legislation for Jackson Co. over while they shot craps. Both of them thought that public office is a means of personal enrichment.”And Lesson number three: Truman learned the need to take issues to the people, who would vindicate an honest and well-reasoned position even if ran counter to conventional political wisdom. For instance, when he sought a bond issue for the roads project, he recalled, “Pendergast told me that a county bond issue would not carry.  I told him that if I told the voters how I would handle it, it would carry. I went to the people…and [the] bond issue carried by a three-fourths majority instead of the required two-thirds.”  Now, just because Harry learned these things didn’t mean he always applied these lessons well, but he still seemed to get ahead.  And the office Truman used as county judge is still in this building and is open to the public if you’re interested.  Right outside his office door is the next stop on your cell phone tour. To get to his office, go through the courthouse doors here to the cross hall and turn right (that’d be East). His office is all the way down at the end of the hall.  If his office is open when you’re here, you can go in.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman began his political career at the courthouse as a county judge.
stops.assetName: Historic Truman Courthouse - Harry Truman's office
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go back to the courthouse entrance and stand right inside the door for your next stop.
stops.audioTranscript: This is the office where Harry Truman had to make those hard decisions about paying the price. Overall, Truman gave Pendergast an honest county administration that allowed Pendergast to solidify machine control over rural Jackson County, and thereby, all of Jackson County. Pendergast in return gave Truman a lot of freedom to do what he wanted—and the assistance of the machine’s electoral power. Truman, then also gave Pendergast patronage, but not graft—or at least, not much. There was at least one time, however, that Truman forced to compromise. He wrote out his frustrations about it in kind of a diary-like memo to himself at the time. In part, he wrote, “I had to compromise in order to get the voted road system carried out.  I had to let a former saloonkeeper and murderer, a friend of the Boss’s, steal about $10,000 from the general revenues of the county to keep the crooks from getting a million or more out of the bond issue.  Was I right or did I compound a felony?  Anyway, I’ve got the $6,500,000 worth of roads on the ground and at a figure that makes the crooks tear their hair. Am I an administrator or not? Or am I just a crook to compromise in order to get the job done?” He wondered is he might be better off to just quit and run a gas station. He wrote, “All this gives me headaches….” He suffered from headaches and stomach trouble, apparently brought on by the stress of trying to adapt to a system with which he was not in full agreement.  He was willing to accept the “lesser evil” argument that sanctioned certain activities in order to keep the party in power, but it wasn’t easy for him. And it appears that Truman’s honesty eventually wore Pendergast’s patience kind of thin. It looks like Pendergast might have been ready to move Truman out when his terms as county judge were over. Pendergast didn’t seem to be too interested in getting Truman another job. It appears the only reason Truman was picked to run for the United States Senate is because Pendergast couldn’t find anyone else. Truman was his second or third choice; all the other guys had turned him down. Like all politicians, Truman had been criticized in the local press, but now that his power was potentially national in scope, he really learned how rough the press could be. For instance, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch ran a cartoon that showed Truman as Edgar Bergen’s dummy Charlie McCarthy seated on the lap of Boss Pendergast. The caption read “Charlie McTruman does his stuff.” Another one said that Truman’s nomination for Senator would bring “shrill rejoicing among all the forces of evil in Missouri.” Truman learned to take it in stride, though. He said, “I don’t let these things bother me for the simple reason I know that I am trying to do the right thing, and eventually the facts will come out.” And I think it’s possible to point to the one moment, the one instance, that was probably more satisfying to him, professionally, than any other moment of his life. You can stand exactly where he stood when that moment happened. Try this:  Go back to the south entrance of the courthouse – that’s the door you came in – and stand right inside the door – don’t exit the building yet – just stand right inside the door.

stops.significance: Harry S Truman began his political career at the courthouse as a county judge.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the courthouse and turn left on the sidewalk and follow it around to your last stop at the Truman statue.
stops.audioTranscript: Now, you should be standing right inside the south door of the courthouse. You’re standing where Harry Truman stood in the evening on November 3, 1948. Pretend you’re Harry Truman and see how this feels. This is about victory and vindication. Here’s what’s going on: Today was election day and you were just reelected president in your own right.  Pendergast is dead by now, the machine’s extinct, nobody can say you were elected due to the workings of somebody else’s machine.  Earlier today here in Independence, just a minutes after 10:14 am (that’s when Thomas Dewey conceded the election), every bell, whistle, siren, car horn, seemed to go off at once. It seems nobody planned any kind of celebration, but Mayor Roger Sermon [of the Harpie Club] quickly declared a holiday.  Schools were let out and an impromptu parade started up, going around and around the courthouse square. And now, it’s in the evening, and forty thousand people have jammed the Square to see you, and they’re waiting for you to step out of this door. Now this may sound silly, but nobody knows what you’re doing, so try this. When I say go, step out the south door and picture what Harry Truman saw that night and see if you don’t feel some kind of thrill. When you step out there, picture forty thousand people outside. This is the biggest crowd in the history of the town at this point. All far as you can see, there’s people. They’re at every window, they’re all over the rooftops. These are your friends, your relatives, your teachers. These are the people of Independence, and they like you!  And the second they see you; they are going to roar! Get ready to step out the door and imagine what it must have been like that night for Harry Truman.  When you’re done basking in the praise of your imaginary crowd, walk on back down to the Truman statue and we’ll wrap this up. Ready? They’re waiting for you. Go get ‘em!

stops.significance: Bronze statue of Harry S Truman at the Historic Truman Courthouse.
stops.audioTranscript: Did you feel it back there?  It must have felt good to Harry Truman that night. Despite all the headaches and stomach aches, all the worries about his reputation and all the worries about his family – all the difficulties involved in maintaining political decency – his remaining true to himself and his standards paid off. The city of Independence erected this statue of Mr. Truman in 1976, right across the street from where he had his first job at Clinton’s. President Gerald Ford dedicated the statue.  He said he was Harry Truman’s “No. 1 fan.”Just goes to show how Truman’s reputation had transcended political boundaries. All kinds of political leaders who want to identify themselves with President Truman use this courthouse and statue as a backdrop. Lots American presidents have given speeches on the courthouse steps over the years, and it serves as kind of a focal point for visiting dignitaries and office-seekers. When it came to knowing how to balance out the cost and the gain of politics, Harry Truman, apparently, did okay. Tom Pendergast was convicted and sentenced to Leavenworth in 1939. But, despite his association with Pendergast, though, Truman wasn’t found guilty of anything.  And it’s not as if there wasn’t anybody looking for evidence against him, either. But even Maurice Milligan, the United States attorney who got the conviction for Pendergast said, “At no time did the finger of suspicion ever point in the direction of Senator Truman.”  In 1952, near the end of his 30-year career as a politician, Harry Truman wrote – and this pretty much sums the whole thing up – “Politics force men into contacts with all manner of people, but men of principle need never surrender them in order to gain or to hold political office.” It’s easy for Americans to be cynical about politics sometimes, but here on the town square in Independence, Missouri, is this collection of buildings that remind us that it is possible to wield enormous political power and still not be corrupted by it. Thanks for taking the tour. We hope you enjoyed it. Be careful, and good bye.

data.title: Port Oneida Rural Historic District
data.description: The rolling hills and idyllic landscape of Port Oneida have remained relatively unchanged since the turn of the 20th century. Most of the houses appear much as they did in the last century with only minor changes or “modernization.” Through this well-preserved rural landscape, we can catch glimpses of a rural community’s hard work and struggle to farm the land and provide for and raise their families. These historic properties are being preserved by Lakeshore and its partner Preserve Historic Sleeping Bear.

stops.audioTranscript:
The farmwife’s stove “fired the central glow of life of the family, and her kitchen was the single most important place on the farm.” In her kitchen, the farmwife cooked, canned, washed, cleaned, sewed, and mended, and looked after all the needs of the children. Around her kitchen table, the farmer’s hopes and fears for the future were discussed, meals were served, and children did their schoolwork. 

The woman of the farm kept gardens, raised chickens, gathered eggs, and tended bees. She carried out dozens of household chores without plumbing or electricity. She had a number of simple machines to help her, but every one of them had a lever or a crank or a treadle that she had to activate with her own power. 

Hattie Olsen was one of the luckier wives. The house before you was one of the most modern and the first to have indoor plumbing. But even this modern convenience required manual labor: the Olsens had to pump water by hand into a tank in the attic to create the water pressure needed for the system. 

Charles and Hattie Olsen bought this farm from Fred Dechow in 1915; the house was built around 1918-19. This farm was one of the first Port Oneida farms designated a Class A dairy operation, and the Olsens were the first family to own a tractor. The Olsens also raised grain crops including wheat, oats, and corn, as well as green hay, potatoes and apples.

The reds, pinks, and purples of the gardens and flowers you see around the farmhouse evoke Hattie Olsen’s care, hard work and love of beauty. 

The Olsen barn is one of the largest and best barns in Port Oneida. It is a hillside barn: the lower level was for livestock and the upper level for hay storage. 

You’re welcome to tour the Olsen house and visit the Port Oneida Farms Heritage Center to learn more about Charles and Hattie Olsen’s family and farm.

From 1890 until World War II, Port Oneida was a closely-knit farming community. Early settlement in the area by German and Bohemian settlers helped create a strong and cohesive community—many of farms remained in the possession of the same families.

As Jack Barratt, a lifelong resident put it, “When you grow up in a community where everybody’s connected to somebody else, everybody takes care of everybody else.”

The cooperative nature of farming strengthened these community bonds:  jobs like filling silos, buzzing wood, and thrashing grains required many hands. Farmers came together to form crews that moved from farm to farm. According to Jack Barratt, when it came time to fill the silos, “You’d usually have four or five guys in the field cutting corn and loading the wagons, and you’d have two, three wagons—like Charlie Olsen would bring his two teams and wagons to Burfiends, and maybe we would put a team and wagon over there…If you had any kids around, you’d bring them too, to cut corn. . .[and] The women got to work too—cooking. 

This crossroads where the schoolhouse stands was the center of the Port Oneida community. A church stood here along with the schoolhouse and the cemetery across the road.  A grocery store, telephone exchange, and post office was set up in the Kelderhouse home across the road. 

The Port Oneida School was built in the 1890s. All of the children who grew up in Port Oneida attended school here. The school closed its doors in 1940 and is now owned and maintained by the Glen Lake Community School District so that today’s students can learn about local history and historical preservation.

The farmer had to do the work of dozens of specialists. He was a nurseryman, veterinarian, carpenter, mechanic, blacksmith, plumber, roofer, painter, hunter, trapper, butcher, leather crafter, teacher, cowboy, teamster, engineer, business manager, accountant, and entrepreneur. The most successful entrepreneur in Port Oneida, and Port Oneida’s most famous citizen, was Thomas Kelderhouse.

Thomas P. Kelderhouse arrived in the area in the early 1860s. He purchased the land that became the town of Port Oneida, built a dock, sold cordwood, built a sawmill, built a gristmill, and harvested elderberries from his inland swamp.

Thomas Kelderhouse became one of the prominent businessmen in Leelanau County. He owned more than half of the land north of the Crystal River in Glen Arbor Township, and parts of adjoining Cleveland Township. The Kelderhouse farm was second in size only to that of the Northern Transit Company farm at Glen Haven. Devoted primarily to general agriculture, Kelderhouse’s farm was productive and profitable.

The parcel of land you are standing on now was in the hands of the Kelderhouse family from 1863 until its acquisition by the National Park Service in 1970. In the late 1880s, Thomas’s son William built a log cabin here, and in 1910, the farmhouse. This 65-acre farm was a central gathering place for Port Oneida residents. The house has an arts and crafts interior with some extra decorative touches. It was used as a grocery store, telephone exchange, and post office—all run by William’s wife, Charlotte. 

The sugar maple trees surrounding the house were planted by students from the school across the street. The Kelderhouses tapped the trees to make maple syrup. 

Apple trees with heritage variety apples were planted by Rolland Kelderhouse around the early 1920’s. A remnant orchard of apple trees is currently being restored. You can see, near the house, a fenced-in tree nursery of about 250 heritage apple trees, representing about 30 varieties including Cortland, Russet, Wagener, Ben Davis, Wolf River, Rhode Island Greening, Champion, and Spy. There is also a pear tree between the house and the nearby cemetery.

The principle crops of the Port Oneida area included wheat, corn, oats, barley, buckwheat, vegetables, and potatoes. Although the land provided most farm families with an adequate income, farming in the area was not easy. The price of the main cash crop—potatoes—fluctuated continuously, providing both good and bad income years. The lakeshore’s sandy soils, good for potatoes, became easily exhausted after a few seasons of growing grains and other crops, often resulting in lowered yields when farmers used improper agricultural methods. 

This farm—Frederick and Fredericka Dechow’s farm—had some of the best soil in Port Oneida and was one of the most productive farms. The Dechows purchased the farm in 1857 and built a log cabin. Their sons, John and Charles, built the barn around 1890. Grandson Frank Dechow built the new house—a showplace of modern style—about 1910. A few years later, he was able to add to his farm by purchasing the neighboring land. The Dechows raised apples and dairy cows, and sold milk, cream, and eggs to local resorts.  Standing in the shade of the old oak, you can look out toward the pasture barn and imagine the beautiful orchards that lined the path. 

This farm is a good example of a working farm of the late 1940s where old structures were adapted for new methods. The concrete silo and milking parlor indicate a commitment to dairy production. The large granary building and the small corncrib are typical for farms this far north. These farmers grew less corn because of the short growing season. A large chicken coop for raising fryers for market and another coop for a laying flock round out the barn yard buildings.


The farms of the Port Oneida area are typical of turn of the century farms throughout the Midwest. It is rare, however, to find such a large collection of older farms that are free from modern development. This historic district brings alive the land use practices, architecture and evolution of agricultural technology common to subsistence farms of the upper Great Lakes region. Port Oneida was farmed for over 100 years; the houses and fields passed down from generation to generation, and now, through its preservation by the National Park Service to us.

data.title: Presidio Bronze Cannon Tour
data.description: Discover some hidden history! Explore the bronze cannon that now decorate this park. Learn about the creation of the Spanish Presidio and the American expansion during and after the Spanish American War. Investigate old technology through the description and locations of various emblems and markings found on these intricate weapons. Examine and question their necessity by understanding why and how they are here.

data.title: Presidio: Batteries to Bluffs
data.description: This walking tour starts in the Langdon Court parking lot. It's an approximately 1.5 mile loop with varied elevation that will take you along a beautiful scenic trail highlighting historical and natural points of interest. Watch your footing along the cliff and be mindful of poison oak. There are no bathrooms or water stations along the trail.

stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Golden Gate Overlook, follow the trail north (towards the Golden Gate Bridge) to reach Battery Boutelle.
Follow the trail along the front of Battery Godfrey, stop at the northern end of the battery.
Continue south along the trail until you reach the Godfrey Overlook.
Continue down the Batteries to Bluffs trail, about 100ft. to Battery West.

stops.assetName: Battery West: A Response To Rifled Guns
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue about 0.1 miles along the trail, and stop on the 3rd set of steps for the next stop.
Continue about 400ft on the trail until you reach an overlook on the right.
Continue about 0.2 miles down the trail until you reach a side trail on the right towards Marshall's Beach. Follow the trail until you reach the top of the steps down to the beach.
Return to the main trail and continue south about 300ft for the next stop.

stops.assetName: Willow Grove: Home to Song and Water Birds
stops.directionsToNextStop: Staying here, turn towards the ocean and go to the next stop.
Continue to follow the trail as it bends to the left and reach Battery Crosby.

stops.assetName: Dune Habitat: A Once Common, Now Rare Commodity
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leave Battery Crosby and continue south on the Batteries to Bluffs Trail, when the trail starts to bend to the right, go to the next stop. When you get to the intersection, look to the right up the hill, towards a large memorial.

stops.assetName: West Coast World War II Memorial: Losses Remembered
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the Coastal Trail. The next stop is just past the overlook, stop as the trail starts to go into the trees and look across Lincoln Blvd. towards Battery Dynamite.
Continue along the trail until just before the parking lot. Look across Lincoln Blvd towards the Mission style buildings. That next stop, Fort Scott.
This concludes the tour. To return to the beginning, turn left into the parking lot and find the Golden Gate Overlook.

data.description: One of the features that went into the design of the 1880s historic Pullman town was that everything you needed was within walking distance. You can explore everything the Historical Park has to offer on foot.

data.title: Prospects of Peace 1864: The Last Civil War Yuletide
data.description: Follow this 8-stop self-guided tour for a unique window into the Harpers Ferry’s last Civil War yuletide in 1864. Peak into windows to glimpse War and Christmas side-by-side. See how the indomitable human spirit may find a silver lining in any cloud, even in the clouds of war. Sidewalks along the tour are uneven. Buildings on the tour are open daily 9-5.

stops.significance: Look inside the Provost Marshal’s office. As an occupying force in 1864, the United States Army regulated the lives of townspeople, regardless of their loyalties. The Provost Marshal (whose office is recreated here) was charged with the mission of keeping the rear of Union General Sheridan’s army secure while Sheridan fought a victorious campaign to clean Confederate forces out of the Shenandoah Valley.  During December of 1864, the last Civil War time Yuletide, the Christmas spirit is tempered by concern for the safety of loved ones far from home and employed in harm’s way. Hopes and prayers are that Santa Claus will visit every home, but that a notice of sad tidings from the battlefield will not. The country was torn apart by war, but families remained hopeful of reunion with their loved ones. The spirit of Christmas, of hope, charity, and joy, are muted this holiday season, overshadowed by the clouds of war and an occupying army in the field.
stops.assetName: Provost Marshal, Chief of Military Police
stops.directionsToNextStop: How were Santa and Christmas celebrated in 1864? Let’s go shopping! Exit the Provost Marshal’s office and go next door to the Dry Goods Store window.

stops.significance:
Peer through the window to see children’s toys, simple mid-nineteenth century gifts during the Civil War.  By the winter of 1864, the average shopper would have been a person of color. Prior to the Civil War, citizens earned from 50 cents to over 2 dollars a day. But inflated prices during the war made almost all the Yuletide toys, games, and coveted Yuletide gifts displayed in the store window very expensive. Harpers Ferry was under Union control, and the town had become a magnet for refugees from slavery and freemen who sought the safety of the United States troops that garrisoned the town.  

Not for sale were Christmas wishes for peace, freedom, and charity; their price tag was war and casualties.  Union shipping blockades produced lean southern Yuletides, explained to southern children as “the Yankees stole Santa Claus.”
stops.assetName: Prospects of Peace 1864 Tour: Dry Goods Store
stops.directionsToNextStop: Who was in charge of this military district and how much authority did they have? Leave the Dry Goods Store and turn right. Walk down the block and look for the sign, “Master Armorer’s House.”

stops.significance: Stand in front of the Master Armorer’s house and imagine General Stevenson’s US Military Headquarters at Harpers Ferry, located in this building in 1864. Even during Yuletide, the army delt out severe punishments. On December 2nd, 1864--the 5th anniversary of Abolitionist John Brown’s execution--William Loge, a deserter from the Union Army and known rebel guerilla, was executed at Harpers Ferry. Read the messages exchanged between General Stevenson and Major General Philip Sheridan on the capture and punishment of Loge. “Dec 1, 1864 To Maj Gen Sheridan: I caught yesterday French Bill, a notorious murderer and bushwhacker belonging to White’s battalion, who was with the party that murdered the surgeon of the 6th Pa Cav.  He is a deserter from 61st NY infantry.” To “Brig Gen John Stevenson Dec 1st 1864 : As soon as you have fully ascertained that you have French Bill as your prisoner take him out and hang him.  This will be your authority.”
stops.directionsToNextStop: All armies travel on their stomachs. How was all that food made and delivered? Exit the Master Armorer’s house and follow the sidewalk to the large arsenal.

stops.significance:
The sidewalk leads to the ruins of the large arsenal, bordered by gray stones and filled in the center with mulch. The ruins before you, are those of the former United States Armory called arsenals. Prior to the Civil War, they had the capacity to store approximately 100,000 finished rifles and muskets for national defense. At the outbreak of the Civil War, these structures were set on fire by the United States government to prevent the weapons from falling into the possession of secessionists.   
 
Armies travel on their stomachs. But how was it accomplished during 1864 for Sheridan’s army? By the fall and winter of 1864, the large arsenal was repurposed to bake fresh bread for Sheridan’s army.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The only building left of the US Armory is across the lawn. Follow the sidewalk to John Brown’s Fort. What happened there, and did its meaning change during the war?

stops.significance:
This small red brick building is where John Brown, the abolitionist, and his raiders staged their 1859 ill-fated war on slavery at the US Armory. In the winter of 1864, John Brown’s Fort, as it was then known, contained disloyal prisoners or soldiers of the Confederate army. 

This fire engine house was where Brown was captured by US Marines when he attacked the gun factory. Brown stood trial in Jefferson County, in Charles Town. He was convicted of inciting slaves to revolt, which the Commonwealth considered an automatic death sentence.  Brown was executed on Dec 2nd, 1859. He left his prophesy about the future of slavery on a scrap of paper inside his jail cell: “I John Brown, am now quite certain, that the crimes of this guilty land will never be purged away, but with blood, I had as I now think, vainly flattered myself that without much bloodshed, it might be done.” His raid hastened the Civil War by fueling the flames on the issue of enslavement. Many say the first shot of the Civil War was fired here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This building, the fort, was originally across the street from where it stands. To see where it stood in 1864, walk toward the street and stop at the sidewalk next to the wayside titled “A Nation’s Armory.” Look up and to the right, to the obelisk on top of the berm. This marks the original location of John Brown’s Fort.

stops.significance:
In December 1864, as far as the eye could see up Potomac Street, the US Quartermaster operation stretched up the entire right side of Potomac Street and covered six acres of what was the US Armory. 

Quartermaster Capt Flagg was responsible for everything that General Sheridan’s army required in the 1864 Valley Campaign, from food to weapons, was stored and moved from Harpers Ferry to the front. As Sheridan's Army proceeded southward into the Shenandoah Valley, his supplies were transported from Harpers Ferry by means of great wagon trains, numbering sometimes 1,000 wagons, that were escorted by several thousand soldiers. The wagon trains stretched for miles: the first wagon could reach its destination in Winchester, VA (29 miles from here) as the last wagon in the train exited the armory gates in front of you on Shenandoah street. Troops and supplies steadily poured south from the Ferry by rail and wagon train. Over 60,000 federal soldiers and all their gear passed into the Shenandoah Valley.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Who in the town also provided aid and comfort for the people’s army? Proceed up Potomac Street to White Hall Tavern.

stops.significance:
Look inside White Hall Tavern. During the Civil War, Civilian run organizations like the United States Christian Commission (USCC) provided charity and comfort to soldiers spending another Christmas far from home.  

In 1864, The Roeder Kerns family offered these structures to the United States Christian Commission to store their supplies. The USCC, a descendant of the Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA), ministered to both the souls and bodies of Union soldiers during the war. Formed in November of 1861, this organization attained widespread support among religious, business, and political leaders.  

During the war, the USCC sent over 5,000 delegates into hospitals, garrisons and battlefields to both preach and provide comfort articles and hospital stores.  In the permanent camps, free reading rooms were established. Writing materials, and postage, stamps were furnished to the soldiers, and the agents urged the men to both write and send a considerable part of their pay home.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk to High Street. Look for the ”Confectionery“ sign on the building at the corner of High St. and Hogg Alley.

stops.significance:
Stop by the porch of the Roeder family’s home and confectionery, and imagine the delicious aroma of Christmas cakes, candies, and cookies. During the park’s Christmas 1864 presentation, the Roeder’s home is shown with a favorite Yuletide decoration: a Christmas tree. Embraced by many German families like the Roeders, not many other homes in Harpers Ferry would have had a tree. All through the Civil War years, this Harpers Ferry family was unusual in their support for Abraham Lincoln and his government.  

Prior to the war, Frederick Roeder ran this confectionery that supported his large and growing family. Not just a business, this building was also home to Roeder, his wife, and their seven children. Shortly before the war, Mrs. Maria Roeder died of a disease. Mr. Roeder and his children ran both the house and business. Unfortunately, Mr. Roeder’s death at the start of the Civil War left his children orphans who had to learn to fend for themselves.
stops.directionsToNextStop: End tour

images.credit: Sketch by war-time artist Alfred Waud

data.title: Puzzle Discovery Adventure
data.description: Perfect for families exploring the fort with little ones or aspiring Junior Rangers! This special tour has questions and riddles to help them learn more about the history. Start your adventure in the fort by visiting each of the fort’s rooms and reading the information signs at each spot. These signs will provide answers to each of the quest questions. When you’ve answered each of the fort questions, your adventure takes you outside of the fort to other interesting places nearby.

stops.audioTranscript: Thanks for taking part in the Ft. Stanwix Discovery Adventure! Start your adventure in the fort by visiting each of the fort’s rooms and reading the information signs at each spot.  These signs will provide answers to each of the quest questions. When you’ve answered each of the fort questions, your adventure takes you outside of the fort to other interesting places nearby. A map has been provided to assist with your adventure. If you need help, just ask a Ranger.

As you enter the fort, to this officer you must report. For only he will know if you may stay or if you must go. If his confidence you cannot gain, his guards may say that you must remain....in chains.

Where are you? 

What is attached to the log stump?

They knew their jobs and they did them right. They worked by day, and they worked by night. From carpenters to blacksmith and all jobs in between, the results of their labor, all around can be seen.

Where are you?

What item do you see here?

This man worked hand-in-hand, with the wolf, bear, and turtle clan. Along with the people of the standing stone (the Oneida Indian Nation) he also called this land his home.

Where are you?

What was this man’s job at the fort?

The blankets, food, and other supplies are stored oh so high. They almost reach to the sky! The selection is quite grand. Stopping here should be part of your plan.

Where are you?

What items do you see?

After the mighty cannons cease their fearful roar, the tired men who work with them come here to snore.

Where are you?

What round items can you see on the floor by the back wall?

Oh, woe is me, from our house we must flee. Mother, father, sister, and baby brother, our room is so small, it appears we haven’t enough space for us all.

Where are you?

Who used this room?

Quite the brave man, he was placed in command. Tall and slender, he refused to surrender. His far-reaching plan, to defend this fort to the last man.

Where are you?

Who was that brave man?

In here, the head men do meet.  The room itself was orderly and neat! The fort’s business at hand, was completed by their command.

Where are you?

Who used this space?

My teeth are bad, and I feel really sad. My feet are aching, and my bones may be breaking. I hope this guy doesn't think I'm faking!

Where are you?

Who are you visiting?

It flutters on high, red, white, and blue against the sky.

Where are you?

What flutters?

(Now leave the fort and proceed north on James Street. Venture past St. Peter’s Church to Gansevoort Park for your next series of clues.)

As you round the corner past the church….BEHOLD!  Not far from here the British trenches grew near. Check out this spot and you will learn a lot. (hint…Look for a small stone monument in Gansevoort Park.)

What happened here?

What did the British bring to this spot (hint – BOOM)?

Now turn around and look at the statue in the park.
Who is this tall man, who looks to be so grand?

Have you met him before during you travels?

Follow his gaze to the west and upon the flags your eyes will rest. Go see what awaits you there in your ongoing quest. (Carefully cross James Street.)

With great esteem we remember this patriotic team - the Army, Navy, Air Force, Coast Guard, Marine Corps, and Merchant Marines.

Where are you?

stops.assetName: Tomb of the Unknown Revolutionary War Soldiers
stops.audioTranscript:
Now turn south and walk past the red stone building on your route. 

There you will find the monument of the heroes with no names.

What is the name of this monument?

Who are the heroes you find here?

Before you return to the fort, there’s one more challenge. Proceed south on James Street until you reach W. Dominic St. Turn right and proceed a few blocks until you find the last item in this Discovery Walk.

The “Great Carry” it was called, by one, and by all. Between the Mohawk and Wood Creek, a glorious bronze statue you shall seek. (Hint- look for the standing man.)

Where are you?

Who does this statue honor?
Your quest is now done and we hope you had fun. So return to the fort, and to a Ranger please report.
