data.title: Quick, Basic, & After Hours
data.description: A short walking tour acquaints you with the historic site's main features. This is good tour to take if you arrive after the visitor center, museum, and historic buildings close.

stops.significance: On August 12, 1965, an act of Congress established this park as a national historic site. Since then, the National Park Service has preserved and interpreted the historic structures and landscape of this 187-acre park. In the late 1930's, President Hoover and his wife, Lou Henry Hoover, chose this place to celebrate the values they believed helped shape his life.
stops.directionsToNextStop: A plank walkway begins about 25 feet to your left as you face the map panel of the information kiosk. Follow it about 110 feet to the intersection with the next plank walkway, and then left about 12 feet to the exhibit panel facing the birthplace.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you were going to make a park to commemorate yourself, what would you like future generations to know? What values would you share? Which mementos would be on display? And how many stories would there be to tell?
Herbert Hoover National Historic Site includes many features of Hoover's boyhood landscape that have endured over time and give the site its unique identity as a Presidential birthplace, boyhood home, and memorial. Although much has changed here since Herbert Hoover's birth in 1874, the National Park Service and the Hoover family have worked to preserve key elements of the past that illuminate the life and times of America's 31st president. 
(music) Herbert Hoover's accomplished and public-spirited life drew inspiration from his birthplace. Today you'll have the chance to immerse yourself in the landscape Hoover saw and the activities he participated in as a child. His father's craft as a blacksmith, Hoover's religious upbringing, his love of fishing, the education he received - many of the influences which Herbert Hoover carried into his adult life and that contributed to his character.
You'll also hear eloquent accounts of the adversity that touched a Quaker family and shaped the path of a young boy from West Branch who went on to serve his country as President. 
On August 12, 1965, an act of Congress established this park as a national historic site. Since then, the National Park Service has preserved and interpreted the historic structures and landscape of this park. In the late 1930's, President Hoover and his wife, Lou Henry Hoover, chose this place to celebrate the values they believed helped shape his life. We hope you will find it to be an inspiring, accessible educational and recreational experience for years to come.

stops.significance: West Branch boomed between 1869 and 1873. New buildings constructed in the neighborhood near the Hoovers' small cottage on Downey Street included the Laban Miles House, the Garvin House, and the Methodist Church, which is no longer standing.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross the gravel street to the intersection of the plank walkways next to the street signpost, about 60 feet. Turn left and walk about 50 feet to entrance gate of the small white cottage.
stops.audioTranscript:
It may be hard to imagine, but the road you’re looking at now, was once a very important thoroughfare. Downey Street was the entrance into West Branch from the south. If you look up and down the road, you can still find scattered hitching posts in front of several of the homes. 
(music) In 1870, the U.S. census counted Iowa’s population at almost 1.2 million. The towns and farms that now covered the state had, within a single generation, replaced the traditional American Indian uses of the land. Herbert Hoover’s grandfather, Eli Hoover, was one of the first few settlers of West Branch, arriving by covered wagon in 1854. When the census takers came sixteen years later, the town’s population stood at about 200.  But the railroad’s arrival in West Branch that same year helped the town’s rapid expansion into a thriving agricultural and business centered community.  
During Herbert Hoover’s childhood, the intersection of Downey and Main was the town crossroads. Although several of the streets that existed historically have been moved or no longer exist, you can still see the road trace of the original Downey Street as it runs past the little Birthplace Cottage. Because it wasn’t far, the Hoover family walked down this street into town to do their shopping.
(sound effects: birds chirping) Did you notice how most of the homes along this street have either four-board or picket fencing in their front yards? For modern-day homeowners, what looks like a decorative choice was actually one of necessity for the folks living on Downey Street. When “Bertie” Hoover was a boy, he probably saw local farmers drive their livestock to market down the middle of this wide street - right past his front door.(sound effects: horse and buggy, cows, pigs) But if it weren’t for those fences, a stray pig or cow might have actually wound up eating the vegetables in his mother’s garden or stepping on the tulips in their front yard!
In the 1870’s, the streets of West Branch were either “dusty thoroughfares or muddy bogs.” (sound effects: rain, horse and buggy) When it rained Downey Street would turn sticky with mud and lots of wagon wheel ruts. It wasn’t unusual to see a team of oxen or even a horse and buggy get stuck. At the time of Hoover’s birth in 1874, West Branch didn’t have sidewalks. However, by 1885 the city had finished over three and a half miles of wood plank walkways. The sidewalks here today are representations of those late 19th century boardwalks; they may be slippery when wet, so please watch your step.

stops.significance: In 1871, shortly after their first wedding anniversary, Jesse and Hulda Hoover built their simple but sturdy two-room cottage in the budding town of West Branch, Iowa. Their second child, future president Herbert Hoover, was born in the bedroom on August 10, 1874. In the years following his presidency, Herbert and Lou Hoover restored the president's humble birthplace, which he called, "physical proof of the unbounded opportunity of American life."
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front gate of the cottage, walk back to the signpost intersection. Turn left at the signpost and follow the walkway about 50 feet to the brown building with large barn doors. After hours when the doors are closed an exhibit panel is viewable.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Birthplace Cottage of Herbert Hoover. Before we begin, please note there are three entrance steps to the front door. Wheelchair access is through the back door. 
Like any couple just starting out, 21-year old Hulda Minthorn and 23-year old Jesse Hoover were eager to have a place to call their own. Shortly after their first wedding anniversary, and with the help of his father Eli, Jesse built this simple, but sturdy two-room cottage in the spring of 1871 on the corner of Downey and Penn Streets. Although the house only measured 14 x 20 feet, building it was a challenge. The home's large foundation stones had to be brought by wagon from the open prairie to the west, while the timber used for the board and batten cottage followed an amazing journey of its own. 
Look up at the rafters and see if you can find any that have holes drilled into them. (sound effects: rushing river, saw cutting wood)That's where the trees were lashed together into a giant raft, which was floated down the Mississippi River to a sawmill in Muscatine, about 40 miles southeast of West Branch. There they were turned into lumber, then hauled by ox teams to the home site. Some of the wood was used for the cottage's straight board doors, while more was used for the large vertical wallboards inside the home. Did you know that during the cottage's restoration, architects found strips of cotton fabric stuffed between the seams? (sound effects: winds whirling, blowing) Jesse Hoover installed these to be sure his family would be protected from the winter winds that swept across the Iowa prairie. The small twelve-paned windows also helped by preventing too much heat from escaping the cottage.
(music) Hulda soon set about arranging the home to suit herself, both inside and out. A chicken coop provided fresh eggs. She grew her vegetable garden behind the cottage, while flower gardens of marigolds, peonies, and snapdragons filled the front and side yards. And just like today, seeds, cuttings and bulbs, were traded with family and friends.  The dark red double-petaled tulips that once grew here came from the bulbs Hulda's mother had brought with her from Canada.
Looking around this house, you may think the Hoover family was poor. But their prudent spending, strong work ethic, and resourceful ways were actually a reflection of their Quaker beliefs. With that in mind, you can understand why Herbert Hoover was inspired to write these heartfelt words in his memoirs. 
Hoover: (actor) "This cottage where I was born is physical proof of the unbounded opportunity of American life. In no other land could a boy from a country village, without inheritance or influential friends, look forward with unbound hope."

stops.significance: Built in 1957, this building represents the kind of blacksmith and wagon shops that were common in the 1870s. It is based on the sketches of Herbert's older brother Theodore, from his recollections of what their father's shop looked like. The re-built blacksmith shop sits west of the original shop's location just a stone's throw from the Birthplace Cottage.
stops.assetName: Blacksmith Shop (Herbert Hoover National Historic Site)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the walkway about 70 feet to the exhibit panel by the walkway to the schoolhouse.
stops.audioTranscript:
Jesse Hoover owned and operated a blacksmith shop in West Branch from 1871 to 1879. This reconstructed shop, built in 1957, is based on the sketches of Herbert's older brother Tad, from his recollections of what their father's shop looked like. Lumber salvaged from a nearby barn, which had stood since the 1870's, was used in its construction. Located near its original location, the re-built blacksmith shop still sits just a stone's throw from the Birthplace Cottage.
(sound effects: iron being hammered, horse whinny) The excitement of banging iron, sparking fires, and new visitors, often brought Tad and his younger brother "Bertie", across old Penn street to investigate their father's business. One time in particular, according to Hoover's memoirs, left a "lasting impression", on the young Herbert.
Hoover: (actor) "Playing barefoot around the blacksmith shop, I stepped on a chip of hot iron and carry the brand of Iowa on my foot to this day.",
Although there were other smithies in town, Jesse's friendliness, honesty, and strong work ethic helped his business to grow. His wry sense of humor came across in the ads he ran in the local newspaper, which read: "Horse shoeing and plow work a specialty. Prices to suit the times. J. C. Hoover.",
(sound effects: horse and buggy) The large double doors made it easy to maneuver horses around for shoeing or to bring in large wagon wheels or plows for repair. Inside the main building you'll find a working forge, along with an anvil, and a rack filled with period tools of the trade. Look around and see how many different size horseshoes or wagon rims you can find.
During select times of the year, park visitors can watch a blacksmith demonstrate the skill and hard work needed to turn ordinary iron into useful things. Items made during these demonstrations are for sale at the Visitor Center bookstore.

stops.significance: Herbert Hoover recalled, "Iowa in those years was filled with days of school, and who does not remember with a glow, some gentle woman, who with infinite patience and kindness, drilled into us those foundations of all we know today."
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return the way you came until you are back at the signpost. Turn right and follow the street or sidewalk over the bridge to the next intersection of the gravel and planks, about 350 feet. Follow the plank walkway on the left to the exhibit panel about 50 feet before the white building with two front doors.
stops.audioTranscript:
By 1853, enough settlers lived in West Branch to support and build a public school. Hard work was a core value of the Quaker faith, but so too, was the importance of education for both boys and girls - Hoover's own mother, Hulda had been a teacher before she married. Because the Society of Friends raised much of the money for the construction of this one-room schoolhouse, it was also used as the first Quaker meetinghouse, which might explain its simple, unadorned architecture.
Originally located at the corner of Main and Downey streets, the school was sold and moved several times before its final relocation here in 1968. While it is unknown if Hoover attended school in this building, it is the oldest building at Herbert Hoover National Historic Site.
When 5-year old Herbert "Bertie", Hoover started primary school in 1879, he was following in the footsteps of his big brother, eight-year old "Tad.", (sound effects: bell, children talking, laughing) Mornings were greeted with the ringing of the school bell and the activity of hanging coats and hats on the cloak room hooks just inside the doorway. As you step inside, you'll find a classroom restored to the time of Hoover's youth. Double-seated wooden desks trimmed in cast iron vary in size from large to small. Did you notice the ones directly in front of the teacher's desk? Children sat here when it was time to recite their lessons.
Miss Lizzie Chandler taught Bertie Hoover for first and second grade. Each day, her blackboard was filled with lessons of arithmetic and spelling. No computers or overhead projectors here. Students shared reading books, and practiced penmanship on slate chalkboards, like the ones sitting on these desktops. 
The only source of heat in this schoolhouse came from a pot-bellied wood stove located at the back of the room. In the winter, you can imagine that depending on where you sat, you might be sweating or freezing!  The eight large windows let in lots of natural light, but on cloudy days, it was the kerosene lamps that helped to brighten the room. 
You probably recognize the portraits of George Washington and Abraham Lincoln, the country's first and sixteenth Presidents. Little did Miss Lizzie Chandler know that in less than 50 years, Bertie Hoover would add his name to that distinguished list when he was elected the 31st President of the United States of America.

stops.significance: Herbert Hoover grew up in a religious community that valued peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others. The plainly furnished Friends Meetinghouse, built by the Society of Friends, or Quakers, in 1857, is the physical expression of those values. Now two blocks from its original location, the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation relocated and restored this meetinghouse in 1964.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the plank sidewalk straight away from the exhibit panel until the planks end and the concrete begins, about 50 feet. Continue along the concrete sidewalk to the statue on the left, about 50 feet.
stops.audioTranscript:
Located two blocks from its original site, the Friends Meetinghouse is the physical expression of the values of the Quaker faith practiced by Hoover's family and the community of West Branch. Built by the Society of Friends in 1857, this single story wood frame building was relocated and restored in 1964 to reflect how it looked when Hoover attended services here as a child.
Ruthie Tippin: "The first thing that you notice is how simple it is. The simplicity of the meeting room was intentional, the way it's laid out, the lack of ornamentation, the clarity of it, and that was to allow absolutely nothing to distract one from the presence of God. And that had a great impact on Herbert Hoover, and all others who worship as Friends.", 
Two meetings for worship were held each week, on First Day, Sunday, and Fourth Day, Wednesday. Quakers used numbers to mark their days and months because they didn't believe in the mythological gods whose names were used in Roman calendars "“ like March "“ named for Mars, the god of war.
What Quakers did believe in according to Ruthie Tippin, pastor of the West Branch Friends Church, was the concept of the Inner Light being present in every human soul.
Ruthie Tippin: "Friends started out without a pastor and then, this division came between those who were satisfied and loved the sense of quiet waiting, against those who felt like there was something more to be had in a pastoral setting.", 
When Hoover was a child, there were no paid ministers. For 60 to 90 minutes, without benefit of music, or sacraments, the congregation would sit on the rows of long wooden benches. Find out how long you can sit still for. Just like in the 1870's, women and girls on the left, and men and boys to the right. 
Now did you notice the raised benches at the front of the room? Who sat there?
Ruthie Tippin: "So the elders "“ the ministry and oversight would sit on the facing benches, and they would sit in silence waiting "“ just waiting to see what God would do "“ what God would say "“ through the membership.", 
As the spirit moved them, people rose and spoke spontaneously. When there seemed to be no more messages, the elders rose, shook hands, and the meeting ended. Aware of how their actions might affect the world around them, the Friends tried earnestly to live lives that honored their commitments to love, integrity, equality, and peace. Those testimonies that Herbert Hoover experienced here as a child, instilled in him a drive to become a successful leader and one of the world's great humanitarians.

stops.significance: The bronze, seven and a half foot tall statue "Isis, Goddess of Life" is the work of Belgian sculptor Auguste Puttemans. It was a gift from the people of Belgium in gratitude for Hoover's famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the concrete sidewalk. Round the corner of the limestone building to the right until you get to the front doors of museum, across from the flag poles.
stops.audioTranscript:
Considering Herbert Hoover's Quaker upbringing, you might be wondering why there is a statue of Isis, "the Egyptian goddess of Life", sitting on the grounds of his birthplace.
This bronze, seven and a half foot tall statue is the work of Belgian sculptor Auguste Puttemans, and was a gift from the children, refugees, and soldiers of Belgium in gratitude for Hoover's famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.
When the Belgians shipped the finished statue to California's Stanford University in 1922, it remained on campus until the President and Mrs. Hoover brought it to West Branch in 1939. Both of them wanted it to be placed in a position where it was "contemplating the house," which is why Isis sits in her throne-like chair facing the Birthplace Cottage. 
(Egyptian music) Look closely, and you'll notice that her veil, a symbol of the mysteries of life, cannot hide the strength of her features. Her right hand carries the torch of life - its three flames represent the past, present, and future, while her left hand holds the key of life. 
An Egyptian goddess and an American President. It's an unlikely pairing, but one that provides a powerful visual link between Hoover's childhood and his life's dedication to the welfare of others.

stops.significance: Part of the National Archives, this presidential library allows people to explore the legacy of Herbert Hoover's presidency. It opened to the public on August 10, 1962— Herbert Hoover's 88th birthday. President Hoover himself attended the dedication, along with fellow former President Harry S. Truman.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross the driveway from the front doors of the museum, following the crosswalk between the flag poles, to the sidewalk on the other side, about 50 feet. A sign indicates the direction to the gravesite. Follow the sidewalk to the right, gently uphill about one quarter mile to the gravesite parking area. From that area, the final 280  feet to ascends to the top of a knoll where the graves are. An alternate path from the gravesite parking area to the graves, about 450  feet, starts on the left and has a wheelchair accessible grade.
stops.audioTranscript:
Presidential Libraries give the American people the opportunity to explore the legacy of American Presidential leadership. It is an amazing opportunity to see, hear, and appreciate many of the events that changed our lives and made us who we are as a nation. The Herbert Hoover Presidential Library-Museum was opened to the public on August 10, 1962, Mr. Hoover's 88th birthday. The dedication took place at the library's original entrance, which is the small portico at the east end of the building supported by four white pillars and topped with an earlier version of the presidential seal. 
Timothy Walch, Director of the Herbert Hoover Presidential Library shares a story about that historic day. Tim Walch: "Herbert Hoover went to the dedication of the Truman library in 1957. Well, Harry Truman reciprocates by coming to the dedication of the Hoover library, and when they walk through those doors Truman looks around and with typical Truman bluntness says, 'Mr. President'" turning to Herbert Hoover "'Mr. President, this museum is too damn small.' And Herbert Hoover looks over at Mr. Truman and says, 'Yes, Mr. President, but knowing the federal government, I'm sure it will grow over time.' And both of them were right."  
(music) Since that day, the museum has been expanded and renovated several times, with the most recent change funded by a partnership between the U.S. government and the non-profit Hoover Presidential Library Association.
(music) Although it is located on a National Park Service Historic Site, the Library-Museum is independently operated and maintained by the National Archives and Records Administration. The museum houses millions of papers and over 300 collections relating to both President and Mrs. Hoover, their friends and associates. Permanent galleries take you from President Hoover's boyhood in Iowa and continue on to a recreation of the Waldorf Towers apartment in New York where he spent the final years of his life.
Herbert Hoover was proud of the modest museum here because it fit within the context of the other buildings on the site. Tim Walch: "He was determined to locate it on a lower terrain than others had suggested; they wanted to locate it up on the top of Cook's Hill. And he said, "No, no, I want it down with the other buildings. I don't want it any taller than any of the other buildings on the site. It should fit in, in a very modest way with the other buildings." 
Perhaps what Herbert Hoover didn't foresee back in 1962, was how this Library-Museum would be transformed into a nationally recognized center of study. Tim Walch: "When the Hoover Presidential Library was opened, the expectation was that we would put a few trinkets, trophies, and so forth, on display for the public to see, and that we would have the documents available just for post-doctoral scholars. Well, now these institutions have schools of public service where young people begin to study the values of the president. There are research think-tanks where people prepare policy papers for future governmental administrations." 
Take some time and come inside for a visit. You'll learn the story of Hoover's fifty years of public service and gain a fuller understanding of the life and times of America's 31st President.

stops.significance: Five days after he died on October 20, 1964 at the age of 90, the 31st President was laid to rest in this quiet, grassy hillside. More than 100,000 people lined the funeral procession route from Cedar Rapids to West Branch on that warm fall day.
stops.audioTranscript:
Hoover: (actor) "My grandparents and my parents came here in a covered wagon. In this community they toiled and worshipped God. The most formative years of my boyhood were spent here. My roots are in this soil." 
(music) Those words from his memoirs, illustrate Herbert Hoover's connection to history and place. When Hoover died on October 20, 1964 at the age of 90, the 31st President was laid to rest five days later in this quiet, grassy hillside. More than 100,000 people lined the funeral procession route from Cedar Rapids to West Branch on that warm fall day. 
Iowa architect William Wagner designed the memorial while working closely with the Hoover family to commemorate his life. The tall stand of chestnut, hickory, and black walnut trees planted behind the gravesite were chosen because Hoover remembered them from his childhood. The two plainly inscribed ledger stones of Vermont white marble are in keeping with the Quaker ideal of simplicity. Across the curved walkway, the American flag waves in tribute. Did you know that it was Herbert Hoover who signed the congressional resolution making The Star Spangled Banner the national anthem during his Presidency?
Now take a moment and look past the towering flagpole. There on the horizon, at the end of the two rows of trees, is a direct view of the white, wood-frame cottage where Herbert "Bertie" Hoover was born. As the first President born west of the Mississippi River, Hoover believed that anyone could start from simple beginnings and achieve great things.
Pete Hoover reflects on the qualities that not only made his grandfather so successful, but encouraged the success of others.
Pete Hoover: "Granddad was an interesting guy to be around. There was not a subject that you could raise that he couldn't contribute something on. He never commandeered the conversation. He could contribute to it and do it in an unobtrusive way so that people would understand and learn a little maybe." 
The second marble gravestone is for Lou Henry Hoover, the tireless and intelligent First Lady from Waterloo, Iowa. Following her death in 1944, she was buried in Palo Alto, California, but was moved to rest beside her husband in 1964. Partners in life for almost forty-five years, they had both come back to touch the Iowa soil.

images.title: Gravesite of President & Mrs. Hoover
images.altText: Rows of neatly trimmed bushes and trees form an arc around two marble slabs marking graves.
images.caption: Neatly trimmed plantings surround the President's and First Lady's graves.

data.title: Quilt Tour
data.description: This self-guided auto tour features hand-painted quilt blocks, created by a group of volunteers from Stewart County, Tennessee. There are four different auto tours and one walking tour, the Mourner's Walk. Pick up your maps at the park Visitor Center.

stops.significance:
There are four auto tours and one walking tour.  The Letitia Smith Tour is largely within the confines of the city.  You may also like the Forrest Loop Trail.

No matter the tour that you choose, each quilt pattern is typical of 19th century American quilt patterns.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Please choose the specific tour route and follow the physical address within that tour (on your quilt map tour).  The tours can be a minimal driving distance of 4-5 miles, or as much as 25 or 30  miles.

Make sure to view the quilt block on the south side of the park Visitor Center.

Maps are available inside the park Visitor Center.  Or, you can take this suggested route:  turn right at the park main entrance, drive .5 mile to the Dover Family Pharmacy.  It will be on your right.

Turn into the parking area, and choose a parking spot either in front of the building or behind the building.  The next suggested block is located on the west side of the pharmacy.  Be careful, the drive-thru line is also on this side of the building.

stops.significance: Quilt Tour
stops.directionsToNextStop: You may choose to go to the next location at the Dover Family Pharmacy, 1307 Donelson Parkway, Dover, TN  37058.  Make a right turn at the park entrance, and drive .5 miles to the Pharmacy. It's on the right.  Parking is available. Or, you could follow any route you choose using a paper copy of the Quilt Tour.  Make sure to pick your copy up in the park Visitor Center.

stops.significance: one of the blocks on the Quilt Trail
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the parking area at the pharmacy, drive north on Highway 79 to 174 Church Street (it's just across from the entrance to Tour Stop #11 at the Fort Donelson National Cemetery).  Parking is in the rear of the showboat-style, two-story home.

stops.significance: stop on the quilt trail
stops.directionsToNextStop:
After visiting the Sykes Museum, exit to Cedar Street, drive to the stop sign on Church Street.  Make a right turn on Church Street, leaving the National Cemetery and Sykes Museum area and return to Highway 79.

Turn left on Highway 79, and then a quick right at the traffic light.  This will be Spring Street/Highway 49.  

You may want to stop by the Dover Hotel (tour stop #10); it is located to your left on Petty Street.  To see the next quilt block, continue on Highway 49/Spring Street for .3 mile at the public library.  You will see the library from the highway, across from the middle school.

stops.significance: Quilt Trail - this is from Letitia Smith trail loop
stops.directionsToNextStop:
If you choose to visit the next stop, return to Spring Street, Highway 49 and make a right.  You'll drive approximately five miles to the next stop, turning right on Long Creek Road.  The next quilt block is two miles from Highway 49.  The Maple Grove Farm is on your right.  The large red barn is visible from the road.

If you choose to stay in Dover, try checking out the quilt block at the Stewart County Visitor Center, 117 Visitor Center Lane.  It's located inside the building, and the building is not open each day.

stops.significance: Another stop on the Quilt Trail - this information may be found on the NB Forrest Trail map
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leaving the town of Dover, drive east along Highway 49 to Long Creek  Road.  Make a right turn.  Drive two miles until you see Maple Grove Farm, located on the right.  The large barn with the quilt block is visible from the road.

stops.significance: The Roper Star is based on a circa 1830s quilt made in Stewart County TN.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop for the self-guided Quilt Tour.

data.title: Ranger Guided Tour of White Haven
data.description: The historic White Haven estate is the centerpiece of Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site. Guided tours of Grant's home White Haven are offered on a daily basis. There is no fee to take the tour. Tours meet at the front desk inside the Visitor Center. Tours are usually offered at the top of each hour with the first tour beginning at 10:00 a.m. and the last tour at 4:00 p.m. Advance reservations are not required to take a tour, but spots are offered on a first-come, first-serve basis.

Learn more about the people and activities at Bent's Old Fort in the 1840's. Groups need reservations 719-383-5026. Ranger programs are not available during special events.

data.title: Ranger Talks and Tours
data.description: Park rangers are present in the park daily and are often available to provide presentations and/or guided tours of the park grounds (as staffing permits). If formal programs are not possible during your visit, park staff are available to personally answer your questions and to provide information about the park. Groups of ten to twenty individuals may arrange for a ranger-led program at least one week in advance.

stops.significance: A massive rock structure built by Kamehameha I and his warriors with no mortar and water worn rocks that came from the seashore valley of Pololu. This heiau (temple) played a crucial role in the ruler's ascendancy. With the death of Kamehameha's cousin Keoua, all opposition ended on the island of Hawai'i, and the prophecy began to come true. By 1810, through conquest and treaties, Kamehameha The Great, builder of Pu'ukohola Heiau, was the revered king of all the Hawaiian Islands.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Audio tour starts at the visitor center, head right (north) on the paved path, and continue on the half mile loop trail that will take you to the base of Pu'ukohola Heiau, down to Pelekane Bay, and along the coastal trail looping back to the visitor center.
stops.audioTranscript:
1-Introduction of the park (start at visitor center).
2-History of two Heiau's located on site (Pu'ukohola & Mailekini).
3-John Young Homestead: Not accessible by this trail, ask park ranger or check park brochure for more information or direction.
4-Pelekane Bay (Arrival of Keoua; Birth place of Queen Emma)
5-Ala Kahakai (Coastal Trail System)
6-Conclusion of the park (end at visitor center).

data.title: Rankin Ridge Nature Trail
data.description: The Rankin Ridge trail takes you through a ponderosa pine forest. At several points along the trail you may view the peaks of the Black Hills to the west, and the plains to the east. Rankin Ridge trail is a loop trail, beginning and ending at the parking lot. There are 14 interpretive stops placed at irregular intervals along the path. Your guided tour ends a short distance beyond the fire tower. From the last stop to the parking lot is about a 15 minute walk.

data.title: Rapidan Camp
data.description: Nestled deep in a hollow at the headwaters of the Rapidan River in Shenandoah National Park is a little piece of history. Rapidan Camp was the beautiful, rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Experience this serene spot yourself and explore its history through this self-guided tour. The camp is not accessible by private vehicle. Hike in from Milam Gap or join a Ranger Tour.

stops.significance: An introduction!
The place to start your tour!
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp - Then and Now: Finding your way around the Camp
stops.directionsToNextStop: Just look down!

stops.significance: Rapidan Camp is a National Historic Landmark!
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp - National Historic Landmark Plaque
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk along the pathway to your right.

stops.significance: The signs around the camp indicate points of interest.
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp - Town Hall - Famous Town Visitors
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path to the next sign.

stops.significance: This sign indicates the former location of "Town Hall"
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path.

stops.significance: This sign indicates the location of the former area devoted to recreation at the camp.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path and take a right at the intersection.

stops.significance: Optional 1/2-mile walk to the sluice and back
stops.directionsToNextStop: If you choose to take the 1/2 mile walk to the sluice, follow the path and then return by the same route. To continue follow the path the Prime Minister's Cabin.

stops.significance: If you have taken the walk to the sluice, turn back here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the steps, turn right and follow the path to the Prime Minister's Cabin.

stops.significance: The Prime Minister's Cabin houses an exhibit about the Hoovers and Rapidan Camp. You can visit it during the summer and fall seasons or virtually on our website.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to the Prime Minister's Cabin porch.

stops.significance: This outdoor exhibit tells the story of Rapidan Camp.
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp - Prime Minister's Porch Exhibit
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps to the path intersection and turn right.

stops.significance: This feature was built by the Marines.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the path.

stops.significance: The Marines also built this trout pond.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the path toward the "Brown House."

stops.significance: The Hoovers had a unique interpretation of "lying lightly on the land."
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp - The Brown House Back Entrance
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk around the house to the front of the building.

stops.significance: What a view! What a porch!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path in front of the house to the bridge.

stops.significance: Follow the Hoovers' lead and take time to listen to the sounds of the mountain streams.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path back around to the front of the cabin and go right to large chimney.

stops.significance: The massive stone fireplaces have their own story to tell.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path up the hill toward the last building and look left at the intersection for the next sign.

stops.significance: Can you smell the roasting steaks and potatoes?
stops.directionsToNextStop: Wander a bit further down this path to the stone structure that looks like a wedding cake!

stops.significance: This fountain was part of the elaborate water features the Marines constructed.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps to the intersection, turn left and walk up the path to Creel Cabin.

stops.significance: Then and Now...if you've fallen in love with Rapidan Camp, you can apply to be a volunteer caretaker and live in Creel Cabin!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue up the path to the road.

stops.significance: The Mill Prong Trail brings hikers to the camp.
stops.assetName: Rapidan Camp Road and Mill Prong Trail Intersection
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go left to the next sign.

stops.significance: This sign commemorates the Hoovers' first night at Rapidan Camp.
stops.directionsToNextStop: You can take an optional walk up to the the ruins of Five Tents. It's a bit of a climb, but not far!

stops.significance: All that's left of a once-popular cabin
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps back to the road.

stops.significance: The trails near the camp are open to horses, so you may encounter them and their riders.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If nature's calling you can follow the road back across the bridge to a vault toilet.

stops.significance: In case nature is calling...
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your tour of the camp is complete!

data.title: Red Power on Alcatraz
data.description: Alcatraz Island lies within Ramaytush Ohlone territory. There is no evidence (scientific or oral tradition) regarding Ohlone use of the island. In 1969, a group of Native American students, who later known as “Indians of All Tribes,” came to occupy the island in a political protest. These students fought for inclusion into the educational system that denied them their cultural existence. On this tour, learn the story of the 19-month Indian occupation of Alcatraz Island. The tour is 0.5 mi (0.8km) one way.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue up the road through the Sallyport and around the switchback to Stop 2.
Continue up the hill around the switchback and up to Stop 3 at the end of the road overlooking the water tank.
Turn around and continue heading up the hill to Stop 4 in front of the cellhouse.
Walk past the lighthouse and continue down West Road to Stop 5.
Return back up West Road to Stop 6 at the overlook at the top.
To learn more, visit the Red Power on Alcatraz online exhibit or visit the exhibit in the New Industries Building.

images.altText: Red spray painted graffiti on the water tower on Alcatraz Island.
images.caption: The restored graffiti from the Indian Occupation

data.title: Reflection Tour for Families and Groups
data.description: This reflection tour allows park visitors the opportunity to visit significant areas of Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial and to "Look, Learn and Do" to learn more. Stop at each location stop and "Look" at the place that is an important part of the Lincoln in Indiana story. "Learn" by reading the History Highlight which gives more information about that site. All members of the group will then "Do" an activity to learn more.

stops.significance:
Who is Buried Here?
LOOK: Who is buried in this Pioneer Cemetery?
LEARN: Read the History Highlight: Tragedy in the Pioneer Community
DO: We often honor people and their memories long after they lived. 
How many years after the deaths of Nancy Lincoln, Nancy Brooner and the Sparrows were their headstones installed in this cemetery? Do mental math or do the calculations on paper or a device.
Photographers and Videographers, capture still photos and/or video of the site.
Journalists, ask others in your group an Interview Question while on the move to the next stop: “Where are your ancestors buried?”  “What famous burial sites or national cemeteries have you visited?”  “Have you visited Lincoln’s tomb in Illinois?”
stops.assetName: Grave Site of Nancy Hanks Lincoln
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Continue walking the Lincoln Boyhood Trail to the North Parking Lot, approximately 300 yards. Stop at the sign that reads Southern Boundary Thomas Lincoln Farm at the junction of the trail lined on the left with a split-rail fence.
The tour is a one mile loop along the Lincoln Boyhood Trail and the Trail of Twelve Stones.

stops.significance:
Is it a Trail or A Road? 
LOOK: Notice the crossroads where the two paths join.  Does this look like a trail or a road? 

LEARN: Read the History Highlight: Lincoln’s Big Move

DO:  Have moved from one state to another. Share some examples with your group. 
Or,
DO:  Share if you’ve ever faced a big challenge in another way.

Photographers and Videographers: capture still photos and/or video of the site.
Journalist: ask members of your group an Interview Question while walking the trail to the next stop: “What was difficult about your move?” “What was difficult about your challenge?” “What did you learn about new things.” What did you learn about yourself?"
stops.assetName: Southern Boundary of Thomas Lincoln Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk Lincoln Boyhood Trail 300 yards to the Lincoln Living Historical Farm.

stops.significance:
LOOK: What buildings do you find at the farm?  

LEARN: Read the History Highlight:  Life on the Farm 

DO: “Vote with your feet.”  Go stand by the building where you think you would prefer to spend the most time.  Share your reasons why with other people there.
Photographers and Videographers: capture still photos and/or video at the site.
Journalist: ask others in your group an Interview Question while walking to the next stop: “What would you enjoy about life on the farm? What would you not enjoy about life on the farm? What books would you read by the fire like young Abraham Lincoln did?”
stops.directionsToNextStop: The Trail of Twelves stones trailhead is located to between the crop field and the cabin.

stops.significance:
LOOK: Look at the stones along the “Trail of Twelve Stones” What are the stones representing in Lincoln’s life? 

LEARN: History Highlights: Remembering Abraham Lincoln (Read the article associated with the stone at each of the location stops.)

DO: There are many ways we remember Abraham Lincoln. Share with the group how you want people of the future to remember you?
Photographers and Videographers: capture still photos and/or video of the site.
Journalist: ask the people in your group an Interview Question while walking to the next stop: “What is the coolest thing you learned today?” “What did you enjoy most about spending time in the park?” “What will you want to show others when you bring them to visit the park?”
stops.directionsToNextStop: The Trail of Twelve stones brings hikers back to the Pioneer Cemetery, Stop 1. It's a short walk from there to the Memorial Visitor Center parking lot.

data.title: Restoring Nature Audio Tour
data.description: History isn't the only focus of ours at Fort Clatsop, we also focus on taking care of the land and trying to help it regrow after events of the past. Luckily for us the Lewis and Clark journals tell us just what this land looked like back in the 1800's! This audio tour will take you to four stops on a 1.25 mile (one way) hike down the Netul River trail, starting from the Rain Garden at the Visitor Center and ending at Netul Landing.

park.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
park.name: Lewis and Clark

stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Rain Garden head across the middle of the parking and head on the dirt and gravel trail into the woods. To the right is a picnic area and to the left is a downhill slope. Head down the hill and onto the boardwalk. Follow this trail for about half a mile and stop at the brown metal foot bridge.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Restoring Nature Tour.  This walk is about two miles in length on an easy trail. There will be nine stops along the way beginning at the rain garden in front of the Ft. Clatsop Visitor Center and proceeding down the Netul River Trail. The conclusion of the audio tour will be at the Netul Landing, where the trail opens up to a parking lot. The return walk will bring you back to the visitor center.

Sound of Rain…
	 
Narrator:
Here at Lewis and Clark National Historical Park, where we get around 70 inches of rain per year, we are no strangers to the water cycle. As the rain falls on the sidewalks, parking lots, and roads, it can create problems for our rivers and streams.  The water runs off the hard surfaces and collects debris and pollution from gas, oil, bits of copper from car brakes, and pesticides from local farms and lawns.  These pollutants are deadly to salmon and harmful to our estuaries. 

And what a rain garden does, is it takes and reproduces what a native landscape would do by capturing some of that moisture and allowing Mother Nature  in the form of the plants and the soil and the microorganisms and fungi  and all the things that live in the rain garden, to process those pollutants and  to recharge that water.  
Rob Emanuel, Water Resources and Community Development Specialist with OSU Sea Grant Extension Office.

Narrator:
And it’s a rather amazing process that we would spend millions of dollars to treat if we were to treat these kinds of things in treatment plants, and instead nature does a wonderful job all by herself. 

That odd wooden trough in the middle of the garden is not a water slide for squirrels ride but a scupper, which delivers the rain water from the roof of the visitor center to the garden. When constructing a home or a building, Rob Emanual says it’s cheaper to create a rain garden than laying expensive drainage pipes.  Most rain gardens are designed to fit in urban settings next to city streets or in font yards with small plants. However, this rain garden mirrors the surrounding forests.

One of the important pieces of our landscape up here are nurse logs, and lots and lots of native forest plants that are growing in this rain garden.   And the nurse logs are really showing what a native forest would look like up here which is typically full of downed wood, and the downed wood is covered with moss. It’s also very absorptive of water and lots of plants will grow on it and as in sort of a nursery.

Colby Weathers, an award winning landscape design artist, who was one of the co-designers of this garden says if everyone started managing their storm water in their own backyards, it would change our rivers. 

When we see very large storm events, rain events, and you see the rivers and streams being clouded with muddy water, that’s erosion and sediment that’s being carried off by the truckload and everyone of these types of systems, a rain garden, can protect the property that you’ve actually purchased from being washed away into the watershed. 

To continue to see more restoration projects, walk down the Netul River Trail about a 1/2 mile, and stop at the brown metal foot bridge next to Ft. Clatsop Road.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the Netul Trail for about half a mile more until you reach  the North Netul Picnic Shelter.
stops.audioTranscript:
Sounds of a running stream.

Beneath you, in the dark waters, swim young salmon, coho, chum, and Chinook, as well as cutthroat trout and steelhead. They make their way up the Lewis and Clark River during various seasons of the year and spend time eating and adjusting to the salt water while they live in the wetland. One hundred years ago, just across the road, the area was diked, drained and filled with three feet of dredge spoils from the river to create pasture. 

Sound of bulldozer and trucks.

In 2012, a crew with large earth moving vehicles was out here changing that. Hunter White, a contract  engineer through the National Park Service, explains the project. 

To the extent that we can, we’re trying to turn back the clock on that disturbance and restore the site to as close was we can when Lewis and Clark would have seen when they arrived here.  

Besides moving 12,000 cubic yards of soil, the construction crew even added fallen trees to the marsh. 

We use wood in our restoration projects for several different reasons.  In particular, a lot of these logs you’ll notice, have large root wads attached to them. And those especially have so much more surface area than just the log itself to provide you know, hiding spaces for small fish.  And when the logs are in the streams they also form scour holes around them rather just having one consistent channel bottom. By adding logs in here you are creating  more complicated system with pools and  ripples. 

In the first phase of restoration, the park service installed a bridge in front of you so the water and fish could flow freely with the tides. And that has made all the difference.

Initially, before they put in the bridge. They found 10 salmon total. And then then when we came back the next year, we found 122 salmon.

April Cameron, a Biologist with the Columbia River Estuary Study Taskforce:

Salmon in particular, they are an anadromous fish, and they are dependent on the fresh water and the salt water. So having these habitats here in the lower estuary in particular gives them a place for refuge  to rear and to feed on their way out to sea, and that can be very important. 

FX: Ducks

Narrator:

As the wetland now floods with the daily tides, the number of water fowl has increased dramatically. More ducks and geese have returned to the marsh, as well as shore birds like rails, snipes, and heron.  The park service is planting native plants such as thimble berries and Wapato and the vegetation is becoming healthier on its own, with more native plants like cattails and bulrushes springing up. But the biggest surprise for Nancy Eid, a scientist for the National Park Service, came from some early morning visitors, a few days after the cattle were taken off the land. 

FX: ELK CALL

Nancy Eid

Since that time we have noticed that pretty much every morning for certain periods of the year, we can see the elk herd out in the pasture and we see sign of the elk and we know that they spend a lot of their night time hours out here as well.   
What’s fantastic about working out here in the field, especially here at Ft. Clatsop. We get an opportunity to see a lot of wildlife, and being here in the park, you really get to get up and close. We hear coyotes in the mornings. We have seen a lot of migratory birds. We saw a heron just when we pulled up.
FX HERON

Narrator:

Continue to follow the river trail and keep your eyes peeled for wildlife as you hike. When you reach a sidewalk with some benches and a shelter, you have reached the next stop.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue south a short distance from the shelter until you reach the "Bioswales: A River Friendly Filter" Sign
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Netul Landing. While this place looks quiet, not too long ago, it was the largest sort yard for logging in Clatsop County. Pete Field, a Transportation Planner for the Federal Highway Administration oversaw the transformation of this site for the National Park Service.  

So basically it looked kind of like a race track and in a sense it was an oval loop, where trucks would come in, go by the river, which is now that bulk head by the bus loop and essentially unload into the river, where they would make more log rafts and continue to go back out into the woods to get more logs. 

A hundred trucks per day dumped logs into the river and men in small boats sorted the logs and readied them for tug boats to tow out to ship yards on the Columbia River. From there they were shipped throughout the world. 

FX Ship horn

After the industrial site was removed, a parking lot was put in and trees were planted by local elementary students. The parking lot was built with a slant to help move rain water towards a bios swale, a man-made pond of plants which functions similar in design and concept to a rain garden. Again, Pete Field.

So the bios swale, which was actually a kind of nice feature, a natural accommodation feature, even though we made it. It lets water stand and naturally infiltrate into the ground at that point. So that bioslwale it has that, I guess sponge, it’s literally a delay tactic, to get more of the water sponged into the earth and naturally filtered back to the river. 

Narrator:
Another benefit, the plants clean the water before they release it into the river. 

Sound of kayaker paddling

People love water and it is evident by this site’s popularity. People kayak, fish, walk their dogs and run by this river on a regular basis. On your way back to Ft Clatsop, take your time. Observe and appreciate this abundant resource of the Pacific Northwest.  It sustains us and we must take care of the land to keep our waters clean. 

Thanks for listening.

images.title: South Slough Foot Bridge
images.altText: A long brown metal bridge extends over a still creek, the reflection of the bridge on the water.
images.caption: The South Slough Foot Bridge allows one to see restoration projects on either side.

data.title: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Walking Tour
data.description: We often think of the desert as being a dry place, but if you look closely, you will find that water is truly the desert's "architect". The presence or absence of water affects the variety of plants and animals living here, and the ways in which humans have been able to use this area over time. As you walk the nature trail, let this tour be your guide, but also use your own observational skills to search for adaptations that plants and animals have evolved to survive in the Chihuahuan Desert.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #1
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the boardwalk to the second square platform where two information signs are located.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #2
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the boardwalk for a short distance to the large rectangular platform where two benches are located.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #3
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail off the boardwalk and onto a dirt trail. To access the next stop you will need to climb about 10 dirt steps.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #4
stops.directionsToNextStop: The trail to the next few stops is flat and easy to traverse.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #5
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the level dirt path.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #6
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take a right at the intersection to follow the side trail signed as the River Spur Trail.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #7
stops.directionsToNextStop: The trail to the next several stops traverses a rocky limestone bench. Be cautious with your footing and look closely at the limestone for some fun surprises!

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #8
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following the path along the limestone, taking care not to step in the mortar holes.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #9
stops.directionsToNextStop: The trail drops off the limestone and into sand. The path will curve through a clump of mesquite trees and head straight for the Rio Grande.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #10
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the sandy path towards a barrier of tall, dense cane.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #11
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the edge of the Rio Grande.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #12
stops.directionsToNextStop: The spur trail ends here. Turn around and follow the path back to the signed junction. Once at the junction, if you wish to continue on the loop take a right and continue along the portion of trail signed Overlook Loop Trail. If you wish to return to your vehicle, take a left and retrace your steps.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #13
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue the rocky climb towards the top of the hill.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #14
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue climbing the hill. You are only a short distance from the last intersection. Take a left at the intersection to reach the top of the hill and enjoy a fabulous view.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #15
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the top of the hill to reach the final stop and another great view. Take care, as the trail is very rocky and footing is precarious near the edge.

stops.assetName: Rio Grande Village Nature Trail Stop #16
stops.directionsToNextStop: You have reached the end of the trail. Retrace your route to the intersection, take a left, and descend down the hill. Take a right at the next intersection to return across the boardwalk and back to your vehicle. We hope you enjoyed the Rio Grande Village Nature Trail!

images.caption: Rio Grande Village pond and boardwalk

data.title: River Float Tour
data.description: Take a self-guided tour as you float the Niobrara National Scenic River. This tour identifies landmarks along the river where you can stop and explore, finding waterfalls and scenic views, and rapids for you to avoid too!

stops.significance: Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge's Launch Site is the first public launch on the designated 76 miles of Niobrara National Scenic River.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next official stop on the tour is about 15 minutes downstream, but you can learn more about the refuge in the next slide while you float.

stops.significance: While this is not an active stop on the tour or a river feature you should be looking for, know that you are floating through a National Wildlife Refuge! You might catch a glimpse of the unique wildlife along the riverside and that the first four miles of river are protected as both a National Scenic River and a National Wildlife Refuge.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Just keep floating and look out for a sign on your right that reads "Fort Falls Trail." 
The river is shallow on the floater's right, a great spot to pull off for a waterfall excursion.
To the floater's left at the same location is the Fort Falls Rapid.

stops.significance: The Fort Falls are a popular stop for many of our visitors because they are so easy to get to. Just a quick hike up from the water and you're shaded in the cool canyons that are home to waterfalls, deciduous and coniferous forests and hybrid species unique to our riverbanks.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue your float just around the riverbend and beyond. You'll pass under buffalo bridge be exiting the Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge just before the Berry Bridge and Berry Falls.

stops.significance: These small rapids might not even be noticeable, but they are on the floaters left, across from the Fort Falls Trail sign. They are Class I Rapids, just know that the current at the end of the rapid will want to spin your vessel to the left.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Pull your vessel off to the right onto the sandbar or riverbank for a quick detour to the Fort Falls, just follow the hiking trail up the stream to see these natural waters flow.

stops.significance: After exiting the Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge, you'll come across the Berry Bridge, a popular landing for floaters using private outfitters to make their trip possible. On the floater's right, there is a waterfall known as Berry Falls. See how the Falls are convex, they stick out? This formation is unique to the Niobrara River's waterfalls and you'll see it again later on the tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Enjoy the lazy nature of this section of river. No Rapids to look out for, but plenty of scenic views and canyon walls to marvel at. Soon you'll see the Allen Bridge, a signal that Smith Falls State Park is coming up quickly.

stops.significance:
On your right, there is a sign before the walking bridge for the Smith Falls Landing. You're going to want to pull off here and take another quick walk up to the Smith Falls, the tallest waterfalls in Nebraska!

Smith Falls State Park has been in existence longer that the Niobrara National Scenic River has been protected by the National Park Service.  The story of the Smith Falls is a great example of how deeply the people of the Niobrara River Valley care for and preserve the river and its features.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Jump back into your vessel and continue on! You'll pass under the walking bridge and see the campgrounds for the state park on your left, as you come around the curve, be quick! The Nickols Landing can sneak up on you. It is on the Floater's left.

stops.significance: Nickols Landing is a popular public access point for the Niobrara located at Smith Falls State Park. This is a great landing or launch point, or a good place to stop for lunch if you want to learn more about Smith Falls and stop in at their visitor center.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Just keep floating! Easy as that!

stops.significance:
Brewer Bridge is one of the most popular public access landings on the river. Many outfitters also use it to pick up or drop off floaters.

There is a bridge right before the landing on the floater's left. There are bathrooms, trash, and drinking water at this landing if you need to test out your land-legs before continuing downriver.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Jump back on your tube or boat and let the river take you where it wants!

stops.significance:
Conner Rapids are a good feature to note because it means that you are entering the section of river with more private landings and rapids.

Conner's Rapid is a class I rapid that beginners can handle. Stick to the floater's left and try to stay out of the middle where the water might hit both sides of the boat and make for a rougher ride.

Keep your eyes peeled for more challenging rapids over the next 10 river miles that you might need to portage - pull out and resume floating below.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Enjoy the peaceful waters and keep your eyes peeled for an island coming in just a bit.

As you come to the island, if you stay left, the ride is calm. If you go right, you'll float through Fritzes Island Rapid. Stay to the center. It's deeper than you think.

Note: Niobrara National Scenic River does not endorse nor preference any private businesses along the river corridor. Any names of private landings or locations are named for the convenience of the floater as landmark references for location orientation.

stops.significance:
These Class II Rapids will push your boundaries as a beginner, but no need to fear. Trust your vessel and know that you might get a little wet but you'll be just fine. 

Fritzes Island is a fun rapid and depending on depth, you might not think this one is a challenge!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the curve around the big bend, the next river feature might be unnoticeable.

stops.significance:
Fritzes Narrows are almost not visible and as a class I rapid, we have never had an issue sticking to the middle of the channel where the water is deepest to pass through these little rapids.

If the river is at the right height, you might not even notice these, so if you pass under the County Line Bridge, you've already passed them. You must be a good floater!
stops.directionsToNextStop:
There is quite a gap between the Fritzes Narrows and Rocky Ford but when the river makes a "U" shape, be ready to portage.

Note: Niobrara National Scenic River does not endorse nor preference any private businesses along the river corridor. Any names of private landings or locations are named for the convenience of the floater as landmark references for location orientation.

stops.significance:
Watch for the signs! Rocky Ford is a class III rapid that you're going to want to portage. You can follow the signs to pull out of the river on the floater's left and resume your float further downriver. 

Experienced floaters looking for an advanced experience can spend extra time here making laps in the whitewater.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Resume your float further down-river from the rapids. The next set of rapids is another spot you will need to portage on the floater's left just a few curves ahead.

stops.significance:
Look to your left! This is a portage point. You need to pull over and carry your vessel further downstream to continue. 

Egelhoff's Rapid is a class II+ and we do not recommend any beginners try tackling this feature.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next rapid on the river is much more fun! Float on to the class I Egelhoff's Narrows. They look like a chute that beginners should be okay to float.

stops.significance: One at a time now! The Egelhoff Narrows are a class I rapid that beginners can float, just know that there is a slight whirlpool effect at the end of the chute so stick to the main channel and be ready to ride that one out and get turned around again.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The river flows gently for awhile after this. Sit back and relax. You'll pass the Rock Barn Outfitters and landing before our next rapid of note.

The next rapid is a Class IV Norden Chute. You'll want to portage this one, so look for the signs.

stops.significance:
Portage Highly recommended. Floating the Norden Chute risks life and limb for all floaters, even those with vast experience.

The Norden Chute, while powerful and beautiful, is also dangerous. The water that flows over the chute circulates under the surface and has hydraulic sucking forces that you do not want to be caught in. There may also be debris and rebar under the waters of the Chute. 

Even the most experienced floaters should not attempt the Norden Chute.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Pull your vessel out at the portage point and carry it beyond the chute where it is safe to resume your float again.  And don't forget to stop for a picture and explore the next stop, the Niobrara Valley Preserve along the way!

stops.significance: Over the Norden Bridge and to the floater's right is the Niobrara Valley Preserve. The Preserve is open to the public and can be accessed by making the less the quarter-mile jaunt into the preserve headquarters and trailheads. There are hiking trails, information, and more for visitors to explore at the Nature Conservancy along the Niobrara River.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Resume your float below the Norden Chute and keep your wetsuit on, the eagle rapids are next and are a challenging river feature.

stops.significance: Eagle Rapids are the last featured rapids on the Niobrara NSR. These class II+ rapids are another portage and floaters can stay safe by bypassing them and continuing safely downstream.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Beyond this point in the river things become more braided and are less used. The channel changes every year. You will likely have to pull your vessel a few times to get into the proper channel from here out.

stops.significance: The Highway 7 Bridge is a public access point for floaters on the Eastern Niobrara River. There is a State of Nebraska, Wildlife Management Area on the floater's right, after the bridge, where primitive camping can be done. No fires are allowed here, but floaters can pull their vessels up the bank and into the trees in a pinch.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Highway 7 Bridge to the Highway 137 Bridge is about 15 river miles. This is the last protected length of the Niobrara National Scenic River.

stops.significance:
The Highway 137 Bridge is the end of the designated Niobrara National Scenic River. The landing and parking area is located on the floater's left, before the bridge.
Feb 2020 Note: This landing was damaged in 2019 and is awaiting repair by the NEDOT. Please check our alerts for more information.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Thank you so much for exploring the Niobrara National Scenic River! We hope you'll stop by our visitor center in Valentine, Nebraska and share photos of your experience by tagging #niobraransr on social media.

data.title: Rodeo Lagoon
data.description: The Rodeo Lagoon tour takes you on a 1.6 mile loop from the Marin Headlands Visitor Center around Rodeo Lagoon to Rodeo Beach, through Fort Cronkhite and back around to the Visitor Center. Along the way learn about endangered native plant and animal species, beach geology and some Headlands history.

stops.assetName: Marin Headlands Visitor Center and Rodeo Lagoon
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk to the western edge of the Visitor Center parking lot next to the bathrooms and continue west (left) along the Rodeo Lagoon/Coastal Trail to continue to the next tour point.
Continue on the Rodeo Lagoon/Coastal Trail to reach the next stop
Continue on the Rodeo Lagoon/Coastal Trail until you reach Rodeo Beach.
Continue along the beach, following the fence enclosing the lagoon.

Continue up Hagget St. until you reach Kirkpatrick St. and turn right. Follow the road east, past the Marin Headlands Nursery and Greenhouse, until you reach the Blue Whale Skeleton on the right, just off the road.
Head east towards Bunker Road, but take the trail south before getting to the intersection. The trail will lead you to a crosswalk where you can cross Mitchell Road back towards the lagoon.
Continue along the trail, heading east.
Continue to follow the trail along the lagoon as it bends around the corner, the next stop is at the small bridge overlooking the inlet to the lagoon.
Continue along the trail to the other side of the bridge.
Continue along the trail, and follow signs leading to the right, back to the Marin Headlands Visitor Center. There is a small boardwalk and short set of stairs to climb.
