images.altText: Lake Michigan Sunset Lake View 2018
images.caption: Sunset on Lake Michigan shoreline at Lake View, Indiana Dunes, Fall, 2018.

data.title: Saddle Rock Audio Tour
data.description: Learn more about the prairie ecosystem and geology of Scotts Bluff National Monument on this 1.6 mile long (one way) walking tour of the Saddle Rock Trail.

stops.significance: Learn more about the impression Scotts Bluff left on  emigrants travelling along the North Platte River Valley.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following the Saddle Rock Trail to the north east towards the trail's namesake: Saddle Rock.
stops.audioTranscript: The bluffs stimulated the curiosity of fur traders and emigrant travelers crossing the vast plains to find a place that had “something” to look at.  Often the bluffs reminded travelers of images of home; a crown or perhaps a dome shaped rock resembled buildings creating memories of civilization.  Many of these accounts can still be experienced through the numerous diaries left behind by the passerby of yester-year.  There has also been a scientific interest in these bluffs since the late 1890s when the U.S. Geological Survey made the first formal geologic investigation of the area.

stops.significance: Learn more about the prairie ecosystem that the emigrants travelled through.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue northeast on the trail to a location where a trickle of water flows under the trail through a culvert.
stops.audioTranscript:
Look around you.  You are surrounded by a small intact example of a mixed grass prairie ecosystem.  Approximately 40% of the 3,000 acres of the Scotts Bluff National Monument is mixed-grass prairie.  The prairie would have been a welcomed bounty of nourishment for the emigrant travelers’ livestock.  This prairie is dominated by black-root sedge, and needle-and-thread grass, both cool season species which makes up about 80% of the groundcover. 

If you look off to the west, beyond the Visitor Center you’ll see the geologic formation which led many emigrant travelers to renewed hope, Mitchell Pass.  It represented the completion of one-third of their total journey.  It also signified the end of the easy section, the level, monotonous great plains was completed and the difficult Rocky Mountains lay ahead.  The pass was continuously used beginning in 1851 as the main route through these bluffs.  Prior to 1851, the emigrants would have used Robidoux Pass; by switching to Mitchell Pass they shaved a day’s travel off their journey.

stops.significance: Learn about the geologic forces that have shaped Scotts Bluff.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue up the trail, ascending to the base of a sandstone cliff. Here you will find a tunnel that has been carved into the rock.
stops.audioTranscript:
The creation of this land is millions of years in the making.   An ancient inland sea, referred to as the Cretaceous Sea, once covered this region and began to recede about 65 million years ago.  At the same time as the ancient sea’s recession major uplifting occurred creating the modern Rocky Mountains.  This uplifting would continue sporadically until recent geologic time.  The Rocky Mountains would supply much of the materials needed to create the Great Plains.  

Deposits of sand and mud from wind and streams created the layers of sandstone and siltstone you see at the base of the bluffs.  Wind deposits of volcanic ash are seen represented in layers further up the bluff in contrasting colors.   Supersaturated groundwater rich in lime formed the limestone layers near the top of the bluff; these limestone deposits are often referred to as pipey concretions and act as a hard cap rock for the softer sand and siltstone below it.  We will have a close look at these various layers as we move along the trail.  

Before we move on take a look at the groundwater spring next to the trail, did you notice there is a lot more vegetation here than across the prairie?  Scotts Spring is the only natural spring within the Monument and provides much coveted water to animals and plant life alike.  

This spring represents a connection to the ancient past through water related geologic deposition and erosion.  It also represents a connection with the not so distant past of the emigrant traveler.  The spring was first recorded in pioneer diaries as a place to find clear drinking water as compared to the often muddy water of the North Platte River.  Many families would use the Scotts Bluff area as an overnight location and were very thankful for clear-clean drinking water.  

As you move towards stop number four you’ll notice that you are beginning to climb the fanned base of the bluff.  Take your time and watch as the sandstone and siltstone base begins to change slightly as you climb in elevation.

stops.significance: Learn how the forces of deposition and erosion of sediments have shaped Scotts Bluff.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue through the tunnel, then ascend the switchbacks to a flat area overlooking what appear to be sandstone chimneys.
stops.audioTranscript:
Go ahead and stop here before walking through the tunnel.  If you look to the left of the tunnel along the rock face you will see what is called “breakdown”.  This is a good example of the effects erosional forces have on the sand and siltstone which makes up the majority of the bluff.  Wind and water have over time sliced away a portion of the rock that was connecting this to the rest of the bluff.  Erosion of the bluff occurs slowly and is usually unseen by humans.  Wind, rain, and snow wears the bluff away.  It slowly washes away grains and particles of sand, silt and ash.  Most of the rock slides that occur in the park happen within this the Brule Formation.  The Brule Formation is large and makes up one third of the exposed rock of the bluffs.  

Now look above the tunnel entrance.  Do you notice the thick band of volcanic ash?  It’s a whitish color on top and a brownish color on the bottom.  This layer is several feet thick in some places.  Between 28 to 32 million years ago, massive volcanic eruptions occurred in mountain ranges west of here, some as far away as present day Nevada.   Ash from these eruptions was carried eastward by winds.  It then fell as ashfall on what would one day be western Nebraska.  

Go ahead and walk through the tunnel.  Try to imagine what it would have been like for the young men who built this trail and hand dug this tunnel.  Yep, I said hand dug.  The rock formations here are so fragile and so easily eroded that the decision was made to have the walking trail tunnel hand dug rather than dynamited.

stops.significance: Learn more about the geologic forces that have shaped, and continue to shape Scotts Bluff.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail up to the top of the bluff. At the upper end of the trail, take a right and check out the view from the overlook behind the stone wall.
stops.audioTranscript:
You have just been walking alongside the geologic formation referred to as the Gering Formation.  It may be difficult to tell the layers apart.  As you move further up the trail you will begin to see more changes in the rock types that you are seeing.  

Look out at Saddle Rock; it’s a different perspective from up here.  Did you notice the breakdown in front of you?  Now turn around and look at the rock face.  It almost appears as if the sandstone was sheared off of the rock face.  In October of 2000 there was a major rock slide which resulted in a 1,200 ton block of sandstone sloughing off onto the Saddle Rock Trail.  

Ultimately the massive rock had to be broken down to smaller manageable sized boulders; this was accomplished by the use of dynamite the following May.  Several small charges were set to minimize the impact on the surrounding resources.  The blasting left the park with a 2,000 ton pile of debris.    The trail remained closed for nearly a year due to the slide.  

As you continue up the trail from here you will begin to notice a great deal of gray colored rock protruding from the cliff side.   Go ahead and reach out and touch some of it.  Now compare that feeling to the sandstone that it surrounds.  It’s much harder isn’t it?  These are limestone concretions.  Sometimes the concretions are referred to as pipey concretions indicating the way in which they were deposited.  The pipey concretions have not formed in one continuous layer but rather are found in different shapes and sizes.  Another name for the limestone is cap rock.  This refers to location of the deposition, near the top of the bluffs…capping it off.  The cap rock acts as a protective layer for the bottom portions of the bluff; much like the roof protects your house.  Since it is much harder it can withstand weathering a longer than the sand and siltstone below.  

Continue walking, you are nearing the top of the bluff.  At the top you will be able to dial in for stop number six; your final stop along this tour.

stops.significance: The view from the overlooks here are expansive. On a clear day one can see Chimney Rock, 23 miles to the east and Laramie Peak, over 100 miles to the west.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop on the Saddle Rock Audio Tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
From up here you can see the expanse of the valley.  The North Platte River has been working on carving out what you see below you for millions of years.  You are 800’ above the river from here and 435 feet above the Visitor Center.  Geologists believe that the top of the bluffs is approximately 22 million years old.  At the base of bluffs is where you would find the oldest exposed formations, dating back 33 million years.  Historically speaking the bluffs are very old, but in geologic time the bluffs are relatively young.  About 4 to 5 million years ago the rate of erosion exceeded that of sediment deposition leaving behind the landscape we know as the Great Plains today.   

The geology of Scotts Bluff is significant for scientific and historic reasons. Emigrants typically traveled along the Platte River Valley using both sides of the river.  At Scotts Bluff the geology of the badlands forced the emigrants out of the valley. The badlands presented a barrier to travel because they stretched from the base of the bluff to the river.  The bluff formations forced the travelers to look for a pass to allow them to move through the bluffs and continue on their westward journey.  To see the badlands and what the emigrants were trying to avoid, walk out to the North Over which adjoins with this trail.   

These bluffs hold the secrets of time and have witnessed the vast travels of man.  The bluffs are now witnessing your journey and the journey of all the visitors who come to this National Monument.  Please help us preserve and protect this place and stories it holds by passing on your story of your visit here friends and neighbors.

images.title: Hiking up Saddle Rock Trail
images.altText: A pair of hikers ascends a paved walking trail up a sandstone bluff.
images.caption: Learn more about Scotts Bluff on the Saddle Rock Audio Tour.

data.title: Saddle Rock Geology Hiking Tour
data.description: The Saddle Rock Trail, a 1.6 mile paved trail with 435 of elevation change, features the most accessible exposures of the Arikaree and White River Groups in western Nebraska. A wide variety of sedimentary structures, diagenetic features, trace fossils, and volcaniclastic sediments can be seen along the trail. This tour is based upon the Geological Society of America Centennial Field Guide, North-Central Section developed in 1987 by James B. Swimehart and David B. Loope.

stops.assetName: Stop 1: The Orella badlands from the North Overlook
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the North Overlook, retrace your steps back towards the summit parking area. Take the east portion of each loop to the start of the Saddle Rock Trail.
From the Saddle Rock Trailhead, head down the Saddle Rock Trail to the second switchback.
From the Ash Lens, head down the Saddle Rock Trail to the concrete stairs.
From the concrete stairs, head down the trail about 75 feet. You will see a lens of volcanic ash in the rock cliff to the left of the trail.
Head down the trail to the next major bend in the trail. Just past the major bend, look at the rock cliff to the left of the trail.
Head down the trail. In between the second and third switchbacks on the north side of the bluff, look for crystals in the rock.
Head further down the trail to just before the foot tunnel.
Head down the trail to the next switchback at the head of a canyon.
Head 700 feet down the trail. Look across the ravine to the cliff face at Saddle Rock.
Head down trail out of the ravine. The next stop is an area of lush, green vegetation in the summer. In the winter, a trickle of water may be seen to the right of the trail.

images.title: A Ranger Points Out Geologic Features
images.altText: A park ranger points to a rock cliff while a group of people observes.
images.caption: The Saddle Rock Trail features some very interesting geology.

data.title: Sagamore Hill Self-Guided Grounds Walk
data.description: Explore the outdoors at Sagamore Hill! This tour features several stops of significance to the Roosevelt Family, such as the Roosevelt Home, the pet cemetery, Old Orchard, and the beach on Cold Spring Harbor. This tour is approximately 1.7 miles long and can take one or two hours to complete. Most of the paths are paved, with dirt sections on the carriage path and nature trail. The nature trail section, which begins adjacent to Old Orchard, has moderately steep sections and some beach walking.

stops.significance: Located along the main walking path leading to the Roosevelt Home, this wayside exhibit shows an illustrated aerial depiction the buildings and fields of the Sagamore Hill property circa 1918. It serves as the first stop on the self-guided audio tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk south in the direction of the Roosevelt Home. Stay along the paved path to the left and turn right at sign that reads "Roosevelt Home."
stops.audioTranscript: Sagamore Hill was a typical Long Island country estate of the 1880s. The main house consists of twenty-three rooms, which had grounds to the west and south maintained with lawns and ornamental plantings which compliment the sweeping views and approach of the driveway. To the rear of the house is the servants’ area, a drying yard for laundry, the ice house, and the back porch, where servants would work in warm weather and deliveries would be received. Beyond a screening hedge was a large stable building attached to a lodge where the male servants lived. As one moves away from the house toward the east, the character of the landscape changes to farmland. Under the windmill was a cornfield. What is today a parking lot, was pasture and grain fields. There was a cow barn and other smaller structures used for storage of equipment. There were work areas and outhouses. To the north of the barn and east of the stables were the gardens. Much of the food eaten at Sagamore Hill was grown here. Besides food, the garden also provided a multitude of flowers, which decorated the home. Beyond the farm and through the pasture is the apple orchard, which predates Theodore Roosevelt’s ownership of the property. As one moves down the hill towards Cold Spring Harbor, the cultured landscape gives way to forest, then to a salt marsh which merges with the bay.

stops.significance: Sagamore Hill was the home of Theodore Roosevelt, 26th President of the United States, from 1885 until his death in 1919. The home served as the “Summer White House” during Roosevelt’s presidency. The Queen Anne or shingle style house has 23 rooms and sits atop the highest point on Cove Neck, affording the family a view of Oyster Bay harbor to the west (which today is blocked by trees across the road). Roosevelt was most concerned with comfort and function rather than style or grandeur when planning the house and wanted a large "piazza" or porch facing the water, a library and parlor, plenty of bedrooms for family and guests, and large fireplaces. The rooms of the home are filled with mementos of Roosevelt’s many hunting trips, gifts from around the world, and reminders of his major accomplishments as a soldier and statesman.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk south from the front of the house following a paved path that leads to a dirt trail marked with a "carriage path" sign. Take this path to a clearing with an exhibit sign and bench. This area was the tennis court.
stops.audioTranscript: As you approach the house you are looking at the back of it. Architecturally, the house is an example of a shingle-style, Queen Anne design. The first floor is brick, with the upper floors covered in patterned wood shingles. TR contracted the architects, Lamb and Rich, to design his house. He sketched out the desired arrangement of rooms on the first floor and emphasized the large porch and a multitude of fireplaces. There were few changes made to the house over the years. The most dramatic change was the 1905 addition of the north room. This allowed TR to better accommodate the large groups that came to Sagamore Hill to meet with him. The iron pipes that frame the exterior of the room were used as trellis for wisteria, a climbing vine with fragrant purple flowers. This same vine covered the porte cochére at the front of the house. The front of the house is the most detailed and attractive side. Notice the colored glass panels over the windows and front door. The large terra cotta sunflower medallions are symbolic of happiness. Similar medallions appear on fireplaces inside the house. Notice the elk antlers at the peak of the house. This is TR’s own embellishment. In warm weather the porch, or “piazza” as the family called it, was used as a sitting area and dinner was sometimes served there. TR could often be found sitting in a rocking chair reading or engaged in conversation with visitors. Alice remembered that her father would sometimes rock so vigorously that he would move dangerously close to the edge of the porch. The arrangement of the piazza was changed once the north room was added. A stair was removed from the west side and the deck was extended. The rail was not replaced so that TR had a ready-made platform for addressing the groups that came to see him. It was on the piazza where he formally excepted the nomination for governor of New York State, and vice-president and president of the United States. Groups that came to hear him speak ranged from boy scouts to college students, from suffragettes, to the citizens of Nassau county.

stops.significance: The site of the Roosevelt’s tennis court was located near present-day Sagamore Hill Road. Theodore and the rest of the Roosevelt family enjoyed friendly competition in this shady spot at the bottom of the hill, often making up their own special rules of the game, which allowed for a “let” if a ball that might have landed fairly hit an overhanging branch. There are no known photographs of Theodore Roosevelt playing tennis – he believed that the game was considered a sport for society’s elite and a photo of him engaged in a match might spoil his public image.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on to the sidewalk along Sagamore Hill Road, walking uphill until you come to a cut trail in the meadow. Take that trail up a small incline to the rose arbor (with benches) and the gravel patch with the large memorial stone.
stops.audioTranscript: Here at Sagamore Hill, tennis was a recreational sport enjoyed by every member of the Roosevelt family.  Theodore Roosevelt himself was an avid sportsman and led an active life.  As a young boy, his father once told him, “Theodore, you have the mind but not the body” and encouraged him to regularly exercise in order to build up his strength as a way to overcome his asthma. While at Harvard, Theodore Roosevelt, with the help of his friends, learned how to play tennis.  He admitted that although he was not very good at the game, he enjoyed the competitive nature of the sport.  As president, he insisted that no photographs be taken of him while playing tennis because he thought the game was an elitist sport played by the wealthy. The Roosevelt family had their own special rules for the game of tennis.  The boundary lines were what the family decided that day.  As you look at the area where the tennis court once was, you will notice that it’s a very wooded area.  If the ball hit a branch of a tree, it was still considered in play.  The Roosevelt’s tennis court was not smooth by today’s standards, and the ball would often go in various directions; not necessarily in the direction the player wanted it to go.  The Roosevelt children also enjoyed the game of tennis.  Ted Jr., the oldest son, even went on to play tennis competitively at Harvard.  The family’s tennis racquets were kept in the home’s entrance hall fireplace and the tennis balls were kept in two jars above the mantle.  The children would grab as many balls as they could fit into their pockets because many a ball went off into the woods, never to be found again.  They would frequently drag their father down to the court to play with them as often as they could. While living in Washington DC, Theodore Roosevelt would always try to get a couple of hours of daily exercise which might include a match of tennis with friends.  Many of the friends TR would play with at the White House were cabinet members, and became known as the “Tennis Cabinet.”

stops.significance: The Roosevelt family had a menagerie of pets including dogs, guinea pigs, horses, and even a badger. Many of their pets were buried at the pet cemetery, in a shady spot north of the Roosevelt Home. Some of the pets had their names engraved on a stone under the heading of "Faithful Friends," though there were many more animal companions buried here than are named on the memorial.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the gravel path south, towards the Roosevelt home and take the first left towards the garden. Continue past the privet hedge until the gravel path reaches the paved path and turn left. The site of the garden is the grassy area opposite the carriage house and chicken shed.
stops.audioTranscript: The Pet Cemetery, which is located a short distance from the northwest corner of the Roosevelt’s home is where the Roosevelt family laid to rest some of their most beloved pets. The Roosevelt family had a wide variety of pets while living here at Sagamore hill. They ranged from dogs, horses, rabbits, guinea pigs and chickens, to a badger named Josiah, a bear cub named Jonathan Edwards and oldest daughter Alice’s green snake, known to the family as “Emily Spinach.” Adjacent to the arbor is a large stone inscribed with the names of special pets who are buried here. Of particular note is Jack, a Chesapeake Bay Terrier who was Edith Roosevelt’s favorite dog.  While living in Washington DC, Jack was tragically killed by a passing vehicle and was buried at the White House. At the end of TR’s presidency, Edith requested that Jack’s remains be returned here to Sagamore Hill where he was reburied along with other household pets. Also buried here is “Little Texas”, the horse that Theodore Roosevelt rode during the Spanish American war along with the Rough Riders. The total number of pets buried here is unknown, but the really special ones, usually the horses and dogs, received a full funeral precession, complete with a cart. All of the children would dress in their Sunday best, and say prayers for their dearly departed pets.  The smaller animals would be given private burials by the individual child who cared for the pet.  As Ted Junior once said in a letter: “One of Kermit’s guinea pigs died last night and he buried him in the pet cemetery this morning. It was a private affair.”

stops.significance: The Roosevelt's garden was located on three acres north and west of what is now the parking lot. The family grew vegetables, such as potatoes, beans, lettuce and carrots, as well as fruits such as berries, grapes, peaches, and plums. In addition to food for the table, Mrs. Roosevelt kept a cutting garden for decorative flowers to adorn the Roosevelt home. The structure near the the present-day road was the gardener's shed, where gardener Alfred Davis lived and worked tending to the fruits and vegetables while keeping the Roosevelt children from trampling the flowers and eating too many berries.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved path and gravel path past the parking lot in an eastern direction. Old Orchard is a large brick building just past the open pastures.
stops.audioTranscript: The original garden at Sagamore Hill was not a formal garden. It was simply rows of vegetables and berries used for the table, and flowers which provided decoration in the home. The crabapple trees and the boxwood shrub are historic. The boxwood was grown from a cutting that TR brought home from Abraham Lincoln’s birthplace. One reminder of the garden, is the gardener’s shed, located on the edge of the property. This was used to store tools, seeds, and everything else needed by the gardener. The building was also used to store firewood. There was an area of the garden set aside for children called “the baby’s walk.” Each child had a small plot where he or she learned to grow their favorite vegetables. TR’s wife Edith enjoyed flowers and there were roses and other cut flowers throughout the house. She liked to have floral centerpieces for the dining room table. Her husband did not. He would say, “I married you for your looks and I cannot see you through this mass of foliage.” The flowers came in many varieties, including bell flowers, sunflowers, larkspur, and cabbage roses. The garden provided most of the vegetables for the kitchen. Fruits cultivated included plums, peaches, gooseberries, cherries, a variety of grapes, strawberries, and raspberries. The garden produced corn, asparagus, cantaloupes, and watermelon. The berries were a favorite of the children and although they were not allowed to gorge freely, the temptation was sometimes too much. One of the gardeners was a man named Davis. He lived in the lodge, adjacent to the garden. When the children overstepped the boundaries of the garden, he would holler at them, “Leave it be!” After many such incidents, the admonishment became his nickname: “Old Leave-it-be.”

stops.significance: Formerly the residence of Theodore Roosevelt Jr, the home now serves as a visitor center and museum. Ted and his wife Eleanor Alexander Roosevelt built the house they called “Old Orchard” in 1937-1938 on four acres of land purchased from Ted’s mother in the Sagamore Hill apple orchard.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Stay to the right of the brick building and take the dirt path through the woods.
stops.audioTranscript: Theodore Roosevelt Junior and his wife, Eleanor Alexander Roosevelt, built the house they called “Old Orchard” in 1938 on land purchased from Ted’s mother. The Georgian-style house was designed by Baltimore architect William G. McMillan Jr. “It had always been the family plan for Ted to inherit Sagamore Hill,” recalled Mrs. Roosevelt. “By 1937, we’d been married for 27 years and we were tired of living here and there.” The elegant home was filled with mementos of world travel, including Chinese furniture collected by Eleanor in the 1920s. Also prominent were reminders of Ted’s service in the infantry during the Great War and his varied public career. A successful soldier and leader, Lieutenant Colonel Roosevelt participated at the allied offensive at the Somme in 1918. He received the Distinguished Service Cross and the French Croix de Guerre for his valor. As the war wound down, he and other like-minded American soldiers formed the American Legion to carry forward the camaraderie and the spirit of the doughboys in civilian life. After the war, Ted launched his public career in 1919 as a member of the New York State Assembly. His career included the position of Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Governor of Puerto Rico, and Governor General of the Philippines. He wrote books about his experiences in the Great War, his expedition to China, and his family life. In addition to his stock investments, Ted worked as a publisher and as a chairman of the board of the American Express Company. A seasoned combat veteran, General Roosevelt played a critical role on Utah Beach during the D-Day invasion. Due to an unexpected current and the confusion of battle, the first troops ashore were landed nearly a mile away from the planned landing zone. By making the spot decision, “We’ll start the war from here!” and improvising the orders for all successive landing waves, Roosevelt made order from chaos. On July 12, 1944, Ted Jr. died of heart failure during the allied drive across France. He was awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously. A year before his death, Ted wrote home to Eleanor on the occasion of their wedding anniversary: “Nothing has happened as we imagined it would except our children. We never thought we’d roam the world. We never thought our occupations and interests would cover such a range. We never thought that our 33rd anniversary would find us deep in our second war and me again at the front. Well darling, we’ve lived up to the most.” Eleanor Roosevelt continued to live at Old Orchard until her death in May 1960.

stops.significance: Explore the woodlands and beach of Sagamore Hill on the nature trail. The trail is a 0.7 mile loop of easy to moderate difficulty that leads through an oak-tulip forest to a salt marsh and beach. Visitors can see a variety of wildlife such as songbirds, herons, egrets, osprey, bald eagles, fiddler crabs, white-tail deer, and ducks depending on the season. This short trail includes some steep uphill and downhill sections.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the dirt trail, staying to the right at the fork, eventually walking downhill past a kettle pond. At the bottom of the hill is a footbridge leading across a marsh to the beach.
stops.audioTranscript: The nature trail of Sagamore Hill was one of several paths used by the Roosevelts and was linked to an informal network of bridle paths that covered the north shore of Long Island. Paths such as this one would have been used by the Roosevelt family to access the beach at Cold Spring Harbor. The most important feature of this area for Theodore Roosevelt was the abundant wildlife, especially the birds. As a young man, his family rented a summer house approximately halfway between Cove Neck and the village of Oyster Bay. Always fascinated by the natural world, Theodore Roosevelt would often hunt birds and add the specimens to his extensive collection. Another reason that the young Theodore Roosevelt was attracted to Cove Neck was that it provided an abundance of opportunity for outdoor recreation, such as hiking, swimming, rowing, horseback riding, and chopping wood. These activities quickly became an important part of the young Theodore Roosevelt’s life. Aside from the disappearance of chestnut trees, the forest that surrounds the nature trail has been relatively undisturbed since Theodore Roosevelt’s time here at Sagamore Hill. The existing forest consists of larger tulip, oak, and hickory trees, while the smaller subcanopy trees are mostly sassafras, beech, dogwood, spicebush, and a variety of viburnum shrubs. About three-quarters of the way down the hill, you will encounter a small kettle pond, which is a geological feature associated with the glacial retreat that formed Long Island about 15,000 years ago. As the glacial ice receded, kettle-shaped depressions were left on the surface of the land. Theodore Roosevelt himself referred to this pond as “Heron Pond” because of the Night Herons that nested here. Used by many species of frogs and salamanders for breeding, there are no fish in this pond. On hot days however, keep an eye out for box turtles which may be wallowing in the mud.

stops.significance: On the easternmost boundary of Sagamore Hill lies Eel Creek and Cold Spring Harbor. Eel Creek is a saltwater tidal creek and salt marsh which is home to marsh grass, mollusks, crabs, fish, and wading birds. On the opposite side of the footbridge is a beach on the western shore of Cold Spring Harbor and Oyster Bay National Wildlife Refuge. During the Roosevelt family's time here, they maintained a footbridge, a shack for changing into swimming attire, and a shed to store rowboats. The children enjoyed swimming and playing in the sand, while TR's favorite activity was rowing.
stops.assetName: Eel Creek and Cold Spring Harbor
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the final stop on the self-guided tour. To return to the parking lot, cross the bridge and turn right on the dirt path. Continue uphill, arriving again at the trailhead. Walk past Old Orchard and turn right on the gravel path. This path leads to the parking lot.
stops.audioTranscript: The beach area at Sagamore Hill is protected by the US Fish and Wildlife Service. The Eel Creek salt marsh is a perfect example of the tidal marshes that were once a common feature of the Long Island coastline. At high tide the marsh fills with salt water, which then drains back into the harbor as the tide recedes. Many species of fish and mollusks utilize this salt marsh for spawning, as it will protect their young from predators. The tall grass is known as cordgrass, or spartina alterniflora, and is typical of local salt marshes. The roots of this tall grass will hold the fine sediment in place providing a valuable ecological service that helps prevent erosion. The beach is on the western shore of Cold Spring Harbor. To the north is the mouth of Oyster Bay Harbor which feeds into the Long Island Sound towards Connecticut. It is common to see gulls and kingfishers in all seasons, and in the summer you may see osprey, herons, and cormorants, while in the winter, rafts of ducks, loons, and the occasion snowy owl may be spotted. The only structures that the Roosevelts maintained on the beach were a footbridge over the salt marsh, a small shack for changing into swimming attire, and a shed for storing rowboats. There was also a swimming float anchored just offshore.

images.title: Grounds Walk
images.altText: A park ranger points to a large gray and brick colored house with several visitors nearby.
images.caption: Explore the outdoors at Sagamore Hill!

data.title: Saints Tour of Kalawao and Kalaupapa
data.description: This self-paced tour consists of a series of stops related to Saint Damien and Saint Marianne along a 3+ mile route. The tour includes locations in Kalawao, outside of the Kalaupapa Settlement. Please only go to those tour stops if you are allowed outside the settlement. Be cautious if walking on the side of the street and yield to oncoming traffic. Always be respectful of residents' privacy and heed Kalawao County rules. To help with navigation, download a map app for offline use before starting the tour.

stops.significance: St. Francis church is the most commonly used Catholic Church in the settlement, though Mass is still held once a month at St. Philomena in Kalawao. St. Francis and the congregation pay homage to Saint Marianne and Saint Damien with statues, art, and weekly prayers.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The next stop is Bishop Home to the south of St. Francis. From St. Francis Church head up Beretania Street past the post office then turn right onto Puahi Street just past the State Office. Bishop Home is at the corner of Puahi Street, School Street, and Bishop Road. 

For the directions to each of the next stops, we will occasionally provide cardinal directions (north, east, south, and west). Some helpful tips are that the ocean will generally be to your west when you are in the Kalaupapa Settlement. East is away from the ocean when in the Kalaupapa Settlement. When in Kalawao, the ocean is to the east. The tip of the peninsula will be to your north, the pali will be to your south.

The next stop is Mother Marianne's Grave just down the street to the south of Bishop Home. Walk south on Puahi Street and look for the sign to Mother Marianne's Grave on the east side of the street. If you get to the next road intersection with Puahi Street and Damien Street, then you have gone too far. 

As you walk around the settlement, remember to stay along the side of the street. Vehicles have the right of way in Kalaupapa and pedestrians and cyclists must yield to vehicular traffic by moving completely off the street. Roads are not busy, but stay aware and be on the lookout for cars.

The next stop is Father Damien's Monument. It is right down Puahi Street to the south at the corner of Puahi and School Street. It's only about 150 feet from the entrance to Mother Marianne's Grave and it is on the same side of the street at Mother Marianne's Grave.

stops.significance: A monument erected to celebrate Saint Damien and his legacy.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is St. Philomena Church in Kalawao. To get there you will need to head back down Puahi Street to the north, towards the center of the Kalaupapa Settlement. At the State Office, turn right onto Beretania Street which becomes Damien Road. Head down this road for about 2.5 miles. This road leaves the Kalaupapa Settlement so only continue onto these last two stops of the tour if you are permitted to leave the settlement. The road also becomes unpaved and remains unpaved for about 2 miles. If you are walking or biking you should also note that there is about 500 feet of elevation gain. St. Philomena will be on the north side of the road.

The next stop is Father Damien's Grave just outside of St. Philomena to the east by only 10 feet. The grave is located in the small cemetery next to the church building. It is one of the closest graves to the road and is the largest gravesite.

images.title: Statue at Mother Marianne's Grave
images.altText: A statue with two men, one is on a cross.
images.caption: The statue at Mother Marianne's Grave.

data.title: San Juan Island Salmon Tour
data.description: Coast Salish people have fished in the waters off of San Juan Island since time immemorial. The first trade between Euro-Americans and Native people on this island was for preserved salmon. In the 19th and 20th centuries a major fish preserving industry grew, prospered, and declined on San Juan Island. This tour explores the ecological causes for this industry, the Native Americans, European and Asian immigrants, and old island families who were a part of this industry.

park.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
park.name: San Juan Island

stops.significance:
In 2007, Bill Jakle who grew up in this area, "remember[ed] [that] when I was a kid they had 60 men, at least, on those lifting places. And they had cookhouses and bunkhouses on South Beach."  

Little remains of this thriving f industry, but San Juan Island's abundant fishery has provided income and sustenance for thousands of years. Coast Salish people lived for thousands of years in what are today’s park lands, where numerous people fished for salmon and halibut and preserved their surplus for trade and winter sustenance. Hudson's Bay Company traders first came to San Juan to purchase excess fish from the Tribes who lived and thrived here for generations. 

 In the late 19th century, enhanced canning technology attracted big business to the Salmon Bank. Major corporations, such as the Alaska Packers Association employed fishermen, purchased fish from locals, and canned their haul on this island. Though the yield has declined substantially, if you look to these waters in summer, you can see fishing boats.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk the Coastal Bluffs Trail for a hundred yards until you reach a large and prominent rock.

stops.significance:
This rock takes its name from the Alaska Packers Association (APA), a major corporation/cartel that set prices and production quotas in the salmon industry. The APA was one of three major corporations that by the early 20th century came to dominate the salmon industry and deplete fish populations on San Juan Island.  

 The fish traps that these corporations built demanded large amounts of capital and labor to operate. Their extreme efficiency made independent fishing less profitable, and corporations took much of the harvest that Coast Salish and independent Euro-American fishers once caught. 

 

Nonetheless, corporate fisheries provided opportunities for local people. Their canneries purchased the fish caught by independent fishing entrepreneurs like Henry Cayou, hired local men and women to work in their salmon operations, and purchased supplies from local farmers.

The fishing industry's extreme efficiency decimated the salmon stocks. With less fish in the water, the salmon industry declined.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue about 3/4 of a mile on the Coastal Bluffs Trail until you reach Grandma's Cove where you will walk down a stairway to the beach.

stops.significance:
This protected cove was used by Coast Salish people prior to and after the settlement of the island for reef net fishing. Reef netting is a unique form of indigenous fishing developed by indigenous Coast Salish Tribes in the San Juan Islands.  

Reef net fishing sites use two parallel canoes with an attached net between them. Cedar bark rope interspersed with eelgrass is attached to the nets and canoes, creating an artificial topography that makes the net itself appear to be the ocean floor. This technology lured the salmon into swimming up and into the net where they were trapped. When the net grew sufficiently full, Tribal fishermen pulled up the net, catching dozens of fish at one time.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps to the top of the entrance to Grandma's Cove. Continue uphill to the American Camp Parade Ground and turn right, taking the South Beach Trail back to your vehicle. Drive to Cattle Point Road, take a left on False Bay Drive until you reach the False Bay Preserve

stops.significance:
At this site, Henry Cayou, a Coast Salish entrepreneur, operated the most successful independent fish trap in the San Juan fishing industry in the early 20th century.  Bill Jakle, who grew up in the fishing industry, called Cayou, "a rich Indian" because of his successful trip which allowed him "to catch king salmon headed for the Fraser River. Sometimes he'd get 20 ton lifts." 

 Though Cayou often sold his fish to the major fish packing companies, he also owned his own cannery on Lopez Island. He was also a successful local politician and was responsible for bringing electricity to the San Juan Islands by founding the Orcas Power and Light Corporation. 

Today, the Cayou Channel between Orcas Island and Shaw Island is named after him to honor his impact on our community. Numerous Cayou descendants live in the San Juan Islands. Henry Cayou's historical legacy demonstrates the prominent and important role that the fishing industry played in our community in the early 20th century.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to Cattle Point Road and turn left. At Argyle Avenue, turn right. In a few blocks, turn right on Pear Point road. In a short distance, you will see Jackson Beach to your right, turn right to Jackson Beach.

stops.significance:
From this site, as you look south, you will notice a hulking abandoned industrial building. This structure, constructed in the early 20th century by local farmer John M. Jackson was one of the salmon canneries that processed and preserved fish from our island's waters. 

 

San Juan Island's fish canneries took advantage of the abundant local salmon harvest, packing the best and freshest fish for sale in distant markets. At the peak of the industry, nearly 1,000 people worked in the salmon canneries, making it one of the island's major employers. To get such a large amount of labor to the island, the packeries employed individuals who were normally discriminated against in the industry due to their race or ethnicity. In the late 19th century, it employed Chinese men and Native American women and in the early 20th century, Japanese immigrants made up much of the workforce. 

Imagine this building in its prime:  filled with 100s of workers, thousands of salmon, and the machines that canned and preserved  them.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to Argyle Avenue. Turn Right on Argyle Avenu and follow it to the roundabout where it dead ends on Spring Street. Turn Right on Spring Street, follow Spring Street to First Street, turn  left and in two blocks you will reach The Whale Museum

stops.significance:
Here at the Whale Museum, you can learn about Southern Resident Killer Whales, a critically endangered species whose health and population numbers rely upon healthy salmon populations. Southern Residents rely primarily on chinook salmon as a food source, requiring about 400 pounds of salmon per day to maintain their health. They spend several months every summer and fall in our waters, so the health of the salmon population is critical to their survival and recovery. 

 Southern Residents' mouth structure has evolved differently than other killer whales to facilitate salmon hunting; unlike Biggs Killer Whales, they do not hunt for or eat seals or sea lions. Their salmon consumption is so immense that scientists believe that killer whales consume more salmon than seals, sea lions, and commercial fisheries. While salmon populations have increased moderately in the past 50 years, the health of Southern Residents is a major factor that regulates the legal limit for salmon fishing in our island.

images.title: Salmon Cannery Floor, Friday Harbor
images.altText: Black and white photograph of an industrial floor filled to overflowing with salmon
images.caption: San Juan Island's seemingly limitless fish resources led to a thriving salmon canning industry

Visitors are required to stay on the designated island trail system. No off-trail hiking is permitted. Entering other areas without a ranger is a violation of federal law.

data.title: Sandburg's Hobo Journey
data.description: Carl Sandburg spent six months traveling across the Midwest by train. Along the way he made observations about the people and landscapes he saw. Take a virtual journey along with Sandburg to the cities he visited on his Midwest Hobo Journey!

park.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
park.name: Carl Sandburg Home

stops.directionsToNextStop: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro
stops.audioTranscript: Follow Carl Sandburg's hobo journey, beginning in his hometown of Galesburg, Illinois and ending in Omaha, Nebraska. Visit the cities below to learn about Sandburg's time riding the rails. Library of Congress images used below are for historical context only and do not depict Carl Sandburg or people he knew.

stops.assetName: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro

stops.directionsToNextStop: Keokuk, Iowa
stops.audioTranscript: Galesburg was Carl Sandburg's hometown - where his hobo journey began and ended. In Sandburg's autobiography "Always the Young Strangers" he wrote: The family didn’t like the idea. Papa scowled. Mama kissed me and her eyes had tears after dinner one noon when I walked out of the house with my hands free, no bag or bundle, wearing a black-sateen shirt, coat, vest, and pants, a slouch hat, good shoes and socks, no underwear, in my pockets a small bar of soap, a razor, a comb, a pocket mirror, two handkerchiefs, a piece of string, needles and thread, a Waterbury watch, a knife, a pipe and a sack of tobacco, three dollars and twenty-five cents in cash. A little west of the Santa Fe station stood a freight train. A conductor came out of the station and waved a yellow flimsy in his hand. As the train started I ran along and jumped into a boxcar. From then on I stood at the open side door, watched the running miles of young corn, reading such station names as Cameron and Stronghurst, names of villages and towns I had heard a thousand times and had never had sight of.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Bean Lake, Missouri
stops.audioTranscript: His arrival in Keokuk marked the first time Sandburg had ventured outside the state of Illinois. He later remembered seeing the Mississippi River for the first time as one of the most awe-inspring sites on his whole journey. Crossing the long bridge over the Mississippi my eyes swept over it with a sharp hunger that the grand old river satisfied. A captain of a small steamboat offered the young Sandburg passage to Keokuk for work "shouldering kegs of nails to the wharves." It was in Keokuk that Sandburg met his first fellow hobo. This man was a "tramp," which meant he didn't work for money, but instead relied on the kindness of strangers to survive. He taught Sandburg that a "lump" meant food that was given as a handout, and "sit down" was a phrase used when someone would invite a tramp to the kitchen table to eat. Sandburg also found work in Keokuk that would provide some extra cash and meals. He spent a day going door-to-door with a can of asphaltum for blackening rusty stoves, and then: I saw a sign “Waiter Wanted” in a small lunch counter near the end of Main Street. He said I could make myself useful at 50 cents a day and meals. After a day working at the lunch counter, Sandburg slept that night in a boxcar that took him halfway across Missouri.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Kansas City, Missouri
stops.audioTranscript: The next stop was the railroad section gang at Bean Lake, Missouri. After doing intense, hard labor for two weeks, because of financial struggles for the railroad and the fact that Sandburg didn't have an address at the time, he wasn't paid for his work. He writes: My Irish boss, Fay Connors, hired me at a dollar and twenty-five cents a day and I was to pay him three dollars a week for board and room in his four-room one-story house thirty feet from the railroad tracks. I tamped ties several days from seven till noon, from one till six in the evening. On Sunday I washed my shirt and socks. At the end of two weeks, on a Sunday morning, I hopped a freight for Kansas City and left Boss Connors to collect for my board and room out of my paycheck. The rest of the pay was still owing and was never collected. If Connors did get it he couldn’t have sent it to me, as he didn’t know my address and I wasn’t expecting to have any address for weeks or months.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Emporia, Kansas
stops.audioTranscript: After arriving in Kansas City, Sandburg had little trouble finding his next job. In Kansas City Mrs. Mullin had a sign in the window of her restaurant on Armor Avenue, “Dishwasher Wanted.” . It was a fight in that dish trough to get enough dirty dishes cleaned for serving the customers. I swept the eating room morning and afternoon and mopped it on Saturday. My sleeping place was the end of a hallway with my cot curtained off, and I washed and shaved, using my pocket mirror, at a sink and faucet in the hall... I worked every weekday till eight o’clock at night except for an hour or two in the afternoon. I had three good meals a day. I had Sunday off and walked miles around Kansas City comparing it to Galesburg, Peoria, Keokuk, and Chicago.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Sandburg's Hobo Homecoming
stops.audioTranscript: Omaha was the last city on Sandburg's Hobo Journey. For work in Omaha, he was a dishwasher at the Hotel Mercer for a dollar and fifty cents a week. Unfortunately, for the second time on his journey, Sandburg worked a job without pay. He writes: It was a little queer how standard was the wage rate for a dishwasher. It never went as low as a dollar and twenty-five cents a week nor a high as a dollar and seventy-five cents a week... The hotel was leased and run by a fancily dressed tall man who slid and slunk rather than walked around the place. He was known as Wink Taylor... At the end of the first week I didn't get my standard pay of a dollar and fifty cents nor likewise at the end of the second week. Then came the word that the Hotel Mercer was closed, gone, up the spout, foreclosed, and Wink Taylor vanished. In his writings about Omaha, Carl Sandburg reflected that during his travels he had considered joining the Army multiple times. He remembered walking past the recruiting offices in Kansas City, Denver, and Omaha, but each time he neglected to go inside. Sandburg would eventually go on to join and serve during the Spanish-American War.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Lindsborg, Kansas
stops.audioTranscript: Traveling further west to find work for the Kansas wheat harvest, Sandburg headed to Emporia. The trip between Kansas City and Emporia was eventful. The young hobo hopped a train and snuck onto a car, but he was discovered by a "shack" (term used for a train brakeman) during the trip. After punching Sandburg twice in the face the shack left him to ride the train. In his autobiography, Sandburg reminisced about an early interest in newspaper reporting: I walked past the office of the Emporia Gazette but didn’t have the nerve to step in and ask the editor, William Allen White, how he came to write “What’s the Matter with Kansas?” I didn’t agree with it but I liked his style. After a big two-bit meal I went to the city park, where I lay on the grass for a sleep.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Hutchinson, Kansas
stops.audioTranscript: After a day in Hutchinson, Sandburg traveled to Lindsborg - a predominantly Swedish community. He worked a hay and broomcorn harvest with several other Swedes on a farm near Lindsborg. Although he was staying among people of the same heritage, Sandburg didn't necessarily get along with them. I stayed three days at a dollar a day and meals, sleeping in a barn hayloft. On my third and last morning I had been awake a few minutes when I heard voices down below. One voice came clear to me, a Swede saying, "Is that bum up yet?" I said to myself, "Am I a bum?" And I answered, "Yes, I am a bum."... The first time in my life that I heard myself referred to as a bum was among Swedes I had made a detour to see.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Larned, Kansas
stops.audioTranscript: In Hutchinson, Sandburg learned that people who lived near the tracks were less likely to help out errant travelers because they were approached so often. In his autobiography, he remembered: I walked eight or ten blocks and hit two houses. "Have you got any work I can do for breakfast?" They took one look at me and shut the door. At the third house a woman sent her daughter to get me a saw, showed me a woodpile and a sawbuck. For an hour I kept the saw going, piled the wood, and went to the house.The smiling mother and daughter led me to the family table, set fried ham and potatoes, apple sauce, bread and coffee, before me.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Lakin, Kansas
stops.audioTranscript: Larned was the one place on Carl Sandburg's journey where he refused to refer to himself as a hobo. His father had owned and paid taxes on a quarter section of land in that town. He wrote in his autobiography: When I walked past the courthouse I felt like an important, respectable citizen, even though I was sleeping in empty boxcars that stood on the Santa Fe tracks. Sandburg's work in Larned included assisting a local carpenter for three days at seventy five cents a day and a wheat threshing crew for five days.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Salida, Colorado
stops.audioTranscript: In Lakin, Sandburg took advantage of the Kansas wheat harvest by working for another threshing crew for about three weeks. The work came easier with getting used to it. The dust in your nose and eyes, the chaff sliding down your sweating back, you got used to. One evening at six o'clock the boss said there was only two hours of threshing left and a full moon would be up. We ate supper, at seven went on threshing by the light of a bright full moon, and finished at nine o'clock. On Sandburg's trip out of Lakin, a "shack" (train brakeman) kicked him off the bumpers of a fast freight. Riding the bumpers refers to standing on the couplers between two cars and keeping hold of the brake rod for stability. It was extremely dangerous.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Denver, Colorado
stops.audioTranscript: After Lakin, Sandburg left Kansas. He slept in a boxcar as the train headed towards Colorado. When he awoke the next morning he looked up and found himself in the Rocky Mountains. My eyes caught high rises of tumbling land I had never met before. "Jesus," I said, "those are the Rocky Mountains." I hadn't planned it but there they were, rolling formations of rock and pine lifted away high. "There's the Hand of God." I said. Sandburg spent two days in Salida where he picked pears and earned a few half-dollars.

stops.directionsToNextStop: McCook, Nebraska
stops.audioTranscript: Sandburg took a Colorado Midland train to head back east to Denver. This was the first time Sandburg "rode the bumpers" (the couplers between train cars) late at night. He was so exhausted that he fell asleep while standing on the bumpers and later considered himself very lucky he didn't fall to his death that night. In Denver, Sandburg found work in the Windsor, a high-class hotel, washing dishes. He writes: I saw Pikes Peak so I could say I saw it... I washed dishes for two weeks, collected a dollar and fifty cents a week, a cubbyhole for a room and meals as good as were served to the silk-hat guests. Then came the question whether I should head for the West coast or east to Galesburg. I admitted I was a little homesick for the faces and streets of Galesburg. After this stint in Denver, Sandburg headed back to his hometown.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Nebraska City, Nebraska
stops.audioTranscript: Carl Sandburg spent very little time in McCook, but the trip there was interesting. Along the way, police officers were checking boxcars for vagrants so Sandburg decided to hide on top of the car. Hanging on for dear life, he traveled from Denver to McCook. Upon arriving, Sandburg dismounted and was immediately told to leave the city. I climbed down and started to walk out of the yards. A one-eyed man in plain clothes with a club and a star stood in my way. "Where did you come from?" His tone was hostile. "I just got off that train," I said. He gave me my orders in a more hostile tone: "We don't want the likes of you in this town. You get back on that train." And with that, Sandburg climbed back onto the roof of the boxcar and headed out of McCook.

In Nebraska City, Sandburg spent his time picking apples and chopping wood in exchange for two sit downs (meals at the kitchen table). He also met a lawyer who hired him on to chop wood. About the lawyer, he wrote: Seeing my suit of clothes somewhat ragged, [he] asked me if I would like an old suit of his. He brought it out, an iron-gray all-wool suit, better than any I had had in my life.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Tour Complete
stops.audioTranscript: Sandburg arrived in Galesburg on October 15, I caught one freight train after another till I came in sight of Galesburg the afternoon of October fifteenth. I walked along Berrien Street till I came to the only house in the United States where I could open a door without knocking and walk in for a kiss from the woman of the house. They gave me a sit down and as they had had only two or three letters from me, they asked me where I had been and I told them the half of it. When I showed my father fifteen dollars and a few nickels, he said the money would come in handy and I should watch it. What had the trip done to me? I couldn’t say. It had changed me. I was easier about looking people in the eye. When questions came I was quicker at answering them or turning them off. I had been a young stranger meeting many odd strangers and I had practiced at having answers... Away deep in my heart now I had hope as never before. Struggles lay ahead, I was sure, but whatever they were I would not be afraid of them.

data.title: Santa Fe Downtown Walking Tour: Santa Fe Trail
data.description: Santa Fe is the oldest capital city in the US, founded in 1610, and the highest US capital at 7,000 feet. This tour leads you from the busy Plaza and other major tourist locations to lesser known sites along quiet, old Santa Fe streets. We recommend that you start at the Santa Fe Plaza, the hub of the southwest connecting the Santa Fe Trail with the Old Spanish Trail, and El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro. All three are national historic trails.

stops.significance:
Welcome to Santa Fe, where three historic trails meet at the historic Santa Fe Plaza! Santa Fe is the oldest capital city in the US, founded in 1610, and the highest US capital at 7,000 feet.

We recommend that you start at the Santa Fe Plaza, the hub of the southwest connecting the Santa Fe Trail with the Old Spanish Trail, and El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro. All three are national historic trails.

You can follow the Santa Fe Trail Walking Tour to visit sites within the historic core of the city.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will take you to the Santa Fe Plaza.

stops.significance:
The Plaza marked the Southwestern end of the 900 mile Santa Fe Trail that stretches from Santa Fe to Old Franklin, Missouri. It was also the north marker for the old Camino Real de Tierra Adentro, the 650 mile trail that continues down to Mexico City.

The 33 foot tall Soldiers’ Monument, a granite monolith built in 1868, honors Union soldiers who died at the 1862 Civil War Battle of Glorieta, as well as Santa Fe Trail pioneers and travelers.

Placed in 1901, the Daughters of the American Revolution's (DAR’s) backpack-sized Kearny monument is on the northeast side of the plaza facing the sidewalk. The large grey stone honors General Kearny, the man who led a 1,600 man 'Army of the West' across the Santa Fe Trail in 1846. He claimed then-Mexican land for the US, and seized New Mexico without firing a shot.

The four foot End of the Trail monument near the Plaza’s southeast corner was erected in 1911. It is one of the DAR’s 170 surviving Santa Fe Trail markers erected in 1905-1914.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Palace of the Governors.

stops.significance:
Since 1610, this block-long, one-story adobe building has housed the offices and living quarters of 58 Spanish Colonial Governors, 16 Mexican Governors, four military and three civilian governors during U.S. rule, and 17 Territorial Governors. The building endured the 1680 Pueblo Indian Revolt; the 1692-1693 Spanish reconquest; the 1846 arrival of Brigadier General Kearny (who raised the U.S. flag here and declared New Mexico a part of the U.S.); and the 1862 invasion of Texas Confederate troops. 

Santa Fe Trail traders once rented rooms here from which they sold their wares. At night in his living quarters here in 1878-80, New Mexico Territorial Governor Lew Wallace completed his second novel, Ben Hur, which made him rich and famous. 

Both the Palace of the Governors and the New Mexico History Museum have exhibits related to the Santa Fe Trail.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Roadrunner Cowbelles’ Trail Plaque.

stops.significance:
Roadrunner Cowbelles’ Trail Plaque: Along with an iron hitching rail on Washington Ave., this 1976 bronze plaque honors early Santa Fe Trail drivers. 

Cemented into a brick wall is an old weathered bronze plaque. It reads, "Roadrunner Cowbelle's dedicate this hitching post at the end of the trail to American gentleman and their horses for their glorious role in winning the west."
stops.assetName: Roadrunner Cowbelles’ Santa Fe Trail Plaque
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be Trujillo, Prince & Sena Plazas.

stops.significance:
At 109, 111 & 115 East Palace Avenue, peek into the plazas that date back to the Santa Fe Trail era, located behind the buildings along Palace Avenue - they host shops and restaurants today.

In 1828 to the mid-1830s, the home that became Trujillo and Prince plazas was the modest residence of French-Canadian fur trapper and trader Antoine Robidoux, Brigadier General Kearny’s interpreter in 1846. His widow sold it to Territorial Supreme Court Chief Justice L. Bradford Prince in 1879. Sena Plaza, the home of Juan Estevan and Maria de Rosario Sena y Alarid was given to their son, Manuel, in 1844. He and his son, Civil War hero Jose, Sr., expanded it into a 33-room home by the 1860s; Prince bought it in 1886.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the James Johnson Building Site (Catron Block).

stops.significance: Overlooking the northeast side of the Plaza is the Italian-style Catron Block, built in 1891. Powerful lawyer, banker, and politician Thomas Catron occupied its second floor offices. It replaced Santa Fe Trail merchant James Johnson’s two-story adobe and wood-frame building, a Santa Fe Trail landmark built in 1847. In the 1870s, Johnson’s building housed Catron’s offices, the First National Bank, and the Santa Fe Daily New Mexican. Catron acquired it in 1881. The Catron Block stayed in the family until 1927.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Exchange Hotel Site (La Fonda).

stops.significance:
William and Mary Dodson Donoho, who crossed the Santa Fe Trail from Missouri, operated an inn here known as Los Estados Unidos (spanish for United States) House in 1833-37. By 1847 it had become the Santa Fe House. By 1848 it was the U.S. Hotel, offering liquor and gaming. It became the Exchange Hotel in 1851. The one-story, flat-roofed, Territorial Style adobe hotel began losing clients after 1880, as more modern hotels arose. It was razed in 1919.

The La Fonda inn opened in 1922. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway bought it in 1925 and leased it to Fred Harvey. In 1927 it underwent its first expansion, got its Pueblo Revival look, and was a Harvey House until 1968.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Santa Fe Trail Plaque, Old Santa Fe Trail.

stops.significance: This DAR-placed, 1905 cast bronze plaque is set at eye level in an exterior adobe stucco wall on the west side of Old Santa Fe Trail, across from the La Fonda hotel.
stops.assetName: Santa Fe Trail Plaque, Old Santa Fe Trail
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the La Castrense Site (Plaque).

stops.significance: The Spanish Colonial presidio (military garrison) chapel, Nuestra Senora de la Luz (Our Lady of Light), was built here circa 1760, and razed in 1859.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Mercure Brothers Store Site (La Plaza Galeria).

stops.significance:
Quebec-born Santa Fe Trail trader Francois Aubry, whose enduring fame came in 1848, after racing on horseback across the

Santa Fe Trail from here to Independence, Missouri in record time (five days, 16 hours) to win a $1,000 bet, died here in 1854 after a bar room argument with ex-newspaperman Richard Weightman. His friends, the Montreal-born Mercures, Joseph and Henri, tried to intervene, but Aubry’s knife wound was fatal.
stops.assetName: Mercure Brothers Store Site (La Plaza Galeria)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Ellsberg & Amberg Store Site (1st National Bank).

stops.significance: Westport, Missouri merchants Gustavus Elsberg and Jacob Amberg crossed the Santa Fe Trail in 1856, and opened the two-story Ellsberg & Amberg Building here in 1864. They parted ways in 1869, but their 26-room building lasted until 1917. When Santa Fe Trail land baron Lucien Maxwell founded this bank in 1870 and sold it in 1871 to Santa Fe law partners, Thomas Catron and Stephen Elkins, it was housed in the James Johnson Building, across the Plaza. In 1954, a former 1921-24 movie theater here was transformed into the Pueblo Revival Style bank building you see today.
stops.assetName: Ellsberg & Amberg Store Site (1st National Bank)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the  Eliza Sloan Boarding House & Ft. Marcy HQ Building Sites (New Mexico Arts Museum).

stops.significance: In her published memoirs (1954; Land Of Enchantment), Santa Fe Trail traveler Marian Russell recalled her widowed mother, Eliza, operating a $45 a month boarding house here in 1852-54. Circa 1871 it was replaced by the 16-room Ft. Marcy HQ Building. The NM Fine Arts Museum, home today to SF artist Gerald Cassidy’s 1930 oil painting, End Of The Trail (1850; aka Santa Fe Plaza, ), replaced the old building in 1917.
stops.assetName: Eliza Sloan Boarding House & Ft. Marcy HQ Building Sites (New Mexico Museum of Art)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Felipe Delgado House.

stops.significance: A commercial building since 1980, this restored two-story adobe house, crowned by an Italian Style portico (entry porch) to its second floor front balcony, was built circa 1890 for Santa Fe Trail trader Delgado, who bought the land in 1877. The home stayed in his family until 1970.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Doña Tules’s Gambling Hall Site (Bokum Bluilding).

stops.significance: Born in Sonora, Mexico, Doña Maria Gertrudes Barcelo operated her lavishly decorated saloon and gambling hall here from 1832-36 until her death. Reputedly the best monte dealer in Santa Fe, the red-haired, cigar-smoking “Doña Tules” soon grew wealthy. Scorned by many of the city’s residents, the business woman shrewdly welcomed the U.S. by funding its 1846 wartime expedition to Chihuahua.
stops.assetName: Doña Tules’s Gambling Hall Site (Bokum Building)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Doña Tules’s Home Site (Santa Fe County Courthouse).

stops.significance: Doña "Tules" Barcelo’s one-story, flat-roofed, courtyard home was just across the street from her saloon and gambling hall. Born around 1800-1811, she died here in 1852. The Pueblo Revival Style court house replaced it in 1940.
stops.assetName: Doña Tules’s Home Site (Santa Fe County Courthouse)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Alfred Bergere House (Georgia O’Keeffe Research Center).

stops.significance: One of two surviving Ft. Marcy officers’ quarters built around 1871, it became a 10-day vacation home for former President Ulysses S. Grant and his family in 1880. Bought in 1904 by Bergere, the England-born son of a wealthy Italian shipping magnate, the 7-room home got a full second floor and Pueblo Revival Style makeover in 1926. It stayed in the family until 1975. Only the central hallway’s cherry wood staircase and one fireplace remain from the old Santa Fe Trail days.
stops.assetName: Alfred Bergere House (Georgia O’Keeffe Research Center)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Edgar Hewett House (Museum of NM Foundation Office).

stops.significance: This surviving Ft. Marcy officers’ quarters, once the Quartermaster’s home, was remodeled in the Pueblo Revival Style in 1916. It became the lifetime home of the Edgar Lee Hewett, the Director of the Museum of New Mexico (in 1909) and School of American Research (1917). Hewett died in 1946 and his wife in 1960. After President Teddy Roosevelt gave downtown Ft. Marcy’s 17 acres to the city in 1904, the other 5 officers’ quarters (and military post buildings) were eventually razed.
stops.assetName: Edgar Hewett House (Museum of NM Foundation Office)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Roque Lobato House (private residence).

stops.significance:
Built circa 1786 for Lobato, an armorer and soldier of Santa Fe’s Royal Spanish Garrison. Santa Fe Trail trader Don Gaspar Ortiz y Alarid bought the buildint in 1852. The ruins of Santa Fe’s fortress and powder magazine, La Garita (little guardhouse), built in 1807, stood just northeast of the house until 1954. 

Private residence; photo permissions not granted.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Fort Marcy Ruins.

stops.significance: Built in 1846, this U. S. fort was the first in New Mexico Territory (and is the only fort left in the United States from the Mexican American War). Built for 280 men, this irregularly shaped star fort was never garrisoned. Located on a hill 50 yards higher in elevation than the Plaza, its 14 cannons could have confronted an approaching Mexican army or suppressed a local uprising.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the La Parroquia Site (Cathedral Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi).

stops.significance: Begun in 1869, this sandstone-block, neo- Romanesque Style church was never finished; its plans called for two 165-foot tall steeples and an 85-foot tall dome. It slowly enveloped La Parroquia (the parish church), a Santa Fe Trail landmark that was dismantled starting in 1884. In the north transept, a remnant of the early 1700s parish church, is a two-foot tall bulto (statue) of the oldest Marian figure in the U.S. It came here from Mexico in 1625. Hungary-born NYC sculptor Jeno Juszko’s seven-foot tall, bronze statue of Jean Baptiste Lamy honors the France-born cleric who arrived here in 1851. An energetic visionary, Lamy started a school for girls in 1853; a school for boys in 1858; and a hospital and orphanage in 1865. About 2,000 people viewed the statue’s 1915 unveiling.
stops.assetName: La Parroquia Site (Cathedral Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Magoffin-Fiske Home Site (La Fonda Parking Garage).

stops.significance: Santa Fe Trail bride Susan Magoffin and her husband, trail trader Samuel, lived here in a flat-roofed, four-room adobe home built before 1836, for five weeks in 1846. Here she continued writing in her diary, published in a 1926 book, Down the Santa Fe Trail & Into Mexico. Santa Fe attorney Eugene Fiske bought the home in 1881 and expanded it. The Fiskes sold the house in 1912. In 1949 it was razed to make way for the La Fonda’s first parking lot.
stops.assetName: Magoffin-Fiske Home Site (La Fonda Parking Garage)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Loretto Chapel (Chapel of Our Lady of Light).

stops.significance:
This Gothic Revival chapel, started in 1873 and completed in 1878, was built by young French architect Projectus Mouly for the Sisters of Loretto. In 1855, Jean Baptiste Lamy moved the Loretto Academy here into a former hotel he bought in 1854, La Casa Americana (the American House). That two-story, pitched roof building stood here (next to the south side of the chapel) until 1882 when a two-story convent replaced it and a three-story girls’ school was built on the north side of the chapel. The convent and school were razed in 1971 to make way for the Inn at Loretto.

The chapel is famed for its 20-foot high, circular staircase, built in 1878. While the Lorretines insisted the builder was St. Joseph, recent evidence points to French master carpenter Francois-Jean Rochas.
stops.assetName: Loretto Chapel (Chapel of Our Lady of Light)
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Santa Fe River Park.

stops.significance: Here Santa Fe Trail traders once camped and their animals drank and grazed. The 12-acre, tree-shaded park was built in 1935.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Roque Tudesqui House.

stops.significance: Italy-born Santa Fe Trail trader Tudesqui bought this modest adobe home in 1839. When it was built is unknown. Purple wisteria bloom in its tiny courtyard every June.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Gregorio Crespin House (private residence).

stops.significance: Owned in 1747 by Gregorio Crespin, the house’s vigas (ceiling beams) date back to 1720. Owner Benito Roibal served in the Santa Fe militia in the mid-1860s and traveled the Santa Fe Trail as a soldier.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the San Miguel Chapel

stops.significance: This adobe chapel is a Santa Fe Trail landmark, and was in use before 1626,. Partly destroyed in the 1680 Pueblo Revolt, it was rebuilt in 1710. Its bulto (wooden statue) of St. Michael predates 1709; its wooden reredos (altar screen), painted in 1798, sits above the original altar. Its jewel-studded bell was cast in 1856. The church served the Barrio de Analco (the District on the Other Side of the Water) and St. Michael’s College daily until 1967.
stops.assetName: San Miguel Chapel in Santa Fe
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the James Johnson House (El Zaguan).

stops.significance: When Santa Fe Trail trader James Johnson bought this adobe home in 1849, he expanded it to 19 rooms under a single, unifying zaguan (vestibule). Behind his Territorial Style home, Santa Fe Trail merchants kept their horses and oxen in his corrals before their return trip east.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop will be the Santuario de Guadalupe.

stops.significance: Built in 1776-96, this cruciform adobe church is the oldest extant shrine to Our Lady of Guadalupe in the U.S. Its vigas (ceiling beams), corbels (brackets), and choir loft came from the military chapel, La Castrense. It’s at the east end of Agua Fria St., a remnant of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro (the Royal Road to the Interior Land), later known as the Chihuahua Trail. Outside is Mexican artist Doña Georgina Farias’s 12-foot tall, 2008 bronze statue, Nuestra Senora (Our Lady) de Guadalupe.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the end of the Santa Fe Downtown Walking Tour. Please check the National Park Service Mobile app for more available tours. Thank you.

images.title: Loretto Chapel
images.altText: Two story gothic-revival chapel.
images.caption: Visit Santa Fe, New Mexico for a step back in time.

data.title: Santa Rosa Island: Cherry Canyon Self-Guided Tour

images.title: Cherry Canyon Trail, Santa Rosa Island
