It was this piece of property that is now Oxon Cove Park. Mr. Lingan improved the land but by the turn of the 19th century, he too sold it. The new owner was Dr. Samuel de Butts who, along with his wife Mary, are the next residents we shall meet. [a bell sounds] Proceed down the road to your next marker at a small octagonal building surrounded by a white picket fence and stand of old boxwood.

stops.significance: While looking at a plant that's been here for centuries, learn about some if this land's first European occupants.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed now to the next stop on the river side of the white farmhouse.
stops.audioTranscript:
The plant inside the white picket fence is boxwood. Boxwood is a slow-growing evergreen that is most often used to make musical instruments and chess pieces. Did you know this little plant can live for centuries? The boxwood next to you has grown on that spot for a very long time. It was here when Dr. and Mrs. De Butts lived on this land. These boxwoods truly are a doorway to the past. Born in 1756, Samuel De Butts was a native of Ireland. After finishing college, he moved to England and began a career as a doctor. In England, he met and courted Mary Welby.  Samuel De Butts of the parish of Grantham in the county of Lincoln and Mary Welby of this parish and married in his church by license the 17th day of October in the year of our Lord 1785 by me, W.M. Easton, Rector of Croxby. [Narrator]: Writing of the fine occasion, another commented on the mood of the local squire 

[Woman]: I am very glad to hear that the squire of Denton put on his best wig on your wedding day. 

[Narrator]: Soon afterward in 1786, Mary's relatives wrote 

[A relative of Mary De Butts]: Mrs. De Butts was brought to bed last Monday at five o'clock in the morning of a fine little girl which I have not yet seen, but hear it is very like the doctor. 

[Narrator]: The family began to take shape. Samuel and Mary had more children, however not all of them survived. Only two, Richard and Mary Anne, were living by 1791 when the De Butts faced a difficult decision. Since the doctors medical practice was struggling, should they move to America to try and find a better life? Samuels brother John was already in America. John encouraged the move across the treacherous ocean.  

[John De Butts]: Sell every property in England and Ireland. Lodge your money as securely as possible in London, subject to your drafts at 30 days site. Perhaps it might besides bring you some interest there. Come out in a stout British merchant ship bound for either Baltimore or any other part within the Chesapeake Bay, but prefer Baltimore. Be at as little expense as an outfit as you can. I mean with regard to superfluous clothes and furniture. Sail either from London, Liverpool, Whitehaven, or Bristol and make as good a bargain with the captain of the ship as you can for your passage. Let him find sea stores except for small matters for yourselves and the children. If you find your own stores, the sailors will assuredly pillage you on the voyage. When at Baltimore, your family, self, and luggage may readily procure at Patuxent Boat to convey you to my house where the most hearty welcome will await you all. I will advise you to sail in May, June, or July when you do, these are the most agreeable months for young sailors. 

[Narrator]: The new world was a very different place from the old world. John De Butts, determined to get Samuel and Mary to emigrate, used vivid imagery to answer their every question in an attempt to convince them.  

[John De Butts]: The crops of tobacco wheat, corn, flax, and cotton enables the beginning not only liberally to supply his family but to send considerable quantities to market. Almost every plantation abounds with apples, peaches, and cherries. Our woods and fields abound with partridges, squirrels, opossum, raccoon, and other game such as pheasants, woodcocks, snipes, and some wild turkeys. But the latter are now rarely to be met, besides a variety of other birds and beasts for us in entertainment. The water yields us plenty with various kinds of fish, oysters, crabs etc. and in the winter, great numbers of swan, wild geese, and ducks. In this description, I confined myself to my own neighborhood. The back country affords a variety of animals which I have not mentioned and there is venison is their cheapest meat. 

[Narrator]: Samuel, Mary, and their two children decided to move to America in 1791. The journey was fraught with peril. There were many disasters attendant on so rash a step as crossing the Atlantic especially with young children. They survived the trip and landed in America where another child, John Henry, was born in Maryland. Both Samuel and Mary inherited some wealth from their families and as such were in a better situation than others. After a few years, Dr. De Butts purchased the property on which you stand. Around this time, the white farmhouse ahead of you was built. The area and the home were named Mount Welby in honor of Mary's family, the Welbys. Samuel worked as a doctor but supplemented his income by farming this land. Everyday life was a challenge and for some tragedy struck without warning. 

[Woman]: A most dreadful epidemic has raged here during the whole winter. It is melancholy to see the devastation it has made in various counties. Whole families have been swept away. 

[Narrator]: Mount Welby was not immune. On December 11th, 1814, tragedy hit these hills. 

[Mary De Butts]: Your poor sister is a widow. We had, as usual, spent the months of September and October with our daughter in Loudoun and Dr. De B

stops.significance: Learn about this home during a time of war.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the hill to the pathway and follow the road to your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
[Narrator]: The house that you see before you was constructed around 1800, shortly after Nicholas Lingan purchased the land. Architecturally, the house was typical of the Maryland federal style at the beginning of the 19th century. The plan of the house consisted of a central hall with two rooms on each side, each room with its own fireplace. The house you are looking at today was altered from its original condition in the late 19th century. The roofline was flattened. It used to rise to a peak in the middle, typical of many modern roofing styles. Parts of the walls and windows were rebuilt, perhaps due to a fire. In the interior, the fire places on the east wall were removed although you can still see where the chimneys were along the roof line. Look out from Mount Welby towards the Potomac. The modern-day view is impressive enough, but imagine what this view must have looked like without the trees blocking the way. The house is perfectly located for a gorgeous view of the Potomac shipping traffic and Alexandria's buzzing docks. Washington City, America's young capital was just over the hill to the north. You may even be able to see the tip of the Washington Monument, depending on the time of year and weather. Imagine cruising down the Potomac. Glancing up on this towering hill is a glistening white farmhouse commanding the scene. This was a fine spot indeed. Other notable figures had similar home locations. George Washington lived at Mount Vernon a few miles to our south and later Robert E. Lee resided at Arlington House just up the river to the north. This was the Potomac highway, and you have a truly historic vantage point. 

This same dramatic view provided the De Butts family with a first-hand view of the War of 1812. England and America were at war over many issues. America believed England had been taking sailors off her naval ships and forcing them to work on their own ships. Americans blamed the English for inciting the Native Americans against them. Many Americans also had a desire to conquer and seize Canada. America declared war on England to settle the issues. Wars are much easier to win on paper. The cost was terrible and the results were ultimately inconclusive. The war destroyed shipping. In 1812, Mary De Butts lamented its impact on their crops. 

[Mary De Butts]: We are just now in the midst of a harvest and have every prospect of plentiful crops, but if the war continues we shall have no market for a grain. Tis terrible times for the farmer but the poor merchants will be ruined. Money never was so scarce. There is scarce a dollar to be had. 

[Narrator]: War is painful and terrible. For the De Butts, this war was especially troubling. They now lived in America, but they were from and their family still lived in England. iIf they supported their home and neighbors, they opposed to their own family. War came very close to where you stand. Bladensburg, Maryland, only miles from where you are, was the scene of one of America's greatest defeats. 

[Mary De Butts]: I cannot express to you the distress it has occasioned. At the Battle of Bladensburg, we heard every fire, that place being not more than five or six miles from us. Our house was shook repeatedly by the firing upon forts and bridges. 

[Narrator]: After defeating the American forces at Bladensburg, British soldiers marched into Washington and on August twenty-fourth, 1814 they burned the White House, Capitol building and others structures. Much of Washington City was ablaze, some intentionally, much not. The walls of Mount Welby glowed ominously from the flame signifying the downfall of the American Capital. Days later a British naval fleet sailed up the Potomac directly in front of you. Alexandria Virginia surrendered to the fleet rather than fight it out. 454 United States soldiers were stationed on this hill to aid the defense of Fort Washington a few miles south of us. The fort evacuated in the face of the British advance, opening up the entirety of the Potomac to the world's strongest naval power. Soon fire ships, boats packed with explosives, were intentionally set ablaze by Americans and hurtled down the stretch of the river, hoping to damage the British fleet and force their withdrawal. Mary De Butts later called this time a day and night of horrors. 

[Mary De Butts]: We found three rockets on our hill, evidently pointed at our house but fortunately did not reach it. 

[Narrator]: The two quarreling nations signed a treaty soon afterward. By 1815, the war was over, but neither side emerged as clearly victorious and there was little to show for the carnage. Mary wrote to her brother in 1815 

[Mary De Butts]: The termination of the war has cheered hearts of thousands, but its bitter consequences will long be severely felt. 

[A bell sounds] Proceed down the hill to the pathway and follow the road to your right.

stops.significance: The farm has a number of historic buildings. Learn about some of them at the Root Cellar
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue past the stable to the entrance of the fenced pathway under the large trees.
stops.audioTranscript: As you walk, let your mind transport you. Imagine this wide open land dotting with fields and agriculture. The squeak of the wagon wheels tells you visitors have arrived from their dusty journey. Giggling children run over the hill as many enslaved silently go about their tasks. Across the estate you find yourself on, three buildings remain. Mount Welby dominates the view behind you, but two others survive from the De Butts. You may notice a small brick building on your right, built into the ground. This is the family root cellar, constructed around 1830. Built partially underground, it keeps its contents cool. In the age before modern refrigerators, root cellars were vital to keeping certain food safe for long periods of time. As you continue walking, you may notice a large two-story brick stable ahead of you. The brick stable is even older than the root cellar and was the envy of its visitors. The stable built, around 1820, demonstrates the wealth of the family. Brick buildings were built to last and were subsequently far more expensive than other materials. Choosing to build a two-story stable in brick reveals that the DeButts family had money and they intended to make a permanent impact. [A bell sounds] Continue past the stable to the entrance of the fenced pathway under the large trees where your next marker rests.

stops.significance: A tour of this farm would not be complete without learning about the people enslaved here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed now up the hill to the Red hay barn at your next marker.
stops.audioTranscript: I imagine your feelings must, as an English woman, be hurt at the idea of slavery in a free country, yet to me it is our Negroes are happier better fed and clothed than the peasantry of most countries of Europe. John De Butts. North American slavery predates the very existence of Maryland statehood. Enslaved persons were forced to work in this vicinity nearly 150 years before the American Revolution. For those with wealth, forcing others to do all the work and receive little to no pay seemed ideal. To modern-day audiences, slavery is a most unpleasant and uncomfortable topic, but it's tragic existence remains a crucial part of Maryland and national history. In 1790, 52% of the people in Prince George's County were enslaved individuals. This land had enslaved workers in the 1700s when Samuel and Mary De Butts purchased this land, they soon brought enslaved workers onto this land as well, continuing its tragic pattern of injustice. Most enslaved individuals worked the fields, while a select few worked in the main house. These human beings were considered property, no different than a plough or a horse. They were a tool to do work, nothing more in the eyes of those who held them. They could be given away as family heirlooms. I give and bequeath to my son John Henry De Butts all my slaves, stock, farming utensils, furniture, linens, and books. Enslaved people were counted as inventory on lists of supplies with given values. The law considered the enslaved to be personal property and as such they were often as valuable as the land itself. The same constitutional rights that were used to defend life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness did not apply to all peoples. Wealthy white men benefited most from these beliefs. Women too suffered. With few exceptions, the property of a woman became her husband's upon marriage. Women could neither vote nor hold office even though equality appeared to exist in the Constitution. Freedom has been and always will be a matter of perspective. No one who has always enjoyed the right of Liberty can realize the horrors of slavery. To be at the will of another, to be owned like a cow or horse, and liable at any moment to be sold to the highest bidder, to be transported to a distant part of the country, leaving the dearest relatives behind, to be ground down mentally and physically by the untold curses of slavery may be a very pretty thing to the Masters of the peculiar institution, but it is death to the slaves. Many enslaved people recognize the gross injustice of their situation. There were many ways to resist but they all saw a common theme- freedom. Like Nat Turner, they could turn and fight rallying their companions to turn the suffering onto their oppressors. Like Frederick Douglass, they could take their resistance to the masses through speeches, newspapers, and public opinion. Like Denmark Vesey, they could invoke a higher power or strength to emerge from the shattered lives in which they were bound. Others chose to just disappear and evade capture. An enslaved man kept on this land did just that. 200 reward Negro man Jacob Shaw, aged 35 years rather dark complexion, his hair's inclined to be bushy, a small scar over his left eye. He has a free brother in the city of Washington by the name of Sandy Shaw whose free pass he has probably attained and will try to get to Pennsylvania or New York. The unfortunate nature of slavery in America led to families often being split. When escaping, some chose to try and find their scattered family members then seek freedom together. $30 reward Barba B. Williams is about 50 years of age, 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high, slender built, stoops in her walk, black color a little gray and squints a little out of her right eye. She has relations living at Mr. Thomas E. Berry's Oxon Hill Farm on the Potomac River. Despite the heroic actions of many, enslaved individuals continued to comprise the majority of the labor force in Prince George's County for much of the 19th century. The District of Columbia abolished slavery in 1862 and the constitutional amendments following the Civil War abolished slavery nationwide, but this did not solve the problems of racial discrimination. Although slavery no longer existed by law, the social and economic fabric of the area was very different after the war. Many formerly enslaved people chose to move and find opportunities in new places such as Baltimore. Some chose to stay and work the same land but now for payment, meager as it may be. Compounding the tragedy of slavery is the lack of information that has been left to later generations. No first-person information about the lives of enslaved people here survives. Even their final resting places remain unknown. The location for the enslaved burial ground has been lost for now, but is in the vicinity of where you now stand. Oxon Cove's enslaved people share a voice unheard, but we must never allow them to be forgotten.

stops.significance: Oxon Hill Farm was purchased by the US Government in the 1890s. Learn more about its modern use at this stop.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Visitor Barn
stops.audioTranscript:
[Narrator]: After the De Butts family sold this land in 1843, it passed through a series of short term owners over the next several decades. Meanwhile, in 1852, with the encouragement of Dorothea Dix, the federal government opened St. Elizabeth's hospital to treat people with mental illnesses. The hospital, located only a few miles to our north, was the first large-scale, federally run psychiatric hospital. To support the hospital, the federal government purchased the land on which you stand in 1891. This farm produced food to sustain the hospital but also offered unique therapeutic options. It was decided to use farm work as a method of therapy for the patients. This offered a uniquely peaceful setting in which patients could work. Additionally, it gave them a tangible goal to accomplish. The work had a noticeable reward- food production, which was a value to the larger community. Some of the patients even lived in the building formerly known as Mount Welby, under the watchful eye of the farm caretaker. From the business perspective of the hospital's operation, it provided free farm labor too. This was a major improvement from previous standards of mental treatment. Dorothea Dix, noted advocate for better mental health treatment, described some observations of other types of care she had witnessed: 

[Dorothea Dix]: One subject chained and one in a closed stall for 17 years, one often doubly chained hand and foot, one man caged comfortable, one often closely confined now losing the use of his limbs from want of exercise. The insane are disadvantageously placed in the jail. In the almshouse, two females are in stalls in wooden bunks filled with straw, always shut up. One of these subjects is supposed curable. 

[Narrator]: Dorothea Dix knew there had to be a better way to treat people with mental illness. This land represented one of the great experiments to find that better way. Here, selected patients could work the land outside, unchained. They could accomplish important tasks and stimulate their minds and bodies. Their rooms had no bars or restraints and the hospital in many ways benefited at the same time. This farm was highly productive. It not only served as a home for horses, cattle, pigs, and chickens, but it also produced alfalfa, timothy hay, sweet potatoes, carrots, beets, turnips, asparagus, eggplant, pumpkins, rutabaga, fruits, and honey, in addition to eggs and meat from the animals. Now as an operating government farm the De Butts' Mount Welby was renamed Godding Croft after St. Elizabeth's superintendent at the time Dr. William Godding. Dr. Godding stated his belief: 

[Dr. Godding]: There is no question about the value of labor in the treatment and care of the insane and the varied work of a farm and garden seems admirably suited for the employment of many whose disease is of the chronic type. 

[Narrator]: In 1893, Dr. Godding noted the transformation undergoing on this land as Mount Welby became Godding Croft. 

[Dr. Godding]: The old manor house and barn there have been renovated and occupied. A new shed has been built for the shelter of young stock and the fields are already taking on something of the aspect of a well-ordered farm. There is abundant road making, clearing, and grubbing up that will afford an opportunity for all the winter labor that can be made available for years to come. It will come more and more to depend on a labor of the inmates and in the end they will be found no more slightly or pleasant pastoral region, no fair outlooks, no spot better fitted to bring content to darkened mines, this new domain named Godding Croft. 

[Narrator]: New buildings were constructed including the hay barn at which you now stand. The patients worked two to three-hour shifts twice a day challenging and developing their mind in a home-like atmosphere. It was an exploration in justice for a class of people so long restricted to perpetual injustice. 

[A bell sounds] Walk now to your final stop outside the visitor barn.

stops.significance: Your final stop on the tour
stops.audioTranscript:
[Narrator]: In 1967, the National Park Service opened this park to tell these and other stories. Originally intended to show life on an early 20th century farm, the National Park Service brought dozens of animals onto this land, which remain one of the parks most noticeable aspects. Cows, pigs, horses, chickens, goats, and sheep are just some of the new residents living here. Park Rangers and visitors continue to interact with and learn about the same types of animals that have lived on this land for centuries. Now you can experience glimpses of time with each step. You can see the same crops growing that grew for St. Elizabeth's. You can find the chicken eggs just as the enslaved did. You can get milk from the cow as the De Butts needed. Looking in the woods, you can occasionally spot wild animals peering out at you just as the natives saw. Oxon Cove Park is designed for just such an encounter. The parks mission is to teach us where we've been and what life was like through cultural and natural resources. Cultural resources, like Mount Welby, tell us about families and their lives. Natural resources, like the sprawling fields and winding Potomac River, shape our use of the land. With those resources, this Park preserves the human experience from the past. More than that, Oxon Cove Park does not only preserve the past, we fight to preserve the future. Urban sprawl is everywhere. Places like this are becoming fewer and fewer. Through our collective effort, all of us and you become stewards, ensuring that our children and their children can come for generations yet unseen to experience the exact same parts of the human experience that we now enjoy. By preserving the past, we preserve the future. Nestled in the hustle and bustle of life, Oxon Cove Park provides an escape to explore our collective human experience. Millions have visited the park and the National Park Service values each and every one. The clues remain all around you so many stories are forever entrenched in this land. For thousands of years, a great diversity of people have lived and loved this land. We've seen how this land has changed through time. We've watched its residents come and go. We've witnessed parts of the human experience, some painful, some joyful. No two people are the same and we've seen some very different people who have stood where you now stand. While their stories and lives are different, this place, now named Oxon Cove Park, is the same. It all happened right here and we must never forget. 

A famed American hero once said 

[Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain]: In great deeds something abides, on great field something stays, forms change and pass, bodies disappear but spirits linger to consecrate ground for the vision place of souls. 

[Narrator]: The National Park Service thanks you for visiting Oxon Cove Park. We are grateful you took the time to come today and hope you will come back again with family and friends, adding your stories to those that have gone before us. You are one more thread in the great tapestry that is Oxon Cove Park, a park where every thread is important and without it our great human tapestry will always be incomplete. Thank you for visiting and please come again to experience Oxon Cove Park.

images.altText: 3 red barns, a brick stable, and a metal windmill

data.title: Self-Guided Circle Trail Tour
data.description: The 3/4-mile-long, paved Circle Trail is open 24 hours a day all year long. It offers a chance to learn the cultural, historical, and natural history of this site. For centuries, Indigenous people have journeyed to this area to quarry pipestone and carve pipes to pray with. Pipestone National Monument exists to protect the rights of all American Indians enrolled in federally recognized tribes to quarry this soft, red stone. Enjoy the experience of the trail at your leisure any time!

stops.significance: The Visitor Center has a short film about the site's cultural significance, brochures, exhibits, a park store, park staff to answer questions, and cultural demonstrators during the summer.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop begins on the south side of the Visitor Center (to the right if you're facing the front of the building).

stops.significance:
This spot is a chance to view the layers of a quarry pit up close. Quarriers must break through 6-10 feet of Sioux Quartzite (harder than steel!) with sledge hammers and wedges to reach the softer pipestone layer after days, weeks, or even months of hard work. If you look closely at the bottom of the wall at the end of the quarry, you can see the exposed pipestone.

Use caution - footing is uneven and the stone is as slick as ice when wet!
stops.directionsToNextStop: After exiting the quarry, continue on the trail until the fork just a few feet from the quarry stairs.
stops.audioTranscript: The sound of quarrier and carver Mike Pederson swinging a sledge hammer on a hammer and chisel

stops.significance: This is where visitors may take the South Quarry Trail to the right and view quarry pits from the trail. This trail is an out-and-back (1/2-mile round trip).
stops.assetName: South Quarry Trail Junction - Circle Trail
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the South Quarry Trail to the right and view some active quarry pits. Roughly 400 feet along the trail the path forks to the left and connects back with the main Circle Trail. The next stop is along this path that forks back to the main trail.

stops.significance: Where Abbie Gardner remembered Dakota leader Inkpaduta and his band camping at the quarries while fleeing from U.S. forces.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path back to the main Circle Trail, veering to the right as the paths meet.

stops.significance: At this location, visitors can view an expanse of tallgrass prairie that once covered millions of acres. This prairie boasts over 500 plant species and can be an excellent spot to hear wildlife such as songbirds and boreal chorus frogs when conditions are right. Many Indigenous people use the ash tree at this location for prayer ties and offerings (please do not disturb these important items).
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the path towards the quartzite outcroppings.
stops.audioTranscript: The sound of chorus frogs

stops.significance: Beautiful outcroppings line the eastern side of the trail. Although the colors in the stones vary from light pink to an almost dark purple, none of the stone visible along this point of the trail is actually pipestone. It is all Sioux Quartzite.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved trail, watching your step for uneven spots and watching your head due to overhanging quartzite.

stops.significance:
The Oracle is the profile of a face in the rocks surrounded by cottonwood trees that serves as a reminder that this sacred site is a storied landscape.  Many quarriers, such as Cindy Pederson, are a wealth of stories that tie the land, the people, the water, and even the stars together. Sometimes they share these stories with visitors, adding a meaningful layer to the experience at the pipestone quarries.

**Please do go past the overlook. After enjoying the view, please return to the paved path at the bottom of the stairs. Any "off trail" paths have been created by either wildlife or visitors creating social trails. These are not actual trails.**
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back down the steps to the paved path and continue along the Circle Trail.
stops.audioTranscript:
Cindy Pederson's story:

Once there was a lost and lonely star. The lost and lonely star wanted to find happiness. So the lost and lonely star traveled and spoke with other stars and asked the other stars "How come you're so happy?" "Oh we just love playing with each other!" "Well I'm not very happy, so I'm gonna go find a happy place." And as the star traveled throughout the universe and looked down and saw the earth, and the earth looked beautiful. So the little star went to the earth looking for happiness. And the little star heard a strange sound. It had never heard that sound before. So upon arriving at a gentle flowing, shallow stream he saw giant trees, and he saw little children splashing and playing in the water. And they spoke kindly to each other and they were laughing he loved the sound of their laughter. And he said, "This! This is where I want to live!" So the star stayed there along the stream and he was happy, because he could always hear the laughter of the children. So whenever you find a broken branch from a cottonwood tree - because cottonwood trees grow along lakes and streams - cut it open on the little knuckle and you will find a star inside. And that's where the star lives, because now the star is truly happy.

stops.significance: One of the best spots for photos or just clearing your head! Many people come just to see the waterfall while others walked away surprised it was even here. Visitors sometimes cross paths with artists like local flute player Bruce Wiegle as they draw inspiration from Winnewissa Falls.
stops.directionsToNextStop: After crossing the bridge, either go to the right and take the steps to a short loop which connects back to the main Circle Trail or go to the left to avoid stairs and continue along the main trail. The next stop on this self-guided tour is to the right and up the stairs to the left. Remain on the paved path at the top of the stairs.
stops.audioTranscript: Instrumental flute music

stops.significance: A significant site used for centuries by Indigenous warriors to prove their bravery.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the paved path for just a few feet to the next stop.

stops.significance: Where Joseph Nicollet and other members of his famous 1838 expedition carved their names in the rock. This rock was later used as the center point of a 1-square-mile reservation.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the paved path and turn left onto the quartzite steps. Use caution due to uneven footing. The next stop is located roughly halfway down the stairs - watch for wavy patterns in the stone!

stops.significance: The wavy patterns in some of the stones are ripple marks that reveal evidence of a time in which all of the stone was sand underneath a moving body of water.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the steps and follow the path to the point at which it connects with the main Circle Trail. Look up to your left at the pillar of stone.

stops.significance: Looking up at the same pillar that is called "Leaping Rock" from below, one can see the profile of a face. This is known as "Old Stone Face" from this vantage point.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn right along the trail away from the waterfall and follow the paved path. Do not go off trail towards the water (we must protect plant life and - depending on the time of year - turtle eggs).

stops.significance: To your right along the trail is a large patch of smooth sumac. Around late August/early September the leaves of this plant turn a brilliant fire engine red.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail to the large body of water on your left for the next stop. You will see a wayside and a bench.

stops.significance: This lake was created in the 1930s by the CCC-ID as part of Roosevelt's New Deal. The intention was to provide a swimming hole for Native American children at the Pipestone Indian Boarding School which ran from 1893-1953. Today, the water is extremely contaminated. Please do not go into the water or let pets drink from it.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the paved trail to the next stop.

stops.significance: The stone extracted from the quarry pit nearest the wayside comes out red with white spots, creating beautiful patterns. It is hypothesized that somewhere near this area is where the earliest quarries would have been.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the paved path back towards the Visitor Center or around the building to the parking lot. The final stop can be reached via car along the entrance road on your right as you leave.

stops.significance: These large, granite boulders have been - and still are - sacred to many people for centuries. Understood as guardians or keepers of the quarries, quarriers pray and give offerings at this location. Please do not climb on the boulders and keep a respectful distance.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Thank you for visiting!

images.title: Strolling the Trail
images.altText: A family walking the trail on a sunny day
images.caption: The trail is open 24/7

data.title: Self-Guided Driving Tour
data.description: Whether you are a first timer or a veteran visitor of Kennesaw Mountain, this driving tour with short bits of walking is a great introduction to the country's most heavily visited National Battlefield Park. On this tour, you will see beautiful views, historic earthworks, authentic artillery pieces, and more.

stops.significance: The Visitor Center at Kennesaw Mountain is a key place to orient yourself to the layout and history of the park. You can grab maps, use the restroom, view the museum, and more.
stops.assetName: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park Visitor Center
stops.directionsToNextStop: You can get to the top of Big Kennesaw Mountain by hiking or driving.  To drive (Monday - Friday only), access the mountain road located at the back of the Visitor Center parking lot.

stops.significance: This point is one of the highest in Cobb County and was a key location to the Confederate Army during the battle. It is also a very popular tourist destination.
stops.directionsToNextStop: You will drive back down the mountain road and exit the Visitor Center lot. You will take an immediate left onto Stilesboro Rd. You will continue just over a mile and take a left onto Gilbert Rd. There will be several pull-offs on the left side of the road to park. Once parked, look for the trailhead nearby on that same side of the road and walk a short, flat, 10th of a mile to the first cannon emplacement of the 24-Gun Battery.
stops.audioTranscript: Standing 1,808 above sea level, Big Kennesaw is a prominent mondadknock (isolated peak not connected to another chain) in Cobb County, GA. Offering commanding views to the north and south, this mountain has been significant for centuries. Native Americans were said to have named it either after a prominent Chief in the area, or from the term ‘Ghaneesah’, which meant ‘sacred place’ or ‘burial place’. Looking to the south, you can see several large skylines, the two most prominent being Buckhead and Atlanta. Looking to the north, you can see the path of Cobb Parkway stretching to the northwest horizon. Also, on a clear day, you can see the distant range of the Allatoona Mountains. During the battle, this was also a prominent artillery position for the Confederate army, as evidenced by the 4 cannon emplacements that you see today.

stops.significance: This was a major, and perhaps largest, Union artillery position of the battle.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Gilbert Rd through a small neighborhood. This will end at Old Mountain Rd, where you will take a right. When you get to Burnt Hickory Rd, take a right, and then an immediate left into the parking lot. The top of Pigeon Hill is located across the street, through the crosswalk, at the end of a short, but steep walk up the side of the hill.
stops.audioTranscript: Located on a small, wooded rise facing Little Kennesaw and Pigeon Hill, this Federal gun emplacement accommodated four batteries, each containing six artillery pieces. These guns bombarded Confederate forces on Kennesaw Mountain off and on for 10 days. Today, four artillery pieces have been placed in the historic earthworks: thee 3 inch ordnance rifles (iron tubes painted black) and one 12 pound Napoleon gun (bronze gun with green oxidation).

stops.significance: Site of major Union assault during Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Hike back down to the Burnt Hickory Parking lot. Upon exiting the lot, take a right onto Burnt Hickory Rd. You will continue until you get to the intersection of Whitlock Ave. and Burnt Hickory. You will take a right at this intersection and continue down Whitlock Ave for approximately 5 minutes. You will see a pedestrian crosswalk and crossing signal light and will turn left here onto Cheatham Hill Dr. Drive all the way down into the last parking lot. The Illinois Monument is a short, flat walk just ahead.
stops.audioTranscript: he Union frontal assault at Pigeon Hill was one of two attempts to break the Confederate defenses along the Kennesaw line on June 27th, 1864. While there were not as many casualties here as there were at Cheatham Hill, the assault was still especially difficult. This was largely due to the steep and rocky terrain. The Confederates held the high ground, using the natural defenses to their advantage. It had been raining for nearly 3 weeks prior to the battle, so the Union forces also had the marshy, muddy ground at the foot of the hill to contend with. A portion of the force became lost and began climbing up the draw between Pigeon Hill and Little Kennesaw, right into the face of the cannon positioned there. If you look closely, you can still see the remains of the Confederate cannon positions on Pigeon Hill, appearing in the steep, craggy hill side.

stops.significance: Dedicated to the Union soldiers that fell assaulting the Confederate 'Dead Angle'
stops.directionsToNextStop: Drive out of Cheatham Hill Dr. back to Whitlock Ave. Take a left onto Whitlock Ave. You will continue a short distance to your next traffic light, which is at John Ward Rd. Take a left here and continue through the traffic circle just a short distance away. You will continue along Cheatham Hill Rd for some time until you get to the large 4 way intersection of Powder Springs Rd. and Cheatham Hill Rd. Continue straight through the light, and turn right immediately into the small lot to the right of the family cemetery.
stops.audioTranscript: Dedicated on June 27, 1914, on the 50th Anniversary of the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain, the Illinois Monument was strategically placed at the location where the Federal assault peaked on Cheatham Hill. Originally the Kennesaw Memorial Association, a veteran’s association, tried to raise funds for the monument, but the state of Illinois would provide $20,000.00 to fund the construction of a monument and a gubernatorial appointed commission to oversee the project. The McNeel Marble Company of Marietta, Georgia erected the monument. The monument stands 25 feet high and is made of Georgia white marble. An American eagle sets atop the monument and life-size figures of a Union soldier at parade rest is flanked by two Grecian women. The monument was restored the fall of 2013 through spring of 2014. It was rededicated on June 27, 2014, as part of the 150th Anniversary of the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.

stops.significance: Oldest structure in the park, site of major Civil War Battle (Battle of Kolb's Farm)
stops.audioTranscript:
The Kolb family was one of several pioneering families of Cobb County who came to the area after the removal of the Cherokee people. Peter Valentine and Eliza Kolb purchased 600 acres of woodland, turning it into a prosperous family farm and were considered an upper middle-class family. As a prosperous yeoman farmer, Peter Valentine Kolb had seven children, 10 slaves, several outbuildings, in addition to his to 600 acres of farmland.
On the afternoon of June 22, 1864, Union soldiers repulsed Confederate General Hood’s ill-fated attack just north of Powder Spring Road. The Kolb house was used as headquarters for Union General Joseph Hooker and as a temporary field hospital. During the fighting, the home and farm suffered major damage. Although they did not immediately return to the area, the Kolb family would return to the location after the war. Today, the once large farm consists only of the original farmhouse and the Kolb family cemetery.

images.title: Cannon and Visitor Center
images.altText: Iconic photo of the park's front memorial field with cannon in front
images.caption: Iconic photo of the park's front memorial field with cannon in front

data.title: Self-Guided Driving Tour
data.description: This tour is the 9 mile, 11 stop auto tour of the battlefield. Each stop has a parking lot and interpretive signs providing additional information about each location. Some of the stops also are great places to start a short hike of the surrounding area.

stops.significance: The church is one of the most recognizable structures on a Civil War battlefield.  Action swirled around this building during the battle.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed about a mile north to the North Woods.

stops.significance: Union forces spent the night before the battle on this farm.  At daybreak they advanced from this area south, toward the Cornfield.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Travel east along the tour road, down Mansfield Ave. Turn right at the T intersection and drive to Cornfield Ave. Turn right. The stop for the East Woods will be just a short way down on the right.

stops.significance: There was a small skirmish the night before the battle for control of these woods.  On the morning of the 17th, both sides fought over this ground and Union Gen. Joseph Mansfield was mortally wounded a few hundred yards northeast of this spot.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed west to the top of the hill.  Stop #4 The Cornfield will be on the right side of the road.

stops.significance: A Confederate counterattack in this part of the field inflicted 2300 Union casualties in roughly 30 minutes during the morning of the battle.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Travel south on the Hagerstown Pike.  Turn left on the Smoketown Rd. (just before the Dunker Church.)  Turn right on Mumma Farm Lane and proceed down the hill to the farm.

stops.significance: The Mumma Farm was burned during the battle by the Confederates.  The family was not compensated for their loss.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue from the Mumma Farm down the one-way road about 1/4 of a mile to stop 7, which is a pull off on the left side of the road.

stops.significance: The Union attack upon the Sunken Road advanced across the fields to the east of this stop.  Over 10,000 Federal troops moved through this area over the course of three hours.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the Mumma Farm Lane to the Sunken Road.  Turn left at the intersection and proceed 1/4 mile to the parking lot for stop 8, on the left side of the road.

stops.significance: Confederate forces defended the Sunken Road against numerous Union attacks.  The line broke at noon, but with no troops in the area to capitalize, the Union attacks stalled out.
stops.assetName: Sunken Road at Antietam - Tour Stop 8
stops.directionsToNextStop: Drive toward the stone observation tower.  Continue past the tower and continue down the Sunken Road, all the way to Rt.34.  Be careful crossing Rt 34 and continue to the next intersection and turn left.  Continue to the parking area for stop 9, Burnside Bridge.

stops.significance: This bridge is one of the most recognized landmarks of the Civil War.  Confederate troops held the high ground overlooking the bridge until the third Union assault carried the bridge.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This part of the battlefield is one way.  Drive from the lot down the hill, and go to the stop sign.  Continue straight and you will arrive at stop 10, located on the top of the hill.

stops.significance: The last part of the battle unfolded on the fields around you. 8000 Union troops moved east to west and eventually gained the high ground to the west, only to be turned back by the timely arrival of Confederate reinforcements.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Remember, this is a one way road.  Continue south and eventually you will end up at a T intersection.  Turn right, and head north toward the town of Sharpsburg.  Turn right at the stop sign on Main St.  Continue about 3/4 of a mile to the Antietam National Cemetery.  Parking will be on the right side of the road and just past the cemetery is an overflow parking lot.

stops.significance: The Antietam National Cemetery is the final resting place for 4800 Union soldiers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: To return to the visitor center, head back west, toward Sharpsburg.  Just down the hill from the cemetery, turn right and head north one mile us RT 65 to the visitor center.  The drive for the visitor center is on the right.
