images.altText: civil war cannon
images.caption: Cannon at Antietam

data.title: Self-Guided Park Tour
data.description: Explore the trails and grounds of Homestead National Historical Park to learn more about the impacts of the Homestead Act of 1862.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Enter and explore the Homestead Heritage Center.
stops.audioTranscript:
Hello and welcome to the site of one of the first homestead claimed under the Homestead Act of 1862. Imagine you're seeking a homestead in the late 19th century, and you and your family are traveling west in a covered wagon, and you come upon a homestead. Most likely you would be welcomed warmly and invited to stay for a visit. Since neighbors usually weren't living in close proximity an unexpected visit was a pleasant surprise. Spotting an approaching wagon, children would run outside for a better look. The adults might prepare something to eat or drink for their guests. Despite the fact that homesteaders may have been isolated, they depended on their neighbors to survive, to build a school harvest their crops, care for the sick, birth a baby, and even prevent loneliness. homesteaders work together as a community to be successful. In fact, in order to prove up on your homestead claim and gain legal ownership, you needed two witnesses attesting to your presence and to your improvement of the land… 

To document your travels, you may have written letters or kept a journal to remember those you met, you may have even asked them to sign or write a short note in your autograph book. To have your picture taken with something special was not a common occurrence. Today we encourage you to take photographs, perhaps next to this park entrance sign or out on the prairie, send a postcard to your family or friends. Write your name in the visitor guest book, or even post pictures and comments about your visit on the parks Facebook page. Although we live in the 21st century homestead remembers those people that traveled west, in the hopes of a better life and a place to call their own. However, you decide to spend your time here, we welcome you and hope you enjoy your visit.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the Heritage Center using the back doors and follow the concrete path to the cabin.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Heritage Center. This building was dedicated on May 20 2007 and is designed to represent the Homestead Act of 1862, with its spectacular views and unique roofline resembling a single bottom plow moving through the sod.
 Along the sidewalk entrance to the building is the living wall, every state that had public domain land , open to homesteading is represented, and the cutout represents the percentage of land that was successfully homesteaded. 
Inside the museum, you will find state of the art exhibits presenting homesteading in an interactive setting. These exhibit cover topics such as the Act’s impacts on immigration, agriculture, industrialization, American Indian tribes, the tall grass prairie ecosystem, and federal land policies. You might want to begin your tour by watching the park’s interpretive film, which premiered in April 2008. The film chronicles the great changes brought about by the passage and implementation of the Homestead Act. The Homestead Act transferred from the public domain to private ownership over 270 million acres of land in 30 states between 1863, in 1986. Enjoy your visit to Homestead National Historical Park.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the concrete path to the a view point of your choice to explore what pioneers and early homesteaders first encountered.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now at the Palmer Epard cabin. This cabin was constructed in 1867 on a nearby homestead and moved to the park in 1950. The furnishings depict life in the 1800s. It was constructed of mixed hardwoods including oak hackberry ash locust walnut and Elm and homemade brickset and lime mortar. It measures 14 by 16 feet. The cabin was built by George Washington Palmer. He was a native of Ohio and served as a private in Company B 23rd Wisconsin volunteers during the civil war…. upon his discharge he returned to his Ohio Home and made plans to sell his land and move to Nebraska to homestead…. from his wife's half brothers he heard of the rich soil, mild climate and excellent crops of southeastern Nebraska.
During his first two winters in the area he lived in a dugout on the west bank of Bear Creek in Logan Township, about 14 miles northeast of here. In the spring of 1866. He planted his first crop of corn and pumpkins, and in the fall of the next year, built this cabin with the help of his neighbors.
In the spring of 1868 Palmer brought his wife and children to the homestead and they moved into the cabin. On May 26 1868 George W Palmer filed application number 2614 in the Brownville Land Office for the 160 acres and paid the $14 fee. By March 1875 he had plowed and planted an acre in forest trees, built a stable, a greenery, a cattle yard a corn crib and dug a well.. All of this was part of proving up. in order to receive title to the land, a homesteader had to build a home and make improvements on May 5 1875 Palmer paid the final $4 payment which entitled him to the deed for his 160 acres.
During the five years after 1875 Palmer added a 10 by 12 foot lean to on the rear of their original cabin which served as their kitchen. in 1895 Palmer and his wife sold the farm to their nephews.
This log cabin is just one style of home built and lived-in by homesteaders.

stops.significance: Homestead National Historical Park is home to the oldest restored tallgrass prairie in the National Park Service. The restoration began in 1939.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the concrete path to the beginning of the trail system just behind the Palmer-Epard cabin. Additionally, you can walk down the upland loop trail to explore the hedgerow more.
stops.audioTranscript: Although early explores of the Great Plains called this region the Great American Desert pioneers found the land by the Missouri River, well suited to farming. The area was covered by the lush grasses that can grow up to nine feet tall. This belt of grasslands, extending from Minnesota to Texas became known as the tall grass prairie… as you look out at the restored prairie you are seeing what one of the first homesteader saw. But Daniel Freeman saw this tall grass very differently than we do today. He thought it was a nuisance to be replaced as soon as possible with crops that would pay his way. Freeman filed his homestead claim on January 1 1863 In Brownville Nebraska and returned to his T shaped claim and began the process of homesteading. Over the next five years Freeman constructed a home and cultivated crops. He did this and received his deed on September 1 1869. The original 160 acre homestead claim was purchased by the United States Department of the Interior, in 1936 in order to create Homestead National historical park... This complex ecosystem is made up of flowers, birds, mammals, insects and micro organisms… tall grass prairie is so named because the component grasses. Big Bluestem, Little Bluestem, Indian grass, and switchgrass can reach nine feet tall. You can explore more of the prairie by following one of the walking trails which start at either visitor center. Ask a ranger for a trail map and begin your explorations today.

stops.significance: This hedgerow was planted by Daniel Freeman. Freeman is recognized as one of the first homesteaders in the Nation as he filed his claim the very day the Homestead Act took effect.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow a trail or drive to the Education Center. To travel by car, exit the Heritage Center parking lot and turn left. Follow HWY 4 .5 miles and turn left into the parking lot.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are near the Osage orange hedgerow plan ted by Daniel Freeman, one of the first homesteaders. Once Freeman claimed his 160 acres, he needed to build a home and cultivate some crops. He also needed fencing to mark his property, and to keep his crop safe from livestock, which were allowed to roam freely, and since there was a limited amount of wood to build fences, Freeman chose to plant Osage orange trees. These were not the first trees used for fencing, but by the 1850s, it was considered the premier prairie hedge plant.  agricultural journals and state legislatures were praising Osage orange hedges and recommending their use.

Osage orange has various qualities that made it ideal as a hedge plant for the prairies, it is a hardy tree that grows in different soil types, and can withstand drought, heat, and wind. It has thick set zigzag branchlets with thorns, and its branches touch the ground, if it is kept trimmed correctly, shearing bending and even cutting it off to the ground only encourages new shoes. 

 Most importantly, many farmers found it cheaper to put in, and maintain then wood fences. Proponents of Osage orange trees were also quick to point out the aesthetic value of trees. Some even went so far as to claim that Osage orange would modify the climate by encouraging rain to come to otherwise dry areas. The fact that the trees would break the wind was also important. Despite its advantages, Osage orange hedge, met with some severe criticisms.

 Most of the criticism focused on the labor involved in making a row of Osage orange shrubs, into a good fence. They are painstakingly crafted over a number of years as young shoots are trained to grow horizontally and woven into neighboring plants until the hedge forms a continuous living fence. Daniel Freeman may have been one of those that found it too labor intensive. There are records of him planting the trees, but no record of him maintaining it as a hedge. a hedge had to be trimmed at least once every summer, or the fence would not resist stock correctly. In fact, one farmer from Kansas, had this to say about maintaining the hedge… working a hedge is just about the hardest and most disagreeable work any fellow ever engaged in. besides if great care is not exercised, you may get a thorn thrust into your eye, knee or other joints, thus getting maimed for life. 

Although it was difficult to maintain as a fence, the wood was durable. even after farmers were no longer using it as fencing, they used it to make fence post for the newly invented barbed wire. posts made from Osage orange could last 50 years or longer. Farmers joked that the Osage orange post would outlast two post holes. Its sturdiness can be seen in these trees. 

The three fourths of a mile hedge were planted in the 1870s, and it's still going strong

stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the back doors of the Homestead Education Center and go through the double doors into the farm implement wing.

stops.significance: Explore the advancement of farm machinery and implements.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the farm implement wing and follow the sidewalk over the suspension bridge to view the prairie and native plant display.

The Freeman School is a 1/4 mile west of the Education Center. If you wish to walk, a foot trail follows and crosses the highway. If you wish to drive, an additional parking lot is available north of the school.
stops.audioTranscript:
The restored prairie at Homestead National Historical Park is a good teacher if we look and listen. Many different plant families live here, including the milkweeds the goldenrods and the grasses, these plant families provided food, medicine, and raw materials to the American Indians and the homesteaders. Milkweed are easily recognized, look for the feathery parachutes, these are the odd shaped seed pods that form from the large pink flowers. Milkweed isn't always popular with the farmers but it is important to monarch butterflies, The goldenrod is another common plant of the restored prairie. It is an erect coarse looking perennial herb that is usually about two to three feet tall. The small flower heads, which are almost always yellow but sometimes cream colored or white rays are grouped in either elongated or flattish clusters, the flowers appear from July through October. It is Nebraska State flower. You can also find nebraska’s state grass here, it is little bluestem and is very ornamental bunchgrass that has fine textured foliage that forms, very dense mounds that reach 18 to 24 inches high. 
Slender, blue Greens stems appearing in August reach three foot by September, and become radiant mahogany red and white shining south in the fall. Another type of grass found in the park is prairie cord grass, it is found in the low wet areas and can grow up to eight feet tall. The leaf blades are coarse and very tough, the margins of the leaves are serrated and sharp. The stems are very stiff. Before homesteading the prairie nutrients were restored to it by burning, you might think that fire on the prairie is a bad thing, but really it is good for helping the plants to grow healthy and strong. After a burn the soil is enriched with nutrients.  The last plant family that we see in the park, is also one of the largest…. the Astra family. This includes the sunflowers and the golden rods, and many others. The stem of the flower can grow as high as three meters tall, the tallgrass prairie the first homesteaders encountered was beautiful and diverse in it’s makeup. In restoring the prairie at Homestead National Historical Park, we hope that you can get a glimpse of what those homesteaders saw when they arrived to the Tallgrass Prairie.

stops.directionsToNextStop: End of Tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
Officially know as School District 21, the Freeman School is one of the oldest one room school houses in the state of Nebraska.  The brick school was built on this land during 1871 and 1872. Thomas Freeman made the bricks for the schoolhouse, and it is even possible that the school is named after him. According to records he was paid $100 for them by the school district, Thomas Freeman was not related to Daniel. 
After opening, the Freeman school enjoyed steady growth over the next few years and in 1880 there were 33 students enrolled, both Daniel and his wife Agnes had served as director of the school. 

In 1898 the school received national attention. Miss Edith Beecher was employed that year as the teacher. She asked and was granted permission by the school board to conduct religious exercises in the school. The exercises consisted of reading Bible passages, singing songs from a gospel hymn book, and offering prayers to a deity. Daniel Freeman strongly objected and when the school board and the superintendent supported Miss Beecher, Freeman filed suit in Gage County District Court, asking the school board be forced to discontinue using the Bible and the gospel handbook to conduct religious exercises.  
When The district court judge sided with Miss Beecher and the school board, Freeman then appealed the decision to the Nebraska Supreme Court. In 1902 The court ruled in Freeman's favor saying the district was in violation of the state constitution, which forbids sectarian instruction in any school supported by public funds. However, the court did not find that Bible reading in the public schools was unconstitutional. The court said Bible reading was only unlawful when the teacher becomes a sectarian propagandist. The school operated until 1967 and held the honor of being the oldest continuously operated one room school in the state of Nebraska and the Freeman School became part of Homestead National Historical park in 1970.

images.title: Self-Guided Tour at Homestead
images.altText: Homestead Logo over an image of the pointed roof visitor center in the park.
images.caption: Follow the Self-Guided Tour of the Park

data.title: Self-Guided Park Tour
data.description: We suggest you begin the 16-mile tour at the visitor center, where the new interactive campaign map, exhibits, and a 20-minute film explain the campaign and siege of Vicksburg. The numbered stops on this tour are keyed to the map on the back of the park brochure. During the tour, visitors will notice either red or blue metal markers placed by the War Department as the first interpretation of the park. Blue markers pertain to Union lines or emplacements. Red markers pertain to Confederate forces.

stops.significance: This location demonstrates the dominance the Union artillery would have over the Confederates throughout the siege.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Moving north up Union avenue, vehicles will then follow the road west towards Tour Stop #2, the Shirley House.
stops.audioTranscript:
After Federal forces failed to take the Confederate defenses by storm on May 22nd 1863, General Grant's army began conducting siege operations, digging trenches and placing cannons in strategic locations.

Captain Samuel De Golyer established this battery on May 25th 1863, putting his 8th Battery, Michigan Light Artillery on this ridge. During the siege, upwards of 22 cannons on this ridge bombarded the Confederate defenders both day and night.

Civil War artillery was organized into groups of up to six cannon called batteries which allowed Federal artillerymen to constantly bombard the nine major Confederate forts guarding the roads into the city.  Among the cannon mounted here are smoothbore and rifled models. By looking at the front of the cannon muzzle, you can tell them apart by looking at the interior of the barrel. Rifled guns will have a series or ridges that spiral toward the back of the barrel, while smoothbores are, well, smoothe. 

Another major difference in the guns was the metal used to make the barrels.  All of the green guns you see in the park are made of bronze or iron. To tell the difference, just remember that bronze turns green with age.  

And if there is any doubt about the ability of the Federal gunners positioned here during the siege to hit the Great Redoubt (a Confederate fortification marked by a tall granite monument some 650 in front of you), most of the guns of De Golyer’s battery could hit targets from 1600 to 1800 yards away.

Sadly, De Golyer, who had earned a reputation during the Vicksburg campaign as one of the most capable artillery officers in Grant's army, only served here for a few days before a Confederate sharpshooter severely wounded him which proved mortal.

stops.significance: Understanding part of the civilian experiences during the siege of Vicksburg.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue driving west to Tour Stop #3 - The Third Louisiana Redan.
stops.audioTranscript:
Known by both Union and Confederate soldiers simply as the “White House,” the Shirley House is the only wartime structure that remains on the battlefield.

Built in the late 1830s, James and Adeline Shirley purchased the house in 1851.  Although the Shirleys were slave owners, they were not for disunion. When the Secession Crisis came, James supported the Union, as did the majority of Vicksburg voters who recognized that their fortunes were bound to the free flow of commerce on the Mississippi River.

In early spring 1863, the Shirley House boasted a manicured walkway, a beautiful garden, and fruit trees in the back yard; a pastoral scene that conflicted with the raw Confederate fortifications built the previous year just a few hundred down the Jackson Road leading toward Vicksburg.  

In May, the Shirley’s lives would change forever.  

James and daughter Alice found themselves trapped in Clinton, Mississippi, and separated from the rest of the family when Union soldiers cut the railroad running to Vicksburg.

Home alone with son Quincy, Adeline found herself defending her house—literally.  

Fearing that the Shirley’s house would be used by Union sharpshooters, the Confederates ordered it burned down, and sent a soldier with a torch to complete the task.

But Adeline Shirley, unwilling to let her house go up without a fight, begged the soldier not to, delaying him so long that advancing Union soldiers shot the unfortunate man.

Although she had saved her home, the shot and shell coming from both sides became too dangerous, and she and her son Quincy had to seek shelter in a cave in the Union lines.

They eventually ended up moving into one of their former slave cabins, but never lived in the white house again, the war had damaged it too much.  

Her daughter Alice sold the house to the U. S. Government in May 1900, on the condition that her parents would be buried in the back yard, and that the home be fully restored - circumstances both met at the time.

stops.significance: Understanding the strength of the Confederate fortifications and how the Union army tried different methods in attempting to capture Vicksburg,
stops.directionsToNextStop: Following the tour road, visitors vehicles return past the Illinois monument and Shirley House, then make a 45 degree turn to proceed on the tour road heading north.
stops.audioTranscript:
Having failed to take this Confederate fort by storm on May 22, General Grant ordered his army to begin siege operations against the Confederate works. 

Subsequently, his engineers supervised the digging of approach trenches from the Union lines toward all the forts marked for destruction.

The first of these was started just past the Shirley House and extended to the Third Louisiana Redan, one of two massive forts guarding the old Jackson road into Vicksburg.

The Union soldiers made quick progress, reaching the point of the redan in a matter of weeks.  Not content to stop there, they continued on with a tunnel forty feet long and directly underneath the men of the Third Louisiana Infantry regiment manning the fort.

On June 25, at 3:30 in the afternoon, the front of the fort erupted in a geyser of dirt and smoke.  The Federal infantrymen had packed 2,200 pounds of black powder in the tunnel and hoped that by blowing it up, they could open the way to Vicksburg.  

The earth rose up and swallowed confederate soldiers, leaving a crater forty feet wide and twelve feet deep.  A blue column of Federals stood in the approach trench all the way to the Shirley House; preparing to pour through the smoking hole in the Confederate line and bring the siege to an end.

But that was not to be the case, for when the men of the 45th Illinois rushed into the crater and they ran into a wall of Confederate iron and lead.  

Trapped in the crater and unable to advance, the Union troops persevered for 24 hours before finally withdrawing in failure. On July 1st, they detonated another 1800lbs of gunpowder under the redan, but made no attempt to launch an assault.

stops.significance: John Wesley Powell's involvement in the siege of Vicksburg.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to follow the tour road north to Tour Stop #5 - the Stockade Redan Attack.
stops.audioTranscript:
On June 15th, Union soldiers under the command of General Thomas E. G. Ransom began digging approach trenches toward rifle pits manned by the 37th Mississippi Infantry, some 200 yards away.

In order to better protect his men, General Ransom directed Captain John Wesley Powell of the 2nd Illinois Light Artillery to place an artillery battery a mere 100 yards from the Confederate line.

Although Powell had already lost an arm in the battle of Shiloh, he was up to the task. Powell had his men disassemble two cannon and haul them by hand into position where they were reassembled. 

The guns pounded the Mississippians at point blank range and effectively kept the riflemen’s heads down while the Union slowly constructed the approach trenches in preparation for a charge that would never be ordered.

In 1869, after the Civil War, Powell became famous for leading a successful expedition of nine men in four boats down Colorado River through the Grand Canyon.

In 1881 he became director of the U.S. Geological Survey, and later director of the Bureau of Ethnology at the Smithsonian Institution.

stops.significance: General Grant's army realizes how difficult capturing Vicksburg was going to be.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed up Union Avenue to the fork and make a right on Grant's Avenue. The African American monument is the detour turnaround which leads vehicles back over the Graveyard Road. At the end of the Graveyard Road, make a right for the USS Cairo Gunboat Museum or left to continue on Confederate avenue toward the Visitors Center.
stops.audioTranscript:
Downcast from defeats at Champion Hill and the Big Black River Bridge, the demoralized remnants of Pemberton’s army made its way into the defenses of Vicksburg on May 18.

Hot on their heels and eager to end the campaign quickly, the men of General Sherman’s corps pressed the Confederates relentlessly.  

Having defeating the Confederates every where they encountered them since they crossed the Mississippi, Grant believed a quick, sledgehammer blow would shatter the Confederate line and give him Vicksburg.  

The target of that heavy blow was the Stockade Redan complex, a trio of large forts that blocked the Graveyard Road entrance to the city.

At 2:00 p.m. on May 19, Sherman launched his assault on the huge earthwork that commanded the road.  Struggling through the deep ravines on either side of the road, the blue-clad troops contended with manmade obstacles as well as the steep inclines.  

Pinned down, the Federals sought shelter wherever they could find it and remained until night provided cover for their retreat. The assault cost Sherman close to 1000 casualties.

Three days later on May 22, Stockade Redan was again attacked as part of a general assault on all major Confederate positions along a three mile front. This time, Sherman sent his men straight down the old Graveyard Road. 

When the Union artillery ceased the bombardment that morning, the attackers were led by 150 volunteers who carried planks to bridge the ditch in front of the redan and ladders to scale the walls. 

The Confederate defenders held their fire until the Federals had almost reached the redan. Then they rose from behind the walls and delivered a devastating volley of musket fire that nearly filled the road with dead and wounded.  

Other unsupported assaults by parts of Sherman's corps were unsuccessful, and again, Sherman’s troops were forced to retreat after suffering terrible losses.

stops.significance: Thayer's unique approach and tunnel.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to proceed on Confederate Avenue heading west towards the USS Cairo Gunboat Museum. Tour Stop #9 - Fort Hill is between this stop and the museum.
stops.audioTranscript:
The assaults of May 22nd were heroic, but futile attempts. Here, the Union soldiers attempted to drive the 26th Louisiana Infantry from its positions at the crest of the hill before you.

Having failed to carry this section of Confederate line by storm, General John M. Thayer’s soldiers then began digging a six-foot deep approach trench towards the Rebel positions. 

Union troops digging the approach were concealed by a roof made of bundles of cane called fascines. In addition to providing cover from the hot Mississippi sun, the laboring troops were well-protected from rebel musket fire. 

At one point, to slow their enemy down, the Confederates built a stockade in front of their earthwork, but it had little effect, and the boys in blue dug under it. 

When Thayer’s men neared the Confederate line they began tunneling under the fort and had almost completed their work when the surrender came on July 4th, which was fortunate for the men inside, for if they had held out much longer, the Union soldiers would have filled it with gunpowder and blew it up.

The tunnel under the road was dug by Union troops camped in the rear to avoid crossing the ridge where they would be exposed to Confederate sharpshooters while moving to and from their positions in the lines.

stops.significance: Understanding the uniqueness of sailors manning a battery on the Union siege lines.
stops.directionsToNextStop: *This stop is part of a temporary road closure. The top part of the Navy Monument can be seen from the USS Cairo Gunboat Museum parking lot.
stops.audioTranscript:
Manned entirely by Union sailors, this battery is unique among all the Union artillery positions on the siege lines. 

The battery commander was Thomas O. Selfridge, the former commander of the USS Cairo, which sunk on December 12, 1862, when it struck a torpedoes in the Yazoo River, just a few miles north of here. 

During the siege, this crew was so unusual that Union soldiers regularly gathered here to witness a spectacle unseen by most infantrymen. 

Recreating ship life ashore, the sailors that crewed the naval guns of Battery Selfridge maintained the routine of life aboard ship as best they could. Much to the entertainment of their land based brothers; the sailors slept in hammocks, polished the gun platforms, and manned the guns according to Navy regulations.

The 202-foot tall obelisk is the Navy Monument similar to the Washington Monument, in Washington DC. Around the base are prominent naval commanders who participated in the campaign for Vicksburg. 

Abraham Lincoln jokingly referred to the navy “Uncle Sam’s webbed feet” when speaking of that branch’s contributions to the final Union victory.

stops.significance: Understanding the sacrifices made during the Vicksburg campaign.
stops.directionsToNextStop: *This site is temporarily closed to vehicle traffic but is open for walking. Proceed up Connecting Avenue and turn left up the hill to Tour Stop #9 - Fort Hill.
stops.audioTranscript:
Here, beneath magnolia trees and manicured grounds, rest the remains of those that paid the ultimate sacrifice in service to their country.

With the remains of Union soldiers and sailors buried at every hospital, camp site, and battlefield in the region, Vicksburg National Cemetery was established in 1866 as a final resting place for all Union remains found south of the Arkansas state line and north of Grand Gulf, Mississippi. 

Ultimately, more than 17,000 Unions servicemen were disinterred and reburied, making Vicksburg National Cemetery the largest Civil War burial ground in the nation.  Unfortunately, due to the primitive burial practices of the armies on the move, such as marking graves with wooden slats, 75% of the dead could not be identified.

Although primarily containing Union burials, the cemetery remained open until 1961, accepting the remains of over 1,280 casualties from Spanish-American War, World War I, World War II, and the Korean Conflict, as well as honorably discharged veterans and their spouses.  

Among the civilians in the cemetery are: 129 spouses, 9 children, 4 park superintendents, and 27 government workers.

The remains of Vicksburg’s valiant Confederate defenders lay at Soldier’s Rest in Vicksburg Municipal cemetery not far from here.

Signs along the tour road contain stanzas taken from the Bivouac of the Dead, a poem written in 1847 in honor of the men who died during the Battle of Buena Vista in the Mexican-American War. The poem’s message was so universal, however, that it became a staple of cemeteries and memorial services in both the north and the south.

stops.significance: Understanding the importance of the elevation and the Mississippi that made Vicksburg a focal point of the Civil War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on Confederate Avenue heading east towards Tour Stop #10 - the Stockade Redan.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1863, one would have seen an awesome sight: the great bend of the Mississippi River and the Union navy that sought to control it.

This hill is the reason why Vicksburg became the focal point of the war in the western Confederacy, and from here the Confederates could halt all steamboat movement up and down the river.

The river is no longer here, it changed course during a flood in 1876, but the hill remains, a silent witness to the battle.

This hill was the northern end of the Confederate lines, and so strong that no infantry attack was ever made upon it. 

The Union Navy, however, did do battle with the Confederate gunners stationed here, and with the Water Battery, at the base of the hill near where the National Cemetery is today.

On May 27, 1863, the ironclad gunboat U.S.S. Cincinnati, sister ship of the U.S.S. Cairo, came under fire from these Confederate batteries. 

For over thirty minutes the brave sailors took a pounding from the heavy Rebel guns before sinking in 18 feet of water near the top of the bend. This action marked the second time the Cincinnati was sunk during the war, and after the siege ended, she was raised again, and sent back to the flotilla for more service.

stops.significance: The strength of the Confederate defenses forced the Union army into siege operations.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following Confederate Avenue heading esouth towards Tour Stop #11 - the Great Redoubt.
stops.audioTranscript:
Situated just south of the Graveyard Road, the Stockade Redan formed the center of a group of fortifications that beat back two major Union assaults. 

The northernmost of these fortification, a lunette, or half moon shaped earthwork, was occupied by the 27th Louisiana Infantry.  

From here the Confederates could direct fire at any Union troops who made it to the base of the Stockade Redan. Further blocking Federal hopes on the Graveyard Road, Confederate engineers built a poplar log wall that connected both fortifications.

Another fort, Green's Redan, was positioned 75 yards south of the Stockade Redan to bring fire to bear on any Union troops who went in that direction.

It was along this road during the May 19th attack that Orion P. Howe, a 14-year old Drummer Boy, received serious wounds while attempting to get ammunition for his comrades in the 55th Illinois Infantry Regiment.

The brave young man, though seriously wounded and bleeding badly, made his way through the hail of bullets and shell toward the rear, where he found General William T. Sherman, and gave him the message for more ammunition. 

He was later awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his bravery.  After the war, Howe attended the US Naval Academy, but settled down as a dentist in Missouri.

The fighting at the Stockade Redan on May 19th and May 22nd, typified that of other positions along the Confederate lines, with Union forces huddled at the base of the fortifications, unable to move forward and unable to escape, waiting on night to come so they could get back to their lines.

But while they waited on darkness to come, the Confederates tossed artillery shells over the walls at them. In some cases the Union soldiers caught them and tossed them back, both sides playing a deadly game of survival.

stops.significance: The futility of the Union assaults on the Confederate forts.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to follow Confederate Avenue to Tour Stop #12 - the Second Texas Lunette.
stops.audioTranscript:
Located just south of the Jackson Road, the Great Redoubt was the largest of the Confederate fortifications guarding the roads to Vicksburg. With openings for five guns, it was also among the strongest too.  Occupied by the 21st Louisiana Infantry, the defenders counted Abraham Lincoln's brother-in-law as an officer in their ranks.

On May 22nd, Union General John D. Stevenson's brigade had the responsibility of taking the position. Staging just 200 yards from the fort in a ravine, his men brought scaling ladders to mount the fort's steep walls.  

After running through a deadly wall of artillery fire, and suffering terrible casualties, including the loss of six color bearers, the 7th Missouri Infantry managed to reach the base of the fort, only to make the heartbreaking discovery that their ladders were too short.  

Unable to scale the walls and break into the Great Redoubt, Stevenson's brigade had to brave the artillery and rifle fire again as they retreated from the position they had fought so hard to gain.

Although lasting just 30 minutes, the attack cost the brigade 272 casualties. Any Confederate celebrations, however, were short lived, for three days later on the 25th of May, Union artillerymen established a massed battery just 700 yards away to pound on them day and night for the remainder of the siege.

stops.significance: The heroism displayed during the siege and the changing of the landscape from battlefield to Jewish cemetery.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Just passed the cemetery, turn right and continue on Confederate Avenue onto the South Loop towards Tour Stop #13 - Railroad Redoubt.
stops.audioTranscript:
This lunette, or crescent-shaped fort, was constructed to protect the Baldwin’s Ferry Road entrance to Vicksburg. It gets its name from the 2nd Texas Infantry that defended the fort through the entire siege.

At 6:00 a.m. on May 22, 1863, the still morning air was shattered by a four-hour artillery bombardment from the guns of Grant’s army.

At 10:00 a.m., the thunder of the cannon was replaced by rifle and musket fire of thousands of Union troops from Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, and Ohio as they marched forward through a Confederate rain of fire. 

Many of the blue-clad soldiers fell dead or wounded, while others took shelter behind what little protection they could find.

A handful of Federals made it through the determined rebel resistance, most notably Corporal Thomas J. Higgins, the color bearer of the 99th Illinois Volunteer Infantry. 

The courageous Corporal sprinted across the road and scaled the wall of the lunette only to find himself surrounded by the amazed Texans who had reached out to help the brave Federal over the wall, then shook his hand in amazement of his bravery and luck.

The battle continued throughout the day, but by 5:00 p.m. the Texans were reinforced, and the Federals were forced to retreat to the safety of the Union lines.

The cemetery occupying the site was established after the siege by the local Jewish congregation.

stops.significance: This fort was the only place the Union army was able to capture portions of the Confederate defenses but were forced back.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to proceed down Confederate Avenue to Tour Stop #14 - Fort Garrott.
stops.audioTranscript:
This fort was built by the Confederates to guard the approach to Vicksburg via the Southern Railroad of Mississippi.

Of all of Grant’s assaults on the Confederate defenses on May 22nd, the attack on this fort came closest to succeeding.

After a four-hour artillery bombardment, the Federals gunners had blown a hole through the point of the fort. 

And when the signal for the infantry attack sounded, the 22nd Iowa attacked the destroyed section, and a handful of Federals, led by Sgt. Joseph E. Griffith, entered the fort.

There, the fate of Vicksburg hung in the balance.

If Griffith’s men had held on until reinforcements arrived, then they could break through the Confederate line and defeat Pemberton’s army for the last time and capture Vicksburg.

But that day the Confederates were quicker.  

After members of an Alabama regiment refused to retake the fort, a squad of Texans rushed into the rear of the fort, and after a short fight, retook it, and saved Vicksburg.

Brave as the Texans where, they could not drive off the Union troops massed in the ditch outside the fort’s walls.

One Confederate wrote that he peeped over the top of the wall and saw an sea of blue soldiers below, milling around” but they could not get in.

Using hand grenades as well as muskets, the Confederates harassed the yanks for the rest of the day, and at one point, even General Stephen D. Lee could be seen tossing artillery rounds over the top.

stops.significance: How close the Union soldiers were to the Confederates and why the park has so many trees.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continuing following the tour road and it will lead you into the Union lines towards Tour Stop #15 - Hovey's Approach.
stops.audioTranscript:
Fort Garrott is probably the best-preserved fortification in the park.

Union General Alvin P. Hovey’s division occupied the sector of the Union siege line directly across from the fort, but his division did not arrive on the line until after the general assaults of May 22, so Fort Garrott was not attacked that day. 

During the siege, Hovey’s men dug two approach trenches to within 50 feet of the outer slope of the fort in preparation for an attack, if the siege failed.

As in all Confederate forts, the soldiers here were continually harassed by the deadly, accurate fire of Union sharpshooters. 

On June 17, Colonel Isham W. Garrott, the commander of the 20th Alabama Infantry manning this fort was angered at the suffering caused by the sharpshooters. 

Col. Garrott spied the location of a Union rifleman and he picked up a musket in hopes of silencing the sharpshooter and was instantly killed by a Federal bullet. That day a messenger was sent to notify Colonel Garrott that he had been promoted to brigadier general, but the brave colonel had died before the message reached him.
	
The clear field in front of the fort is typical of what you would have seen here in 1863. The trees that now cover the park were planted during the 1930s by the Civilian Conservation Corps. With the discovery that grasses are better at controlling erosion than trees in this region, the park hopes to selectively cut more trees so as to open more historic vistas.

stops.significance: How fast Union engineers were able to dig approach trenches and force the surrender of Vicksburg.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following the tour road back to the Visitor Center.
stops.audioTranscript:
Siege warfare differed from other manifestations of Civil War combat, in that, it was more structured and moved at a much slower pace. While the goal remained the same, the method was completely different.

Rather than a rapid assault across a field toward the Confederate defenses, Union soldiers dug approach trenches, which were zigzag in shape, and protected at the front by a sap roller: a large loosely woven basket filled with cotton or sticks.

Once the soldiers advanced a suitable distance, the work parties dug parallel trenches from which sharpshooters could further harass their opponents.

The constant fire forced the Confederates to take cover, allowing the Union work parties to speed their digging. By the end of the siege, Union soldiers were close enough to hold conversations with the Confederates.

In all, General Grant’s men dug 13 different approaches at Vicksburg.  

Hovey’s approach, seen at the southeastern corner of Fort Garrott, was begun on June 23rd and nearly reached the fort by the time of the surrender on July 4th.

images.title: Self-Guided Tour
images.altText: Pink, wavy clouds float over the Memorial Arch at the beginning of the park tour road.
images.caption: All tours of the park begin by passing through the Memorial Archway.

data.title: Self-Guided Tour
data.description: This walking tour highlights seven major places in the park that focus on the prehistoric and Civil War history of the area.

stops.significance:
The Visitor Center has a unique history. Construction for it began in 1938, two years after President Franklin D. Roosevelt proclaimed the Ocmulgee site a National Monument. However, construction was suspended in 1941 due to World War II. For ten years the Visitor Center sat incomplete before its construction was finally finished November 1951. 

The Visitor Center’s purpose was to house the park’s administration, museum exhibits, and the artifact collection generated by the excavations here in the 1930s and 40s. The building was designed by National Park Service assistant architect James Swanson. The style is Art Deco and is designed to look like one of the clay pots discovered during the excavations. Notice how the structure consists of stucco concrete with glass blocks and rounded corners – a unique style for a NPS visitor center. Look up at the red cornice, which was inspired by the “Lamar Bold” pottery style discovered here. The Visitor Center is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk around to the back of the Visitor Center and up to the park road. Cross the road and walk a short distance towards the park entrance. Take a right along the gravel path through the woods, and then another right once you reach the open field. The Civil War Earthworks will be off to the right.

stops.significance:
The white house in the field to your left is the Dunlap House, constructed by Samuel Dunlap in 1856 as part of his 400-acre cotton plantation. On July 30, 1864, Union General George Stoneman and his troops occupied the Dunlap House as temporary headquarters. Stoneman wanted to take Macon and free Union prisoners held at Camp Oglethorpe in Macon. When Stoneman couldn’t take Macon by storm, he began lobbing shells into the city. That afternoon General Stoneman retreated from Macon, but the Rebels captured Stoneman at Sunshine Church north of Macon and sent his troops to the prison camp at Andersonville. The Confederates constructed the U-shape earthworks here to protect the Walnut Creek railroad trestle from future attacks.  

Fighting took place here again in November 1864 at the Battle of Walnut Creek, when Union Calvary was sent to divert attention from General Sherman’s March to the Sea through Georgia. The Dunlap House now houses park staff, and is one of the oldest houses in Macon.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Visitor Center. Facing the Visitor Center entrance, follow the sidewalk on your left down the hill and over the bridge to reach the Earth Lodge.

stops.significance:
The Earth Lodge was built by the Mississippians who lived here from 900 to 1250 CE. The Lodge was a ceremonial council chamber, and the clay floor dates to 1015 C.E. Across from the entrance is a bird effigy platform. The three seats atop it were likely reserved for the chief, second chief, and the public speaker. 47 seats descend in height as they move away from the platform, suggesting a seating hierarchy. Each seat has a small oval depression in front of it, which may have been used to present ceremonial objects. The firepit in the center was likely used for ceremonies.

The Lodge was burned in the late 13th century; perhaps as a ritual for renewal or purification, or possibly because the building had deteriorated too much for any further use. Either way, as the roof caved in, it buried and preserved the clay floor for 800 years until it was rediscovered in 1934. To preserve and protect the prehistoric floor, reconstruction of the Earth Lodge began in 1936 and was completed in 1938 by the CCC and WPA.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Earth Lodge entrance, circle around the right side of the Lodge to the small mound behind it.

stops.significance: The Cornfield Mound dates to the Mississippian period. The Mississippians were master farmers who grew corn, beans, squash, sunflowers, and tobacco. When archaeologists excavated this mound in the 1930s, they discovered cultivated rows and a charred corncob, leading them to believe that the Mississippians used the area as a cornfield before building the mound over it. The Mississippians farmed most of their crops near the Ocmulgee River, while this cornfield was likely used for ceremonies since it's near the Earth Lodge. Look at the prehistoric trenches on the right-side of the Cornfield mound with the Earth Lodge behind you. These trenches were partially excavated and left unfilled. The trenches are between 3 to 9 feet deep and 15 to 25 feet wide. The parallel trenches remain in sections as a series of oval depressions in semicircular bands. The purpose of these trenches is unknown; they may have been for irrigation or as a defensive barrier, but most likely they were borrow pits for building the mounds.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go back to the sidewalk in front of the Earth Lodge and follow it across the railroad bridge to reach a grassy field with a wooden outline of the Trading Post on the ground.

stops.significance:
While the trading post is no more, the wooden beams here outline where it was established in 1690 C.E. by Charleston traders. The British competed with the Spanish operating in the area. The Indians preferred British trade items over Spanish because British goods were superior, their trading prices lower, and their demands on Indian culture were less. Indians traded deerskins for guns, beads, bells, and other European goods until around 1715, when the Indians were unable to produce enough deerskins to compensate for the European goods. Some traders, reacting to the London-based capitalist demands for payment, sold Indian women and children into slavery in the Caribbean. This led to the Yamasee War. The colonists defeated the Indian uprising in 1717, but by then the trading post here had been burned and abandoned. 

The site was excavated in 1935-36. Artifacts collected include gun parts, flints, musket balls, glass shards, beads, kaolin pipes, axes, knives, and copper bracelets.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Standing near the railroad bridge facing the trading post, turn right and follow the path down the hill and over the wooden bridge. When the trail meets the park road, take a right and go to the parking lot next to the Funeral Mound.

stops.significance: The Funeral Mound is the only burial mound in the park. It was where the Mississippian village leaders were buried. The mound was built in seven stages with structures on top of each level, which were probably used to prepare the dead for burial and the accompanying ceremonies. Massive log tombs were contained in its lowest level and over a hundred burials were placed throughout the mound with elaborate copper and shell ornaments that suggest high-status burials. The 1870s railroad construction bisected the mound and left only the southern portion intact. Archaeologists later excavated this section in December of 1933. The mound’s current height is at the third level of the mound and is 20 feet high. When the mound had the seventh and final level during the Mississippian period, it would have been 280 feet long, 100 feet wide, and 25 feet high. Out of respect for those buried here, please do not walk on this mound.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the park road towards the Visitor Center. The Great Temple Mound will be at the next parking lot on your right.

stops.significance:
The Great Temple Mound (GTM) is the tallest mound in the park, standing at 55 feet tall. All of the mounds built by the Mississippians were built by hand using basketfuls of dirt. It’s estimated that 10 million baskets of dirt, weighing around 60 pounds each, were used to build the GTM! Imagine the organization and diligence required by the entire village to accomplish such a feat. The mounds were used by the elite of the society of building their houses and temples on top of them. The GTM was most likely where the Mississippian chief lived, while the Lesser Temple Mound (LTM) may have been where the second chief lived. 

The LTM was partially destroyed by railroad construction in 1843 and is now a quarter of its original size. Excavation of the mound in 1934 revealed that the LTM had been built in four phases. A small village site with earth lodges and homes were also found between the GTM and the LTM.

images.altText: A view of the Lesser Temple Mound and Funeral Mound from on top of the Great Temple Mound
images.caption: A view of the Lesser Temple Mound and Funeral Mound from on top of the Great Temple Mound
