data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour
data.description: Explore the living community of Nicodemus by foot as explore the oldest lived in African American settlement west of the Mississippi. The walking tour route is about .6 miles (1 k). The path follows flat paved, and dirt roads and seen by car, bicycle and covered wagon. There are a few ways to explore Nicodemus by walking tour. Self-guided tours are possible by using the Nicodemus Walking. The walking tour does go through busy streets and near private homes and residences.

stops.significance: The beginning of the self-guided tour! Nicodemus Township Hall is owned by the Town of Nicodemus and is used by the Park Service as a visitor center.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leave the Visitor Center and turn right, or west. Walking down the St. Francis hotel will be on the corner of 3rd Street and Washington Ave. Look for the two-story building on the left side of the road.

stops.significance:
The Saint Francis Hotel Switzer Family Residence was used for a variety of purposes throughout the Nicodemus history. The original owners were Zachary and Jenny Fletcher. The two-bedroom hotel was also used as the first post office, schoolhouse, general store, candy shop and stagecoach station. Later the hotel was used by the Switzer family as a family residence.

The great plains and grasslands of Kansas lacks an easily accessible source of wood for building which lead to the hotel being made of limestone bricks. These lime stone bricks can viewed on the west side of the structure where the stucco has fallen away. Former Green Bay Packers player Veryl Switzer was raised in the residence in 1930s and 40s. Veryl later became community leader in preserving Nicodemus' historic buildings like the one he grew up in.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the corner take a left heading south down 3rd Street. The A.M.E Church will be on your right at the end of the block.

stops.significance: The A.M.E. church has just received major restoration, the project entailed restoring the floors, walls, ceiling, and altar. The church will be open for visitation and visitors will be able to see the oldest structure still standing in Nicodemus.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leaving the A.M.E Church you can see the next stop the School house on a hill about 200 yards away. Take a right on the corner of 3rd street onto Adams Ave, eventually turning left on 4th Street. Walk down 4th street until you reach the School District building.

stops.significance: The First Baptist Church has a unique history in Nicodemus. Church/religion was very important for the settlers of Nicodemus as the town was settled by several Preachers. The First Baptist Church was established in 1878, in the beginning the Nicodemus Colony members attended church services in a dugout. Members of the church when wanting to be baptized were baptized in a creek located on Thomas Johnson's Homestead north of town. Thomas Johnson was a deacon of the church and arrived with the first colony in September 17, 1877.  Eventually the congregation was established enough to build a small structured church. As the town grew the church grew and the congregation needed a larger building. A larger building was built in 1907 and the older generations tell the story how the larger church building was built around the smaller building and the smaller building was demolished piece by piece and removed out the door and windows of the newer church building. The congregation used that method so that they could con
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the fifth and last Historic building. Continue down Washington Ave to return to the Township Hall and Visitor Center. The Visitor Center will be on the left side of the street.

stops.significance: Settler's quickly established a school for children once arriving at Nicodemus. In 1879 the town established the first organized school in the country with the title "School District No. 1." Many different structures were used a schoolhouses such as sod dug outs, and the Saint Francis hotel. Due to many first settlers being born into slavery a large importance was put upon education especially reading and writing. Within a few years many settler's were literate with two news papers being printed within the town. The current school house was built in 1918 before closing in the 1960s due low enrollment numbers. The building was purchased by the American Legion in 1983.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head back the way you came walking down 4th street heading North. You will pass the Nicodemus baseball field on your left. You will see the 1st Baptist Church on the corner on 4th Street and Washington Ave.

stops.significance: An unofficial historic building, the Ace Williams House is an example of a typical Nicodemus home in the early 20th century.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue 50 yards south towards the 1st District School House.

images.altText: Park Ranger leading a tour.

data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour Through Fort Vancouver
data.description: Discover the history behind the buildings in the reconstructed Fort Vancouver, each of which is built on the archaeological footprint of the original structure.

stops.significance: The Fort Vancouver Garden was an important part of life at Fort Vancouver. It provided food for those living inside the fort, and a place for the fort's upper class to relax.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed to the gates of the reconstructed fort and stop at the Contact Station just inside to pay entrance fees or present your America the Beautiful pass and get more information from the park ranger there.

stops.significance: At the Contact Station you can pay entrance fees or present your America the Beautiful pass, and get information on your visit from a national park ranger.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the Contact Station and proceed south along the paved pathways. Turn left towards the large white building - the Chief Factor's House.

stops.significance: The Chief Factor's House was the residence of the leaders of Fort Vancouver and their families.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of the Chief Factor's House, proceed east, then turn left. the Kitchen is located behind the Chief Factor's House.

stops.significance: Food for the residents and guests of the Chief Factor's House was cooked in this Kitchen.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Kitchen, walk on the pathways leading south, then turn left and go around the rectangular building where restrooms are located. You will see the large well sweep and the raised wooden platform covering the well's opening.

stops.significance: Fort Vancouver's residents got their water from this well. When you look down into the well, you are seeing the last remaining structure of the original Fort Vancouver. While the fort's buildings burned down in the 1860s, this well was preserved underground, and later uncovered by archaeologists!
stops.directionsToNextStop: To the east of the Well, you will see a white painted building - the Bake House - that is partially inside and partially outside the palisade walls of the fort.

stops.significance: The Bake House provided bread and sea biscuits for fur traders on long fur trapping brigades and for sailors aboard the ships that visited Fort Vancouver.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Bake House, proceed on the paved trails south to the southeast corner of the fort. The Blacksmith Shop is located in the fort's southeast corner.

stops.significance: At the Blacksmith Shop, the fort's blacksmiths made animal traps, farming equipment, building hardware, and other necessary supplies.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The Indian Trade Shop & Hospital is located just to the west of the Blacksmith Shop.

stops.significance: Fur trappers could bring their furs to the Indian Trade Shop to trade. Medical care for the fort's officers was provided at this hospital.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Indian Trade Shop & Hospital, proceed west on the paved paths towards the Fur Store, a large wooden building. At one corner of the building is a flagpole flying the Hudson's Bay Company flag.

stops.significance: Furs were sorted and packed for shipment at the Fur Store.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Fur Store, follow the paved paths to the northwest corner of the fort. There, you will find the Bastion, a three-story wooden tower.

stops.significance: The Bastion is an iconic symbol of Fort Vancouver. It was not used for defense, but instead had ceremonial and lookout functions.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Bastion, follow the paths east to the Carpenter Shop, a wooden, rectangular building with a red door.

stops.significance: At the Carpenter Shop, the fort's carpenters made a wide variety of items necessary for life at Fort Vancouver.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Carpenter Shop, follow the paths south and east to the front of a square, white building: The Counting House.

stops.significance: The Jail housed those who were accused of breaking Hudson's Bay Company rules.

images.title: Fort Vancouver
images.altText: The wooden bastion, a tower in the corner of the Fort Vancouver palisade wall.
images.caption: Fort Vancouver's palisade wall and bastion.

data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour of Cabrillo National Monument Hilltop
data.description: This tour takes you through a short walking loop around the "upper" portion of Cabrillo National Monument - that is, the portion of the park that sits on the crest of Point Loma. Along the way you will learn about many of the major things to see at the park and be given a chance to find a greater personal meaning in them.

stops.significance: Starting point for the Cabrillo National Monument Hilltop Area Walking Tour. Pick-up / drop-off location adjacent to the park visitor center.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the traffic circle, follow the sidewalk to your left – the first left turn will lead to an overlook of San Diego bay with the statue of the explorer. Stop once you’ve reached the statue.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Cabrillo National Monument! To have a safe and enjoyable visit, please remember to follow park rules and regulations. Before we get started, here are some helpful tips and things to remember when out and about in the park!

Bring enough food and water for the day!

Remember to pack out all your trash to help keep the park clean!

Stay safe from the sun by using sunscreen, hats, and sunglasses.

Watch out for slippery rocks when you explore the tidepools!

Friendly reminder - dogs are only allowed along on coastal trail near the tidepool area on a 6’ or shorter leash. They must remain in your vehicle in all other areas of the park. 

We are a non-smoking and non-vaping park.

Remember, you can always check with a Park Ranger or our website for current information.

As you explore, use this audio tour to learn about areas of the park and to reflect on the various stories that are told here. Put yourself in the shoes of a historical figure! Imagine what it would be like as an animal to adapt to such unique ecosystems! Challenge yourself to identify your own connection with the park! If you are visiting alone, think about these ideas as you venture around the park, listening to the tour. If you are visiting with friends or family, challenge each other and discuss these ideas together.

We hope you enjoy your time at Cabrillo National Monument! 

Why do we call this place Cabrillo? To start our loop of the hilltop area of Cabrillo National Monument, let’s first head to the statue of our park’s namesake – Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo!

stops.significance: Statue commemorating the voyage of explorer Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo, the first European to lead an expedition charting the west coast of what would become the United States of America.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the statue, return to the sidewalk path and follow it up the hill towards the lighthouse. Stop at the Bayside Trail Head turnoff to learn about what awaits you should you choose to hike the Bayside Trail.
stops.audioTranscript:
Take a good look at the statue before you. Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo. Spanish Explorer. First European to set foot on the West Coast of the United States. Cabrillo left Spain as a young man to become a soldier, participating in conquests in Panama, Cuba, Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras. For his service to the Spanish Crown, he was awarded encomiendas, or land grants, in Guatemala, where he became a citizen.

Cabrillo and his expedition of over 100 men aboard three ships departed from the port of Navidad, Mexico on June 27, 1542 - over 1,200 miles (1,931 km) away, as the crow flies. Three months later he arrived at what he described in his captain's log as "a very good enclosed port," which is known today as San Diego Bay. If you are facing the front of the statue, look to your left toward the bay. Historians believe that Cabrillo first anchored his flagship, the San Salvador here, on September 28, 1542. Cabrillo was in this area for about 6 days before sailing Northwest toward the Channel Islands.

When the Cabrillo expedition landed here, they met the Kumeyaay people, who have lived in the San Diego area for thousands of years. The expedition's goal was to explore and make observations along the California Coast, not to conquer it, so interactions with the Kumeyaay were relatively peaceful. This stood in stark contrast to Cabrillo’s life in Guatemala where he lived as a colonizer. There he forced indigenous peoples (such as the Maya-Q’eqchi of Cobán) to work in his mines, farms, and shipyards.

There is controversy over how Cabrillo’s story is remembered due to the nature of his past as a conquistador and colonizer. Was he a legendary explorer? A ruthless soldier? An ambitious merchant? In any case, his legacy is prolific in the state of California – in fact, there are more places named after him than any other person in the state.

Take a moment to imagine you are a member of the Cabrillo expedition. You are on a crowded, cold, and wet ship, exploring a world where everything is new to you, and wondering if you will ever return home to see your family again. Now, put yourself in the shoes of one of the Kumeyaay people at that first meeting with Cabrillo. You may have heard stories from desert tribes who encountered bearded Spaniards from the Coronado expedition along the Colorado River. You would be very aware of their acts of conquest. How would you react to meeting these strangers?

After spending six days in San Diego, the Cabrillo expedition continued to explore the California coastline. In December of 1542, the expedition stopped in the Channel Islands to replenish drinking water supplies. While there, Cabrillo broke a bone while rushing from the ship to respond to a skirmish between his crew and native Chumash people. He died from a gangrene infection on January 3, 1543. His crew continued to explore without their captain, reaching as far north as the Rogue River in Oregon, but eventually turned back due to supply issues and bad weather. Despite the inglorious end of the expedition, Cabrillo and his crew successfully charted much of the west coast of North America. They were the first Europeans to explore the West Coast, and their records of the winds and currents unlocked the mystery of the Pacific Ocean for future explorers.

Have you found anything during your time exploring the park that you did not expect?

stops.significance: Scenic nature trail overlooking San Diego Bay.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue uphill and stop when you reach the Old Point Loma Lighthouse Grounds.
stops.audioTranscript:
Whether or not you decide to hike down the Bayside Trail, there are plenty of opportunities to experience the natural resources here at Cabrillo National Monument. In Southern California, we experience a Mediterranean climate, just like the countries that border the Mediterranean Sea in Europe! We have hot dry summers with long periods of drought punctuated by cooler and wetter winters. The plants found in these habitats have adapted to survive in a place with little rain. We like to think of the plants here as survivors in a harsh, yet mild climate.

As you look around the trailhead you may be able to identify some plants. Lemonade Berry has green and rounded leaves, sometimes with red berries. Take a moment and see if you can find them! There are two species of sage nearby, California Sagebrush and Black Sage. California Sagebrush has a mint green color and is made up of lots of soft and skinny leaves. Black sage has leathery dark green leaves that are sticky. Both can be found flowering or dried out. If the wind is blowing just right, you might smell their strong aroma. Feel free to touch them! Gently rub the leaves between your fingers and then smell your hand. Remember that these plants are protected, so make sure not to pick them. Do you like or dislike this smell? Did you think it would have such a strong scent? Why might a plant smell like this?

Take a moment to consider how all of these plants came to be. We can thank one group of critters for our wonderful plant life here at Cabrillo National Monument: the pollinators! Pollinators can come in a range of shapes and sizes. They include insects, birds, and bats, just to name a few. You may encounter bees buzzing around or hummingbirds flying about. Bats may come through in the evenings to snack on the insect life that is darting about. 

Plants at Cabrillo National Monument have a very hard life; they live on exposed windswept hillsides in a relatively dry climate. Please help them (and the pollinators that depend upon them) survive their stressful lives by leaving their flowers and leaves intact. This is their home, and with your help, will continue to be for generations to come!

As you travel through the park, try to think of ways you could use the plants and animals you see to survive, if you had to live in this harsh environment.

stops.significance: Learn about what work and family life was like surviving at the tip of Point Loma and maintaining the lighthouse.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue past the lighthouse grounds to the ¼ mile loop for the Kelp Forest and Whale Overlook. Stop once you arrive at the shaded exhibit area.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Old Point Loma Lighthouse rests 422 feet (129m) above the ocean. When it was first lit in 1855, it was nearly 10 miles (16 km) from town. As a result, the light keepers of Point Loma were early pioneers of working from home and being distant from society!

Life here was isolated and challenging. Something as simple as going to school required the kids to take a boat across the bay! There was no fresh water readily available and the area was relatively barren. The lighthouse had a catchment built to catch rain water, but given that San Diego’s average rainfall is barely over 10 inches per year, that wasn’t nearly enough to get by. Water and food had to be shipped in from town along dirt roads by horse and buggy.

Most of the actual work at the lighthouse was upkeep and managing supplies. All of this supported the one crucial task - keeping the lighthouse’s light lit all night to warn ships of the rocky coastline. On a clear night you could see the light for miles. On a night with high fog, you may not see it at all. The lighthouse’s high elevation was a double-edged sword – it often put the light above the fog line, where it was obscured. What would you do on a foggy night if you were the keeper? On more than one occasion, the last and longest keeper, Robert Israel, improvised. He grabbed a gun and fired off warning shots from the shore to alert nearby boats! 

What was family life like, living where the keeper worked? It was much like anywhere else, just more remote—the lighthouse was a home after all. The kids still went to school, the family tended a garden, and there were plenty of books for everyone to read – the Lighthouse Board provided a portable library. The family would also go down to the coast and gather shellfish like abalone, often turning leftover shells into arts and crafts. In one case, Robert Israel’s wife, Mary, even became the Assistant Keeper for a couple years! 

As you wander the grounds, imagine what it would be like to live and work here. Do you think you could do it? What do you think would be the most fun? What do you think would be hardest? Now imagine trying to live here in the ocean. There’s a whole world here beneath the blue waves of the Pacific!

stops.significance: Scenic viewpoint and whale watching overlook.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the paved spur trail of the Kelp Forest and Whale Overlook loop located just south of the covered overlook area. Stop in front of the bunker structure.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are standing in front of the Kelp Forest and Whale Overlook, a short, paved walkway with magnificent views over the Pacific Ocean. These elevated cliffs are the perfect place to watch hawks flying, ships sailing, and whales migrating just below. That’s right! The Pacific Gray Whale travels through the water below during its annual migration. Bring your own binoculars to the park and you’ll have a better chance of seeing one (or many) along their approximately 10,000 mile (16,093 km) trip! Pacific Gray Whales have one of the longest annual migrations of any mammal on Earth. 

Why do they make this trip, which puts them through great hardship and takes them away from their main food source? For the survival of their species! Gray whales spend the summer months feeding in the Arctic, where the nutrient-rich cold waters harbor their primary source of food. In the fall, they begin the long journey south down the coast. Calves are born during migration or in the shallow lagoons and bays off Baja California, Mexico. These shallow, protected bays act as a nursery for the calves; allowing them to put on weight and build muscles for their long journey back.  The prime time to see whales from Cabrillo is late December through mid-March. 

Look for the Blow or Spout - these spouts are created when warm, moist air exhaled from a whale’s lungs meets the cool air at the ocean’s surface. They can be up to 15 feet (4.5 meters) high and each one is visible for about 5 seconds! These can be seen from here even without binoculars. Also look for the tail! Gray whales typically spout 3-5 times before taking a big breath for a deep dive. Before their deepest dive, gray whales often display their 12-foot fan-shaped flukes, or tails. The weight of the tail above the whale’s body helps the whale dive deep. Finally, Look for a breach and splash. Sometimes gray whales hurl themselves out of the water and plunge back in with a huge splash. This is called breaching. Breaching is a rare occurrence, as these whales are trying to conserve as much energy as they can during their long migration.

Pro tip: Look for large white boats with a lot of people onboard. These are whale watching boats. Find one of these and you are almost guaranteed to see a whale spouting nearby.  

From here, set your gaze about hundred yards off of shore where you will see discolored blotches of water – it may not look like much, but you are looking at an entire forest of kelp! During a good low tide you can also see the Rocky Intertidal area exposed at the shoreline. The tidepools become exposed during a low tide event and act as a window into the ocean, exposing plant and animals life normally covered by water!

As you walk along this loop trail, do you notice anything out of the ordinary? Perhaps you noticed the man-made bunker-like structures punctuating and blending into the hillside. Why are they here and what were they for? Let's take a look!

stops.significance: Fire control station for Battery Humphreys, a World War II coastal artillery emplacement.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Return to the visitor center and make your way to its east-facing (back) patio that overlooks the city of San Diego.

If you would like to learn more about World War II history in Point Loma, feel free to visit the Coast Defense Exhibit and Fire Control Station bunker for Battery Ashburn on the way back the visitor center. A concrete path leads to the exhibit and a dirt trail leads to the bunker.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are currently standing next to the fire control station for Battery Humphreys. The two bunkers that comprise it are part of a network of hillside buildings used to aim and fire two 6-inch guns that were located just south of here. These coastal artillery cannons were used to defend the southern approach to San Diego during World War II.

The lower bunker served as an observation post that was used to aim the battery’s guns while the top bunker was the command post where the firing order was given. This order was the “trigger” that told the actual guns at the main battery fire.

The guns of Battery Humphreys worked in concert with the other artillery emplacements in San Diego to cover each other’s gaps and provide coverage for the whole city. The other gun emplacements similarly needed networks of observation and fire-control stations, just like Battery Humphreys did. For example, the fire control station bunker for Battery Ashburn has a similar setup. The top bunker served as the command post, while the lower bunker served as one of its observation posts.

The soldiers here were the last line of defense against a full-scale invasion. The thought that San Diego could become the next Pearl Harbor weighed heavily on everyone's mind. Imagine knowing that an attack could come from the horizon at any minute, and that 400,000 San Diegans were depending on you with their lives. How would that effect your decision making on the job?

Put yourself in the shoes of a duty officer, for a moment. It’s the middle of a foggy night and the radar operator detects a large object heading towards San Diego. You contact the navy and harbor control to see if any ships are expected off Point Loma – there aren’t. The ship is alone and isn’t responding to radio. What do you do? Do you risk firing on a non-responsive friendly ship? Maybe their radio is down. Or do you risk letting an enemy slip into the bay unchallenged?

A scenario like this actually happened to duty officer George S. Prugh when a heavy cruiser involved in a classified mission sailed into San Diego but didn’t use any radio communications until it was exceptionally close. Fortunately, nothing happened. He later reflected, “I’ve often wondered about how near this came to being a disaster – and how close I came to making a bit of history.”

The coastal artillery of Point Loma and its soldiers gave San Diego a way to engage conventional enemy ships before they got in range of the city and its harbor. Any invaders had to deal with the window-rattling blasts of coastal artillery and the vigilant soldiers that watched the coast. As a local, the blasts may rattle your house, but how would they make you feel, knowing the canons were there to protect you?

When you get a chance, take a moment to gaze across the city. What part of San Diego do you most want to protect?

stops.significance: This offers sweeping views of the city of San Diego and San Diego Bay. This stop concludes the tour. You may continue to explore the park from here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the final stop on this self-guided tour. Feel free to continue exploring the park!
stops.audioTranscript:
We end our tour here at the Visitor Center and View Building. This is a good hopping-off point to continue exploring the park. Here you can take a break and use the facilities, visit the Cabrillo store, or take in the views of the city.

If you make your way around the building to the east-facing back patio, you will have a sweeping view of San Diego Bay and the city of San Diego. Here you can see the full story of Cabrillo before you, from past to present. The landscape of the past meets a bustling city of tomorrow. Try to imagine what has changed, and what has stayed the same.

We hope you’ve had fun exploring Cabrillo National Monument! Cabrillo truly is a place full of diversity, whether it’s the landscape, wildlife, or human history. What did you learn, while exploring the park? Did you find something you didn’t expect? As you wrap up your time here, think about these questions or discuss them with your friends or family.

Here at Cabrillo, every piece of nature and every bit of history has a story to tell. While some stories here are finished, others are ongoing. Perhaps best of all, some stories have yet to be told! We are all continuously discovering new stories in this hidden jewel of a site. There is something here for everyone, whether you are a historian, scientist, park ranger, volunteer, or a visitor like you! The 160 acres that make up Cabrillo National Monument are very special. Here the past, present, and future are nestled together in an oasis of nature and history, providing an escape from the hustle and bustle of modern life.

We hope that you have had a wonderful time immersing yourself in the park by exploring, learning, soaking up the sunshine, or cooling off in the foggy marine layer. You have experienced the park in your own way, which makes you a part of Cabrillo National Monument’s story. We hope you enjoyed your time here and that you will share your part of the story with others. With your help, the story here will grow for generations to come.

images.title: Hilltop of Cabrillo National Monument
images.altText: View of the hilltop area of Cabrillo National Monument as seen from the Visitor Center breezeway.
images.caption: All sorts of stories are hiding in plain sight in Cabrillo National Monument's hilltop area!

data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour with Audio & Transcript
data.description: This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the 1st attempt to integrate Central High School on Sept. 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration & written transcript is directly from eyewitness & published accounts & includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism & bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

park.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
park.name: Little Rock Central High School

tags: little rock central high school national historic site

stops.significance: A timeline of events between 1954 and 1957 leading up to the Little Rock Central High desegregation crisis.
stops.assetName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site Visitor Center
stops.directionsToNextStop:
If you are inside the visitor center, exit through its west doors, immediately turn left & proceed south approximately 137 feet (42 meters) to reach the sidewalk parallel to W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Turn right & head west approximately 43 feet (13 meters) to reach the northeast corner of W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and S. Park Street. 

If in the parking lot or outside the visitor center, proceed north using the sidewalks/ramps to reach the sidewalk parallel to W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Turn right & head west to reach the northeast corner of W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive & S. Park Street. 

From the northeast corner & using the crosswalk, head due west approximately 47 feet (14 meters) & cross S. Park Street. Using the sidewalk, head north approximately 125 feet (38 meters) until you reach an entrance to the Commemorative Garden. Proceed west up the sloped sidewalk & curved path until you reach a pair of brick & concrete arches. Stop inside the arches & face south toward Central High School.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

1954:

May 17: The U.S. Supreme Court rules unanimously in Brown v. Board of Education that state laws mandating segregated public schools are unconstitutional under the 14th Amendment, declaring that segregated schools are “inherently unequal.”

1955: 
May 22: The Little Rock School Board and Superintendent Blossom issue a plan for gradual integration to begin in 1957.

1956: 
January 28: Governor Faubus reports that “85 percent of all the people” in Arkansas oppose school desegregation in a survey he commissioned.

May 9: Little Rock opens the new Horace Mann High School as a segregated facility for black students.

1957:
February 26: Faubus signs into law four segregation bills passed by Arkansas legislators.

April 30: The pro-segregation Capital Citizens Council of Little Rock appeals to Faubus in a letter to “order the two races to attend their own schools.”

July 23: The Little Rock School Board reveals that Central High will be the system’s only school with black enrollment. All 700 students at the new Hall High will be white.

August 23: Just after midnight, a rock is thrown through the window at the home of Daisy Bates and her husband. A note tied to the rock said, “Stone this time, Dynamite next.”

August 25: A cross 8 feet high is burned on the lawn of L.C. and Daisy Bates. A sign near the cross bears a white-lettered message - “Go back to Africa. KKK.”

September 1: “The LR School Board Issues [Call] for Cooperation [and] Understanding.” 

September 2: Faubus orders Arkansas Guard “Troops Take-Over at Central High; Negroes Told, Wait.” 

September 3: Federal “Judge Orders Start of Integration Today.”

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: A narration from several of the Little Rock Nine and the Governor of Arkansas immediately before the first day of school at Little Rock Central High in September 1957.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the arches in the Commemorative Garden, head west and follow the curved sidewalk until you reach the south entrance to the Commemorative Garden. Proceed east heading to your left approximately 75 feet (23 meters) to reach the northwest corner of W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and S. Park Street and then stop. Please stay on the sidewalk back from these two city streets.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette Editor – Harry Ashmore

ASHMORE: “A Time of Testing”: In the wake of changes in the law, this is a time of testing for all of us. We are confident that the citizens of Little Rock will demonstrate on Tuesday, for the world to see, that we are a law-abiding people. 

NARRATOR: Carlotta Walls

WALLS: The integration of the finest high school in Arkansas would happen just once in our lifetime, and I had to have a dress to match the occasion. Mother and I found the perfect outfit: a black skirt set… sophisticated and smart, not too dainty. I hung the skirt set in my closet to wait for the big day.

NARRATOR: Terrence Roberts
  
ROBERTS: The conversations at home that night before did not include much speculation about what the next day might bring, just the usual banter typical of our household full of children. 

WALLS: That night Mrs. Bates had called again to tell my parents to drop me off at 8:30 a.m. at 13th and Park Street, about a block from the school. An interracial group of ministers would meet us there to escort us to school, she said. We wouldn’t have to walk alone.

NARRATOR: Elizabeth Eckford

ECKFORD: The night before, I was so excited I couldn’t sleep.

ROBERTS: Perhaps the most significant thing said came from my parents. “Son,” they said, “we want you to know that if you are set on going through with this, we are behind you. But if you decide not to do it, you have our full support for that decision, too.”

WALLS: Governor Faubus appeared on late-night television to make a speech about Central. My parents liked Faubus. They had voted for him twice before. He was a man of the people, I’d heard them say, not a strident segregationist. My parents and I had no clue that Faubus was moments away from announcing a bold, about-face move that would write Little Rock’s civil rights history.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus

FAUBUS: Units of the National Guard have been mobilized with the mission to maintain the peace and good order of this community, and to act in every way possible to protect the lives and property of the citizens of Pulaski County.

WALLS: I was a citizen of Pulaski County. My parents paid taxes; they were citizens, too. I honestly believed that I was included in those our governor was deploying the Guard to protect. When I closed my eyes that night, I was confident that I would be at Central the next day and that I would be safe.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: The northwest corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street) is a stop on the Little Rock Central High School NHS self-guided audio tour. From this location on September 4, 1957, members of the Little Rock Nine and minsters gathered before crossing 14th Street and attempting to integrate Central High School for the first time in its history.
stops.assetName: NW Corner of Park Street and Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Using the crosswalk and ramps, proceed south from the northwest corner of S. Park and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive approximately 42 feet (13 meters) to cross W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street). 

You will arrive on the southwest corner of Park and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Stop on the sidewalk and stay back from this busy intersection.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: The next morning I was about the first one up. While I was pressing my black and white dress — I had made it to wear on the first day of school — my little brother turned on the TV set. Mother called from the kitchen…

BIRDIE ECKFORD: “Turn that TV off!”
 
ELIZABETH ECKFORD: She was so upset and worried. Before I left home, she said we should have a word of prayer. Then I caught the bus.

CARLOTTA WALLS: The next morning, I popped out of bed without hesitation. It was really going to happen, I thought. The anticipation of walking up those regal steps into Central made each moment seem to tick by slowly.

TERRENCE ROBERTS: This was to be no ordinary day. Already, my parents and I had witnessed the gathering crowds around the school as we tuned in to the morning TV news shows. We calculated, however, that the imagined threat was bigger by far than any real element of danger based on the fact that National Guardsmen were there. 

CARLOTTA WALLS: At the meeting spot, we noticed a small group of students; although I couldn’t see Elizabeth or Terrence or Melba, there were two black ministers whom Mother recognized. Three older white ministers and a young white man were there, too. We chatted anxiously until one of the ministers approached and said it was time to get moving. But first, he said, we needed to pray.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Gazette Editor [Harry] Ashmore

HARRY ASHMORE: At Second Presbyterian Church yesterday, the Reverend Marion A. Boggs offered a special prayer: 

REVEREND MARION A. BOGGS: We pray that all persons in authority be given wisdom, and we ask God to restrain the passions of violent men. We pray that we will not suffer the spirit of lawlessness to gain ascendancy in our community, and that all the persons have the patience to wait the due process of law.

[BACKGROUND NOISE OF HOSTILE CROWD AT CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL]

HARRY ASHMORE: These words speak for the great silent, mass of our people who abhor violence, respect the law, and would be ashamed for any child of any race to look upon the naked face of hatred.

[BACKGROUND NOISE OF HOSTILE CROWD AT CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL]

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: And I got off a block from school. I saw a large crowd of people standing across the street from the soldiers guarding Central. As I walked on, the crowd suddenly got very quiet.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: The southwest corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street) is location where Elizabeth Eckford, one of the Little Rock Nine, was initially turned away from entering Central High School by the Arkansas National Guard on September 4, 1957.
stops.assetName: SW Corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The sidewalk in front of Central High School is comprised of two 6 foot by 6 foot (1.8 x 1.8 meters) square concrete tiles inset side by side. We recommend using the west set of tiles (the portion closest to Central High School) to avoid the curb parallel to S. Park Street, a fire hydrant and other potential tripping hazards.

The first fire hydrant is located on the east set of tiles 7 feet south of the southwest corner of Park and Daisy Bates and 2 feet west of the curb.

Using the sidewalk, proceed south on the sidewalk approximately 65 feet (20 meters). You will be at the intersection of a curved sidewalk on your right and the west square tiled sidewalk parallel to both S. Park Street and Central High School.

Adjacent to the North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk at Central High School is the location where Elizabeth Eckford is first identified by segregationists and converged upon as she proceeds down Park Street on September 4, 1957 - the first attempt to integrate Little Rock Central High School.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: September 5th: The first Negro applicant to try to enroll at Little Rock Central High School, Elizabeth Eckford, 15, wearing sunglasses and a white dress with broad checkered trim on the skirt and carrying a small green notebook, alighted from a public transportation bus at Thirteenth Street and Park Avenue at 7:50 a.m. and walked a block to Park and Fourteenth Street.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Democrat Photographer Will Counts

WILL COUNTS: There were only a couple of other newsmen waiting at 14th and Park when Elizabeth Eckford approached the National Guardsmen. White students had been passing through the line of troops along the sidewalk. I had suspicions but no real knowledge that the Guardsmen had orders to block students from entering.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: At the corner, I tried to pass through the line of guards around the school so as to enter the school grounds behind them. One of the guards pointed across the street. He wouldn’t speak.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: She approached the Guardsmen on the corner. They drew together and blocked her entrance to the sidewalk. 

NARRATOR: Carlotta, arriving with group at the same corner, minutes later.

CARLOTTA WALLS: The guardsmen had formed a ring around the school. But I wasn’t afraid. They blocked the entrance, but I was certain that when they saw us, they would just step aside and allow us through. They were, after all, there to protect us and keep out the troublemakers, I thought. But not one of the guardsmen in front of us, budged. Ernest Green said, 

ERNEST GREEN: You’re not going to let us in?” 

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Gazette Editor Harry Ashmore

HARRY ASHMORE: “The Crisis Mr. Faubus Made” — Little Rock arose yesterday to gaze upon the incredible spectacle of a high school surrounded by National Guard troops called out by Governor Faubus to protect life and property. The crisis Mr. Faubus made is one he must now live with and the rest of us must suffer under. If Mr. Faubus in fact has no intention of defying federal authority, now is the time for him to call a halt to resistance. And certainly, he should do so before his own actions become the cause of the violence he professes to fear.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: Adjacent to the North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk at Central High School is the location where Elizabeth Eckford is first identified by segregationists and converged upon as she proceeds down Park Street on September 4, 1957 - the first attempt to integrate Little Rock Central High School.
stops.assetName: North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk at Central High School
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The sidewalk in front of Central High School is comprised of two 6 foot by 6 foot (1.8 x 1.8 meters) square concrete tiles inset side by side. We recommend using the west set of tiles (the portion closest to Central High School) to avoid the curb parallel to S. Park Street and other potential tripping hazards. The west set of tiles are 6 feet west of the curb on S. Park Street as you head south on this audio tour.
 
Using the west set of tiles on the sidewalk, proceed south from the North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk approximately 165 feet (50 meters) to the where North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk meets the sidewalk at the mid-block. 

Note: this curvilinear sidewalk is a semicircle.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: So, I walked across the street, then someone shouted,

[LOUD NOISE OF CROWD IN THE BACKGROUND]

CROWD/MALE 1: Here she comes, get ready!

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: Before she had taken 25 steps, she cut back into the street and walked back to the line of Guardsmen. It was then that a crowd of 200 saw her and rushed to the scene.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: The crowd moved in closer and then began to follow me, calling me names. I still wasn’t afraid. Just a little bit nervous. I kept thinking the guards would protect me. Then my knees began to shake all of a sudden, and I wondered whether or not I could make it. It was the longest block I ever walked in my whole life.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Democrat Photographer Will Counts

WILL COUNTS: When she was turned away by the National Guard troops, the courage and grace she exhibited as she walked two blocks through the mob of school-integration dissidents became one of my most moving experiences. Her actions epitomized for me the nonviolent principles Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference had begun using to compel the country toward racial justice.

CARLOTTA WALLS: We didn’t realize that Elizabeth had already arrived and was trapped in the crowd at the end of the block. Meanwhile, around us, the scene felt surreal. With everyone jeering and screaming at once, their words sounded muddled, except for one: nigger… nigger… nigger. It shot out of angry mouths like bullets and pierced my ears again and again. 

TERRENCE ROBERTS: I still hear the sound of shrill voices filling the air with vicious knife-edged words, calculated to hurt as much as possible.

CARLOTTA WALLS: Adrenaline pulsed through my body and quickened the pace of my heart. I had never seen such raw anger up close before. And this was directed at me. For what? Because I wanted to go to school? 

NARRATOR: Melba Pattillo

MELBA PATTILLO: Mother and I had come on our own, saw the crowd, and parked two blocks away. As we drew near, the angry outbursts became even more intense, and we began to hear their words more clearly - “Niggers, go home! Niggers, go back where you belong!” 

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: Eckford, silent and looking straight ahead, walked alone at a brisk pace down the line of troops. The crowd walked along with her and began a stream of cat-calling. A woman made a lunge at the girl.
 
A MAN IN THE CROWD: Go back where you came from! 

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: and was pushed back by a Guard officer. Another in the crowd said, 

A FEMALE IN THE CROWD: “You’ve got a better school than ours so why don’t you go back to it.”

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: Near this location, Elizabeth Eckford (one of the Little Rock Nine) is turned away and denied entrance on to the grounds of Central High School for a second time by Arkansas National Guardsmen; this first attempt to integrate Little Rock Central High School occurs on September 4, 1957.
stops.assetName: North Junction of Front Curvilinear Sidewalks at Central High School
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The sidewalk in front of Central High School is comprised of two 6 foot by 6 foot (1.8 x 1.8 meters) square concrete tiles inset side by side. We recommend using the west set of tiles (the portion closest to Central High School) to avoid the curb parallel to S. Park Street and other potential tripping hazards. The west set of tiles are 6 feet west of the curb on S. Park Street as you head south on this audio tour. 

Using the west set of tiles on the sidewalk, proceed south approximately 185 feet (56 meters) to reach the South Curvilinear Front Sidewalk Junction on your right and then stop. You will pass the main front vista of Central High School. 

Note – there is a fire hydrant on the east set of sidewalk tiles approximately 140 feet (43 meters) south of the North Junction of Curvilinear Sidewalks OR 45 feet (14 meters) north of the South Junction of Curvilinear Sidewalks. The fire hydrant is inset 2.5 feet (.76 meters) from the sidewalk curb parallel to S. Park Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: When I got to the middle of the block in front of the school, I went straight up to the guard again, but he didn’t let me move to pass him. I didn’t know what to do. So, I walked until I was right in front of the path to the front door.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: She made an attempt in the middle of the line to cross onto the school grounds and again was stopped by Guardsmen, 

ANGRY WOMAN IN THE CROWD: “Don’t let her in our school — that ‘nigger’.”

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: I stood looking at the school — it looked so big! Just then, the guards let some white students through. The crowd was quiet again, waiting to see what was going to happen. When I was able to steady my knees, I walked up to the guard who had let the white students in. When I tried to squeeze past him, he raised his bayonet and then the other guards moved in.

NARRATOR: Arkansas Democrat

ARKANSAS DEMOCRAT: As she walked along the Guard line in the street in front of the high school, the crowd followed, calling her names.

ANGRY WOMAN IN THE CROWD: “Go home nigger, you will never get into this school. We don’t want you here.”

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: They glared at me with a mean look, and I was very frightened but didn’t know what to do. I turned around, and the crowd came toward me. They moved closer and closer.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Democrat Photographer Will Counts

WILL COUNTS: Her imperturbable walk through the mob has become a slow-motion cinema verité memory. I still find it difficult to believe that this display of racial hatred was happening in front of my old high school — and my camera.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Gazette [Editor] Harry Ashmore

HARRY ASHMORE: But the point is that the armed troops Governor Faubus placed around Central High School had orders to keep the Negro children out of school – and did so. Until last Thursday, the matter of gradual, limited integration in the Little Rock schools was a local problem. On that day, Mr. Faubus appeared in court on behalf of a small but militant minority and chose to make it a state problem. On Monday night, he called out the National Guard and made it a national problem.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: Near this sidewalk junction, Arkansas Democrat photographer Will Counts captures lone walk of Elizabeth Eckford and the faces of discrimination and ignorance behind her as she proceeds down Park Street. Repeatedly denied access to Central High School by the Arkansas National Guard, Eckford decides to seek solace on a bus bench a half-block ahead of her.
stops.assetName: South Junction of Front Curvilinear Sidewalks at Central High School
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Proceed south on the street sidewalk approximately 250 feet (76 meters) to reach the northwest corner of S. Park Street and 16th Street. 

Note – there is a fire hydrant on the east set of sidewalk tiles approximately 247 feet (75 meters) south of the South Junction of Curvilinear Sidewalks OR 3 feet (.91 meters) north of the northwest corner of S. Park and 16th Streets. The fire hydrant is inset 2 feet (.6 meters) from the sidewalk curb parallel to S. Park Street. 

Using the crosswalk, proceed east approximately 65 feet (20 meters) to arrive at the Elizabeth Eckford bus bench near the northeast corner of Park and 16th Streets. The bench is approximately 25 feet (8 meters) east of the northeast corner of S. Park and 16th Streets and approximately 6 feet (2 meters) north of the curb parallel to 16th Street. There is a semicircular concrete path around the bench facing north with concrete pavers around the north border. Flowers chosen by Ms. Eckford encircle the bench inside the paver semicircle.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

CROWD OF SEVERAL WOMEN AND MEN: Two, four, six, eight, we ain’t gonna integrate!

CROWD VOICES IN UNISON: Two, four, six, eight, we ain’t gonna integrate! {Getting louder}

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: I tried to see a friendly face somewhere in the mob — anybody who maybe would help. I looked into the face of an old woman, but when I looked at her again, she spat on me. I turned back to the guards, but their faces told me I wouldn’t get any help from them. 

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: Then I looked down the block and saw a bench at the bus stop. “If only I can get there, I will be safe.” I don’t know why the bench seemed a safe place to me, but I started walking towards it. I tried to close my mind to what they were shouting. 

MAN IN THE CROWD: If we let ‘em in, next thing they’ll be marrying our daughters! 

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: Just let those niggers show up! Just let ‘em try!

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: And kept saying to myself, “If only I can make it to the bench, I’ll be safe.”

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Democrat Photographer Will Counts

WILL COUNTS: As I watched and composed the photographs, I didn’t know what might happen after each step Elizabeth took. The mob became increasingly strident, and while I saw no one attempt to strike Elizabeth, that possibility was always present.

NARRATOR: Eleanor Roosevelt, Washington, D.C.

ELEANOR ROOSEVELT: Within all of us there are two sides. One reaches for the stars, the other descends to the level of the beasts. The picture of the mobs in Little Rock shows clearly that the beast in us was predominant. 

NARRATOR: Martin Luther King, Jr. telegram to The White House

MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR.: Mr. President, if the federal government fails to take a strong, positive stand at this time, it will set the process of integration back fifty years.

ELEANOR ROOSEVELT: No one in authority in this city tried to control and draw out the best in people instead of the worst. That is the sad thing about it. Not even the few courageous ministers could kindle even a spark of courage which would have turned the tide.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: If only I can make it to the bench, I’ll be safe. 

NARRATOR: Arkansas Gazette
    
ARKANSAS GAZETTE: Grand Forks, N.D. (Associated Press) – Trumpet player Louis (“Satchmo”) Armstrong said he’s given up plans for a government-sponsored trip to Russia because…

LOUIS ARMSTRONG: The way they are treating my people in the South, the government can go to hell. It’s getting almost so bad a colored man hasn’t got any country.

ARKANSAS GAZETTE: …the Negro entertainer said. One official at the State Department commented gloomily that Russian propagandists undoubtedly would seize on Armstrong’s words. The Reds have been pounding away at the school integration problems in the South as evidence of American intolerance of colored peoples.

LOUIS ARMSTRONG: The people over there ask me what’s wrong with my country. What am I supposed to say?

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: If only I can make it to the bench, I will be safe.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

stops.significance: Elizabeth waits for a bus after being locked out of Ponder’s Drug Store when she tried to call for a taxi. While waiting on the bus bench, she is approached by several individuals (L.C. Bates, Terrence Roberts, CBS newsman Robert Schakne, NY Times Reporter Benjamin Fine, and Grace Lorch) but remains surrounded by the crowd. When a city bus arrives, she boards, leaves for her mother’s workplace, and accompanied for a short time by Grace Lorch, the wife of a white professor at Philander Smith College who supported integration.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Using the crosswalk and ramp, proceed west approximately 65 feet (20 meters) to arrive at the northwest corner of S. Park Street and 16th Street. The sidewalk in front of Central High School is comprised of two 6 foot by 6 foot (1.8 x 1.8 meters) square concrete tiles inset side by side. We recommend using the west set of tiles (the portion closest to Central High School) to avoid the curb parallel to S. Park Street and other potential tripping hazards. The west set of tiles are 6 feet west of the curb on S. Park Street. 

Using the west set of tiles in front of Central High School, proceed north approximately 670 feet (204 meters) to reach the southwest corner of S. Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive.

Using this crosswalk, head east approximately 45 feet (14 meters) across S. Park Street to arrive at the Magnolia Mobil Station. You will be facing the station, but standing outside the security bollards in place to prevent vehicular traffic from entering onto the Magnolia Mobil Station apron.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: When I finally got there to the bus stop bench, I don’t think I could have gone another step. I sat down and the mob hollered…

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: Go back where you came from!

MAN IN THE CROWD: Go home before you get hurt, nigger!  

MAN IN THE CROWD: If they’re in my class I’ll walk out!

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: If they don’t have guards with them niggers, they’re gonna get murdered. 

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: We got us a nigger right here!

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: Drag her over to this tree!

MAN IN THE CROWD: Lynch her!   

ELIZABETH ECKFORD: Just then a white man sat down beside me, put his arm around me, and patted my shoulder. He raised my chin and said, 

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: Don’t let them see you cry.

TERRENCE ROBERTS: Elizabeth was visibly shaken by all of the hostility directed toward her, and I had begun to feel a higher level of fear myself as I listened to the taunts and name-calling from the mob. I made my way over to Elizabeth to see if I could offer anything that might help her. I suggested she walk home with me, but she declined. She told me later that if she had gone home with me, she would still have had to find a way to get to her own home. Grace Lorch, a white woman from Little Rock, stayed with Elizabeth and said that she would see to it that she got on the bus. I decided it would be best if I went back home, and I turned away from the mob and started to walk.

CARLOTTA WALLS: The next day, the New York Times would run this account of the moment when a lone white woman—Grace Lorch, whose husband taught at Philander Smith College—came to Elizabeth’s aid:

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: The Negro girl sat on a bench. She seemed in a state of shock. A white woman, Grace Lorch, walked over to comfort her.

MAN IN THE CROWD: “What are you doing, you nigger lover?” …

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: …Mrs. Lorch was asked.

WOMAN IN THE CROWD: “You stay away from that girl!”

GRACE LORCH: “She’s scared,”

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: she said, appealing to the men and women around her.

GRACE LORCH: “Why don’t you calm down?”

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: …, she asked the crowd.

GRACE LORCH: “Six months from now you’ll be ashamed of what you’re doing.”

NEW YORK TIMES REPORTER BENJAMIN FINE: Mrs. Lorch escorted the Negro student to the other side of the street, but the crowd followed. Finally, after being jostled by the crowd, she worked her way to the street corner, and the two boarded a bus.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas Democrat Photographer] Will Counts

WILL COUNTS: The National Guard troops remained on the sidewalk, passively watching the crowd verbally assail her. Elizabeth has told me that [as] she was sitting on a bench at the bus stop, she wondered why the newsmen—including me—who crowded around, didn’t assist her onto a bus. I have no good answer for her question.

NARRATOR: Eleanor Roosevelt

ELEANOR ROOSEVELT: The world is made up of people of many races and many colors. They must be accepted as people and treated with the same dignity and respect wherever they are. Until we do this with our own citizens at home, we will be suspect to the world, our leadership will have little value, and we will endanger the peace of the world. We have the responsibility to give an example of how nations can live together in peace and unity.

NARRATOR: [Arkansas] Gazette [Editor] Harry Ashmore

HARRY ASHMORE: “Reflections in a Hurricane’s Eye” – We are going to have to decide what kind of people we are—whether we obey the law only when we approve of it, or whether we obey it no matter how distasteful we may find it.

stops.significance:
This stop looks at key events that occur after September 4 including the entry of the Little Rock Nine into Central High under escort from the 101st Airborne. 

The station was built in the Spanish Colonial Revival style, a popular design for gas stations in the 1920s and 1930s. Magnolia Oil (later Mobil), a pioneer in regional architectural styles for gas stations, frequently made use of the Spanish Colonial Revival style. The station walls are masonry with a stucco exterior and the building has a red barrel tile roof. The main body of the building is one story with a one-story canopy supported by two large square columns and extending out over the service area. Three restored gas pumps are located on a raised base on either side of the columns. Throughout the years, the building served as a gas station, a hangout for students, a temporary “office” for reporters during the 1957 desegregation crisis, a storage space for a wholesale florist business, and a National Historic Site visitor center until 2007.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
This is the final location for the self-guided audio tour with the accompanying transcript. 

To return to the visitor center from the Magnolia Mobil Station, turn around and proceed west from your location outside the security bollards. Using the curb cut and crosswalk, proceed west approximately 46 feet (14 meters) to arrive at the southwest corner of S. Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Turn right and, using the crosswalk and ramp, proceed north approximately 55 feet (17 meters) to arrive at the northwest corner of S. Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Turn right and proceed east, using the crosswalk and ramp, approximately 49 feet (15 meters) to arrive at the northeast corner of S. Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. The visitor center is directly northeast of your location.
stops.audioTranscript:
This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript is directly from eyewitness and published accounts and includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

1957

September 20— Federal Judge Davies rules that Governor Faubus did not use the National Guard troops to preserve law and order and forbids him from interfering with the integration of Central High. The governor removes the National Guard. Little Rock Police then move in.

September 23 — The Little Rock Nine enter a side door at Central High School as a crowd of about 1,000 whites riot out front. The police cannot handle the crowd. The nine students are removed from the school before noon for their safety. President Eisenhower calls the rioting ‘disgraceful’ and issues Executive Order #10730 paving the way for the use of federal troops to stop it.

September 25— Under federal troop escort, the nine students ride up to Central High School in an Army staff car and finally enter the school for their first full day of classes.

1958

January 24 — Five bomb threats in five days occur at Central, but nothing is found except a stick of dynamite without a fuse or cap and a few firecrackers.

February 17 — Minnijean Brown is expelled from Central. Minnijean says that she is being punished for calling a girl “white trash” after the other girl hit her. Sammie Dean Parker, a white student, is suspended for pushing Gloria Ray, one of the nine, down a flight of stairs and two white boys are suspended for showing cards saying, “One down, eight to go.”

May 25— The first African American student to graduate from Central High School is Ernest Green. Civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is in attendance at the ceremony as a guest of the Green family.

NARRATOR: Atlanta Daily World, September 26, 1957: “Dr. King Asks Non-Violence in Little Rock School Crisis”

DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR.: History is on your side. World opinion is with you. The moral conscience of millions of white Americans is with you. Keep struggling with this faith and the tragic midnight of anarchy and mob rule which encompasses your city at this time will be transformed into the glowing daybreak of freedom and justice.

This tour has retraced the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the first attempt to integrate Central High School on September 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration and written transcript was directly taken from eyewitness and published accounts and included racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language was meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism and bigotry. Thank you for using appropriate guidance when using this resource.

images.altText: A drawing of Elizabeth Eckford with shadowy characters and the word "hate" behind her - Sept. 4, '57
