data.title: Self-Guided tour of Plains, Georgia
data.description: A Self-Guided tour of Plains, Georgia.

stops.significance: Plains High School is where both Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter attended grades one through eleven. Today Plains High School is the main visitor center and museum for the Jimmy Carter National Historic Site.
stops.assetName: Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front steps on Plains High School, facing the parking lot, turn right and follow either driveway to North Bond Street/ Highway 45 North. Look both ways before crossing the street. Once the street is crossed you are on Pascal street; look to your right for Plains Baptist Church.
stops.audioTranscript: Plains High School was built in 1921 and was the focal point of the town and the surrounding community. Although it has always been known as the Plains High School, it served as the elementary school also. President Jimmy Carter and Mrs. Rosalynn Carter both graduated from this school in 1941 and 1944, respectively. There were only eleven grades until 1952 when the State of Georgia added the twelfth grade. The Plains High School now serves as the visitor center for the National Park Service and has the distinction of being the official State School of Georgia an official State Symbol.

stops.significance: Plains Baptist Church is where Jimmy Carter attended church as a child, and later attended church after his return from the Navy in 1953.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking down Pascal street for two blocks. On your left hand side you will see a wayside for Apartment 9A

stops.significance: Apartment 9A is the low income housing that Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter and their three sons moved into upon their return to Plains in 1953.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Apartment 9A continue down Pascal street 50 feet until you reach Thomas street. Make a left onto Thomas street and proceed to the end of the road; U.S. Highway 280. Make a right onto the sidewalk and continue down for two blocks to the Carter Home Overlook on your right. Do not climb over the split rail fence.

stops.significance: Carter Home Overlook is where visitors can see the managed landscape of the Carter home, catch a glimpse of the Carter Home, and see the pond that Jimmy Carter had installed after his return from the White House.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Carefully cross highway 280. Walk back towards downtown. Two block down Plains United Methodist Church will be on your right.

stops.significance: Plains United Methodist Church is the home church of Rosalynn Smith Carter. This is the church that Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter were married in on July 7, 1946.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of Plains United Methodist Church continue walking down the sidewalk for two blocks towards the town of Plains. You will pass Plains City Park. This park has public restrooms. Continue down the sidewalk until you reach Plains City Hall.

stops.significance: Plains City Hall is where the Carter family would have registered their home, paid utilities and licensing fees, and came to public meetings about the city of Plains.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Plains City Hall make a right onto M.L. Hudson street. Cross over the railroad tracks, being careful of the uneven surfaces, and proceed to the front of the Plains Depot, which faces Main Street.
stops.audioTranscript: In the 1940s Oliver Spann, son of Ernest and Carrie Oliver Spann, operated a bowling alley in this building. This was a delightful recreation time for the older as well as the young people of Plains. This building has served a number of different functions including a gas station, café, and beauty shop. Today this building serves as Plains City Hall.

stops.significance: Plains Depot is the oldest building in Plains and the site of the 1976 Presidential Campaign Headquarters for Jimmy Carter.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of the Plains Depot walk across Main street to Plains Pharmacy.
stops.audioTranscript: With the arrival of the railroad in rural areas of the South, it meant not only survival, but prosperity. The Plains Depot was built in 1888 in the center of town, and residential neighborhoods began to develop. Milton Leander Hudson donated the land for the town itself and the depot soon followed. Although the depot closed in 1951, it was reopened on April 18, 1976 to serve as the Presidential Campaign Headquarters for Jimmy Carter. During that time approximately 10,000 people a day came to Plains to find out about candidate Carter. Many state primary victories, as well as the Presidential victory, were held in the streets around the depot. The depot now contains a self-guided museum with exhibits focusing on the 1976 Presidential campaign.

stops.significance: Plains Pharmacy served as the cultural hub for the younger people in Plains and was where the Carter family would have filled prescriptions for medicine.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Plains Pharmacy continue down M.L. Hudson street less than one Block. The Graham Store is the beige building on your left. If you reach Dollar General you have gone too far.
stops.audioTranscript: In the early 1900’s, this was a two story brick building erected by the Wise brothers for their first hospital in Plains.  Plains pharmacy was located on the ground floor of this building.  Eventually the hospital was relocated and the second floor became a beauty shop owned and operated by Mrs. Anne Gay Dodson, as well as , offices for Dr. Bowman Wise.   In 1912, Dr. L.E. Godwin and Dr. J. J. Monts bought into the drug store as partners.  During these years, the drug store was a center of community life with a victrola to provide music, a soda fountain for refreshments, three soda tables with chairs for comfort and a ceiling fan for pleasure. In 1954 at the time of his father’s death, L.E. Godwin, Jr. became owner of Plains Pharmacy and at his retirement in 1968, L.E. Godwin III assumed ownership.

stops.significance: The Graham Store is where Mr. Graham, a well respected African-American gentleman, ran a dry goods store. The school children, including Jimmy and Rosalynn, would have stopped by after school in hopes of getting a piece of pie fresh out of the oven.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around and walk back up the sidewalk and cross M.L. Hudson street at the corner of Main Street. Walk down Main street one block towards the downtown strip of stores. Plains Historic Inn and Antiques Mall will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript: In the 1920s General Meyers and John Graham both had thriving mercantile businesses to the southside of the Plains Pharmacy Building. They were two black gentleman who held high reputations in the area. Raisin and blueberry pies were made by Mrs. Graham and sold for ten cents each at the Graham store. The local children knew the exact time she would take them from the oven and carry them to the store.

stops.significance: Plains Historic Inn and Antiques Mall plays a central role in the history of Plains, Georgia. When the building was renovated into the Inn (2002), President and Mrs. Carter assisted with the renovations and made suggestions about how the rooms were furnished.
stops.assetName: Plains Historic Inn and Antique Mall
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the sidewalk about fifty feet to the Buffalo Cafe at the Old Bank.
stops.audioTranscript: Originally the Oliver-MCDonanld store.  This building came into existence around 1901.  The two-story section was added to house a furniture store and funeral home managed by Ross Dean.  In 1934 two of the buildings were sold to Alton Carter for his established Plains Mercantile Company Business and Plains Mercantile Bank.  The hand drawn elevator was installed for the moving of furniture and caskets to the upstairs area.  In 1971, the building and the one beside it became Hugh Carter’s Antiques.  The building came into its present use in 2002, when it became the Plains Inn and Antique Mall.

stops.significance: The Old Bank building was a bank and later a post office for the town of Plains. Before the post office moved into the building Jimmy Carter and his cousin sold ice cream and hamburgers from the store front. Later after the post office moved, Hugh Carter used the building as the offices for his worm farm.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the sidewalk ten feet to Plains Trading Post.
stops.audioTranscript:
Old Bank Building
Plains Bank was organized in 1901 in a one-story brick building located in the middle of the store area on Main street. R.S. Oliver served as President, W. L Thomas Vice President, and C. C. Lunsford as Cashier. The bank became delinquent between January the second 1919 and January the fifth 1920. After the failure of Plains Bank, Mr. Alton Carter added banking facilities to his Plain Mercantile Company which gave an appreciative convenience to the citizens of the area.

stops.significance: Plains Trading Post served as a store, a hardware store, and a grocery store before becoming a souvenir store during the 1976 Presidential Campaign.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the sidewalk fifty feet to Plain Peanuts.

stops.significance: Plain Peanuts originally was built as a hotel and then it became a hospital. Later Earl Carter ran his peanut warehouse and insurance agency from this building. Jimmy Carter used this location for his peanut warehouse until 1961.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk to the end of the sidewalk and turn left onto Highway 45/ South Bond Street. Walk across the railroad tracks, being careful of the uneven surfaces, and continue onto the sidewalk. On the sidewalk turn left and walk down to the crosswalk. Push the button and wait for the traffic to stop before entering the crosswalk. Once across the street the Billy Carter Service Station is in front of you.
stops.audioTranscript:
Old Carter Peanut Warehouse. 
Built circa 1903 the third and fourth buildings from the ends were originally known as the A. C. Wellons building, or Wise Sanitarium number one. Intended as a hotel it house retail services on the ground floor and the twenty bed Wise Sanitarium on the top floor. The Wise brothers used this location until 1920, when they moved to the newly completed hospital. Earl Carter rented the building here in 1934 and operated a peanut business and the Earl Carter Insurance, ran by Mrs. Nell Walters. This building is where President Carter launched his senatorial and gubernatorial campaigns. Earl Carter ran the peanut warehouse until his death in 1953. Jimmy Carter ran the peanut warehouse out of location until 1961, when the current location east of here was constructed.

stops.significance: Billy Carter Service Station is where reporters covering the 1976 Presidential Campaign would gather to talk to residents and to hear Billy Carter share his opinions on matters of the day.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of Billy Carter's Service Station walk down to the corner of Highway 280 and Highway 45/ North Bond Street. Cross the road and turn left on the sidewalk. Plains High School is three hundred feet on your left.
stops.audioTranscript: An important landmark in the history of Plains, this building was purchased in 1972 by Billy Carter, brother of President Jimmy Carter, from Mill Jennings. Mill formerly owned and operated a Standard Oil station, located where Citizens Bank now stands. In 1954, Jennings purchased this building from Thad Jones, moving it to this site where the Plains Hotel has recently been torn down. The building had formerly served as a playhouse and dance studio for Jones’s daughter. In 1976 Billy’s station became famous nationwide as journalists covering Jimmy Carter’s presidential campaign made it their headquarters. In 1981 Billy sold his station to his son-in-law, Mark Fuller.

images.title: Plains, Georgia Welcome Sign
images.altText: A brown metal sign that reads welcome to Plains Georgia the home of Jimmy Carter 39 president
images.caption: Welcome to Plains, Georgia

data.title: Self-guided tours Plains High School
data.description: Self-guided tours of Plains High School are available from 9am until 5pm daily. Visitors may request the introductory film at the front desk. This 25 minute films plays in the restored auditorium and is an overview of President Carter's life, times, and achievements. The rooms of Plains high School are self-guided and have audio, audio-visual, and tactile elements in the rooms. Feel free to explore at your own pace.

images.title: Plains High School
images.altText: a front view of the red brick, two story building, with large columns in the front;.
images.caption: Plains High School

data.title: Self-guided tours of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
data.description: Self-guided tours of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm are available from 10am until 5pm daily, weather permitting. Visitors are able to stroll the grounds of the farm, enter the buildings, and listen to audio programs via a push button system both inside and outside the buildings at the farm.

stops.significance: The starting point for self-guided walking tours of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
stops.assetName: Flagpole at Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the flagpole, walk to the large 3 panel sign.

stops.significance: The three panel sign gives an overview of Jimmy Carter's life and accomplishments.
stops.assetName: 3 Panel Sign at Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the red colored sidewalk until you reach the first sign on your right, Approx. sixty feet.

stops.significance: This sign captures the work ethic of Earl Carter, Jimmy Carter's father.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the sidewalk to the next sign on your right.

stops.significance: Provides information on Jimmy Carter's childhood.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Enter the back of the Carter Home either by climbing the stairs or using the ramp. The door on the left side of the porch is unlocked. Walk into the hallway and turn left into the first room on your left.
stops.audioTranscript: Hello I’m Jimmy Carter. Welcome to the house and farm where I spent my youth. Here we had long working days, during those Depression years. We would wake up each morning when the bell would ring, about 4 o’clock sun time, which was long before sunrise. We didn’t have any electricity and we didn’t have running water in the house; we got water from hand pumps for both livestock and our own use. It was quite a change for us when electricity came. My daddy believed in everyone on the farm doing their share. Here in the back yard we had chicken and ducks and guinea hens that we had to feed and of course we to sweep the yards all the time. We also had to cut wood and bring it in the house for Mama to use on the stove and also the fireplaces to keep us warm. The hardest work, though, was in the field: I had to carry water in two-and-a-half gallon buckets to workers in the field on hot days, and when I got older of course I helped milk the cows. But I also had a lot of fun as a child – I played with my playmates who lived nearby, particularly whenever it rained and we couldn’t work in the field or after the crops were plowed and before the harvest. We pushed steel barrel hoops with a wire pusher, and in the nearby streams we went fishing regularly, we built small dams, we went swimming in the creeks, so we had a lot of fun around the house and barns, and also in the distant fields

stops.significance: This is the room where Jimmy Carter was raised from the age of four until he went off to college at the age of seventeen.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the hall into the living room.
stops.audioTranscript: When I was a boy I was strongly influenced by my Uncle Tom Gordy, who served in the Navy and served in the Pacific on a ship, and he would often send me letters and souvenir gifts from China, Japan, the Philippines, and other places that he visited. One of the presents he sent me was a small model of a Chinese junk or ship, and of course it was one of my most cherished possessions. One of my fondest memories was of Christmas morning when I was a little boy. I had long wanted a pony, and was discouraged from expecting it but I woke up one Christmas – I was ill, I couldn’t get out of the house because I had measles, and my mother and father said that maybe Santa Claus had left me something outside in the yard so I raised the window in my bedroom, looked out, and there was a pony. I had never been more excited in my life; and then of course for years I rode my pony, whom I called Lady – she had colts that I cherished, and it really was a transforming moment of my boyhood. As a boy I was an avid reader, as was my mother. Whenever I was asked what I wanted for Christmas, for Santa Claus to bring me, I always said books. Reading was really my major contact with the outside world… what happened in Africa with Tarzan, what happened with Tom Swift and his adventures, and developments in scientific developments of those days. It was reading and the books that opened up my eyes to the world that I didn’t yet know as a boy. That reading habit stuck with me throughout my life and that’s one of the reasons I still like to read and write books of my own.

stops.significance: The Living Room of the Carter Home
stops.assetName: Living Room In the Carter Boyhood Home
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk out the door and make a left at the bottom of the steps. Walk over to the next white building known as the Commissary.
stops.audioTranscript:
(Radio static)
(Announcer)
The Johnson Wax Program with Fibber McGee and Molly.
(music)
(President Jimmy Carter)
Before we had electricity in our home, one of our major treasures was a battery-operated radio. It was placed in the living room and we would all sit and watch the radio while we listened to the exciting programs of a very limited nature. Daddy was very stingy about running the battery down so our time was limited. Most of our listening was in the evening and our course sometimes on the weekend when we were not working. We really enjoyed programs like Amos and Andy, Little Orphan Annie, and Fibber McGee and Mollie.
(Radio program excerpt: well I must say…McGee, McGee, she’s here inside. Doorbell chimes)
Usually we all watched and listened the radio at the same time but I had a special interest in Glenn Miller’s music which unfortunately came on quite late at night, like eight o’clock. Daddy would let me stay up after the other family went to bed. I would lie in front of the fireplace, we had a clock on the mantle in the living room, and when eight o’clock came I would turn on the radio and listen to Glenn Miller for fifteen minutes. 
(music plays) 
One of my most vivid memories about the radio is when there was a heavyweight boxing match between Joe Lewis who was black and Max Schmeling a white German. 
(Announcer)
Here is the biggest show on Earth. Joe Lewis the worlds heavyweight champion versus Max Schmeling, Germany’s contender.
(Bell rings)
(Announcer)
Weighing one ninety-eight and three quarters, wearing black trunks, the famous Detroit Brown Bomber, world’s heavyweight champion, Joe Lewis. 
(President Jimmy Carter)
This was a rematch, and it was filled with heavy racial overtones I guess all over the world, but particularly in the deep south.  As the time for the math approached, our black neighbors, about thirty or forty of them asked my father if they could listen to the radio. Daddy approved of course and in the living room on the windowsill he put the radio so that you could hear it inside the house and outside under the mulberry tree. A large crowd assembled out there. In the first round Joe Lewis almost Killed Max Schmeling. 

(Announcer)
Five, six, seven, eight …the men are in the ring. The fight is over on a technical knockout. Max Schmeling is beaten in one round. The first time in a world…
(President Jimmy Carter)
Our neighbors observing their southern proprieties didn’t make a sound. They very carefully walked out of the yard, crossed the railroad, and went to a distant house. They celebrated until the wee hours of the morning.

stops.significance: Commissary on the Carter Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the sidewalk and you'll see a sign by the Windmill. That is your next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
We had a store, or what we called a commissary, on the farm which was quite common in rural communities because they provided the basic necessities that had to be bought by the workers and by our family as well. What happened, usually, was that the purchases were on credit. And payment for the different items were made on payday, or sometimes even at the end of the season when the crops were harvested. The stores were convenient for three reasons: One, they were close by and most of the transportation was on foot. Secondly, the land owner, the larger ones, owned the store and wanted to make a profit on items sold. And third, the people who lived on the farm or nearby, quite often had no credit rating in town. Whereas a land owner, that owned the store, would know them and if they wanted to buy a pair of shoes or a shirt or some tobacco they didn’t have to worry about credit because they had ready credit, since the landowner knew them well and since the landowner knew that when he paid them for their work he could collect the bill. 

This store was not kept open all the time but it was open all day Saturday, because that was a day for major purchases, that was the day when workers were paid and when they paid off what they owed. The rest of the week the store was closed except when anyone wanted to make any kind of purchase. Both we and they were out of the fields during mealtimes. So almost every time I ever sat down at a meal, someone knocked on the back door and wanted to make a purchase from the store, my daddy would throw the keys across the table to me, I would get up and miss part of the meal, walk out to the store, unlock it, sell five cents worth of chewing tobacco or a bottle of castor oil or two pounds of sugar, make a ticket showing that the person had bought something on credit, lock the store back up, then go back to our meal. I hardly ever remember going through an entire meal without having to be interrupted to go to the store and open it to make a sale.

stops.significance: The windmill helped Jimmy Carter develop interest in alternative energy sources.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk past the garden to the blacksmith shop, the first building on your right. It has a sharpening wheel and a chimney visible from the windmill.

stops.significance: This is the first place that Jimmy Carter was able to work beside his father and where he learned the value of hard work.
stops.assetName: Blacksmith Shop at Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the blacksmith shop continue on the sidewalk to the edge of the barn. The catch the Mules sign is around the corner, at the edge of the large barn.
stops.audioTranscript: This building served as a blacksmith and a carpenter shop. Here we shod mules and horses, we sharpened plow points, repaired machinery, made simple iron implements, and did woodwork also, with daddy providing overall supervision. This is one of the first places where I was able to work alongside my father. I would turn the hand crank of the forge blower fast enough to keep the charcoal fire ablaze and then would hold some of the red hot pieces on the anvil with tongs while my daddy shaped them with a hammer and then plunged them, hissing into the water or oil for tempering. I learned a lot of skills from my father in this very building, and also from Jack Clark, our farm supervisor, who did most of the shoeing of our mules and horses. Of course, I also learned farm techniques at school. There was certainly no assurance that I would ever go to the Naval Academy so I had to prepare for other future possibilities. And, the most natural would be as a farmer. So, along with more than half the other boys in my high school I joined the Future Farmers of America program. We took many agricultural classes and, in the workshop at school, we practiced carpentry and blacksmithing, welding, and furniture making. Our teacher worked closely with each of our fathers to ensure that our work at school was compatible with what was being done on the farm.

stops.significance: The change from horse power to machinery took place during President Carter's lifetime.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk toward the large farm bell and turn left. Your destination is the closest green building just off to the right.
stops.audioTranscript:
The barn was the center of our attention on the farm because all of our work was focused there. It was a very exciting place, as a matter of fact. We caught the mules and horses early in the morning, took them to the field hooked to wagons and plows. That’s where we brought them back at night for feed and for watering. We also had a good time around the barn. For instance, when daddy thrashed oats and wheat, we had a thrashing machine just behind the barn and we would have a big pile of loose hay. We used to get a running start in the loft of the barn and leap out of the window and land on the soft pile of hay. Throughout my young life I worked and played with my boyhood neighbors. My neighbors were African American. And we were equal to one another. But, when I was about fourteen years old, there was a profound experience that I had, that didn’t seem to be important at the time. But later in my life I realized it was one of the turning points in my life. I wrote a poem about it. 
The pasture gate: This empty house, three miles from town was where I lived. Here I was back, and found most homes around were gone. The folks who stayed here now were black, like Johnny and A.D., my friends. As boys we worked in Daddy’s fields, hunted rabbits, squirrels, and quail, caught and cooked catfish and eels, searched the land for arrowheads, tried to fly the smallest kite, steered barrel hoops with strands of wire, and wrestled hard. At times we’d fight, without a thought of who might be boss, who was the smartest or the best; the leader for a few brief hours was who had won the last contest. But then – we were fourteen or so – as we approached the pasture gate, they went to open it, and then stood back. This made me hesitate, sure it must have been a joke, a tripwire, maybe, they had planned. I reckon they had to obey their parents’ prompting. Or command. We only saw it vaguely then, but we were transformed at that place. A silent line was drawn between friend and friend, race and race.

stops.significance: This home is where the couple lived that were like a second set of parent to Jimmy Carter.
stops.assetName: Clark House at Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back to the barn and follow the sidewalk to the right. This will lead you back to the sign called Cash Crops.
stops.audioTranscript: In addition to my mother and father, there were a few people that shaped my life. Two of them were Jack and Rachel Clark, who lived in this house. When my mother and father would go off on vacation, I would stay with Jack and Rachel and they provided me with information about the basic rudiments of life, the priorities that any human being should accrue, and also my entrée into understanding how the sharecroppers and day laborers lived in a strictly segregated society. Much later I wrote a poem about Rachel Clark titled “Rachel”: My young life, shaped by those I loved, felt the gentle touch of Rachel Clark, our neighbor on the farm, whose husband, Jack, cared for the barn and did the kind of work that we boys most admired. He tended mules, and rang the cast-iron bell that brought an end to sleep, and later told the time to rest. His wife was small and quiet. Her brown skin fixed her in our segregated world, yet Rachel had the aura of a queen that somehow wouldn’t let the white folks ask for her to do the chores around their place – like cooking, ironing clothes or tending babes. But she would volunteer with quiet grace any time she learned the need was real. For miles around, the farming folks would know what Rachel did while working in the field. I’d pick a hundred and fifty pounds or so of cotton if I never stopped to rest – no man could do much more – but Rachel Clark could pick near twice as much as second best. At sundown we would tie what we had got in burlap sheets, and watch the foreman weigh, see for ourselves that Rachel had the most, and if she had topped her own best mark that day. She’d put a lot more peanuts on the stacks, hoe more weeds, shuck more corn – no one, in fact, could equal anything she did. These kinds of deeds that may seem small to some were big events for use, in which we all competed, as our farm life would allow. When work was done, or when a heavy rain made the fields too wet to hoe or plow and open cotton bolls too damp to pick sometimes she’d smile at me and mention fish. Then she and I would leave the farm and walk six miles or so to reach a stream she knew. These journeys gave us ample time to talk – or rather, I would listen to her words, as she would think awhile, and then hold forth about God’s holy way: how, when we deal with nature, we are stewards of the earth, she’d say that blessings bring on debts to pay, describe the duties of a man and wife, and say that the brave and strongest need not fight. She’d tell how praying gave her life a lift, and how it made her act and not just talk – like staying up all night with someone sick. It wasn’t empty preaching, like in church: sometimes I wasn’t glad to reach the creek. Our bait was crawfish, lizards, crickets, worms or whatever she would recommend for perch, catfish, and bass – which we call trout, misnamed by our European kin, or mine at least’ I knew that Rachel’s folks were brought, themselves, to be my people’s slaves. The swamps and woodlands came alive for me. She taught the way every person craves to learn. Our creels were empty flour sacks that kept our catch in water, fresh and safe from water snakes and snapping turtles, that would have left us bones instead of fish. Rachel used exactly seven poles, for reasons I never could figure out. I asked her, “Why not eight or six?” She only smiled at me, then went ahead and caught, with luck or skill, five fish to one of mine. She made it seem a favor, heading home if some of hers would end up in my sack. Those might have been the best days I have known. With my folks gone, I’d stay with her and Jack. Newspapered walls all leaned, the sagging doors stayed open, letting flies and breezes in. I smelled the lye that cleaned the holy floors. Saving kerosene, we slept at dusk on lumpy corn shucks, not my feather bed. They always made me feel like I belonged, and knew what things were better left unsaid. Although the food was plain and seldom changed, I never thought our big house down the road was better. They all knew I liked to be with Rachel Clark. I guess my feelings showed. In later years, I’d visit Rachel’s home In public housing; sometimes I’d find her on the village street. Then, still a queen, her apron sagging with a can of beer, she’d laugh about what good times there had been, and tell me what she thought I ought to do in Washington, where I was working then.

stops.significance: Cash Crops talks about the crops grown on the Carter farm. It also describes "mopping cotton", a chore Jimmy Carter and his young friends despised.
stops.directionsToNextStop: continue walking down the sidewalk towards the tree line. The next stop is sixty feet down and on the left.

stops.significance: Jimmy Carter describes he upbringing on the Boyhood Farm and how it shaped his life
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the trail ten feet to the next sign.

stops.significance: Jimmy Carter talks about how stewardship of the farm shaped his views on the environment as an adult.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk to the end and you will be at the main parking lot of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm.
stops.audioTranscript: One of my most vivid memories of my childhood was of the earth. There was a closeness, almost an immersion in the sand, loam, and red clay that seemed both natural and constant. I remember how enjoyable it was to walk behind the plow, my bare feet caressed by the soft and cool freshly turned earth. The Great Depression really devastated our rural farming economy. The New Deal programs initiated under President Roosevelt’s administration helped to combat this economic downturn and were meant to help farmers conserve the precious topsoil making the land more productive. On our farm, we concentrated on minimizing erosion by terracing the fields and planting the rows on contour. We planted soil building crops like clover, legumes, and vetch; and we worked to enhance wildlife habitat. I learned early on that if we take care of the land, it will take care of us. It may or may not be my descendants who live on our land in the future, but I’m confident that the earth itself will basically remain the same, continuing to shape the lives of its owners for good or ill, as it has for generations. It’s good to realize that if love and peace can prevail on earth, and if we can teach our children to honor nature’s gifts, the joy and beauties of the outdoors will be here forever.

data.title: Self-guided tours of the Plains Depot (1976 Campaign Headquarters)
data.description: Self-guided tours of Plains Depot are available from 9am until 4:30pm daily, weather permitting. The Plains Depot has exhibits dedicated to President Carter's campaigns for local, state, and national government. a 12 minute video of the 1976 Presidential Campaign plays on a loop on the upper level of Plains Depot.

images.title: Plains Depot
images.altText: a front view of the Plains Depot (1976 Presidential Campaign Headquarters)
images.caption: Plains Depot (1976 Presidential Campaign Headquarters)

data.title: Seminole Rest Audio Tour
data.description: Seminole Rest is open daily from sunrise to sunset. There is a half mile path that is handicap accessible. Read about various snapshots of history about Timucuan and then Reconstruction Era settlers at this location on the various wayside stops along the way. This site is located in Oak Hill, Florida along the west side of Mosquito Lagoon. Enjoy the views of the lagoon, wildlife viewing and serenity during your visit. These are the very same qualities it's early inhabitants so enjoyed!

stops.directionsToNextStop: Enter the trail head path and take the path towards the right which takes you directly to the edge of Mosquito Lagoon and stop and the first informational wayside.
Keep going along the path and the second informational wayside is not too far away along with a bench to rest at.

stops.assetName: Seminole Rest Wayside, What Do You Think?
stops.directionsToNextStop: Stay on the path and walk towards the next informational wayside which is directly in front of the historic Snyder home.

stops.assetName: Seminole Rest Wayside, Preserving the Mound
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path. Stop at the dock to view the lagoon and watch for wildlife. Next to the dock is located the next information wayside and a bench.
Follow the path around the caretaker's home. Stop and look at the caretaker's house and the larger Snyder home. Or if pressed for time continue past the home to the next informational wayside.

stops.assetName: Seminole Rest Wayside, Mounds of Evidence
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path to the next and last informational wayside.

stops.assetName: Seminole Rest Wayside, The Timucuan Way of Life
stops.directionsToNextStop: If you keep going along the path to exit the trail and make a right at the fork in the path.

images.title: Seminole Rest Home
images.altText: Seminole Rest home a top of Snyder's mound.
images.caption: Seminole Rest home rests at the top of Snyder's mound.

data.title: Seven Prisons
data.description: This thirty-minute walking tour takes you to the sites of six different prisons on Alcatraz Island and connects their stories with our criminal justice system today, the “seventh prison.” While we explore the different sites, ask yourselves about the purpose of incarcerating people in these prisons. Did these prisons serve their purpose, and do our prisons today?

stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk from the Dock up the hill to the Sallyport and find the room across from the cannon.
Continue outside the Guardhouse to the next building, the Electric Shop
Continue around the corner and up the road to the wayside sign for the Lower Prison.

stops.assetName: The Lower Prison Complex: Seven Prisons
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue up the road to the Parade Ground.
Continue up the road to the lighthouse.
Continue down the west side of the prison until you see the red door.

images.altText: Aerial view of Alcatraz Island
images.caption: Alcatraz Island
