data.title: Shiloh Battlefield Auto Tour
data.description: This 12.7 mile driving tour will take visitors through the two days of bloody fighting at Shiloh. Learn about the battle that changed the public perception of the American Civil War.

stops.significance: Introduction for the 22-stop auto driving tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow signs to tour stop #1.
stops.audioTranscript: Welcome to Shiloh National Military Park, this driving tour covers 12. 7 miles and normally takes about 3 hours. As you drove into the park today you probably noticed a number of monuments and cannon. This park was established in 1894 and they were placed to mark the positions of military units during the battle of Shiloh. You may wonder how the terrain has changed since the time of the battle in April 1862. One major change, to keep in mind, is that in most places the wooded areas had much less undergrowth and were clearer than today. This was a farming community and the farmers let their livestock run loose, with the result that most of the undergrowth had been trampled or eaten. Where the cannon appear to be pointed at thick woods today, you would have been able to see several hundred yards in 1862.

stops.significance: Final position for Federal forces on the evening of April 6, 1862.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to Tour Stop #2, the Confederate Memorial. Drive west on Pittsburg Landing Rd. and take your first left. Follow the road approximately one mile, bearing right at the fork in the road, the Memorial will be on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
2:30 pm, April 6, 1862
 
Across the road from the Iowa State Monument you will see two large 24-pounder siege guns and one stubby 8-inch Siege Howitzer, marking the position of Battery B, 2nd Illinois Light Artillery. Col. Joseph Dana Webster, Grant's Chief of Staff was ordered to place infantry and artillery units in line here after they came off the battlefield and were resupplied. 

He had men detailed to drag five 24-pounder iron siege guns, normally pulled by oxen, from the boats at the landing to take a key position in the defense. Around the nucleus of this artillery was placed a total of 50 cannon and about 20,000 infantry to hold back the Confederates. 

Union forces were thrown into a temporary panic when Gage's Alabama Battery unlimbered on the other side of the ravine and started firing toward the landing. A cannonball took off the head of Capt. Irving Carson, a volunteer scout, who was accompanying Grant.

Gen. William "Bull" Nelson had arrived in Savannah at Grant's Headquarters the evening of April 5th and had been advised he could march to the bank opposite Pittsburg Landing to be ferried across. Hearing the noise of the battle, Nelson sent the message to his men struggling through a "black mud swamp". "Col. Ammen, the General sends his compliments to hurry up or all will be lost; the enemy is driving our men." 

On reaching the opposite bank, Nelson and his staff were ferried across the river. Nelson was appalled at the thousands of shirkers he witnessed cowering under the riverbank. ·When the gangplank dropped at Pittsburg Landing, Nelson shouted to his staff, "Gentlemen, draw your sabers and trample these bastards into the mud!"

stops.significance: Memorial to all Confederate troops at Shiloh.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the tour road to Tour Stop #3 - Duncan Field.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1900, Cornelia Irwin, the sister of former Confederate cavalry officer, Captain James Irwin, started a project to erect a memorial to all Confederate soldiers, especially those who fell at Shiloh. 

Irwin had organized the United Daughters of the Confederacy chapter in Savannah, Tennessee, and at the first meeting, the group pledged to work towards funding the memorial.· 

The ladies sold items and solicited fonds from several sources. By 1909, they had raised $50,000 and selected Frederick C. Hibbard, a Missourian based in Chicago, as the artist for the monument. Hibbard was known for his work on the Illinois Monument at Vicksburg National Military Park. 
 
On May 17, 1917, the Confederate Memorial was unveiled and presented to the national military park. The event, which was attended by 15,000 people, included speeches by Governor Thomas 
C. Fry, members of the UDC, and the artist Hibbard. 

We invite you to visit the monument and read the wayside exhibit explaining the monument's heavy use of symbolism to tell a story of theConfederate soldier's experience at Shiloh

stops.significance: Iconic Civil War site
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on tour road a short distance to Tour Stop #4 - Ruggles' Battery
stops.audioTranscript:
On April 6, at 8:30 am, General William H.L. Wallace, commanding Grant's 2nd Division, advanced Colonel James Tuttle's Brigade down the Eastern Corinth Road in an attempt to aid General Prentiss at the front. Unable to reach Prentiss' camps, at 9:00 am they formed a line clown an old wagon rut facing Duncan Field. The rut today is known as the Sunken Road.

On Tuttle's right was the brigade of Colonel Thomas Sweeny which deployed in the open field. Wallace's three batteries formed on the ridge behind this strong infantry line of around 5,400 soldiers. At 10:00 am, what was left of Prentiss' Division had fallen back to this position and linked his battered forces on the left of Tuttle in a dense thicket.

Here Wallace's Division would defend the right of the Sunken Road until being flanked by the enemy at about 5 :00 pm. At that time Wallace ordered his men to fall back, but several of his
regiments did not get the orders, and they were captured in the Hornets' Nest.

Within minutes, General Wallace received a mortal wound to the head.

stops.significance: Iconic Civil War battle location
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on tour road, following signage, to Tour Stop #5 - Shiloh Church
stops.audioTranscript:
On your left, you will see a long line of cannon positioned hub-to-hub. From this position, Confederate General Daniel Ruggles witnessed multiple failed infantry assaults against the dense thicket and Sm1ken Road line. At 3: 00 pm, Ruggles sent his staff to locate and bring forward all available artillery they could find. 

Fifty-three guns, later nick-named "Ruggles' Battery" would assemble here and pound the Federal line. This massed battery would be the largest single battlefield concentration of field artillery ever deployed on the North American continent up to that time.

stops.significance: Iconic Civil War site
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the tour road down the hill and take your first left. Tour Stop #6 is on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The stone church you see today, completed in 1953, rests on the same site as the historic building. The original church, built about 1853, was a one-room, rough-hewn log building, simple in appearance, with no stained windows, no pulpit, and no carved decorations. It did have two doors and one. window but without glass. The reproduction wooden church you see across the parking lot is based on a drawing made by a soldier before the battle. Unfortunately, like most of the more than 70 log buildings present at Shiloh in 1862, the original church was damaged in the momentous battle that took its name. 

At around 7:00 am on April 6, Gen. William T. Sherman, whose headquarters tent was in the woods behind the church, placed the three Ohio regiments of Col. Ralph Buckland' s Brigade on the hill to the right, across the road from the church, where you see the two cannons and monument for Barrett's Illinois Battery, and the two remaining Ohio, regiments of Col. Jesse Hildebrand's Brigade to the left supporting the guns of Waterhouse's Illinois Battery.

This was a good defensive position, since the Confederates would have to come up the hill in the face of concentrated musket and cannon fire, after making their way through the swampy ground of Shiloh Branch. Confederate units stalled as they met this obstacle and the intense fire from Sherman's men. By 10:00 AM, three Confederate Brigades had become entangled in the low ground of Shiloh Branch as they were stopped by Union resistance and tenain. Col. William B. Bate commanding the 2nd Tennessee, on the left flank General Cleburne's Brigade, tried to make an attack against the flank of the Federal position but his unit lost heavily when caught in a severe crossfire. After his brother Capt. Humphrey Bate was killed he ordered another attack against Barrett's Battery but was badly wounded in the left leg and his unit fell back. 

Bate would later become a Major General and Senator and Governor from Tem1essee. He would raise the money to have a monument erected to his unit with the quote," Stranger, Go tell Tennessee that we died here fighting for her." This monument would be the first Confederate monument placed on the Shiloh Battlefield in 1905. If you would like to see the monument near the spot Bate was wounded follow the trail across the road in front of the cannon a short distance to the monument and that of their opponents, the 70th Ohio, commanded by Col. Joseph R. Cockerill. Col. Cockerill's son, John, a sixteen year old musician in the 24th Ohio had come to visit his father· s camp at Shiloh to recover from an illness. The young man would provide a recollection of his first action here.

stops.significance: Iconic Civil War site
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn right out of the parking area and left on the Corinth Road. Follow to Tour Stop #7 - Fraley Field.
stops.audioTranscript:
Although Peabody's patrol provided some warning the Union Army would be surprised by the magnitude of the Confederate attack that hit them on the morning of April 6th. The majority of troops, approximately 65 percent, in both the western Union and Confederate armies were green, raw recruits who had never been in battle, "seen the elephant' as they said in those days. Another factor was the belief by Union generals that General Johnston would not attack, but remain on defense in Corinth, fortify his position, and wait for the threatened Union offensive. Grant's instructions from his own superior, General Henry W. Halleck, headquartered in St. Louis, forbade him to advance until Buell an-ived on his overland march from Nashville and reinforced Grant with the Army of the Ohio. Grant wo1Tied more about training the inexperienced recruits and preparing for the planned offensive, than he did about the intentions Gen. Johnston. In obedience to Halleck's instructions not to engage the Confederates, each time Union pickets or patrols encountered enemy forces prior to the battle; they simply defended their positions and were forbidden to advance: As one Union recruit recalled decades later when the Rebel onslaught rolled into the Federal camps that Sabbath morning, the entire Federal army reacted as if it had been "struck by an electric shock." 

Gen. William T. Sherman was among those shocked by the Confederate onslaught. Here at Rhea Field, he first became aware of the Confederate attack. On April 4th a detachment of Sherman' s infantry and cavalry had encountered Confederates in strength, including cavalry, artillery, and infantry a short march from camp. When his officers expressed concern about the presence of a strong enemy force, Sherman said, "Oh! Tut; tut. You militia officers get scared too easily." 

Sherman concluded that the force was a Confederate brigade making a reconnaissance in force of the Union camps. 
Col. Jesse Appler had his 53rd Ohio Infantry camped in the field across the road in an isolated position cut off from the rest of his brigade by Shiloh Branch. On April St􀀴 Appler sent a detachment to investigate signs of enemy activity and when firing broke out he formed his regiment and sent his quartermaster to notify Sherman, who was camped near Shiloh Church. Sherman sent Appler the message: "Take your damned regiment back to Ohio, There is no enemy nearer than Corinth." Sherman would send a letter to Grant on April 5th, stating: "I will not be drawn out far unless with certainty of advantage, and I do not apprehend anything like an attack on our position." 

Grant would write his superior on the evening of April 5th: "The main force of the enemy is at Corinth scarcely the faintest idea of an attack being made upon us, but will be prepared should such a thing take place." 

On the morning of April 6th Jesse Appler, camped here at Rhea Field felt anything but secure as he heard the noise of action at Fraley Field, a short distance away. He sent messengers to warn his Division Commander, Sherman. The messenger to Sherman reported back, "General Sherman says you must be badly scared over there." Appler would form his men in line facing south where you can see the monument for the 53rd Ohio. 
Finally, sometime after 7 am, Sherman appeared with his staff to examine the situation. While Sherman was looking to the southern end of the field, where Confederates had been spotted, Confederate skirmishers, advancing in front of Gen. Patrick Cleburne's Brigade, emerged from the woods on the west side of the field. Seeing the threat Adjutant Dawes of the 53rd Ohio, yelled out to Lt. Eustace Ball, of Company E: "Ball, Sherman will be shot!" Ball yelled out, 
"General look to your right!" As the Confederates fired, Sherman was hit in the hand by a piece of buckshot and his aide, next to him, Private Thomas D. Holliday, was hit and instantly killed. Sherman said, "The shot that killed him was meant for me". My God, we are attacked!" Sherman's Division was under attack from Gen. Patrick Clebune's Brigade, part of the first line of the Confederate attack, over 6,700 men under Gen. William Hardee. Sherman told Col. Appler, "Hold your position; I will support you". Sherman moved back to the area of Shiloh Chuch to organize a defense of the hill above Shiloh Branch. 

With Confederates coming into Rhea Field from the west and crossing to the south, Appler withdrew the 53rd Ohio to the wood line on the east side of the field and reformed facing the field. Gen. Patrick Cleburne led his brigade forward into the marshy ground along Shiloh Branch. As he urged his horse forward into the brush he was thrown off into the mud. His Brigade, hitting the same morass, split in two with two regiments the 6th Mississippi Infantry and 23rd Tennessee moving off to the east toward this Field. These two regiments would charge across the field across the road from you taking artillery fire on their left flank from Waterhouse's Batter

stops.significance: Starting point of the Battle of Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Reconnoitering Road .4 miles to Tour Stop #8 - Confederates Gain Ground
stops.audioTranscript:
Grant and his generals believed that the Southerners did not possess the resolve, nor the ability, to attack them in the open field. The Northern generals all missed the motivation behind the Confederate concentration at Corinth. They viewed the deployment as having been made for the defense of the important railroads only, when in reality the Confederates had gathered together their scattered western forces for the purpose of mounting a major counter-offensive. 

On the night of April 2, Albert Sidney Johnston received information that Buell, moving overland from Nashville with the Army of the Ohio was but a few days march from Savannah. On Beauregard's advice that "now is the time to go," Johnston determined to move at once, assemble his troops and attack Grant at Pittsburg Landing. The surprise attack was planned to begin on April 4th, but there were several unfortunate delays.

That evening, April 5, after three days of delays, Johnston's army lay deployed within striking distance of the forward Union camps at Shiloh Church. In a meeting of the Confederate generals, Beauregard, who had helped plan the attack, voiced concern that the element of surprise had been lost. General Hardee's troops, who had led the advance, had fought a number of skirmishes with Union pickets and cavalry for the last two days. Both Beauregard and General Braxton Bragg pointed out that the Confederate troops were out of rations and completely exhausted from the muddy marching conditions. Furthermore, Beauregard believed that the alerted Yankees were now entrenched to the eyes! He felt they should cancel the attack and return to Corinth. Johnston decided otherwise: "Gentlemen" he said to his staff: "We shall attack at daylight tomorrow. I would fight them if they were a million." Johnston's battle plan was to strike the Union left sweep through to Pittsburg Landing, denying Grant access to supplies and reinforcements, and trap the Union Army against the swampy ground along Snake and Owl Creeks. 

Fraley Field, where the first shots were fired, is a two-minute walk down the path to the west. The field to the north- east is known as Seay :field. 
By nightfall on April 5, Union soldiers in the forward camps had grown nervous and apprehensive. Many of the Federals reported having seen formations of enemy cavalry, or heard the sounds of drums and bugles, arid some claimed to have seen sunlight reflect off distant cannon barrels in the forest. The concerns of the Union pickets were passed up the line, but at division headquarters the warnings went unheeded. 

Alarmed by recent brushes with Confederate patrols, and by reports that strange sounds and movements could be heard in front of the picket lines, Union Colonel Everett Peabody, a Massachusetts graduate of Harvard and railroad construction engineer from Missouri, decided to act on his own judgment. Without advising his superior, General Benjamin Prentiss, of his action, the colonel ordered Maj. James Powell of the 25th Missouri Infantry, to take a patrol and reconnoiter forward of the army's pickets for potential enemy forces. Powell's small force of 250 men rolled out of their blankets at 3 a.m. Within the hour, the small patrol moved out and disappeared into the darkness, advancing southwest along an old wagon trace now called Reconnoitering Road. As the first streaks of dawn gathered on the eastern horizon, Powell's men discovered three Rebel horsemen on the Corinth Road. Warning shots rang out, as the mounted troopers fired on the advancing Federals at about 4:55 a.m. Powell deployed his anxious troops into a dispersed skirmish line and advanced westward towards the farm of J.C. Fraley. As they emerged frori1 the woods into Fraley :field, the Union troops encountered two Confederate picket posts and more scattered shots pierced the still morning air. On high ground to the west, across the old cotton :field, Powell's men saw shadowy forms scattered along a fence. Suddenly, the dark western horizon flashed yellow-bright with the blast of nearly 300 muskets as Confederate pickets from the 3rd Mississippi Battalion, under Maj. Aaron B. Hardcastle, fired into the Yankee patrol. Powell's men returned the fire. The battle of Shiloh had begun. The skirmish in Fraley field lasted about an hour with little change, except the steady exodus of wounded.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Reconnoitering Road to Tour Stop #9 - Invasion of the Union Camps
stops.audioTranscript:
Colonel Peabody, now aware of the situation, would send his entire brigade forward to bolster the defense. 

Along a low wooded ridge in front of you, overlooking a feeder branch of Shiloh Creek, only a quarter-mile south of his brigade camp, Peabody deployed his men. Joined there by Powell's retreating combat team and the 21st Missouri, the brigade line of battle rested to the right ( or west) of the Eastern Corinth road. Meanwhile, General Prentiss hastily formed his second brigade, commanded by Colonel Madison Miller, and advanced south into Peter Spain's field, located east of the Eastern Corinth road about 600 yards to your right or east. The 5,400 troops in Prentiss's division defended a line that extended 2/3 's of a mile from west to east. The green Union troops had only moments to spare.

Peabody's brigade made a determined resistance, driving back in confusion some of the advanced regiments, which General Johnston assisted in rallying. 

Peabody's outnumbered brigade would be outflanked and overwhelmed by superior numbers. The union forces fell back to their camps where Col. Peabody attempted to rally them. The Confederates continued advancing against them.

stops.assetName: Invasion of the Union Camps - Tour Stop #9
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow Peabody Road until it turns left and becomes the Eastern Corinth Road. Follow north through intersection of the Hamburg-Purdy Road to Tour Stop #10 - Hornets' Nest.
stops.audioTranscript:
Throughout the morning, Sunday, April 6, Union soldiers assigned to the division of General Prentiss and that of Brig. Gen. William T. Sherman, holding ground at Shiloh church, stubbornly contested a number of defensive lines in an effort to halt the Confederate tide of battle. Here within its camp, Prentiss's division made a brief second stand. By then, the green Union troops were heavily outnumbered by massed Confederate brigades and flanked by advancing columns of southern troops on both ends of the camp. 

Col. Peabody, already bleeding from four wounds, rode among the tents of his command attempting to rally his troops, shouting, "Stand to it Yet!" He was suddenly hit in the head by a musket ball and instantly killed, next to his headquaiiers tent. His brigade began to break up and fall back as the Confederate attack continued. The monument to your right with an upright cannon surrounded by four small pyramids of cannonballs is a mortuary monument. You will see other places on the battlefield 'marked with these monuments where brigade commanders or higher ranking generals were killed or mortally wounded. 

On Prentiss left flank about half a mile to the east, behind you, was Prentiss' other brigade commanded by Col. Madison Miller. Miller's green brigade was eating breakfast. The newly organized 61st Illinois was still in camp when a staff officer rushed over yelling,  "My God! This regiment's not in line yet! They have been fighting on the right for over an hour!" Col. Miller's Brigade would form in line and inflict heavy casualties on Gen. Adley Gladden's attacking Confederates, including Gladden who would be mortally wounded by exploding case shot from a Union artillery battery. The Union forces were soon outnumbered and outflanked by Gen. James Chalmers' Brigade.
 
At 9:00 a.m., Prentiss's front collapsed. The routed northern soldiers fled through their camp towards the Hamburg-Purdy road a half-mile to the north. Gen. Prentiss would manage to rally some of his men along a farm road, now known as the "Sunken Road", about a mile to the north. Many of the defeated troops would continue running though until they reached Pittsburg Landing where they formed a disorganized mob.

Many of the Confederate soldiers had eaten their rations several clays before and were now hungry after their difficult march from Corinth. As they overran the Union camps they found fresh food and other items of interest in the abandoned camps.

Confederates were leaving the ranks to loot the captured camps helping themselves to Union supplies and often straggling and becoming separated from their units.
 
Gen. Johnston riding forward on Fire Eater behind the victorious Confederates entered the camp of the 18th Wisconsin which had just been captured. When he saw an officer coming out of a Union tent with valuables he rebuked him, "None of that, sir; we are not here for plunder!" Seeing the shame of his subordinate, Johnston leaned from his horse and picked up a tin cup in the camp, stating, "Let this be my share of the spoils to-clay." He then ordered the men to keep advancing toward the battle. Seeing wounded enemy soldiers in the same camp, Johnston instructed his personal physician, Dr. D. W. Yandell to give them medical assistance. "These men were our enemies a moment ago, they are prisoners now; take care of them." 

Scouting reports gathered by the Confederates before the battle had indicated to Gen. Johnston that Prentiss' Division was the left flank of the Union Army and that Shiloh Church was a mile closer to the landing than it was. Gen. Sherman's Division was still fighting the attacking Confederates near Shiloh Church and another line of camps, McClernand's Division, could be seen beyond them. Under the impression that he had turned the Union left, and unaware that there were still two Union divisions between him and the landing, Gen. Johnston committed the bulk of the army to driving northwest against the remaining Union opposition. Victory appeared at hand if the Confederates could push the remaining Union forces toward Owl Creek with ten of the sixteen Confederate infantry brigades.

As you look down the road just past the Arkansas Monument you will see a heavily wooded area to your left. This is one part of the battlefield which was thicker in 1862 than it is today. This was an area of second growth with brush, briars, and vines making it almost impassible which would become known as the Hornet's Nest. 

By 9 AM, Gen Prentiss had managed to rally some of his troops a short distance to your left on a farm road which became known as the "sunken road". With fragments of the regiments that had fought earlier in the day, two artillery batteries and the newly arrived 23rd Missouri, Prentiss had approximately 1,100 men.

stops.significance: One of the most iconic sites of the American Civil War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue north and turn right at stop sign. Follow the Corinth Road past Confederate Memorial and take first left on Jones Field Road. Tour Stop #11 will be on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
As you look down the road just past the Arkansas Monument you will see a heavily wooded area. This is one part of the battlefield which was thicker in 1862 than it is today. This was an area of second growth with brush, briars, and vines making it almost impassible which would become known as the Hornet's Nest. By 9 AM, Gen. Prentiss had managed to rally some of his troops a short distance to your left on a farm road which became known as the "sunken road". With fragments of the regiments that had fought earlier in the day, two artillery batteries and the newly arrived 23rd Missouri, Prentiss had approximately 1,100 men. Prentiss' soldiers had seen the elephant and were shaky, according to one officer from the 44th Indiana they "acted like a flock of frightened sheep, ready to start in any direction." 

By 10 a.m., parts of two Union brigades commanded by General William Wallace joined Prentiss to form a strong line of defense, facing west-southwest, along this old wagon road. Just to the east two Indiana Regiments from Gen. Stephen Hurlbut's Division would help hold the line until 2 PM. This made over 8,000 Union troops available in this area to hold the Union center. For the next six hours, while the bulk of the Confederate army engaged either the right or left flank of Grant's army, a succession of piecemeal brigade sized attacks were hurled through the dense oak thicket south of this area against the Federals. Legend states there were a total of eleven Southern assaults repulsed on this line. Actually, historical accounts document seven to nine failed Confederate charges. In no instance during these assaults through the thicket did the attacking Confederate force number more than 3,500 men, while the opposing Union force numbered 6,200 men and 27 cannon, with an additional 2,500 infantry held in reserve. 

Advised by General Grant to hold this position at all hazards, the troops under Wallace, Prentiss, and Hurlbut stubbornly defended the center with a shower of musketry and cannon fire. By noon, few of the attacking Confederate troops had managed to advance any closer than 100 yards of the Union front. In each assault, the attacking rebel force was driven to ground inside the dense thicket along the Eastern Corinth Road, and ultimately forced to retire, with heavy loss, to seek shelter somewhere beyond musket range. 

On the Confederate left, the corps commanders tried to organize the confused situation. When General Polk asked Gen. Bragg where he should have his command. "He replied 'If you will take care of the center, I will go to the right.' It was understood that General Hardee was attending to the left." As Bragg moved to the area just to the south of here he observed Col. Randall Gibson's Brigade.

At noon General Braxton Bragg assumed command here, and immediately ordered Colonel Randall Lee Gibson's Louisiana and Arkansas brigade to attack the thicket. As they advanced into an almost impenetrable thicket, the 2,400-man brigade was "raked by battery fire and steady thunderous volleys of musketry," which exploded across their front to consume the forest, ripping trees and underbrush to pieces. The whizzing sounds of the minie balls and shrapnel reminded the Confederate troops of a swarm of hornets and thus this area would ever after be known as the "Hornets' Nest". 

Col. Henry Allen commanding the 4th Louisiana described the attack: "At the command to advance we charged up the hill into an almost impenetrable thicket. The enemy opened a deadly fire, which was quickly returned." "The regiment retired, formed again and again charged. Here fell many of my bravest and best men in the thick brushwood without ever seeing the enemy." 

General Bragg was upset when Gibson's men again retreated. Bragg probably did not fully understand the great difficulties his men faced in the thicket. Confronting General Bragg on the field, Col. Henry Watkins Allen of the 4th Louisiana Infantry, recently shot through the mouth during the previous charge, pleaded that they lacked the manpower to storm the position from the front and recommended they flank the thicket. Bragg desired the offensive to keep moving and he scolded the wounded colonel, stating, "I want no faltering now." Holding the regimental colors aloft, Allen painfully called out to his volunteers, "Here boys is as good a place as any on this battlefield to meet death!" For a third time, the bloodied Confederate brigade charged into the face of almost certain death. 

The artillery played a key role in repulsing the Confederate attacks. Capt. Andrew Hickenlooper's Ohio Battery fired rounds of canister into the attacking infantry inflicted heavy casualties on the Confederates. 

By 4:00 PM the Union forces had repulsed a series of piecemeal attacks, but the withdrawal of Hurlbut on their left and Sherman on their right allowed over 20,000 Confederates to surround the Union center. Prentiss would soon surrender, and Wallace would be mortally wounded.

stops.significance: Final resting place of Confederate soldiers killed at the battle of Shiloh.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on tour road west to Tour Stop #12 - Jones Field.
stops.audioTranscript:
One of five known Confederate burial trenches marked and preserved on the battlefield. Following the bloody Battle of Shiloh, General Grant, fearing the outbreak of disease, ordered all Union and Confederate dead buried as quickly as possible. For the same reason he also ordered all the dead mules and horses to be burned. Union and Confederate troops were buried separately, with the Confederates' placed in up to nine trenches according to the Shiloh Commission's report of 1903. Unfortunately, the cyclone of 1909 destroyed many records, and the location of four of the trenches are now known but to God.

In 1917, the United Daughters of the Confederacy unveiled the Confederate Memorial at Tour Stop #2. With money left over from the project, the Daughters' erected a small memorial at the largest burial trench between Tour Stops # 13 and # 14. In 1935, the Tennessee chapter of the UDC placed similar monuments at the other four trenches like the one you see here.

stops.significance: Iconic 2nd Day area at Shiloh National Military Park
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on tour route to Tour Stop #13 - Woolf Field
stops.audioTranscript:
GRANT STRIKES BACK-APRIL 7, 1862 

Gen. Lew Wallace had arrived with his Division to reinforce Grant after dark on April 6th but had no contact with the General until the morning of the 7th when Grant arrived and pointed out the intended direction of attack. Wallace' s attack across Tilghman Branch Ravine was opposed by Col. Preston Pond's Brigade on the north end of the field, you are looking at, and supported by the 6 guns of Ketchum's Alabama Artillery Battery. Pond's was the only Confederate infantry unit that failed to get Beauregard's order to withdraw the previous evening and stayed in close contact with the enemy. 

Thomas W. Durham of the 11th Indiana Infantry had been ordered to take command of the right wing of the skirmish line as they advanced across the ravine under fire. Gen. Wallace rode along the line asking, him: 

"How are you feeling this morning Tom?" He responded, "I feel like I want to see my mother." Wallace said, "That is right, go in and remember the old folks at home." "As they advanced they came under fire from the enemy battery with shells bursting and tearing up the ground around them. Durham was watching their battery to get a chance for the skirmishers to jump over the fence and get into the ravine...He saw the chance to vault over but as he did a shell fragment hit him on the right hip ad lodged against the bone .... He started crawling back toward the regiment and some of the men saw him and carried him back to the surgeon." Durham would survive, the surgeon telling him he was too game to die. 

Wallace's three brigades would advance across the ravine and outflank Pond's Brigade which was forced to withdraw before they could get any support. Wallace's Division would take a position in the north end of the field, expecting the rest of Grant's Army to come in from the east. 

At the same time, Confederate forces were rushed forward from the Shiloh Church area by Braxton Bragg and thrown into a line on the south side of the field along the wood line in front of you. Gen. Ruggles ordered Col. Randall Gibson's and Gen. S.A.M. Wood's Brigades to counterattack Wallace's line. They advanced diagonally across this field placing most of them perpendicular to the Federal line of fire. The poorly coordinated attack crumbled under the withering fire and fell back. Col. William K. Patterson of the 8th Arkansas described it as "a destructive enfilading fire...under which many of our men fell horribly mangled."

Finally at about 10 AM Sherman and McClernand's men started to arrive after crossing Tilghman Branch. Wallace advanced with the newly arrived force to form a line facing south about half-way across the field. This line is marked by the closest line of tablets to the north in Jones Field. The Confederates fought desperately to hold back the Federal threat but by 11 :00 AM Wallace's Division made a left wheel extending Grant's line by half a mile to the west where the picnic area is today. This completely outflanked the Confederate line which was forced to withdraw south in the direction of Shiloh Church. As the Confederates withdrew  Wallace's Division continued to advance in the direction of the Hamburg-Purdy Road but would stop in line on a ridge when their left flank seemed threatened.

stops.significance: Important action takes place here during the Battle of Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on tour road a short distance to Tour Stop #14 - Water Oaks Pond.
stops.audioTranscript:
By noon on April 6, the Confederate offensive in this sector of the battlefield began to stall. Although achieving early success against Sherman and McClernand's Divisions, by noon, several Confederate units were physically exhausted having been in combat since dawn. Commands became comingled and suffered a high attrition of line officers: Some units were pillaging the newly captured Union camps, and others stopped to be resupplied with ammunition. 

This pause gave Union forces here an opportunity to counter-attack. Sherman had recently reunited with McDowell's lost brigade and McClernand was reinforced by the addition of the 15th and 16th Iowa Infantry Regiments. With Sherman on the left, and McClernand on the right, they counter-attacked from Jones Field into Woolf Field. The advance was rapid, and the Confederates were driven back about½ a mile with severe losses. 

Although stunned, General PGT Beauregard countered by throwing his last reserve brigade, Trabue' s fresh Kentuckians and Tennesseans forward, joined by elements of Generals Hardee' s and Polk's Corps. By 2:00 pm, the Confederates regained the upper hand forcing Sherman and McClemand to fall back though Jones Field and across the rugged Tilghman Branch which formed a natural defensive position. 

A lack of ammunition caused another lull in the Confederate push. By the time of Confederates were resupplied, the roar of fighting to their right caused a shift in deployment of the Confederate line in that direction. One last assault on the Federals east of Jones Field occurred around 4:.00 pm, as Preston Pond's Louisiana Brigade and Wharton's Texas Cavalry led an assault that was soundly defeated by the larger Federal force.

stops.significance: Important action takes place here dung the Battle of Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Stay straight on tour road and follow signage taking a left at the four-way intersection. Follow the Hamburg-Purdy Road through the Eastern-Corinth intersection to Tour Stop #15 - Daniel Davis Wheat Field.
stops.audioTranscript:
By about noon on April 7, Gen. Lew Wallace just to the west of this position was desperate. "Scarcely had the front been changed when the supporting force on the left again gave way, closely followed by masses of the enemy. My position was critical, as isolation from the rest of the army seemed imminent." Rousseau's Brigade which had arrived at the edge of Woolf Field, on the wood line behind you, was out of ammunition. A gap had developed between McCook and Crittenden and the Confederates appeared to be massing troops to turn McCook's right flank. 

Wallace's concerns were soon relieved by the arrival of the all-German 32nd Indiana Infantry which had moved ahead of its brigade. "Fortunately, before the enemy could avail themselves of their advantage some fresh troops clashed against them, and drove them back. This was due to Col. August Willich and his famous German regiment." Sherman who had just arrived witnessed the attack and said "Then arose the severest musketry fire I ever heard which lasted some twenty minutes, when this splendid regiment had to fall back." The attack gave time for Col. Edward Kirks Brigade from McCook's Division to deploy in line in this field where they soon came under fire from Confederate artillery near the crossroads. The 34th Illinois on the left were exposed to heavy fire and When their commander Major Charles Leavanway was killed by a round of canister in the throat, they might have panicked but Col. Kirk rallied them with the only unwounded member of the color guard. 

The Confederates holding the crossroads were Rutledge's Tennessee Battery and Gen. S.AM. Wood's Brigade around which other Confederate units gathered. When the Confederate attacks faltered Major John Kelly of the 9th Arkansas battalion dashed through Water Oaks Pond, to your left, on his horse to rally them. The regiment to the left of Gen. Wood had fallen back, and he went over to steady them, but their colonel said his men were worn-out and could not be rallied. With the arrival of fresh union units across the field, and lacking support, Wood was forced to withdraw from the Crossroads. Beauregard at Shiloh Church was now in danger of losing the battle and would personally take charge of attacks to regain the lost grotmd. Before you move on to the last stop at Shiloh Church you may want to examine the Te1messee Monument which was placed here in 2005. Tennessee regiments fought throughout the battlefield with 12,000 men in the Confederate Army, but a large number were present in the fighting near Woolf Field.

stops.significance: Important location of second day fighting at Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue east on the Hamburg-Purdy Road to Tour Stop #16, Field Hospital Site.
stops.audioTranscript:
April 7, 1862 

A very disorganized Confederate Army awoke this morning to the sound of heavy skirmishing. Southern soldiers across this battlefield, were shocked by the booming of the guns, and the rush of their own pickets streaming back under fire. The unexpected appearance of so many Federals confused the Confederates. Southern soldiers that were still recovering from the first day's fight were rushed into line. 
Ragtag defensive lines were fonned by officers utilizing any and every individual or unit that could shoulder a musket. General Braxton Bragg complained: "Our force was disorganized, demoralized, and exhausted ... they were mostly out of ammunition, and though millions of cartridges were around them, not one officer in ten supplied their men." 

By 10:00 am, Confederate leaders had assembled a comingled and disjointed 3-mile front. Sgt. Robert D. Smith of Bate's 2nd Tennessee Infantry remembered that: "staff officers rode among the camps seizing all detached units and individual soldiers." Many southern field officers and their men had little to no idea who they were serving with or where they were fighting on this day. 
In the Davis Wheat Field, Union Colonel William B. Hazen's three regiments pushed forward driving Confederate pickets from the woods. Hazen' s units overran the Confederate guns here of the 5th company of Louisiana's famed Washington Light Artillery. In the fight for one of the guns, Union Colonel Walter Whitaker, of the 6th Kentucky Infantry, cut down a cannoneer with a Bowie Knife he had taken from a Texas soldier. 

However, these Union regiments had advanced beyond their support and were pushed back by the Crescent Regiment which saved the guns. The Confederates in this sector would hold on until 3:00 pm when General Hardee ordered the retreat. These Confederate units would help form the rear guard of the Confederate army as it withdrew.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed along the tour route .3 miles to General Johnston's death site, Tour Stop #17.
stops.audioTranscript:
Here, after the battle ended on the evening of April 7, an innovative Federal surgeon established one of the :first consolidated tent hospitals of the Civil War. Throughout the battle attempts were made by surgeons to provide medical assistance for the over 16,400 men wounded. Numerous operating stations were hastily thrown up by surgeons on both sides. On the first day of battle, April 6, many of the operating stations established by Union surgeons were repeatedly forced to move, as Grant's troops were forced to grudgingly give ground, fighting from a number of successive lines. 

The field hospital established here, on Monday afternoon, April 7, as the Confederate army withdrew, was erected under the direction of Capt. Bernard J.D. Irwin, an Assistant Surgeon who served with Buell's Army of the Ohio. Dr. Irwin opened up his operating station, a large farmhouse that sat on this site. He ordered tents moved from nearby Federal camps and set up around the house. The next day he stripped neighboring Union camps of bedding, cooking utensils, medical supplies, and more tents to enlarge the hospital to 300 beds. Inside the house, Irwin set up an operating room dispensary, office, kitchen, and medical officers' dining room. More medical supplies reached him form Savam1ah, Tem1essee that evening. By nightfall all patients, Union and Confederate, were treated, fed and bedded. Experience gained at Shiloh demonstrated that the patients in this improvised tent hospital fared better than the wounded hastily loaded aboard steamboats at Pittsburg Landing. From such pioneering efforts the present ­day concept of mobile army field hospitals was later developed.

stops.significance: Area where the highest ranking American officer was killed in battle.
stops.assetName: Death of Albert Sidney Johnston - Tour Stop #17
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn right onto tour road and proceed .2 miles to the Peach Orchard on your left, Tour Stop #18.
stops.audioTranscript:
For five bitterly contested hours 'on April 6, from 10:00 am until 3 :00 pm, the majority of Johnston's Confederate brigades, under the immediate supervision of Generals Beauregard, Hardee, and Leonidas Polk, maintained a continuous assault on Grant's stubborn right flank north of Shiloh Church. During the same period, Albert Sidney Johnston, accompanied by Brig. Gen. John C. Breckinridge, directed one-third of his army eastward from Prentiss's captured camp to engage what Johnston apparently believed to be the exposed rear of the Union army, but in actuality proved to be the left of Grant's line under Gen. Hurlbut. The 9th Illinois took a position in the ravine in front of you which acted as a natural trench where they could duck clown to reload then stand up to fire at the enemy. Here astride the Hamburg­-Savannah road, the two opposing forces grappled for several hours into the early afternoon. Repeatedly, Southern troops pressed forward, only to be driven back by murderous Union musketry and cannon fire. 

Gen. Breckenridge, commander of the Confederate Reserve Corp, was having problems getting his troops to move forward through the field in front of the Union line. The 45th Tennessee, a green unit had stopped at the mule lot of widow Sarah Bell's farm and had become disorganized. In frustration, Breckenridge reported to Johnston that he had "a Tennessee regiment that won't fight". The Confederate Governor Tennessee Isham Harris, who was accompanying Johnston as an aide, went to attempt to rally the troops from his state. The Confederate attack had stalled and Breckenridge expressed farther frustration at his unit's failure. Anxious to continue the advance, Johnston replied "Then I will help you, we can get them to make the charge." Just prior to 2 p.m., Johnston rode forward to encourage his troops to mount another bayonet charge against the Union force blocking advance up the River Road. The Union front lay to the north and occupied a position that ran parallel with the southern edge of the Peach Orchard along the low rise you see marked by monuments across the field. Passing along the front, Johnston reached the 9th Arkansas of Bowen's Brigade and called out, "Soldiers, get ready! Soldiers of the 9th Arkansas Regiment are you ready to drive the invaders of the country from our soil?" As he rode along the line he touched their fixed bayonets with the tin cup he had picked up in a Union camp earlier in the clay and said, "Men they are stubborn; we must use the bayonet." He turned and said, "I will lead you." 

Under Johnston's supervision, six Confederate brigades comprising a line of battle nearly a mile in width, pressed northward astride the road. This strong advance drove back the opposing Union line and permitted Southern troops to establish a new line of battle along the south edge of the peach orchard. 

The charge Johnston had led was successful but there was still firing on the left and Governor Harris assisted Col. W. S. Statham in getting Tennessee units to charge in that direction leaving Johnston behind with Capt. W.L. Wickham. 

On his return to this location, the governor noticed that something was extremely wrong with the Southern commander, who appeared flushed and faint. Suddenly, Johnston "reeled in the saddle," and Harris grasped the general's shoulders to keep him from falling. Asked by Harris if he was wounded, Johnston, in a deliberate tone, replied, "Yes, and I fear seriously." 

Johnston, now unconscious, was taken to the ravine just down the trail south of this monument. Hidden from plain view, the general had been hit behind the right knee with a  .58 cal. Minnie Ball which torn the popliteal artery. The extreme loss of blood had not been observed earlier, because it either collected internally or in Johnston's high boot, which reached to his knee. The Confederate commander apparently had been wounded for several minutes before Harris saw him reel in the saddle. 

Shortly before 2:45, Albert Sidney Johnston died from an acute loss of blood. Ranked second only to Inspector General Samuel Cooper among the top general officers in the Confederate Army, Johnston would be the highest-ranking officer of either army killed in action during the Civil War. A tragic irony was that in his coat pocket was found a field tourniquet, which might have saved his life if used quickly and properly. Johnston's body was secretly escorted by his staff to Shiloh Church, while messengers carried word to Beauregard that he now commanded the Southern Army. 

Before driving to the next stop you may want to take the short walk down to the ravine where Johnston died. His body would be removed to Corinth and then interred in New Orleans. After the war he would be reinterred in Austin, Texas. Although born in Kentucky, Johnston had adopted Texas as his native state and resigned from the U.S. Army to join the Confederacy when Texas seceded.

stops.significance: Iconic site from the Battle of Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn left out of parking area onto tour road. A short distance on your left is the Bloody Pond, Tour Stop #19.
stops.audioTranscript:
As you look toward the previous stop, you are looking across the Peach Orchard and the site of Sarah Bell's farm. The battlefield was the home to a number of farm families many of whom had fled when it became clear that a battle was about to start. As they fled they left behind their farms and livestock which suffered damage or destruction as the fighting swirled around their homesteads. During the fighting Sarah Bell's herd of goats came between the two lines of battle and were wiped out. The cabin you see as you look to your right belonged to Sarah Bell's son­-in-law, William Manse George. During the battle the cabin was destroyed but, George moved an undamaged cabin from another part of the battlefield to take its place. The cabin you see is the sole surviving structure from the Battle of Shiloh and is a reminder of the losses suffered by those who came into the path of conflict during the Civil War.

Here astride the Hamburg-Savannah road, also called the River road, the left flank of Grant's army found a good position to make a stand. From 9 a.m. until 2 p.m., this front defended by Federal troops commanded by Brig. Gen. Stephen Hurlbut, supported by brigades under Brig. Gen. John McArthur and Col. David Stuart, was the scene of intense fighting. The Union line of battle marked by monuments and tablets on the south side of the Peach Orchard, extended from ridges and ravines three-quarters mile to the east, to the dense oak thicket of the Hornets' Nest position located one-quarter mile to the west-northwest. Located beyond the wood-line to the north behind you is the famous sunken road, at the time of the battle this wagon trace cut through the forest to link the River Road with the Corinth Road, located a half-mile to the northwest. Just 
beyond that road is the Bloody Pond, Tour Stop 19. 

Filing into line to the left of the River Road two regiments from McArthur' s brigade, the 9th and the 12th, or Highland Guard, along with the 50th Illinois from Col. Thomas Sweeney's Brigade extended the line in the direction of Stuart's isolated regiments. As Stuart's men fell back around 2 p.m. these units come under flank attack by Confederate forces. The 50th Illinois under Col. Moses Bane became confused as forces across the ravine approached. The flag they saw looked similar to the U.S. flag and it was not until this Confederate force fired into their flank that they realized it was the Confederate First National Flag, or Stars and Bars. Col. Bane was wounded and the unit fell back in turn exposing the flanks of the 12th Illinois and then the 9th Illinois in the ravine just this side of the Johnston Monument. 

What had been a refuge for soldiers of the 9th Illinois became a trap as Confederates struck them from the front and flank from the neck of the ravine. 

Although the Federal line fell back, Gen. Hurlbut and his staff were able to rally the men and form another line just north of the Bloody Pond. They would hold there until 4 PM when that line was also outflanked by Confederate Infantry. An attempt to rally the men another time near Hurlbut's Headquarters would prove unsuccessful and they would fall back to Grant's last line near Pittsburg Landing.

stops.significance: Iconic location on the Shiloh battlefield
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue north on the Hamburg-Savannah Road for approximately .5 miles. After passing the Alabama Monument take your first right on Brown's Landing Road. This road will take you through the ancient Indian Mound Village and to Tour Stop #20 - Dill Branch Ravine.
stops.audioTranscript:
The legend of the Bloody Pond holds that dozens if not hundreds of wounded and dying men, came here to drink and wash their wounds, turning the small pond red with blood. Although the Bloody Pond receives a great amount of attention to this day in the annals of the Battle of Shiloh, no evidence of this story comes from contemporary sources. However, it is true that several soldiers wrote of the staggering amount of blood that covered this battlefield after the fighting was over. 

The carnage witnessed at Shiloh was unprecedented in the history of the Western Hemisphere up to that time. And as with all Civil War battlefields, wounded soldiers often migrated to water sources for a drink. One Federal officer reported that after the Battle of Shiloh he “found a Rebel soldier, one of the 18th Louisiana laid full length, spread out and arms downward in the water,” in the spring his regiment had used before the battle.

stops.significance: Important site during the Battle of Shiloh
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the tour road for .2 miles. Tour Stop #21 is on your right.
stops.audioTranscript: Here, you will see cannon marking Union artillery positions, which would be firing into the right flank of the advancing Confederates. This is the begim1ing of Grant's Last Line. The ravine and artillery presented a considerable obstacle to a continued Confederate advance but several Confederate generals including Bragg urged them to push on. He felt there "was every prospect of success."

stops.significance: The left flank of the Union army on the evening of April 6.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the tour road for .3 miles. Tour Stop #22 is on your right.

stops.significance: Shiloh National Cemetery and the Tennessee River
stops.directionsToNextStop: End of battlefield auto tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
The National Cemetery, seen to the north, was established in 1866, one year after the end of the Civil War. Over 3,500 United States soldiers who served in the Civil War are interred here; two ­thirds of them are classified as unknown. The large monument - three cannon barrels pointing upward - marks the battlefield headquarters of General Ulysses S. Grant, the Union Army commander on the evening of April 6th. 

Many people wonder why a major battle was fought here, seemingly miles from anywhere. For the answer to that you need to look no further than the river before you. With the capture of Fort Hemy, north of here, the Tennessee River provided a swift invasion route for Union forces into the Confederate heartland. By the beginning of April 1862, a strong Union army commanded by General Ulysses S. Grant had disembarked here, and at Crump's Landing, six miles down-river to the north, in preparation for an attack against the strategic railroad junction at Corinth, Mississippi, only 22 miles to the southwest. 

However, a Confederate army under the command of General Albert Sidney Johnston, struck first, delive1ing a surprise attack on Pittsburg Landing, where the bulk of General Grant's Federal troops lay encamped around a log church called Shiloh Meeting House. Named for the church, Shiloh exploded into one of the most decisive and vicious battles of the Civil War, and proved to be the deadliest combat Americans had experienced up to that time. Nearly 24,000 men were killed, wounded, or reported missing in two terrible days of fighting. 

Ulysses. S. Grant later stated that Shiloh was the severest battle fought in the West during the war, and that few in the East equaled it for hard, determined fighting.

stops.significance: End of the Shiloh Battlefield tour
stops.audioTranscript:
The battle of Shiloh mutilated the western army of the Confederacy. The awful carnage deprived the South of ten thousand six hundred and ninety-nine men killed, wounded, and missing. Albert Sidney Johnston, Adley Gladden, and a host of subordinate officers would never fight again. Tennessee, with its vast reservoir of manpower and critical war resources, was virtually lost; a strengthened Union advance against Corinth, Mississippi, would only be a matter of time; and the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, the primary east-west line of communication and supply  with the Mississippi Valley, remained imperiled. Strategically and tactically, Shiloh must be regarded as a Union victory. Although the battle temporarily crippled Grant's army, supplied many of the Southern troops with new firearms, and revealed the merits and demerits of many western Confederate commanders, the vital objective of Albert Sidney Johnston's momentous western counterattack --- the destruction of Grant's army-was not realized.

Perhaps the greatest impact of Shiloh was how the divided nation came to view the war. For the first time since April 186L citizens on both sides opened their eyes to the magnitude of the terrible conflict. There were more casualties here in two days, 23,746, than in the Revolutionary War, the War of 1812, and the Mexican War combined. After Shiloh, the brutal realities of civil war began to be felt in every community, every home, and every family. Before the battle, Grant had believed that the Confederates in the West could be finished off in one last great combat. Now he "gave up all idea of saving the Union except by complete conquest." The bitter legacy cast from the savage carnage that was Shiloh---would be that the war became an increasingly bloodier conflict.an immense ideological struggle that steadily consumed the irreplaceable resources of a divided people for three more years.
 
As the Union soldiers moved back into their camps it became their task to clean up the debris of battle and deal with the dead and wounded from both sides. 

John Bell of the 2nd Iowa Infantry said "In places dead men lay so closely that a person could walk over two acres of ground and not step off the bodies."

data.title: Shiloh Indian Mounds Interpretive Trail
data.description: The Shiloh Indian Mounds Trail is a 1.3-mile loop with thirteen wayside interpretive exhibits. This tour features seven tour stops. The hike is easy to moderate with slight elevation changes. Learn about this prehistoric village that was inhabited between 1050 and 1400 A.D.

data.title: Slatersville: America's First Planned Mill Village
data.description: Welcome to Slatersville, one of six sites that make up Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park. At first glance, Slatersville looks like a classic New England small town, but in reality, Slatersville is America's first planned mill village. Its true heart is the massive stone mill. Join us as we explore this rich cultural landscape and uncover the story of America's first planned industrial community.

park.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
park.name: Blackstone River Valley

stops.significance: The river and it's drop of 40 feet in 1 mile at this location provided the ideal location for water-powered mills. Eventually the water-power available at this site powered the three textile mills.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back up the path which lead to the top of the hill. Once in the parking lot, turn right and walk towards the North Smithfield Public Library. Stand on the sidewalk in front of the library and look at the large brick buildings on the opposite side of the road.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Slatersville, Rhode Island, one of six sites that make up Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park.  

What makes this place special? At first glance, Slatersville looks like a classic small town in New England. But Slatersville is more than a quaint village. Slatersville was once a blueprint for industrial America.  

To understand Slatersville’s evolution, we must start with water. You are now standing along the banks of the Branch River. The Branch River is a tributary of the Blackstone River, meaning it flows into the Blackstone. At the point where you are now standing, the river drops 40 feet in just a mile. That is a tremendous drop, and it makes this place ideal for building a water-powered mill.  

In fact, it was this drop, and the potential power it provided, that attracted industrialist John Slater to this site. John, the younger brother of his more famous brother Samuel, convinced his brother, and other business partners to purchase 1,200 acres of land and the rights to the water. 

As you look at the river, you may notice two distinct waterfalls. These are not natural waterfalls but human-made dams. The dam off in the distance is the middle dam. The middle dam and its twenty-foot drop create a reservoir of water, known as a mill pond. This mill pond is over 170 acres in size. A mill pond is intended to provide a water-powered mill with an ample source of water that could power, at first, wooden waterwheels, and eventually mechanical turbines.  

Although it might not be evident today, this human manipulation of the river stored enough water to eventually power 3 large textile mills on this site. One of those mills, the Western Mill, once stood on the hillside behind. We will see one of the two remaining structures from this complex at one of our next stops.

stops.significance: The company store became an important part of a mill village. Here worker's were provided with all the necessities of life, but could pay off debts against their paychecks. This indebted many mill employees to their employers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From where you are standing, turn around and look at the older stone construction that makes up part of the North Smithfield Public Library.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Slaters finished construction of their first mill in 1807. They succeeded in building the largest textile mill in the country at the time. But they soon faced a big problem: their new mill was essentially isolated. There was very little infrastructure around them, and there was only small cluster of buildings nearby. This meant that the Slaters and their partners needed to hire people to build everything that their newly arrived workers would need. This included a store where workers could purchase goods.  

By 1850, a larger store was needed and the brick building you see on the right was constructed. A second commercial building was added by 1870 (the one on the left). These structures housed the company store, a bank, barber shop, hardware store, and eventually a dance and movie hall. 

The company store became an important part of a mill village. This was where employees went to purchase everything from dry goods to foodstuffs. Often, only company script could be used in the store and workers could pay off their debts against their paychecks. This indebted many workers to their employers through the guise of the company store.

stops.significance: This is one of the only remaining structures that was once part of the Western Mill Complex.
stops.assetName: The Western Mill and Slatersville Library
stops.directionsToNextStop: If facing the library, turn left and walk down the sidewalk towards the mill complex off in the distance. Cross the street at a crosswalk or safe crossing point. Walk onto the grassy area in front of the buildings. You should be able to see a wooden structure to your right, two stone mills in front of you, and a large brick mill.
stops.audioTranscript: Elements of this structure are part of what little remains of the once large Western Mill complex. In 1821, the Slaters constructed an additional eight buildings in town. The Western Mills complex, as it was known, doubled the company’s capacity. During the mid-to-late 1800s, the complex expanded to include additional buildings. In each one, workers completed some part of the textile production process. However, much of the Western Mill Complex was condemned and demolished in the early 20th century. Only two of the buildings remain today. The former storehouse, which you see in front of you, became part of the North Smithfield Public Library in 1966. Some traces of the past are still with us, such as the rubble-stone construction you see here. This offers a window into what this complex once looked like.

stops.significance: This area made up the heart of Slatersville's industrial core. Three mills still stand as a testament to the growth and development of the operations here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back in the direction of the road. Turn right and walk up the sidewalk, up the hill. Follow the road up and to the right. When you arrive at the crosswalk, cross the street. Once you arrive on the opposite side of the street, turn right and walk down the sidewalk. Stop when you arrive in front of the large white building (the Congregational Church).
stops.audioTranscript:
The original Slatersville Mill, built in 1807, burned down in 1826 and was replaced by the large stone mill in front of you. Known as the Center Mill or Mill number 1, this four-story building features a beautiful 5 story belltower. The belltower became an iconic feature in mill construction. It was the mill’s belltower that dictated daily life to the village’s inhabitants. A Providence-based poet writing in the 1830s critiqued this system: “Hark! Don’t you hear the factory bell? Of Wit and Learning ‘tis the knell. It rings them out it tolls them in. Where men they weave and girls they spin.” 

By 1833, Slaterville Mills had 9,500 spindles and 225 looms in action. 66 men, 109 women, and 169 children operated these machines, either making thread or weaving that thread into cloth. The work was tedious and repetitive. While not as physically demanding as some other jobs, without safety regulations, conditions were often dangerous. Laborers were also expected to do this work 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. All 344 worker’s wages combined totaled $57,000 annually. That’s only a little higher than the average annual wage earned by a single person in the United States today. 

In 1843, a third mill was added in Slatersville. This mill still stands behind the 1826 mill. At its peak of water-powered operations, three mills were all powered by this section of the Branch River. In 1894, the large brick mill was constructed, and steam powered operations commenced at the site. The wooden building to your right, the last remaining structure from the original 1807 mill, served as the office building for the company.  

In 2007, this place that had once been for labor became a place of rest. The mills were converted to a new life as an apartment complex. The restored mill remains the center and heart of the village.

stops.significance: The Church was another important element of a mill village. The mill church provided employees with the one of the only places to socially gather outside of the mill, but also reinforced the values and mores mill owners wanted from their employees.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If you’re looking at the Congregational Church, turn left and walk to the end of the green. Look across the street at the houses which line the street.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Slatersville church common has long served as an important social center for the village. The common, laid out by the Slaters in 1838, also adds to the traditional New England essence of Slatersville. The Slater family built this Greek Revival church in 1838. The first church, built in 1808, is now a private residence located behind this structure. 

The company church became an important part of a mill village. It was constructed to meet both the social and spiritual needs of the company’s employees. Church festivals, organizations, and prayer groups offered church members with a sense of community. This was one of the only places, outside of the mill, where workers could gather. It was also a place management and workers congregated together.  

Even though the Slaters were raised in the Church of England, they decided to open a Congregationalist Church because most of their workers were Congregationalists. Their main concern was that workers were attending services. Preachers, selected and paid by mill owners, were sure to focus on the less radical teachings of Christianity. They preached on ideas of obedience to authority, timeliness, and thrift. The very ideals mill owners wanted to reinforce in their workers. Often the pulpit became a mouthpiece for the mill’s ownership – another example of how owners sought to manipulate and control their workers.

stops.significance: Slatersville worker housing is a great example of the living conditions of employees here in Slatersville. Here entire families lived in the place where they also labored. This family-based system came to be known as the Rhode Island System of Manufacture.
stops.directionsToNextStop: If facing the worker’s houses, turn around walk across the green, past the Congregationalist Church and up to the road. Turn left and walk down the road until you see the blue home next to the church.
stops.audioTranscript:
Would you want to live where you work? These are some of the earliest worker houses built here in Slatersville around 1810. Originally, these were very plain, multi-family worker homes. Four families inhabited each house: two families on the first floor and two families on second floor and attic space. On average, one of these Slatersville homes would have housed between 20 to 45 occupants. This would have made for cramped living conditions.  

Although family units shared a house, each family had their own living space. For the most part, everyone in these homes worked for the Slaters. This system, known as the Rhode Island System of Manufacture, or the Slater System, used the entire family for employment in the mills. Fathers often worked on the company owned farm or as mechanics fixing the machines, while mothers and children worked in the mill. About 88% of the laborers in Slater-owned mills came from families employed by the company and living in company houses. 

Children were the driving force behind this system. H. Humphrey, a noted 19th century author, wrote, “Our children must have employment – must be brought up in habits of industry. It is sinful, it is cruel to neglect this essential branch of their education.” Today, children in the United States are obligated to receive a different kind of education, one that does not involve a factory. Many would even view the Slaters’ use and manipulation of children in mills today as sinful or cruel. This marks a major change from how children lived in Slatersville throughout most of the nineteenth century. 

In the 1920s, these mill houses you are now looking at were converted to single-family management homes, by the then owner of the mill, Henry Kendall. Kendall added ornamental touches like side porches, fancier doorways, and white picket fences as part of his efforts to restore Slatersville.

stops.significance: The former home of John Slater demonstrates how perspectives and practices of industrialists changed with succeeding generations of owners.
stops.audioTranscript:
John Slater built this home in 1810. It originally stood on the corner of North Main and Green Streets, where the North Smithfield Town Hall now stands. This home was much like his employee housing. The major difference was that he shared his home with one other family, not two or three. Though he lived at a higher standard, John still lived and worked alongside his workers. While he oversaw a system which ensured his workers could be managed and controlled, he too was held accountable to his employees. There was a certain degree of respect between both employer and employee which came from the proximity in which they all lived. As future generations of Slaters moved further and further away from the community, they became increasingly disinterested in their employees. This would lead to even more labor unrest. 

John would remain personally and financially invested in the community until his death in 1843. After his death, the family moved the house to its current location and converted it into worker housing. The family moved to a large mansion home which once stood on the outskirts of the village. 

Slatersville served as the model for other mill villages  throughout the Blackstone Valley, and eventually in other parts of the Northeast. This type of industrially planned community was also replicated again and again in factory towns, mine towns, and mill villages across the country. In each of these communities, workers faced tradeoffs. Living and working together, laborers of all ages usually endured the tight supervision of a family or corporation. Yet some also experienced new freedoms and a chance to begin again in a new place or new country.  

Perhaps the most enduring legacy of Slatersville is the fact that it is still here – a testament to the resiliency of a community and of the people who call it home.
