data.title: Slavery and the Underground Railroad in Delaware
data.description: This tour is meant to be conducted at your own pace, as the sites mentioned stretch over the length of Delaware. Please be careful when travelling, and make sure to look up the hours and visitor information for each site beforehand. Contact information, hours, and how to make reservations, if they are necessary, can be found both in the First State National Historical Park section of the NPS mobile app and on the Park’s website, at www.nps.gov/frst.

stops.significance: The John Dickinson Plantation was the home of one of the most famous of the Founders, John Dickinson, often referred to as the "penman of the Revolution". While Dickinson wrote so eloquently about concepts like freedom and liberty, he also enslaved people on his plantation. It is through the life of Dickinson and all the others, free and enslaved, who live here that we can explore the contradictory truths at the heart of the American Revolution.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is the Green in Dover, Delaware. You will need a vehicle to travel there.
stops.audioTranscript:
The history of slavery in Delaware is complex and deep, and one cannot properly explore this story of the First State without examining the lasting impact that the enslavement of tens of thousands of people for more than two centuries had, and continues to have, on Delaware. During this tour you will visit four sites of First State National Historical Park, each stop a link in the story of slavery in the First State. We will touch on a few different threads of this history. This tour is organized thematically, not chronologically, and will explore areas such as the status of enslaved Africans in New Sweden in the 1600s; the relationship of one of the most famous of the Founders, John Dickinson, to slavery; and  the efforts of brave individuals to help enslaved people emancipate themselves within the Underground Railroad Network to Freedom. 

John Dickinson, often called the “penman of the American Revolution”, was one of the most prominent members of the generation of thinkers, writers, philosophers, politicians, and soldiers who made up the Founders, which shaped so much of the American Revolution. He was also an enslaver. 

Though rightly lauded for his literary accomplishments during the first part of the American Revolution, in those tumultuous years leading to the War of Independence, John Dickinson also kept people in bondage on his plantation. The uncompensated labor of these people provided a large part of Dickinson’s wealth, and was thus free to spend his days in scholarly and philosophical pursuits. This story was replicated throughout Colonial America. While not all of the Founders were enslavers, many were. To put thing into perspective, of the 56 men who put their signatures on the Declaration of Independence in 1776, representing all Thirteen Colonies then in rebellion against the British Empire, 41 either enslaved people at the time of the signing or had at some point before that. Those that did hold people in bondage often used the wealth and perhaps more importantly, free time, made possible by enslaved labor, to develop some of the most cherished ideas and institutions of the United States. 

How we reconcile these two contradictory truths, that the very people who so fervently believed in freedom and liberty, were at the same time willing and able to keep people in bondage based on nothing but their skin color, informs much of how we view the American project as a whole. 

Before continuing on with the rest of this tour, if you are able to, we ardently recommend that you spend time at the John Dickinson Plantation, and if possible take a guided tour or attend an interpretive program, so that you may gain a better understanding of how  all people, free and enslaved, lived and worked on the plantation landscape. When you are ready to move on, our next stop will be The Green in the center of Dover, Delaware.

stops.significance: The Dover Green has been the center of this community since the city's founding. It has been the stage for numerous historical events, including the auction of Samuel Burris into slavery in 1848. By exploring the life of Burris, we can a better understanding of how the Black Americans, both free and enslaved, lived in Delaware before the Civil War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: We will now turn our attention to the history of how slavery originally came to the First State, and our next stop will be Fort Christina in Wilmington, Delaware. Please be aware that Fort Christina National Historic Landmark  is open limited times  of the year. Please visit the First State NHP website at www.nps.gov/frst for more information. You may wish to still travel to the site, or simply listen to the audio narration.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Green has served as a center of Dover since its founding in 1693. The Old State House stands at the east end of the Green and has been the setting for many historical events, including perhaps the most infamous auction of an enslaved person in Delaware history. 

Samuel Burris was a free Black man born in Delaware in 1813. He worked hard throughout his life, both in manual labor as well as a teacher. Details about his life are somewhat sparse, but we do know that by 1840, he had a family of his own and was living in Philadelphia, though he continued to teach in Wilmington, Delaware. The reason for re-locating his family to Pennsylvania was tied to the increasingly repressive laws aimed at Delaware’s free Black population. Through the first half of the 1800s, the numbers of enslaved people within the First State stagnated, however this was accompanied by ever harsher laws which deprived free Black Delawareans of their constitutional rights. By the 1830s, free Black people in Delaware were denied the right to vote, the right to free speech, to assemble, to bear arms, and by 1863 were even forbidden from re-entering Delaware if they had left the state for more than five days. 

Given Delaware’s geographic position, it became a corridor for enslaved people seeking  freedom in Pennsylvania, which had begun to gradually abolish slavery in 1780. As such, the Underground Railroad, the name given in the mid-1800s to the secret network of abolitionists, safe houses, and escape routes, was quite active within Delaware. Burris became involved with the activities of the Underground Railroad by 1840, mainly through his membership in the Philadelphia Anti-Slavery Society. Burris was a “conductor” on the Underground Railroad, guiding  freedom seekers through Delaware, and arranging for safe houses and further passage on to other northern states or Canada. 

Burris often worked with two wealthy white abolitionists in his endeavors, John Hunn and Thomas Garret, and it was with these men that he would be caught trying to help Maria Matthews escape slavery by getting her onboard a steamship in 1847. They were unsuccessful, and all three were soon arrested and charged with violating the 1793 Fugitive Slave Law. Hunn and Garret were found guilty and fined into financial oblivion, though they escaped prison time. Burris was not as fortunate, and after being found guilty, was sentenced to 14 months of imprisonment. At the conclusion of this portion of his sentence, he was then to be auctioned into 14 years of slavery. That auction took place in September of 1848, on the  front steps of the Old State House, which you are currently standing in front of. 

Imagine the scene in 1848, as Burris, in chains and standing defiantly, was led in front of a crowd of men looking to purchase him like they would an animal. What do you think Burris was feeling at that moment, looking out over the crowd and realizing that he was almost certain to never see his family or his home again? What would you have done if you were in his place? (PAUSE)
Luckily for Burris, such a dark fate was not to be his destiny. During the 14 months of his imprisonment, his fellow abolitionists had not been idle. While a campaign had unfortunately failed to sway politicians to intervene on Burris behalf, it thankfully caught the attention of an even wider audience.  Eventually the Philadelphia Anti-Slavery Society raised enough funds to rescue Burris.  They had a Quaker from Philadelphia, Isaac Flint, take $500 (equivalent to $15,000 in 2021) to the auction, and pretend to be interested in purchasing Burris. As William Still relates, Flint had to be canny to avoid being detected as an imposter, 
“The usual opportunity was given to traders and speculators to thoroughly examine the property on the block, and most skillfully was Burris examined from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head; legs, arms and body, being handled as horse-jockeys treat horses. Flint watched the ways of the traders and followed for effect their example.”

Having thus passed scrutiny, Flint and the others began the bidding process. The price for Burris was soon above $500, exceeding the funds the abolitionists had gathered. Thinking fast, Flint bribed the highest bidder into withdrawing, and then was declared the winner himself. Burris was led into a cart, which Flint proceeded to drive out of town. However, rather than heading South, as soon as was safe, Flint informed Burris "not to fear, you have been purchased with abolitionist gold and I will spirit you away to Philadelphia."

Burris was free, and though he never returned South, he continued to help freedom seekers when they arrived in Pennsylvania. In 1850, his family moved to San Francisco, and he followed a few years later. There he kept up his activism, focusing on education and job training for Black Americans. He also continued to lecture on the importance of abolition until his death in 1863.

stops.significance: Fort Christina marks the nucleus of the colony of New Sweden, the first successful European colony in what would become Delaware. Though slavery was not present at its beginning, and only gradually grew over the course of New Sweden's existence, it was nevertheless the germ from which the institution grew in the Delaware region. We cannot fully explore the history of slavery in Delaware without looking at how it began.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is a border marker in the Brandywine Valley unity of First State NHP. There is a small gravel parking lot on Beaver Valley Road, at coordinates 39.84379464067705, -75.55535685654554 that provides the easiest access to the trails leading to the marker. Once you arrive at the parking lot, reference the First State NHP map in the mobile app to decide on a trail route you would like to take to reach the marker. Please be prepared for the trail conditions, and make sure you have plenty of water and proper footwear.
stops.audioTranscript:
The history of slavery in Delaware began with the colony of New Sweden, which was established here with the construction of Fort Christina, named after their 12-year-old Queen of Sweden, along Christina River in 1638. Though there was a previous attempt to set up a Dutch colony, called Zwannandael, in southern Delaware, it failed after less than a year. New Sweden’s colonists consisted of Swedish, Finnish, and Dutch settlers  and was more successful.  The colony lasted until 1655, when it was taken over by Dutch forces from a  much larger colony  further to the North. Dutch rule was ended  by English forces in 1664, paving the way for the creation of the colonies of Pennsylvania and Delaware. 

When the first wave of Europeans arrived to start the colony of New Sweden in 1638, they had no enslaved people with them. However, within a year, there would be at least one enslaved Black person we know by the name of Anthony Swart. Swart’s origins and much of his life is shrouded in mystery. We know that he was brought back to New Sweden aboard the Vogel Grip, which was a Dutch captained ship in the service of Sweden. The Vogel Grip had made an expedition down to the English colony of Virginia soon after the founding of New Sweden in an attempt to trade for an extremely lucrative commodity, tobacco. This was unsuccessful however, and so the Vogel Grip continued into the Caribbean, perhaps looking for easy profits in raiding Spanish treasure ships. Whatever the captain’s intentions, he was also largely unsuccessful in this endeavor, but he did bring back a Black man, who went by the name Anthony Swart, probably captured from a Spanish vessel and held because of his seafaring skills. Such skills would have been of immense value to the burgeoning colony of New Sweden, due to its orientation along the Delaware River Bay and the tributaries feeding into it, putting maritime expertise at a premium. Swart lived in the colony of New Sweden as an enslaved man almost until the colony’s take over by the Dutch in 1655. What happened to him after that, and details about his 15 years  in the colony, are essentially non-existent. Anthony was mentioned in only a few official records, the last of which was a bill of sale for supplies from a colony store, shortly before he disappears from the record. He may have travelled elsewhere after the Dutch takeover, perhaps even choosing to settle with the Lenape people, who he would have had contact with when he served as an agent for Johann Printz, who had been governor of New Sweden and the enslaver of Anthony during  1643-1653. Alternatively he may have ended up travelling back to the Caribbean,  or a worse fate may have befallen him. While slavery was present in the colony of New Sweden, it was never particularly wide spread or common. This would change as Dutch influence from the larger colony of New Amsterdam,  modern day New York, increased during the 1640s and 50s, and even more so after the Dutch takeover. 

The Dutch in the 1600s were the masters of the Atlantic slave trade. Thousands of enslaved Black people from Africa were transported to Dutch colonies in the Caribbean and New Amsterdam. Many were then transported further on to the South River, which is what the Dutch called the colony of New Sweden. This occurred, even though there was resistance to the concept of slavery in Swedish culture, because constant labor shortages threatened the colony’s existence. Unable to convince enough Swedes and Finns to make the dangerous ocean crossing to the Americas, the colony imported enslaved Africans and Dutch settlers convicted of crimes and sentenced to hard labor into New Sweden in small but growing numbers over the 1640s. 

It was from this small but significant beginning that the institution of slavery grew in what eventually became the State of Delaware. 
We will now travel further north to the border between Delaware & Pennsylvania, in the Brandywine Valley, to explore the invisible line which separated so many humans held in bondage from freedom in the 1800s.

stops.significance: This is one of many markers placed by the 1892 Hodgkins survey of the "12-mile arc", the unique circular boundary between Delaware & Pennsylvania. Though the border had been established in the late 1600s, its circular shape made it difficult to survey and demarcate until the late 1800s. While the marker itself was placed after slavery was abolished in the United States, the border it represents was established long before that, and for many thousands of enslaved people seeking freedom, this was the last barrier they had to cross before they were on free soil.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop of the tour. Please enjoy the rest of your visit to First State National Historical Park.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are standing at one of the border markers along the unusual boundary between Delaware and Pennsylvania. When Pennsylvania was created in 1681 as a proprietary colony of William Penn  the “Three Lower Counties of Pennsylvania” , which make up Delaware today, were to be administered from Philadelphia. By 1704 however the three counties had established their own colonial legislature, and in 1776 when Delaware declared independence from the British Empire, it simultaneously declared independence from Pennsylvania as well. 

The border between Delaware and Pennsylvania is unique, being one of the few circular boundaries in the United States. When Pennsylvania was established, the area for 12 miles around New Castle was carved out as a separate territory. However exactly where to draw this 12-mile circle, and how to properly survey and demarcate it, proved to be exceptionally difficult for Colonial authorities. It wasn’t until the later 1800s  that the border was finally properly surveyed, and markers placed every half mile and mile along the arc of the 12-mile circle. You can learn more about the survey process on the First State NHP website. 

For now though, examine this stone plinth, one of the ½ mile markers along the arc. It might not have stood here during the existence of legal slavery in the United States, but the line it marked did and still does. To the south is Delaware, to the north is Pennsylvania. Now imagine you are in the year 1855, and you are an enslaved person who has escaped from a plantation further south in Delaware or Maryland. You have braved the elements, hid from slave patrols, navigated through unfamiliar landscapes, and now you stand at the border between Delaware, a slave state, and Pennsylvania, a free state. The line that this marker represents is all the stands between you and freedom. What might you be feeling as you step over that invisible line? Think of how many enslaved people took that same step, what do you think they felt? 

The history of slavery in Delaware, much like that of the nation, continues to have an impact on us even today. These are not events that can be simply relegated to dusty tomes in libraries, but are stories and legacies that shape our society, how we see our fellow Americans, and how we conceptualize America. Thank you for taking the time to learn about the history of slavery in the First State. We invite you to contact us with any questions or comments you may have. Enjoy the rest of your visit to First State National Historical Park.

data.title: Smith Spring Trail Loop
data.description: The Guadalupe Mountains rise out of the surrounding desert, providing habitat for a variety of unique plants and animals that are not found anywhere in the surrounding arid lands. The riparian woodland surrounding Smith Spring is one of the unique ecosystems found within the Guadalupe Mountains. The hike is a 2.3-mile loop with a 400-foot elevation gain. Allow from one and a half to two hours to complete. Bring plenty of water, a trail map, and comfortable hiking shoes.

stops.significance: The Frijole Ranch Trailhead has a restroom and picnic tables. The historic Frijole Ranch is just a short walk from the trailhead.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the trailhead, proceed on the path to the historic Frijole Ranch.

stops.significance:
It is not hard to imagine why Frijole Ranch was constructed at this site. Frijole Spring provided the water that was essential to survival here in the desert. Because of this water, the area is a great place to find a variety of birds and other wildlife. Scrub jays, chipping sparrows, house finches, Say's phoebes, white-winged doves, and ladder-backed woodpeckers are year-round residents. In winter watch for pyrrhuloxia, phainopeplas, cedar waxwings, and western bluebirds. In spring and summer, look for summer and western tanagers, plumbeous vireos, Cassin's kingbird, blue grosbeak, and a variety of warblers.

Before starting out on the trail, take some time to explore around Frijole Ranch. Interpretive signs will tell you about the history of the Smith Family and later the Kincaid Family who called this place home. If the museum is open, there are exhibits inside that chronicle over 10,000 years of human history in the Guadalupe Mountains.
stops.directionsToNextStop: After visiting the ranch begin hiking on the paved path that starts behind the schoolhouse or through the orchard. As you are walking along the paved path you will have views of a conical shaped hill to the right of the trail. This is Nipple Hill. It is not a volcanic cinder cone as one might think, but rather composed of the same limestone and sandstone as the surrounding landscape. It is an erosional remnant of two river valleys eroding into a ridge.

stops.significance: Manzanita Spring is reached via an accessible trail and is a small pool of water in an otherwise seemingly barren desert landscape.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Past the spring, the trail turns to a dirt surface. Proceed on the trail until you reach Smith Spring.

stops.significance: Perhaps the very best place in the park to rest and reflect, Smith Spring is a lush oasis tucked up against the Guadalupe Mountains Wilderness.
stops.directionsToNextStop: When you are ready to continue, proceed on the trail to return to the Frijole Ranch trailhead.

images.title: Smith Spring pool
images.altText: Water flows into a pool under a canopy of trees
images.caption: Smith Spring is a destination along the east side of the Guadalupe Mountains

data.title: Sound of Silence Trail: Tilted Landscapes
data.description: While you hike through one of the quietest places in the West, natural sounds will prevail, including the call of birds and the rustle of wind through the plants. Though we may associate this place with quiet, the landscape can speak to us - if we are ready to listen. Numbered signposts along the trail correspond with this tour, taking you through different habitats and millions of years of time.

stops.significance:
While you hike through one of the quietest places in the West, natural sounds will prevail, including the call of birds and the rustle of wind through the plants. Though we may associate this place with quiet, the landscape can speak to us - if we are ready to listen. Numbered signposts along the trail correspond with this tour, taking you through different habitats and millions of years of time.
The trail is easy at first, but it gets more difficult the further you hike and includes a short rock scramble near the end. Trail conditions vary depending on weather. The lack of shade can be potentially dangerous during the summer heat. It is best to hike in the early morning when temperatures are cooler. Recent rain may make sections of the trail muddy and slick. Please stay on the trail unless you are on solid rock or sand. Desert soils are delicate and may be destroyed by walking on them - you will hear more about these biological soil crusts later. Pets and bikes are not permitted.
stops.audioTranscript:
While you hike through one of the quietest places in the West, natural sounds will prevail, including the call of birds and the rustle of wind through the plants. Though we may associate this place with quiet, the landscape can speak to us - if we are ready to listen. Numbered signposts along the trail correspond with this tour, taking you through different habitats and millions of years of time.

The trail is easy at first, but it gets more difficult the further you hike and includes a short rock scramble near the end. Trail conditions vary depending on weather. The lack of shade can be potentially dangerous during the summer heat. It is best to hike in the early morning when temperatures are cooler. Recent rain may make sections of the trail muddy and slick.

Please stay on the trail unless you are on solid rock or sand. Desert soils are delicate and may be destroyed by walking on them - you will hear more about these biological soil crusts later. Pets and bikes are not permitted. 

Remember that all plants, animals, flowers, artifacts, fossils, and rocks are protected. Please leave everything where you find it. Take only pictures and leave only memories.

stops.significance:
Dinosaur National Monument is best known for its dinosaur fossils, but it protects so much more. 23 geologic layers are exposed in the monument, spanning more than one billion years of Earth's history. Sparse vegetation reveals these layers that tell us about the distant past. 

Look to the west and view geologic layers through time. Frontier Formation and Mowry Shale to the south (on your left) are younger rock layers, dating to the late Cretaceous, approximately 98 million years ago. The Nugget Sandstone to the north (on your right) is much older, extending back to the Triassic, 200 million years ago. In front of you is over 100 million years of climatic and environmental change.

Change can be continuous and slow or incredibly quick in a desert environment like this. Soon you will encounter an intermittent stream bed (referred to as a wash). It is often dry, but water roaring downhill after intense thunderstorms can rapidly reshape the landscape.
stops.audioTranscript:
Dinosaur National Monument is best known for its dinosaur fossils, but it protects so much more. 23 geologic layers are exposed in the monument, spanning more than one billion years of Earth's history. Sparse vegetation reveals these layers that tell us about the distant past.

Look to the west and view geologic layers through time. Frontier Formation and Mowry Shale to the south (on your left) are younger rock layers, dating to the late Cretaceous, approximately 98 million years ago. The Nugget Sandstone to the north (on your right) is much older, extending back to the Triassic, 200 million years ago. In front of you is over 100 million years of climatic and environmental change.

Change can be continuous and slow or incredibly quick in a desert environment like this. Soon you will encounter an intermittent stream bed (referred to as a wash). It is often dry, but water roaring downhill after intense thunderstorms can rapidly reshape the landscape.

stops.significance:
Many sections of this trail never look the same way twice, and this wash is a good example of constant change. Water is a powerful force that shapes soils as well as rocks. Water can build as well as erode. Plants nourished by water soften the landscape and make it possible for animals, birds, insects, and reptiles to live here. Listen and watch for signs of life as you proceed.

Signs of animals include the game trails that elk and deer create as they crisscross the washes that the Sound of Silence Trail follows. Don’t be tempted to follow these tracks up and out of the wash though — they will lead you through some rough territory!
stops.directionsToNextStop: You will soon come to an intersection. This is where the trail returns to complete the 3.2 mile hiking loop. This guide is written to follow clockwise travel. Continue walking straight here, in the wash, toward the cottonwood tree ahead.
stops.audioTranscript:
Many sections of this trail never look the same way twice, and this wash is a good example of constant change. Water is a powerful force that shapes soils as well as rocks. Water can build as well as erode. Plants nourished by water soften the landscape and make it possible for animals, birds, insects, and reptiles to live here. Listen and watch for signs of life as you proceed.

Signs of animals include the game trails that elk and deer create as they crisscross the washes that the Sound of Silence Trail follows. Don’t be tempted to follow these tracks up and out of the wash though — they will lead you through some rough territory!

stops.significance: You might expect a large Fremont Cottonwood tree like this to grow near a more obvious source of water. What does its presence here tell us? The surrounding rocks funnel seasonal rainwater to its thirsty roots. This tree, with leaves that sing and whisper in the breeze, provides habitat for birds and insects, and shade for all. Rabbits, deer, and elk feed on its shoots and stems. Insects live on it that are food for birds. Hawks and bats may use cottonwoods as sites to nest or roost. Even in death, tree cavities are refuges for many species of animals. Ahead you will find other refuges used by animals to escape the mid-day sun.
stops.audioTranscript: You might expect a large Fremont Cottonwood tree like this to grow near a more obvious source of water. What does its presence here tell us? The surrounding rocks funnel seasonal rainwater to its thirsty roots. This tree, with leaves that sing and whisper in the breeze, provides habitat for birds and insects, and shade for all. Rabbits, deer, and elk feed on its shoots and stems. Insects live on it that are food for birds. Hawks and bats may use cottonwoods as sites to nest or roost. Even in death, tree cavities are refuges for many species of animals. Ahead you will find other refuges used by animals to escape the mid-day sun.

stops.significance: Take a close look at the earthen bank on your right for evidence of flowing water — sometimes swift and other times slow. Faster water can carry larger particles. Can you find a layer that was accompanied by the sound of rushing water? Slower water can only carry fine sediments. Try to find a layer that would have been deposited by a quiet trickle. The surrounding cliffs, slowly eroded by wind and water, add to the diverse, sorted sediment layers. Erosion continues with each new rainstorm moving more sediment downstream. Differences in the sediment layers help natural cavities develop. Holes may be enlarged and used by squirrels and birds, as nesting sites. Listen carefully and you may hear the scratchy call of a Rock Wren or the melodic song of a Canyon Wren. Look carefully and you may see a Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel peeking out of a hole, its high pitched alarm call warning others of your presence.
stops.audioTranscript: Take a close look at the earthen bank on your right for evidence of flowing water — sometimes swift and other times slow. Faster water can carry larger particles. Can you find a layer that was accompanied by the sound of rushing water? Slower water can only carry fine sediments. Try to find a layer that would have been deposited by a quiet trickle. The surrounding cliffs, slowly eroded by wind and water, add to the diverse, sorted sediment layers. Erosion continues with each new rainstorm moving more sediment downstream. Differences in the sediment layers help natural cavities develop. Holes may be enlarged and used by squirrels and birds, as nesting sites. Listen carefully and you may hear the scratchy call of a Rock Wren or the melodic song of a Canyon Wren. Look carefully and you may see a Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel peeking out of a hole, its high pitched alarm call warning others of your presence.

stops.significance: The rounded bluffs of Nugget Sandstone towering above you are remnants of a vast desert that once covered much of what is now the western United States. Thin diagonal layers called cross-beds formed as wind blown sand dunes moved across the desert 200 million years ago. The steep fronts of these dunes were hundreds of feet high. Trace fossils in the Nugget Sandstone include the tracks of scorpions, spiders, and Brasilichnium, an early relative of mammals. Bones from an early Triassic dinosaur have also been found in this rock layer.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue in the wash for the next 0.3 miles until you see an arrow marker on your right directing you up and out of the wash. Don’t be fooled by the numerous animal trails!
stops.audioTranscript: The rounded bluffs of Nugget Sandstone towering above you are remnants of a vast desert that once covered much of what is now the western United States. Thin diagonal layers called cross-beds formed as wind blown sand dunes moved across the desert 200 million years ago. The steep fronts of these dunes were hundreds of feet high. Trace fossils in the Nugget Sandstone include the tracks of scorpions, spiders, and Brasilichnium, an early relative of mammals. Bones from an early Triassic dinosaur have also been found in this rock layer.

stops.significance: Enjoy the view as you study the plants growing all around you. Does the pattern of their placement say anything to you? The bench of land you are on overlooks a riparian area, filled with Fremont Cottonwood trees growing where water is more plentiful and soil is deeper. On the rocky ledges above are junipers, which can survive on very little water. In between, where you are now, are shrubs like greasewood and sage. Many vegetation patterns occur throughout Dinosaur National Monument, influenced by elevation, amount of water, minerals in the soils, or sunlight. In turn, these zones provide a variety of unique habitats for wildlife.
stops.audioTranscript: Enjoy the view as you study the plants growing all around you. Does the pattern of their placement say anything to you? The bench of land you are on overlooks a riparian area, filled with Fremont Cottonwood trees growing where water is more plentiful and soil is deeper. On the rocky ledges above are junipers, which can survive on very little water. In between, where you are now, are shrubs like greasewood and sage. Many vegetation patterns occur throughout Dinosaur National Monument, influenced by elevation, amount of water, minerals in the soils, or sunlight. In turn, these zones provide a variety of unique habitats for wildlife.

stops.significance: Within this shady rock overhang, can you spot a portion of a packrat debris pile, also known as a midden? It is above your head, in the crevice between the two large rocks that form the overhang. Look for twigs, rocks and fecal pellets, all held together by shiny crystallized urine. Middens can tell us about past environments. They may exist and be added to for thousands of years. Radiocarbon dating has identified middens up to 50,000 years old. Middens may contain leaves, seeds, fruit, twigs, pollen, bone, shells and scales, leading to identification of past environments. We know from middens that Douglas Fir and Ponderosa Pine once grew in this area, during a cooler and wetter time. As the climate changed over the last 10,000 years, these species retreated to higher elevations where they are still found.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The trail proceeds on this bench for another 50 yards before it returns to the wash. Watch for signposts.
stops.audioTranscript:
Within this shady rock overhang, can you spot a portion of a packrat debris pile, also known as a midden? It is above your head, in the crevice between the two large rocks that form the overhang. Look for twigs, rocks and fecal pellets, all held together by shiny crystallized urine. Middens can tell us about past environments. They may exist and be added to for thousands of years. Radiocarbon dating has identified middens up to 50,000 years old. Middens may contain leaves, seeds, fruit, twigs, pollen, bone, shells and scales, leading to identification of past environments. We know from middens that Douglas Fir and Ponderosa Pine once grew in this area, during a cooler and wetter time. As the climate changed over the last 10,000 years, these species retreated to higher elevations where they are still found.

You may notice some plant stumps with large root structures. Why would monument staff cut down these plants? Look around for the feathery leaves of tamarisk, also known as salt cedar. If it is blooming, it will have small, white to pink flowers. It is a non-native tree that grows in riparian areas. Brought to North America in the early 19th century for use as an ornamental wind break, and to fight erosion, it quickly spread and became an invasive weed, often outcompeting native plants. Its presence on the river banks of the Green and Yampa Rivers, and here in this intermittent stream, changes river flow and makes it difficult for deer, elk, and sheep to get to water. In 2006 and 2007, Dinosaur National Monument introduced 50,000 non-native northern tamarisk beetles to four locations in the monument. The most intensively studied biocontrol agent in North America, the beetle eats only tamarisk. While tamarisk will never be entirely eliminated, the beetles are helping to keep it under control and allow native vegetation to rebound.

stops.significance: While native plants like the greasewood, rabbitbrush, and sage are important habitat, what about the rock walls themselves? The large cliff to the south has, in past years, been the nesting place of Peregrine Falcons. Once an endangered species, their numbers have now grown. Thanks to a ban on the pesticide DDT, and protected nesting places like this cliff face in Dinosaur National Monument, you may see a Peregrine Falcon soaring overhead. Listen carefully for the highpitched “kak, kak, kak” call.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking in the wash. Watch for markers ahead with arrows directing you to turn right. You will leave the wide wash and follow a narrow path through weathered hills.
stops.audioTranscript: While native plants like the greasewood, rabbitbrush, and sage are important habitat, what about the rock walls themselves? The large cliff to the south has, in past years, been the nesting place of Peregrine Falcons. Once an endangered species, their numbers have now grown. Thanks to a ban on the pesticide DDT, and protected nesting places like this cliff face in Dinosaur National Monument, you may see a Peregrine Falcon soaring overhead. Listen carefully for the highpitched “kak, kak, kak” call.

stops.significance: Hidden within these hills are clues of their origin. Look for ripple marks on some of the rocks, and imagine the lapping sound of waves, a message from the past. You are now walking through the remains of a shallow, watery environment from 250 million years ago called the Moenkopi Formation. Muds and sands were deposited in thin beds on the edges and bottoms of watery areas. Reptiles and amphibians moved stealthily along shorelines and through these shallow waters, in a time before the dinosaurs. Invertebrates burrowed in the muds of the floodplains, and ammonites (a type of mollusk) swam in the seaways. Although the weathered soils of the Moenkopi Formation may look inhospitable, flowering plants like Desert Paintbrush, Pale Evening Primrose and the dramatic Prince’s Plume grow here. What are these plants telling us? These soils are high in selenium, which the Prince’s Plume utilizes so that it is unpalatable and even toxic if consumed.
stops.audioTranscript: Hidden within these hills are clues of their origin. Look for ripple marks on some of the rocks, and imagine the lapping sound of waves, a message from the past. Muds and sands were deposited in thin beds on the edges and bottoms of watery areas. Reptiles and amphibians moved stealthily along shorelines and through these shallow waters, in a time before the dinosaurs. stops.significance: What is happening beneath our feet to result in such a dramatic landscape at the surface? The noticeable curve of Split Mountain is part of an anticline - an upward fold of rock. While Split Mountain arcs up, other features seem to sag. The sags are called synclines. This underlying rollercoaster of rock formed when formerly flat sedimentary layers were compressed and wrinkled. Forces related to the building of the Rocky and Uinta Mountains 70 - 40 million years ago caused the uplifting, tilting, faulting and folding of the rock layers. While some layers erode into mounds, others stick out as ridges.
stops.audioTranscript:
What is happening beneath our feet to result in such a dramatic landscape at the surface? The noticeable curve of Split Mountain is part of an anticline - an upward fold of rock. While Split Mountain arcs up, other features seem to sag. The sags are called synclines. This underlying rollercoaster of rock formed when formerly flat sedimentary layers were compressed and wrinkled. Forces related to the building of the Rocky and Uinta Mountains 70 - 40 million years ago caused the uplifting, tilting, faulting and folding of the rock layers. While some layers erode into mounds, others stick out as ridges. 

Erosion reveals not only a variety of shapes, but also an array of colors. Look back across the Moenkopi Formation labyrinth you just traversed. In the distance you will see a swath of red rock known as “The Racetrack.” The “lanes” are made up of Triassic-aged Moenkopi and Chinle formations, seemingly wrapping around the corner. These rust colored rocks are rich in iron and are sometimes called the Triassic Red Beds. Iron is also responsible for many of the yellow, orange and greenish tints to the rock layers here. Obviously inspired by the colors and shapes from near this ridge, Ernest Untermann brought his paints and easel to this area in the mid-1900s. A German immigrant, he became known as “The Artist of the Uintas,” and Dinosaur’s dramatic landscapes spoke to him. The sedimentary rocks around you were originally flat, horizontal layers when they were deposited. Each layer represents its own story of a different past environment, different fauna and flora, a succession of time and life on our planet. For millions of years, these stories were buried deep underground. Thanks to uplift and erosion, they are once again free to tell colorful tales of change over time.

stops.significance:
Soils in an arid environment are fragile. Take a minute here to inspect the crusty biological soil. It is mostly cyanobacteria (sometimes called blue-green algae), and also includes lichens, mosses, green algae, microfungi and bacteria. It takes many years for this soil to form and support life. While cyanobacteria are mobile and will regenerate if disturbed, lichens and mosses are not, and will die if trampled. Blown by wind or moved by other forces, it is estimated that lichens will recolonize an area in 45 years, while it takes mosses an estimated 250 years. These crusts control erosion and fix nitrogen, helping other plants to grow. Please stay on the trail to help preserve these unique soils.

All around you is Ephedra viridis, commonly called Mormon Tea because it was used by early Native Americans and settlers to make an invigorating tea. It is an important browse crop for livestock and also deer, elk, and sheep, especially in the winter months.

These crusts control erosion and fix nitrogen, helping other plants to grow. Please stay on the trail to help preserve these unique soils.

All around you is Ephedra viridis, commonly called Mormon Tea because it was used by early Native Americans and settlers to make an invigorating tea. It is an important browse crop for livestock and also deer, elk, and sheep, especially in the winter months. The large seeds are a good protein source for small mammals and birds. The drug ephedrine, an antidepressant and decongestant, can be extracted from this and other Ephedra species. This area is a great place to look for animal tracks, scat, and game trails. Can you distinguish between carnivore and herbivore scat? Look for fur and bones in the long, slender pieces of mountain lion, coyote, and bobcat scat. Deer, elk and rabbit scat will be more smooth and rounded. You may see game trails in this area, made primarily by elk and deer. See if you can distinguish these game trails from the people trail you are following now!

stops.significance: This spot provides a place to rest, rejuvenate, and cool down before climbing the rocky ridge ahead. Solitude and refuge are two things that national parks and monuments offer. These are places to reflect, learn, and experience nature. Also protected are other qualities such as dark night skies and natural quiet — rare commodities in cities where many of us live. Growing around you on the slope are Utah junipers. The most common tree species in Utah, it covers one-fifth of the land area of the state. It seems like they can grow nearly anywhere, even out of solid rock. Their roots are the secret. A massive system that makes up 2/3 of the tree’s total mass, the tap root can be 25 feet deep and lateral roots may extend out 100 feet. The juniper berry is actually a tiny pinecone, and is eaten by rabbit, fox, coyote, and many species of birds. Junipers grow slowly. Older trees, which may be 650-850 years old, have sculptural qualities. Even dead, a juniper may stand silent and strong for several hundred years.
stops.audioTranscript:
This spot provides a place to rest, rejuvenate, and cool down before climbing the rocky ridge ahead. Solitude and refuge are two things that national parks and monuments offer. These are places to reflect, learn, and experience nature. Also protected are other qualities such as dark night skies and natural quiet — rare commodities in cities where many of us live. Growing around you on the slope are Utah junipers. The most common tree species in Utah, it covers one-fifth of the land area of the state. It seems like they can grow nearly anywhere, even out of solid rock. Their roots are the secret. A massive system that makes up 2/3 of the tree’s total mass, the tap root can be 25 feet deep and lateral roots may extend out 100 feet. The juniper berry is actually a tiny pinecone, and is eaten by rabbit, fox, coyote, and many species of birds. Junipers grow slowly. Older trees, which may be 650-850 years old, have sculptural qualities. Even dead, a juniper may stand silent and strong for several hundred years. Like all of the plants at this 5,000 foot elevation, the juniper must survive on a sparse 10 inches of precipitation a year.

As you hike, check out the sky and you may see a Turkey Vulture or two, flying on silent wings high above you. Lightweight for such a wide wingspan, they teeter and totter on the breeze, rarely flapping their wings. An excellent sense of smell leads Turkey Vultures to carcasses where they feed cooperatively. Think of these silent birds not as purveyors of death, but rather as elegant birds who transform death into life on the wing. Look carefully at each soaring bird and you may be lucky to see a Golden Eagle, easily confused with a vulture at first glance. The Golden Eagle, at 10 pounds, is a much heavier bird, outweighing the vulture by 6 pounds. Eagles do not teeter and totter, and they hold their wings out flat, while vultures hold their wings in a slight V-shape. Both are dark birds, the vulture is here only during the summer, the eagle a year-round  bird. Perhaps a lizard has caught your attention during your hike, lending even more life to the desert. Six species of lizards are found here: sagebrush, plateau, western whiptail, shorthorned, side-blotched and tree lizard. Listen for lizards rushing about in the leaf litter, looking for spiders or insects to eat.

stops.significance: In the distance to the south you might be able to pick out the Green River. This source of water in the desert attracted not only the Fremont and Ute people who once dwelt here, but before them, people going back 10,000 years. Petroglyphs, pictographs and former dwelling sites dot the landscape. John Wesley Powell boated through here on his way down to the Colorado River about 150 years ago. He made natural history observations, mapped the area, and named many features. The Green River remains a source of adventure and sustenance today.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The trail’s descent from this ridge to the next stop is marked with rock cairns.
stops.audioTranscript: In the distance to the south you might be able to pick out the Green River. This source of water in the desert attracted not only the Fremont and Ute people who once dwelt here, but before them, people going back 10,000 years. Petroglyphs, pictographs and former dwelling sites dot the landscape. John Wesley Powell boated through here on his way down to the Colorado River about 150 years ago. He made natural history observations, mapped the area, and named many features. The Green River remains a source of adventure and sustenance today.

stops.significance: On this ridge, take a moment to rest in the shade of the small Singleleaf Ash tree, a species unique to the American Southwest. Surviving by means of deep roots and sheer perseverance, they often take on a dwarfed appearance. Unlike most species of ash trees, which have compound leaves, this western ash has a single leaf on each stem. The red rock ridge underneath you is the Chinle Formation, formed during a time when rivers, marshes, and small lakes covered the landscape. Plants would not have included a flowering tree like the Singleleaf Ash. Instead, conifers, cycads, ferns, and horsetail plants grew here. Dinosaurs made their first appearance in this time period, about 225 million years ago. Coelophysis, a three-toed, therapod dinosaur about the size of a large dog, roamed the land. Large crocodile-type creatures called phytosaurs lurked in the waters. Imagine how different the sounds of the Triassic would be from the sounds of today!
stops.audioTranscript: On this ridge, take a moment to rest in the shade of the small Singleleaf Ash tree, a species unique to the American Southwest. Surviving by means of deep roots and sheer perseverance, they often take on a dwarfed appearance. Unlike most species of ash trees, which have compound leaves, this western ash has a single leaf on each stem. The red rock ridge underneath you is the Chinle Formation, formed during a time when rivers, marshes, and small lakes covered the landscape. Plants would not have included a flowering tree like the Singleleaf Ash. Instead, conifers, cycads, ferns, and horsetail plants grew here. Dinosaurs made their first appearance in this time period, about 225 million years ago. Coelophysis, a three-toed, therapod dinosaur about the size of a large dog, roamed the land. Large crocodile-type creatures called phytosaurs lurked in the waters. Imagine how different the sounds of the Triassic would be from the sounds of today!

stops.significance: For those feeling fit and adventurous, an optional side trip is available at this spot. Climb the sloping rock stretching to the sky to the west. Step carefully, move slowly, and when you reach the top, you will be rewarded with a 360° panorama. Alternatively, you can enjoy the view from the shade of the juniper tree beside the trail marker, and contemplate that you are standing at the northern edge of the Colorado Plateau. Encompassing 240,000 square miles, this area is sometimes known as “Red Rock Country” and centers on the Four Corners area where Colorado, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico meet. There are 27 National Parks and Monuments, 30 wilderness areas, millions of acres of National Forest and many other protected areas in this high desert region of the plateau. Dinosaur National Monument is the northernmost of these parks. Each place has a unique contribution to the story of the southwest.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next section of the trail uses arrows, rock cairns and rock alignments to guide you. Scramble carefully down the crevice and continue hiking in the sandy wash.
stops.audioTranscript: For those feeling fit and adventurous, an optional side trip is available at this spot. Climb the sloping rock stretching to the sky to the west. Step carefully, move slowly, and when you reach the top, you will be rewarded with a 360° panorama. Alternatively, you can enjoy the view from the shade of the juniper tree beside the trail marker, and contemplate that you are standing at the northern edge of the Colorado Plateau. Encompassing 240,000 square miles, this area is sometimes known as “Red Rock Country” and centers on the Four Corners area where Colorado, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico meet. There are 27 National Parks and Monuments, 30 wilderness areas, millions of acres of National Forest and many other protected areas in this high desert region of the plateau. Dinosaur National Monument is the northernmost of these parks. Each place has a unique contribution to the story of the southwest.

stops.significance: For many of us, the simple beauty of the land’s colors and textures may be enough to satisfy, awe, and inspire. These places also allow geologists, paleontologists, biologists, and archeologists to more deeply investigate and study the Earth and our history. On this hike, you have seen the silent reminders of many changes —sometimes occurring over millions of years, or sometimes occurring very quickly. Sediments, rocks, plants, animals, and the other features of the landscape all speak to those who slow down and take the time to hear what they have to say.

images.caption: The Sound of Silence wanders through stunning desert landscapes.

data.title: South District Driving Tour
data.description: Enjoy this driving tour of the highlights of the South District of Cape Cod National Seashore (Eastham and Wellfleet areas). Stop by the visitor center to plan your trip or follow along on this short, 2-3 hour tour!

stops.directionsToNextStop: Drive back down Fort Hill Road from the upper parking lot about 1/4 a mile to reach the Captain Penniman House, the next stop on the tour.
stops.audioTranscript: Fort Hill Historic District has thousands of years of history embedded within the landscape.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit Fort Hill Road back to Route 6. Turn right onto Route 6 to head towards Eastham. Drive about 1.3 miles and turn right onto Nauset Road. Continue straight down Nauset Road, which turns into Doane Road, bear left onto Ocean View Drive. Nauset Light is at the intersection of Cable Road and Ocean View Drive.
Drive about 1/4 of a mile up Cable Road. There is a small parking area next to the Three Sisters Lighthouses.

Continue west on Cable Road. Turn right onto Nauset Road. Turn right onto Route 6 towards Wellfleet. Stay on Route 6 for 2.7 miles. At the stop light, turn right onto Marconi Beach Road. Turn right onto Marconi Station Road. Follow the road for one mile to the parking area.

images.title: Aerial view of Marconi Beach
images.altText: Aerial view of Marconi Beach. Trees, sand, and the ocean dot the landscape.
images.caption: Aerial view of Marconi Beach in Wellfleet.

data.title: South Rim; The 1–2 hour visit.
data.description: While one can get lost for days on end at a place like Grand Canyon, we don't always have the time. Thankfully even a short trip to Grand Canyon can still yield some amazing views and life long memories. The following is our Ranger Recommended 1–2 visit for the South Rim that includes a short walk, and our free shuttle bus service, but remember that there is no wrong way to visit the canyon. Relax, enjoy the views, and thanks for visiting.

stops.significance: Grand Canyon Visitor Center is a great place to start any trip to the canyon! The park film plays every 30 minutes, additional exhibits and displays tell the canyon's stories, Rangers are on hand to trip plan and answer questions you may have about local animals, plants, or rocks, and the nearby stores can help set you up with snacks, drinks, or souvenirs.
stops.directionsToNextStop: When facing the front of the visitor center walk to your right and follow the large paved path (up the small hill) to your first view of Grand Canyon at Mather Point.

stops.significance:
From Mather Point you have a visual range of over 60 miles looking at Grand Canyon from East to West. A sharp eye will pick out the Desert View Watchtower far to the east, the Grand Canyon Lodge on the North Rim, Phantom Ranch down in the canyon depths, and even a small patch of the Colorado River, complete with white water. 

Take your time to wonder around the area and appreciate the views.
stops.directionsToNextStop: When you're ready, head west (left when facing the canyon) on the paved path to Yavapai Geology Museum. This 0.7 mile (1 km) walk can also be done by hopping on the Kaibab/Rim Route (Orange) Route shuttle bus at the stop just west of the viewpoint.

stops.significance: The Yavapai Geology Museum is an excellent place to take a moment to answer some of those big questions, How? Why? What? that you might be pondering after seeing the canyon for the first time. It's also a great view of the canyon that has two views of the Colorado River, one of which also provides a view of the Kaibab trail's foot bridge across the river.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
When you're ready head down to the parking lot to grab a Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route shuttle bus back to the visitor center and beyond to Yaki Point. 

If you're time is running short get off at the Visitor Center to return to your vehicle.

stops.significance: Yet another wide sweeping panoramic view of the canyon this view looks slightly more to the East than Mather Point and offers a clearer view of the dramatic formations off in that direction. Far below you can see the South Kaibab Trail and sharp eye (or pair of binoculars) may spot hikers in the canyon. A short walk to the east of the viewpoint can yield some dramatic views and quieter nooks to stop and enjoy for a moment.
stops.directionsToNextStop: When ready, head back to the bus stop and return to the Visitor Center. If you're doing OK on time you can also stop at Pipe Creek Vista for another canyon view.

stops.assetName: Grand Canyon Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal

images.title: Mather Point
images.altText: A small group of people look out over Grand Canyon from behind a metal railing
images.caption: One of our favorite canyon views!

data.description: The story of the U.S.-Mexican War is complex. There are several U.S.-Mexican War sites you can visit in starting in the Corpus Christi, TX area and down the Lower Rio Grande Valley.

park.fullName: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park
park.name: Palo Alto Battlefield

images.caption: The cemetery's origin was due to a need for a formal burial ground for the U.S. Army of Occupation.

data.title: Southern Scenic Driving Tour
data.description: The New River Gorge National Park and Preserve encompasses over 70,000 acres of land as it follows the New River through the lower reaches of West Virginia. Beginning at the Grandview, this riverside driving tour ventures along the Park’s most scenic roads to the southern tip of its boundary, directing visitors towards some great views, recreational opportunities, and historic sites along the way.

park.fullName: New River Gorge National Park and Preserve
park.name: New River Gorge

stops.directionsToNextStop: Take Route 9 back to I-64 and head east. Take exit 139 to Sandstone Visitor Center.

stops.significance: Note: Looking for camping opportunities in the South District? Meadow Creek Campground is located about a mile up the road from the Sandstone Visitor Center, and is a year-round, tent-only, first-come first-serve campground.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head southbound on WV Route 20 for 3 miles to reach Sandstone Falls Overlook on the right.

stops.significance: The Sandstone Falls overlook is the first official park vista that visitors will pass on Route 20 during this tour. Just as the name entails, this overlook provides a spectacular cliff-side view of Sandstone Falls nearly 600 feet above the water. This stop also has picnic tables and a restroom.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Route 20 for another 1.8 miles to reach the next overlook on the right.

stops.significance: Brooks Island Overlook peers over the mile-long Brooks Island, a perennial bald eagle nesting site. Since 2010, three mated bald eagle couples have used the established nest in an American sycamore tree to incubate and raise their chicks. Though once listed as a threatened and endangered species, the bald eagle population within the country has steadily improved, and their sightings in the park have become more frequent! Two other nesting sites have been confirmed within the park in more recent years.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on Route 20 for a mile – there will be a brown and white Park sign on the righthand side of the road indicating the turnoff towards Gwinn Ridge Trail in another 50 feet. The turn will be on the left-hand side and lead onto Brooks Mountain Road. Stay on Brooks Mountain Road for 2.5 miles. Parking for Gwinn Ridge Trial will be on the left.

stops.significance:
The Gwinn Ridge Trail is a moderately strenuous 3 mile loop on the Brooks Mountain ridge-top that winds through a hilled meadow and old-growth forest. As one of the lesser-known trails in the park, Gwinn Ridge trail provides visitors a quiet hike, and, if trekked in the winter, good views.  

Note: Though not affiliated with the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve, the Three Rivers Avian Center is also located on Brooks Mountain Road. This “private nonprofit organization [is] dedicated to wild bird conservation and to educating and involving people in ecosystem stewardship,” and is open to public tours by appointment or between the 1st Saturday from May- October from 1 to 5 pm.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit Brooks Mountain Road back onto Route 20, and continue for four miles until the road forks onto Summers Street and becomes one way. Following Summers Street for another mile will take visitors directly into downtown Hinton.

stops.significance:
Though not technically under park jurisdiction, the charming town of Hinton is designated the southern gateway to the gorge and offers different opportunities for visitors who may be passing through, including Amtrak access, a railroad museum, several local restaurants, antique and retail shops, and historic sites which have ties to the region’s railroad and coaling industry. The Hinton Historic District is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is comprised of over 40 different historic structures within the downtown area. Thanks to the effort of the city, several of the buildings are being revitalized with renovations and restorations.

For more information on Hinton and all that the surrounding area has to offer, visit the New River Convention and Visitors Bureau located at 300 2nd Avenue or exploresummerscounty.com.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take Route 20 over the Hinton Bridge. At the other side of the river, take a right onto River Road and continue for 2 miles. A small parking lot for Richmond-Hamilton Farm will be on the left (including a vault toilet), with the historic farmstead only a short walk away.

stops.significance: First established in the 19th century, Richmond-Hamilton Farm now remains as one of a handful of historic homestead sites in the park. The fertile, flat land in this area provided the ideal environment for settlers to engage in subsistence farming – a traditional lifestyle of self-sufficiency that existed outside the advent of the coaling and railroad industry within the region. Homesteaders, such as the Richmond-Hamilton family, relied on the production of their own food, shelter, and water to survive, though trading and bartering resources with neighbors was also common practice. The Richmond-Hamilton farm showcases the standard homesteading format with a main house and several additional outbuildings that support the subsistence lifestyle, which often include a barn, shed, springhouse, and outhouse. Since its acquisition into the park, Richmond-Hamilton Farm has been preserved and restored, and is now regularly maintained as a historic site for visitors.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down River Road for another 2 miles. Brooks Falls Roadside Park will be on the right side; this stop also accommodates parking for the Big Branch Trail.

stops.significance: Another low-traffic hike, the Big Branch Trail offers a strenuous 2-mile loop through a peaceful forest landscape. Hikers of this trail will pass by two waterfalls, as well as the remains of an old homestead. During the springtime, this trail boasts colorful blooms; in the winter, the trail allows for ridge-top views of both the gorge and Brooks Falls.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down River Road for 4.3 miles to reach the final stop on this tour at Sandstone Falls. A parking lot for the day use area will be on the right side.

stops.significance: Brooks Falls, the smaller sister to Sandstone Falls, is a 4 foot drop that spans the 1000 foot width of the river. Though the name suggests it as a waterfall, Brooks Falls is perhaps better described as a runnable, Class III rapid. The Brooks Falls Roadside Park provides a small observation of the falls, as well as restroom facilities, picnic spots, and river access. *CAUTION* Always wear a life jacket when wading or swimming in the shallow river access eddies.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross the road to reach the Big Branch Trial trailhead.

stops.significance:
Sandstone Falls is the largest waterfall in the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve, with a river wide crest of 1500 feet that plunges from heights of 10-25 feet. These falls were created over thousands of years as water cut through and disintegrated the soft conglomerate rock layer that sits underneath the initial sandstone riverbed. This erosion resulted in a terraced waterfall formation with many small islands – several of which are home to the unique Appalachian flat rock ecosystem. Visitors are invited to explore the area with the established observation areas, waysides exhibits, and trails. The Sandstone Falls Boardwalk crosses over small tributaries and islets, and ends with an impressive view of the falls. The scenic Island Loop Trail leads visitors around the lower island where a grist mill once operated. 

*CAUTION* Several spots on the west bank of the river are suitable for wading and swimming, though visitors should always exercise caution by wearing a life jacket and shoes.

images.title: Map of the tour area in the park
images.altText: Map of the southern area of the park. North is at the top. Grandview and Sandstone are shown
images.caption: Map of the southern area of New River Gorge National Park and Preserve
