data.title: The Birds of South Marble Island
data.description: Learn the many species of birds who call South Marble Island home! This rocky island is not only home to endangered Steller Sea Lions, but also many birds who feast in the productive waters surrounding the island. Keep a look out for humpback whales who also frequent this area.

stops.significance: A highlight of any trip into the bay is the variety birds readily seen. A slow cruise past South Marble Island offers the opportunity to see many species of birds at once. The island provides nesting habitat for some, while also providing space for birds to rest between feeding excursions. Here are a few of the birds to look out for at South Marble Island and elsewhere in the bay.
stops.assetName: South Marble Island - Bird Tour Introduction
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you approach South Marble Island, take note of where birds appear. Some may live high on grassy hillsides of the island. Some birds will perch on cliff faces, and many more birds will be swimming in the water around the island, diving for fish to eat.

stops.significance: The glaucous-winged gull is not the heaviest bird that lives on South Marble Island, but it does have the largest wingspan at around 58 inches. Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Glaucous-winged Gull
stops.directionsToNextStop: While large white glaucous-winged gulls soar overhead or stand high on grassy hillsides of the island, look for smaller white birds flying in groups or perched on cliff faces... a clue to your next bird.

stops.significance: This bird's name comes from their call, a repeated, "Kitti-wake, kitti-wake, kitti-wake!". Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Black-legged Kittiwake
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop on your tour guides you to a bird loved by so many visitors to Glacier Bay and Alaska. Just don't get it confused with a penguin, these birds are from an entirely different scientific family.

stops.significance: How do these birds use their beautiful orange bill? Not only is it used to scoop up numerous fish to eat, these birds nest in burrows dug into the earthen hills of South Marble Island, and they use their large bills to dig with.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Tufted Puffin
stops.directionsToNextStop: Up next is a less commonly seen sibling of this member of the Alcidae family. Without the flashy 'tufts' on their head, this next bird also possesses an incredible bill.

stops.significance: Puffin bills function like pipe wrenches, opening wide to allow them to carry many fish at one time. And while puffins do fly, they are adapted to be excellent swimmers, diving deep and able to catch several fish at once in their spectacular bills.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Horned Puffin
stops.directionsToNextStop: Up next is a dark black/brown bird that is often found swimming in the waters around South Marble Island. A monochrome bird, look for its vivid orange/red feet just beneath the water's surface.

stops.significance: The pigeon guillemot's wings are rounded to help it 'fly' underwater. Like other birds at South Marble, it is an even more capable swimmer than flier.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Pigeon Guillemot
stops.directionsToNextStop: Another all-black bird with colorful accent features, your next stop is a bird that is often found at the shoreline. Don't disturb its nest, or this bird will raise a ruckus!

stops.significance: An all-black bird with a vivid orange beak, the black oystercatcher is a striking bird that nests just above the high tide line on Glacier Bay's beaches. Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Black Oystercatcher
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next bird might appear to be another all-black bird, but look close, this bird's feathers have a beautiful iridescence in certain lighting conditions. Continue the tour to find out which bird it is!

stops.significance: The pelagic cormorant is a striking bird. It's long neck and large wingspan allow it to fly with grace above the water's surface, and you are probably noticing a trend here, allows it to swim and fish with power and expert ability.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Pelagic Cormorant
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next bird is a smaller one, able to dive up to 500 feet deep to pursue fish and invertebrates.

stops.significance: The Common Murre is an understated bird, but remarkable nonetheless. They nest on rocky leges around South Marble Island, and their eggs have a unique characteristic: They are rounded at one end, which lets them roll in a circle, rather than off the side of the cliffs upon which they nest.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Common Murre
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop is for a bird you may have seen on your journey already. This bird is often found at South Marble Island, but also found throughout Glacier Bay. Flying just above the water's surface, they appear similar to a flying football or potato... any guesses?

stops.significance: The marbeled murrelet is a brown bird during their breeding season in Glacier Bay, their round bodies and low flight with rapid wing beats has earned them the nickname of "flying baked potatoes." Click explore to learn more and see anatomical statistics.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Marbled Murrelet
stops.directionsToNextStop: The final bird on your tour of South Marble Island is unique to Alaska and eastern Russia. These birds rely on glacial habitat to live, which makes Glacier Bay a great place to live, while glaciers are still present.

stops.significance: The final stop of your tour ends with the Kittlitz's Murrelet. A large portion of this bird's worldwide population is thought to live in Glacier Bay. Scientists continue to study these unassuming birds as glaciers melt and the habitat they rely on shrinks with the melting ice.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Kittlitz's Murrelet
stops.directionsToNextStop: Thanks for joining us on this tour of South Marble Islands many bird species! We hope you enjoy your visit to Glacier Bay.

images.title: South Marble Island bird's eye view
images.altText: aerial view of south marble island, a rocky outcropping. Trees and green cover the higher parts.
images.caption: Bird's eye view of South Marble Island

data.title: The Black Heritage Trail®
data.description: The Black Heritage Trail® showcases residences and community buildings associated with a Black community that thrived on, and near, the north slope of Beacon Hill before, during, and after the American Civil War. Throughout that time, this community struggled and organized for equal rights and access to equal education. Community members championed the movement to abolish slavery and even housed freedom seekers on their journey along the Underground Railroad.
tags: Boston African American National Historic Site

stops.significance: The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments. Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel. Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the U.S. forces. To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon St. across from the Massachusetts State House. Unveiled in 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon St. off to war in 1863.
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial
stops.directionsToNextStop: The Robert Gould Shaw/54th Massachusetts Regiment Memorial is on Beacon Street directly opposite the Massachusetts State House. Cross Beacon Street in front of the Massachusetts State House, near the intersection with Park Street. Turn left on Beacon Street. Turn right on Joy Street. Turn left onto Pinckney Street. George Middleton House is on the right side of the street at 5-7 Pinckney Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Virtual Black Heritage Trail. This tour explores the inspiring history of the free African American community of Beacon Hill in the 19th century, a community that led the city and the nation in the fight against slavery and racial injustice.  
We will be stopping at historic homes, churches, schools, and other important sites as we discuss the lives and legacies of these leaders and activists.  
Together with those that found common cause with them, this community helped turn Boston into a crucial center of the Abolition Movement, the Underground Railroad, and the early struggle for civil rights and equality.  
Facing powerful opposition both within the city and throughout the country, this community persevered, and in doing so, helped further Boston’s reputation as a "Cradle of Liberty" in the ongoing American Revolution.  
Our first stop is The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial, which commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments.  Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel.  
Notable abolitionists including Frederick Douglass and local leaders such as Lewis Hayden recruited men for the 54th Regiment. Men enlisted from every region of the country, and from as far away as Canada and the Caribbean.
Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the United States forces. 
Sergeant William H. Carney, severely injured in the battle, saved the regiment’s flag. For this act of bravery, he became the first African American recipient of the Medal of Honor. 
To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon Street across from the Massachusetts State House. Saint-Gaudens took nearly fourteen years to complete his masterpiece. 
Unveiled on May 31st, 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon Street off for war in 1863.
It stands as a powerful testament to the cost of freedom and to the true meaning of the Civil War.

stops.significance:
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. During the Revolution, George Middleton led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution. A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. Middleton and others also organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. As a community leader, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the George Middleton House, turn left and walk down Pinckney Street. The Phillips School is on the right, at the intersection of Pinckney and Anderson Streets. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Our next stop is the George Middleton House, which takes us right back to the late 1780s in Boston, in the years just after the American Revolution. The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts had declared slavery “inconsistent” with our State Constitution a few years earlier in 1783.  While Black families had begun settling this north slope of Beacon Hill about a generation before, in the mid-1760s, Middleton’s arrival to this emerging neighborhood signaled a new beginning as he and others in that Revolutionary generation staked their claim in Boston and laid the foundation for the larger abolition and equal rights movements to come.  
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. Glapion lived and ran his business here until his death in 1813. His wife, Lucy, continued to live here until 1832.
We know a little bit more about George Middleton.  During the Revolution, he led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution and may have also been known as the "Protectors." Near the close of the Revolution, Governor John Hancock presented Middleton and the Bucks of America with a company flag. According to the historian William Cooper Nell, this banner, now preserved in the collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society, served “as a tribute to their courage and devotion through the struggle.”
A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. In 1796, Middleton and others organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. He became a licensed teacher in that organization as well.
Middleton married Elsey Marsh in 1781 at Trinity Church and died in 1815, apparently not survived by his wife or children.
As a leader concerned with education, the abolition of slavery, and the needs of his community, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.

stops.significance: Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School. Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Phillips School from Pinckney Street, turn left. The John J. Smith House is on the left side of the street at 86 Pinckney Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Our next site is the Phillips School. Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. 
Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students, a stark reminder of the discrimination faced by Black children and families. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School.
To combat this injustice, Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. 
Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body. 
In 1863, the Phillips School moved to a new building on Phillips Street and became the Wendell Phillips School, named after the famed abolitionist and son of the school’s original namesake. 
In the early 1870s, Elizabeth Smith, daughter of abolitionist John J. Smith, started teaching at the Phillips School, likely becoming the first African American teacher in an integrated Boston public school.

stops.significance: John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893. Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him and helped him make his way to freedom in Canada. Smith and his wife, Georgiana, also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston. During the Civil War, Smith recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the John J. Smith House from Pickney Street, turn right. Turn left on to Cedar Lane Way. Turn right onto Mount Vernon Street and carefully cross Charles Street. Charles Street Meeting House is at the intersection of Charles and Mount Vernon Streets.
stops.audioTranscript:
John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893.
Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. His clients included the abolitionist Senator Charles Sumner, who could often be found at Smith’s barbershop while in town. His shop also reportedly served a rendezvous point for “secret councils” that offered protection and assistance to those escaping slavery on the Underground Railroad.
Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him. He hid out the rest of the day first in a home on the north slope of Beacon Hill, then just outside the city. Late that night, Smith, along with Lewis Hayden, secretly took Minkins to a safe house in Concord, where he stayed before making the rest of his way to freedom in Canada. 
Smith and his wife Georgiana also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston.
During the Civil War, he recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council where he worked successfully to have the first African American appointed to the Boston police force. Smith died in 1906 while living with his family in Dorchester.

stops.significance: Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. In April 1836, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew. The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation. He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church, which became officially recognized in 1839. In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation purchased the Charles Street Meeting House. This prompted one historian to note while African Americans once sat in one section of the church, "now they own the building." The Meeting House also served as a forum and gathering place for activists. For example, in 1895 Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other Black clubwomen formed the National Federation of Afro-American women, a precursor to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, becoming the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Standing with your back to the Charles Street Meeting House on Charles Street, turn left and walk a couple blocks. Turn right on to Revere Street, carefully crossing Charles Street. Turn left on to West Cedar Street. Turn right on to Phillips Street. The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House is on the right at 66 Phillips Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. Like most churches, the segregationist tradition of New England church seating patterns prevailed here. 
In April 1836, however, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew.  The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation.  
He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church. Officially recognized in 1839, this church eventually became Tremont Temple, considered “the first integrated church in America.” Tremont Temple declared that “’all who practice slavery or justify it shall be excluded from the church and its communion.’”  Tremont Temple soon hosted giants in the abolition movement including Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth and others. 
In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation, earlier located on today’s Anderson Street, purchased the Charles Street Meetinghouse.  This prompted one historian to note that in the early days of the Meeting House, African Americans could only sit in a certain section of the church, but “now they own the building.” 
In addition to religious services, the Charles Street Meeting House served as a forum and gathering place for activists.  For example, on the final day of the 1895 First National Conference of Colored Women of America, Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other local Black clubwomen organized a special session at Charles Street A.M.E. Church. Here, delegates from across the United States agreed to form the National Federation of Afro-American women, one of the precursors to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, even after many of its members had moved to the South End of Boston. It became the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill. Still called the Charles Street AME Church, it is now located in Roxbury in Boston.

stops.significance: The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated it as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. The Haydens notably assisted in high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases, helping William and Ellen Craft as well as Shadrach Minkins on their journeys to freedom. In addition to their Underground Railroad work, Lewis and Harriet played other prominent roles in the community. Lewis served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings, and participated in the Equal Schools movement. During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts regiments. Following the War, Lewis Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and, along with Harriet, lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Hayden House, turn left. Walk down Phillips Street. The John Coburn House is to the right facing Phillips Street at the intersection of Irving and Phillips Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. A long-time colleague of the Hayden, Henry Bowditch recalled that their house served as “the temple of refuge for any hunted refugee from Southern slavery.”  
Following the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Bostonians created their third and final Vigilance Committee, an organization dedicated to fugitive assistance. As one of the most active members of this committee, Lewis sheltered and assisted scores of freedom seekers. The Haydens provided shelter, clothing, carriages, and fare to get people out of the city and further North to freedom. 
In 1850, the Haydens sheltered the famous couple William and Ellen Craft who had escaped from slavery in Georgia through an elaborate disguise and story. The light-skinned Ellen dressed in men’s clothing and “passed” as a white male slaveholder traveling North by train and ship with her trusted “slave” William. In October 1850, slave catchers came looking for the couple in Boston’s first test of the new Fugitive Slave Law.  According to William Craft, “Lewis Hayden and I had a keg of gunpowder under his house ...with a fuse attached ready to light it should any attempt be made to capture us.” Given all of the abolitionist hostility and threats to their safety, the slave catchers abandoned their pursuit of the Crafts.  A journalist later wrote that the slave catcher called off  his pursuit because he “knew that the road to hell lay over Lewis Hayden’s threshold; and the cost to him would be rather more than the Slave Power would be ready to make up to him.” 
In addition to protecting the Crafts, Lewis also played a crucial role in other high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases in the city.  On February 15, 1851, slave catchers arrested Shadrach Minkins who had escaped from Virginia months earlier. Within three hours of the arrest, Hayden led a group of Black men in a daring courthouse rescue, freed Minkins from his captors, and successfully got him out of the city and further on the Underground Railroad network to Canada. In 1854, Hayden and others attempted to rescue Anthony Burns from federal custody at the same courthouse. Unfortunately, they failed, and authorities soon returned Burns to the South under heavy martial guard.  
In addition to his Underground Railroad work, Lewis played other prominent roles in his community. He served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings and participated in the Equal Schools movement. In the late 1850s, he began serving as Messenger to the Secretary of State, a politically appointed position, likely making him one of the first Black state employees.
During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts civil war regiments. Following the War, Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.
Harriet outlived her husband by four years.  When she passed away in 1893, she left her estate, valued at $5000, to Harvard University to establish the Lewis and Harriet Hayden Scholarship for Black students wishing to attend the Medical School.

stops.significance: Clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts. Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With back to John Coburn house, turn right to the intersection of Phillips and Irving Streets. Turn left down Irving Street. At Cambridge Street, turn right. Turn right on to Joy Street. Turn right at Smith Court. Smith Court Residences are on the right. NOTE: These houses are private residences and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Born in Boston in the early 1800s, clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. However, his community activism is far better documented.
Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. Formed in the early 1840s, this group sought “to extend a helping hand to all who may bid adieu to whips and chains, and by the welcome light of the North Star, reach a haven where they can be protected from the grasp of the man-stealer.” 
In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Witness reported seeing him at the courthouse “’making inflammatory remarks shortly before the rescue began.’” 
Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Though state officials ignored their requests for official recognition and support, the Massasoit Guards continued to operate as a force for community self-defense. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts.
Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.

stops.significance: As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home. Residents of 3 Smith Court, James Scott and William Cooper Nell, both sheltered freedom seekers in the 1850s. In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. He served as deacon of the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer Joseph Scarlett owned 7 Smith Court, 7A Smith Court, and 2 Smith Court. Living in 2 Smith Court, Scarlett rented out the other properties. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned 15 different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With back to the residences, walk directly ahead to the path between two brick buildings. The Abiel Smith School is on the left and is operated by the Museum of African American History. Walk down the stairs to the entrance of the Museum.
stops.audioTranscript:
As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home.
For example, 3 Smith Court has a long association of African American occupants as well as significant activists in Boston. James Scott, the longest resident of 3 Smith Court, lived here for nearly 50 years. Born in Virginia, Scott worked as a clothing dealer in Boston. In 1851, local authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Scott for his alleged role in the rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse. Though his involvement in the Shadrach rescue is unclear, Scott did assist other freedom seekers at his home, including Henry Jackson and his family as they made their way to freedom on the Underground Railroad in 1856. For most of the 1850s, William Cooper Nell also resided at 3 Smith Court. One of the most prominent community activists, Nell provided crucial leadership in the abolition movement and the struggle for equal education. With the publication of his book "Colored Patriots of the American Revolution," Nell became one of the first published African American historians.  Like Scott, he also sheltered freedom seekers at his home on Smith Court. 
In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. Born in Massachusetts in 1795, Washington worked as a bootblack and waiter.  He also served as deacon at the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Washington and his wife Rachel had ten children. Although he died in 1871, this house remained in the family until 1917. 
7 Smith Court served as rental property for Joseph Scarlett, an African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer.  He mainly rented to other African Americans including laborers and mariners that rarely stayed longer than three years at this property. 
Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. This became another rental property for Scarlett in 1858.  
2 Smith Court, built in 1853, served as the home and investment property for Scarlett as well. Prior to its construction, an earlier home stood on this site owned by William Henry, an African American tailor. Henry, his family, as well as some tenants lived here. Scarlett purchased the property in 1852, built this home, and lived here for most of the 1860s. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned fifteen different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown. In his will, Scarlett left bequests to the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church and to the Home for Aged Colored Women.

stops.significance: The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House. Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 1850s. William Cooper Nell led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than 15 years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855. Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the Museum at the Abiel Smith School. Walk up the stairs and directly ahead is the African Meeting House.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House.  
Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 50s.  
William Cooper Nell, who as student at the African School realized the inequality of segregated education, vowed at an early age to        “hasten the day when the color of the skin would be no barrier to equal school rights.” As an adult, he led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than fifteen years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855.  
On the day before the first day of school that year, Nell, then living at 3 Smith Court, recalled seeing a young Black student walk past the Smith School. “Good bye forever colored school!,” the student said, “Tomorrow we are like the other Boston boys.”
Following this landmark victory, the Smith School closed briefly then later reopened as an integrated primary school for a time. It also became a storage facility for the city, as well as a home to several veterans’ posts.  
Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.

stops.significance: Built in 1806, the Meeting House stands as the oldest surviving Black church structure in the nation. It first served as the home for the First African Baptist Church. It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes. The Meeting House also served as a gathering space for social activism. Maria Stewart, William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others used its platform to fight for equal school rights, the end of slavery, and for civil rights. During the Civil War, the Meeting House became a recruitment center for the MA 54th Regiment. A Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s, it became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.
stops.audioTranscript:
We conclude our virtual tour here at the African Meeting House, a fitting location, as this place was such powerful center of African American community life and culture in 19th century Boston.  
Built in 1806, the Meeting House served as the home for the First African Baptist Church, originally headed by Reverend Thomas Paul, a key leader and activist in the community. 
It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes.  
The Meeting House also served as gathering space for social activism. This is where you joined with William Cooper Nell as he advocated for Equal School Rights. This is where Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others protested the Fugitive Slave Law and planned how to assist freedom seekers that came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. This is where you came in the early 1830s to hear Maria Stewart call for the end of slavery and for equal rights for women. This is where the Massachusetts General Colored Association came together to fight for the end of slavery and discrimination throughout the country. It is where William Lloyd Garrison formed the New England Antislavery Society, whose principles he said would quote “shake the nation by their mighty power.” It also served as a recruitment center for the 54th Regiment.
In his recruitment speech for the 54th, Frederick Douglass said "... We can get at the throat of treason and slavery through the State of Massachusetts. She was first in the War of Independence; first to break the chains of her slaves; first to make the black man equal before the law; first to admit colored children to her common schools, and she was first to answer with her blood the alarm cry of the nation, when its capital was menaced by rebels. You know her patriotic governor, and you know Charles Summer. I need not add more. Massachusetts now welcomes you to arms as soldiers."
This is such a ringing endorsement of the central role played by Boston in the fight against slavery and racial injustice...so much of which emanated from this neighborhood, from this community, and from within the walls of the African Meeting House.
The Meeting House continued to serve as a Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s. It became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.  
In 1980, Boston African American National Historic Site was created as a partner with the Museum to keep these important sites preserved and protected, and to keep these crucial stories of our ongoing American Revolution alive.  
Thank you for joining us for this tour of the Black Heritage Trail.

images.title: The Black Heritage Trail®
images.altText: Smith Court with brick buildings surrounding the court.
images.caption: Smith Court is home to three stops on The Black Heritage Trail®.

data.title: The British Occupation of Philadelphia
data.description: Hear stories of the officers, soldiers, and civilians during the British Occupation of Philadelphia from September 1777 to June 1778. Which side would you choose?

stops.significance: Benjamin Franklin constructed a large and elegant house in this quiet courtyard, outlined at present by a modern steel "ghost" structure. During the occupation, Franklin was in Paris negotiating an alliance with the French. While he was away, British General Charles Grey took up residence in Franklin’s large, three story home. It was one of the finest in the city, and contained a library and electrical equipment. The British stole many of Franklin’s musical instruments, books, and printing tools as well as his portrait. When told that General Howe had captured Philadelphia, Franklin replied, “It is Philadelphia that has captured Howe.” The city that had once so charmed Franklin seemed to have the same effect on the British officers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the Franklin Court courtyard through the alley toward Chestnut Street. Turn right on Chestnut Street. Cross over Chestnut Street at 4th Street. Turn left on Chestnut Street. Halfway down the block on the right is the entrance to Carpenters' Court. Carpenters' Hall is straight ahead.  It will be closed for renovation beginning on April 17, 2022.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the summer of 1777, British General William Howe embarked on a journey with a bold mission. Capture the enemy city of Philadelphia, and lower the spirit of those Americans who favored independence. Prior to the occupation, panic gripped the city. Some residents fled, but others stayed, uncertain of what the future would bring. The British marched into the city in late September 1777.

During the occupation, Dr. Franklin was in Paris negotiating an alliance with the French. While he was away, British General Charles Grey took up residence in Franklin’s large, three story home. The home used to stand where you see the larger steel framed structure today. It was one of the finest in the city, and contained a library and electrical equipment. The British stole many of Franklin’s musical instruments, books, and printing tools as well as his portrait. When told that General Howe had captured Philadelphia, Franklin replied, “It is Philadelphia that has captured Howe.” The city that had once so charmed Franklin seemed to have the same effect on the British officers.

stops.significance: Philadelphia’s population nearly doubled once the bulk of the British army arrived to occupy the city. Here at Carpenters’ Hall—where the First Continental Congress met in 1774—British soldiers were treated for their wounds. Local residents worked in the building’s basement, weaving blankets and stitching clothes. For six weeks, conditions were difficult. City residents and the British army lacked food, clothing, firewood and other necessities because supply ships could not reach the city. The American garrison at Ft. Mifflin on the Delaware River posed one obstacle for the ships. The Americans had also placed chevaux de frise, devices used to impale ships’ hulls, in the Delaware River.  Aiding the British was Philadelphian Abraham Carlisle, a member of the Carpenters’ Company.  He informed the British where these devices were hidden. When the American garrison fell, the British used the Carlisle's information to bring their supply ships into the city. Carlisle was later tried and hanged for treason.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path to the right of Carpenters' Hall, heading toward 4th Street. Turn right on 4th Street, heading toward Chestnut Street. Turn left on Chestnut Street, crossing over 4th Street. Continue on Chestnut Street toward 5th Street. Cross over 5th Street. Enter the security screening area just past Old City Hall. Bear to the right after exiting the screening area. Independence Hall is the large brick building with the bell tower in the middle of the lock. Timed entry tickets are required to see the interior of the building from March through December, and winter holiday weekends.
stops.audioTranscript: Philadelphia’s population nearly doubled once the bulk of the British army arrived to occupy the city in late September 1777. Here at Carpenters’ Hall—where the First Continental Congress met in 1774—British soldiers were treated for their wounds. Local residents worked tirelessly in the building’s basement, weaving blankets and stitching clothes for the poor. For six weeks, conditions were difficult. City residents and the British army lacked food, clothing, firewood and other necessities because supply ships could not reach the city. The American garrison at Ft. Mifflin on the Delaware River posed one obstacle for the ships. The Americans had also placed chevaux de frise, devices used to impale ships’ hulls, in the Delaware River.  Aiding the British was Philadelphian Abraham Carlisle, a member of the Carpenters’ Company.  He informed the British where these devices were hidden. The American garrison finally fell, and using the information provided by Carlisle, the British were able to bring their supply ships into the city. Carlisle was later tried and hanged for treason.

stops.significance: In late September 1777, the British army sacked the city. Some of the soldiers made quarters in the Assembly Room of this building, where the Declaration the Independence had been adopted a year earlier. A large pit was dug nearby, where the British disposed of dead men, horses and garbage. The stench was so unbearable that the State House could not be used for a number of months after the American army returned in 1778. A large room spanning the second floor, called the Long Gallery, took on a new use. In happier times, it was a place where Pennsylvania officials hosted elaborate banquets and parties. During the occupation, it was the scene of illness and death. The British imprisoned wounded or ill American officers there.  The sick and dying were placed on litters. Some prisoners were able to survive. Others succumbed to their afflictions. Imagine—as a soldier—dying for your country in the very building were the country was founded.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Explore the open area with the benches behind Independence Hall. Please remain within the security area.
stops.audioTranscript: In late September 1777, the British army sacked the city. Some of the soldiers made quarters in the Assembly Room of this building, where the Declaration the Independence had been adopted a year earlier. A large pit was dug nearby, where the British disposed of dead men, horses and garbage. The stench was so unbearable that the State House could not be used for a number of months after the American army returned in 1778. A large room spanning the second floor, called the Long Gallery, took on a new use. In happier times, it was a place where Pennsylvania officials hosted elaborate banquets and parties. During the occupation, it was the scene of illness and death. The British imprisoned wounded or ill American officers there.  The sick and dying were placed on litters. Some prisoners were able to survive. Others succumbed to their afflictions. Imagine—as a soldier—dying for your country in the very building were the country was founded.

stops.significance: On July 8th, 1776, the Declaration of Independence was publicly read here in the yard before a large, enthusiastic crowd. Little over a year later, Philadelphians witnessed red-coated British soldiers marching in precision in the same yard.  Across the street, where you see an insurance company building today, sat the Walnut Street jail. Here the British incarcerated American soldiers and ordinary citizens. These citizens had been accused of aiding the enemy cause. Philadelphia Loyalist Joseph Galloway implemented a network of over 80 spies. The spies were city residents who passed along information about their friends or neighbors to Galloway. Those imprisoned met a harsh fate. Hundreds died of mistreatment, beatings and starvation under the approval of Provost Marshal William Cunningham. Philadelphia resident Mrs. Eliza Farmar wrote that one day she sent broth and other food to the prisoners. Cunningham kicked the broth over onto the dirt and laughed as the starving prisoners tried to lap it up.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head toward Congress Hall and look for the exit gate in front of the building. Exit the secure area at 6th and Chestnut Streets. Turn left and walk down 6th Street toward Walnut Street. Cross over Walnut Street. The entrance to Washington Square is on the right.
stops.audioTranscript:
On July 8th, 1776, the Declaration of Independence was publicly read here in the yard before a large, enthusiastic crowd.  Little over a year later, Philadelphians witnessed red-coated British soldiers marching in precision in the same yard.  It was the fall of 1777 and the British occupation was underway.

Across the street, where you see an insurance company building today, sat the Walnut Street jail.  Here the British incarcerated American soldiers and ordinary citizens.  These citizens had been accused of aiding the enemy cause.  Philadelphia Loyalist Joseph Galloway implemented a network of over 80 spies.  The spies were city residents who passed along information about their friends or neighbors to Galloway.  Those imprisoned met a harsh fate.  Hundreds died of mistreatment, beatings and starvation under the approval of Provost Marshal William Cunningham.  Philadelphia resident Mrs. Eliza Farmar wrote that one day she sent broth and other food to the prisoners.  Cunningham kicked the broth over onto the dirt and laughed as the starving prisoners tried to lap it up.

stops.significance: Formerly called Southeast Square, Washington Square was one of the five public squares laid out by William Penn’s surveyor, Thomas Holme. In the 18th century, it was a pasture as well as a potters’ field, or burial ground. During the British occupation in 1777 and 1778, American soldiers died while incarcerated in the nearby Walnut Street jail. Others succumbed to their wounds on the second floor of Independence Hall. The British buried some of those men in this Square. It is believed that several thousand British and American soldiers are buried here, in unmarked graves. Look for the Tomb of the Unknown Revolutionary War soldier. Today, an eternal flame burns in memoriam where the remains of an American soldier lie in silent repose.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit Washington Square at 6th and Walnut Streets (where you entered). Walk up 6th Street to Market Street. Turn right on Market Street. The President's House Site is on the right.
stops.audioTranscript: Formerly called Southeast Square, Washington Square was one of the five public squares laid out by William Penn’s surveyor, Thomas Holme.  In the 18th century, it was a pasture as well as a potters’ field, or burial ground.  John Adams, delegate to the Second Continental Congress from Massachusetts, visited here before the British occupation of Philadelphia.  He wrote to his wife Abigail, “I have spent an hour this morning, in the congregation of the dead.  I took a walk into the Potters Field, a burying ground…and I never in my whole life was affected with so much melancholy.” During the British occupation in 1777 and 1778, American soldiers died while incarcerated in the nearby Walnut Street jail.  Others succumbed to their wounds on the second floor of Independence Hall.  The British buried some of those men in this Square.  It is believed that several thousand British and American soldiers are buried here, in unmarked graves.  Look for the Tomb of the Unknown Revolutionary War soldier.  Today, an eternal flame burns in memoriam where the remains of an American soldier lie in silent repose.

stops.significance:
In 1777-1778, British General William Howe made himself at home in this large house vacated by Pennsylvania proprietor Richard Penn.  Later occupants included American General Benedict Arnold and Presidents Washington and Adams.

During the British Occupation, General Howe hosted parties here.  He and the other British officers also attended lavish affairs all across the city.  They – along with Philadelphia’s Loyalist elite-socialized at everything from foot races to play performances.  

Although the home was demolished in 1832, the foundations are still embedded in the ground and form part of the outdoor exhibit. The exhibit examines the paradox between slavery and freedom, and includes a memorial wall recognizing those who toiled in bondage at this site. Located just steps from the Liberty Bell Center, the exhibit is open daily from 7am to 10pm. No tickets are required, and there is no admission fee.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the President's House Site on Market Street. Continue toward 5th Street. Cross over 5th Street. Walk 3 blocks to 2nd Street. Turn left on 2nd Street. Look for the church steeple. Christ Church is on the left, in the middle of the block.
stops.audioTranscript:
The British occupied Philadelphia in the fall of 1777.  British General William Howe resided comfortably with his staff here in a large home.  The house had been vacated by Pennsylvania’s proprietor Richard Penn.

Howe hosted and attended lavish parties throughout the city.  Foot races, cockfights, sleigh rides and play performances entertained British officers and Philadelphia’s Loyalist elite during the winter.  In May 1778, Howe’s officers held a lavish farewell for their commanding officer, who had received orders to return to England.  This grand affair was called the Meschianza, Italian for “mixing and mingling”.  It featured everything from music to a mock jousting tournament to fireworks and a midnight supper.  A month later, the British army left Philadelphia and marched north.  The American army returned to the city, and American General Benedict Arnold took up residence at this site.  Arnold later changed sides and decided to fight for the British.  In the 1790s, Presidents Washington and Adams also lived here.  Look for the foundations of the home once occupied by Generals and Presidents.

stops.significance:
Both patriots and loyalists worshipped at Christ Church. During the Revolutionary War, Rector Jacob Duche initially supported the American cause, serving as chaplain to the Second Continental Congress. But Duche remained in the city when the British invaded in 1777. During Sunday services at Christ Church, he said prayers on behalf of King George III, perhaps fearing retribution for his allegiance to the Congress. Despite this, the British arrested Duche.  After a night in the Walnut Street jail, Duche recanted his allegiance to the United States. He even sent a letter to General Washington urging him to surrender. Washington was furious, but later came to believe that Duche’s actions were motivated by fear. Duche left with the British army and sailed to England. After the war, he returned to Philadelphia. 
Take a moment to consider the impact of the occupation on all Philadelphians. If you were living in Philadelphia during the British occupation, which side would you choose?
stops.audioTranscript:
Both patriots and loyalists worshipped at Christ Church.  During the Revolutionary War, Rector Jacob Duche initially supported the American cause, serving as chaplain to the Second Continental Congress.  But Duche remained in the city when the British invaded in 1777 .  During Sunday services at Christ Church, he said prayers on behalf of King George III, perhaps fearing retribution for his allegiance to the Congress.  Despite this, the British arrested Duche.  After a night in the Walnut Street jail, Duche recanted his allegiance to the United States.  He even sent a letter to General Washington urging him to surrender.  Washington was furious, but later came to believe that Duche’s actions were motivated by fear.  Duche left with the British army and sailed to England.  After the war, he returned to Philadelphia.

Sit in George Washington’s pew and take a moment to consider the impact of the occupation on all Philadelphians.  Those loyal to the American cause tended to keep their real feelings to themselves.  Many Quakers remained neutral.  Other people expressed happiness that the British had “rescued” their city from the Congress.  If you were living in Philadelphia during the British occupation, which side would you choose?

images.title: The State House After the Battle
images.altText: A 19th century painting showing wounded soldiers being treated at Independence Hall.
images.caption: After the Battle of Germantown, The British army housed wounded soldiers inside Independence Hall.

data.title: The Business of Slavery
data.description: The history of this coastal region includes stories of hard work, noble ideals and freedom. These narratives become less romantic and more difficult to understand when we include the story of slavery. On this walking tour, we’ll explore how enslaved labor in the West Indies fueled colonial New England’s economy and examine the story of a well-known Salem merchant, Richard Derby, to consider the opportunities slavery afforded white colonists.

stops.significance: In Salem, fish would not only be a vital food source but the ticket to a global trade market.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed to the Derby Wharf gravel path. Head towards Derby Street and cross at the crosswalk to stand in front of the Custom House. Follow the sidewalk on your right around to the back and through a fence.
stops.audioTranscript:
The first British colonists to settle on the shores of present day Salem arrived in 1626. They traveled from nearby Cape Ann, abandoning a fishing settlement that failed to produce profit. Within three years fishing stages were constructed on Winter Island to unload and clean large quantities of fish.  

By the 1640s, Salem merchants were exporting Atlantic cod fish to slave plantations in the West Indies, also known as the Caribbean. Some scholars call this the “business of slavery,” the trade commodities bought and sold that created and maintained the system of slavery. This business of slavery connected New England to a global market stretching across the Atlantic, known today as the Atlantic slave economy.     

Through the American Revolution, Salem’s most profitable trading relationship remained with slave plantations in the West Indies. The business of slavery provided employment, generated industry, garnered wealth, and touched the life of every resident as it became the center of New England’s economy. And as New England’s role continued to expand in the Atlantic slave economy, so too did the threat to England’s authority.

stops.significance: Before American independence, the British Customs Service collected duties (taxes) on imported cargo. Later the U.S. Customs Service stored cargo in bonded warehouses like this one until merchants paid duties and storage fees. This system allowed merchants to maximize profit by waiting for trade goods to increase in value before paying duties and putting goods on the market.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the way you came and head back towards Derby Street. Take a left down the sidewalk passing the yellow house with a white fence. Stop at the next brick house on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the West Indies, Salem merchants traded fish and other food products, like onions and potatoes. These commodities maintained the system of slavery as the food source for enslaved people. Salem merchants returned with trade goods produced at forced labor camps, also known as slave plantations. The most profitable commodities were sugar and its byproduct molasses, which was distilled into rum and consumed locally or exported across the Atlantic. A demand for these and other products, like tobacco, coffee, and cacao, created the system of slavery.  

Richard Derby’s sailing vessel, Schooner Pembrock, travelled from Salem to Dominica with twelve barrels of fish in 1764. The cargo also included eleven horses, sold at 20 pounds each, and nine feet of boards, lumber used to fuel fires and construct buildings and barrels.   

The Pembrock returned to Salem with barrels, known as hogsheads, filled with the products of enslaved labor. It’s cargo included one hogshead of coffee, four hogsheads of sugar, and 90 and a half hogsheads of molasses. By 1770, Essex County was home to at least 19 rum distilleries, with 5 in Salem alone. Most were owned or financed by the same merchants who imported molasses, like Richard Derby.

stops.significance: Wealthy Salem merchants amassed enough wealth to own large houses, fishing stations, fishing and trading vessels, rum distilleries, farms, and wharves. Stories of colonial prosperity speak to hard work, innovation, and are early examples of the American dream fulfilled in the business of slavery.
stops.directionsToNextStop: To the right of the Derby House is a blue building called the West India Goods Store.
stops.audioTranscript:
Richard Derby, like many merchants and sea captains, built his fortune from the business of slavery. The slave economy stretched across the Atlantic, but in Salem, the center of trade was the harbor. For this reason, the Derby House was built directly across from the busy wharves. In 1762, Richard Derby gifted this house to his son, Elias Hasket Derby. Elias joined his father’s business and went on to make his own fortune, becoming one of the region’s wealthiest merchants, often recognized as the nation’s first millionaire.   

But the business of slavery reached far beyond the wealthy merchant-class. Small-scale farmers and fishermen supplied the food products exported to feed enslaved people in the West Indies. As this trade steadily increased through the 17th and 18th centuries, shipbuilding became a major industry in port cities like Salem. It employed ironworkers, ship builders, carpenters, sailmakers, and various other skilled positions. Fishing vessels and larger trading vessels included crews of ship boys, sailors, and captains. Shopkeepers sold the various goods produced in forced labor camps. Rum distillers used molasses to produce rum, which was widely purchased and consumed throughout New England.  

By the outbreak of the American Revolution, almost 80% of New England’s exports were traded in the West Indies, where colonists depended on New England for supplies to operate the forced labor camps–mainly fish, lumber, and livestock. Today, a four-foot sculpture of an Atlantic cod fish hangs in the Massachusetts’ state capitol as a tribute to the trade that built the colony—the business of slavery.

stops.significance: This structure, built by Captain Henry Prince, was documented in Salem directories as a “West India Goods Store” from 1836 to 1851. Like other retail shops, this store sold items from all over the world, in addition to local produce and products. Items from the West Indies–sugar, molasses, coffee, indigo–were the products of forced labor camps, also known as slave plantations.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go back towards the Custom House and cross Derby Street at the crosswalk. Walk down the Derby Wharf gravel path passing a large wood-sided building. The ship will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
Before Salem colonists could purchase coffee or consume rum, Caribbean trade goods had to be produced at forced labor camps in the West Indies. Sugar production especially relied on intense, physical labor.    

During harvest time, enslaved men and women worked as teams to cut towering sugarcane. The backbreaking work lasted as long as the mills were running, usually from about 4 PM to 10 AM, though some accounts describe mills running 24 hours straight. At the mill, enslaved workers fed the cane through huge rollers to extract juice. At the boiling house, enslaved workers strained syrup under suffocating heat.  

At every stage the labor was dangerous, especially with little to no rest. One visitor to a Brazilian sugar plantation described the scene as, “People the color of the very night, working briskly and moaning at the same time without a moment of peace or rest, whoever sees all the confused and noisy machinery...will say that this indeed is the image of Hell.”  

The Atlantic slave economy resulted in the kidnapping, murder, and enslavement of millions of Africans. The same economic system generated privilege, power, and wealth for others across the Atlantic world as sugar became known as the “white gold.”

stops.significance: The original FRIENDSHIP was built in 1796 in a Salem shipbuilding yard. This trading vessel traveled across the Atlantic world, including one trip to Venezuela in 1799. It returned with products of enslaved labor–cocoa, indigo, and coffee.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Go back to the gravel path. It runs the entire length of Derby Wharf. As you head back towards Derby Street, an open lawn area will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
During the Pequot War, over two hundred Indigenous people were captured in New England. Some were enslaved in colonial towns like Salem while others were forcibly transported to the West Indies. In 1637, the Salem-owned ship DESIRE, carried 15 boys and 2 women of the Pequot Nation to the island of Providence and returned the following year with cotton, tobacco, and enslaved Africans.  

The business of slavery was a system of capitalism, producers making profit by supplying consumer demands, in this case, people. Slavery’s main purpose was to maximize profits by using unpaid labor to produce goods and services.  

In 1741, Richard Derby received a Captain’s Orders from Benjamin Gerrish Jr., instructing Derby to purchase an enslaved African boy, about 17 years old, while trading in Barbados. The following year Gerrish visited Derby’s wife and then wrote Derby to say, “I... delivered your wife a note of hand...for your quarter of Negro man Jack, which I sold for 120 pounds.”   

As New England merchants became more involved in the Atlantic slave economy and generated more wealth, they too began purchasing people as if they were commodities capable of being sold. In 1755, Richard Derby listed, “wine, rum, and a Negro boy” in a shipping manifest. He would go on to enslave at least six people in his Salem home.

stops.significance: With increasing fortune, Richard and Elias Hasket Derby began construction of Derby Wharf in 1762. The wharf became a center of maritime trade and later privateering during the Revolutionary War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk up the gravel path and cross Derby Street to stand in front of the Custom House.
stops.audioTranscript:
British colonists in the West Indies struggled to compete with the low prices of neighboring French, Dutch, and Spanish colonies. British colonists from New England easily smuggled foreign trade-goods, ignoring tax regulations and generating significant profit. By the mid-18th century, the business of slavery had transformed Salem from a rural fishing village to a thriving market town of five thousand. But from Great Britain’s point of view, the illegal trade was a threat to the empire’s power and prosperity. The solution was a stricter enforcement of tax regulations, authorized in the 1764 Sugar Act.  

Merchants saw the act as a threat to their freedom—their right to conduct trade in the West Indies in the most profitable way possible. The solution was to discourage British Customs agents from enforcing regulations by punishing those that dared to. 

In September of 1768, a British customs agent in Salem was dragged to the Common and attacked by a mob of outraged men, including Richard Derby. The agent, Thomas Row, became a target after reporting a group of colonists secretly removing molasses from a ship without paying taxes. The angry mob waxed the hair from his head, covered him with tar and feathers, and beat him, before parading him on a cart through town for all to see.  

The business of slavery was so fundamental to New England, that similar protests erupted into riots in other port cities. Almost ten years before the Boston Tea Party, sugar and its by-product molasses were fueling a fire that would lead to revolution.

stops.significance: The business of slavery continued in New England following the Revolutionary War with the U.S. Customs Service collecting taxes on goods produced by forced labor.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1792, Elias Hasket Derby traded fish, barrels of beef, legs of bacon, flour, and beets at forced labor camps in the West Indies. Merchants continued to import trade goods produced on slave plantations. Now the U.S. Customs Service, as opposed to the British Customs Service, collected the taxes responsible for building a treasury and funding a nation.  

New England’s participation in the Atlantic slave economy is still largely untold, partly because American history often follows a narrative of hard work and free labor. But history is complex, an ongoing discovery process as new questions develop and more perspectives are explored.  It’s also an opportunity to reflect on the significance of stories and their relevancy in a modern world. 

Leaving this tour we invite you to consider—does understanding a history of injustice help you understand a fight for freedom today?

images.title: FRIENDSHIP OF SALEM
images.altText: Black and white photo of large sailing vessel travelling through open water.
images.caption: The FRIENDSHIP was a trading vessel that traveled the world.

data.title: The Confederate Line of Cheatham Hill
data.description: This self-guided tour will explore some of the key points of the Confederate defensive position and their actions near Cheatham Hill during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.

stops.significance: Monument honoring the Texas regiments present during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. Monument also stands at the location where most of the regiments were located during the battle.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Cheatham Hill drive for less than half a mile. Next stop 'The Truce' will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript: The Texas Monument is dedicated to the Texans that fought here at the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. There were roughly 8 regiments that fought in this general area. This particular part of the Confederate defensive line was particularly well fortified and extremely difficult for the Union to penetrate. Private W.T. Barnes of the 1st Arkansas Infantry regiment writes "We had cut down and placed in our front hundreds of black jack saplings as abattis, cutting off the tips of the limbs with our jackknives and whittling them so sharp and close it would have been an uphill business for a rabbit to creep through"

stops.significance: This was the site of a notable truce during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain. Both sides ceased firing and worked together to drag wounded and burning men to safety.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Cheatham Hill Dr. to where it dead ends into a parking lot. The next stop 'Mebane's Battery' will be just beyond the parking lot at the trailhead.
stops.audioTranscript: While war is full of horror and chaos, it is not without it's rare and seemingly random acts of grace. One notable example happened near this spot during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. W.T. Barnes of the 1st Arkansas describes the scene: " .. our cannon were placed for execution. Their redoubts so low, the cannon's mouth nearly on the ground, and at every discharge a blaze of fire sprang out among the dry leaves, which were soon ablaze and eating their way toward the gully, which was full of a mass of human beings, squirming around... Ah, but little can a peaceful citizen imagine the horror of war...At this stage our colonel, Will H. Martin, sang out, "'Boys, this is butchery,"' and, mounting our head logs, with a white hankerchief, he sang out to the Yanks as well as to our own men, "'Cease firing and help get out those men."' Col. Martin's actions would save the lives of many Union soldiers in that incident. In a show of respect for this act of humanity, one of the Union officers would present Col. Martin with a pair of pearl-handled Colt revolvers.

stops.significance: Key artillery position utilized by the Confederate defense during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take wide dirt path to the right of the earthworks. Continue 150 - 200 yards until you get to the Illinois Monument and the next stop 'The Dead Angle'. Location will be on your left.
stops.audioTranscript: Confederate artillery, especially in this position, played a key part in the defense of Cheatham Hill. Major General Benjamin Cheatham (for whom this location is named) planned his defense very strategically. As early as June 24th, Cheatham would order the batteries "to be closely masked with brush and under no circumstances to reply to the artillery of the enemy'. This strategy would be effective in essentially keeping the Federals in the dark as to where the Confederate artillery was and what kind of artillery they had. As a result, when the thickly amassed column of Union infantry approached during the battle on the 27th, they made it to within 60 yards of this position without knowing any cannons were there at all. Cheatham writes "The advance was nearly all swept down by the first volley, the remainder being driven in confusion into the ranks of the assaulting mass". Also, this and the batteries on the right and left of it created a deadly crossfire for the upcoming infantry, creating chaos. This 2 gun section was commanded by John W. Mebane, under Lieutenant J. W. Phillips. The guns in this section were most likely 12 pound Napoleans, just like the ones that sit here today.

stops.significance: Arguably the most violent and chaotic location during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain and the site of the most casualties.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From here, follow the trail east, with the Illinois Monument on your right, and the earthworks on your left. Travel a short distance down a small hill to the next and last stop, 'The Grave of the Unknown Soldier'. Stop will be on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The 'Dead Angle' was the site of perhaps the bloodiest and most chaotic fighting during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. The name comes from not only the bloodshed, but also the 'dead space' offered by the angle, meaning that anyone in this position would not be visible to those in the earthworks above. Still visible today, this bulge or 'salient' in the Confederate defenses was where roughly 8 regiments (over 1,000) of Union soldiers concentrated their attack. Making it past the various field fortifications, the Federals make it to the top of the 8 foot tall earthen works and the fighting dissolves into hand to hand combat, with men using their muskets as clubs. Sam Watkins of the 1st Tennessee Infantry writes "My pen is unable to describe the scene of carnage and death that ensued in the next two hours...talk about other battles, victories, shouts, cheers, and triumphs, but in comparison with this day's fight, all other dwarf into insignificance."

Despite the 'carnage', the Confederate line held. Lieutenant Thomas Maney of the 1st Tennessee writes 'the word passed down to us to hold the works at all hazards, and it did look as if we would be pushed back by sheer force. But stand we must, and stand we did." The Union soldiers attacking both sides of the angle would fall back, but the ones assaulting the angle itself would dig in directly below the works, taking advantage of the 'dead space'. Today, the Illinois Monument marks that position.

stops.significance: A grave honoring an unknown soldier of the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. This is the only official burial in the park.
stops.assetName: The Grave of the Unknown Soldier
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop of this tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
One of the tragic, inescapable results of the Civil War was death on a colossal scale. Perhaps even more tragic is the presence of the unknown dead in those ranks. Honored and interred here is an unknown soldier from the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. While many of the other soldiers who perished here were reinterred in soldier's cemeteries, this young man's remains were missed. They were discovered in the trenches near this location in early 1934 by the Work's Progress Administration (WPA) as part of a trail building project. His remains were moved to this current location in order to be closer to the trail. A ceremony was held to honor his service and memory on July 1st, 1934 and his casket was lowered into the grave draped in both a U.S and Confederate flag. His grave sits directly in between in what was both the Union and Confederate lines.
