Scriptures were read from the pulpit, reconstructed on the east wall beside the sanctuary. The service was conducted in a combination of Latin, Spanish, and O’odham.
 
Standing under the high dome, you might imagine the brightly painted decorations on the walls and ceilings, flickering candles, the congregants kneeling in the nave, the sound of chants, prayers, and song reverberating through the room. The combination of these things was meant to create a mental distance from the day’s hard work happening just outside the doors.

The O’odham and Yoeme people of the mission might have found the rituals of the Mass strange upon first introduction to the Catholic faith. The practice of kneeling, standing, and then kneeling again, during a ceremony conducted in primarily foreign tongues, was no doubt confusing for some. Eventually, however, these strange customs became familiar and blended with the spiritual and religious beliefs of the indigenous communities. Today, many O’odham and Yoeme people practice this uniquely intertwined religious tradition.

stops.directionsToNextStop: At the base of the ramp, look up and to the left to see the opening of the choir loft.
stops.audioTranscript:
Step through the arched entryway and into the remains of an impressive nave, the central hall of the church. In this room, indigenous people and Spanish settlers prayed and celebrated the Mass each day. There were no pews. People knelt or stood during services. Along the walls are four side altars where devotional candles might be placed. In the walls above are niches where ornate statues of saints once stood.

Along the interior walls, weathering has exposed the sun-dried adobe bricks made by mission residents. The once brightly-painted walls were decorated by the steady hands of artisans both indigenous and Spanish.

With the rising sun, families and individuals living in the mission would make their way to the nave to gather and start the day. It is likely that men and women were separated by sex, as was the colonial manner. Here, indigenous people learned and practiced new religious traditions in new languages. They adopted new deities and established a new worldview under the direction of the padres. In this space, there were tears, both happy and sad. There was loss, celebration, learning, and change.

Shortly after the residents left in 1848, the roof timbers were taken by local settlers for construction elsewhere. For the next seventy years, the nave was exposed and heavily damaged by weather. Looters, seeking Jesuit treasure that never existed, dug holes in the walls and floors.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn left at the base of the ramp into the small baptistry room.
stops.audioTranscript:
Facing the front door of the church, you can see where the choir loft once stood. Notice the entrance to the balcony high on the left wall, and the ruined bases of the two pillars that supported the arch below it.

Music played an important role in mission life, as it always had in the lives of the O’odham and Yoeme. Tumacácori likely supported anywhere from eight to ten choir members, both men and women, at a given time. There were also musicians who played instruments such as oboe, flute, and zither (guitar), adding flourish to the sound of the Masses and other religious ceremonies held here.

Singers needed to memorize up to twenty-five songs for the community’s Masses, services, and processions. Despite the fact that few could read or write, they learned and performed hymns and kyries in Latin, Greek, Spanish, and O’odham. 

You are welcome to sing a few bars of your favorite song here. The excellent acoustics of the building are no accident—the sound, along with the height, color, and beauty of the space, were designed to inspire feelings of awe, and a sense of power and majesty.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the church up the ramp through the front door. Turn around to examine the façade.
stops.audioTranscript:
To the right of the church entrance is a small room where baptisms were performed. The room is composed of sun-dried adobe walls, nine feet thick with an inner rock core, which support the bell tower above. The stairway (inaccessible to visitors for reasons of safety) leads to the choir loft, the robing room, and beyond to the bell tower and roof.

Baptism was the first major sacrament undertaken by mission residents. Adults participated in religious instruction in order to learn about the doctrine of the Catholic church. Infants were baptized by padres with the permission and presence of the parents. All newly baptized individuals were given at least one godmother or godfather whose job it was to provide spiritual support. In the baptistry, the Catholic religion officially became a part of the lives of community members.

How did the new converts undergoing baptism feel? Were they apprehensive? Proud? Would they have to give up their traditional beliefs, or could they practice all of their spiritual beliefs simultaneously? We may never know. One thing is certain, though, this room was a space of transition and change.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Look up and to the right of the main façade to the exposed brick bell tower. (No need to leave the pavement here.)
stops.audioTranscript:
Spanish maestros de obra used architectural traditions from across the globe. The capitals at the tops of the columns are Egyptian in style. The plastered arch design over the front door is Roman. The pointed tops on the statue niches on the second level come from the Moorish influence of the middle east and northern Africa. Even the bell tower niche scallop shell motif, a nod to Spain’s patron saint, has Roman origins.

Spain’s influences made their way to Tumacácori in color, as well. The columns on the front of the church were painted red, the capitals yellow with black markings. Statues stood against a blue background in their niches. The plaster of the doorway was carved and painted to resemble blocks of orange marble. You can still see original paint in the doorway and under the cornice below the window.

The monumental building with its bright color scheme and decorative elements would have been unlike anything in O’odham tradition. Previously, natural features like springs and mountains provided a community’s identity and place name. But after the O’odham labored for more than twenty years to build this new face for their village, it became a landscape feature itself, and a symbol for Tumacácori’s complex story.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the paved path around the rectangular vats to the next intersection.
stops.audioTranscript:
The bell tower was built in three stories: on the ground floor lies the baptistry, on the second level the preparation room for the choir, and on the third level the arches and bells. The scallop shell niches harken to Saint James, Santiago de Compostela, the patron saint of Spain, and indicate a baptistry below.

A bell hung under each of the four arches. With imagination, you can see young O’odham boys and girls standing on the ground below, pulling on ropes dangling from the tower, signaling for Mass to begin. Forty-niners, en route to the California gold rush, recalled the haunting sound of the bells ringing through the river valley as they approached. The whereabouts of those original bells remains a mystery. They have since been replaced.

The bells rang many times each day, instructing mission residents when to eat, work, and pray. Yet the tower was never completed; round holes mark where construction scaffolding still supported the work in progress. Although the bell tower appears to be in ruin, it has changed little since the last residents left in 1848. The fired bricks of the bell arches never received their finishing coats of plaster. And whether a dome was intended to sit atop the tower we may never know.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Across the path from the vats is a blocked-off entryway at a low-slung building. You may also enter the convento fragment on the south side, near the buttresses.
stops.audioTranscript:
Directly in front of the most important, most symbolic, and most decorated structure of the mission are three features whose purpose remains a mystery.

Early excavations found hydraulic lime surfaces at the bottom of the boxes, suggesting they were meant to be water tight. However, archeologists and historians continue to disagree about their original function. Some refer to them as cisterns. Others theorize they provided rudimentary “indoor plumbing” to the convento. Still others look to the unfinished bell tower as evidence the vats served a function in working limestone plaster.

The side walls are reconstructions. We do not know if they originally rose above ground level. What is your leading theory?

stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around and follow the paved path toward picnic area. The ramada will be to your right, between the trash/recycling and green water fountain.
stops.audioTranscript:
Only portions of the original three-sided convento complex remain today: the two-story storeroom at the northwest corner, and this fragment. Just ahead of you was the arched entrance into the convento courtyard, graced by a small dome above. The priest also lived in this wing of the complex.

Originally, Tumacácori was only a visita—a visiting station for Catholic missionaries. It wasn’t until 1768 that Tumacácori became a cabecera—a mission that housed a resident priest. This likely caused a significant disturbance for the O’odham of Tumacácori. With only occasional visits from the priest, they could openly continue their traditional religious and social practices. Now, under the watchful eye of a resident priest, they had to conceal those practices in order to model Spanish and Catholic values.

This structure continued to serve the Tumacácori community long after the mission era. In the late 1800s and early 1900s, this remaining section of the convento served as a residence, a school, and later housed the museum of the fledgling Tumacácori National Monument. A herringbone-pattern floor currently duplicates and protects the original floor beneath one room. More than any other structure here it has seen many preservation techniques tried to protect it.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn back to the visitor center building, passing through the mission model room where you began and out the breezeway into the courtyard garden.
stops.audioTranscript:
Once it gained its independence from Spain, the new nation of Mexico no longer valued the missions for their original purpose of converting native people into European-style citizens. Priests born in Spain were deported, including Tumacácori’s last resident priest in 1828. The mission families stayed on for another twenty years. For reasons that they did not record, in 1848 the residents of Tumacácori moved away, the women carrying their precious santos (saint statues) on their backs in burden baskets to San Xavier del Bac. They left behind their church, cemetery, fields, and homes.

With the Gadsden Purchase in 1854, Tumacácori became part of the United States. The U.S. reservation system eventually limited the legal territory of the O’odham to five sister
reservations: the San Xavier and Tohono (desert) O’odham, and Gila River, Salt River, and Ak-Chin Pima (river) nations.

Today, the Tohono O’odham and Pima are known for their beautiful basketry, woven using materials collected from the deserts and rivers of their homeland. The Yoeme (Yaqui) are famous for their carvings and religious dance, the Apache for their beadwork. Many still speak the languages of their ancestors.

After hundreds of years of mixing, marrying, creating new families, and blending traditions, a new people emerged: the mestizaje of Mexico. Flavors like chiles, carne asada, and tortillas reflect this mixing of origins. Sharing traditional foods—made fresh in kitchens such as this one—connects us to each other and to our shared heritage.

Missions took their garden design from Spanish tradition, which itself borrowed from Arabic, Moorish, and Roman architectural tradition. An ideal Spanish garden incorporated a walled courtyard with a central fountain that promoted shade, fragrance, and color.

These gardens featured mostly plants imported from Europe and brought to the New World by the padres. They were each valuable in their own way—for cultural, religious, or symbolic importance, medicinal or food value, shade, or aesthetics. The tranquility of these natural spaces brought the Spanish and indigenous communities together to savor common cultural values: beauty and utility.

The courtyard garden at Tumacácori was built in 1939 as part of the visitor center’s “New Deal” era construction. Its design, like that of the adjacent visitor center, was inspired by other missions in the Pimería Alta. Several agencies were involved, but the original plantings were carried out by sixteen young men employed by the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC). Three native mesquite trees were left in place and continue to grow in the garden. The olive, ornamental pomegranate, and monk’s pepper trees survive to this day. When the original apricot tree had to be removed, a seed from that tree provided its replacement.

images.title: Tumacácori's Landscape
images.altText: illustration of oblique aerial view of mission grounds with agricultural landscape and mountains
images.caption: A mission was more than a church.

data.title: The Lowell Public Art Collection
data.description: In Lowell, where the motto on the city seal is "art is the handmaid of human good," it seems only fitting that contemporary works of art stand alongside historical sites. Created by international artists, these works specifically address the themes of the Lowell National Historical Park: the Industrial City, Labor, Machines, Power, and Capital. Each artist selected the site for their original work, and we encourage you to explore the art, history, and culture along this walking tour.

stops.significance:
This life-size bronze sculpture of an Irish canal digger stands as a tribute to those nineteenth-century laborers who by hand dug Lowell's 5.6 miles of canals. The water in these canals powered the city's textile mills. The granite blocks stacked in the middle of the fountain resemble those used to construct the canal walls. The realistic figure symbolizes the lives and struggles of all workers who have contributed to our industrial society. Labor and power are two of five interpretive themes of the Lowell National Historical Park and the Lowell Heritage State Park. Through various public history and educational programs, the Parks celebrate the heritage of Lowell's working people and the city's water power system.

Realistic figures created by artists Ivan and Elliot Schwartz have been displayed in many museum exhibits and theater productions. Their work has also been featured at the National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back towards the Visitor Center, crossing both Shattuck and Market Street in the process. Head east on Market Street (with the Visitor Center on your right) for about 150 feet until you reach the green space to the right side. This is Market Mills park. Proceed further down the black fence until you reach the opening. You will now see the Homage to Women statue on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
This life-size bronze sculpture of an Irish canal digger stands as a tribute to those nineteenth-century laborers who by hand dug Lowell's 5.6 miles of canals. The water in these canals powered the city's textile mills. The granite blocks stacked in the middle of the fountain resemble those used to construct the canal walls. The realistic figure symbolizes the lives and struggles of all workers who have contributed to our industrial society. Labor and power are two of five interpretive themes of the Lowell National Historical Park and the Lowell Heritage State Park. Through various public history and educational programs, the Parks celebrate the heritage of Lowell's working people and the city's water power system.

Realistic figures created by artists Ivan and Elliot Schwartz have been displayed in many museum exhibits and theater productions. Their work has also been featured at the National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.

Site: Mack Plaza, Lowell Heritage State Park, Corner of Market and Shattuck Streets
Artists: Ivan and Elliot Schwartz. Fountain and plaza designed by Krent Pafford Associates
Materials: Bronze, granite, and water

stops.significance:
This larger-than-life sculpture of five intertwined figures is a tribute to Lowell's nineteenth century "mill girls," yet it also celebrates the contributions made by women throughout time. The statue suggests the struggles and aspirations of working women everywhere. The figures are intended to represent women of different races. "Women all over the world have one trait in common," the artist explains. "They work, they work hard, and their work is unheralded."

Mico Kaufman, of Tewksbury, Massachusetts, is considered one of the premiere medal artists of his time. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Rome and Florence. He designed the official inaugural medals for presidents Ford and Reagan, and was named Sculptor of the Year in 1978 by the American Numismatic Association. Among his other works of public art in the area are a tribute to Claude Debussy at UMass Lowell, the Rouse Monument at J.F.K. Plaza near Lowell City Hall, and the statue of Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan in Tewksbury.
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you depart Market Mills park, turn right and head further down Market Street towards the Leo A. Roy Parking Facility. Walk all the way down the street until you reach the intersection with Central Street. Cross Central Street and turn right to head towards the Central Street Bridge. You will see a ramp on the left leading down towards the canal walkway and the Lower Locks Gatehouse. Continue down the ramp and walkway, keeping the canal on your left. As you approach the glass bridge over the canal look to the right of the bridge to see an overlook and the Pawtucket Prism sculpture.
stops.audioTranscript:
Homage to Women (1984)

This larger-than-life sculpture of five intertwined figures is a tribute to Lowell's nineteenth century "mill girls," yet it also celebrates the contributions made by women throughout time. The statue suggests the struggles and aspirations of working women everywhere. The figures are intended to represent women of different races. "Women all over the world have one trait in common," the artist explains. "They work, they work hard, and their work is unheralded."

Mico Kaufman, of Tewksbury, Massachusetts, is considered one of the premiere medal artists of his time. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Rome and Florence. He designed the official inaugural medals for presidents Ford and Reagan, and was named Sculptor of the Year in 1978 by the American Numismatic Association. Among his other works of public art in the area are a tribute to Claude Debussy at University of Massachusetts Lowell, the Rouse Monument at J.F.K. Plaza near Lowell City Hall, and the statue of Helen Keller with her teacher, Annie Sullivan, in Tewksbury.

Site: Market Mills Park, Market and Palmer Street

Artists: Mico Kaufman

Materials: Bronze and granite

stops.significance:
This twenty-foot-high kinetic sculpture captures the essence of flowing water with sunlight and sound. This piece, which illustrates the theme of "the power of water," won a nationwide design competition. Ihara designed his piece so that originally the fountain's flow would move the 40 copper-colored steel cubes, which are arranged in a pyramid pattern. Today wind spins the cubes and simulates the sparkling quality of water as it is moved by wind and light plays upon it. Pawtucket is a Native American word for "falling water."

A graduate of Tokyo University, Micho Ihara is a former fellow of the Center for Advanced Visual Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. A number of his works are kinetically engineered to move in the wind. "Composing music must be very close to the process of orchestrating the structure of my sculpture," the artist says. Although he works with metal, usually stainless steel, his sculptures are much more about air and light.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leaving Pawtucket Prism, head across the glass bridge towards the Middlesex Community College Dr. Carole A. Cowen Center. While crossing, make sure to look to your left to see the water flowing through the gatehouse. When you reach the end of the bridge, turn to your left and head up the stone walkway up towards the Lower Lock building. Continue straight with the canal on your left until you reach the agapetime statue.
stops.audioTranscript:
Pawtucket Prism (1987)

This twenty-foot-high kinetic sculpture captures the essence of flowing water with sunlight and sound. This piece, which illustrates the theme of "the power of water," won a nationwide design competition. Ihara designed his piece so that originally the fountain's flow would move the 40 copper-colored steel cubes, which are arranged in a pyramid pattern. Today wind spins the cubes and simulates the sparkling quality of water as it is moved by wind and light plays upon it. Pawtucket is a Native American word for "falling water."

A graduate of Tokyo University, Micho Ihara is a former fellow of the Center for Advanced Visual Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has recieved awards from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, and the Graham Foundation. Since 1956 Ihara has produced more than 50 commissioned works in this country, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, and Singapore. His art is on view at the International Building of Rockafeller Center in New York City and Neiman-Marcus in Beverly Hills. A number of his works are kinetically engineered to move in the wind. "Composing music must be very close to the process of orchestrating the structure of my sculpture," the artist says. Although he works with metal, usually stainless steel, his sculptures are much more about air and light.

Site: Overlooking the confluence of the Pawtucket Canal and Concord River
Artist: Michio Ihara
Materials: Stainless and gold-plated steel

stops.significance:
This black patina bronze sculpture was commissioned by former U.S. Senator Paul E. Tsongas and Nicola Sauvage Tsongas in memory of their families. The sculpture's bold form and three distinct, yet related, elements suggest the embracing strength of a family group. Its title means "love and honor" in Greek, and the piece symbolizes a universal tribute to the family, particularly those Lowell families of immigrant heritage.

Born in New York City, Dimitri Hadzi moved to Europe following service in the Second World War. In 1956 he represented the United States at the Venice Biennale, a major international art exhibition. His sculptures are presently on view in museums and public spaces all over the world. Although the artist considered himself a "traditional sculptor," most of his work is abstract in style. He reduces ideas and complex visual information into simpler forms. His shapes are often based on natural forms and have an organic energy.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Leaving agapetime, turn and continue along the red brick path with the trolley tracks on your left. Cross Merrimack Street at the crosswalk and continue straight. Cross over the wood planked bridge. At the end of the bridge turn right and continue towards the trees and park. The Kerouac Memorial Park is on your left (look for the tall stone pillars and stone benches).
stops.audioTranscript:
Agapetime (1990)

This black patina bronze sculpture was commissioned by former U.S. Senator Paul E. Tsongas and Nicola Sauvage Tsongas in memory of their families. The sculpture's bold form and three distinct, yet related, elements suggest the embracing strength of a family group. Its title means "love and honor" in Greek, and the piece symbolizes a universal tribute to the family, particularly those Lowell families of immigrant heritage.

Born in New York City, Dimitri Hadzi moved to Europe following service in the Second World War. In 1956 he represented the United States at the Venice Biennale, a major international art exhibition. His sculptures are presently on view in museums and public spaces all over the world. Although the artist considered himself a "traditional sculptor," most of his work is abstract in style. He reduces ideas and complex visual information into simpler forms. His shapes are often based on natural forms and have an organic energy.

Site: Lower Locks, at the junction of the Pawtucket and Eastern Canals
Artist: Dimitri Hadzi
Materials: Bronze and granite

stops.significance:
This work of public art is a tribute to Jack Kerouac (1922-1969), the Lowell native whose most famous book, On The Road, challenged the conformism of the 1950s and remains a pivotal "coming of age" novel. Five of his novels are set in Lowell and his writings are part of the city's cultural heritage.

Excepts from 10 of Kerouac's 20 books appear on eight triangular, polished, reddish-brown granite columns, creating a literary giant's memorial in language. The granite was quarried in South Dakota, and cut in Minnesota. West Virginia graphic designers worked on the text. The paved path, shaped as a cross and series of circles, refers to Kerouac's Roman Catholic and Buddhist beliefs, and evokes his lifelong spiritual quest. The design is reminiscent of a mandala, a pattern symbolizing the universe.

The artist, Ben Woitena, of Houston, Texas, knows Kerouac's work well. His design was selected in a national competition. His preferred medium is welded and and painted steel.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the Jack Kerouac Commemorative behind you, cross at the intersection of Bridge Street and French Street. Proceed straight along French Street up to John Street. At the next intersection of John Street and French Street, Boardinghouse Park will be on your right. The statues are located along the perimeter of Boarding House Park.
stops.audioTranscript:
Jack Kerouac Commemorative (1988)

This work of public art is a tribute to Jack Kerouac (1922-1969), the Lowell native whose most famous book, On The Road, challenged the conformism of the 1950s and remains a pivotal "coming of age" novel. Five of his novels are set in Lowell and his writings are part of the city's cultural heritage.

Excepts from 10 of Kerouac's 20 books appear on eight triangular, polished, reddish-brown granite columns, creating a literary giant's memorial in language. The granite was quarried in South Dakota, and cut in Minnesota. West Virginia graphic designers worked on the text. The paved path, shaped as a cross and series of circles, refers to Kerouac's Roman Catholic and Buddhist beliefs, and evokes his lifelong spiritual quest. The design is reminiscent of a mandala, a pattern symbolizing the universe.

The artist, Ben Woitena, of Houston, Texas, knows Kerouac's work well. His design was selected in a national competition. Woitena was a faculty member at Glassel School for 27 years. His preferred medium is welded and painted steel, and his sculptures are found at public sites all over Texas, including the Houston and San Antonio Museums of Fine Art, and the State Capital Building.

Site: Eastern Canal Park, Bridge and French Street
Artists: Ben Woitena
Materials: Granite and Stainless Steel

stops.significance:
These three pieces are derived from Lowell's industrial symbols. They are intended to be objects for seating and climbing, functioning as a kind of furniture as well as visual art.

Sculpture One is a six-ton silhouette of Francis Cabot Lowell (1774-1817), the early textile manufacturer for whom the city is named. Sculpture Two is a tipped, mammoth, granite thread spool mounted on a granite base, which can also be seen as a spindle or beehive, symbolizing hard work and industry. Sculpture Three is a saw-toothed horizontal piece that might be the roofline of a boardinghouse or factory, or, perhaps, gears belonging to textile machinery. The ten-foot high spindle or smokestack is located near the entrance to the Boott Cotton Mills and emulates its red-brick chimney. The Lowell Sculptures was the winner of a nationwide design competition.

Connecticut artist Robert Cumming is a painter, photographer, and printmaker, as well as a sculptor.
stops.assetName: "The Lowell Sculptures: One, Two, and Three" Sculptures
stops.audioTranscript:
The Lowell Sculptures: One, Two, and Three (1990)

These three pieces are derived from Lowell's industrial symbols. They are intended to be objects for seating and climbing, functioning as a kind of furniture as well as visual art.

Sculpture One is a six-ton silhouette of Francis Cabot Lowell (1774-1817), the early textile manufacturer for whom the city is named. Sculpture Two is a tipped, mammoth, granite thread spool mounted on a granite base, which can also be seen as a spindle or beehive, symbolizing hard work and industry. Sculpture Three is a saw-toothed horizontal piece that might be the roofline of a boardinghouse or factory, or, perhaps, gears belonging to textile machinery. The ten-foot high spindle or smokestack is located near the entrance to the Boott Cotton Mills and emulates its red-brick chimney. The Lowell Sculptures was the winner of a nationwide design competition.

Connecticut artist Robert Cumming is a painter, photographer, and printmaker, as well as a sculptor. His works rank among the collections of major American art museums, including the Museum of Modern Art and Whitney Museum in New York, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, and the Hirshhorn Museum and Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. In 1984 he was one of ten artists invited to document the Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

Site: Boarding House Park, corner of French and John Streets
Artists: Robert Cumming
Materials: Granite, Brick, and Steel

images.title: Homage to Women
images.altText: A metal sculpture of five women, together in a group looking into the distance.
images.caption: "Homeage to Women" Sculpture

data.title: The Making of a National Monument
data.description: This tour traces the planning and development of the park and how the reconstructed Fort Stanwix came into being.

stops.significance: The location you are standing at is known locally as the "American Corners." It is the intersection of modern roads today. But during the time of the American Revolution it was the center of the Oneida Carry, and during the early years of the nation's history, it became the starting point of the the Erie Canal build. The canal eventually ran straight through this location, replacing the portage that came before it.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down the park path to the east of the visitor center. Stop and face the flagpole.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Fort Stanwix National Monument. We hope you enjoy your visit to the park and this audio tour. The first stop on this audio tours located in front of the park visitor center, located at the intersection of James and Dominick Streets. The tour then follows the path toward the fort’s entrance, into the fort, and then around the Black River Boulevard side of the fort, and concludes on the trail near the St. Peter's Church. If you have any questions or comments about this tour, or the park in general, please visit the park's visitor. This tour and admission to Fort Stanwix National Monument are free. For more information about Fort Stanwix National Monument, please visit our web page at www.nps.gov/fost
We hope you enjoy your visit to park.

Fort Stanwix was declared a national monument on August 21st, 1935. At that time, no remains of the fort were visible above ground. You are standing at the intersection of James and Dominick Streets, locally known as the “American Corners.” This was the downtown of the City of Rome, New York. The city’s top of Commerce. From here you would have seen banks, stores businesses, a theatre, a hotel, and apartments on the upper floors of the three to four story buildings lining the streets. After the national monument was established, small plaques were installed to identify the site of the fort. The fort and surrounding grounds were not reconstructed until the 1970s, with the fort opening to the public in 1976 for the nation’s bicentennial. The trail you are you were standing on represents the Oneida Caring Place; a portage between the Mohawk River to the east and Wood Creek to the west. This was a major route for trade and the movement of armies during the 1700s. Fort Stanwix was built to protect this portage, the trade the that crossed the portage, and the movement of armies travelling east and west during the French & Indian and American Revolutionary Wars. In many respects the portage is just as important to us today. The location of Fort Stanwix National Monument has active partnerships with the City of Rome, Oneida County, the State of New York Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, and other private and public sites surrounding the fort and in areas to the east and west.

stops.significance: During the Siege of 1777, an American flag flew over this wall of the fort in defiance of British orders to surrender.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the path approximately 100 yards and walk into the fort or stop at the fort gate.
stops.audioTranscript: Before you is the southwest bastion, also known as the “flag bastion.” From 1758 to today, different flags flew over the fort. During the French & Indian War (also known as the Seven Years War), the King’s Colors flew over the fort. The King’s Colors represented the United Kingdom, also known as Great Britain. The British Army and American colonial provincial soldiers garrisoned the fort, and kept the French army in Canada from invading the Colony of New York. Over the course of the American Revolutionary War different flags flew from the flagpole. On August 3rd 1777, during the British siege of the American occupied fort, a red, white, and blue flag was hoisted over the fort. We do not know what that flag looked like because there are three descriptions of the flag. One description is of 13 alternating red, white, and blue stripes. Another source describes 13 alternating red-and-white stripes with the King’s Colors at the canton; the top left-hand corner. That flag is also known as the Grand Union or the Continental Army flag. The third description is of the “Stars and Stripes,” but with the 13 white stars in the blue canton. Today, our nation’s “Stars and Stripes” flies over the fort most of the time. During special park events that commemorate the forts historic events, you may also see other flags that may have flown from 1758 to 1781.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back to the main path. Continue to follow it to the east around the sidewalk near Black River Boulevard.
stops.audioTranscript: You are now inside the fort. Archaeological investigations of the site during the early 1970s identified where the fort and its buildings stood from 1758 to 1781. What you see around you is what the fort may have looked like during the American Revolutionary War from 1776 to 1781. The fort features and buildings are located where they stood during that time. What you see above ground is based upon extensive archeological and architectural historic research. The result is considered the best reconstructed American Revolutionary War fort in the nation. Five structures have not been reconstructed. Two of them inside and three outside the fort. One of the structures inside the fort was the headquarters that stood between the whipping post and the north casemate. The other structure inside the fort was the guardhouse, which was located between the public restrooms and the Gregg Barracks. The three structures outside the fort included the ravelin that protected the front gate of the fort, the necessary or outhouse that extended off the east side of the fort, and the communication tunnel and ravelin that protected the fort sallyport entrance also on the east side of the fort.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking up the park trail, turn left at the fork, and continue walking until you reach the sidewalk in front of the neighboring church.
stops.audioTranscript: You may be wondering why there is not a ditch on this side of the fort. During the 1700s, the area in front of you was a swamp with a stream running through it. The fort was built on a bluff overlooking the swamp, which extended to the Mohawk River. The swamp and river were natural barriers, or protective features, that protected the fort. To the right, the fort's necessary, or outhouse, extended from the fort over the stream, which washed the human waste downstream. Men, women, and children obtain fresh water for the fort from the stream in the area in front of you. During the British siege of the American held fort, in August of 1777, British engineers dug a channel and built a dam to redirect the fresh stream water to the Mohawk River and away from the fort. The men and women inside the fort were forced to drink water from wells that had been built inside the fort. The water was stagnant swamp water and unhealthy for the people drinking it. Where is the swamp today? During the 1800s the swamp was covered over with a landfill where trash and fill were dumped. Buildings were later constructed on the landfill during the fort’s reconstruction a representative stream bed was dug to show where that stream may been located.

stops.significance: Within the bounds of this park are monuments dedicated to the fort's commander, Peter Gansevoort, the Erie Canal, and Siege of 1777. Bordering it is the Rome Historical Society - Friends of the Fort and the National Park Service administration building.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to James St. Then carefully cross and walk to the left/south. A black rod iron fence surrounds a small park at the corners of James and Dominick Streets.
stops.audioTranscript: During the final days of the fort’s siege, American loyalists and British engineers dug a siege trench against the fort and were forced to stop near where Saint Peter's Church stands today. With the approach of Continental Soldiers commanded by American General Benedict Arnold the siege was ended. The Americans won a key victory. When combined with American victories in the Hudson and Lake Champlain Valleys, the Americans were able to defeat British General John Burgoyne and his army after the Battles of Saratoga. This series of battles combined are considered the turning point of the American Revolutionary War. Fort Stanwix continued to protect New York from the British in Canada until 1781, when it was finally abandoned. After the American Revolutionary War, the Oneida Carrying Place remained important for trade and the movement of armies travelling east and west. The Portage was replaced by roads, canals, and then railroads. Lynchville, later renamed Rome, was built around then over the site of Fort Stanwix and has enjoyed years of innovation and prosperity because of the commerce that passes through it. Truly, all roads do lead to Rome. Across the parking lot stands the city of Rome former post office. After the new post office was opened, the Rome Historical Society moved into the building. We encourage you to visit the Rome Historical Society Tuesdays to Fridays 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. to learn more about the development of Rome and the city's innovations and prosperity.

stops.significance: This memorial was completed in 1976 in honor of those who fought and died at Fort Stanwix/Schuyler during the American Revolution.
stops.assetName: Tomb of the Unknown Revolutionary War Soldiers
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the final stop. To return to the visitor center, walk to the south, down the main sidewalk on the James Street side of the park.
stops.audioTranscript:
Due primarily to the work of community and history minded people in the City of Rome, Fort Stanwix was designated a National Monument in 1935. It would not be until the end of the 1960’s, however that the land where the original fort sat could be donated to the federal government. Along with being part of downtown Rome’s urban renewal efforts, Fort Stanwix was also rebuilt to help celebrate the Bicentennial of the United States in 1976. The National Park Service undertook three years of archeological work between 1970 and 1973, followed by three years of reconstruction from 1973 to 1976. Fort Stanwix National Monument officially opened to the public on May 20, 1976. 

Before you is the Tomb of the Unknown Soldiers of the American Revolution. In 1972, during excavations for utility lines in conjunction with the rebuilding of Fort Stanwix, the remains of eight men were uncovered. They were laid out in a haphazard fashion and were not part of a larger cemetery. Study of the remains led to the determination that they were soldiers from the American Revolution. As part of the local celebrations for the country’s bicentennial in 1976, it was decided to create a tomb memorial for these men. This became the Tomb of the Unknown Soldiers of the American Revolution. The tomb was the last architectural project undertaken by Lorimar Rich. Rich was a Rome area native who also designed the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the Arlington National Cemetery. On July 4th, 1976, the remains of the eight soldiers were reinterred in their final resting place at the tomb.

images.title: Overhead Fort Stanwix
images.altText: From above a 4-pointed star-shaped wooden fort.
images.caption: Aerial view of Fort Stanwix National Monument.

data.title: The Man from the Sinking Spring - Memorial and Grounds Walking Tour
data.description: View the First Lincoln Memorial, Symbolic Cabin, Sinking Spring, and more as you enjoy a walk at Birthplace Unit.

park.fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
park.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace

stops.assetName: Visitor Center at Abraham Lincoln Birthplace
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you leave the front doors of the Visitor Center, head right and follow the sidewalk until you reach the bottom of the stairs of The First Lincoln Memorial.

stops.assetName: The First Lincoln Memorial - Bottom of Stairs
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed up the 56 stairs, reaching the top of the hill. You will enter the memorial building from the doors at the back of the building.
Leave the building, and return back down the 56 stairs. Once at the bottom of the stairs, turn right. You will follow of stairs a few yards away leading down into the earth.
Follow the spring stairs back up and turn right. Continue on the sidewalk until the pavement ends.

data.title: The Mesquite Self-Guided Tour
data.description: Journey back in time to the early ranching days of the Texas Panhandle on a self-guided tour. On this .3 mile tour, you will see ice-age mesquite trees, ranchland grasses, cattle forage plants, native wildflowers, insects, birds, reptiles, and "Cowboy Plums."

images.title: The Mesquite Self-Guided Tour
images.altText: This trail is surrounded by pink wildflowers and mesquite trees.  The trail is covered in red dirt.
images.caption: The Mesquite Self-Guided Trail

data.title: The Model City Walking Tour
data.description: Take a stroll through 100 years of Anniston history and learn about some of the people, places, and changes that have shaped the "Model City" from its founding in the 1870s through the integration efforts of the Bi-Racial Human Relations Council in the 1960s. The "Model City" Walking Tour route is about two miles long and includes seven stops throughout downtown Anniston. For the full experience, listen to the tour's interpretive audio, or follow along with the accompanying transcript.

stops.significance: The Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot witnessed the early stages of an attack on a small group of nonviolent civil rights activists in Anniston in May of 1961.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head North on Gurnee Avenue. You will pass the Calhoun County Courthouse on your right as you walk towards Zinn Park. After two city blocks, you will arrive at the entrance to Zinn Park.
stops.audioTranscript:
Hello, and thank you for taking this walking tour of historic downtown Anniston! First, a bit about Freedom Riders National Monument. The Freedom Riders were a group of diverse, non-violent, and mostly young activists who traveled through the South in small interracial groups during the summer of 1961. In total, more than 400 riders participated in more than 50 rides, challenging discriminatory state laws and local customs; testing if bus station facilities were complying with US Supreme Court decisions that ruled segregation during interstate travel was unconstitutional.  For these simple acts, riders faced violence and imprisonment.



On May 14, 1961, ten days after the rides began in Washington, D.C., the first group of Freedom Riders were ambushed, chased, and badly beaten by a white mob. The attack started here, at the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot, and ended near a burning bus out on Highway 202. Media coverage of the violence, broadcast worldwide, forced Federal involvement, and inspired others to join the Freedom Rides. Freedom Riders National Monument was established in 2017 to tell this story.



The story of Anniston doesn’t start in 1961.  The story of Anniston begins almost 100 hundred years prior. Called the “Model City”, Anniston experienced four distinct eras between 1870 and 1970: Company Town, Segregated Commercial Center, New South “Model City,” and Civil Rights Battleground. Key tensions – between tradition and progress, between white and black, between civic pride and civic pessimism – shaped a century of change that created the modern “Model City.”  



Remember those tensions – progress, race, and civic identity – because you will find them interwoven into the stories we will encounter along Anniston’s story.



Discussion Question: Think about a time when your home changed. How did you react?

stops.significance: Zinn Park is an inviting downtown park, located a few blocks off Noble Street in downtown Anniston.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Zinn Park's entrance, head diagonally (northwest) through Zinn Park. You will pass the Unity House on your left and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Pavilion on your right. Exit Zinn Park onto Moore Avenue, then go one block north to 15th Street. Cross through the intersection, then turn left. Go west on 15th Street until you see two brick pillars on either side of the street, then continue through the pillars until you reach the West 15th Street Historic District marker.
stops.audioTranscript:
Did you know that Anniston was a company before it was a town? In 1872, Samuel Noble and his business partner Alfred Noble founded the Woodstock Iron Company. During the Reconstruction Era (1863-1877) after the end of the Civil War, businessmen like Noble and Tyler rushed to develop Southern states’ mineral resources.

The Woodstock Company produced iron via charcoal furnaces that required a lot of fuel and manpower. The company recruited skilled European ironmakers as well as black and white laborers from surrounding areas. In 1873, the new enterprise and its employees formed the town of Anniston, named after Annie Tyler of the Tyler family.

Prior to 1883, Anniston was a company town, which meant it operated and developed differently from other towns. The Woodstock Company owned virtually all stores and homes in Anniston. Workers paved the streets, laid sewers, built homes and industrial buildings, raised food on company farms, and purchased everything at the company store using company-issued “scrip” currency. The company built and staffed churches, schools, a doctor’s office, and emergency services.

The Woodstock Company oversaw the design and construction of downtown Anniston, and the area’s careful grid pattern included the land where you are standing. Much of the area surrounding Gurnee Avenue was occupied by Woodstock facilities, and the plot of land where the Greyhound Depot now stands used to be housing for Anniston’s industrial workers and their families.

Discussion Questions:

Would you have liked living in a company town? What aspects of life would have been nice? What aspects would have been difficult? 

How would life have been different in Anniston then in other surrounding communities?

stops.significance: A "city within a city," the West 15th Historic District was the epicenter for African American commercial and social life in Anniston between 1898 and 1950.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the W. 15th Street Historic District Marker, head east down 15th Street towards Noble Street. Walk three blocks, then turn right on Noble Street. Head south on Noble Street. Walk four blocks, then take a break at the next stop near the corner of Noble Street and 11th Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
Anniston “opened” as a public community with the arrival of the Georgia Pacific railroad in 1883. A construction boom followed: churches, the railway depot, The Anniston Inn, a renowned opera house, the Noble Brothers Car Wheel Works, a textile factory, and dozens of new homes and businesses sprang up quickly. Growth led to an 1883 designation of Anniston as the “Model City of the New South.”

While Anniston’s industrial outlook was progressive, its leaders and power structures worked to establish segregation (both legally and in practice) in the years after the city opened to the public. Massive population growth, combined with visible racial violence between Anniston residents, white soldiers, and black soldiers of the Third Alabama Regiment stationed at Camp Shipp, contributed to white investment in segregation.

As Reconstruction faded, legal segregation rose, solidified by the 1896 Plessy v. Ferguson Supreme Court decision. This “separate but equal” standard paved the way for sweeping changes to Alabama state law. In 1901, Anniston attorney John B. Knox chaired the Alabama Constitutional Convention and opened the proceedings by stating the convention’s purpose, which was to rewrite Alabama’s constitution “to establish white supremacy in this state.” Legal segregation was soon codified in both law and custom in the “Model City” around the turn of the 20th century.

Despite segregation’s inhumanity, African American residents of Anniston carved out “A City Within A City” for themselves in the city’s commercial landscape. 15th street was the epicenter for African American commercial and social life between 1898 and 1950. Shops, services, restaurants, and entertainment could all be found here. These businesses and social spaces supported a distinctive community that thrived because of both community investment and necessity.

Discussion Questions:

Why did the railroad have such a significant impact on Anniston? 

How would integration have affected businesses in an African American business district? 

Why was it necessary for Anniston’s leaders to change segregation by custom into segregation by law? 

In what ways was Anniston a “model” city? Are there ways in which Anniston failed to live up to its “model” identity?

stops.significance:
Located in the heart of the Downtown Anniston Historic District, this street corner provides a welcome resting place during an afternoon of exploration in downtown Anniston. 

From this point, visitors can few several notable historic buildings in downtown Anniston, including the Kress building (1108 Noble Street), site of some of Anniston's earliest integration efforts, the Calhoun County Courthouse (25 W. 11th Street), site of the trial of Willie Brewster, and many other historic commercial buildings built during the 20th century.
stops.assetName: Corner of Noble Street and 11th Street
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head west on 11th Street towards the Calhoun County Courthouse. Go one block, then turn left. Go south for about 20 steps on Gurnee Avenue. The alleyway containing the "Could You Get On The Bus?" mural will be on your left, facing Gurnee Avenue.
stops.audioTranscript:
Anniston’s development during the mid-20th century was tied to the city’s relationship to conflict – specifically, the Spanish-American War, World War I, and World War II. In 1898, Camp Shipp was established on a hill above Anniston as a base for Army reserves. Laid out to house 10,000 men, the arrival of Camp Shipp led to a brief revitalization and construction boom between 1898 and 1899.  

Following the Spanish-American war, attracting military investment became a political priority. Camp McClellan was established during World War I and by 1917, hosted 27,000 National Guardsmen. In 1929, Camp McClellan became Fort McClellan, a permanent Army installation. Military investment in the Anniston area, including the creation and expansion of the Anniston Army Depot between 1941 and 1945, fueling economic and population growth in the “Model City” into the post-war period. 

 Noble Street, the commercial center of the segregated Model City, boomed as military investment swelled Aniston's population. Notable 20th century additions include the Lyric Theater, built in 1918, and many other commercial buildings today preserved in the Downtown Anniston Historic District. 

Discussion Questions: 

How would the growth of military investment and development in Anniston have changed life for residents? 

As Anniston's identity shifted from industrial to a military character, what aspects of life would have changed? What traditions or beliefs endured? 

Can local traditions prevent or impede progress, or do they provide opportunities for change?

stops.significance: The Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot witnessed the early stages of mob violence against a small group of nonviolent Freedom Riders in May of 1961.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head south on Gurnee Avenue. Go one block, then turn left on 10th Street. Head east on 10th Street and walk one block to the intersection of 10th Street and Noble Street. Cross straight through the intersection, then turn right. Head south on Noble Street and walk one block. You've arrived at the next stop when you see the "Trailways Station Attack" historic marker.
stops.audioTranscript:
Progress brings changes that can cause tensions within communities. In 1961, events unfolded at the Greyhound Bus Depot in Anniston that reflected these tensions. Two groups of Freedom Riders, on Greyhound and Trailways buses, arrived in Anniston on a quiet Sunday afternoon in May of 1961. Riders on the Greyhound bus were met by an angry mob of more than 100 white segregationists led by members of the Ku Klux Klan. The mob threw rocks at the bus, broke windows, and slashed tires, leaving the Freedom riders stranded. 

The Freedom Riders’ bus eventually escaped the depot ambush, but damage to the bus’s tires forced it to the shoulder outside the city, near the Forsyth and Son Grocery Store. The mob followed and tossed a firebomb through the rear window. Freedom Riders struggled as members of the mob trapped them inside, escaping only when an explosion temporarily drove the crowd away. As the Freedom Riders poured off the burning bus, they displayed courage, resilience, and a commitment to non-violence as they were attacked and beaten by the mob. 

During the attack, twelve-year-old Janie Forsyth was standing in front of her father’s grocery store. Upon witnessing people in pain, Janie sprang into action, giving water and aid to the riders because, in Janie’s own words, “That’s something I can do.” Janie faced challenges growing up in Anniston because of her decision on that day but was recognized later in life for her courageous act of civility. Due to the courage and determination of Janie and the Freedom Riders, Anniston’s story was forever changed.

Discussion Questions:

What makes a good citizen? 

As a citizen, how do you respond when your community lets you down? 

Knowing the troubles that the Freedom Riders faced, could you have gotten on the bus like so many that followed them?

stops.significance: The Trailways Station in downtown Anniston was the site of violence and intimidation of Freedom Riders in route to Birmingham on May 14, 1961.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head east on 9th Street. Go one block and cross straight through the intersection of 9th Street and Wilmer Avenue. Turn left on Wilmer Avenue and head north. Go one block, then turn right on 10th Street. The Public Library of Anniston-Calhoun County is on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
While the Greyhound bus was under attack, the Trailways bus arrived at the other station in Anniston to a mostly quiet reception.  However, a group of Klansmen boarded the bus, forcibly segregated the passengers, and harassed and intimidated the Freedom Riders.

Upon arrival in Birmingham, the Freedom Riders were attacked by another white supremacist mob of wielding fists, iron pipes, baseball bats, and other weapons.  Birmingham authorities gave the mob time to attack the Freedom Riders before the police arrived. 

The Trailways bus carried the youngest Freedom Rider, Charles Person, who at nineteen-years-old made the decision to leave Morehouse College to contribute to the Civil Rights Movement. Mr. Person was severely beaten but met this brutality with dedicated non-violence. 

Though the Freedom Riders endured violence, the movement did not end in Alabama. Over 400 Freedom Riders joined during the summer of 1961, and most faced violence, arrests, and prison sentences in places like Mississippi’s notorious Parchman Prison. Many Freedom Riders became local and national community leaders, and the movement itself succeeded in forcing federal involvement to end segregation in interstate travel.

Discussion Questions: 

As a citizen, how do you conceive of your role when your city, community, or home lets you down? 

What experiences of race, positive, or negative, have shaped your identity? 

What are some examples of the legacies of American segregation that you have encountered in your lived experiences?

stops.significance: The Public Library of Anniston-Calhoun County was the site of integration efforts by African American faith leaders in 1963.
stops.directionsToNextStop: You've reached the end of the tour! To return to the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot, head west on 10th Street. Walk one block, cross over Noble Street, then walk one more block and turn right on Gurnee Avenue. The Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot is straight ahead at 1031 Gurnee Avenue.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the months following the 1961 attack on Freedom Riders, Annistonians came to terms with the city’s capacity for racial violence. African American residents organized the Calhoun County Improvement Association to lobby for integration but received little encouragement. Business and government leaders resisted changes while simultaneously worrying about Anniston’s negative national reputation. 

Ministers became leading voices in the fight for integration. In 1962, Reverend William B. McClain (a black Methodist) and Reverend Nimrod Reynolds (a black Baptist) began meeting with Reverend Phil Noble (a white Presbyterian). Emotional bonds formed at these meetings grew into the integrated Anniston Ministerial Association. Discussions on faith, duty, and the current state of Anniston’s segregated community among these ministers planted the seeds that became the Anniston Bi-Racial Human Relations Council. 

Formed in 1963, the Anniston Bi-Racial Human Relations Council created lines of communication between faith, business, and political leaders. African American members of the Council set the agenda and integration efforts began soon after the council’s creation. The first barriers to fall were segregated public accommodations at national chain “dime stores” in Anniston, including Kress’s on Noble Street. Small victories accumulated in the years that followed. 

Integration efforts continued to encounter violent resistance, most notably during the September 1963 attack on Revs. McClain and Reynolds while they attempted to integrate the downtown Anniston Public Library. However, the communication and trust created by the Council’s efforts set a positive tone for Anniston’s integration and earned the city praise from President Kennedy, who hoped Anniston’s approach would allow it to serve as a “model for other communities.” Once again, Anniston was recognized as a “Model City.”

Discussion Questions: 

How did Anniston’s “model” identity change throughout its history? 

Think about the story of Anniston’s traditions and the city’s history of progress. If you were telling the story to a friend, what parts of the story would you include? Is there anything you would leave out? 

Why was the Anniston Bi-Racial Human Relations Council successful? What can we learn from its example?

images.title: Greyhound Mural
images.altText: a red-brick wall facing an empty alleyway featuring a large silver painting of a bus and panels.
images.caption: The Greyhound mural, titled "Could You Get on the Bus?" at the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot.

data.title: The Road to Revolution
data.description: You are standing on Tory Row, famous for the wealthy people who lived here before the American Revolution. What convinced them to stay loyal to the Crown and did their neighbors agree? What did it mean to be a loyal in 1774? Come find out! This walking tour takes about 1 hour to complete and covers 0.7 miles from 105 Brattle Street to the Cambridge Common. The path stays on sidewalks and paved trails, but can be uneven. The tour can be paired with the park’s “The Road to Revolution” Junior Ranger book.

park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance:
John Vassall built this colonial mansion in 1759 with the money he received from the sugar industry. Vassall inherited a plantation in Jamaica and enslaved people who worked on the plantation and in this home. Vassall benefitted from his family’s status. He attended Harvard, served as a justice of the peace and was a militia officer. He was a typical British country gentleman and well respected. Until the 1770s, that is.  

 In March of 1770, the Boston Massacre occurred between colonists and British soldiers occupying the city. Five people were killed by the soldiers and became martyrs for a budding anti-British cause. In December 1773, during the Boston Tea Party, colonists took to the streets in protest, throwing 342 chests of tea into the harbor. Additionally, Boston colonists destroyed the governor's home, marched with effigies of government officials, and deployed intimidation tactics against merchants selling British goods. John Vassall would have heard of these unsettling events.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of the house, cross Brattle Street toward Longfellow Park using the crosswalk. Turn left and continue down Brattle Street for one block until you come to the large grey house with the red door.

stops.significance:
This is the home of Penelope and Henry Vassall, aunt and uncle of John Vassall. By September 1774, Penelope was a widow and would have looked out these windows as the turmoil reached her neighborhood.

Colonists had discovered that the governor had retrieved a nearby stockpile of gunpowder and brought it back to Boston. The man who gave the governor the key to the powder house was none other than William Brattle, who lived down the road. In protest, 4,000 colonists descended on Cambridge. After chasing Brattle out of town, they turned and marched down this street, passing in front of Penelope’s home. The colonist surrounded homes further down the street, demanding that the men inside resign from their government positions.

To avoid potential property damage and bloodshed, the men agreed to resign and their families fled. Penelope left for the safety of her Caribbean plantation. Both sides felt that they were the loyal British subjects upholding English liberties. So, what does it mean to be a loyal citizen?
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Brattle Street in the same direction (away from Longfellow House) and turn left onto Farwell Place. Just past the library and before the blue house, you will see a brick path to your left. Follow it a few steps to the yellow house with a dark colored door.

stops.significance:
The Read family stayed in Cambridge after the Powder Alarm. Eight months later on April 19th, 1775 two Reads marched to Lexington and Concord. This community had begun to take sides – “Loyalist” or “Patriot”- with shrinking room for the neutral.

These events did much to change the minds of the uncertain. Parliament had decided that Boston must pay for its actions and passed the Coercive Acts to compel them to cooperate.  The acts closed the port of Boston to trade, its main lifeline and limited colonists’ right to self-govern, ultimately replacing their governor with British General Gage. Instead of subduing colonists, it provoked outrage. Local Patriots saw the Powder Alarm as another tyrannical grab for power. When the midnight rider, William Dawes, came through town in April, people like the Reads were ready to arm themselves.

After the official start of the American Revolution, soldiers from all over New England gathered in Cambridge. The conviction of these soldiers would soon be tried again.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return down the brick path to Farwell Place. Turn left and continue toward what looks like a dead end. Go to the right corner between a house and the rear of the church and you will find a path that will take you to Chris Church and the Cambridge Burying Ground. Make your way to the front of the church first.

stops.significance:
Christ Church, the oldest surviving church in Cambridge, was built in 1760 by the wealthy inhabitants of the town, including John Vassall. By 1775, with its Anglican parishioners gone, the church sat empty.  

The New England army quickly moved in and used the church as barracks for its soldiers. This was the fate of many of the abandoned properties in Cambridge. Penelope Vassall’s house was used as a hospital and John Vassall’s, where the tour began, housed a regiment of soldiers from Marblehead, Massachusetts. This was no longer Loyalist country, but an encampment for the fledgling New England Army.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the front of the church, return back toward the path you arrived at to find the entrance to the Cambridge Burying Ground. Upon reaching the entrance, take the path to the left, toward a large oak tree, to find the monuments to soldiers who died in the American Revolution.

stops.significance:
After Lexington and Concord, British troops retreated to the safety of Boston. The city sat on a peninsula and was heavily guarded by land and sea. However, the British generals knew that they needed to claim the high ground to protect themselves. They set their eyes on Charlestown.

The New England Army in Cambridge got wind of the plan. Colonists marched to Charlestown and dug an entrenchment on Breed's hill. The next morning, the British were surprised to see the land they intended to claim had been taken. Throughout June 16th, British forces attacked the New England army and bombarded Charlestown with cannon fire. Eventually, British soldiers overtook the hill, forcing colonists to retreat. Though they won the battle, it was at a high cost of life.

Follow the northern path, just to the left of the cemetery entrance, along Garden Street. After the large oak tree in the corner, there are two monuments to fallen soldiers from Lexington and Concord and the Battle of Bunker Hill.
stops.directionsToNextStop: In front of Christ Church, turn let and go down Garden Street. Use the crosswalk at the corner of Garden and Appian Way to cross over to the Cambridge Common. Then turn left and head toward the Elm tree and cannons.

stops.significance:
After the Battle of Bunker Hill a new leader would ask for the New England soldiers' loyalty.

General George Washington arrived on July 2nd. He was sent to Cambridge by the Continental Congress to develop a professional army and get the British to leave Boston. Though a myth, the monument here says he took command at this spot. Washington’s first headquarters, ironically, was the home of a Loyalist we already met – John Vassall.

Earning the loyalty of New England soldiers would not be easy. As a Virginian, and an outsider, he harbored negative views of the soldiers and was challenged by the fact that the army was racially integrated. He eventually earned their respect, though, by forcing the British to evacuated Boston on March 17th, 1776. Washington knew that his success depended on the loyalty of his soldiers, and he made a bid for that loyalty in his first General Orders on July 14th, 1775. That text is immortalized on the back of this monument.

What does loyalty mean to you?
