data.title: The Sunken Forest: A Story of Balance
data.description: This self-guided audio tour of the Sunken Forest will take you through the dynamic habitat of Fire Island's crown jewel to teach you about this globally rare ecosystem, it's unique natural history, and a variety of challenges to its continued preservation.

stops.significance: An Introduction to Sailors Haven and this self-guided audio tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Please proceed south down the main walkway to the ocean beach.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Fire Island National Seashore, Sailors Haven, and the Sunken Forest. Though the island is narrow from ocean to bay, this dynamic barrier beach is home to a diverse range of ecosystems, each with its own distinct climate, soil, and vegetation. 

Throughout this tour we’ll be identifying the unique plant communities which help to shape Fire Island, as well as several specific species which will help us to better understand its dynamic nature. As we move from ocean to bay we’ll travel in time through the faces of Fire Island. 

Before beginning, please be aware of the presence of ticks, mosquitoes, and poison ivy on the island. The Rangers here recommend exercising caution, staying on trails, wearing bug spray, avoiding tall grass and brush, and, perhaps most importantly, inspecting yourself for ticks when you get home. Please remember to stay hydrated, and to protect yourself from the sun. 

The Sunken Forest and Sailors Haven are special places, home to many wild animals and plants. Please be respectful of them and of other visitors by keeping the park clean. We encourage visitors to carry in/carry out, removing all trash with you upon departure. 

Please proceed to the ocean beach, where we will begin our journey across the crown jewel of Fire Island.

stops.significance: This view of the ocean beach gives us a glimpse into Fire Island's earliest days.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around and head back down the boardwalk, north toward the bathrooms. Continue until you near the sand crossing.
stops.audioTranscript:
It may seem odd to start a tour of the forest here at the ocean beach, but in order to understand what makes the Sunken Forest so special it helps to understand where the forest came from.

For humans, the ocean beach is a relaxing and hospitable place, but for many plant species, the ocean beach is incredibly challenging. Survival here is not easy. Consider, for example, the forces of ocean tides, winds, waves, salt water and storms and you start to see why most plants avoid growing here. Sand is a particular challenge for many plant species, as it lacks the nutrients of soil, and as it shifts and moves too easily for most plants to adequately settle.

Atop the dune you may notice a small variety of hardy plants, from amaranth to beach pea, growing on the sands below. Perhaps the easiest plant on Fire Island to overlook is also, perhaps, its most important. Gaze from the ocean to the toe of the Dune and you’ll notice the very first plant occupying this exposed, ever changing, and nutrient-poor environment. American Beach Grass is Fire Island’s first pioneer.

American beach grass is tougher than most plants. Over millions of years it has evolved to survive where other plants cannot. There are many adaptations which make American Beach Grass suitable to this environment. 

One such adaptation is the unique structure of American Beach grasses' vast system of underground roots. These roots are interconnected, running from plant to plant. They enable beach grass to move water throughout its system from one plant to another while holding the grass together, keeping it grounded in the face of shifting sands and strong ocean storms.

As the roots run underneath the beach they help to hold the dunes together. In the same way that pioneers might begin settling in a new place, making it habitable for other people, pioneer species such as American beach grass shapes the island, making it habitable for everything which grows behind the protective barrier of the primary dunes.

stops.significance: The swale is an arid, almost desert-like habitat.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed north down the main walkway toward the marina and visitor center where you began. To your left you'll spot a sign that reads "Sunken Forest"
stops.audioTranscript:
Protected from the ocean by the primary dunes, this ecosystem is home to a wider variety of plant species than the ocean beach. Look around and you’ll notice the stout gray and green patches of Beach Heather, lush bushes of Beach Plum, or even the scrubby form of Pines and Cedars.

The “swale”, as this area is called, is the open space between the primary and secondary dune line. Swale’s on Fire Island host a variety of plant species which are often associated with Long Island’s coastal environments. Many of these plants are not as well adapted to the harsh conditions of the ocean beach as American Beach Grass, but they are still quite hardy. As the American Beach Grass primes the environment by constructing protective dunes and forming soil through decomposition, they are succeeded by the plants we see here. 

“Succession” refers to the gradual process of change in an ecosystem brought about as one community of plants is replaced progressively by another. On Fire Island we can travel through time through different stages of succession as we move from the ocean to forest. 

Most of the plants which call the swale home are well-adapted to its unique conditions. Swales can be hot spots. Situated between the two dune lines, swales often lack a comfortable breeze. Swales are also sunnier environments, as the white sandy faces of the two dunes refract light into the swale like a sun reflector one might use to tan on the beach. Because of this, swales are arid and desert-like habitats, sometimes even supporting cacti and other desert-like species.

One iconic swale plant is Bayberry. Bayberry bushes have several unique adaptations designed to help them survive in the sunny swale. They are easily identified by the presence of the small whitish berries to which they owe their name. Observe the berries closely and you will see a thin coat of wax which helps the berry to retain moisture. As wax is hydrophobic, water is unable to escape the berry, preventing them from shriveling up in the hot sun. This wax has been used traditionally in the production of special “bayberry candles” often associated with good fortune when burnt on cusp of the new year.

stops.significance: The entryway to this globally rare ecological community.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest at Sailors Haven
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the forest trail for a short stretch until you arrive at an open platform featuring benches and several log-pillars.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are about to enter the Sunken Forest, a globally rare ecological community and home to a diverse array of wild animals and plants. It is one of just two forests of its kind on the entire planet. 

The process of succession which led to this climax community likely began over 300 years ago, when a large set of both primary and secondary dunes made this environment habitable to the trees which make it unique. The Sunken Forest is, more specifically, a maritime holly forest meaning that it is an ocean-side forest predominantly made up of American Holly trees. It’s sister forest is also preserved by the National Park Service, and is located in Sandy Hook New Jersey at Gateway National Recreational Area.

First protected from development in the early 1950s by a concerned group of private citizens, a roughly 50-acre tract of beach, dunes and ancient holly forest just east of Point O'Woods was gradually cobbled together through a fundraising campaign spearheaded in 1952 by the Wildlife Preserves, Inc, and The Nature Conservancy. The Sunken Forest Sanctuary was officially dedicated as the Sunken Forest Preserve in 1960. The entrance plaque can still be seen along the western trail entrance.

In May 1966, the Sunken Forest Preserve, Inc. donated the property to the recently established Fire Island National Seashore, under the condition that the property shall always be maintained in its natural state and operated as a sanctuary, and that no public road or highway shall be built through it.

As a globally rare ecosystem, the Sunken Forest is an astounding example of biodiversity. As you walk through the forest take care to listen for migrating songbirds, stoic box turtles, slithering black racer snakes, and grazing deer. These are just some of the creatures that make their home in this sanctuary.

stops.significance: Stop here to learn more about how salt spray from the Atlantic Ocean impacts the trees here in the Sunken Forest.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: Salt Spray Dynamics
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the boardwalk trail, past the bay overlook, until you come to a tree on your left-hand side that features many small holes.
stops.audioTranscript:
As a “climax community” The Sunken Forest would not exist except through centuries of gradual succession. From Beach Grass to Bayberry, Pitch Pine to Black Berry Cherry, each plant that has grown on Fire Island has helped to pave the way for what you see here. Look above at the flat canopy overhead and you may start to understand why this place is so unique. Where else on Long Island can you listen to the crashing of ocean waves beneath a canopy of towering trees?

This forest exists in a delicate state of balance. As waves on the beach crash, they toss salt into the air forming what is commonly referred to as “Salt Spray.” To humans salt spray can be quite pleasant, it’s what gives the beach that familiar summer smell, but salt spray can have a harsh effect on plants, sapping their leaves of precious water. 

As that salt spray travels across Fire Island, carried across by the ocean breeze, it sweeps through the swale and other plant communities. Most of these communities are somewhat adapted to that constant exposure to salt spray, but here in the Sunken Forest the trees are not. 

So then, how do these trees manage to grow in an environment which is normally so inhospitable to them? The answer lies in the set of ancient dunes you see before you. Here at Sailors Haven we are lucky to have not only a robust and healthy set of primary dunes, those tall hills of sand you saw when you began on the beach, but also a vast system of secondary dunes. It’s this double dune system which acts as a shield, protecting the forest from the effects of salt spray exposure. 

Though the dunes work to protect the forest from most of the salt spray, containing it upon the beach and within the swale, some of that salt spray continues to sweep above the canopy of trees you see overhead. As it does it actively trims or “prunes” the trees in an effect we call “salt spray pruning.” Pay attention to the height of the trees as you walk through the Sunken Forest. You will notice that as you rise closer to the top of the dunes, the trees will shrink, and as you sink below the dunes the trees will grow. It is as if a “salt spray ceiling” sits above the forest preventing its upward growth. This creates the “Sunken” effect to which this forest owes its name, as the trees appear to have sunk into the dunes they grow upon.

When it comes to salt spray, however, it is not all destruction. Even as the salt trims the tree tops, potentially killing the forest if the dunes were to suddenly vanish, that same salt spray is what enables this forest to grow here at all. You see, Fire Island and the Sunken Forest are young ecosystems. Their soil is sandy and thin. Even still, were you to investigate the soil of the Sunken Forest you would find it packed with minerals and nutrients brought in by that same salt spray. Those minerals and nutrients act as food for the trees. Without this delicate balance, this forest would not be here for us to enjoy.

stops.significance: Juneberry is one of the three primary species which make up a bulk of the Sunken Forest canopy.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the Sunken Forest trail for several minutes. Along the way you will pass a small hill and several bends in the trail. You will arrive at a wide clearing in the trees overhead, and may see standing water alongside short shrubs.
stops.audioTranscript:
Though the Sunken forest is made up of a wide range of tree species, from oaks to maples, pines and cedars, three of the most common species here make up a bulk of the canopy. 

The tree before you is commonly referred to by several names. Around here it often referred to as “Juneberry”, though you may also hear it identified as “Serviceberry”, “Shadblow”, “Shadbush”, or “Shadtree.”

The first name, Juneberry, is likely the easiest to remember and to identify. “Juneberry” comes from the fact that its berries, quite tasty though containing large seeds, often appear and rippen throughout the month of June. 

The name “Shadblow” is often tied to a fish called shad which, like salmon in the pacific, travel from the ocean up rivers like the Hudson in order to lay their eggs. Fishermen would use the appearance of flowers on “Shadblow” in early spring to know when the shad run had begun. 

The last name “Serviceberry” is among the more interesting names for this tree. Various accounts suggest that the appearance of its flowers in the early spring are often associated with the thawing of winter ice in the ground. This is important, especially up north, when ground ice can prevent the digging of holes. As a result of this tree's timing, it is often planted in front of funeral homes and in graveyards to help indicate the time of year when thawing ground ice allowed for the digging of graves and hosting of funeral “services”. This, of course, is just one of several stories associated with the name “serviceberry.”. 

You may notice the odd little holes in this tree. These holes were created by a small woodpecker called a “yellow-bellied sapsucker.” Sapsuckers, as their name implies, poke holes into the side of trees in order to drink their sap.

stops.significance: A break in the forest canopy reveals a bit more about the unique ecology of Fire Island.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: Freshwater Bog
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the boardwalk for a few minutes until you come over a large hill and into an open clearing that features a stand of tall cornstalk-like phragmites.
stops.audioTranscript:
You might imagine that, for many wild animals living on Fire Island, water can be a scarce commodity. While there is plenty of water to the south in the Atlantic Ocean, that water is too salty to drink. The same is true of the brackish water north in the Great South Bay. In light of this, the location in front of you is a critical site for wild animals, as this is part of Fire Island where the island itself dips low enough for fresh rain water to collect. Because of this, this site is an excellent place to observe wild animals such as birds, butterflies, turtles and other creatures.You may also see an interesting assortment of plants such as blueberry and cranberry. 

While these small wetlands are critical to the ecosystem of the Sunken Forest, there are some indications of trouble ahead. Over the last sixty years many of these small bogs have appeared to be growing, spreading throughout the forest as the “vadose zone”, the dry space between the water table and the surface of the ground, appears to thin. This thinning has already impacted the ecology of the Sunken Forest, killing some trees and spreading species that were once uncommon here. The tall bushes of groundsel in front of you were once much less prevalent then they are today. Now, as more water appears throughout the forest, groundsel is a more common sight. 

Fire Island is always changing, and this dynamic nature is part of what makes it so unique. The Sunken Forest, however, is among Fire Island’s more stable systems. It exists within a delicate state of balance that has persisted for centuries, allowing for the growth of an assortment of trees and other plants that make this such a rare habitat. Today, however, there is evidence of various forces that are actively upsetting this balance.

stops.significance: This stand of phragmites reveals much about historical interaction with natural landscapes.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: Phragmites Stand
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the boardwalk trail. You will turn a corner and approach another clearing. Before you reach the clearing look for one of several small to mid-sized trees that feature deep criss-crossing bark, and round leaves with single, double, and triple lobes.
stops.audioTranscript:
As you came over the last small dune you may have noticed a dramatic change in the landscape. The location where you now stand exists largely on the outskirts of the Sunken Forest, where fresh water bogs give way to freshwater and saltwater marshes. These marshes are dominated not by trees, but by an assortment of species which are well adapted to growth within habitats which feature consistently wet soil. Native species you may spot from here include swamp rose mallow, blueberry, and some strains of native phragmites. However, most of what you see growing here, these tall cornstalk-like grasses, are of a non-native and potentially invasive variety of phragmites.

Phragmites Australis, or common reed, is a tall and hardy wetland grass broadly distributed and found throughout many parts of the world. Though it’s status is a subject of debate, in many places throughout North America it is considered non-native and even invasive. In the same way that an invader takes over the territory of another group of people, an invasive species aggressively takes over the habitat of a native species. In the case of Phragmites Australis, this takeover is the result of its aggressive root system, its tall overcrowding stalks, and the release of a corroding substance called “gallic acid” by the plant as it decays. 

Most of this Phragmites Australis is itself something of a colonial artifact, likely introduced by Europeans during the early to mid-stages of expansion into North America throughout the late 17 and early 1800s. It was often used within the hulls of ships as ballast material, or alternatively as thatching on the roofs of houses. Everywhere European ships landed, Phragmites Australis followed. 

Today Phragmites Australis is closely observed and maintained by the National Park Service, especially in areas where it appears to be expanding. Here in the Sunken Forest Phragmites Australis is considered somewhat naturalized, having replaced native stains of Phramites Australis that came before. Recent DNA evidence suggests that some strains of Phragmites Australis actually predate European colonization, though these strains are usually less common and less aggressive.

stops.significance: Sassafras is among the three primary species of tree in the Sunken Forest.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the forest trail a short distance until you come to the next clearing. There you may see the iconic conrdog-like punks that adorn the central stalks of cattail.
stops.audioTranscript:
Sassafras is among the three most common species of tree here in the Sunken Forest. It is easily identified by its three distinct leaves. Look closely and you’ll notice single-lobed leaves, double-lobed leaves which look similar to mittens, and triple-lobed leaves which look a bit like a dinosaur's foot. You may also notice the deep criss-crossing and cinnamon colored bark of mature trees.

Sassafras is an exceedingly useful plant to both wildlife and people. While it is no longer very commonly used, having been linked to carcinogenic properties, everything from its roots to it’s leaves were once traditionally been used for medicinal, culinary, and aromatic purposes. It’s many uses made it an extremely valuable plant to the economy of colonial America and the early United States.

Perhaps most popularly sassafras was once commonly used in the production of root beers and teas. Its dried and ground-up leaves are also an important ingredient in traditional Louisiana-based creole cooking. Oil extracted from its leaves and bark were used in many products for its aroma. Today it’s scent is replicated in many artificial aromatics. You’re probably familiar with the smell of sassafras, whether you know it or not.

stops.significance: Cattail is an iconic wetland grass with a variety of uses.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the trail for a short distance until you come to the next stand of trees.
stops.audioTranscript:
Cattail is another species of plant commonly sighted throughout wetland habitats on Fire Island. You can readily identify it by the long corndog-like “punk” that adorns its central stalk during parts of the year. You may also recognize its fan-like base and flat blade-like leaves.

“Cattail” refers to a genus of over 30 species of plant found throughout many parts of the world. Able to survive in muddy and wet soil, cattail is often among the first plant species to take root in newly moistened habitats. The fluffy dandelion-like seeds of its decaying punks are easily spread with the wind. While cattail is considered native to this region it is considered invasive in some places.

Throughout the world, species of cattail have been made useful to people in many aspects of life, from agriculture, to building material, and even as biofuel! Native Americans, who were the first to visit Fire Island, had many uses for this plant. The seeds from its punks can be used as tinder to start fires and as insulation. Its stalk, roots and rhizomes can be eaten outright, or used to produce flour for making bread and other baked goods.

The abundance of cattail, as well as oysters, clams, and even seals on Fire Island meant that Native American Tribes such as the Unkechaug of Poospatuck often visited and made use of the island and it’s resources. The Unkechaug were famously skilled whalers who launched their boats from these shores. Since long before the arrival of European colonists, this land has been a home and haven to many.

stops.significance: The Sunken Forest is one of just two maritime holly forests on planet earth. Stop here to learn a bit more about American Holly trees.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: Holly Grove
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed a short distance until you come to the next break in the canopy. Look carefully off of the boardwalk to your left for the decaying trunk of a fallen holly tree.
stops.audioTranscript:
Near the beginning of this tour we mentioned that the Sunken Forest is one of two maritime holly forests on the planet. You are probably familiar with holly. It’s pointed leaves, and the bright red berries of the female plants are often associated with the holiday season. Look closely at the bark and you may also notice its slight greenish hue, and the odd eye-like knots that adorn its surface. Those eyes are, or course, not eyes at all, but the remnants of old branches shed from the tree in a process called “self-pruning.” 

Ilex Opaca, or American Holly is a broadleaved evergreen native to the Northeastern United States. Though it is hardy, it is not a particularly salt-tolerant plant and so, rarely occurs in this density as close to the ocean as we are now. Protected from the salt spray by the tall set of primary and secondary dunes, these trees have beaten the odds and grown in a most unlikely spot.

There are, unfortunately, signs of trouble in regard to this rare stand of holly trees. Look out to the ground and you may notice almost no young saplings or adolescent holly. Over the last sixty or so years the Sunken Forest has undergone a dramatic transformation. What was once a thick understory is now relatively barren, a worrying sign for future generations. But, what happened to all of the young holly?

You may be surprised to hear this, but holly saplings are popular food items for herbivores such as deer on Fire Island. Though it’s leaves are sharp and painful in mature holly, young saplings feature soft and juicy leaves. As a result of overgrazing, due in no small part to the exceedingly large population of deer on Fire Island, an entire generation of holly trees is missing from the forest. This means that if and when an adult holly tree dies or is knocked over, its children are no longer there to replace it.

But how can the deer be having this impact on the Sunken Forest only now? The unfortunate answer lies in our hands. There are estimated to be as many as three to four times as many deer on Fire Island then can survive here on their own based on the island's acreage. This unusually dense population appears to be the result of illegal or accidental feeding. Whether they are rummaging through garbage pails, or taking food from the hands of visitors, deer often become sickly or unhealthy from this process. Even still, many survive and reproduce at much higher rates than you would expect in a wild space. As a result of their proliferation, the Sunken Forest and many other habitats on Fire Island have been placed in jeopardy.

What can you do to help both the deer and the Sunken Forest? Above all it our goal to ensure that we keep wildlife wild. This means that under no circumstances should we feed or interact with wild animals such as deer. We must also take care to secure our food and garbage away from deer. With this in mind we can all do our part to take care of this environment holistically, ensuring the health and safety of the deer, the holly, and all of the other plants and animals which make this place unique.

stops.significance: At this site we can contemplate the forces of change and preservation.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: Change and Preservation
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the main path until you arrive at a large open platform where several trails converge.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you had stood here in the summer of 2012 you would have been comfortably shaded by the towering body of a tall holly tree. Looking closely to brush before you and you may see its decaying trunk and skyward roots. The holly tree that once stood here came down during Superstorm Sandy in October of 2012. It’s collapse is a troubling sign.

Tree’s falling in forests, of course, is not uncommon. In fact, trees collapsing due to illness or other factors is an important part of the natural life of forests. Decaying trees, branches and leaves enrich the soil of the forest, providing food for the plants which would grow up in its place. As trees fall they open up holes in the canopy overhead, allowing light to reach down to plants where it could not before. This allows young trees and saplings to grow in its place. 

The natural replacement of one tree with another is part of the process that fuels the succession we talked about before. In stable “climax communities” when an adult tree dies it is replaced by its own young. For reasons we outlined at our last stop this process is being interrupted. You may notice, for example, sapling Black Cherry trees growing in this holly’s place. Black cherries, though tasty to us, are not particularly popular with deer. Their leaves are packed with cyanide and likely to upset their stomachs when eaten. This results in what is called “selective grazing” where herbivores actively shape an ecosystem by eating some things and avoiding others. 

Black cherries, while native to this area, are common on Fire Island, thus the rare maritime holly forest is slowly being replaced by a more common habitat, representing a loss of global biodiversity.

But why did this tree fall in the first place? Recall when we discussed the rising water table, and thinning “vadose  zone” while visiting the freshwater bog. Look below the boardwalk and you may see standing water beneath the holly tree’s roots. For many years this tree grew up in dry soil. By the time the tree collapsed, it’s soil was inundated with water which likely contributed to “root rot” and it’s eventual fall.

All around the Sunken Forest water is appearing in places where it did not before. Scientists in the park have been observing this phenomenon, monitoring the water table and testing it for salinity from sea water. It appears as though the water table on Fire Island is rising in concert with sea-level rise, one very troubling symptom of anthropogenic, or human-cause, climate change.

stops.significance: The Heart of the Sunken Forest is the space where the trails converge.
stops.assetName: The Sunken Forest Tour: The Heart of the Forest
stops.directionsToNextStop: You may wish to continue down either path to explore the Sunken Forest. Take the path to your left for the fastest route to the final stop of the Sunken Forest Tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
We call this “the heart” because it is the space where the trails all converge. From here you may choose to proceed west, down the longer loop to your right, or south, down the trail to your left. This audio tour will continue down the southward trail for one last stop. 

Before we proceed to that stop, however, it is useful to take stock of what we’ve learned. This spot is not just “the heart” because of the trails convergence. It is also one part of Fire Island where the holly trees which make the forest so special grow the tallest. Many of these trees are a hundred to two hundred years old. They exist here within a delicate balance, one managed by each and every plant and animal which calls this forest home. 

The forces of wind, waves, and water are constantly reshaping Fire Island, but here an unusual degree of stability has fostered a globally rare ecosystem, and a profound example of  biodiversity. As stewards of this forest, you are part of this delicate balance, responsible for its continued survival and enjoyment for yourself and for future generations. 

It is up to us to find solutions to these monumental problems. Concerning the deer, it is easy to avoid feeding them. In addition to artificial reduction and other related management policies we believe it is possible to restore balance between the deer and this environment, but only if we are careful to respect wildlife and keep it wild. 

As to climate change it is important to remember that human produced greenhouse gases like CO2 are contributing most to the planet's warming, producing a “heat trapping blanket” which envelopes the earth's atmosphere. By reducing carbon emissions from greenhouse gases, and by maintaining and even cultivating habitats like this we could work to offset these effects. It may feel like an overwhelming task, but the future remains unwritten. 

Though there are concerning signs of decline due to climate change and due to human interaction with the island’s deer, our scientists are actually quite hopeful. They believe that with respect and proper management, this forest can continue to shade us for years to come.

stops.significance: This is the end of the Sunken Forest Tour. From here we can take a better look at the ocean, the swale, and the forest together to better understand the unique nature of Fire Island.
stops.assetName: Fire Island: A Story of Change
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the final stop of the tour. Visitors may choose to proceed down the boardwalk trail, or go back the way you came. The trail ahead converges with a concrete walkway. Go left on that walkway to return to the bathrooms, and right to walk down the longer forest loop. You may also head straight out onto the ocean beach.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the end of the Sunken Forest tour. We hope that you enjoyed your time exploring this incredible place. From atop the secondary dune we can see clearly the desert-like swale, the primary dune, and the vast Atlantic Ocean. To the west you can see Point ’O Woods and other Fire Island communities. To your east stands a short but remarkable little American holly tree.

Compare this holly to the ones you saw in the heart of the forest and you may recognize the effects of salt spray pruning. Where before the trees stood tall, now they are short and stubby. You may even notice their windswept or hedge-like appearance, as though someone came here and trimmed its top off. 

For over three-hundred years the Sunken Forest has stood as a profound and unique example of the resilience and adaptability of life on a constantly shifting barrier island. There are lessons to learn from this everywhere we look. You need only to keep your eyes open.

Proceeding from here visitors may choose to go back the way they came, or to proceed forward into the swale. Be warned that the swale can be quite hot on sunny summer days. Once you are in the swale you will notice a concrete walkway. You may head left to return to the bathrooms near where we began, right to head back towards the heart of the forest down the longer loop, or straight out onto the ocean beach. Wherever you go we hope you will take time to listen to and enjoy this marvelous place. We also encourage you to visit the Sailors Haven Visitor Center to speak to a ranger, or even join one on a public tour!

Remember, Fire Island National Seashore is your national park. Thank you for joining us as we explored it together. 

The Sunken Forest Self-Guided Audio Tour was written, recorded, edited, and produced by Kelsey Sucena of the National Park Service and Fire Island National Seashore. 

All photographs by Kelsey Sucena of the National Park Service.

Special thanks to Chris Olijnyk, and Kristin Santos for editing and guidance. Thank you also to Dave Raymond and to Jordan Raphael for your wealth of knowledge on the Sunken Forest.

This audio tour is provided for free by Fire Island National Seashore, the National Park Service , and the United States Department of the Interior.

Thank you for joining us today.

images.title: The Sunken Forest
images.altText: A stand of trees surrounds a small pool of water, as light filters through the caopy overhead
images.caption: The Sunken Forest is a globally rare maritime holly forest. One of just two of it's kind on Earth.

data.title: The Truman Farm
data.description: Welcome to Harry S Truman National Historic Site. The Truman Farm tour will teach you about the 11 years Harry Truman spent on the farm.

park.fullName: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
park.name: Harry S Truman

tags: Harry S Truman National Historic Site

stops.significance: The farm home of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: Up the walk ahead of you is the Truman farm home.  It was originally called the Young farm, since it belonged to Harriet Louisa Young, Harry Truman’s maternal grandmother.  Harry Truman grew up in Independence and moved to Kansas City after he graduated from high school in 1901.  His father suffered some serious financial setbacks that year due to some bad investments, which resulted in the rest of the Truman family (that would be Harry’s mother, his father, his brother, and his sister) moving here to Grandview to live with Harry’s Grandmother, in 1905.  The next year, 1906, his father decided he needed Harry’s help to run the farm, so Harry left Kansas City, where he’d been working as a bank clerk, and came here to live here with the rest of his family in this farm house—with no running water, no heat, no electricity—he’d had all those things—he was 22 years old, grown up in town, and he’d never farmed a day in his life.  He learned, though, and ended up spending the next eleven years here.  By 1917, World War I had begun, and Harry enlisted in the military.  He came back from the war two years later, in 1919, and married Bess Wallace, who was living in her maternal grandmother’s home up in Independence.  That Independence home is what is now called the Truman home.  Harry moved in with Bess and her extended family in Independence and lived there the rest of his life—before, during, and after his time in the White House.  Mr. Truman never returned to farming, but he later referred to this property as “the finest place in the world.”  Most of the farm is gone now, but the old house still stands, as well as a couple of outbuildings that were here when Harry Truman lived here.  Take this short tour to learn about some of the experiences on this farm that helped shape a young man that grew up to be President of the United States.

stops.significance: Farm home of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: The house you’re standing in front of is not the first house that was built here.  The house you’re looking at was meant to be temporary.  The original house, built in 1867 by Harry Truman’s grandparents, Solomon and Harriet Young, sat on the same site as the current farmhouse.  That first house was a big, stately mansion with large rooms and long porches stretching along the north and south sides.  Harry’s grandparents, the Youngs, were wealthy people and their house reflected their status.  Unfortunately, however, that original house burned down in 1894.  Harry grandfather, Solomon, was dead by that time, and his grandmother had this smaller house in front of you constructed later that same year—1894—with the intention of turning it into a tenant house after she got around to rebuilding the big one.  But unexpected things happen sometimes, and, as it turned out, she never did get around to rebuilding the big one, so it’s this house you’re looking at that Harry Truman moved into in 1906.

stops.significance: Farm home of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: At the time Harry Truman moved here to his grandmother’s property, the farm was one of the largest in the state of Missouri—about four times the average Missouri farm, in fact.  Most farms in Missouri around 1910 were about 125 acres.  The Young farm was 600 acres.  If you look across Blue Ridge Boulevard to the west—that’s away from the farm house—you can see two stone pillars on the far side of the parking lot across the street.  Those pillars were there when Harry Truman lived here, and they mark the original entrance to the Young’s property.  The driveway came towards you, curved off to your left, and then pretty much followed the driveway you drove in on today.  It’s hard to imagine how much land was here at the time Harry lived here, but you can get a little bit of an idea just by seeing that their front yard used to be at least twice as long as it is now.  This was a lot of land, and it was worth a lot of money.  It also required a lot of work to keep a farm that size going, especially in the days when farmers still had to use horses and mules rather than tractors or combines.  Harry’s grandmother appreciated the Trumans coming to help her run the farm, and when she died in 1911—three years after the Trumans had been living here helping her—she left them all the land and all her money.  The Trumans should have been set, but unfortunately, other relatives tried to break the will.  The resulting lawsuit lasted about three years.  The Trumans got to keep the land but had to pay the other relatives $9,500.  The lawyers got $3,000.  Today, all that money—$12,500—would be worth over a quarter of a million dollars.  The resulting financial pinch caused the Trumans to have to mortgage the farm.  The mortgage meant that the Trumans, despite their best efforts and the fact that the farm made a ton of money, were never debt-free again for as long as they lived here.  “We always owed the bank something,” Mr. Truman later wrote, “sometimes more, sometimes less—but we always owed the bank.”

stops.significance: Farm of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: The chicken coop was here when Harry Truman lived here.  The outhouse and the shed to the right of the chicken coop were brought in later, but the chicken coop is original.  Farming has never been easy work, especially when one has to deal with animals.  One time Harry wrote to Bess in Independence that he’d been trying to get 29 pigs into the barn.  He got 15 of them in and then decided to put corn in the barn to entice in the rest of them.  All of them went in except what he called “the extra smart one,” who ran in, grabbed an ear of corn, and ran out right between Harry legs.  He fell down in the mud, the barn door came open, and all the pigs got back out.  Harry said that whenever the barn door was open and he didn’t want the pigs in there, of course, every one of them would go right in.  Chickens, however, when it came to farm animals, seemed the least offensive.  They’re mainly just dumb, but they don’t get into that much trouble.  Truman’s chickens did however, get lice, and Harry wrote Bess about his mother’s special recipe for chicken dip.  And it doesn’t sound like something the lice would enjoy.  He said his mother would get some chewing tobacco and steep it in hot water as if she was making tea.  He said she would use four twists per bucket.  Then she would put in enough cold water to cover up the chicken and cool down the water so the chicken didn’t get burned.  Next, she would put in a tablespoonful of melted grease.  Lastly, she would put her hand over the chicken’s eyes and bill (hold his nose, so to speak), and, as Harry wrote, “souse him good.”  “Young and old alike can go through the process without harm,” he told Bess.  He said it was a good idea to pick a warm day if you’re going to be dipping chickens.  For a young man who had grown up in town, life of this farm—chickens, chicken lice, extra smart hogs—it all must have taken some getting used to.

stops.significance: Farm of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: If you look down towards the back of the property, you can see some sets of stone posts.  These were originally gate posts.  If you walk up to them, you can see the remains of the gates and the hinges.  Fences ran down the length between the sets of posts and enclosed a big barnyard.  It looks like a lawn now, but when Harry lived here it was probably a big muddy mess.  Six hundred acres is almost a square mile, but this property wasn’t in a square.  It was more of a dog leg shape and extended straight back for over a mile.  It was good land, but farming was—and still is—an unpredictable profession.  Everything depends on something no one can control:  the weather.  “It rained within a quarter mile of our field and never a drop in it,” Harry wrote to Bess.  “There’s always something the matter with a crop. It’s either too dry or too wet or too short or too long or too much or not enough,” he wrote her in 1913. “If is the largest word in a farmer’s language.”  Certain things are just out of our control sometimes, and Harry Truman seems to have learned that here on this farm.  There was no time to sit around feeling sorry for himself or wishing things were different.  Harry had to learn to make decisions and deal with situations as they were, rather than as he would like them to be.  He later wrote, “Once I had made [a] decision, I didn’t worry over it.  If I made a wrong decision, I made another one to correct it.”  Of course, he had no idea about some of the decisions he was going to have to make in the future.

stops.significance: Farm of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: Harry Truman is known for his common sense and this pump is a good example of why.  In 1912, he painted the pump white because, as he wrote to Bess, “It stands immediately in front of the back door, and in one of those horribly dark nights I was telling you of when the Noland's were here, I was endeavoring to get out of Ethel’s way in a hurry and collided with the pump.  I dislocated my specs and gave myself a black eye.  For this reason, I decided to paint it white.  Now it can be seen on the darkest nights.”  “It was on the farm that Harry got his common sense,” his mother said later.  “He didn’t get it in town.”

stops.significance: Farm of Harry S Truman.
stops.audioTranscript: In 1914, Harry Truman bought a car, and this is the garage where he parked it.  It was a 1911 Stafford—he got it used.  There were only about three hundred of them made.  New, they sold $2,350—quite a bit of money in 1911.  Harry paid $650 for his.  In less than a month, he reported to Bess, “I have been endeavoring to learn to push an auto.”  His brother told him he should sell the car and use the money to buy cows.  He got the hang of it, though.  The Stafford gave him a freedom he’d never known before.  Most specifically, it allowed him to drive to Independence and see Bess much more often than he’d ever been able to do by taking the train.  It wasn’t long before he wrote her, “I am getting so I don’t object to driving like I did to begin with.  Getting sort of used to it I suppose—five thousand miles in three months is moving around somewhat….”  If you’d like to hear the end of the tour there's one more stop.

stops.significance: Farm of Harry S Truman,
stops.audioTranscript: It wasn’t the Stafford that took him away from the farm for good, though.  It was World War I.  He joined up in 1917, spent 1918 fighting in France, and by Spring of 1919, he was back in the States.  Within a couple of months, he and Bess were finally able to get married.  The courtship had gone on for nine years.  Both Bess’s father and grandfather were dead by this time and Harry moved into her family home in Independence, never to live on the farm again.  One wonders what he would have thought if you’d told him in 1906, when he first came to the farm at age 22, that he was going to stay for 11 years, spend two years fighting in a World War, and then, at age 35, finally marry the girl he’d had a crush on since he was six years old.  And of course, one wonders what he would have thought if you’d told that 22-year-old farmer (as he was dipping chickens) that he was going to be the president of the United States someday.  “We can never tell what’s in store for us,” he wrote later.  And of course, none of us can.  And that’s the story of Harry Truman.  Thanks for taking the Truman Farm Home cell phone tour.

images.title: Truman Farm Home
images.altText: The two-story white Truman farm home with a front porch and green trim.
images.caption: The Truman Farm Home

data.title: The Tukudika
data.description: This audio tour introduces you to the Tukudika Indians, a band or related bands of Mountain Shoshone whose teviwa (Shoshone for homeland) included the area that is now Yellowstone National Park. During the tour, you will learn about Tukudika lifeways. As you listen, imagine what Yellowstone might have been like before it became the world’s first national park. Reflect upon what the concepts of home and lifeways mean to you.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the Grand Loop Road from Roaring Mountain to Obsidian Cliff. There is a parking lot and interpretive signs just north of Obsidian Cliff.
stops.audioTranscript:
This audio tour introduces you to the Tukudika Indians, a band or related bands of Mountain Shoshone whose teviwa (Shoshone for homeland) included the area that is now Yellowstone National Park. The tour begins at Roaring Mountain, then takes you to Obsidian Cliff, Indian Creek, and Sheepeater Cliff, where it concludes. If traveling from the north (Sheepeater Cliff), you can begin the tour there. At each stop, you will learn about Tukudika lifeways. As you listen, imagine what Yellowstone might have been like before it became the world’s first national park. Reflect upon what the concepts of home and lifeways mean to you. 

Roaring Mountain takes its name from the fumaroles (steam vents) that punctuate its surface. The name makes the geologic feature seem lifelike. Thinking about the significance of place names creates an opening for thinking about how Native American names are both used and misused. Tuku is the Shoshone word for bighorn sheep, and dika is the Shoshone word for eaters. Thus, Tukudika means “eaters of the mountain sheep.” The Shoshone gave their bands names for the foods each band ate or for places they traveled to or stayed in. By the late nineteenth century, the name Sheepeater was commonplace in English. The name is not a misnomer; neither does it tell the full story of this fascinating group; and it was problematic because some early European American travelers used the name pejoratively. 

Nineteenth-century accounts by Euro-American traders and travelers claimed that Native Americans were afraid of thermal features and that this fear led them not only to give a wide berth to the features but to avoid the Yellowstone region altogether. Although this claim was easily debunked in the twentieth century, it bolstered the case of early park managers to remove American Indians from the park and move them onto reservations. In fact, Native Americans had many uses—practical, medicinal, and spiritual—for the area’s abundant thermal features. The Tukudika soaked the sinews of bighorn sheep in thermal waters in order to make them pliable for bow-making. Their well-designed bows were desirable trade goods to other Native Americans and to European Americans.

Of course, bows could not function alone. To learn more about their counterpart, the arrow, travel now to Obsidian Cliff.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue north to the Indian Creek Campground turn-off. There is a small parking lot and picnic area where you can stop and take in the river and views.
stops.audioTranscript:
Three miles from Roaring Mountain stands the massive Obsidian Cliff, which was formed out of a 180,000-year-old lava flow. Obsidian is volcanic glass that forms when rhyolitic (silica-rich) magma cools quickly, leaving no opportunity for crystals to form in the rock. (In the late nineteenth century, Obsidian Cliff was called Glass Mountain. This is another instance of a name that has changed as more knowledge has become available.) The higher the silica content, the smoother and sharper the stone. Silica accounts for more than 75 percent of obsidian’s composition, which makes it the ideal material out of which to fashion tools and weapons. 

Working in extended-family groups, the Tukudika dug out pits atop Obsidian Cliff with shovels made from bison or elk bone. (Numerous quarries have been identified at this site.) After the intense labor of flint-knapping, a cantaloupe-sized piece of obsidian would yield two to three arrowheads. In addition to arrowheads, the Tukudika and other Native American groups made spear points, knives, and scraping tools out of obsidian. Archaeological evidence of quarries and workshop sites is complemented by evidence of stone circles, which indicate that Native Americans camped near the cliff while they collected stone.

Obsidian Cliff provided an essential resource and may have also served as a neutral meeting ground where tribes could quarry the stone peacefully. Although Native Americans quarried many types of stone, including chert, most developed a definite preference for Obsidian Cliff obsidian, which they valued for its utility and abundance as well as for its beauty. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis tells us that obsidian was quarried here at least 11,000 years ago. Obsidian from this site traveled far and wide on North American trade routes.

The Tukudika were hunter-gatherers to whom trade routes were of vital importance.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue north on the Grand Loop Road until the turn-off for Sheepeater Cliff just north of the bridge. Follow the side road to a view of Sheepeater Cliff.
stops.audioTranscript:
En route to Sheepeater Cliff is Indian Creek, so named for the trail that runs parallel to it. This path is believed to be part of the Bannock Trail, a corridor through the northern and northeastern parts of the park that connected seasonal hunting grounds and that was traversed by many Native American tribes.

Like many tribes of the western United States, the Tukudika were not fixed in one place. However, unlike most western tribes, including other Shoshone bands, they did not adopt the horse. Instead, they hunted on foot in alpine areas, accompanied by work dogs. These medium-sized dogs, which looked like a wolf-husky cross, hauled travois (two-pole sleds) laden with supplies. Archaeologists have uncovered evidence that the Tukudika were buried with their dogs, a finding that suggests the animals were also companions.

Fur-trapper Osborne Russell’s 1835 encounter with a group of Tukudika in the Lamar Valley (possibly also along the Bannock Trail) runs counter to other early Euro American stories, for it is generally positive, albeit somewhat romantic. Russell refers to the Tukudika as Snake Indians, another problematic name sometimes used for Shoshonean groups in the nineteenth century. He writes, “They were all neatly clothed in dressed deer and Sheep [sic] skins of the best quality and seemed to be perfectly contented and happy” (26). He goes on to describe camping with the Indians and trading household goods and tools for animal skins. “They were well armed with bows and arrows pointed with obsidian[.] The bows were beautifully wrought from Sheep, Buffaloe [sic] and Elk horns secured with Deer and Elk sinews and ornamented with porcupine quills and generally about 3 feet long” (26-7).

The Tukudika spent time in the Lamar Valley and along the Yellowstone Lake, but they are associated most closely with a geologic formation called Sheepeater Cliff. Indeed, this site helps us to understand the Tukudika’s day-to-day existence.

This ancient formation of columnar basalt, five miles south of Mammoth Hot Springs and in the shadow of Bunsen Peak, was named Sheepeater Cliff by Philetus Norris, Yellowstone’s second superintendent, for an Indian camp located here in the nineteenth century. Although Sheepeater Cliff was not the exclusive domain of the Tukudika, the area affords a microcosmic view of the Tukudika way of life, highlighting the ways in which they harnessed Yellowstone’s resources to forge a productive relationship to the land. A relatively protected area, Sheepeater Cliff possesses several useful features: cliffs that provide shelter and game, flat areas for setting up camp and work sites, and access to the Gardner River.

The Tukudika were known for their timber traps for game, particularly bighorn sheep, as well as for hunting blinds and drivelines. In addition to bighorn sheep (Ovis canadensis), the Tukudika ate small game such as deer, rabbits, and marmots. More than 50 percent of their diet consisted of plants, roots, nuts, and berries. For preparing these foods, they used steatite (soapstone) vessels. In camp, they constructed newe-gahni (Shoshone for “houses built to suit a specific purpose”), structures akin to wickiups. A typical structure was composed of lodgepole pine curved at the top and covered with grasses and leaves. It could be situated against a cliff face or rock overhang to provide greater shelter and stability.

Early park officials pined for an uninhabited, pristine wilderness. At the same time that writers, painters, and photographers depicted Yellowstone for a popular audience, American Indians were pushed out of the story and out of the frame by these first non-indigenous storytellers. In fact, even to early explorers, this land would not have seemed uninhabited, for signs of Native-American presence—trails, camps and campfires, hunting and fishing traps, wickiups and other structures, the quarry at Obsidian Cliff as well as other quarries—would have been thick on the ground.

The Shoshone word for homeland is teviwa, and the area you have just traveled through was once part of the Tukudika teviwa. (Indeed, many Native American groups consider Yellowstone to be part of their ancestral lands.) How might you expand your definitions of home and lifeways after listening to this tour? How might you see, or think about, the park differently now that you have this knowledge? What stories will you tell about your time in Yellowstone?

We hope you enjoyed learning about the Tukudika’s significance to Yellowstone National Park and about Yellowstone’s significance to them. To learn more about Native Americans in Yellowstone, visit the park’s web site (www.nps.gov/yell), where you can read pages on history, culture, and tribal relations. You can also search the entries in the park’s annual Resources and Issues Handbook.

data.title: The Underground Railroad in Boston
data.description: Over the next twelve stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers* along their way. This tour weaves through Beacon Hill followed by a few stops in Downtown Boston. The tour concludes at Long Wharf. *"Freedom seeker" refers to an enslaved person who took action to obtain their freedom from slavery (NPS Network to Freedom).

park.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
park.name: Boston African American

stops.significance:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Underground Railroad walking tour. Over the next 12 stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers.
Our tour begins here on Smith Court, a center of Black life and activism in 1800s Boston. The African Meeting House served as a church, schoolroom, and gathering space for the community. Here, Underground Railroad activists planned how they were going to help those escaping slavery.
Black Bostonians also gathered here in response to the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to roam free states in search of runaways and mandated the assistance of state and local authorities, as well as the public, in returning freedom seekers to slavery.
Those who lived in this court helped shelter freedom seekers, and in one case, saved a freedom seeker from an attempted capture by a slave catcher.
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you walk through Beacon Hill, please watch your step as many side walks are uneven. Exit Smith Court and turn right up Joy Street. Cross Myrtle Street and continue on Joy Street. Take the next right onto Pickney Street. Walk down the street until you reach the next intersection, then cross to the left side of the street, where you will find the Hillard House, 62 Pinckney Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Underground Railroad walking tour. Over the next twelve stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers along their way.
We will spend the first part of our tour on the north slope of Beacon Hill, home to Boston’s free Black neighborhood. Members of this community came together to provide a safe-haven and support for many freedom seekers.
We will then walk downtown where many Beacon Hill activists joined other Bostonians to engage in high profile protests and rescues.  
We will end our tour near the waterfront, which served as an entry point for so many freedom seekers on the Underground Railroad.      
Bear in mind, Boston’s Underground Railroad history is expansive. No tour, including this one, can claim to be all encompassing. Rather, we hope to shed light on some of the lesser-known stories, not already featured on our other tours, including the Black Heritage Trail, which you can find on the National Park Service app as well.    
Let’s get started. 
Our tour begins here on Smith Court, an integral center of Black life and activism in 1800s Boston. The African Meeting House, the three story-brick building with tall arched windows, served as a church, schoolroom, and gathering space for the community. Here, Underground Railroad activists planned how they were going to help those escaping slavery. For example, in the early 1840s, Black Bostonians formed the New England Freedom Association which held their meetings here.  According to William Cooper Nell, one of the leaders of this group: 
"The object of our Association is to extend a helping hand to all who may bid adieu to whips and chains, and by the welcome light of the North Star, reach a haven where they can be protected from the grasp of the man-stealer… "
Groups such as the New England Freedom Association, and later the Boston Vigilance Committee, provided funds, clothing, food, information, and other assistance to the freedom seekers coming to and through Boston on the Underground Railroad. 
In 1850, the federal government enacted a harsh new Fugitive Slave Law that allowed slave catchers to roam free states in search of runaways and mandated the assistance of state and local authorities, as well as the public, in returning freedom seekers to slavery.  Soon after, Black Bostonians rallied here at the African Meeting House to plan their collective response. Lewis Hayden, Boston’s most prominent Underground Railroad leader presided. One activist, Joshua B. Smith, militantly claimed, “If liberty is not worth fighting for, it is not worth having” and encouraged his listeners to arm themselves against the slave catchers...For as Smith said, “When he could not live here in Boston, A FREEMAN...’He had lived long enough.”
Directly across from the African Meeting House stands 3 Smith Court, the yellow house. According to the records of the Boston Vigilance Committee, Black activist and clothing dealer James Scott sheltered several freedom seekers here in the 1850s, as did William Cooper Nell, another prominent Underground Railroad operative, who also boarded here. Authorities arrested, tried, but did not convict Scott for his alleged role in leading the successful courthouse rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins in 1851.   
Smith Court also witnessed a dramatic Underground Railroad confrontation in 1847.  A slave catcher attempted to capture Mrs. Dorsey, a freedom seeker, in her home at the end of Smith Court. Black activist Nancy Prince hurried to the scene, grappled with the slave catcher, and threw him out of the house.  She then rallied the women and children who gathered during the commotion and got them to hurl stones and anything else they could find at the slave catcher, running him out of the neighborhood.   
Before we move on to our next stop, we encourage you to take a walk to the rear of Smith Court.  Look right and left, up and down the alley. See how tightly packed these little hidden homes and neighborhoods are.  These densely crowded streets and tucked away alleys and houses served as temporary homes and safe havens for so many freedom seekers fleeing slavery on the Underground Railroad.

stops.significance:
While much of the Underground Railroad activity in Beacon Hill occurred among the Black residents of the community, there are also instances of White allies providing refuge to freedom seekers. Two of these allies, George and Susan Hillard, used their status and privilege to shelter several freedom seekers at their home.
Susan Hillard was a staunch abolitionist and used her husband's political cover as a conservative politician to hide freedom seekers in their home throughout the 1850s. While it is unclear how much George knew of Susan’s ongoing Underground Railroad activities, he likely had some awareness and either did not interfere, or quietly supported her efforts.
The Hillards most notably sheltered freedom seeker Ellen Craft in October 1850 when slave catchers tracked her and her husband William to Boston. With the help of both the Hillards, Ellen and William Craft averted the slave catchers.
When the home underwent repairs years later, a secret attic was found, as well as two plates and two spoons.
stops.assetName: George S. and Susan Hillard House
stops.directionsToNextStop: With your back to the Hillard House, walk straight on to Anderson Street along the left side of the street. Turn left onto Revere Street. Turn right onto Grove Street. At the intersection of Grove Street and Phillips Street, turn left onto Phillips Street so that you are on the left side of the street. You can remain at this corner or walk down Phillips Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
While much of the Underground Railroad activity in Beacon Hill occurred among the Black residents of the community, there are also instances of white allies providing refuge to freedom seekers. Two of these allies, George and Susan Hillard, used their status and privilege to shelter several freedom seekers at their home here at 62 Pinckney Street.
At first glance, George Hillard did not appear to be the typical ally of the Underground Railroad. Although a former law partner to the radical abolitionist Charles Sumner and generally in favor of racial equality, George Hillard opposed the more radical abolitionist calls to end slavery immediately. As a federal commissioner, Hillard also had to uphold the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, which had strict consequences for those aiding freedom seekers. 
Susan Hillard, unlike her husband, was a staunch abolitionist and used George's political cover to hide freedom seekers in their home throughout the 1850s. Records document the Hillard home as a safe house for at least five freedom seekers during this time. While it is unclear how much George knew of Susan’s ongoing Underground Railroad activities, he likely had some awareness and either did not interfere, or quietly supported her efforts. 
The Hillards most notably sheltered freedom seeker Ellen Craft in October 1850 when slave catchers tracked her and her husband William to Boston. Upon hearing the news of the slave catchers’ arrival, Susan Hillard found Ellen Craft in a home on Mt. Vernon Street, the next street over. Susan acted immediately:  
"I proposed to Ellen to come and do some work for me, intending not to alarm her. My manner, which I supposed to be indifferent and calm, betrayed me, and she threw herself into my arms, sobbing and weeping…She, however, recovered her composure as soon as we reached the street, and was very firm ever after."   
George supported his wife’s efforts to conceal Ellen Craft. Susan recalled her husband saying, "I am perfectly willing to meeting the penalty, should [Ellen] be found here, but will never give her up."  
With the help of both the Hillards, Ellen and William Craft averted the slave catchers. 
From their unassuming home on Beacon Hill, George and Susan Hillard sheltered those on their journey to freedom. Evidence of 62 Pinckney Street’s Underground Railroad past gathered public attention decades after the Hillards lived here. According to a 1926 Boston Transcript article:  
"Only a few years ago, when some repairs were being made in the plastering of the ell, a well-concealed trap door in the ceiling of a closet unexpectedly dropped upon the head of a workman, revealing an unfinished space under the lean-to roof large enough to hold several human beings. This place was without windows, but it was ventilated in a measure by an opening into a shaft under a skylight. Recalling the tradition that this house had been a station on the ‘Underground’ in Mr. Hillard’s time the then owner had the place explored, with the result that two tin plates and two iron spoons were found on the floor. Were these the relics of the last meal ever served to fugitives under this roof?"

stops.significance:
You are now in the Lower Southac neighborhood, so named because Phillips Street once was called Southac Street. This neighborhood teemed with Underground Railroad activity.
Lewis and Harriet Hayden lived at number 66. The Haydens, who fled slavery themselves, sheltered scores of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft.
A couple doors down, 70 Phillips Street, was the home of Elizabeth Riley. Riley sheltered freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins in her attic after he was rescued from the courthouse.
The Riley home also included 1 Southac Court, where famed freedom seeker Jane Johnson and her sons lived. Johnson took in other freedoms seekers at her home here on Southac Court and at her later Beacon Hill residences.
Across the street stands 81-83 Phillips Street. Black lawyer, doctor, dentist, and activist, John Sweat Rock, lived here and provided medical care to freedom seekers. Two boardinghouses that housed freedom seekers once stood here as well, operated by John R. Taylor and William Manix.
stops.assetName: Site of William and Elizabeth Riley's House
stops.directionsToNextStop: With your back towards the downward slope of Phillips street, walk up Phillips street, crossing Grove street. Stop at around 44 Phillips Street. Look across the street to see the former site of Twelfth Baptist Church.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now in the Lower Southac neighborhood, so named because Phillips Street once was called Southac Street. This neighborhood teemed with Underground Railroad activity.  Feel free to walk down and up this block while listening to this stop, or find a place in the shade and look down the street.  
If you walk down the lefthand side of the street to number 66, with the dark green door and bronze plaque, you will come to the home of Lewis and Harriet Hayden. The Haydens, who fled slavery themselves, sheltered scores of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft. To learn more about the Haydens, we encourage you to take the Black Heritage Trail tour offered on the National Park Service App.
A couple doors down you will come to 70 Phillips Street, the home of Elizabeth Riley. In February 1851, slave catchers arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and held him at the courthouse. Within hours, Black Bostonians, led by Lewis Hayden, rescued Minkins and brought him to Riley’s home where she sheltered him in her attic. According to Lewis Hayden, he and Black attorney Robert Morris:  
“safely lodged him [Minkins] in the attic of a widow, Mrs. Elizabeth Riley, one of our race, whose fidelity and humanity we all fully confided in.'"  
The Riley home also included 1 Southac Court, one of those tucked away alley dwellings so prevalent throughout Beacon Hill.  The famed freedom seeker Jane Johnson and her sons lived here beginning in 1856. The year prior, Johnson and her sons escaped their enslaver John Wheeler as they all traveled through Pennsylvania, a free state.  Johnson and her sons came to Boston to begin their new life in freedom.  She courageously returned to Philadelphia a few months later to testify against Wheeler.  
According to the Liberator, when lawyers called Johnson to the stand:  
"The name was followed by a breathless silence and a buzz of incredulity…When Jane first appeared, he (Wheeler) laughed immoderately and nervously, then became deadly pale, and as the testimony went on, red and pale by turns. At last, he could bear it no longer, but picked up his hat and disappeared… " 
Johnson then left the courtroom escorted by abolitionists as well as state and local authorities, who guarded her from the federal marshals and slave catchers. Having secured her own freedom, Johnson took in other freedoms seekers both at her home here on Southac Court and at her later Beacon Hill residences. 
Diagonally across and a little further down the street stands 81-83 Phillips Street. You will see a plaque indicating that on this site once stood the home of John Sweat Rock, a Black lawyer, doctor, dentist, and activist.  Rock not only provided medical care to freedom seekers, but also had a strong friendship with Harriet Tubman, the famous Underground Railroad conductor, who stayed at his home when in Boston. Two boardinghouses once stood here as well, operated by John R. Taylor and William Manix. Boston Vigilance Committee records show that both Taylor and Manix sheltered many freedom seekers at their boardinghouses, including Jane Johnson and her sons.   
As you walk back up the street, reflect upon these stories of bravery and resilience. And remember, they only provide a snapshot of the Underground Railroad history hidden in plain view here in the Lower Southac neighborhood.

stops.significance:
Twelfth Baptist Church, known as the "Fugitive Slave’s Church," once stood at this approximate site. With many freedom seekers worshipping here, Twelfth Baptist Church served as a sacred space for its congregants as well as a center for Underground Railroad assistance.
Reverend Leonard Grimes led this church for 25 years. After growing up free in Virginia, Grimes dedicated his life to supporting freedom seekers, using his position in the Beacon Hill community to do so.
After the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, more than 40 congregants of Twelfth Baptist fled north out of fear of capture. Grimes raised money to pay for many of these individuals’ freedoms and supported many more freedom seekers on their journey.
Grimes played a role in almost every major fugitive slave case in Boston in the 1850s, as some of these freedom seekers, including Shadrach Minkins and Anthony Burns, worshipped at Twelfth Baptist.
Today, there is a plaque at the site of Leonard Grimes’ 28 Grove St. home.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking up Phillips Street, crossing Anderson Street and Garden Street. Cross to the left side of Phillips Street. 5 Phillips Street is halfway down the last block of Phillips Street before Irving Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
As you continue up Phillips Street, look across the street at a brick building with a geometric entryway. The Twelfth Baptist Church, known as the “Fugitive Slave’s Church,” once stood at this approximate site.  With many freedom seekers worshipping here, Twelfth Baptist Church became more than just a sacred space for its congregants. As an 1874 history of this church stated, 
"[Twelfth Baptist] was the home of the oppressed, the vantage ground of the champions of human freedom. … The fugitive was never refused its shelter and protection... In short, this church became the vantage ground of the “new party;” the platform from which slavery was assailed most grandly and fearlessly."  
Reverend Leonard Grimes led this church for 25 years, during the height of the anti-slavery era. With the support of his congregants, Grimes played a critical role in Boston’s Underground Railroad.  
Grimes became pastor of Twelfth Baptist in 1848, having moved to Boston several years prior.  Although he grew up free in Virginia, Grimes witnessed the horrors of slavery. He used his profession as a hackman, or carriage driver, to illegally transport freedom seekers. In 1840, Grimes was convicted and sentenced to two years of hard labor for helping an enslaved woman and her six children escape to Canada. While serving his sentence in Virginia, Grimes began preaching, which he continued to do once released. When he moved to Boston and became Reverend of Twelfth Baptist Church, Grimes used his position in the community to continue his support of freedom seekers.  
After the passage of the Fugitive Slave Law in 1850, more than forty congregants of Twelfth Baptist fled north out of fear of capture. Grimes raised money to pay for many of these individuals’ freedoms and supported many more freedom seekers on their journey.  
Grimes played a role in almost every major fugitive slave case in Boston in the 1850s, as some of these freedom seekers, including Shadrach Minkins and Anthony Burns, worshipped at Twelfth Baptist.  
When Grimes passed away in 1873, The Boston Globe printed,  
“It was credibly stated that [Grimes] had been instrumental in enabling four hundred persons of his own race to escape from Southern bondage.”   
Today, there is a plaque at the site of Leonard Grimes’ home at 28 Grove Street, near the intersection of Grove and Phillips Streets, just steps away from where you stand. Feel free to take a moment to visit this plaque before continuing with the tour.

stops.significance:
Here at 5 Phillips Street once stood the home of Henry Thacker, a prominent Black caterer and activist. In 1847, Thacker aided George and Lizzie Lewis, a father and daughter who escaped from slavery. Forced to separate on their journey north, Lizzie came to Boston and stayed at Thacker’s home. George, on the other hand, went to Albany, New York. While there, George learned his daughter was in Boston. Reverend Grimes visited George and assured George his daughter was safe with the Thackers. Soon after, Captain Austin Bearse, brought George to the city.
Outside this home is where father and daughter finally reunited.
Across the street lived Joshua Bowen Smith, known as the “Prince of Caterers.” In this high-profile position, Smith was able to keep a careful watch out for slave catchers. He also employed and assisted numerous freedom seekers. Smith lived with fellow activist John Coburn, who assisted with the rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse in 1851.
stops.assetName: Site of Henry L. W. Thacker House
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take a left at Irving Street and walk down to Cambridge Street. Turn right onto Cambridge Street. You can listen to the next stop while you walk or wait until you have reached Hancock Street. Pause at this corner and look across the street. This general area is the approximate location of William Craft's Shop.
stops.audioTranscript:
Here at 5 Phillips Street once stood the home of Henry Thacker, a prominent Black caterer and activist. His home is also a site of one heart-warming Underground Railroad reunion.   
In 1847, Thacker aided George and Lizzie Lewis, a father and daughter who escaped from slavery.  Forced to separate on their journey north, Lizzie came to Boston and stayed at Thacker’s home.  George, on the other hand, went to Albany, New York.  While there, George met a Black crew member of a ship from Boston who told him that he had met Lizzie and that she was staying “at Mr. Thacker’s in Southac Street.”  Reverend Leonard Grimes, who we just heard about, went to Albany and assured George that his daughter was safe and well in Boston with the Thackers.  Soon after, Austin Bearse, a ship captain and member of the Boston Vigilance Committee, brought George to the city. According to Bearse, when they reached the city, a fellow abolitionist took them to this street:  
"…and while we were looking for the number of the house, I heard some one say, “Well, there’s father!” We turned to look, and it was indeed Lizzie calling “Father!”"  
You stand today where father and daughter finally reunited.  Imagine the flood of emotions that took place in that personal and powerful moment here on that day.  
Across the street lived Joshua Bowen Smith, the militant abolitionist we heard from in the first stop at the African Meeting House.  Henry Thacker employed Smith in his catering business before Smith set out on his own and soon established himself as the “Prince of Caterers.” In this high-profile position, Smith was able to keep a careful watch out for slave catchers. He also employed and assisted numerous freedom seekers as a member of both the Boston Vigilance Committee and the New England Freedom Association.  
Here on Southac Street, Smith lived with fellow activist and New England Freedom Association member John Coburn, who was arrested for “aiding and abetting” the successful rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse in 1851. You can learn more about John Coburn on our Black Heritage Trail walking tour.

stops.significance:
Today’s bustling Cambridge Street looks different than the Cambridge Street of the mid-1800s, which was narrower and still somewhat residential.
