Black porter Burrill Smith, who sheltered freedom seekers and hosted the famed Underground Railroad conductor Harriet Tubman, lived at 168 Cambridge Street.
Black-owned businesses, including Lewis Hayden’s clothing shop, were also located on Cambridge Street. Many of these businesses, including Hayden’s, became informal community centers for activists. Sometimes, these shops also served as safe houses or rendezvous points for freedom seekers.
Freedom seeker William Craft established his cabinet making shop at 51 Cambridge Street.  When slave catchers came looking for William and his wife Ellen in October 1850, William barricaded himself in his shop. Abolitionists, “armed to the teeth,” guarded the Crafts and forced the slave catchers to abandon their plans and leave the city. The Crafts fled to England, returning to the U.S. following the Civil War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along Cambridge Street. Cross Bowdoin Street and pause at this corner to learn about the next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
We have just left the relatively quiet residential neighborhood of Beacon Hill and are now standing on Cambridge Street. Today, this is a bustling city street full of businesses, restaurants, hotels, as well as Massachusetts General Hospital. Cambridge Street of the mid-1800s, however, was narrower and still somewhat residential. Black porter Burrill Smith lived at 168 Cambridge Street. Not only did Smith shelter freedom seekers in his boardinghouse, but he also hosted famed Underground Railroad conductor Harriet Tubman during some of her early visits to Boston.
In addition to the residences here, Cambridge Street served as a hub of Black-owned businesses. Lewis Hayden, who escaped slavery with his family and later became Boston’s most prominent Underground Railroad operative, ran his clothing shop on Cambridge Street.1 Many Black-owned businesses, including Hayden’s, also became important informal community centers, where activists came together, conversed, and planned their collective action.  Sometimes, these shops also served as safe houses and rendezvous points for freedom seekers escaping on the Underground Railroad.  
William Craft, who had escaped slavery with his wife Ellen and stayed with the Haydens for a time, established his cabinet making shop at 51 Cambridge Street, which is no longer standing.  In Boston’s first test of the new federal Fugitive Slave Law, slave catchers came looking for William and Ellen Craft in October 1850. Evading capture while his wife hid with the Hillards, William barricaded himself in his shop armed with two knives and several pistols. One reporter claimed: 
"No man could approach within a hundred yards of Craft’s shop without being seen by a hundred eyes, and a signal would call a powerful body at a moment’s notice..." 
Abolitionists, “armed to the teeth,” guarded the Crafts and thwarted the slave catchers at every turn. Fearful for their own safety, the slave catchers ultimately abandoned their plans to capture the Crafts and left the city. The Crafts fled to England, and eventually returned to the United States following the Civil War.

stops.significance:
The Revere House Hotel, which used to stand here at Bowdoin Square, has unique ties to the Underground Railroad history of Boston.
In April 1850, Massachusetts Senator Daniel Webster delivered a speech at the Revere House Hotel in support of the Compromise of 1850. This package of legislation included the new Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to apprehend freedom seekers without due process throughout the country and mandated local and state authorities, as well as the public, to comply with it. Responding to fierce backlash, Webster called upon Massachusetts residents to enforce this law as their Constitutional duty, despite whatever misguided convictions they had.
Once in effect, the Fugitive Slave Law drew slave catchers to Boston in search of freedom seekers believed to be in the area. With its proximity to Beacon Hill's Black community, the Revere House Hotel provided enslavers and their agents a place to lodge while they pursued freedom seekers living and working in the city.
stops.assetName: Site of the Revere House Hotel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along this curved section of Cambridge Street. Once you reach the intersection of Cambridge Street, Court Street, and Tremont Street, cross the street towards the Government Center T stop. Walk a few steps along Court Street and then turn left to walk along the brick path between the T stop on the left and the buildings on the right. Feel free to find a place to sit along this curved path to listen to the next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now in Bowdoin Square and the former site of the Revere House Hotel. This Hotel has unique ties to the Underground Railroad history of Boston. 
In April 1850, Senator Daniel Webster, the famous statesman and orator from Massachusetts, arrived at the Revere House Hotel.  A month prior Webster delivered his infamous “Seventh of March” speech, throwing his full support behind the Compromise of 1850, a package of legislation that included the new Fugitive Slave Law. This law allowed slave catchers to apprehend freedom seekers without due process throughout the country, including free states, and it mandated the compliance of local and state authorities and the public at large. Facing strong backlash in Boston for his support of this law, Webster delivered a speech from the portico of the Revere House Hotel defending his stance as the way to ensure national unity. Standing on the front steps, Webster called upon Massachusetts residents to enforce this new law as their Constitutional duty, despite whatever “misguided” convictions they had.  
Once in effect, however, the Fugitive Slave Law drew slave catchers to Boston in search of freedom seekers believed to be residing in the area.  With its close proximity to the Black community on Beacon Hill, the Revere House Hotel provided enslavers and their agents a central and convenient place to lodge while they pursued freedom seekers living and working in the city.  
For example, in 1854, Col. Charles Suttle, the enslaver of Anthony Burns, tracked the young freedom seeker to Boston and stayed at the Revere House Hotel throughout the duration of the case. Abolitionists harassed Suttle from the moment he checked into the hotel.  Much like they did during the Craft case in 1850, activists kept a careful watch on Suttle and his colleagues and tried to impede them at every turn.  Suttle even had to relocate from the ground floor to an attic room at the hotel with armed guards due to credible death threats. 
The Fugitive Slave Law galvanized Bostonians to embrace more brazen and militant tactics to protect those seeking their freedom in the city.

stops.significance:
Writers for "The Liberator," a major printed voice of the anti-slavery movement, never shied away from confronting those who supported slavery and the Fugitive Slave Law. Instead, they advocated for open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law and called upon people to directly assist freedom seekers.
For almost three decades, "The Liberator’s" office stood on Cornhill Street, which was located roughly in this area of City Hall Plaza. 
Working alongside Black writers such as William Cooper Nell, editor William Lloyd Garrison used "The Liberator" to call for immediate emancipation and equal rights for Black Americans. This paper documented anti-slavery meetings and shared the stories of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft, Shadrach Minkins, Anthony Burns, and others.
When freedom seekers arrived in Boston, they knew they could find support and aid at "The Liberator" office. This office stood as a central hub of Underground Railroad activity where allies directly provided support for freedom seekers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along this path and turn left at the intersection. Walk to the top of the stairs and pause here to listen to the next stop about Faneuil Hall.
stops.audioTranscript:
Writers for The Liberator, a major printed voice of the anti-slavery movement, never shied away from confronting those who supported slavery and the Fugitive Slave Law, whether it be the slave holders themselves or those the writers saw as their northern accomplices, including Senator Daniel Webster. Instead, they advocated for open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law and called upon people to directly assist freedom seekers.
For almost three decades, The Liberator’s office stood on Cornhill Street, first at number 25 and later at 21 Cornhill, which was located roughly in this area of City Hall Plaza. This office served as a hotbed of both anti-slavery and Underground Railroad activity. 
Working alongside Black writers such as William Cooper Nell, editor William Lloyd Garrison used The Liberator to call for immediate emancipation and equal rights for Black Americans.4 This paper documented anti-slavery meetings and shared the stories of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft, Shadrach Minkins, Anthony Burns, and others.   
The paper matched its advocacy with direct calls for assistance for freedom seekers, whether it be money, clothes, or employment opportunities. After the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Robert Wallcut, General Agent of the paper and a member of the Vigilance Committee, printed an article titled, “To the Friends of the Fugitive,” stating: 
"Alarmed at the operation of the new Fugitive Slave Law, the Fugitives from slavery are pressing Northward…They are coming to us in increasing numbers, and they look to us for aid. ... who will help them? Their first and most earnest desire is for employment…Cannot you find… one or more places where the hunted slave may abide securely, and work through the winter? … Many of the fugitives come very poorly provided with clothing; and those who have garments of any kind to spare, will be sure to confer them on the suffering and needy by sending them, marked 'For fugitives,' at 21 Cornhill... "
When freedom seekers arrived in Boston, they knew they could find support and aid at The Liberator office. One abolitionist recalled that the attic of the office even served as a hiding place for freedom seekers.  
While the paper advocated for change through the written word, The Liberator office stood as a central hub of Underground Railroad activity where allies, such as the paper’s editor and general agent, directly provided support for freedom seekers.

stops.significance:
Faneuil Hall gained its reputation as the "Cradle of Liberty" from the meetings that helped inspire the American Revolution. It lived up to that nickname with its abolitionist and Underground Railroad connections.
By the late 1830s, Boston abolitionists began using Faneuil Hall to host meetings and rallies. Oftentimes, they called these meetings to protest high profile fugitive slave cases.
For example, in 1842, authorities arrested freedom seeker George Latimer, which prompted abolitionists to gather in Faneuil Hall to call for action against Latimer’s arrest. His case led to a petition drive that spurred the 1843 Personal Liberty Act, which prevented state officials and facilities from supporting the capture of freedom seekers.
Following the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Bostonians held a meeting here to establish the Boston Vigilance Committee. This organization provided valuable assistance to freedom seekers: shelter, clothing, money, legal aid, medical attention, and passage further north.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps to the intersection of the two pathways. Walk straight in between to two buildings, towards Court Street. At the light, cross Court Street. Turn right and cross Washington street. Feel free to rest at one of the benches along court street or walk up to the columned building, on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you look down the stairs and across Congress Street you will see Faneuil Hall. This historic gathering space gained its reputation as the “Cradle of Liberty” from the meetings held here that helped inspire the American Revolution. However, it equally lived up to that nickname when considering its abolitionist and Underground Railroad history.
By the late 1830s, Boston abolitionists had begun regularly using Faneuil Hall to host their meetings and rallies. Oftentimes, they called these meetings to protest high profile fugitive slave cases in the city, encouraging supporters to help those in need and thwart the slave catchers. 
For example, in 1842, authorities arrested freedom seeker George Latimer, which prompted major protests throughout the city. On October 30, abolitionists gathered in Faneuil Hall to call for action against Latimer’s arrest. Among other resolutions, the attendees declared: 
"if the soul-traders and slave-drivers of the South imagine that Massachusetts is slave-hunting ground, on which they may run down their prey with impunity...they will find themselves mistaken."  
Though Bostonians quickly purchased Latimer’s freedom, his case galvanized the abolitionist community. They soon gathered thousands of signatures for a petition that led to the passage of the 1843 Personal Liberty Act, which prevented state officials and facilities from supporting the capture of freedom seekers. 
A few years later, following the arrest of another freedom seeker in 1846, thousands of Bostonians once more gathered in the Hall in protest, with former president John Quincy Adams presiding over the meeting. Here they established a Vigilance Committee to assist those escaping from slavery on the Underground Railroad.  
With the passage of the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850, Bostonians flocked again to Faneuil Hall. At this meeting, the abolitionists expressed their outrage at the unjust and inhumane law. Abolitionist Caroline Dall attended this meeting and recorded her experience in her journal: 
"I could not resist going to the meeting at Faneuil Hall in the evening. It was a grand meeting. There was but one feeling among the 6000 persons assembled there, and that was to trample this law under foot." 
By the end of the meeting, those in attendance had established the final iteration of the Boston Vigilance Committee.  This organization provided valuable assistance to freedom seekers coming to and through Boston in the form of shelter, clothing, money, legal aid, medical attention, and passage further north for the duration of the Fugitive Slave Law years.

stops.significance:
Though no longer standing, the Boston Court House played a crucial role in several Fugitive Slave Law cases. In February 1851, authorities arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and brought him to this courthouse. Lewis Hayden and other militant abolitionists stormed the building, overwhelmed the guards, and carried Minkins to safety.
The federal government responded by arresting freedom seeker Thomas Sims a couple months later. This time, the courthouse was draped in chains and guards were stationed outside. Abolitionists could not free the heavily guarded Sims. On April 12, 1851, authorities marched Sims to Long Wharf and sent him back into slavery.
In 1854, slave catchers arrested freedom seeker Anthony Burns and brought him to this courthouse. Militant abolitionists led a failed assault on the courthouse to free Burns. In the aftermath of the assault, federal troops were brought in to guard the courthouse while Burns awaited his return into slavery.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down Court Street to the front of the State House.
stops.audioTranscript:
Though no longer standing, the Boston Court House played a crucial role in several Fugitive Slave Law cases. Feel free to walk to the columned building, where the courthouse once stood, or take a seat at one of the benches along Court Street while you listen along.  
In February 1851, five months after the Fugitive Slave Law went into effect, authorities arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and brought him to this courthouse. Lewis Hayden and other militant abolitionists heard about the arrest and decided to act. During the hearing, they stormed inside, overwhelmed the guards, and carried Minkins to the safety of Elisabeth Riley’s attic on Beacon Hill. Five days later he arrived in Montreal Canada where he lived free for the rest of his life. Rev. Theodore Parker later described the rescue of Minkins as  
“the most noble deed done in Boston since the destruction of the tea in 1773.”  
The rescue of Minkins sparked outrage from federal officials. Secretary of State Daniel Webster, former senator from Massachusetts, referred to the rescue as “a case of treason.”  
The federal government responded by showing they could enforce the Fugitive Slave Law in Boston with the arrest of freedom seeker Thomas Sims a couple months later. After escaping from Georgia, Sims lived in a boarding house in the North End of Boston until his arrest in early April. Holding Sims in this courthouse, federal officials took the threat of another rescue seriously. Guards were stationed outside of the courthouse, a militia was garrisoned at Faneuil Hall, and the courthouse itself was draped in chains, while Sims was held captive in a third-floor room. Describing the excessive display of force, Abolitionist lawyer Richard Henry Dana wrote, 
“Our temple of justice is a slave pen!”  
Undeterred, abolitionists hatched a plan to rescue Sims. They planned to place mattresses below the third story window where Sims was held so that he could jump to freedom. However, it appears officials heard of the plot and fixed iron bars to the window, thereby thwarting the plan. In the early morning of April 12, 1851, authorities marched Sims to Long Wharf and sent him back into slavery on the ship The Acorn.  
Three years after the return of Thomas Sims, the eyes of the nation again turned to Boston with the arrest of 20-year-old freedom seeker Anthony Burns. Born in Virginia, Burns escaped to Boston via ship and worked at a local clothing store. After slave catchers arrested Burns in May 1854 and brought him to this courthouse, word of his arrest quickly spread. Anti-slavery activists called for a mass meeting at Faneuil Hall while a smaller group of White and Black militant abolitionists met at Tremont Temple.  
During the Faneuil Hall meeting, the group from Tremont Temple began an assault on the courthouse to free Burns. Using a makeshift battering ram, abolitionists broke down the courthouse's door and began hand to hand fighting with federal marshals guarding Burns. The rescue attempt failed, but during the attack, an abolitionist fired a pistol, killing one of the deputies. 
In the aftermath of the assault, federal troops, with permission from President Franklin Pierce, were brought in to guard the courthouse while Burns awaited his return into slavery.  
Make your way to our next stop, the site of the Boston Massacre at the top of State Street, to hear more of Burns’ story.

stops.significance:
Standing in front of the Old State House, you will see a circular cobblestone marker commemorating the Boston Massacre, the 1770 incident in which British soldiers shot and killed five protesting Bostonians, including Crispus Attucks, likely a freedom seeker of mixed African and Native ancestry.
On the morning of June 2, 1854, federal troops marched Anthony Burns over this spot as they made their way to the waterfront where a ship awaited to bring Burns back to slavery. While hundreds of federal soldiers guarded and escorted Burns, an estimated 50,000 people lined State Street in protest.
The sad irony of federal marshals marching Anthony Burns back to slavery over this very spot where Attucks fell was not lost on the abolitionists in the crowd, who called it the "death of liberty."  
Nine months following Burns' return to slavery, Bostonians, under the leadership of Reverend Leonard Grimes, raised money and secured Anthony Burns’ freedom. He later attended Oberlin College and became a minister.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking down State Street, crossing through the Rose Kennedy Greenway. Passing the Marriott on the left, continue walking down State Street as it turns into Long Wharf. Pause any where along the wharf or continue to the end of the wharf to finish the tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
Standing in front of the Old State House, at the top of State Street, you will see set into the ground a circular cobblestone marker commemorating the Boston Massacre, the 1770 incident in which British soldiers shot and killed five protesting Bostonians, including Crispus Attucks, likely a freedom seeker of mixed African and Native ancestry.  
On the morning of June 2, 1854, federal troops marched Anthony Burns over this spot as they made their way to the water where a ship awaited to bring Burns back to slavery. While hundreds of federal soldiers guarded and escorted Burns, an estimated 50,000 people lined State Street in protest.  
Martha Russell, a journalist for the National Era, witnessed this procession and wrote: 
"Did you ever feel every drop of blood in you boiling and seething, throbbing and burning, until it seemed you should suffocate? Did you ever set your teeth hard together to keep down the spirit that was urging you to do something... that good and wise people would call violence - treason? I have felt all this today. I have seen that poor slave, Anthony Burns, carried back into slavery!" 
With the city under heavy martial guard, black drapes hung on buildings lining State Street and abolitionists strung up a coffin over the street with the word "Liberty" inscribed on it.  
This “death of liberty” served as a powerful metaphor in a city that strongly embraced its reputation as the “Cradle of Liberty” for its role in the early days of the American Revolution. The sad irony of federal marshals marching Anthony Burns back to slavery over this very spot where Attucks fell was not lost on the abolitionists in the crowd. 
Nine months following Burns’ return to slavery, Bostonians, under the leadership of Reverend Leonard Grimes, raised money and secured Anthony Burns’ freedom. He later attended Oberlin College and became a minister.  
Nine years after the military escorted Burns down State Street, the 54th Massachusetts, one of the first Black regiments in the U.S. Civil War, marched down the very same street amid huge fanfare as they set off to fight in the war of emancipation. Among their well-wishers along the route stood Thomas Sims, who had escaped slavery once again and returned to Boston.  
Reflecting on the procession down State Street, Captain Luis Emilio of the 54th Massachusetts wrote:  
"the band played the stirring music of John Brown's hymn, while passing over ground moistened by the blood of Crispus Attucks, and over which Anthony Burns and Thomas Sims had been carried back to bondage."

stops.significance:
Long Wharf, the port, and the surrounding harbor strongly tie to the history of slavery in Boston, from the years of the slave trade to those of the Underground Railroad and emancipation.
During the colonial period, local merchants created vast amounts of wealth by trafficking enslaved individuals and trading goods consumed and produced by enslaved labor. Long Wharf served as one of the primary entry points for enslaved individuals into the colony. During the Underground Railroad years, Boston’s wharves became both an entry and departure point for freedom seekers. While those such as Thomas Sims and Anthony Burns were forcibly transported back into slavery through the Harbor, the wharves also welcomed freedom seekers, such as Elizabeth Blakeley, as they took their first steps into a free state.
Freedom seekers and their supporters created a legacy of resilience, bravery, and sacrifice that continues to inspire us today and encourages us to consider how we too can ensure a more just and freer world.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are currently standing at the end of Long Wharf, the last stop of this tour. This wharf, the port, and the surrounding harbor strongly tie to the history of slavery in Boston, from the years of the slave trade to those of the Underground Railroad and emancipation.  
During the colonial period, local merchants created vast amounts of wealth by trafficking enslaved individuals and trading goods consumed and produced by enslaved labor. Long Wharf served as one of the primary entry points for enslaved individuals into the colony. The Middle Passage Port Marker formally honors and remembers the Africans who died and those who endured the transatlantic voyage known as the Middle Passage. It also recognizes the vital role that Africans and their descendants played in the development of both the Massachusetts Bay Colony and the United States. 
During the Underground Railroad years, Boston’s wharves became both an entry and departure point for freedom seekers. While those such as Thomas Sims and Anthony Burns were forcibly transported back into slavery through the Harbor, the wharves also welcomed freedom seekers as they took their first steps into a free state.  
Many people, including Burns and Sims, had escaped southern slavery by stowing-away on ships bound for Boston. The Boston Vigilance Committee stood ready to help those individuals, by sending “Committees of Reception” to ships suspected to have stowaways aboard. These committees provided food, clothing, and crucial information to freedom seekers. Black women served as critical members of these committees since captains rarely perceived them as threats. As Vigilance Committee member Thomas Wentworth Higginson recalled,  
"The practice was to take along a colored woman with fresh fruit, pies, &c – she easily got on board & when there, usually found out if there was any fugitive on board; then he was sometimes taken away by night." 
Captain Austin Bearse, another member of the Boston Vigilance Committee, provided aid to freedom seekers who came to Boston by sea. In one instance, Bearse learned of a stowaway on a ship docked near Castle Island, just south of Boston. Bearse sailed his boat up to the ship, but its captain immediately threatened violence if Bearse attempted to rescue the stowaway. Bearse returned here to Long Wharf to regroup. When he failed to find anyone to assist him, Bearse took bold action: 
"Knowing it was daylight soon I had to lay a plot. I took a dozen old hats and coats and fastened them up to the rail in my yacht, which gave me the appearance of having so many men; I then went down back alongside the schooner again and told the captain I  had now come prepared, and he had better give up the fugitive and save bloodshed. After parleying a little while he agreed to put the slave in my boat." 
Due to Bearse’s cunning efforts, the freedom seeker successfully escaped to Canada. 
While those who made it to shore received assistance from Boston abolitionists, the journey proved grueling and demonstrates the strength of those who embarked on this difficult path to freedom. One of these courageous individuals was Elisabeth Blakeley, a freedom seeker from North Carolina. Fleeing a life of unimaginable horror in December of 1849, she snuck aboard a boat and hid herself in a narrow hole. Abolitionist Wendell Philips later shared her experience hiding aboard,  
“she lay while her inhuman master, almost certain she was on board the vessel, called out to her, ‘you had better come out! I am going to smoke the vessel!’ She tells: I heard him call, but my mind was liberty or death.”
With her enslaver unable to find her, Blakeley hid aboard the ship for four weeks as it sailed north during the middle of winter. When Blakeley arrived in Boston in late January, she could barely stand because her feet were so badly frostbitten. The abolitionist community welcomed her and helped her begin her new life in freedom.  
-- 
Elisabeth Blakeley’s story, as well as the others you have heard on this tour, exemplify the immense courage and ingenuity of freedom seekers who escaped slavery and made their way to Boston on the Underground Railroad. These stories also highlight the various ways Boston activists sought to help them gain and maintain their freedom.  
Together, the freedom seekers and those who assisted them along their way, created a legacy of resilience, bravery, and sacrifice, that continues to inspire us today and encourages us to consider how we too can ensure a more just and freer world.

images.credit: Matt Teuten (left image), NPS Photo (right image)
images.title: Underground Railroad in Boston
images.altText: 2 images merged with gradient, left is African Meeting House on Smith Court, right is Long Wharf.
images.caption: This 12-stop audio tour shares Underground Railroad stories from Beacon Hill to Long Wharf.

data.title: The Underground Railroad in Boston
data.description: Over the next twelve stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers* along their way. This tour weaves through Beacon Hill followed by a few stops in Downtown Boston. The tour concludes at Long Wharf. *"Freedom seeker" refers to an enslaved person who took action to obtain their freedom from slavery (NPS Network to Freedom).

stops.significance:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Underground Railroad walking tour. Over the next 12 stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers.
Our tour begins here on Smith Court, a center of Black life and activism in 1800s Boston. The African Meeting House served as a church, schoolroom, and gathering space for the community. Here, Underground Railroad activists planned how they were going to help those escaping slavery.
Black Bostonians also gathered here in response to the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to roam free states in search of runaways and mandated the assistance of state and local authorities, as well as the public, in returning freedom seekers to slavery.
Those who lived in this court helped shelter freedom seekers, and in one case, saved a freedom seeker from an attempted capture by a slave catcher.
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you walk through Beacon Hill, please watch your step as many side walks are uneven. Exit Smith Court and turn right up Joy Street. Cross Myrtle Street and continue on Joy Street. Take the next right onto Pickney Street. Walk down the street until you reach the next intersection, then cross to the left side of the street, where you will find the Hillard House, 62 Pinckney Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Underground Railroad walking tour. Over the next twelve stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers along their way.
We will spend the first part of our tour on the north slope of Beacon Hill, home to Boston’s free Black neighborhood. Members of this community came together to provide a safe-haven and support for many freedom seekers.
We will then walk downtown where many Beacon Hill activists joined other Bostonians to engage in high profile protests and rescues.  
We will end our tour near the waterfront, which served as an entry point for so many freedom seekers on the Underground Railroad.      
Bear in mind, Boston’s Underground Railroad history is expansive. No tour, including this one, can claim to be all encompassing. Rather, we hope to shed light on some of the lesser-known stories, not already featured on our other tours, including the Black Heritage Trail, which you can find on the National Park Service app as well.    
Let’s get started. 
Our tour begins here on Smith Court, an integral center of Black life and activism in 1800s Boston. The African Meeting House, the three story-brick building with tall arched windows, served as a church, schoolroom, and gathering space for the community. Here, Underground Railroad activists planned how they were going to help those escaping slavery. For example, in the early 1840s, Black Bostonians formed the New England Freedom Association which held their meetings here.  According to William Cooper Nell, one of the leaders of this group: 
"The object of our Association is to extend a helping hand to all who may bid adieu to whips and chains, and by the welcome light of the North Star, reach a haven where they can be protected from the grasp of the man-stealer… "
Groups such as the New England Freedom Association, and later the Boston Vigilance Committee, provided funds, clothing, food, information, and other assistance to the freedom seekers coming to and through Boston on the Underground Railroad. 
In 1850, the federal government enacted a harsh new Fugitive Slave Law that allowed slave catchers to roam free states in search of runaways and mandated the assistance of state and local authorities, as well as the public, in returning freedom seekers to slavery.  Soon after, Black Bostonians rallied here at the African Meeting House to plan their collective response. Lewis Hayden, Boston’s most prominent Underground Railroad leader presided. One activist, Joshua B. Smith, militantly claimed, “If liberty is not worth fighting for, it is not worth having” and encouraged his listeners to arm themselves against the slave catchers...For as Smith said, “When he could not live here in Boston, A FREEMAN...’He had lived long enough.”
Directly across from the African Meeting House stands 3 Smith Court, the yellow house. According to the records of the Boston Vigilance Committee, Black activist and clothing dealer James Scott sheltered several freedom seekers here in the 1850s, as did William Cooper Nell, another prominent Underground Railroad operative, who also boarded here. Authorities arrested, tried, but did not convict Scott for his alleged role in leading the successful courthouse rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins in 1851.   
Smith Court also witnessed a dramatic Underground Railroad confrontation in 1847.  A slave catcher attempted to capture Mrs. Dorsey, a freedom seeker, in her home at the end of Smith Court. Black activist Nancy Prince hurried to the scene, grappled with the slave catcher, and threw him out of the house.  She then rallied the women and children who gathered during the commotion and got them to hurl stones and anything else they could find at the slave catcher, running him out of the neighborhood.   
Before we move on to our next stop, we encourage you to take a walk to the rear of Smith Court.  Look right and left, up and down the alley. See how tightly packed these little hidden homes and neighborhoods are.  These densely crowded streets and tucked away alleys and houses served as temporary homes and safe havens for so many freedom seekers fleeing slavery on the Underground Railroad.

stops.significance:
While much of the Underground Railroad activity in Beacon Hill occurred among the Black residents of the community, there are also instances of White allies providing refuge to freedom seekers. Two of these allies, George and Susan Hillard, used their status and privilege to shelter several freedom seekers at their home.
Susan Hillard was a staunch abolitionist and used her husband's political cover as a conservative politician to hide freedom seekers in their home throughout the 1850s. While it is unclear how much George knew of Susan’s ongoing Underground Railroad activities, he likely had some awareness and either did not interfere, or quietly supported her efforts.
The Hillards most notably sheltered freedom seeker Ellen Craft in October 1850 when slave catchers tracked her and her husband William to Boston. With the help of both the Hillards, Ellen and William Craft averted the slave catchers.
When the home underwent repairs years later, a secret attic was found, as well as two plates and two spoons.
stops.assetName: George S. and Susan Hillard House
stops.directionsToNextStop: With your back to the Hillard House, walk straight on to Anderson Street along the left side of the street. Turn left onto Revere Street. Turn right onto Grove Street. At the intersection of Grove Street and Phillips Street, turn left onto Phillips Street so that you are on the left side of the street. You can remain at this corner or walk down Phillips Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
While much of the Underground Railroad activity in Beacon Hill occurred among the Black residents of the community, there are also instances of white allies providing refuge to freedom seekers. Two of these allies, George and Susan Hillard, used their status and privilege to shelter several freedom seekers at their home here at 62 Pinckney Street.
At first glance, George Hillard did not appear to be the typical ally of the Underground Railroad. Although a former law partner to the radical abolitionist Charles Sumner and generally in favor of racial equality, George Hillard opposed the more radical abolitionist calls to end slavery immediately. As a federal commissioner, Hillard also had to uphold the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, which had strict consequences for those aiding freedom seekers. 
Susan Hillard, unlike her husband, was a staunch abolitionist and used George's political cover to hide freedom seekers in their home throughout the 1850s. Records document the Hillard home as a safe house for at least five freedom seekers during this time. While it is unclear how much George knew of Susan’s ongoing Underground Railroad activities, he likely had some awareness and either did not interfere, or quietly supported her efforts. 
The Hillards most notably sheltered freedom seeker Ellen Craft in October 1850 when slave catchers tracked her and her husband William to Boston. Upon hearing the news of the slave catchers’ arrival, Susan Hillard found Ellen Craft in a home on Mt. Vernon Street, the next street over. Susan acted immediately:  
"I proposed to Ellen to come and do some work for me, intending not to alarm her. My manner, which I supposed to be indifferent and calm, betrayed me, and she threw herself into my arms, sobbing and weeping…She, however, recovered her composure as soon as we reached the street, and was very firm ever after."   
George supported his wife’s efforts to conceal Ellen Craft. Susan recalled her husband saying, "I am perfectly willing to meeting the penalty, should [Ellen] be found here, but will never give her up."  
With the help of both the Hillards, Ellen and William Craft averted the slave catchers. 
From their unassuming home on Beacon Hill, George and Susan Hillard sheltered those on their journey to freedom. Evidence of 62 Pinckney Street’s Underground Railroad past gathered public attention decades after the Hillards lived here. According to a 1926 Boston Transcript article:  
"Only a few years ago, when some repairs were being made in the plastering of the ell, a well-concealed trap door in the ceiling of a closet unexpectedly dropped upon the head of a workman, revealing an unfinished space under the lean-to roof large enough to hold several human beings. This place was without windows, but it was ventilated in a measure by an opening into a shaft under a skylight. Recalling the tradition that this house had been a station on the ‘Underground’ in Mr. Hillard’s time the then owner had the place explored, with the result that two tin plates and two iron spoons were found on the floor. Were these the relics of the last meal ever served to fugitives under this roof?"

stops.significance:
You are now in the Lower Southac neighborhood, so named because Phillips Street once was called Southac Street. This neighborhood teemed with Underground Railroad activity.
Lewis and Harriet Hayden lived at number 66. The Haydens, who fled slavery themselves, sheltered scores of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft.
A couple doors down, 70 Phillips Street, was the home of Elizabeth Riley. Riley sheltered freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins in her attic after he was rescued from the courthouse.
The Riley home also included 1 Southac Court, where famed freedom seeker Jane Johnson and her sons lived. Johnson took in other freedoms seekers at her home here on Southac Court and at her later Beacon Hill residences.
Across the street stands 81-83 Phillips Street. Black lawyer, doctor, dentist, and activist, John Sweat Rock, lived here and provided medical care to freedom seekers. Two boardinghouses that housed freedom seekers once stood here as well, operated by John R. Taylor and William Manix.
stops.assetName: Site of William and Elizabeth Riley's House
stops.directionsToNextStop: With your back towards the downward slope of Phillips street, walk up Phillips street, crossing Grove street. Stop at around 44 Phillips Street. Look across the street to see the former site of Twelfth Baptist Church.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now in the Lower Southac neighborhood, so named because Phillips Street once was called Southac Street. This neighborhood teemed with Underground Railroad activity.  Feel free to walk down and up this block while listening to this stop, or find a place in the shade and look down the street.  
If you walk down the lefthand side of the street to number 66, with the dark green door and bronze plaque, you will come to the home of Lewis and Harriet Hayden. The Haydens, who fled slavery themselves, sheltered scores of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft. To learn more about the Haydens, we encourage you to take the Black Heritage Trail tour offered on the National Park Service App.
A couple doors down you will come to 70 Phillips Street, the home of Elizabeth Riley. In February 1851, slave catchers arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and held him at the courthouse. Within hours, Black Bostonians, led by Lewis Hayden, rescued Minkins and brought him to Riley’s home where she sheltered him in her attic. According to Lewis Hayden, he and Black attorney Robert Morris:  
“safely lodged him [Minkins] in the attic of a widow, Mrs. Elizabeth Riley, one of our race, whose fidelity and humanity we all fully confided in.'"  
The Riley home also included 1 Southac Court, one of those tucked away alley dwellings so prevalent throughout Beacon Hill.  The famed freedom seeker Jane Johnson and her sons lived here beginning in 1856. The year prior, Johnson and her sons escaped their enslaver John Wheeler as they all traveled through Pennsylvania, a free state.  Johnson and her sons came to Boston to begin their new life in freedom.  She courageously returned to Philadelphia a few months later to testify against Wheeler.  
According to the Liberator, when lawyers called Johnson to the stand:  
"The name was followed by a breathless silence and a buzz of incredulity…When Jane first appeared, he (Wheeler) laughed immoderately and nervously, then became deadly pale, and as the testimony went on, red and pale by turns. At last, he could bear it no longer, but picked up his hat and disappeared… " 
Johnson then left the courtroom escorted by abolitionists as well as state and local authorities, who guarded her from the federal marshals and slave catchers. Having secured her own freedom, Johnson took in other freedoms seekers both at her home here on Southac Court and at her later Beacon Hill residences. 
Diagonally across and a little further down the street stands 81-83 Phillips Street. You will see a plaque indicating that on this site once stood the home of John Sweat Rock, a Black lawyer, doctor, dentist, and activist.  Rock not only provided medical care to freedom seekers, but also had a strong friendship with Harriet Tubman, the famous Underground Railroad conductor, who stayed at his home when in Boston. Two boardinghouses once stood here as well, operated by John R. Taylor and William Manix. Boston Vigilance Committee records show that both Taylor and Manix sheltered many freedom seekers at their boardinghouses, including Jane Johnson and her sons.   
As you walk back up the street, reflect upon these stories of bravery and resilience. And remember, they only provide a snapshot of the Underground Railroad history hidden in plain view here in the Lower Southac neighborhood.

stops.significance:
Twelfth Baptist Church, known as the "Fugitive Slave’s Church," once stood at this approximate site. With many freedom seekers worshipping here, Twelfth Baptist Church served as a sacred space for its congregants as well as a center for Underground Railroad assistance.
Reverend Leonard Grimes led this church for 25 years. After growing up free in Virginia, Grimes dedicated his life to supporting freedom seekers, using his position in the Beacon Hill community to do so.
After the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, more than 40 congregants of Twelfth Baptist fled north out of fear of capture. Grimes raised money to pay for many of these individuals’ freedoms and supported many more freedom seekers on their journey.
Grimes played a role in almost every major fugitive slave case in Boston in the 1850s, as some of these freedom seekers, including Shadrach Minkins and Anthony Burns, worshipped at Twelfth Baptist.
Today, there is a plaque at the site of Leonard Grimes’ 28 Grove St. home.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking up Phillips Street, crossing Anderson Street and Garden Street. Cross to the left side of Phillips Street. 5 Phillips Street is halfway down the last block of Phillips Street before Irving Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
As you continue up Phillips Street, look across the street at a brick building with a geometric entryway. The Twelfth Baptist Church, known as the “Fugitive Slave’s Church,” once stood at this approximate site.  With many freedom seekers worshipping here, Twelfth Baptist Church became more than just a sacred space for its congregants. As an 1874 history of this church stated, 
"[Twelfth Baptist] was the home of the oppressed, the vantage ground of the champions of human freedom. … The fugitive was never refused its shelter and protection... In short, this church became the vantage ground of the “new party;” the platform from which slavery was assailed most grandly and fearlessly."  
Reverend Leonard Grimes led this church for 25 years, during the height of the anti-slavery era. With the support of his congregants, Grimes played a critical role in Boston’s Underground Railroad.  
Grimes became pastor of Twelfth Baptist in 1848, having moved to Boston several years prior.  Although he grew up free in Virginia, Grimes witnessed the horrors of slavery. He used his profession as a hackman, or carriage driver, to illegally transport freedom seekers. In 1840, Grimes was convicted and sentenced to two years of hard labor for helping an enslaved woman and her six children escape to Canada. While serving his sentence in Virginia, Grimes began preaching, which he continued to do once released. When he moved to Boston and became Reverend of Twelfth Baptist Church, Grimes used his position in the community to continue his support of freedom seekers.  
After the passage of the Fugitive Slave Law in 1850, more than forty congregants of Twelfth Baptist fled north out of fear of capture. Grimes raised money to pay for many of these individuals’ freedoms and supported many more freedom seekers on their journey.  
Grimes played a role in almost every major fugitive slave case in Boston in the 1850s, as some of these freedom seekers, including Shadrach Minkins and Anthony Burns, worshipped at Twelfth Baptist.  
When Grimes passed away in 1873, The Boston Globe printed,  
“It was credibly stated that [Grimes] had been instrumental in enabling four hundred persons of his own race to escape from Southern bondage.”   
Today, there is a plaque at the site of Leonard Grimes’ home at 28 Grove Street, near the intersection of Grove and Phillips Streets, just steps away from where you stand. Feel free to take a moment to visit this plaque before continuing with the tour.

stops.significance:
Here at 5 Phillips Street once stood the home of Henry Thacker, a prominent Black caterer and activist. In 1847, Thacker aided George and Lizzie Lewis, a father and daughter who escaped from slavery. Forced to separate on their journey north, Lizzie came to Boston and stayed at Thacker’s home. George, on the other hand, went to Albany, New York. While there, George learned his daughter was in Boston. Reverend Grimes visited George and assured George his daughter was safe with the Thackers. Soon after, Captain Austin Bearse, brought George to the city.
Outside this home is where father and daughter finally reunited.
Across the street lived Joshua Bowen Smith, known as the “Prince of Caterers.” In this high-profile position, Smith was able to keep a careful watch out for slave catchers. He also employed and assisted numerous freedom seekers. Smith lived with fellow activist John Coburn, who assisted with the rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse in 1851.
stops.assetName: Site of Henry L. W. Thacker House
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take a left at Irving Street and walk down to Cambridge Street. Turn right onto Cambridge Street. You can listen to the next stop while you walk or wait until you have reached Hancock Street. Pause at this corner and look across the street. This general area is the approximate location of William Craft's Shop.
stops.audioTranscript:
Here at 5 Phillips Street once stood the home of Henry Thacker, a prominent Black caterer and activist. His home is also a site of one heart-warming Underground Railroad reunion.   
In 1847, Thacker aided George and Lizzie Lewis, a father and daughter who escaped from slavery.  Forced to separate on their journey north, Lizzie came to Boston and stayed at Thacker’s home.  George, on the other hand, went to Albany, New York.  While there, George met a Black crew member of a ship from Boston who told him that he had met Lizzie and that she was staying “at Mr. Thacker’s in Southac Street.”  Reverend Leonard Grimes, who we just heard about, went to Albany and assured George that his daughter was safe and well in Boston with the Thackers.  Soon after, Austin Bearse, a ship captain and member of the Boston Vigilance Committee, brought George to the city. According to Bearse, when they reached the city, a fellow abolitionist took them to this street:  
"…and while we were looking for the number of the house, I heard some one say, “Well, there’s father!” We turned to look, and it was indeed Lizzie calling “Father!”"  
You stand today where father and daughter finally reunited.  Imagine the flood of emotions that took place in that personal and powerful moment here on that day.  
Across the street lived Joshua Bowen Smith, the militant abolitionist we heard from in the first stop at the African Meeting House.  Henry Thacker employed Smith in his catering business before Smith set out on his own and soon established himself as the “Prince of Caterers.” In this high-profile position, Smith was able to keep a careful watch out for slave catchers. He also employed and assisted numerous freedom seekers as a member of both the Boston Vigilance Committee and the New England Freedom Association.  
Here on Southac Street, Smith lived with fellow activist and New England Freedom Association member John Coburn, who was arrested for “aiding and abetting” the successful rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse in 1851. You can learn more about John Coburn on our Black Heritage Trail walking tour.

stops.significance:
Today’s bustling Cambridge Street looks different than the Cambridge Street of the mid-1800s, which was narrower and still somewhat residential. Black porter Burrill Smith, who sheltered freedom seekers and hosted the famed Underground Railroad conductor Harriet Tubman, lived at 168 Cambridge Street.
Black-owned businesses, including Lewis Hayden’s clothing shop, were also located on Cambridge Street. Many of these businesses, including Hayden’s, became informal community centers for activists. Sometimes, these shops also served as safe houses or rendezvous points for freedom seekers.
Freedom seeker William Craft established his cabinet making shop at 51 Cambridge Street.  When slave catchers came looking for William and his wife Ellen in October 1850, William barricaded himself in his shop. Abolitionists, “armed to the teeth,” guarded the Crafts and forced the slave catchers to abandon their plans and leave the city. The Crafts fled to England, returning to the U.S. following the Civil War.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along Cambridge Street. Cross Bowdoin Street and pause at this corner to learn about the next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
We have just left the relatively quiet residential neighborhood of Beacon Hill and are now standing on Cambridge Street. Today, this is a bustling city street full of businesses, restaurants, hotels, as well as Massachusetts General Hospital. Cambridge Street of the mid-1800s, however, was narrower and still somewhat residential. Black porter Burrill Smith lived at 168 Cambridge Street. Not only did Smith shelter freedom seekers in his boardinghouse, but he also hosted famed Underground Railroad conductor Harriet Tubman during some of her early visits to Boston.
In addition to the residences here, Cambridge Street served as a hub of Black-owned businesses. Lewis Hayden, who escaped slavery with his family and later became Boston’s most prominent Underground Railroad operative, ran his clothing shop on Cambridge Street.1 Many Black-owned businesses, including Hayden’s, also became important informal community centers, where activists came together, conversed, and planned their collective action.  Sometimes, these shops also served as safe houses and rendezvous points for freedom seekers escaping on the Underground Railroad.  
William Craft, who had escaped slavery with his wife Ellen and stayed with the Haydens for a time, established his cabinet making shop at 51 Cambridge Street, which is no longer standing.  In Boston’s first test of the new federal Fugitive Slave Law, slave catchers came looking for William and Ellen Craft in October 1850. Evading capture while his wife hid with the Hillards, William barricaded himself in his shop armed with two knives and several pistols. One reporter claimed: 
"No man could approach within a hundred yards of Craft’s shop without being seen by a hundred eyes, and a signal would call a powerful body at a moment’s notice..." 
Abolitionists, “armed to the teeth,” guarded the Crafts and thwarted the slave catchers at every turn. Fearful for their own safety, the slave catchers ultimately abandoned their plans to capture the Crafts and left the city. The Crafts fled to England, and eventually returned to the United States following the Civil War.

stops.significance:
The Revere House Hotel, which used to stand here at Bowdoin Square, has unique ties to the Underground Railroad history of Boston.
In April 1850, Massachusetts Senator Daniel Webster delivered a speech at the Revere House Hotel in support of the Compromise of 1850. This package of legislation included the new Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to apprehend freedom seekers without due process throughout the country and mandated local and state authorities, as well as the public, to comply with it. Responding to fierce backlash, Webster called upon Massachusetts residents to enforce this law as their Constitutional duty, despite whatever misguided convictions they had.
Once in effect, the Fugitive Slave Law drew slave catchers to Boston in search of freedom seekers believed to be in the area. With its proximity to Beacon Hill's Black community, the Revere House Hotel provided enslavers and their agents a place to lodge while they pursued freedom seekers living and working in the city.
stops.assetName: Site of the Revere House Hotel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along this curved section of Cambridge Street. Once you reach the intersection of Cambridge Street, Court Street, and Tremont Street, cross the street towards the Government Center T stop. Walk a few steps along Court Street and then turn left to walk along the brick path between the T stop on the left and the buildings on the right. Feel free to find a place to sit along this curved path to listen to the next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now in Bowdoin Square and the former site of the Revere House Hotel. This Hotel has unique ties to the Underground Railroad history of Boston. 
In April 1850, Senator Daniel Webster, the famous statesman and orator from Massachusetts, arrived at the Revere House Hotel.  A month prior Webster delivered his infamous “Seventh of March” speech, throwing his full support behind the Compromise of 1850, a package of legislation that included the new Fugitive Slave Law. This law allowed slave catchers to apprehend freedom seekers without due process throughout the country, including free states, and it mandated the compliance of local and state authorities and the public at large. Facing strong backlash in Boston for his support of this law, Webster delivered a speech from the portico of the Revere House Hotel defending his stance as the way to ensure national unity. Standing on the front steps, Webster called upon Massachusetts residents to enforce this new law as their Constitutional duty, despite whatever “misguided” convictions they had.  
Once in effect, however, the Fugitive Slave Law drew slave catchers to Boston in search of freedom seekers believed to be residing in the area.  With its close proximity to the Black community on Beacon Hill, the Revere House Hotel provided enslavers and their agents a central and convenient place to lodge while they pursued freedom seekers living and working in the city.  
For example, in 1854, Col. Charles Suttle, the enslaver of Anthony Burns, tracked the young freedom seeker to Boston and stayed at the Revere House Hotel throughout the duration of the case. Abolitionists harassed Suttle from the moment he checked into the hotel.  Much like they did during the Craft case in 1850, activists kept a careful watch on Suttle and his colleagues and tried to impede them at every turn.  Suttle even had to relocate from the ground floor to an attic room at the hotel with armed guards due to credible death threats. 
The Fugitive Slave Law galvanized Bostonians to embrace more brazen and militant tactics to protect those seeking their freedom in the city.

stops.significance:
Writers for "The Liberator," a major printed voice of the anti-slavery movement, never shied away from confronting those who supported slavery and the Fugitive Slave Law. Instead, they advocated for open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law and called upon people to directly assist freedom seekers.
For almost three decades, "The Liberator’s" office stood on Cornhill Street, which was located roughly in this area of City Hall Plaza. 
Working alongside Black writers such as William Cooper Nell, editor William Lloyd Garrison used "The Liberator" to call for immediate emancipation and equal rights for Black Americans. This paper documented anti-slavery meetings and shared the stories of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft, Shadrach Minkins, Anthony Burns, and others.
When freedom seekers arrived in Boston, they knew they could find support and aid at "The Liberator" office. This office stood as a central hub of Underground Railroad activity where allies directly provided support for freedom seekers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along this path and turn left at the intersection. Walk to the top of the stairs and pause here to listen to the next stop about Faneuil Hall.
stops.audioTranscript:
Writers for The Liberator, a major printed voice of the anti-slavery movement, never shied away from confronting those who supported slavery and the Fugitive Slave Law, whether it be the slave holders themselves or those the writers saw as their northern accomplices, including Senator Daniel Webster. Instead, they advocated for open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law and called upon people to directly assist freedom seekers.
For almost three decades, The Liberator’s office stood on Cornhill Street, first at number 25 and later at 21 Cornhill, which was located roughly in this area of City Hall Plaza. This office served as a hotbed of both anti-slavery and Underground Railroad activity. 
Working alongside Black writers such as William Cooper Nell, editor William Lloyd Garrison used The Liberator to call for immediate emancipation and equal rights for Black Americans.4 This paper documented anti-slavery meetings and shared the stories of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft, Shadrach Minkins, Anthony Burns, and others.   
The paper matched its advocacy with direct calls for assistance for freedom seekers, whether it be money, clothes, or employment opportunities. After the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Robert Wallcut, General Agent of the paper and a member of the Vigilance Committee, printed an article titled, “To the Friends of the Fugitive,” stating: 
"Alarmed at the operation of the new Fugitive Slave Law, the Fugitives from slavery are pressing Northward…They are coming to us in increasing numbers, and they look to us for aid. ... who will help them? Their first and most earnest desire is for employment…Cannot you find… one or more places where the hunted slave may abide securely, and work through the winter? … Many of the fugitives come very poorly provided with clothing; and those who have garments of any kind to spare, will be sure to confer them on the suffering and needy by sending them, marked 'For fugitives,' at 21 Cornhill... "
When freedom seekers arrived in Boston, they knew they could find support and aid at The Liberator office. One abolitionist recalled that the attic of the office even served as a hiding place for freedom seekers.  
While the paper advocated for change through the written word, The Liberator office stood as a central hub of Underground Railroad activity where allies, such as the paper’s editor and general agent, directly provided support for freedom seekers.

stops.significance:
Faneuil Hall gained its reputation as the "Cradle of Liberty" from the meetings that helped inspire the American Revolution. It lived up to that nickname with its abolitionist and Underground Railroad connections.
By the late 1830s, Boston abolitionists began using Faneuil Hall to host meetings and rallies. Oftentimes, they called these meetings to protest high profile fugitive slave cases.
For example, in 1842, authorities arrested freedom seeker George Latimer, which prompted abolitionists to gather in Faneuil Hall to call for action against Latimer’s arrest. His case led to a petition drive that spurred the 1843 Personal Liberty Act, which prevented state officials and facilities from supporting the capture of freedom seekers.
Following the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Bostonians held a meeting here to establish the Boston Vigilance Committee. This organization provided valuable assistance to freedom seekers: shelter, clothing, money, legal aid, medical attention, and passage further north.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Retrace your steps to the intersection of the two pathways. Walk straight in between to two buildings, towards Court Street. At the light, cross Court Street. Turn right and cross Washington street. Feel free to rest at one of the benches along court street or walk up to the columned building, on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you look down the stairs and across Congress Street you will see Faneuil Hall. This historic gathering space gained its reputation as the “Cradle of Liberty” from the meetings held here that helped inspire the American Revolution. However, it equally lived up to that nickname when considering its abolitionist and Underground Railroad history.
By the late 1830s, Boston abolitionists had begun regularly using Faneuil Hall to host their meetings and rallies. Oftentimes, they called these meetings to protest high profile fugitive slave cases in the city, encouraging supporters to help those in need and thwart the slave catchers. 
For example, in 1842, authorities arrested freedom seeker George Latimer, which prompted major protests throughout the city. On October 30, abolitionists gathered in Faneuil Hall to call for action against Latimer’s arrest. Among other resolutions, the attendees declared: 
"if the soul-traders and slave-drivers of the South imagine that Massachusetts is slave-hunting ground, on which they may run down their prey with impunity...they will find themselves mistaken."  
Though Bostonians quickly purchased Latimer’s freedom, his case galvanized the abolitionist community. They soon gathered thousands of signatures for a petition that led to the passage of the 1843 Personal Liberty Act, which prevented state officials and facilities from supporting the capture of freedom seekers. 
A few years later, following the arrest of another freedom seeker in 1846, thousands of Bostonians once more gathered in the Hall in protest, with former president John Quincy Adams presiding over the meeting. Here they established a Vigilance Committee to assist those escaping from slavery on the Underground Railroad.  
With the passage of the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850, Bostonians flocked again to Faneuil Hall. At this meeting, the abolitionists expressed their outrage at the unjust and inhumane law. Abolitionist Caroline Dall attended this meeting and recorded her experience in her journal: 
"I could not resist going to the meeting at Faneuil Hall in the evening. It was a grand meeting. There was but one feeling among the 6000 persons assembled there, and that was to trample this law under foot." 
By the end of the meeting, those in attendance had established the final iteration of the Boston Vigilance Committee.  This organization provided valuable assistance to freedom seekers coming to and through Boston in the form of shelter, clothing, money, legal aid, medical attention, and passage further north for the duration of the Fugitive Slave Law years.

stops.significance:
Though no longer standing, the Boston Court House played a crucial role in several Fugitive Slave Law cases. In February 1851, authorities arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and brought him to this courthouse. Lewis Hayden and other militant abolitionists stormed the building, overwhelmed the guards, and carried Minkins to safety.
The federal government responded by arresting freedom seeker Thomas Sims a couple months later. This time, the courthouse was draped in chains and guards were stationed outside. Abolitionists could not free the heavily guarded Sims. On April 12, 1851, authorities marched Sims to Long Wharf and sent him back into slavery.
In 1854, slave catchers arrested freedom seeker Anthony Burns and brought him to this courthouse. Militant abolitionists led a failed assault on the courthouse to free Burns. In the aftermath of the assault, federal troops were brought in to guard the courthouse while Burns awaited his return into slavery.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk down Court Street to the front of the State House.
stops.audioTranscript:
Though no longer standing, the Boston Court House played a crucial role in several Fugitive Slave Law cases. Feel free to walk to the columned building, where the courthouse once stood, or take a seat at one of the benches along Court Street while you listen along.  
In February 1851, five months after the Fugitive Slave Law went into effect, authorities arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and brought him to this courthouse. Lewis Hayden and other militant abolitionists heard about the arrest and decided to act. During the hearing, they stormed inside, overwhelmed the guards, and carried Minkins to the safety of Elisabeth Riley’s attic on Beacon Hill. Five days later he arrived in Montreal Canada where he lived free for the rest of his life. Rev. Theodore Parker later described the rescue of Minkins as  
“the most noble deed done in Boston since the destruction of the tea in 1773.”  
The rescue of Minkins sparked outrage from federal officials. Secretary of State Daniel Webster, former senator from Massachusetts, referred to the rescue as “a case of treason.”  
The federal government responded by showing they could enforce the Fugitive Slave Law in Boston with the arrest of freedom seeker Thomas Sims a couple months later. After escaping from Georgia, Sims lived in a boarding house in the North End of Boston until his arrest in early April. Holding Sims in this courthouse, federal officials took the threat of another rescue seriously. Guards were stationed outside of the courthouse, a militia was garrisoned at Faneuil Hall, and the courthouse itself was draped in chains, while Sims was held captive in a third-floor room. Describing the excessive display of force, Abolitionist lawyer Richard Henry Dana wrote, 
“Our temple of justice is a slave pen!”  
Undeterred, abolitionists hatched a plan to rescue Sims. They planned to place mattresses below the third story window where Sims was held so that he could jump to freedom. However, it appears officials heard of the plot and fixed iron bars to the window, thereby thwarting the plan. In the early morning of April 12, 1851, authorities marched Sims to Long Wharf and sent him back into slavery on the ship The Acorn.  
Three years after the return of Thomas Sims, the eyes of the nation again turned to Boston with the arrest of 20-year-old freedom seeker Anthony Burns. Born in Virginia, Burns escaped to Boston via ship and worked at a local clothing store. After slave catchers arrested Burns in May 1854 and brought him to this courthouse, word of his arrest quickly spread. Anti-slavery activists called for a mass meeting at Faneuil Hall while a smaller group of White and Black militant abolitionists met at Tremont Temple.  
During the Faneuil Hall meeting, the group from Tremont Temple began an assault on the courthouse to free Burns. Using a makeshift battering ram, abolitionists broke down the courthouse's door and began hand to hand fighting with federal marshals guarding Burns. The rescue attempt failed, but during the attack, an abolitionist fired a pistol, killing one of the deputies. 
In the aftermath of the assault, federal troops, with permission from President Franklin Pierce, were brought in to guard the courthouse while Burns awaited his return into slavery.  
Make your way to our next stop, the site of the Boston Massacre at the top of State Street, to hear more of Burns’ story.

stops.significance:
Standing in front of the Old State House, you will see a circular cobblestone marker commemorating the Boston Massacre, the 1770 incident in which British soldiers shot and killed five protesting Bostonians, including Crispus Attucks, likely a freedom seeker of mixed African and Native ancestry.
On the morning of June 2, 1854, federal troops marched Anthony Burns over this spot as they made their way to the waterfront where a ship awaited to bring Burns back to slavery. While hundreds of federal soldiers guarded and escorted Burns, an estimated 50,000 people lined State Street in protest.
The sad irony of federal marshals marching Anthony Burns back to slavery over this very spot where Attucks fell was not lost on the abolitionists in the crowd, who called it the "death of liberty."  
Nine months following Burns' return to slavery, Bostonians, under the leadership of Reverend Leonard Grimes, raised money and secured Anthony Burns’ freedom. He later attended Oberlin College and became a minister.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking down State Street, crossing through the Rose Kennedy Greenway. Passing the Marriott on the left, continue walking down State Street as it turns into Long Wharf. Pause any where along the wharf or continue to the end of the wharf to finish the tour.
stops.audioTranscript:
Standing in front of the Old State House, at the top of State Street, you will see set into the ground a circular cobblestone marker commemorating the Boston Massacre, the 1770 incident in which British soldiers shot and killed five protesting Bostonians, including Crispus Attucks, likely a freedom seeker of mixed African and Native ancestry.  
On the morning of June 2, 1854, federal troops marched Anthony Burns over this spot as they made their way to the water where a ship awaited to bring Burns back to slavery. While hundreds of federal soldiers guarded and escorted Burns, an estimated 50,000 people lined State Street in protest.  
Martha Russell, a journalist for the National Era, witnessed this procession and wrote: 
"Did you ever feel every drop of blood in you boiling and seething, throbbing and burning, until it seemed you should suffocate? Did you ever set your teeth hard together to keep down the spirit that was urging you to do something... that good and wise people would call violence - treason? I have felt all this today. I have seen that poor slave, Anthony Burns, carried back into slavery!" 
With the city under heavy martial guard, black drapes hung on buildings lining State Street and abolitionists strung up a coffin over the street with the word "Liberty" inscribed on it.  
This “death of liberty” served as a powerful metaphor in a city that strongly embraced its reputation as the “Cradle of Liberty” for its role in the early days of the American Revolution. The sad irony of federal marshals marching Anthony Burns back to slavery over this very spot where Attucks fell was not lost on the abolitionists in the crowd. 
Nine months following Burns’ return to slavery, Bostonians, under the leadership of Reverend Leonard Grimes, raised money and secured Anthony Burns’ freedom. He later attended Oberlin College and became a minister.  
Nine years after the military escorted Burns down State Street, the 54th Massachusetts, one of the first Black regiments in the U.S. Civil War, marched down the very same street amid huge fanfare as they set off to fight in the war of emancipation. Among their well-wishers along the route stood Thomas Sims, who had escaped slavery once again and returned to Boston.  
Reflecting on the procession down State Street, Captain Luis Emilio of the 54th Massachusetts wrote:  
"the band played the stirring music of John Brown's hymn, while passing over ground moistened by the blood of Crispus Attucks, and over which Anthony Burns and Thomas Sims had been carried back to bondage."

stops.significance:
Long Wharf, the port, and the surrounding harbor strongly tie to the history of slavery in Boston, from the years of the slave trade to those of the Underground Railroad and emancipation.
During the colonial period, local merchants created vast amounts of wealth by trafficking enslaved individuals and trading goods consumed and produced by enslaved labor. Long Wharf served as one of the primary entry points for enslaved individuals into the colony. During the Underground Railroad years, Boston’s wharves became both an entry and departure point for freedom seekers. While those such as Thomas Sims and Anthony Burns were forcibly transported back into slavery through the Harbor, the wharves also welcomed freedom seekers, such as Elizabeth Blakeley, as they took their first steps into a free state.
Freedom seekers and their supporters created a legacy of resilience, bravery, and sacrifice that continues to inspire us today and encourages us to consider how we too can ensure a more just and freer world.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are currently standing at the end of Long Wharf, the last stop of this tour. This wharf, the port, and the surrounding harbor strongly tie to the history of slavery in Boston, from the years of the slave trade to those of the Underground Railroad and emancipation.  
During the colonial period, local merchants created vast amounts of wealth by trafficking enslaved individuals and trading goods consumed and produced by enslaved labor. Long Wharf served as one of the primary entry points for enslaved individuals into the colony. The Middle Passage Port Marker formally honors and remembers the Africans who died and those who endured the transatlantic voyage known as the Middle Passage. It also recognizes the vital role that Africans and their descendants played in the development of both the Massachusetts Bay Colony and the United States. 
During the Underground Railroad years, Boston’s wharves became both an entry and departure point for freedom seekers. While those such as Thomas Sims and Anthony Burns were forcibly transported back into slavery through the Harbor, the wharves also welcomed freedom seekers as they took their first steps into a free state.  
Many people, including Burns and Sims, had escaped southern slavery by stowing-away on ships bound for Boston. The Boston Vigilance Committee stood ready to help those individuals, by sending “Committees of Reception” to ships suspected to have stowaways aboard. These committees provided food, clothing, and crucial information to freedom seekers. Black women served as critical members of these committees since captains rarely perceived them as threats. As Vigilance Committee member Thomas Wentworth Higginson recalled,  
"The practice was to take along a colored woman with fresh fruit, pies, &c – she easily got on board & when there, usually found out if there was any fugitive on board; then he was sometimes taken away by night." 
Captain Austin Bearse, another member of the Boston Vigilance Committee, provided aid to freedom seekers who came to Boston by sea. In one instance, Bearse learned of a stowaway on a ship docked near Castle Island, just south of Boston. Bearse sailed his boat up to the ship, but its captain immediately threatened violence if Bearse attempted to rescue the stowaway. Bearse returned here to Long Wharf to regroup. When he failed to find anyone to assist him, Bearse took bold action: 
"Knowing it was daylight soon I had to lay a plot. I took a dozen old hats and coats and fastened them up to the rail in my yacht, which gave me the appearance of having so many men; I then went down back alongside the schooner again and told the captain I  had now come prepared, and he had better give up the fugitive and save bloodshed. After parleying a little while he agreed to put the slave in my boat." 
Due to Bearse’s cunning efforts, the freedom seeker successfully escaped to Canada. 
While those who made it to shore received assistance from Boston abolitionists, the journey proved grueling and demonstrates the strength of those who embarked on this difficult path to freedom. One of these courageous individuals was Elisabeth Blakeley, a freedom seeker from North Carolina. Fleeing a life of unimaginable horror in December of 1849, she snuck aboard a boat and hid herself in a narrow hole. Abolitionist Wendell Philips later shared her experience hiding aboard,  
“she lay while her inhuman master, almost certain she was on board the vessel, called out to her, ‘you had better come out! I am going to smoke the vessel!’ She tells: I heard him call, but my mind was liberty or death.”
With her enslaver unable to find her, Blakeley hid aboard the ship for four weeks as it sailed north during the middle of winter. When Blakeley arrived in Boston in late January, she could barely stand because her feet were so badly frostbitten.
