data.title: Tour the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial
data.description: See all the points of interest at the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial. Enter the memorial at the nearest intersection on 6th and Independence Ave SW to begin the tour.

stops.significance: On a pedestal at the northwest plaza entrance, a life-size sculpture of Eisenhower as a young man depicts the trajectory of his life as the quintessential American story. Inscribed in stone nearby is an excerpt from Eisenhower's Abilene Homecoming Speech on June 22, 1945.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: The Young Man
stops.directionsToNextStop: Immediately in front of the statue is the next stop.

stops.significance: Dwight Eisenhower returned to Abilene on June 22, 1945 to a parade welcoming him home and honoring his leadership in Europe during World War II. After watching the celebration, his grateful acceptance of the recognition began with the above quote. He went on to say that this parade was not just for him; he was only a "symbol" of the soldiers, sailors and airmen who helped bring Allied victory.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Homecoming Speech
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue through the memorial to the first set of statues on the right side of the walkway

stops.significance:
On the right side of the memorial core, Eisenhower as the Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force during World War II is commemorated by a bronze heroic-sized statue with sculptures of his soldiers inspired by the famous photograph with the 101st Airborne Division before their jump into France. Behind the sculptures is a bas relief depicting the Normandy landings on D-Day, June 6, 1944.

On the back side of the stone you will see an inscription of Eisenhower's Guildhall acceptance speech given after receiving the “Freedom of the City” at London’s Guildhall, a symbolic act making him a citizen of the city.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Honoring the General
stops.directionsToNextStop: Across the plaza is the next stop

stops.significance:
On the left side of the memorial core, the bronze heroic-sized statue of Eisenhower as 34th President of the United States places him at the center of the White House Oval Office flanked by sculptures of civilian and military advisors, symbolizing the balance Eisenhower struck between conflicting demands of national security and peaceful progress. The bas-relief global background depicts a map of the world symbolizing Eisenhower's role as a world statesman and preeminent internationalist pursuing universal peace.

On the back side of the stone you will see an inscription of President Eisenhower's First Inaugural and Farewell Address to the country.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Honoring the President
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is above the statues spanning the length of the memorial

stops.significance: Under the design direction of architect Frank Gehry, artist Tomas Osinski has created a stainless-steel tapestry for the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial. The tapestry depicts the Pointe du Hoc promontory of France’s Normandy coastline during peacetime and serves as a symbol of the peace Eisenhower sought and won as Supreme Allied Commander during World War II and then maintained and nurtured as 34th president. Although the artistic feature draws inspiration from historic tapestries, the process and materials implemented in the Eisenhower Memorial introduce a new innovative perspective on the conventional practice of tapestry weaving.

data.title: Tour the grounds with 2 cell phone apps.
data.description: Visitors walking the grounds can gain additional perspectives with two cell phone tours. Stops #1 - #10 provide a general overview of the 8 acre property with references to the historic 1880 farm that once occupied nearly 160 acres; stops #11-#20 focus on the 1880 presidential campaign that was conducted from the front porch of the Garfield Home. Wayfinding signs with the phone number and QR code are located around the site. A map with stops is also available inside the Visitor Center and brochure box.

data.title: Trail Guide: Kīpukapuaulu
data.description: This trail reveals a story of struggle and survival for some of rarest plants and animals of Hawaiʻi. Plant picking is prohibited in this Special Ecological Area (SEA). Dogs, horses, and bicycles are prohibited on this trail.

images.title: Kīpukapuaulu
images.altText: Old growth mesic forest with dirt trail.
images.caption: Kīpukapuaulu is a hot spot of biological diversity and a fertile oasis of flourishing plants.

data.title: Trail Guide: Maunaulu
data.description: Venture through a landscape formed in a five-year eruption that re-created this land. This trail tells the story of one of the longest known rift zone eruptions of Kīlauea. The well-marked trail crosses massive lava fields, skirts gaping fissures, and takes you to spectacular features formed by rapidly cooling lava flows.

stops.assetName: Other Lava Shields Along the East Rift Zone

images.title: Maunaulu Eruption Guide
images.altText: Barren volcano sits in a distance. Red and green fern grows in one of its cracks.
images.caption: The powerful forces that created this landscape will reshape it in the future.

data.title: Trail Guide: Puʻuloa Petroglyphs
data.description: Walk in the footsteps of the kūpuna (elders) to Puʻuloa (hill of long life). It is a sacred and awe-inspiring gallery of kiʻi pōhaku (images carved in stone). These simple etchings document the life and culture of the native Hawaiian people. The petroglyphs are very fragile. Stay on the boardwalk. Walking on the lava surface will fragment the delicate petroglyphs.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow marked trail to the next GPS point.
Follow the marked trail to the next GPS point. Stop will be located near the wayside to the left.

stops.significance: Storied place of Hawaiʻi.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the marked trail to the next GPS point. Stop will be located near the start of the wooden boardwalk.
stops.audioTranscript:
The story of Kaʻehuikimanōopuʻuloa, the little brown shark of Puʻuloa

A story about Kaʻehuikimanōopuʻuloa unfolds along the Pānau coast of Kīlauea volcano. Oral tradition says that a pregnant woman went into the ocean and had a miscarriage while she was in the water. When she later returned to the ocean, a shark came up under her, and turned out to be her miscarried child transformed; it had become a manō (shark). The child is named Kaʻehuikimanōopuʻuloa (the little-brown shark of Puʻuloa), also referred to as Kaʻehuiki. The child’s mother, Hōlei, and father, Kapukapu, named their son after the great shark deity Kaʻahupāhau (cloak that is well cared for) from Keawalauopuʻuloa; currently known as Pearl Harbor in Oʻahu. Their child resembled Kaʻahupāhau because he was ʻehu, or reddish-tinged, like her hair.

Kaʻehuiki was nourished on ʻawa by his father and diluted with the milk of his mother for 10 days when he was put in a sea cave. When his parents decided to go to the uplands, Kaʻehuiki had to care for himself and became a shark ʻaumakua (deified family guardian).

One night, Kaʻehuiki appeared in his father’s dream and asked his permission to travel around the coast of Hawaiʻi to pay homage to all the district sharks. His intent was to meet the oldest brother of Pele, Kamohoaliʻi - the king of all sharks. He hoped Kamohoaliʻi would adopt him into the family. His father picked ʻawa roots, coconut, red-fish, and fowl and continued to chant as he went to the sea cave. A little brown shark, Kaʻehuiki, swam in the cave as his father began to consecrate the shark in chant for a long and successful journey.

In the fourth month, Kaʻehuiki first traveled to Hilo and met the great shark, Kepanila. Later he met Kaneilehia of Kaʻū. He continued to befriend the other district sharks of the island of Hawaiʻi and asked them to become his traveling companions on his journey: Kua of Kona, Manokini of Kohala, and Kapulena of Hāmākua

The shark of Kohala, Manokini, described to Kaʻehuiki the difficulty of traveling across the rough ʻAlenuihāhā channel to the island of Maui, and the ferocious shark, Kauhuhu of Maui, that governed it. Upon their arrival to Maui, Kauhuhu called out to them for being in his cave. He extended and opened his large jaws to bite Kaʻehuiki. Kaʻehuiki swiftly entered his wide mouth and devoured his vitals from the inside; leaving Kauhuhu lifeless as he floated in the tides.

Finally, the voyage led to the island of Kahoʻolawe, where they could pay homage to Kamohoaliʻi-- the “king of all sharks”. He was overgrown with sea moss and barnacles - his mana emanated from him. Kamohoaliʻi consented to adopt the little-brown shark and an elaborate ceremony took place. He gave Kaʻehuiki the ability to take a hundred diﬀerent forms, immeasurable mana, and a long life.

The journey of Kaʻehuiki continued all the way to the distant lands of Kahiki, however, today he lives within the sea caves of Pānau. Oral history tells us that Kaʻehuikimanōopuʻuloa is an ʻaumakua (who is part of the Pele family), a form of the great Kamohoaliʻi, and a shark who invokes the power of Kaʻahupāhau. Puʻuloa, now within Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park, is seen as the place of the birth of Kaʻehuikimanōopuʻuloa. It is where many Hawaiians connect the piko (umbilical stump) of their child to his birthing place. It is a way to obtain a long life, and life-prolonging protection from an ʻaumakua of this land.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the boardwalk to the far end.

data.title: Trail of the Shadows Walking Tour
data.description: The Trail of the Shadows is an easy, 0.7 mile-loop trail that weaves around the Longmire Meadow. Created by volcanic mineral springs, this unique low elevation meadow is home to a rich ecosystem of plants and animals and has a long history of human use. This tour follows a set of exhibit panels located along the trail travelling counterclockwise from the main trailhead, which is located across the street from the National Park Inn in Longmire.

stops.significance: James Longmire, a pioneer and mountain guide, settled in the area that would come to be known by his name during the late 1800s.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Settling Into History Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path and take the short spur trail to the left to view the next exhibit panel, straight ahead at the end of the spur trail.

stops.significance: The Longmire Meadow is home to a diverse community of plants and animals.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Welcome to the Neighborhood Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next exhibit panel is also located at the end of the spur trail, to the right of the current panel overlooking the Longmire Meadow.

stops.significance: Rampart Ridge frames the Longmire Meadow with tall cliffs, evidence of the glacier that once filled this valley. On clear days, Mount Rainier is also visible from this location.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Cast in Ice Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back along the spur trail. The next exhibit panel is near the junction with the main trail on the left side.

stops.significance: Visitors have been drawn to the volcanic mineral springs in the meadow for a variety of purposes.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Nature's Own Laboratory Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the main path to the left (counterclockwise). The next panel is on the right side of the trail just past a mineral spring bordered by a low rock wall.

stops.significance: Early settlers developed the natural mineral springs into a health resort.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Nature's Spa Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path until you reach the next panel, which overlooks a pond at the top of the meadow.

stops.significance: Humans are not the only ones that have developed the meadow.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Local Homesteaders Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path until you reach a small wood cabin with an exhibit panel in front of it.

stops.significance: This cabin is all that remains of several structures that once existed around the Longmire Meadow.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Shadow of the Past Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is a short walk away, down the slope from the cabin and next to a stone-framed spring on the right side of the trail.

stops.significance: Iron minerals in the water give this spring its name – “Iron Mike” – and its rusty red color.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Rusty Springs Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Find the next exhibit panel a short distance away on the left side of the trail, just before a wooden footbridge over a creek.

stops.significance: Many amphibians can be found in the water sources around the meadow, including the elusive Coastal tailed frog.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Cryptic Creatures Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the trail over the bridge and up and over a short slope to the next panel, located on the left side of the trail before a section of wooden boardwalk.

stops.significance: Fallen trees are part of the nature cycle of the forest, supporting future generations of trees as nurse logs.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: On the Shoulders of Giants Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop is located along the boardwalk on the right side of the trail.

stops.significance: Look closer at the trees surrounding you to find rich colonies of lichen and moss.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Hiding in the Shadows Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail, which weaves along the border between the meadow and the forest. The next panel will be on the left side of the trail.

stops.significance: Enjoy the best of both worlds! The border between forest and meadow is home to many species.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Border Town Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the trail. Pause to take a short spur trail on the left, which provides a view of the meadow and a travertine spring, then continue on the main path to the next exhibit panel on the right of the trail surrounded by tall trees.

stops.significance: Tall trees provide the foundation of the old-growth forest surrounding the meadow.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Structural Support Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Keep left along the path as it curves around the bottom of the meadow, crossing over a wooden footbridge. The Rampart Ridge Trail starts to the right. The next panel is on the left side of the trail, next to a creek.

stops.significance: This area along the trail is covered with primordial plants like skunk cabbage and devil’s club.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Rooted in Time Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail over another footbridge and through the forest until you reach the next exhibit panel on the left side of the trail bordered by a split rail fence.

stops.significance: Generations of visitors have lived and recreated around the Longmire Meadow.
stops.assetName: Trail of the Shadows: Life on the Edge Exhibit Panel
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the path, keeping to the left to return to the main trailhead, or cross back over the road to reach the National Park Inn and explore the rest of Longmire Historic District.

data.title: Tule Lake Segregation Center Jail
data.description: The Tule Lake Segregation Center was the only one of the ten War Relocation Centers to be converted into a maximum-security segregation center and the only to have a jail built onsite. The is historic jail was recently restored. To set up a tour of the jail please call 530-260-0537, at least 2 weeks in advance.

stops.significance:
The Tulelake-Butte Valley Fairgrounds Museum of local history displays a variety of exhibits which include Modoc history, agricultural history, homesteading and settlement of the Tulelake Basin area, the history of Japanese American incarceration at the nearby segregation center, and a variety of other topics.

The Tulelake-Butte Valley Fairgrounds museum is open Monday - Friday 9:30 am - 4:30 PM. We recommend calling the fairgrounds to confirm their hours before your visit at 530-667-5312.
The Tule Lake Segregation Center was the only one of the ten War Relocation Centers to be converted into a maximum security segregation center and add a stockade and jail to the grounds.

Tule Lake was one of ten American Concentration Camps established during World War II to incarcerate 110,000 persons of Japanese ancestry, of whom the majority were American citizens, Behind barbed wire and guard towers without charge, trial or establishment of build. These camps are reminders of how racism, economic and political exploitation, and expediency can undermine the constitutional guarantees of United States citizens and aliens alike. May the injustices and humiliation suffered here never recur.

California Registered Historical Landmark No. 850-2 Plaque placed by the State Department of Parks and Recreation in cooperation with the Northern California-Western Nevada District Council. Japanese American Citizens League. May 27, 1979.

The Camp was first built by the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) in 1935, but later housed Japanese Americans in 1943 then German Prisoners of War from 1944 - 1946. It is located on Hill Road approximately two miles north of the Klamath Basin Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center.

The site can only be accessed while on a ranger guided tour, otherwise the site is closed to the public and can only be viewed from outside of the monument. Visitors are welcome to take pictures of the buildings and view the road side exhibits from outside the fence.

Rangers are staffed between Memorial Day and Labor day at the visitor center and provide tours every Saturday. The visitor center is located at the Tulelake Fairgrounds Museum, at 800 Main St., Tulelake, CA. Groups wanting a tour on a day other than Saturday need to request a tour at least 2 weeks in advance. Due to limited staffing, we may not be able to accommodate all requests. To reserve a spot on either tour please call 530-260-0537

data.title: Tuolumne Meadows - Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Self-Guided Tour
data.description: Explore the mystery that is Soda Springs and delve into the history of Parsons Lodge on this delightful walk through Tuolumne Meadows. Soda Springs--cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground--is protected within a log enclosure. Historic Parsons Memorial Lodge offers exhibits (limited hours--see Yosemite Guide for schedule). A path to the bridge below the lodge continues to the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center. Please stay on established trails. Pets, bicycles, or strollers are not allowed on trail.

data.title: Upper Terrace Drive
data.description: Upper Terrace Drive is a 1.5-mile (2.4-km) loop around the Upper Terrace of the Mammoth Hot Springs of Yellowstone National Park. This drive is open to automobiles and pedestrians during the summer, while the rest of the year it can be walked, skied, and snowshoed.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road to the right (north) to the fist parking area on the left.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the Mammoth Upper Terraces Drive. You can drive or walk this 1.5-mile (2.4 km) paved road along hot springs and travertine formations. If driving, the route is one way. Trailers, buses, and motor homes are prohibited on the drive due to limited parking and a narrow, winding roadway. If you are driving a vehicle like this, you may park it in the lot beside the Grand Loop Road and enjoy the sights on foot.

A few safety notes before you begin, either by foot or car:

•	For your safety and to protect these fragile features, it is important to stay on all boardwalks or paved trails.
•	Do not touch the water. Water temperatures are high and could cause severe burns.  
•	Hot-spring vents can become easily clogged; please do not throw anything in them. 
•	Watch for wildlife, especially if walking, and maintain a minimum of 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves and 25 yards (23 m) from all other wildlife. 
•	Be sure to take water to drink if you are walking and bring along any other weather-related items such as sunscreen, raincoats, and gloves. 
•	The only restroom available is a vault toilet in the parking lot at the start of this 1.5-mile drive or hike.

Ready? Go .1 mile to the first pullout.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road north until you reach the large parking area that overlooks the whole Mammoth Hot Springs area.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are entering one of the world’s best protected examples of travertine-depositing hot springs. Though there are similar deposits elsewhere in the world, many have been impacted by human use or are in remote areas that are much harder to reach.

 So why do we see these terraces here?  While the volcanic heat source for Mammoth Hot Springs remains somewhat of a mystery, scientists have proposed two possibilities. One is the large magma chamber underlying the Yellowstone Caldera; the other is perhaps a smaller heat source closer to Mammoth.

At Mammoth, a network of fractures and fissures forms the plumbing system that allows hot water from underground to reach the surface. The water comes from rain and snow falling on the surrounding mountains and seeping deep into the earth where it is heated.  Small earthquakes may keep the plumbing open.

Limestone, deposited here millions of years ago when a vast sea covered this area, provides the final ingredient. Hot water with dissolved carbon dioxide makes a solution of weak carbonic acid.  As the solution rises through rock, it dissolves calcium carbonate, the primary compound in limestone.  At the surface, the calcium carbonate is deposited in the form of travertine, the rock that forms the terraces of Mammoth Hot Springs.

Continue to the first overlook, where you’ll see active springs interspersed with dormant travertine terraces.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road northwest to the next parking area.
stops.audioTranscript:
To the east is an expansive flat travertine terrace, called Main Terrace. The active spring in the distance on the far right is Canary Spring, currently the largest active hot spring at Mammoth Hot Springs.  If you would like to get a closer look at it, you can either park here, if driving, and walk down the boardwalk to the right of this point, or you can continue on around this loop drive and park at the entrance area and then walk down a boardwalk that leads to Canary Spring from that parking lot.

Another Spring on the Main Terrace to the far left is New Blue Spring. It is one of the best examples of the area’s dynamic character. It shifts activity frequently and can become active or inactive several times in one year. A boardwalk to the left will take you to this hot spring if you would like to take a closer look.

Terraces are like living sculptures, shaped by the volume of water, the slope of the ground, and objects in the water’s path. Travertine builds up rapidly here at Mammoth and causes the features to change quickly and constantly. Approximately two tons of travertine are deposited daily in the Mammoth Hot Spring Terraces.

Some vents will clog completely, new vents may form, and old vents may reopen.  Sometimes the water is concentrated in a few springs; at other times, water may spread across many outlets. Visitors are surprised to find that a favorite hot spring has dried up since they were last here. This does not mean the springs are drying up; it just means that the water is changing its location of output within the area. For example, Canary Spring is once again experiencing dry periods.
In every case, water follows the path of least resistance, which could be above ground or underground. Scientists estimate that, at any given time, about 10 percent of the water in the Mammoth Hot Springs system is on the surface; the other 90 percent is underground.

The features are always changing, but the overall activity of the entire area and the volume of water discharged remains relatively constant. The Mammoth Terraces is one of the few places on Earth where rock forms before your eyes. You can actually see the changes. 

Continue up the hill to the next pullout on the right, which will give you a good view of Fort Yellowstone.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road west around a large bend to the parking lot on the left.
stops.audioTranscript:
For the decade after Yellowstone National Park was established in 1872, the park was under serious threat from those who would exploit, rather than protect, its resources. Poachers killed animals. Souvenir hunters broke off large pieces of these hot-spring terraces and also from geyser cones in other areas of the park. Developers set up camps for tourists near hot springs, along with bath and laundry facilities in the hot springs. Civilian superintendents who were hired to preserve and protect the land had differing expertise and intentions, but all were underfunded and understaffed. Thus, Yellowstone National Park turned to the US Army for help. In 1886, men from Company M, First United States Cavalry, Fort Custer, Montana Territory, came to Yellowstone under command of Captain Moses Harris. They began what would be 32 years of military presence in the park.

At first, soldiers lived in temporary frame buildings at Camp Sheridan at the foot of the Mammoth Hot Springs Terraces. After enduring five cold, harsh winters and realizing there was no end in sight to this assignment, Congress appropriated money for a permanent post. From 1891 through 1909, Fort Yellowstone was built, most of which still stands today and is used for housing and administrative offices. In 1916, when Congress created the National Park Service, the Army turned Fort Yellowstone over to the new agency. The fort has served the park well ever since, both as administrative headquarters and as a constant reminder of the debt the nation owes the officers and enlisted men of the United States Army for protecting and preserving Yellowstone National Park for future generations.

Continue to the left. You’ll travel past dormant hot-spring terraces on both sides of the road and stop at a small pullout to the left.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road south until the next parking area on the right.
stops.audioTranscript:
Can you see how this area was active at one time?  Travertine deposited many years ago is all around you.  But it is not colorful like active springs that you have seen. Thermophiles, which are heat-loving microorganisms, create tapestries of color where hot water flows among the terraces.  Colorless and yellow thermophiles grow in the hottest water, whereas orange, brown, and green thermophiles thrive in cooler water.  Colors also change with the seasons due to differing amounts of sunlight.  When a hot spring stops flowing, the thermophiles responsible for the color die, and the travertine deposit is then eroded by weather. Here, you can see that at one time most of this area was active, but now only the eroded travertine remains.  This is not to say that it will not become active again. Time will tell.

Continue on to the next pullout on the right side of the road to see Prospect Spring.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road about 0.2 mile (0.3 km).
stops.audioTranscript:
Prospect Terrace is a typical feature that exhibits constantly changing activity.  Some years there has been no activity. At present, there is one active spring on the north side of the terrace.  

Across the road stands a ridge of travertine called the Buttress, which has long been dormant. At its base, however, is a sunken area with hot gases rising from it.  Gases can be toxic and have killed birds and small animals that have entered these sunken areas. Please remember to stay on boardwalks or official trails for your safety and to protect fragile formations.

Now it’s time to head up the hill, through a forest of juniper, limber pine, and Douglas-fir, to the next pullout on the right.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road southwest about 0.1 mile (0.2 km) to the parking area just around the curve in the road.
stops.audioTranscript:
Look at the contrast between the hill on the left and the hill on the right.  On the left is New Highland Terrace, which was active from the 1950s through the 1980s. Ranger notes from 1973 say, “New Highland is certainly one of the top two or three attractions along the Upper Loop Drive, probably drawing more traffic than any other parking area, except the main overlook.” Water running down the terraces at that time flooded, killed, and entombed trees growing there, so a fresh runoff channel had to be dug next to the road to channel all the water. Activity declined after the 1980s, but then resumed to a lesser degree in 2011.

To the right, across the road from New Highland Terrace, is a healthy mixed forest of limber pine, juniper, and Douglas-fir trees. What a difference in the growth of trees! This is probably what the forest to the left looked like before the hot-spring activity began. 

This is also a good place to see birds such as Clark’s nutcrackers, magpies, and northern flickers. Look also for red squirrels and chipmunks who eat seeds, buds, fungi, and insects. You might even see deer, elk, or a black bear in the area.

Time to continue ahead. You’ll pass Orange Spring Mound and park in the pullout just after the big curve to the left.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road east for about 0.2 mile (0.3 km).
stops.audioTranscript:
Orange Spring Mound flows from several springs on its top and sides and has been active since at least 1871. It is called Orange Spring Mound because of the orange-colored thermophiles growing in the hot water, which must reach a temperature of at least 95°F (35°C) and up to 135°F (57°C) for the orange thermophiles to grow. Tangerine Spring flows behind Orange Spring Mound. It can be seen by walking the boardwalk that takes you behind the larger feature, Orange Spring Mound. 

Across the road is a small mound which was colloquially named Little Burper. It was active into the 1990s and used to regularly “burp” water out of its top. The name was given before 1970 either by park guests or by tour-bus drivers.  Another name for it was Little Bubbler because it was said to sound like a coffee pot percolating.  It is no longer active.  

Continue on the road over a hill to a pullout on the right side to learn more about a historic warm pool named Bath Lake.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road south as it winded through the terraces for about 0.2 mile (0.3 km).
stops.audioTranscript:
If you were here before 1926, you would be looking out over a warm pool of water that filled the depression in the ground to the northwest.  It was named Bath Lake around 1883 because bathers began to use it for soaking at that time.  This activity in hot springs is no longer allowed due to safety concerns and the damage it causes to the feature.

Geologist Walter Weed, who studied the spring in the summer of 1883, described the lake’s shores as strewn with discarded men’s bathsuits. In the early days, women were barred from swimming in Bath Lake because in good weather a large number of nude male bathers occupied it exclusively. GL Henderson, owner of the Cottage Hotel at Mammoth, suggested the government should regulate this matter by either constructing or permitting the construction of dressing rooms so that women and men in bathing suits could use the spring together. Eventually a bath house was constructed in 1919. When Bath Lake went dry in 1926, the bath house was removed. The 1959 Hebgen Lake Earthquake restored water flow to the lake, but by this time bathing was no longer allowed in any springs. In 1984, the lake dried up once again and remains dry.

Continue up the next hill to the second pullout on the right to see White Elephant Back Terrace.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the road south and then around several curves to the east for about 0.4 mile (0.6 km).
stops.audioTranscript:
Take a look back to the left along the travertine terrace.  Can you see an elephant’s back?  The first recorded use of this name was when a tourist from Cooperstown, New York, referred to it in the Helena Weekly Herald in 1888 as resembling “the vertebral column of a gigantic quadruped.” Water laden with calcium carbonate has flowed from a fissure to build this ridge. As with many of the other springs you have seen, activity shifts constantly. 

Continue down the hill.  You’ll be passing once again through a mixed forest of Douglas-fir, juniper, and limber pine on your way to Angel Terrace.

The dramatic presence of this feature comes from abundant water, white formations, and colorful thermophiles that thrive in hot water. Angel Terrace was named around 1895, most likely by photographer F.J. Haynes, who likely chose the name because of the “purity of the deposit and the snowy whiteness when inactive.” At the height of its activity in the 1920s and 1930s, Angel Terrace was described in ranger notes as the “Gem of the Mammoth formations.”

After the 1930s, activity declined, and Angel Terrace was dry and crumbling for decades. In 1985, however, it resumed activity once again! As you have seen here, at Mammoth, changes cannot be predicted, but they are certain to occur.

From here you can return to the parking lot if walking, or return to the Grand Loop Road if driving.

If you are interested in walking other trails, don’t forget about Canary Spring Trail that starts here from the parking lot.  Also, Palette Spring is a level boardwalk that starts at the bottom of the Mammoth Terraces.  Mound Terrace is also an active, colorful spring, but does involve a steep uphill walk on boardwalk with many steps from the bottom of the Mammoth Terraces. 

We hope you enjoyed the views of past and present hot-spring activity along the Mammoth Hot Springs Upper Terrace Drive. In addition, we hope you have found many reasons to preserve and protect the resources of this planet—from the thermal features of Yellowstone to the nature near your home.

data.title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial Tour
data.description: See all the points of interest at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial

stops.significance: The information kiosk is a place to get visitor information and brochures. There is also rubbing paper and pencil for wall rubbings. Rangers are available to provide assistance.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the kiosk, walk to the right. Take the left most path towards the American flagpole. As you approach the memorial there are stanchions lining the left side of the walkway. This is the next stop.

stops.significance:
This sculpture of three warriors was dedicated on Veterans Day in
1984. It was designed and sculpted by the late Frederick Hart. Hart, who won third place in the original memorial design competition, was awarded the commission to create a representational sculpture. The hope was that this sculpture would quiet all opposition to the memorials avant-garde design.
stops.assetName: Vietnam Veterans Memorial: Three Servicemen Statue
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Three Servicemen statue turn to the left towards the chained off area. The plaque on the ground is the next stop.

stops.significance: This plaque honors those veterans who died after their service in the Vietnam War and as a result of that service. These names would not otherwise be eligible for placement on the Memorial wall.
stops.assetName: Vietnam Veterans Memorial: In Memory Plaque
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the walkway to the black marble path. This marks the beginning of the Vietnam Wall.

stops.significance:
Dedicated in 1982, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial was a revolutionary minimalist design. The memorial includes the names of over 58,000 servicemen and women who gave their lives in service of the Vietnam War. 

Each name is preceded (on the West Wall) or followed (on the East Wall) by a symbol designating that person’s status. The diamond symbol denotes that the service member's death was confirmed; the plus sign (or cross) denotes the person was missing at the end of the war and remains missing and unaccounted for.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the black marble walkway. Take the right path at the end of the wall. Follow this path to the asphalt walkway. The next stop is across this walkway.

stops.significance:
The Vietnam Women’s Memorial was the third addition to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. It was designed by Glenna Goodacre and dedicated on Veterans Day in 1993. 

The memorial was created to honor the women who risked their lives in service during the Vietnam War. Planted around the statue’s plaza are eight yellowwood trees, one to commemorate each of the women who died in Vietnam.

data.title: Virtual Wayside Tour
data.description: This virtual tour is based on two of our most popular and informative trails where you can learn more about the geologic heritage of the Florissant Valley. The Petrified Forest Loop wanders amongst giant stumps of ancient redwood trees that grew in this valley during the Eocene epoch 34 million years ago, while the Geologic Trail takes you even deeper to explore events of Earth’s history more than a billion years old. Click on the picture at the top of the pages to see the full image

stops.assetName: On Top of a Forest, on the Bottom of a Lake

data.title: Visit Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark
data.description: Located in the center of Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve, Kennecott is a park within a park. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1978 and designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1986, Kennecott is considered the best remaining example of early 20th Century copper mining. In June 1998, the National Park Service acquired many of the significant buildings and lands of the historic copper mining town of Kennecott and is still in the process of stabilizing many structures.

park.fullName: Wrangell - St Elias National Park & Preserve
park.name: Wrangell - St Elias

stops.significance: National Historic Landmark within a National Park.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Begin at the Kennecott Visitor Center within the historic Blackburn School building and continue on the self-guided tour around the town. The Interpretive exhibits and structures open to the public can be explored in any order you prefer. Please respect private property and the residents who live within Kennecott town.
stops.audioTranscript: Located in the center of Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve, Kennecott is a park within a park. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1978 and designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1986, Kennecott is considered the best remaining example of early 20th Century copper mining. In June 1998, the National Park Service acquired many of the significant buildings and lands of the historic copper mining town of Kennecott and is still in the process of stabilizing many structures.

stops.significance: Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark exhibits walking tour map
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue from the beginning parking area wayside exhibits to the Kennecott Visitor Center in the historic Blackburn School.
stops.audioTranscript: "Shuttle Turnaround. 14 Â½ minutes. Located at the far southern end of Kennecott, at the northern end of a 30-foot (9 m) wide, half-moon shaped shuttle bus turnaround, an eight-foot (2 m) tall by twelve-foot (2.5 m) wide rusted, sculptural metal sign announces the Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark. Several three- to four-foot (1.25 m) tall circular metal cogs and wheels are embedded in the ground in front of the sign, with a boulder on the ground with a plaque that commemorates the National Historic Landmark.Just to the left of the sign, a wood plank boardwalk runs past a 10-foot (2.75 m) wide by six-foot (2 m) deep covered bus shelter and information kiosk with a 10-foot (2.75 m) tall triangular roof. Note a wooden bench in the center, information panels on the interior and exterior walls, and at the front right corner post, maps of the area inside a metal brochure box with a slanted, hinged lid. Behind a three and a half -foot (1.25 m) tall wooden railing, the boardwalk continues around to the left along the top of the bluff, overlooking the Kennicott Valley and Glacier below. There are two wooden benches spaced roughly evenly along the boardwalk, and three additional three-foot (1 m) wide by two-foot (60 cm) tall information panels to the south along the railing.Note that the buses do not typically use this shuttle stop, but drop passengers near private businesses in town. It is however, used for day use parking. A wheelchair-accessible ramp and boardwalk to the north links the turnaround to the Old Blackburn School, Kennecott Visitor Center and bookstore. Note there is an ADA accessible outhouse midway along the ramp just before you reach the school building, located to the east along a 12-foot (3.5 m) wide wooden deck.Note that while many of the approaches to the buildings here at Kennecott are accessible by many new wheelchairs, the town is filled with unpaved gravel surfaces and uneven terrain.An information panel on the right exterior wall of the kiosk displays a hiking trail map of the area. Text at the top left of the panel reads:Learn MoreCome visit us in the Visitor Center to learn about recreational opportunities, backcountry etiquette, bear safety, and more. For more information on these and other trails, pick up free handouts at the Visitor Center.Continuing down the left side of the panel, text next to an illustration of a black bear reads:Be Bear Aware!You are in bear country. Bears are attracted by smells, including food and other fragrant items. Unfortunately, receiving them can lead to aggressive behavior that puts both bears and humans in jeopardy. To help bears focus on foraging for their natural foods, and to keep yourself safe:Food must be in your direct control or in an approved Bear Resistant Container at all times-even in the middle of the day, even on the glacier.Bear Resistant Food Lockers are available at popular camping locations in Kennicott Valley.Portable Bear Resistant Food Containers can be borrowed from the Park's Visitor Center, free of charge.Federal law requires proper food storage at all times. Improperly stored food can result in a fine or imprisonment. At the middle left of the panel, text next to an illustration of a hand shovel reads:Pack in, pack out, dig deepThis area is managed as wilderness. Please pack out everything you pack in. Bury your solid human waste at least 6 to 8 inches deep, and 200 feet (60 m) from water, camp, and trails. Make it look like you were never there!Further down on the left, text next to an illustration of a boot with spikes sticking down from the sole reads:Hiking on GlaciersGlaciers provide unique and rewarding hiking experiences, best enjoyed with caution. A glacier's edge, glacial melt pools, and river potholes can be extremely dangerous due to rotting ice and swift, cold water. Fine glacial silt may look dry but can be very slippery, and contrary to first impressions, there is only a thin layer of rocks covering the ice. Crampons are strongly recommended. Remember, you are still in bear country when on a glacier.At the bottom left, text next to an image of a sheet of paper and a pencil reads:Backcountry ItinerariesIf you are heading into the backcountry, we encourage you to tell a third party your trip route and expected return time. Voluntary Backcountry Itinerary forms are also available. This will not result in an automatic search, but enables us to assist if you run into trouble. A map fills the right-hand side of the panel, showing the Root Glacier, a large, pale-blue area at the top, converging with the Kennicott Glacier in the middle. An orange "You Are Here" sign in the center shows your current position, with the town of McCarthy and the airport indicated at the bottom of the map. In the narrow green forested areas to the right of the glaciers, a dotted red line shows the paths of the five hiking trails here at Kennecott Mines. Small inset black-and-white boxes point to each trail with a brief description.

stops.significance: Kennecott Visitor Center in the historic Blackburn School building.
stops.assetName: Kennecott Visitor Center in Blackburn School
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue exploring through town for other interpretive exhibits in any order you prefer.
stops.audioTranscript:
Kennecott Visitor Center. 3 ¾ minutes.
The one-story, red and white painted wood Blackburn School is the first building at the far southern end of the town at Kennecott. 
Note a wheelchair accessible ramp to the north of a 16-foot (5 m) wide wooden deck outside the west side of the building, ringed with a three and a half-foot (1.1 m) tall wooden railing, and an ADA accessible outhouse down a short ramp to the south. Note this same ramp also continues south, linking the visitor center to the shuttle bus turnaround.
A three-foot (1 m) tall, cast bronze, tactile, topographical model of the town sits in the middle of the deck. Measuring about five feet (1.25 m) wide by three-feet (1 m) deep, feel the locations of all the buildings and surrounding topography of the town. 
A visual map of the town just below the touchable exhibit show the various buildings in different shades of red, orange, yellow, white, and gray. These indicate which are National Park Service structures versus private property, and which structures are open to the public. Text at the left of the map reads:

Explore Kennecott Mill Town
A remarkable lode of copper ore near this very spot was discovered by American prospectors in 1900. Workers then developed the camp, mill, mines, and railway over the next decade. Kennecott Mines went into regular production in 1911, and proved hugely profitable. The mines were tapped out and closed in 1938.
Today, Kennecott mill town is the best preserved example of early 20th century copper mining technology in the country. It is also a thriving community and a gateway to an immense wilderness.

Behind and to the right of the outdoor model, a single wood door leads inside the school from the outside deck. 
Inside at the left, a black-and-white photograph fills the bottom of a four-foot (1.25 m) tall by three-foot (1 m) wide angled metal display panel on the floor. A woman in the center, dressed in a long sleeve white, high-collar shirt and floor-length black skirt, stands behind a couple rows of boys and girls of various ages, from six years old to teenagers. Information at the top of the panel tells us that the Blackburn School was built in 1913, moved to Kennecott circa 1915, and restored between 2002 and 2005. Beside a copy of a hand-written inventory of supplies and books at the school, text continues:

Moving with the boom and bust of mining towns
In 1913, the Kennecott Copper Corporation supplied materials to construct this building in the tiny community of Blackburn. Located along the railway between Kennecott and the future town of McCarthy, Blackburn had grown up as prospectors moved into the valley.
By 1915, however, Blackburn was mostly empty—its spring dried up and everyone moved to McCarthy, which was booming as a stop-over on the way to the Chisana gold fields. Kennecott was also booming, so the Corporation moved this building up to its present location on a flatcar. It served as a school for workers’ children until the end of the 1921-1922 school year, when the student population had grown again and classes moved to the new and larger Two Room School. The Old School was converted to storage.

Inside the School, staff and additional exhibits answer questions about the backcountry, front country trails, and the landmark, and more maps, books, and gifts are available for sale in the Alaska Geographic bookstore.

stops.significance: Historic Recreation Hall within Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark and Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to other interpretive exhibits in town in any order as you prefer.
stops.audioTranscript: "Recreation Hall. 12 minutes.Located 50 feet (15 m) to the north from the Kennicott Glacier Lodge, a set of wooden stairs and a wheelchair accessible ramp around the building from below, leads to a one-story red and white wooden building.Using the stairs, from the main gravel road, proceed 13 steps down a set of four-foot (1.25 m) wide wooden stairs, with four-foot (1.25 m) tall railings on either side, to a small wooden landing. Proceed down nine more steps to an eight-foot (2.5 m) wide by 19 foot (5.8 m) long wooden platform in front of the Recreation Hall. The single red and white wood door entrance is located in the middle of the building.Note the wheelchair accessible ramp is located on the west side of the building, but is reachable only from the lower service road. Note also there are two, red and white, gender neutral accessible outhouses near the base of the ramp, located immediately to the south along a 10-foot (2.75 m) gravel driveway leading west back to the service road.Facing the front door, exercise caution moving over the slightly raised wooden threshold onto the hardwood floor of a small, 10-square foot (three-square meter) anteroom. At the right, two pot belly stoves sit on a single-brick raised platform. At the left, a two and a half-foot (0.75 m) tall flip book display, mounted on an angle, stands in front of a three and a half-foot (1.1 m) wide by seven-foot (2.1 m) tall wall panel at the back. The panel presents information about the activities that took place here, while the flipbook offers more vignettes about the community's social and political history up to the present day.Beyond this entrance area, the hall opens up into a 30-foot (9 m) wide by 50-foot (15 m) long open, rectangular room with 15 foot (4.5 m) ceilings. Rows of six-foot (2 m) square windows line the center of both walls, looking up to the mountains on the east and out over the Kennicott Glacier on the west. Rows of wooden benches at the base of the walls sit on opposite sides of the dark, hardwood floor. A large movie screen hangs at the back of the hall, and there's a modern, black and silver wood stove in the far back left corner.Back inside the anteroom, facing the two pot belly stoves, the stove at the left is identified as a Great Western wood burning stove. It stands six feet (2 m) tall with a nearly three-foot (1 m) wide square black base. It has a generally cylindrical body with metal castings and hardware that rises to another dark cylinder at the top, connecting to a stovepipe into the ceiling above. Feel free to explore this original artifact.Opposite the stove, a black-and-white photograph at the top of the wall panel shows the frontier buildings and town of Kennecott in the early 20th century. A hand-written musical score appears across the bottom of the panel. Next to an image in the center of a pair of brown leather boxing gloves with green lacing, text reads:Recreation HallBuilt in 1916, restoration complete in 2003A place to socialize and celebrateThe twinkle of lights and sound of music enticed managers, their families, and workers to fill the Recreation Hall for dances, symphonies, school plays, Christmas pageants, movies, the occasional church service, and indoor sports like basketball, shuffleboard, roller skating, wrestling, and boxing matches. Organizing and enjoying these activities together helped create a sense of community among employees.The Kennecott Copper Corporation provided the Recreation Hall and other comforts to attract and keep workers. In exchange, the Corporation expected them to work hard and stay out of trouble.Below this text, between the wall panel and the flip book, note a music stand on the vignette with some sheet music from the era. There is also a lady's dance card from the 1920s for use at Kennecott dances, with numbered lines and a white string loop and small tassel.Turning to the first page of the flip book, a quote at the top of the dark purple page reads:"Such an abundance of dancing partners."Text continues:Dances were held in the Recreation Hall two to four times a month in the 1920s, although this dwindled to once a month by the late 1930s. In those decades, dancing required a partner of the opposite sex, but women-nurses, teachers, secretaries, and wives-were in short supply at Kennecott. To keep things orderly and to be sure that everyone had a turn, men reserved a dance by writing their name on a lady's dance card. Dance cards could fill up very quickly.A quote at the bottom reads:"There is a recreation hall where a few of the dances-the big ones like New Years and Fourth of July, etc., are held and everybody attends... the men outnumber [us] ... and no matter how much your feet hurt or your knees weaken, you have to keep on dancing."- Ethel LeCount in a letter to a friend, 1938.To the right on page two, a black-and-white photograph shows a line of men in suits and women in long elegant dresses standing underneath hundreds of strands of twisted streamers.

stops.significance: Historic Kennecott General Store, Warehouse and Post Office
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to other interpretive exhibits in town in any order as you prefer.
stops.audioTranscript:
"General Store, Exhibit Center, Warehouse, Storeroom, and Post Office. 87 Â½ minutes.
The General Store, Exhibit Center, Warehouse, Storeroom, and Post Office are all located in the three-story red and white wood building on the west side of the main gravel road, just north of the intersection of the inclined, gravel service road.
Facing the building, a five-foot (1.5 m) wide wood plank boardwalk spans the front of the 35-foot (10 m) wide storefront. Two sets of bay windows at the right flank a recessed wood and glass door leading into the General Store. About six feet to the left of the left-hand bay window, a single wood door leads into the Post Office, flanked by two white double-hung windows.
Note a wooden bench along the boardwalk under the window to the left of the bay.
You may enter the General Store or Warehouse from four different locations. Either: 1) through the front door of the General Store, the main entrance; 2) at the far right, through a side door on the north side of the building, from a 40-foot (12 m) long by four-foot (1.25 m) wide wheelchair accessible catwalk; 3) through the Post Office door immediately to the left; or 4) at the far left, up a short flight of four stairs to an open, 10-foot (2.75 m) square wooden platform with a couple wooden benches, then right 40 feet (12 m) down a slightly inclined ramp with wooden railings through a set of double wood doors on the south side of the building.

To enter the Post Office, move through the single door located towards the left-hand side of the storefront. Once inside, move five feet left (1.5 m) on a 45-degree angle to a narrow, open wooden doorway. Just to the right of the door is a small, chest high open counter window. Several letters and stamps are displayed on the counter under glass.
To the right of the counter, rows of wooden mail boxes line the wall, some with historic brass fronts with small glass windows and combination locks. The original Kennecott post office sign hangs above the boxes, a four-foot (1.5 m) wide black sign with white block letters reading, "U.S. Post Office, Kennecott, Alaska." Note a reproduction hangs in the original location, directly above the door outside.
To the left of the door is a floor-standing information panel. Text at the top of the panel reads:

Post Office
Built in 1917, restoration completed in 2006
Keeping in touch with home
The vast majority of Kennecott workers were far from home and family, so the Post Office was an important link to their loved ones. Workers sent letters and money orders-after all, they were here to make and save money. They also received news and mail-order goods. Mail traveled by train and, in later years, by air. Some long-term staff had brass mailboxes here, but most letters were sent to their recipients via general delivery.
To send news or to wire money home more quickly -and at greater expense-workers went to the Wells Fargo telegraph service in the Railway Depot.

A black-and-white photograph, entitled "Snowbird at the post office, 1937," fills the bottom of the panel. It shows a woman standing outside in front of the snowy and ice-covered Post Office next to a modified automobile with caterpillar tracks in the rear and skis in the front.
Move through the door to enter the back room of the Post Office. The open backs of the letter boxes line the wall to your right. Opposite the boxes, a mail duffel bag artifact hangs on the back wall at the left.
Another single wooden door at the back left of the Post Office leads into the Storeroom, though it is highly recommended you move back outside through the front door of the Post Office to continue your tour, beginning in the Store.

Note that beacons inside each of the remaining three entrances will automatically trigger the appropriate interior audio description for your location.â€ƒ
"

stops.significance: Historic General Manager's Office, Kennecott Copper Corporation
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to other interpretive exhibits in any order you prefer.
stops.audioTranscript:
"General Manager's Office. 37 Â½ minutes.
The General Manager's Office is located up a moderately steep, switchback gravel path to the east from the main gravel road, just north of the wood plank bridge over National Creek. A flagpole sits outside the building at the left.
The central log portion of the red and white, two-story building is the oldest building in Kennecott. Later additions at the left and right provided more office, safe, payroll, and drafting space.
This 2,451 square foot (745 square meter) building was the hub of corporate activity in the 1920s and 1930s. There are numerous exhibits inside this self-guided facility, providing access to historic and interpretive documents about Kennecott Copper Corporation, biographical information on corporate leaders, reproductions of mining maps, photos, surveys, engineering reports, employment records, and drawings of buildings and machinery.
"

stops.significance: Historic Power Plant for the mining town of Kennecott, 1911 - 1938.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue to other interpretive exhibits in town in any order you prefer.
stops.audioTranscript:
"Power Plant. 4 Â½ minutes.
Located at the northern end of town along the west side of the main gravel road, four towering smoke stacks rise from the three-story, 13,218 square foot (4,025 square meter) Power Plant.
As you move along the road toward the center of the plant, be mindful of rusted metal rails and other large metal debris lying in front of the nearly 120 foot (36 m) long structure.
Banks of three, eight-foot (2.5 m) tall by 10-foot (2.75 m) wide double hung white windows line the walls of the first section of the long red building.
A 10-foot (2.75 m) wide wood plank boardwalk near the end of this portion of the plant leads over a set of railroad tracks and over a small wooden threshold through a set of double red and white wooden doors onto a 10-foot (2.75 m) wide by five-foot (1.5 m) deep metal platform. A four-foot (1.25 m) tall metal railing surrounds the platform, with metal mesh screening between the rails.
The platform looks out over the power plant floor, to four enormous, two-story tall boilers at the right. A smokestack rises up from each, penetrating the roof and reaching for the sky beyond. To the left and right, additional large tanks and pipes line the periphery of the inside walls of the plant.
Straight ahead, on a catwalk on the other side of the plant, across the shop floor, a seven-foot (2.1 m) tall black-and-white floor-standing photograph shows a man in a long-sleeve shirt, tie, soft-billed cap and overalls standing before the turbines holding a pair of gloves. Mr. McGavoch was one of the electrician's here at the plant.
A three and a half-foot (1.1 m) wide angled information panel mounted flush with the top of the railing at the left tells the story of the Power Plant. Text next to an image of an early electric light bulb reads:

Built and expanded 1911-1917, rebuilt after the 1924 fire, restoration completed in 2014
Power was essential for Kennecott operations
In the earliest years, a small wood-burning boiler powered the sawmill. The first of the boilers in front of you came up when the railway was completed in 1911. As the others were added, this became one of the largest power plants in Alaska.
The boilers burned oil to generate steam. The steam generated electricity in the Mill's steam turbines, heated the ammonia reaction in the leaching plant, and warmed buildings throughout the Mill camp. The diesel-electric generators (to your left) sent electricity to the camp, Mill, trams, and mines. The Pelton wheel generator hiding behind them was used in emergencies. Multiple ways to generate power meant that even if something went wrong, operations could continue.

A black-and-white photograph at the right side of the panel shows an aerial view of the plant from the west. A quote at the bottom of the panel reads:

"An oil storage tank located on the hill above the power plant held enough oil to operate Kennecott all winter...At 30 degrees below zero, the steam plant was a nice place to work."
-Wesley Bloom, journeyman electrician at Kennecott, 1935-1937

From this location, note an exterior, four-foot (1.25 m) wide wood plank boardwalk, parallel to the plant that runs about 60 feet (18 m) north to a second, wooden observation platform inside the plant at the left. Inside, the boardwalk extends left from the platform, snaking around some of the pipes and tanks inside the plant, providing additional viewing vantage points closer to the boilers and smokestacks.
Power played a critical role in Kennecott's self-sufficiency. Industry requires power, and generating power in the wilderness, on a sizable scale, required imagination and herculean effort. The plant provided power and steam heat to the entire town. Steam traveled to outlying buildings through underground wooden conduits. These were often built under wooden sidewalks, keeping them free of snow and ice in the winter. Water for the steam boilers was diverted from Bonanza Creek, north of the town. Power was also transmitted over a high-tension line to Bonanza and then across the hill to Jumbo.
"
