images.altText: A boardwalk leads to the upper right entrance of a cave, while to the left, water flows below.
images.caption: Step back into history

data.title: Walking Tour- Battle of Guilford Courthouse
data.description: This is a walking tour of the Guilford Courthouse battlefield. You will walk over 2 miles of the park, visiting crucial spots and learning how one of the most important battles of the American Revolution unfolded.

stops.significance: This is both the site of the Historic Hoskins Farm and the area where the British army deployed before it attacked the American first line to begin the battle of Guilford Courthouse.
stops.assetName: Hoskins Farm Entrance and British Deployment Area
stops.directionsToNextStop: You are now ready to move to your next tour stop. Proceed 50 yards up the hill to the Historic Hoskins Farm buildings so that you can also see the New garden Road to the north.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Guilford Courthouse National Military Park! Founded in 1917, this was the first National Park to ever preserve a battlefield of the American Revolution. Today the park is over 250 acres, preserving a unique battlefield and a beautiful forest. 
For your safety today, any time you are on the tour road, stay to the left side which is labeled with the pedestrian symbol, and share the road with vehicles and cyclists.
Your tour will take you over 1 ½ miles from your first to your last stop. 

You are at the site of the largest field battle to occur in the Southern Colonies during the war. Over 6300 soldiers took part in 2 ½ hours of fighting here. 
But how and why did two large armies fight in the central piedmont region of North Carolina? This would have been a sparsely populated section of the poorest rebelling colony. 
To answer that question, we need to understand what events led us to this point, and we can do that by breaking the American War of Independence down into 3 major phases.
The First Phase of the war began in 1775 in Massachusetts. After a decade of protests and antagonism over how the British Empire should be run, and what role the colonies would play within it, troops were sent to occupy Boston and enforce the Coercive Acts. These actions were in retaliation for the Boston Tea Party, which occurred at the end of 1773.
The British wanted to make an example of Boston to prevent any further acts of rebellion, get repayment for the destroyed tea, and restore some sense of order in America. Fighting began when British troops clashed with Americans at the Battles of Lexington and Concord in April 1775. They soon found themselves surrounded in Boston, with rebels from several colonies swarming the countryside. By early 1776 the British were forced to evacuate Boston, but both they and their American opponents knew that the British army would return soon enough.
In the summer of 1776, the new United States declared independence on July 4, and just a month later the British returned, landing an army in New York to begin the second phase of the war. This phase sees the British trying to fight the Americans as though they were a foreign enemy. They sought decisive battles, seized crucial ports, and also tried to cut New England off from the other colonies. Now,  despite repeated battlefield successes, the British were unable to crush the rebellion, and slowly realized this was a different kind of war, a war that would require winning the hearts and minds of the people.
When a British army surrendered at Saratoga, New York in 1777, the face of the war changed again. The French, who were already supplying the Americans with weapons and war materials, entered the war and would now contribute their army and navy to the American cause. This change of events led the British to change strategy, and leads us to the third and final phase of the war, the Southern Phase.

The reason the British army came to the South was to reclaim its most profitable colonies, and to recruit loyalists. With the French in the war, the British needed to send more men and more ships to protect the rest of their empire. With less men for North America, they hoped loyalists could help fill the gap in manpower. These colonists who stayed dedicated to the Crown were the British army’s biggest hope in the Southern theater.
The British initially captured Savannah Georgia in 1778, then defended it from French and American forces in 1779. By 1780, the British were ready for their full-scale invasion, capturing an American army in Charleston in May, then spreading out into the backcountry, establishing forts and outposts all through South Carolina and Georgia. In August, another American army was sent to stop the British tide, but it was routed at the Battle of Camden. It seemed the British would soon be moving into North Carolina, but resistance fighters in the countryside, sickness in camp, and the devastating defeat of British loyalists at the Battle of King’s Mountain in October, stopped the British momentum as winter set in at the end of 1780.

In December 1780, a new American commander arrived to take control of the forces in the south. Major General Nathanael Greene was a former Quaker and a self-taught military man who had served in the Continental army since the siege of Boston. A combat commander and former quartermaster general, this was his first independent command in the war.
Facing Greene was General Charles Cornwallis. An aggressive and skilled combat commander, Cornwallis had previous command experiences before the War of Independence. The south was also his first totally independent command, but he was slowly growing frustrated with the slow process of pacifying the countryside. 
As the year 1781 began, these two commanders could not have realized they were about to embark on a campaign that would shift the war in a new direction.

stops.significance: The Hoskins Farm would serve as a headquarters and as a hospital in the aftermath of the battle.
stops.assetName: Snake Rail Fences at the Hoskins Farm
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed out the back gate of the Hoskins Farm Site, and turn left, walking up Green Acres lane. Proceed 300 yards until you see the Crown Forces monument on your left, it will be a tall obelisk standing alone in a field. That is your next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
A few points of reference as we get started on our tour. You are now at the Hoskins Farm Site on the western boundary of the battlefield. The Guilford Courthouse, which no longer stands, would have been at the far eastern boundary of the battlefield, near modern day Tour Stop 6. The only major road at the time of the battle would have been the New Garden Road running west to east up the middle of the battlefield. Today the modern New Garden Road runs right up to the park’s main gate, then becomes a gravel walking trail the rest of the way to the court house site.
If you would like to learn more about the Hoskins Family, what brought them here, and what their farm was like, there is a separate, 4 stop, audio tour you can take of the farm site.

Now, back to the battle. March 15, 1781 dawned damp and cold. The British army were on the road by 5 a.m. determined to not let the Americans get away. What they didn’t know was that the Americans had stopped running. Greene’s army received numerous reinforcements in the week leading up to the battle. Where once, the two armies were equal in size, the American rebels now outnumbered the British two to one. Greene’s army had approximately 4400 troops to General Cornwallis’ 2100 soldiers.
Light Horse Harry Lee led a portion of American cavalry and infantry out early that morning to keep an eye on the British and provide a warning of their approach. His men clashed with the men of Tarleton’s British legion early that morning at another Quaker settlement only 4 miles from where you are located, called New Garden. At some point in the fighting, Banastre Tarleton lost two fingers when a musket ball smashed into his sword hand. But Tarleton quickly received treatment, and he still led the cavalry when they arrived here later in the morning. 
Just before NOON on March 15, 1781, the British army began gathering at the Hoskins farm, and started deploying for battle. As they did so, their artillery, which would have been on the New Garden Road to your north, fired up the road at the Continental Artillery which sat in the middle of the American first line. 
If we were here in 1781, the ground to your east, between the Hoskins farm and the American first line, would have contained several large, open farm fields, about 400 yards in length. The fields would be enclosed by fences like the ones you see at the farm today. Across those fields, we would be able to see the North Carolina Militia, over 1100 strong, waiting for the oncoming British attack. But where is the rest of the American army? The British cannot see it through the woods, and they know they are outnumbered, but they are still determined to launch an attack. While they appreciate the ability of militia to fight like guerilla fighters, they do not respect the American ability to fight in a traditional field battle. They plan to march up, deliver a volley then drive the rebels away with the bayonet. For weeks, they have tried to force the Americans to stop retreating and fight them, hoping for the opportunity to route the American Army from the field like they did at the Battle of Camden. 
But what the British soldiers don’t know is that Greene has deployed his army into 3 defensive lines. The first line that they can see is made up of North Carolina Militia. A second line waits further in the forest. These men are Virginia militia. Beyond them, near the courthouse is General Greene’s third and main line of defense, made up of professional continental soldiers. The plan is that the first two lines will deliberately give way after causing casualties and wreaking havoc to British organization. Greene’s hope was that by the time the British reached the third American line, they would be worn down, disorganized, and vulnerable to a devastating defeat by the Continentals.
By 12:30, the British Army was deployed all around you, facing east. It was time for Cornwallis to launch his infantry attack, and at our next stop, we will witness the beginning of what would be over 2 hours of merciless fighting.

Proceed out the back gate of the Hoskins Farm Site, and turn left, walking up Green Acres lane. Proceed 300 yards until you see the Crown Forces monument on your left, it will be a tall obelisk standing alone in a field. That is your next stop.

stops.significance: The Crown Forces monument commemorates the individuals who served the British cause at this battle, and marks the approximate location that the British advanced to when the North Carolina militia fired on them and began the battle in earnest.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Join the park road by passing the red and white electric gate, then follow the tour road to your left. Continue beyond the visitor center, going to the left, around the building, until you reach the loose gravel path representing the Historic trace of the New Garden road. Follow that path to your next tour stop near the Nathanael Greene Monument. The total distance is 1/4 mile away.
stops.audioTranscript:
You are now at the Crown forces monument. Dedicated in 2016, this monument is meant to commemorate all the men who served the British cause here. Cornwallis, confidently leads into battle several of the finest regiments in the British Army whose colorful names and long histories speak of proud service to king and country. The elite Brigade of Guards, led by Charles O’Hara, stand in reserve behind the main battle line along with troops of Loyalist and British cavalry under Banastre Tarleton;. The 23rd Regiment of Foot (famously known as the Royal Welch Fusiliers); and the 33rd of Foot, advance on the north side of the New Garden Road, under the command of James Webster, and supported by a company of light infantry and a company of German riflemen called jaegers.  Where we are standing is where the 71st Highlanders would have crossed the farm field as they attacked the American first line. Off to our right in the woods, the Hessian Regiment Von Bose represented the British right flank in this initial attack. These units south of the new garden road are commanded by Alexander Leslie.
Supporting these foot and mounted units are six guns of the Royal Artillery, 4 six pounder guns and two smaller 3 pounder guns, sometimes called “Grasshoppers”.

If you look towards the park tour road, that is where the American first line was located. A mere 60 yards from you is how far apart soldiers would typically be in this era before they fired volleys with their smoothbore muskets. A volley is when all of the soldiers fire at the same time. Their weapons were so inaccurate that they fired together to essentially create a devastating wall of bullets flying through the air, hoping that they would actually hit someone on the opposing side.
  These 1,100 North Carolina militiamen were in two brigades divided by New Garden Road.  To north and south of them on their flanks were what would be called “Corps of Observation”--cavalry and infantry supported by riflemen. These Corps on the flanks are under the command of Colonels William Washington to the north and Henry Lee to the south.  In the center, on New Garden Road, were two six-pounder guns of the First Continental Artillery  under Captain Anthony Singleton. Aware of the militia’s limited military ability, Greene urged their two commanders, Generals Thomas Eaton and John Butler, to make a stand, fire two shots, but yield to British bayonets.  Their job wasn’t to try and stop the British. Their job was to weaken them by causing casualties.

As the British arrived at our position, the Americans fired a massive volley into them.
The redcoats returned fire and then charged the militia line with their bayonets.  Many of the militiamen at the center of the line broke and disappeared into the forest after only firing one shot.  A few continue to fire, then feeling their mission finished, rushed to join them.  less than half will be rallied at the courthouse.

In contrast, William Washington’s and Henry Lee’s forces on the far flanks retreat in proper military fashion.  Washington on the north falls back with Webster’s light infantry and German riflemen in rapid pursuit, while Lee’s men gradually moved southeast.  
As this happens, British infantry in the center paused at the fence to reform their tattered ranks and gaze back at their wounded comrades who littered the Hoskins’ farm fields. They then pushed into the woods, seeking out the rest of the American army. 
 
On your way to the American second line, take time to examine the varied monuments. The vast majority of the Monuments at Guilford Courthouse were placed in the park in an era before it was owned by the National Park Service. In the 19th century a group of local businessmen formed the Guilford Battleground Company, and purchased the land for preservation but their ideas of how to use the battlefield were very different from the modern day mission of the National Park Service. The Original Battleground Company wanted the park to be a patriotic pleasure park and added shrubberies and even a man-made lake to the battlefield. They also reinterred several prominent North Carolinians from the Revolution here, some with ties to the battle, others with no direct involvement. 
Another monument that is directly related to the fight here, is the Arthur Forbis monument, visible from where you are, beside the tour road with an interpretive sign beside it. Captain Forbis was a part of the Guilford militia, the militia of this very county. As they waited for the approaching British infantry that morning, his commanding officer saw a British officer mounted on horseback. Forbis carried a rifle that was more accurate than the common musket, and his commander asked Forbis if he could take out the officer. Forbis lined up his shot, fired and killed the officer. In the ensuing battle, Forbis was wounded and left on the battlefield until his family came searching for him and took him home.

stops.significance: This is the center of the American 2nd Line. This is where the 2nd line starts to crumble when the militia advance into trouble. This is also close to where General Cornwallis nearly rides into an ambush during the confused fighting.
stops.assetName: 2nd American Line on the New Garden Road
stops.directionsToNextStop: To get to your next stop, follow the trail to the right of the Greene monument. When the trail forks, continue to the right, until you reach auto tour stop 3. That is your next stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
To orient you to this location, be sure to face west, towards the direction you just came from.
Waiting in the midst of this forest, about 400 yards behind the first line, is Greene’s second line.  Here, 1,200 Virginia militiamen stand divided by the Road into two brigades commanded by Generals Robert Lawson, on the north, and Edward Stevens, on the south. You can imagine these men in an irregular line, extending parallel to the base of the General Greene monument. Greene has placed these men here because he knows the forest, like a vast maze, will confuse and slow down the British infantry and limit the use of their cavalry and artillery.  Although these Virginians are the citizen-soldiers of the militia, both brigades contain many ex-Continental soldiers and officers, veterans who will lead and help provide a steady example for their comrades.  

The light infantry and Jägers of Webster’s brigade far to our north, are moving in pursuit of Washington’s infantry, cavalry and riflemen, and reach the right flank of the Virginia line .Off to your right, General Lawson pushes some of his men forward, towards the modern day parking lot off to your right, trying to exploit the flank of Webster’s brigade, but in doing so, they expose their left flank to the approaching redcoats of the 23rd regiment and Guards Brigade, who would be directly approaching your current location.  Surprised by the sudden presence of more British troops, these militiamen flee with only a portion being halted and reformed by their officers.  The firefight in the woods here breaks into small unit actions as Webster’s redcoats push back Lawson’s Virginians and Washington’s infantry and riflemen to the north. At one point in the smoke and confusion, General Cornwallis, who has already had one horse shot out from under him, nearly rides into an ambush before a Sergeant of the Welch Fusiliers redirects him to safety.
As this end of the second line disintegrates, the south end of the line fights on for over 30 minutes. At our next stop, we will talk about the events on that end of the line.


Be sure to check out the Nathanael Greene monument on your way to your next stop. Built in 1915, and designed by Francis Herman Packer, this 8,000 pound, cast bronze monument is dedicated to the American Commander at this battle, who is also the namesake of the City of Greensboro.
To get to your next stop, follow the trail to the right of the Greene monument. When the trail forks, continue to the right, until you reach auto tour stop 3. That is your next stop.

stops.significance: The south end of the American 2nd Line is where Edward Stevens' Virginia militia resist the longest, and only retreat when Stevens is wounded.
stops.assetName: South End of the American 2nd Line
stops.directionsToNextStop: When you are ready, follow the road 200 yards to the left to Auto tour stop 4, the site of the Joseph Winston Monument.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the woods south of the road,  Stevens’ 600 Virginians contest the advance of General Leslie’s 71stHighlanders, the First Guards, and the Von Bose Regiment.  As a precaution, and to encourage their resistance, Stevens has placed picked men in low ground behind the line to shoot down any man who runs. Stevens has done this in part because he has suffered devastating defeat before. At the battle of Camden, it was his men who fled at the first shots and triggered the route of the American army. Stevens was determined to never let such a tragedy happen again.

Emboldened, Stevens’ men retreat stubbornly.  After over 30 minutes of resistance, Stevens receives a severe wound in the thigh and it is only when that happens that the Virginia general finally gives the order to retreat.

Something that General Cornwallis does not realize is that with the collapse of the American second line, his ability to destroy the American army is actually getting weaker. The southern end of the British line has broken off in pursuit of remnants of the Virginia Militia and riflemen. As they drift away, they are not able to contribute to the main British attack along the New Garden road.

 That separate fight starts to form in what is now Forest Lawn Cemetery off to the south, on your left. As the British pushed through the woods, a section of Virginia militia had moved off to attack what it thought was an isolated British unit, the 1st battalion of guards. They pushed them south, up a rise, before the British regrouped and pushed the militia back to their starting position near where we currently stand. By the time this happens, the hessian Regiment Von Bose appears. They had been delayed due to the chaos of hand to hand fighting with the North Carolinians at the first line. But when they appear, the Virginians mistake them for allies. The Hessians are wearing Blue coats that appear very similar to the uniforms of the professional American soldiers, called Continentals. It is not until the Hessians unleash a point-blank blast of musket fire that the Virginians realize their error. But as the Virginians retreat to the southwest, The Hessians and Guards continue to pursue them, drifting farther and farther away from the main body of the British army, and deeper and deeper into woods now inhabited by militiamen, riflemen, and the troops of Light Horse Harry Lee’s Legion.
And at our next stop, we will reveal how this separate comes to a surprising finish.


When you are ready, follow the road left to Auto tour stop 4, the site of the Joseph Winston Monument.

stops.significance: The separate fight saw 1/4 of the British army engaged in confused fighting in the woods. This prevents them from helping the main attack on the American third line near the site of the courthouse.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the Park’s tour road down the steep slope and passing by tour stop 5. At the Bottom of the hill, turn left onto the gravel path, then immediately turn right onto the narrow walking trail. Stay on this trail, go right at the fork, until you reach a small bridge over the creek.
stops.audioTranscript:
Walk to the interpretive sign close to the Joseph Winston Monument, when you are facing it, you are now facing south, in the direction of the separate fight. 

The First Guards and Von Bose Regiment pursued Light Horse Harry Lee, moving toward the southeast as Lee fell back from the first American line with his cavalry and infantry. Lee was supported by riflemen from the mountains of Virginia under Colonel William Campbell and from western North Carolina under Major Joseph Winston. Unlike the smoothbore musket carried by the majority of soldiers on both sides of this battle, the rifle is accurate to distances of 2-300 yards. This is due to the rifle grooves on the inside of the barrel, that grip and spin the musket ball as it exits the weapon, giving it a reliable and predictable flight path. One thing we need to keep in mind about this weapon though, is that it takes a lot longer to reload than a musket. A trained soldier with a smoothbore could fire 3-4 shots per minute. That’s a shot every 15-20 seconds. For a rifleman, it took 45 second to a full minute to load and fire one shot. And most riflemen couldn’t put a bayonet on the end of their weapon like a musket. All the more reason for them to try and keep their distance from their enemies and rely on the accuracy of their weapons. 

The separate fight, instigated by Lee’s withdrawal to the southeast, consumed much of the strength of the Von Bose Hessians and the First Guards. This extended back and forth battle raged across the area that is now the modern day Forest Lawn Cemetery and spilled into what is Greensboro Country Park directly to your south.  
As the Hessians and Guards push into the woods, they slowly get surrounded. The riflemen use the trees and the steep terrain to hide and reload before closing in and shooting at the disoriented professional troops. 

The tide turned when Lee left the area. When the main battle was raging at the American third line near the courthouse, Lee departed to investigate what was happening. The asbsence of Lee’s infantry and cavalry left the riflemen and a few Virginia Militia to keep the battered Redcoats in check. But without the cavalry, they were left dangerously vulnerable just as Tarleton’s British Legion unexpectedly arrived to support the Guards. The First Guards and Von Bose Regiment could now reform, and they fired a deadly volley into the American line. Immediately, Tarleton’s cavalry charged ferociously into the Americans who now had no defense. During the final moments of the battle, the militia fled into the woods. Tarleton’s troopers saved the British and Hessian troops from annihilation.

The Monument you see here is topped with a statue of Major Joseph Winston and is dedicated to him and two officers under his command, Captain Jesse Franklin, and Lieutenant Richard Taliaferro. These men were engaged in the separate fight here, but Lt. Taliaferro didn’t survive. As Tarleton’s final charge crashed home, the militia fled to their horses, but Taliaferro was shot and killed as he went to mount his horse. 


Winston would go on to survive the war and serve in the state legislature and congress. In 1849, when Forsyth county was created, the county seat was named after him. Over time it slowly grew and meshed with another village, forming the modern-day city of Winston-Salem.
Franklin served in the United States Senate and was briefly Governor of North Carolina in the 19th century. Both men were not initially buried here, and had their bodies moved here by the Guilford Battleground Company in the 1890s. Underneath the tree to your right, you can also see the burial site of Winston and Franklin.  Taliaferro is believed to have been buried on the battlefield, but the site of his hasty burial is unknown.


Follow the Park’s tour road down the steep slope and passing by tour stop 5. At the Bottom of the hill, turn left onto the gravel path, then immediately turn right onto the walking trail. Stay on this trail until you see the sign for the next tour stop, near a small bridge over the creek.

stops.significance: You are standing in the low ground that the British infantry had to cross to attack the third line. At the time of the battle, this entire area would have been cleared farm field.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the foot trail up the other side of the vale. 100 yards away you will see two 6 pounder cannons parked by the trail. They are your next tour stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
Several hundred yards behind the Virginians, within sight of the courthouse building, is Greene’s third and final line of defense. Arrayed along the high ground in front of you are Two brigades Greene’s best troops. At the time of the battle the area you now stand in would have been cleared fields just like the Hoskins farm, and a strip of land south of the new garden road would have been clear as well. 

  The brigade on the left end of the American third line, directly to your front, consists of two regiments of Continentals from Maryland and Delaware under Colonel Otho H. Williams; the regiments on the right side, off to your left, are two regiments of Virginia 18-month Troops under General Isaac Huger. Between these two brigades are two six-pounder guns under Lieutenant Ebenezer Finley. At the left end of the line, with the 2nd Maryland, are the two six pounder guns of Anthony singleton.


To our north, your left, the first British troops appear and attempt an attack on the American third line.
Lt. Col. James Webster is Cornwallis’s most aggressive commander.  His light infantry and Jägers hound William Washington’s troops through the forest from ravine to ravine.  Finally, Washington’s men exit from the forest and cross the wooded ravine to our north and quickly reform on the far northern end of the third line, which is beyond the modern park boundary.
As the battle begins approaching his last line, General Greene grows cautious.  To protect his main retreat route he dispatches Colonel John Green’s Virginia regiment across the road toward the Reedy Fork Creek crossing, two miles north.  Sensing an attack by Webster’s redcoats, Greene orders Colonel John Gunby’s First Maryland, a regiment of seasoned veterans, to swing right and fire into the lone British unit as it appears. 
Instead of facing you, their line would swing like a gate, and would now be facing to your left.

As soon as the 33rd regiment of foot arrives, they sweep down the steep slope just to the north of the modern tour road.   The First Maryland Regiment are now in a position to rake their right flank with fire, and with Washington and Hawes attacking them in front, they pour in deadly volleys of musket fire.  One ball strikes General Webster, seriously wounding him in the knee.  In pain, the British commander orders a withdrawal and the 33rd regiment retreats back up the slope until more British troops can arrive.

Coming out of the forest on the new Garden Road to your right, the Second Guards enter the open ground at the third line, we are standing close to where their left flank would pass.  With them rides Cornwallis followed by two three-pounder guns of the Royal Artillery.

Opposing them on the south end of the third line is Colonel Benjamin Ford’s Second Maryland, a new regiment whose men are entering battle for the first time. These men swing their left flank forward as they try to push into the field to cover the rear of the First Maryland and oppose the approaching Second Guards.  As the Guards approach, the Second Maryland hesitate and adjust their line.  Suddenly, the Guards surge forward, catching Ford’s men off balance.  The Marylanders fire an ineffectual volley and, much to the disgust of their officers, break, and dissolve into the woods behind.  The Guards, now unopposed, eagerly take advantage of the situation to move upon the rest of Greene’s last line. 
But thanks to the quick thinking and initiative of a few commanders close buy, the battle is not yet lost for Greene’s army.


Continue along the foot trail up the other side of the vale. You will see two 6 pounder cannons parked by the trail. They are your next tour stop.

stops.significance: This is where the battle of Guilford Courthouse reached its crescendo. The 2nd Guards Battalion swept through this area trying to roll up the American third line, but was met with fierce counterattacks by the American infantry and cavalry.
stops.assetName: American Six Pounders on the Third Line
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed up the trail and get back on the Historic New Garden Trail. Turn left and stop when you reach the wayside sign that features an artists rendering of the Guilford courthouse. That is your last stop.
stops.audioTranscript:
Taking advantage of the breaking Second Maryland, the Second Guards captured Singleton’s two cannons, represented by the reproduction guns just a few yards down the walking trail from you. The guards swung north hoping to roll up the American third line but Greene reacted immediately, ordering Colonel Gunby to turn his Marylanders around and stop the Guards.  As they faced about, William Washington’s horsemen, thundering south down the Reedy Fork Road with sabers drawn, charged into the Guards.  Now turned, the First Maryland fired on the Guards at point blank range. With Lieutenant Colonel John Eager Howard leading them, the Marylanders charged forward, trapping the Guards between the bayonet and the saber in a vicious hand-to-hand contest. All around you, these soldiers were gripped in vicious fighting.

On a slight rise on the west side of the field, where the modern-day tour road meets the historic New Garden Road, Cornwallis and Guards commander General O’Hara, witnessed the Guards caught in this two-sided attack. As Washington’s horsemen completely plowed through the redcoat ranks, they turned to strike again.  At this moment, Cornwallis made a snap decision—he ordered the Royal Artillery’s three-pounder guns, loaded with “grapeshot”, to fire on the American cavalry before they either charged back into the Guards or turned to capture him and the guns.  Clusters of iron projectiles shot through the air and cut down men and horses, Marylanders, and even some of the Guards Battalion!  Washington’s horsemen gallop off under this destructive fire.  Cornwallis’ terrible gamble saved the Guards.

As more redcoats emerged from the woods to the south and west, Howard ordered the First Maryland to withdraw and join the rest of the army moving north on the Reedy Fork Road. The American army was now in full retreat to its camps at Troublesome Creek, 12 miles away.


Proceed up the trail and get back on the Historic New Garden Trail. Turn left and stop when you reach the wayside sign that features an artists rendering of the Guilford courthouse. This is your last stop.

stops.significance: The former site of the historic courthouse was close to this spot. Post war, a small village called Martinville grew in this area until the courthouse was moved to the newly founded city of Greensboro in 1808.
stops.assetName: Former site of the Guilford Courthouse
stops.directionsToNextStop:
The quickest way back to the visitor center is to follow the Historic New Garden Trail. It is 1 mile back to the Visitor Center and 1.5 miles back to the Hoskins Farm.

Thank you for visiting! And enjoy the rest of your day.
stops.audioTranscript:
Greene’s army was in full retreat. Cornwallis sent the 23rd and 71st regiments in pursuit of the American army, capturing the last of Greene’s artillery and all its ammunition. Two miles north they encountered a line of Continentals drawn up in defense of a ford.  After marching and fighting since early morning, these exhausted British regiments were stopped by one powerful volley and decided to return to the battlefield. Greene’s retreating army continued north toward its camp.  The Battle was over in this area, but it did not truly end until that separate fight that we covered at tour stop 5 was finally resolved by the charge of Tarleton’s Cavalry.

 Fighting to destroy their enemy, Cornwallis’s army suffered 27% casualties, losses they could ill afford so far from re-supply and reinforcement.  In contrast, Greene’s defeated army suffered far less, and in a few days it began to recover its strength. In the immediate aftermath of the battle, houses and buildings within a few miles of the courthouse became shelters for the wounded and dying. Both armies provided doctors to help treat the men. They are aided by camp followers, the women that were employed by the army and helped to nurse the soldiers, and they are also aided by the local Quakers. Despite being pacifists, the Quakers felt that it was their duty to help treat the men and try to ease their suffering.

On March 17, Cornwallis marched his battered army out of Guilford Courthouse and  Greene pursued.  After Cornwallis turned southeast toward British-held Wilmington on the coast of North Carolina, the American general chose to head back to South Carolina and begin a campaign against the British and loyalist garrisons that lasted until 1782.  At Wilmington, Cornwallis decided to abandon the Carolinas, move his tired troops into Virginia, and join British forces already there. Tired of trying to win Hearts and Minds, Cornwallis returned to destructive offensive operations in Virginia. His hope was that he could cut off men and supplies from reaching General Greene, forcing the American commander to abandon the Carolinas.

Ultimately the overall British commander, Sir Henry Clinton, ordered Cornwallis to secure a naval base on the Chesapeake where he could be reinforced and resupplied. Their hope was for a new campaign in Virginia in 1782.
 But to their shock, at Yorktown in October, Cornwallis surrendered to the combined French and American armies under General George Washington and General Rochambeau. These armies had managed to sneak away from the British in New York and catch Cornwallis by surprise, while the French navy trapped him by sea. 

It is the surrender at Yorktown that finally breaks British spirits. No longer able to muster the political will to fight, Parliament had to pursue peace and recognition of American Independence.


Guilford Courthouse was one of the many battles that made this possible. Along with the battles of Kings Mountain and Cowpens, they prevented British pacification of North Carolina, and frustrated Cornwallis so badly that he made the rash decision of moving into an isolated position in Virginia. 

The war formally ended in 1783, but it would take the people of the former colonies many more years to recover from the death and destruction of their war for Independence. 
For the enslaved, most saw no change in their status in this society, while many others escaped to freedom with the British when they evacuated. 
For the native peoples of the western frontier, it was the beginning of unrelenting invasion and war as their American neighbors sought more and more land. 
For thousands of loyalists, the result was being forced to flee the only homeland they had ever known. For others, they managed to stay in America and find some level of normalcy within their new circumstances.
For most who supported the rebellion, this was the birth of a new era of liberty. Life under a government of their own design.

We hope you have enjoyed your tour of the battlefield. Please be sure to stop by the Visitors Center to see artifacts recovered from the battlefield and be sure to check out our park website for more information. 
The quickest way back to the visitor center is to follow the Historic New Garden Trail. 

Thank you for visiting! And enjoy the rest of your day.

images.title: Kids walking to monument
images.altText: Five African American children walk on a path to a monument at the end of the trail.
images.caption: Explore the battlefield on foot

data.title: Walking Tour: The Mountain View Nature Trail
data.description: The Mountain View Nature Trail is a ¼ mile long path around the Lehman Caves Visitor Center. Along this hike, you will see how humans, native plants, animals, rocks, and soils are all parts of a large, diverse environment. Look for numbered posts along the path which match the stops found in this digital tour. The path is not accessible to wheelchairs. The trail is at 7000ft elevation, so the air is thin. Please take extra care. Lastly, stay on the trail so those who come after may also enjoy the scenery.

stops.significance: A historic cabin, one of the first permanent structures constructed in the Lehman Caves area.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the rear of the cabin, begin the trail. Lehman's irrigation remnants will be on the downhill side.

stops.significance: A source of water in a parched landscape.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the trail, up a pair of mellow switchbacks. A bench awaits those needing a rest.

stops.significance: A look at the wondrous flora filling the Pinyon/Juniper life zone.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail south, keeping an eye on the rocks that jut out of the earth.

stops.significance: A deeper look into the origins of the rock beneath your feet.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue a short way down the trail. Views of the valley will be extensive.

stops.significance: A greater look at the Great Basin!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Keep following the trail, pondering the enormity of the caves currently below your feet.

stops.significance: Limestone and Marble that connect to Lehman Caves.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail until standing at the railings and metal structure covering the cave's natural entrance.

stops.significance: The only human-sized entrance to Lehman Caves. Slightly visible at the beginning of a cave tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail to the paved path down from the cave exit. Either walk through the Visitor Center or follow the driveway down the side to the front. Walk down the sidewalks to the Lehman Orchard.

stops.significance: Lehman's historic orchard and the newly added educational wayside.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Meander through the orchard or down to the right to the wooden viewing platform and bench.

stops.significance: The end of the tour and a guide to make your own pies!

images.title: Mountain View Nature Trail
images.altText: A green, snow topped sign reads "Mountain View Nature Trail" with a white arrow pointing right.
images.caption: One potential start of the Mountain View Nature Trail

data.title: Walking/Driving Tour of Saddlehorn Historic District
data.description: This self-guided tour introduces you to some Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) (1933-1942) and Mission 66 (1956-1966) projects at Colorado National Monument. You may visit 9 locations. The CCC and Mission 66 locations will intertwine as you read about each stop. This can also be done by car. You do not have to visit the park to do this tour.

stops.significance: This is the beginning point for the historic walking/driving tour.
stops.assetName: Historic Tour Starting Point Saddlehorn Visitor Center
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Walking Directions - Standing outside the front doors of the visitor center, facing the parking lot turn to the right and follow the covered sidewalk along the building. At the end of the building continue straight along the asphalt path. You will pass a large sandstone block garage. Continue to the front of the house built of the same stones. 
Driving Directions - In your vehicle leave the visitor center parking lot from the north-east corner. Turn right onto Rim Rock Drive. Make an immediate right turn onto the Saddlehorn Loop road. Stop in front of the large sandstone block house on your right.

stops.significance: This is the second stop on the tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: While facing the Caretaker's House turn left and walk or drive out of the circular drive. At the intersection follow the signs for the Saddlehorn Campground. Walk (or drive) until you come to the kiosk which has information about the campground.

stops.significance: This is the third stop along the historic walking/driving tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue about a 1/4 mile along the Saddlehorn Loop Road. Pass the three entrances to the C-Loop of the campground. On your right will be a small parking area. To the right, beyond the parking area, take the path to the two sandstone brick buildings.

stops.significance: This is the fourth stop along the historic walking tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Saddlehorn Loop Road. Continue in the previous direction of travel. On the left will be the Bookcliff View Shelter.

stops.significance: This is the fifth stop along the historic walking tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Stay here and choose the Canyon Rim Trail selection to learn about Canyon Rim trail. Once you have done this you may continue along the Saddlehorn Loop Road. You will pass the exit for Loop C of the campground. After a short uphill section you will see the entrance to the Saddlenhorn picnic area on your right.

stops.significance: This is the 6th stop along the historic walking tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The historic walking/driving tour continues along Saddlehorn Loop Road. However, you may also walk along the Canyon Rim trail as it exits the shelter to the right. This 1/2 mile trail will take you back to the Visitor Center. To continue on the tour return to the Saddlehorn Loop Road and continue in the direction you were traveling. You will pass the exit of the campground on your right. After going up a small hill you will see the entrance to the picnic area on your right.

stops.significance: This is the 7th stop on the historic walking tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Saddlehorn Loop Road. Turn right and walk/drive until the Saddlehorn Rock Formation is close to the road. Face in the opposite direction of the rock formation.

stops.significance: The 8th stop along the historic walking/driving historic tour.
stops.assetName: Location of Civilian Conservation Camp NM-2
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Saddlehorn Loop Road. Go past the Caretakers House to the intersection of Rim Rock Drive.

stops.significance: Last Stop on the historic walking/driving tour. From this point a left turn on Rim Rock Drive and a left in the parking lot will return you to the visitor center.

data.title: Washita Battlefield Walking Tour
data.description: Take a walk to learn about the attack through 15 stops along the park's 1.5 mile loop trail.

stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the trail east from the overlook as it winds north through the gate. Stay straight on the paved trail to do the loop in a clockwise direction until you reach post one.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post two.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post three.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post four.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post five.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction, staying to the left at the fork at the bottom of the hill until you reach post six.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post seven.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post eight.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction as the trail changes to a dirt and grass trail until you reach post nine.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post ten.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post eleven.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction, staying left as you return to paved trail until you reach post twelve.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction as the trail switches to dirt and grass, climbing some steps up the hill until you reach post thirteen.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post fourteen.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction until you reach post fifteen.
Continue on the trail in a clockwise direction. Take a left upon reaching the paved trail to return to the overlook.

data.title: Waterfall Tour
data.description: Michigan's Upper Peninsula is famous for its many waterfalls - and the Pictured Rocks area has some of the most beautiful! This tour covers the easiest waterfalls within and nearby the park to access by vehicle. Walks to these waterfalls range in distance from just outside the parking area to 1.2 miles round trip. Driving from one end of the park to the other and back takes about 2.5 hours. Add another 1 - 2 hours to walk to and enjoy all six waterfalls.

stops.significance: Wagner Falls is a lovely waterfall that is particularly popular with local artists and photographers. It is also one of the few waterfalls easy to access by vehicle in winter.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Wagner Falls, follow M-94 east towards Munising. At the intersection of M-94 and M-28, Alger Falls is directly ahead. Carefully cross the highway and park on the shoulder.

stops.significance: Alger Falls is the only waterfall on the tour that requires no walking. It can easily be viewed from the shoulder of M-28. Watch for traffic as you exit your vehicle to view this waterfall.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Alger Falls, followed M-28 north into Munising. At the traffic circle, turn right onto E. Munising Ave (Alger County Road H-58). About a mile down, watch for signs for Munising Falls and Sand Point, and turn left onto Washington Street.  About a mile down Washington Street, you will see signs and the parking lot for Munising Falls Visitor Center on your right, across from the hospital. Park in the lot and then walk 800 yards to the falls.

stops.significance: Munising Falls is the most visited of the Pictured Rocks waterfalls. It is beautiful in all seasons, and particularly stunning in winter.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Munising Falls parking lot, turn left onto Washington Street and drive almost a mile back to the intersection of Alger County Road H-58. Turn left and follow H-58 for 4 miles to Miners Castle Road (H-11). Turn left on Miners Castle Road and drive for 4 miles to the turnoff for Miners Falls. Drive 1/2 mile on the unpaved road to the parking lot. From the parking lot, the walk to the falls is 0.6 miles one way. (Note: Vehicles longer than 32 feet are prohibited at the small Miners Falls parking lot)

stops.significance: Miners Falls is the most powerful of the Pictured Rocks waterfalls. The fairly level forested walk is the longest on the tour; 1.2 miles round trip.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the parking lot, return to Miners Castle Road. Turn right and go the next intersection, and turn right towards Miners Beach. Follow the Miners Beach Road to the T-intersection at the end. Turn right and go to the small parking lot at the end of the road. Walk the short trail through the woods to the beach. Once on the beach, you will see small Elliot Falls a couple of hundred yards to the right, where the beach meets the cliffs.

stops.significance: Elliot Falls is the only waterfall on the tour flowing directly into Lake Superior. The stunning scenery of the lake, rugged shoreline, and forested cliffs makes this picturesque waterfall very popular with visitors.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the parking lot, follow the Miners Beach Road back to Miners Castle Road, turn left, and follow back the way you came to where the road intersects Alger County Road H-58. Turn left and follow H-58 east about 40 miles to the Sable Falls parking lot, near the eastern end of the park outside of Grand Marais.

stops.significance: Sable Falls, the last waterfall on the tour, cascades 75 feet over a series of sandstone ledges. The rocks exposed at the lower portion of the waterfall are estimated to be about 1 billion years old.

images.title: Miners Falls
images.altText: Miners Falls flowing over a forested cliff
images.caption: Miners Falls is the park's most powerful waterfall.

data.title: Wayside Description
data.description: Audio description of the wayside at Wright Brothers National Memorial

stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to the right and follow the sidewalk about 75 feet. The next wayside will be on the left.
Turn to the right and continue along the sidewalk. The next wayside will be on the right after about 70 feet.
Turn left and continue along the sidewalk another 200 feet. The sidewalk comes to a corner, turn right and walk another 25 feet. The next wayside will be in between the buildings on the right.
Turn to your left and walk about 30 feet diagonally, watching out for the awning supports of the building in front of you. The next wayside will be to the left.
Turn and walk diagonally towards the right. The next wayside is on the opposite side of the sidewalk about 25 feet.
Turn left and walk about 70 feet along the sidewalk. You should be in front of the first flight boulder. Turn left and walk another 40 feet along the sidewalk, the next wayside will be on the right.
Continue left and follow the sidewalk about 0.25 miles. The next wayside will be at the end of the sidewalk on the right, just before the road and crosswalk.

Continue straight ahead from the wayside along the sidewalk, you will be crossing the Loop Road in the crosswalk in about 50 feet. Once you cross the road, continue straight for another 180 feet. At the intersection, turn right and follow the sidewalk for another 880 feet. The sidewalk will curve towards the left a little as you walk and the wayside will be on the left, facing towards the monument.

Turn around and walk a few steps to the left, follow the sidewalk to the right about 20 feet, you will reach a crosswalk. Cross the road, you will come to the grass on the other side. Turn left and walk along the grass for 30 feet, you will come to a road/driveway. Turn right. Walk straight along the pavement about 188 feet and turn left, walk another 25 feet to cross the pavement and you will be facing the next wayside.

From here, turn around and cross the pavement again and follow the drive back to the main loop road, 188 feet. Turn left and walk 30 feet along the grass to return to the cross walk. Once you cross the road, follow the sidewalk, turn right and follow the sidewalk for 0.25 miles. The next wayside will be on the left. A small parking lot will be just off the sidewalk to the right.
To reach the next wayside safely, you can either turn left or right and walk 150 feet to the cross walk. Once there, cross the road. Follow the sidewalk 150 feet.
Turn right, walk about 10 feet and turn left. Walk another 10 feet and the next wayside will be on your left.

stops.assetName: 13 - If you decide to try your machine here…you will find a hospitable people…
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn right, walk about 10 feet. Then turn left and walk another 10 feet, the wayside will be on your left.

stops.assetName: 14 - In commemoration of the conquest of the air…
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Turn left. follow the sidewalk about 90 feet. You will arrive at a fork. Follow the sidewalk to the right. Walk another 200 feet along the path, it will curve slightly to the right and left as you continue to walk, ending with a curve to the left. The wayside will be on the left. 

Continue along the sidewalk to the right to return back to the fork and follow that path back to the main road. From here, you can turn right or left, walk 150 feet and cross safely back to the main path around Big Kill Devil hill.

data.title: West Thumb Geyser Basin
data.description: Explore this fascinating thermal area on the edge of Yellowstone Lake.

stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to West Thumb Geyser Basin, a caldera within a caldera, formed by a volcanic eruption approximately 174,000 years ago. The resulting caldera filled with water, forming an extension of Yellowstone Lake. The lake resembles the shape of a human hand, and West Thumb is the large western bay that would be the thumb. 

The waters of Yellowstone Lake are the lifeblood for a large network of plant and animal communities. As you walk the geyser basin and enjoy views of the lake, you might see trumpeter swans, pelicans, eagles, and other wildlife. 

Please note: Thermal activity occurs throughout this area. Stay on the boardwalk at all times. 

Because of the dynamic nature of the features along this tour, you may complete the tour in as little as a half-hour or be out for an hour or more. Before heading out, a few safety notes: 

It can be windy, so cinch down your hats and secure personal items. 

Stay on the boardwalks and established trails at all times. Superheated water is just below a thin crust throughout the basin. Besides the high chance of breaking through the crust and causing bodily injury or death, leaving the trail can damage hydrothermal features—ruining the experience for everyone. 

Boardwalks can be slippery when wet or covered in snow. 

Watch for wildlife and maintain the minimum safe distance of 25 yards (2 bus-lengths) from any wildlife—and 100 yards (8 bus-lengths) from bears or wolves. 

The trail is .5 mile (.8 km) around the outer boardwalk loop, and .25 mi (.4 km) around the inner loop. This tour follows the outer loop first and the inner boardwalk second.  
 
Ready? Head on to the next stop: Thumb Paint Pots.

The Hayden Expedition of 1871 originally named these fanciful features the “Mud Puffs.” Picture a field of miniature mud volcanoes 3–4 feet (1 m) high with steam curling from delicate mud chimneys in various shades of red. Surrounding the cones, the mud appears to be stirred and mixed to a smooth, satiny consistency by some unseen hand.  
 
Mudpots differ from other thermal features; their water is much more acidic and dissolves the surrounding rock into clay. Also, mudpots vary with precipitation and groundwater levels. Sometimes they look like muddy water; other times they look as if you could build pottery with their mud. What do these unique thermal features conjure in your imagination?

Seismograph and Bluebell pools used to be known as the “Blue Pools.” After the intense Hebgen Lake Earthquake of 1959, which measured 7.5 on the Richter scale, the pools were renamed. No one knows why, but perhaps someone thought Seismograph Pool somehow “registered” the earthquake. (A seismograph measures the intensity and duration of earthquakes.) These days, Seismograph is sometimes muddy—but not from earthquakes. Can you guess where the mud comes from? Hint: notice the runoff of nearby thermal features.

Lakeshore’s two vents are underwater in the spring and early summer. Once exposed, the geyser may splash a couple of feet high. Accounts from the 1920s and 1930s tell of Lakeshore Geyser erupting frequently to 25 feet (7.6 m). Since then, it has been mostly inactive—eruptions haven’t been seen since 2003, and those were small. Don’t rule out future activity, though. One day, earthquake activity or other processes may cause the geyser to gain energy and begin erupting more forcefully again.

Mountain men told of a geyser along an alpine lake where one could catch a trout, swing the pole around, dip it into the boiling pool, and cook the fish without taking it off the line. 

This cooking-on-the-hook feat at Fishing Cone became famous after being described by the 1870 Washburn Expedition. Visitors often dressed in a cook’s hat and apron to have their pictures taken at the “Chowder Pot” or the “Fish Pot.” Anglers often injured themselves while straddling the boiling water, and their feet damaged the geyser cone. Fishing is no longer allowed from Fishing Cone. 

Visitors are sometimes surprised to find Fishing Cone underwater during the spring and early summer, when lake levels rise from melting snow and cover the vent. When exposed, the temperature of the cone’s water averages just above boiling (199°F /93°C).

The colors you see in the pools of West Thumb are created, in part, by thermophiles (heat-loving microorganisms). Generally, green and brown indicate organisms living in cooler water, and orange and yellow indicate those living in hotter water. Only a few microorganisms thrive in the springs where the temperature is close to boiling. This,  so we see the clear, blue water.. In these hot springs, the water absorbs all wavelengths of light except blue, which the pool reflects. 

At one time, Black Pool really was black. Lower water temperature allowed thick mats of dark green and brown thermophiles to grow in the pool, causing it to appear black. But in the summer of 1991, the water temperature rose, killing the organisms. Black Pool is now a quiet and beautiful pool.

One of the deeper hot springs in the park, Abyss Pool descends to 53 feet (16 m). Here you can see a range of colors from turquoise blue to emerald green to various shades of brown.  

Abyss Pool erupted for the first time in recent history in August 1987. It remained quiet again until September 1991, when it erupted frequently in spectacular, but quick, 100 feet (30 m) bursts. The next active period lasted from December 1991 through June 1992, when it erupted several times per day. Each eruption was a series of explosive bursts, sending water 30–80 feet (9–24 m) high and a plume of steam above the treetops. The pool’s entire body of water appeared to turn end-over-end in a turbulent boil. Since that time, Abyss has been a quiet, notable feature at West Thumb.

Twin Geysers—technically one geyser with two vents—has short periods of dramatic eruptions and extended periods of dormancy. Its last known eruption was in 1999. Visitors lucky enough to witness an eruption see a two-part event, with both vents erupting as high as 75 feet (23 m). 

Next, let’s explore the pools and springs of the Central Basin.

“Dynamic” describes any geyser basin, but particularly the central area at West Thumb where features frequently change.  

Blue Funnel Spring was long known for the distinctive blue color around its perimeter. But when Abyss Pool began erupting in 1991, the water in Blue Funnel and in adjacent Perforated Pool and Ephedra Spring cooled and sank below the rim. The next year, all four springs were quiet, full pools. In early 2010, however, Blue Funnel, Ephedra, and Perforated pools drained. Percolating Spring erupts infrequently—most recently in 2005.

Named for their appearances, Ledge Spring and Collapsing Pool have both erupted: Ledge in 2004 and 2005, Collapsing Pool in 2001. In early 2010, both overflowed and receded several times, and Ledge roiled several feet.

Surging Spring is true to its name—when it is active. It domes and overflows, sending waves of water surging into the lake. Quiet since 2002, it began overflowing in early 2010. 

We hope you enjoyed West Thumb’s lakeshore views and thermal features and found many reasons to preserve and protect the resources of this planet—from the thermal features of Yellowstone to the nature near your home.
