data.title: What About Those Other Houses?
data.description: What are those other houses at Herbert Hoover National Historic Site? Several were part of President Hoover's early childhood neighborhood. Others were built after he moved away from West Branch. Their architectural styles recall the late late 1800s and round out the neighborhood setting of the President's upbringing.

stops.significance: West Branch boomed between 1869 and 1873. New buildings constructed in the neighborhood near the Hoovers' small cottage on Downey Street included the Laban Miles House, the Garvin House, and the Methodist Church, which is no longer standing. When the Burlington, Cedar Rapids & Northern Railroad arrived in West Branch on December 20, 1870, two hundred of the town's residents celebrated with a picnic dinner.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the exhibit panel facing the birthplace, walk 60 feet down the plank walkway to the right. Stop at the gate in front of the grey and brown house with the rail fence.
stops.audioTranscript:
It may be hard to imagine, but the road you’re looking at now, was once a very important thoroughfare. Downey Street was the entrance into West Branch from the south. If you look up and down the road, you can still find scattered hitching posts in front of several of the homes. 
(music) In 1870, the U.S. census counted Iowa’s population at almost 1.2 million. The towns and farms that now covered the state had, within a single generation, replaced the traditional American Indian uses of the land. Herbert Hoover’s grandfather, Eli Hoover, was one of the first few settlers of West Branch, arriving by covered wagon in 1854. When the census takers came sixteen years later, the town’s population stood at about 200.  But the railroad’s arrival in West Branch that same year helped the town’s rapid expansion into a thriving agricultural and business centered community.  
During Herbert Hoover’s childhood, the intersection of Downey and Main was the town crossroads. Although several of the streets that existed historically have been moved or no longer exist, you can still see the road trace of the original Downey Street as it runs past the little Birthplace Cottage. Because it wasn’t far, the Hoover family walked down this street into town to do their shopping.
(sound effects: birds chirping) Did you notice how most of the homes along this street have either four-board or picket fencing in their front yards? For modern-day homeowners, what looks like a decorative choice was actually one of necessity for the folks living on Downey Street. When “Bertie” Hoover was a boy, he probably saw local farmers drive their livestock to market down the middle of this wide street - right past his front door.(sound effects: horse and buggy, cows, pigs) But if it weren’t for those fences, a stray pig or cow might have actually wound up eating the vegetables in his mother’s garden or stepping on the tulips in their front yard!
In the 1870’s, the streets of West Branch were either “dusty thoroughfares or muddy bogs.” (sound effects: rain, horse and buggy) When it rained Downey Street would turn sticky with mud and lots of wagon wheel ruts. It wasn’t unusual to see a team of oxen or even a horse and buggy get stuck. At the time of Hoover’s birth in 1874, West Branch didn’t have sidewalks. However, by 1885 the city had finished over three and a half miles of wood plank walkways. The sidewalks here today are representations of those late 19th century boardwalks; they may be slippery when wet, so please watch your step.

stops.significance: Hannah Varney built this house in 1899 shortly after divorcing her husband. The West Branch Times described the house as being of "fine appearance and finished in modern style."
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue in the same direction along the plank walkway about 65 feet to the gate in the picket fence of the white and blue house.

stops.significance: For thirty-six years Dr. L.J. Leech, a Civil War veteran and graduate of Iowa State University, had lived in the Laban Miles House next door; renting it at first in 1884, and then buying it two years later when the bank foreclosed on the home. By 1920, the well-liked country doctor and Iowa legislator decided to have a new home built for himself.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Keep walking on the plank walkway along the picket fence. Stop at the gate in front of the yellow house.
stops.audioTranscript:
For thirty-six years Dr. L.J. Leech, a Civil War veteran and graduate of Iowa State University, had lived in the Laban Miles House; renting it at first in 1884, and then purchasing it two years later when the bank foreclosed on the home. By 1920, the well-liked country doctor and Iowa legislator decided to have a new home built for himself. The result was this white, one and a half story wood frame house with large overhanging eaves, an airy L-shaped veranda supported by four Doric columns, and a small inset balcony above the front porch that overlooks Downey Street. 
(music) However, at the turn of the century when Dr. Leech was still living in the Miles house, the empty lot where this home now sits became one of the most popular social centers in West Branch. (sound effects: talking, laughing, fireworks) Here during the hot Midwest summers, Dr. Leech held ice cream socials church groups and 4th of July celebrations for the whole town. His lawn parties grew in popularity when box supper socials to benefit the volunteer fire company became an annual event. The West Branch Times wrote, "All gentlemen are invited to come and buy a box and take supper with your own or someone's best girl!", 
Although this home was built many years after Herbert Hoover's childhood, there is still a connection between the physician who practiced medicine in West Branch for 55 years and the young boy who left and became the nation's 31st President. When Dr. Leech passed away at the age of 91 in 1937, services were held at the West Branch Methodist Church. Herbert Hoover, ever guided by the understanding that it takes a community to raise a child, sent a personal message of sympathy that was read at the funeral. In it, the former President remembered and praised Dr. Leech's "long life of usefulness to the community and loyalty to his neighbors and friends.", 
If you haven't been there already, you can go one block west to learn about the historic West Branch homes located on Poplar Street.

stops.significance: In 1870, Laban Miles had married Hulda Hoover’s younger sister, Agnes Minthorn, just five days after Hulda and Jesse Hoover were wed. By 1875 they were settling down in this house, built sometime between 1869 and 1872, with a family of their own.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk about 20 more feet down the plank walkway. Turn left at the upright exhibit panel and cross the gravel street, about 50 feet to the other side. Follow the plank walkway to the left about 30 feet. Stop at the gate in the picket fence in front of the yellow house with red trim.
stops.audioTranscript:
This yellow, two story L-shaped structure with the offset porch was built sometime between 1869 and 1872. Cedar County Deed Records show that in 1875, Laban Miles purchased the home at 113 S. Downey Street for $2,250.00. In 1870, Miles had married Hulda's younger sister, Agnes Minthorn, just five days after Hulda and Jesse Hoover were wed. Now they were settling down with a family of their own.
There was much visiting back and forth between the Miles and Hoover homes, and the two families became close friends. The short walk on Downey Street often brought the Hoover children, Tad, Bertie, and Mary, together with their cousins for playtime or a shared pot of soup that had spent the day simmering on a wood stove. But their time together was short-lived.
In the spring of 1878, President Rutherford B. Hayes appointed Miles to serve as an agent responsible for the care and education of the Osage and Kaw tribes in the Oklahoma territory. When Laban, Agnes and their children left that summer, they rented their home first to the Methodist Church for a parsonage, and then to Dr. L.J. Leech, a well-known and respected physician in West Branch.
But the ties between the Miles and Hoover families remained strong. Following Jesse Hoover's death, Laban Miles asked Hulda if his nephew could come to live with them on the Osage reservation. In 1882, eight-year-old Herbert spent eight months there with his aunt, uncle and cousins. For the future President, they were memories that lasted a lifetime.

stops.significance: Amanda Garvin was a single 35-year old woman when she bought this property in 1870 for $90.00. She had this cottage built by 1872. The Garvin house is a wonderful example of the Gothic Revival style with its steeply pitched roof, gingerbread bargeboard trim, and ornamental arches framing the open front porch.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue about 65 feet in the same direction to the white and blue house with the conical porch. Stop at the gate in the picket fence.
stops.audioTranscript:
Amanda Garvin was a single 35-year old woman when she bought Lot number 6 in May of 1870 for the sum of $90.00. By 1872, the small, one and a half story wood frame cottage at 114 South Downey Street was built on her property. Herbert "Bertie" Hoover and his older brother Tad would have passed by this cottage on their way to school each day. 
The cream-colored Garvin house is a wonderful example of the Gothic Revival style with its steeply pitched roof, gingerbread bargeboard trim, and ornamental arches framing the open front porch. If you're familiar with Grant Wood's painting of the pitch-fork holding farmer and his wife called "American Gothic," you'll recognize how the Cedar Rapids artist drew inspiration from an eastern Iowa architectural staple.
By 1878, Miss Garvin was using her cottage as a rental property. Two years later, and still single, the U.S. Census showed she was living and working as a housekeeper for the Presbyterian Minister A.M. Heizer and his family. During the fifteen years she owned the property, Amanda Garvin mortgaged it several times. It was however, one time too many. The shed addition on the back of the house, and the hipped roofed addition on the north side were added a few years after Miss Garvin lost the home to foreclosure in 1885. 
The cream-colored Garvin house is a wonderful example of the Gothic Revival style with its steeply pitched roof, gingerbread bargeboard trim, and ornamental arches framing the open front porch. If you're familiar with Grant Wood's painting of the pitch-fork holding farmer and his wife called "American Gothic,", you'll recognize how the Cedar Rapids artist drew inspiration from an eastern Iowa architectural staple.
By 1878, Miss Garvin was using her cottage as a rental property. Two years later, and still single, the U.S. Census showed she was living and working as a housekeeper for the Presbyterian Minister A.M. Heizer and his family. During the fifteen years she owned the property, Amanda Garvin mortgaged it several times. It was however, one time too many. The shed addition on the back of the house, and the hipped roofed addition on the north side were added a few years after Miss Garvin lost the home to foreclosure in 1885.

stops.significance: Charles E. Smith was a carpenter and a Civil War veteran. In 1903, he completed his dream home for himself and his wife, Deborah, atop Cooks Hill where each spring, he would tap his maple trees to make maple syrup. The National Park Service relocated it near Herbert Hoover's birthplace in 1969.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Keep walking about 100 feet to the signpost at the intersection of Downey and Penn streets. Turn right and walk about 170 feet, past the blacksmith and schoolhouse. Turn right and walk about 250 feet to the exhibit panel on the left, near the end of the plank walkway.
stops.audioTranscript:
When Herbert Hoover was growing up, a Methodist Church, built in 1870, occupied the lot where C.E. Smith's house now stands. A towering three-story steeple impressively pointed to the heavens, and it's likely the Hoover household heard its ringing bell on Sunday mornings. (sound effects: church bell) This 11-foot tall street lamp is a historic reconstruction of the copper lantern box and post that stood in front of that Church. The original lamp burned kerosene oil, and was one of eleven that were lighting the streets of West Branch by 1883. 
The house that you see here today is known as the C.E. Smith House. Charles E. Smith was a carpenter and a Civil War veteran. In 1903, he completed his dream home for himself and his wife, Deborah atop Cooks Hill where each spring, he would tap his maple trees to make maple syrup. Although this home was built eighteen years after Herbert Hoover left West Branch, the National Park Service decided to relocate it here in 1969.
(music) This large, white, one and a half story Queen Anne style house includes intersecting gables. Cut cedar shingles painted a robin's egg blue, are used for the siding underneath the gables. One of the most unusual features of this house is the open octagon-shaped front porch; its' sloping tent roof is supported by four machine turned posts framed with decoratively scrolled brackets. The Smith home's graceful and charming appearance fits comfortably in the neighborhood, and contributes to the historic setting of the Iowa village that President Hoover called home.

stops.significance: West Branch was barely a settlement in 1852 when Baltimore native Aaron Baker came here to claim the free land he'd received from the United States government for his service in the Mexican War. He promptly sold all 160 acres of it for about a dollar apiece.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the exhibit panel, return the way you came. Stop after about 40 feet at the gate of the yellow house on the left.
stops.audioTranscript:
West Branch was barely a settlement in 1852 when Baltimore native Aaron Baker came here to claim the free land he'd received from the United States government for his service in the Mexican War. He promptly sold all 160 acres of it for about a dollar apiece.
By the time John Wetherell purchased five acres in 1869, the price of land had risen considerably. The new real estate developer set about subdividing his property into town lots, and also decided to name a nearby street after himself. 
As you look around, you might be surprised to learn that Herbert Hoover didn't live in one of these larger homes. By comparison, his home measured only 14 x 20 feet in size. You will get the chance to go inside the cottage where America's 31st President was born; however, the homes here on Poplar Street are not open to the public and are used as offices or private residences.

stops.significance: In 1869, carpenter David Mackey, who designed and built this humble two-story home. The cheerful yellow house would have been a familiar landmark to the young Herbert Hoover. The young widower, one of the town's few Democrats, was elected the Mayor of West Branch in 1879.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next stop may be seen directly across the gravel street to the other side. It is a white house with yellow trim.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1869, after subdividing his recently purchased five-acre real estate investment, John Wetherell sold two of the lots to David Mackey for $50 each. The Mackey house is one of the oldest homes in the historic core of West Branch. This cheerful yellow wood framed home would have been a familiar landmark to the young Herbert "Bertie" Hoover while growing up. 
Did you notice the small, simple hood over the entryway? Mackey designed and built this humble two-story house with a gable roof and a red brick chimney. Just a few years after construction was complete, his wife Mary died, leaving the carpenter with a baby son named Charles. Soon after, Mackey's sister, Martha moved in to help take care of the child. 
The young widower, one of the town's few Democrats, was surprisingly elected the Mayor of West Branch in 1879. Of the homes in the core area dating back to Hoover's boyhood, this house and the Wright home, across the street, have been the least altered in appearance.

stops.significance: The main wing of this white, two-story wood frame structure was completed in 1872, two years before Herbert Hoover was born. Dr. James Staples and his wife Eliza bought it in 1876. The couple, originally from Vermont, had decided to retire in West Branch.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the plank walkway about 50 feet. The next stop is a beige house with brown trim that may been seen from across the gravel street.
stops.audioTranscript:
The main wing of this white, two-story wood frame structure was completed in 1872, two years before Hoover was born. Did you know that the yellow-trimmed door on the left was the original entry to the home? Another owner added the enclosed five-windowed porch in the early 1900's. After Wetherell's death in 1876, his widow, Mary sold the three lots, along with the home, to Dr. John Staples and his wife Eliza for $1,500.00. 
The couple, originally from Vermont, had decided to retire in West Branch. When the 76-year old doctor passed away in 1891, he left the home to his four grandchildren. The Staples house has since become a part of the historic village landscape from Herbert Hoover's youth.

stops.significance: In 1873, J. M. Wetherell sold two lots to Mary Wright. She owned the property for the next 48 years. Her husband, William “Billy” Wright, owned a blacksmith shop at the southwest corner of Main and Poplar streets. Perhaps the competition from neighbor Jesse Hoover, Herbert’s dad, was what led Billy to sell his business in 1875 and open a harness and boot shop.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Keep following the plank walkway about 65 feet. The next stop is a yellow house with peach trim. It may be seen from across the gravel street.
stops.audioTranscript:
On April 30, 1873, J. M. Wetherell sold Lots 23 & 24 to Mary Wright for $270. She owned the property for the next 48 years. If you're wondering why the deed was in her name, it might have something to do with the fact that in 1870, Mary had learned some surprising news. Even though she and her husband, William "Billy" Wright had been married for thirteen years, and she'd given him six children, he had never divorced his first wife. When the first Mrs. Wright tracked down her deserting husband, Billy sent her $40 and she agreed to never trouble him again. 
The Wright House features a clapboard-sided front porch with a pyramid-shaped hip roof that's supported by two short, square columns painted brown like the rest of the home's trim. This large white house also features a few other architectural embellishments. You've probably already noticed the beautiful bay window that faces the street. But can you find the triple-paned piano window?
For a time, Wright owned a blacksmith shop at the southwest corner of Main and Poplar. Perhaps the competition from neighbor Jesse Hoover, Herbert's dad, was what led Billy to sell his business in 1875 and open a harness and boot shop.

stops.significance: In 1870, real-estate developer J.M. Wetherell sold three lots to E.S. Hayhurst. Hayhurst built his house here in 1872.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Walk another 40 feet to the intersection with the other plank walkway. Turn left and walk to the signpost near the corner of the birthplace cottage, about 260 feet. 
Turn right and follow the street or sidewalk over the bridge to the next intersection of the gravel and planks, about 350 feet. Follow the plank walkway on the left about 50 feet. Turn right and take the plank walkway about to the exhibit panel in front of the meetinghouse. 
Follow the plank walkway to the right. The path crosses a driveway after about 300 feet. Be careful of cars while crossing, then continue along the planks about 150 feet to the end of a walkway by a green house.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1870, real-estate developer J. M. Wetherell managed to sell three lots to E.S. Hayhurst for $325. This cream-colored house with brown trim, completed in 1872, has an open porch with machine-turned posts framed by decorative brackets. Three steps span the full width of the entryway. Notice how the roof lines intersect with each other. Can you see the similarity between this 1-1/2 story T-shaped building and the Staples house at the North end of Poplar Street? It's possible that the same carpenters had a hand in building both. 
Unfortunately, Hayhurst and his family were only able to call this place home for less than a decade. When they couldn't make the payments, the mortgage was foreclosed and the family left town in 1878. Ever the businessman, Wetherell repossessed the lots and turned the house into a rental property.

stops.significance: The P.T. Smith House is the only house that Herbert Hoover remembered when he visited West Branch many years later.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
Again, be careful recrossing the driveway. Return the way you came to the exhibit panel in front of the meetinghouse. Turn left at and follow the planks until they end, about 50 feet. 
Continue along the concrete sidewalk, past the statue, for about 350 feet. At the corner of the museum, round the corner to the right until you get to the front doors of museum across from the flag poles, about 50 feet. 
Cross the driveway from the front doors of the museum, following the crosswalk between the flag poles, to the concrete walkway on the other side, about 50 feet. A sign indicates the direction to the gravesite. Follow the walkway to the right. Use caution crossing a driveway after about 100  feet. Continue to the tallgrass prairie trailhead on the left, about 100  feet. 
Follow the mowed grass trail to the left, about 500  feet. Stop near the top of the slope by a complex of farm buildings with a red barn.

stops.significance: Isaac Miles was a widower with two young daughters when he moved to West Branch in 1874 and opened a drugstore. Isaac's daughters, Providence and Abbie were around the same age as the Hoover children, and it's likely they played together in this rural playground filled with natural wonders.
stops.audioTranscript:
If you look beyond the tallgrass prairie, on the horizon, you can see a red barn with white trim tucked beneath some trees. This 3-level wooden barn, part of the Miles Farmstead, is the only agricultural structure in the area that survives from the time when Hoover was a young boy.
(sound effects: native birds) Isaac Miles was a widower with two young daughters when he moved to West Branch in 1874 and opened a drugstore. Three years later, he met and married a young woman, who had inherited 100 acres of farmland to the southwest of the Hoover cottage. So Miles sold his drugstore and decided to give farming a try. And as soon as the two-story frame house and barn were built, the new family moved in. Isaac's daughters, Providence and Abbie were around the same age as the Hoover children, and it's likely they played together in this rural playground filled with natural wonders.
(music) Iowa farmsteads were laid out according to the character of the land. Rolling hills could serve as pasture or as a partial support for buildings like a barn. Where the ground was flat, crops were planted; (sound effects: chickens, rooster) outbuildings like chicken coops were constructed close to the home, but definitely downwind, to make for a short walk in the winter. And a road was leveled to give the farmer access to railroads and markets where he could sell his harvest. 
An 1880 census showed that Miles had managed to get 73 acres under cultivation with corn, oats, rye, potatoes, and apples. He also raised 5 milk cows, 5 beef cattle, 55 pigs, and 20 chickens. Farming did provide for Isaac and his family, but in 1882, Isaac became involved with his father Benjamin in the establishment of a Quaker-inspired school to educate Native American children in the industrial arts. It was during this time, when some of the Osage, Cheyenne, and Arapaho children lived and worked on the Miles Farm, that 8-year old Bert Hoover fished and hunted the countryside with them, learned the lore of the woods, and how to make bows and arrows.

images.title: Amanda Garvin House
images.altText: A tree filters summer sunlight onto a wood frame house with gothic arches.
images.caption: Barn at the Isaac Miles Farmstead next to the tallgrass prairie.

data.title: Whitman Mission Walking History Tour
data.description: Introduction to differencing expectations and misunderstandings between the Whitman's and the Cayuse that lead to the events that occurred here and the impact it had on the peoples of this continent.

stops.significance: Before you begin your tour, stop by the visitor center to pick up a park brochure, watch the park film, and talk to a ranger.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit out the back doors on the right side of the visitor center and follow the paved path.

stops.significance: Since time immemorial, people have lived here and cared for this land.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the paved path on your right towards the mission grounds.  When you come to the Y in the path, continue on the right hand path.
stops.audioTranscript:
Since time immemorial, weyíıletpuu, or Cayuse, people have cared for and built relationships with the land according to tamáalwıt. tamáalwıt is rooted in traditional ecological knowledge, governing ethical stewardship of the land in accordance with natural cycles. These beliefs and practices dictate how humans relate to water, animals, plants, the land, each other, and the Creator.

Abiding by tamáalwıt, Native Peoples enjoyed stable cultural and political communities coupled with sustained economic success. Native people of the Columbia Plateau were connected to each other and other nations across the continent by an extensive trade network. Through this network, weyíıletpuu people exchanged horses, camas, and more for everything from dentalium and abalone from coastal nations to bison hides from plains nations.

The Cayuse Nation is made up of multiple bands. In the early to mid-1800’s, tílewkeỷkt was the leader of the band that lived here each winter. Around that same time, foreigners began entering weyíiletpuu homeland looking for beaver and other animals. The fur trade was booming, and they were looking to profit. These newcomers built off the existing Native trade network, relying on the knowledge and infrastructure of Native peoples. Trading posts were built by competing American and British fur companies. One of these posts was built in 1818 on the Columbia River 25 miles west of here. This post became Fort Walla Walla, operated by the Hudson’s Bay Company. Much closer, just two miles from here, a small community of retired fur trappers received permission from weyíıletpuu leaders to build homes along the Walla Walla River beginning in 1823. Many members of this community were French Canadian or Métis, having both Native and French-Canadian heritage.

stops.significance: It was the trade network and its reliance on Native knowledge of the environment that shaped relationships between Native nations and the newcomers to the Pacific Northwest. When missionaries arrived, they had to find their own place within this pre-existing social structure. The Whitmans chose to mirror the economic relationship that the traders had with Native peoples, but their perception of weyíiletpuu people as “inferior” prevented them from creating deep personal ties with the community
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue walking along the paved path.
stops.audioTranscript:
It was the trade network and its reliance on Plateau Peoples’ knowledge of the environment that shaped relationships between Native nations and the newcomers to the Pacific Northwest. The relationship between fur trappers and Native peoples were primarily one of economics and exchange, but often business was strengthened by close personal ties. Many Hudson’s Bay Company employees married Indian women and benefitted from their knowledge of local languages and their connections to nearby communities.

When missionaries arrived here, they had to find their own place within this pre-existing social structure. The Whitmans chose to mirror the economic relationship that the traders had with Plateau Peoples, but their perception of weyíiletpuu people as “inferior” prevented them from creating deep personal ties to the community.

Many parts of traditional weyíiletpuu life relied on reciprocal relationships to establish trust and personal bonds. When tílewkeỷkt gave the missionaries permission to build a mission here, the expectation was that they would participate in a reciprocal relationship by giving back to the community. It was a surprise when the Whitmans instead put up fences, put locks on their doors, and kept Native people out of their house. For the Whitmans, these measures were an attempt to recreate their concepts of “civilization” and safety.

The missionaries and weyíiletpuu people entered this relationship with different expectations of each other which quickly dissolved into disappointment and frustration for everyone. Frustrations only grew as it became clear that the Whitmans would never successfully learn the Cayuse-Nez Perce language nor teach English.

How do you feel when reality does not live up to your expectations?

stops.significance: This area was quickly becoming an international crossroads. Plateau people adopted aspects of other cultures, including religious beliefs, depending on their interest. Back in the United States, news of Native interest in other cultures reached Americans in the throes of the Second Great Awakening. The First House marked the beginning of the mission at weyíiletpe as well as the beginning of the missionaries’ attempts to reshape the lifestyle of the weyíiletpuu.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following the paved path toward the pond.
stops.audioTranscript:
This region was quickly becoming an international crossroads. Plateau Peoples adopted aspects of other cultures, including religious beliefs, depending on their interest. Back in the United States, news of Native interest in other cultures reached Americans in the throes of the Second Great Awakening. Renewed commitment to spreading Christianity fueled missionary organizations. The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (ABCFM) was one organization in search of missionaries to send beyond the borders of the United States. In 1836, the ABCFM recruited Marcus and Narcissa Whitman, Henry and Eliza Spalding, and William Gray to spread Christianity in what was then known as Oregon Country.

Upon the missionary party’s arrival in the pášx̣apa valley in the fall of 1836, the actual location of the mission was still undecided. The ABCFM had originally set aside funding for a single mission in the Oregon Country. What they had not planned for was the amount of personal discord that led to the mission party refusing to settle together. Both the weyíiletpuu and the nimiipuu, the Nez Perce, were interested in hosting the missionaries. So as a result, the Spaldings settled among the nimiipuu while the Whitmans and Gray stayed here.

stops.significance: Some weyíiletpuu people quickly accepted the religious teachings and new technologies brought by the missionaries. The Whitmans believed that good Christians would “multiply and replenish the earth,” and so many of these technologies were used for farming. The grist mill was one example of a technology that was appreciated by many. The use of the grist mill and the broader introduction of agriculture were not without conflict, however.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue following the paved path
stops.audioTranscript:
Many weyíiletpuu traditions and cultural practices revolved around returning to set village sites at set times of year based on when and where things like roots, berries, fish, and game were abundant. weyíiletpuu people also used this Seasonal Round as an opportunity to trade and socialize with other bands and nations.

For the missionaries, this movement proved to be a problem. Their idea of a civilized Christian society involved staying in one place, and that is what they planned to re-create here. To them, the traditional weyíiletpuu lifestyle was “uncivilized” and lacked value. What could they do to convince this community to stay in one place year-round?

They hoped agriculture would be the answer.

But for many weyíiletpuu families, agriculture meant giving up much more than they gained. Staying in one spot meant losing opportunities to trade and socialize with other bands and nations. Not only was agriculture a complete change of lifestyle, it would be a change to a less sustainable system. Farming meant trying to cultivate crops imported from the east that were not as well suited for the land and the climate here.

In reports sent back to the ABCFM in 1844, Marcus wrote:
 “You will excuse me for want of particulars about the Indians and things in general, for my time is so occupied between attending to the Mill, the sowing of my wheat, attention to the wants of my family and the supply of the Imigrants that little time is left for writing.” 

The Cayuse continued working with the missionaries, but the missionaries’ attention was quickly shifting to the immigrants arriving from the United States.

The rising flood of immigrants led to rising tensions at weyíiletpe. At times, the gristmill was at the center of the growing frustration. After a particularly heated argument regarding the mill, Tomahas threw sticks into the mill and attacked Marcus. Tilewkikt stepped in to stop Tomahas. During a separate but similar incident, Tomahas told Marcus that he should leave permanently. It was neither the first time Marcus had been threatened nor the last time the Whitmans would be told to leave.

stops.significance: Fundamental differences regarding ownership and land management continued to grow, further deteriorating trust and respect between the weyíiletpuu people and the missionaries. There was also recurring conflict amongst the Oregon missionaries. William Gray and the “emigrant house” he built here would be central to some of these dramas. Attempting to resolve the inter-missionary strife, the ABCFM ordered an end to the Oregon mission.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved path.
stops.audioTranscript:
In 1842, William Gray was so frustrated with his place at the mission that he left, but not before airing his grievances. Gray sent letters to Reverend David Greene, the secretary of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (ABCFM) who had appointed each of the missionaries. Fellow Oregon missionaries Asa Smith and Cornelius Rogers sent letters to Greene, too. Each letter spoke poorly of the other missionaries’ character, ability, and competence.

Because of the long-winded and detailed complaints that they received from Oregon, the ABCFM decided to put an end to the mission stations at weyíiletpe and lapwai, relieve the Spaldings, Grays, and Smiths of their duties, and send the Whitmans to the Tshimakain station. It was suggested that the Rogers go north with the Whitmans. Greene wrote:

“It seems to be the unanimous opinion of you all… that your company can not live & labor together… This is to the Committee extremely painful and humiliating. It is an alternative to which they have never been brought by any other mission; & which for the honor of the cause, they trust may never occur again.”

It took a full two years to receive a response to a letter sent across the continent. By the time the missionaries received Greene’s orders, the Grays and Smiths had already left and the disagreements among the remaining missionaries had seemingly passed. But the ABCFM’s orders stood. Without delay, the Oregon missionaries decided to send Dr. Whitman to the ABCFM in Boston. When he returned, he brought news: all the mission stations would remain active. The Spaldings continued at lapwai, the Whitmans at weyíiletpe, and the immigrants continued to flood the region.

stops.significance: Along with the gristmill and a sawmill built closer to the Blue Mountains, the mission at weyíiletpe also eventually included a blacksmith shop. Discussions surrounding the blacksmith shop provide further insight into the slowly shifting goals of the missionaries.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved path.
stops.audioTranscript:
When wave after wave of immigrants began settling in the region and even being housed at the mission station, some weyíiletpuu people began to question the missionaries’ intentions, especially when it came to Dr. Whitman.

At first, the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (ABCFM) generally supported the Whitmans’ dual focus on incoming immigrants and the Cayuse People. By 1846, though, it seemed that the Whitmans were neglecting their designated purpose in favor of supplying the

immigrants coming into Oregon Country. In a letter dated April 6, 1846, Rev. David Greene of the ABCFM wrote to Marcus:

“Still we are not quite sure that you ought to devote so much time and thought to feeding the emigrants, and thus make your station a great restaurant for the weary pilgrims on their way to their promised land. Such a work is a very humane & good work; but the work of guiding men to Christ is a better one and coincides better with the vocation of a missionary laborer.”

Perhaps the ABCFM began to worry because the number of immigrants from the United States was growing exponentially and could therefore take up an exponential amount of the Whitmans’ time. Perhaps they worried because the weyíiletpuu mission, which by that time had been active for ten years, had not yet officially welcomed a single soul into the church. Though many Cayuse people adopted parts of Christianity, none met the extensive membership requirements upheld by the missionaries.

Concern was growing throughout the surrounding Cayuse communities as well. The flood of immigrants on which the Whitmans seemed so intently focused had brought with them a deadly stowaway: measles.

In 1847, a measles epidemic swept through the area. It was not the first time the Cayuse had encountered measles- unfamiliar diseases had been making their way into the Pacific Northwest since European and American travelers had begun interacting with the peoples of the region- but this was a particularly deadly outbreak. Up to six Cayuse people died each day, mostly children and the elderly. This death rate was especially alarming. Many American immigrants got sick as well, but far fewer died from the disease.

stops.significance: When the Whitmans arrived in Oregon Country, their task was ambitious: to convert the Cayuse Nation to Christianity. To meet their definition of religious conversion, the missionaries also asked the Cayuse to learn English and abandon their native languages, to adopt settled agriculture, and to upend Cayuse cultural norms. The Whitmans took actions to distance themselves from weyíiletpuu individuals and culture which complicated their task. How does one build relationships and teach about language, farming, and religion, when space is not made at home for the people one wishes to teach
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved path. Take a right and following the path back toward the visitor center.
stops.audioTranscript:
Some of the tensions surrounding the mission were caused by two poisoning incidents. The first involved William Gray. When a few of his watermelons were taken, Gray was upset. He put emetic, a substance that induces vomiting, into some of the remaining melons to deter others from taking more. A few weyíiletpuu men ate some of the contaminated watermelons and became sick. The emetic was from Whitman’s medical supplies. Since Whitman had supplied the emetic, he was blamed for the incident.

Later, some arsenic-poisoned meat was placed out to protect the mission’s livestock from wolves. Unfortunately, Cayuse men saw the meat going to waste and ate it, not knowing that it was tainted. The men survived but developed a severe rash, a symptom of arsenic poisoning.

Each of these incidents was a seed of doubt in the minds of the weyíiletpuu people.

Making things worse, news of Indian Removal in the United States had traveled to Oregon Country along with stories from the Pacific Coast of a trader threatening to unleash disease if Native peoples did not cooperate with his trading post. Later in 1847, when measles struck, many Cayuse people fell ill and developed a severe rash. The similarities between the measles rash and the rash from the arsenic poisoning, as well as news coming from other Indian nations, fed suspicions regarding the missionaries’ involvement.

Dr. Whitman had stepped into a medical role knowing that he would be held to the standards of a tıwáat, a weyíiletpuu doctor. He knew that the weyíiletpuu penalty for malpractice was death. During the measles epidemic, Dr. Whitman treated both Americans and Cayuse patients. Despite using the same treatments, fewer Americans died under his care. Many Cayuse people questioned the doctor’s abilities and motives and wondered if the Cayuse deaths were intentional.

Dr. Whitman was cautioned multiple times, by various groups, that he was endangering himself if he stayed. On November 28th, 1847, as measles raged, Whitman was once again warned to leave the mission. He did not heed the warning. That night, a small group of men led by tílewkeykt finalized their plan to save their communities from measles: killing Dr. Whitman. By evening of the following day, both missionaries and many of the adult men at the mission were dead. Over the following month, the 47 people remaining at the mission site were held hostage.

stops.significance: The attack on the mission had far-reaching impacts on both the people of the region and the interests of the United States. It sparked a chain of events that led to wars, treaty negotiations, reservations, and more. What began here in the 1800s is still impacting thousands of lives today.
stops.assetName: Reconstructed Oregon Trail at Whitman Mission
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the paved path, passing the visitor center. Continue walking toward the hill.
stops.audioTranscript:
Officials from the Hudson’s Bay Company arranged for the release of the 47 people who were still at the mission after the attack. With the mission closed this branch of the Oregon Trail was abandoned, but waves of American immigrants continued to travel into and through Cayuse homeland. Militias were hastily formed in the Willamette Valley in a frenzied response to the attack. Even those who didn’t join militias wanted revenge. The regional newspaper, The Oregon Spectator, called for the Cayuse to “…be hunted as beasts of prey…” and “…their name and race be blotted from the face of the earth.” These quotes show that though there were only a small group of men who were involved, the entire Cayuse Nation was blamed and vilified for the events.

Just three months later, the Oregon Volunteer Militia began waging war on the weyíiletpuu nation. From 1848 to 1850, weyíiletpuu families hid and fled from armed forces who disrupted seasonal harvests, stole livestock, and pushed entire communities to the edge of starvation. To end the persecution, weyíiletpuu leaders surrendered five men to the army.

News of the attack on the mission station had quickly traveled back to the United States, where reactions were also severe. As a direct result, the United States formed Oregon Territory in August 1848, encompassing most of the present-day states of Washington, Oregon, and Idaho, and surrounding the Cayuse Nation. The new Oregon Territorial Government put the five surrendered men, collectively referred to as the Cayuse Five, on trial for the death of Dr. Whitman in 1851. From the beginning there were questions over jurisdiction. Witnesses also failed to identify some of the defendants as the attackers. And yet, all five were quickly convicted, hanged, and buried in an unmarked grave. Descendants of the Cayuse Five are still seeking justice for their ancestors.

In 1855 weyíiletpuu leaders, along with leaders from other Native nations, met with U.S. officials near the present-day town of Walla Walla to negotiate a treaty. After ensuring some of their most important lands were reserved for exclusive use, these leaders signed a treaty to share other lands with the expanding United States. This agreement between nations is still in effect today; it guarantees certain rights and activities to members of the nations that signed.

stops.significance: The attack on the mission station began a chain of events that still touches our lives today. It led to armed conflict, the creation of Oregon Territory, the Treaty of 1855, and the beginning of the reservation system in the Pacific Northwest. The events and people involved have left behind many different legacies that are evident in the many different ways this history has been told.
stops.audioTranscript:
After the attack on the mission, historians looked to the written accounts left by white survivors of the events. Though Cayuse accounts of the events were shared through Oral Tradition, they were not written down until much later. Because Oral Tradition was often not considered reliable by scholars, the written accounts were the only records that were used in historical research. Over time, misconceptions surrounding Oral Tradition have been dispelled and it is now recognized as a valuable source of information on the past. As a result, this history has been told many different ways and has had many different legacies.

A one-sided version of this history was reinforced by the physical monuments placed here during and after the mission-period. The missionaries and their descendants wanted to demonstrate their presence through physical markers: buildings, monuments, gravestones, and changes to the landscape.  While there is no physical monument to the weyíiletpuu within the park, the Cayuse people of the past are memorialized through the continued sovereignty of the Cayuse Nation. Weyíiletpuu people are still living on the lands of their ancestors and continue to keep their memory alive through their culture. 

We are left with legacies that are not easy or comfortable to face because of the decisions made here. All the people who were here experienced tragedy and trauma that has reverberated across generations. Today, all who live in this region, and this nation, still struggle with the implications of this history. Now, it is up to us to ask ourselves: what will we do with these legacies as we move forward?

data.title: Wild San Antonio
data.description: Take a walk on the wild side with the Wild San Antonio Tour. This tour will take you to three places that are great for viewing the cities wildlife. First stop, the San Antonio River near the Espada Dam. This is a great stop to see birds and turtles. Next stop is the pollinator garden at Mission San Juan. This is a great place to see native plants, butterflies, bees, and other insects. Last stop is the Yanaguana trail, a 1/3 mile loop trail, that is a great place to see birds and turtles,
