data.title: Women of Beacon Hill Tour
data.description: During the 1800s, Beacon Hill served as a center in the work to abolish slavery, the fight for equal education, & the struggle for women’s rights. Black & White women played a significant role in these & other efforts, having aspirational visions of a just & equitable world. Working from their homes & in community spaces, they used tools at their disposal to define their own sphere of action & influence. Join us as we explore stories of the inspiring women who lived & made a difference in this community.

park.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
park.name: Boston African American

stops.significance: Sitting atop Beacon Hill, the golden-domed Massachusetts State House has served as the state’s seat of power since 1798. In its over-200 year history, however, its doors were not always open to all. Women had to fight for their right to be heard within its walls. In 1838, Angelina Grimke spoke at the State House, becoming the first woman to address a U.S. governing body. Women suffragists later came knocking at the State House doors, winning victory in 1919 when the State Legislature ratified the 19th Amendment. While some fought for access to the State House, many of Boston’s women worked beyond its walls to make change in their communities. This tour will guide us through stories of Black and White women in Beacon Hill who participated in various social and political movements during the 1800s. Join us as we stroll through the historic district of Beacon Hill and explore stories of the innovative and inspiring women who made a difference in this community.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Massachusetts State House, turn left down Beacon Street. Turn right on Joy Street. Turn left onto Pinckney Street. The house of Thomas Aves is on the right side of the street at 21 Pinckney Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Sitting atop Beacon Hill, the golden-domed Massachusetts State House has served as the state’s seat of power since 1798. In its over-200 year history, however, its doors were not always open to all. Women had to fight for their right to be heard within its walls, first by writing fiery petitions on slavery and women’s rights. In 1838, Abolitionist Angelina Grimke spoke on behalf of these petitioners at the State House, becoming the first woman to address a U.S. governing body. During her anti-slavery speech, she advocated for women’s rightful place in society:  

“These petitions relate to the great and solemn subject of American slavery-a subject fraught with the deepest interest to this republic, whether we regard it in its political, moral, or religious   aspects. And because it is a political subject, it has often been tauntingly said, that woman has nothing to do with it...  

This domination of women must be resigned-the sooner the better; in the age which is approaching, she should be something more–she should be a citizen... I hold, Mr. Chairman, that  American women have to do with this subject, not only because it is moral and religious, but  because it is political, inasmuch as we are citizens of this republic, and as such our honor, happiness, and well being, are bound up in its politics and government and laws.” 

Following the Civil War, women’s suffragists came knocking at the State House doors. The decades that followed saw numerous hearings where suffragists and their opponents engaged in intense debate over women’s right to vote. Suffragists won victory in 1919 when the Massachusetts State Legislature ratified the 19th Amendment. The following year, Democrat Susan Fitzgerald and Republican Sylvia M. Donaldson became the first women to win elected state representative seats. 

While some fought for access to the Massachusetts State House, many of Boston’s women worked beyond its walls to make change and better their communities.  

This tour will guide us through stories of Black and White women from a community just next door to the State House, Beacon Hill. During the 1800s, Beacon Hill served as a hotbed of activity in the work to abolish slavery, the fight for equal education, and the struggle for women’s rights. Women in Beacon Hill played a significant role in these and other efforts, having forward-thinking and aspirational visions of a just and equitable world. Working from their homes or in community spaces, these women used the tools and skills at their disposal to define their own sphere of action and influence. Join us as we stroll through the historic district of Beacon Hill and explore stories of the innovative and inspiring women who lived and made a difference in this community.

stops.significance:
During the summer of 1836, Mary Aves Slater traveled from her home in New Orleans to visit her father Thomas Aves in Boston. Slater brought a six-year-old enslaved girl named Med with her, leaving Med’s mother behind in New Orleans.
The Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society soon learned of the enslavement of Med in the home of Thomas Aves at 21 Pinckney Street. Member Lydia Maria Child recalled, “We obtained all the evidence we wanted, carried it to a lawyer, who petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus; the judge granted the petition; and  the man who held little Med in custody was brought up for trial.”
Although Slater legally owned Med in New Orleans, Judge Lemuel Shaw granted Med her freedom on the basis that enslaved people brought to the free state of Massachusetts could not be held against their will. The Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society's success in freeing Med was short-lived; two years later Med died in the Samaritan Asylum for Indigent Children in Boston, before being reunited with her mother.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Pinckney Street. At the Anderson Street intersection, cross to the other side of Pinckney Street. 62 Pinckney Street stands almost directly at the end of Anderson Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
During the summer of 1836, Mary Aves Slater traveled from her home in New Orleans, Louisiana to visit her father Thomas Aves in Boston. Upon her departure from New Orleans, Slater made the critical decision to bring a six-year-old enslaved girl named Med with her on the journey, leaving Med’s mother behind. Slater traveled from Louisiana, a slave state, to the state of Massachusetts, which legally abolished slavery in 1783. 

In August 1836, the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society learned of Med’s presence in the home of Thomas Aves at 21 Pinckney Street. Historical records suggest that members of the Society posed as Sunday School recruiters in order to gain access to the home of Thomas Aves. Member Lydia Maria Child recalled, “We obtained all the evidence we wanted, carried it to a lawyer, who petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus; the judge granted the petition; and the man who held little Med in custody was brought up for trial.”  

On August 27, 1836, Chief Justice Lemuel Shaw presided over the case Commonwealth v. Aves, ultimately ruling that enslaved people brought to Massachusetts by their enslavers could not be held against their will. Shaw’s ruling removed Med from the institution of slavery, but due to her young age, Med was placed in the care of the Samaritan Asylum for Indigent Children in Boston. Commonwealth v. Aves set an important legal precedent for free states and served as a landmark victory for the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society. However, the newly emancipated Med never reunited with her mother and died two years later at the Asylum.

stops.significance: The success of the Underground Railroad in Boston required the collective efforts of Black and White women. Each group used their unique position in society as dictated by their gender and race to support their singular cause. As the Boston Evening Transcript recalled, “Frequently it became too hazardous to board fugitives among their own people…Under such circumstance safe harborages were found without expense among the white abolitionists. One such refuge was in the house of George S. Hillard at 62 Pinckney street.” Throughout the 1850s, George’s wife Susan routinely welcomed freedom seekers into her home, using her husband’s reputation as a Websterian politician to conceal her work with the Underground Railroad. Most notably, Susan Hillard sheltered Ellen Craft in October 1850 as slave catchers searched Beacon Hill for the freedom seeker.
stops.assetName: George S. and Susan Hillard House
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Pinckney Street, crossing Louisburg Square on your left. At Charles Street, turn left and go down one block to the intersection of Charles Street and Mt Vernon Street. The Charles Street Meeting House is located on the opposite corner.
stops.audioTranscript:
The success of the Underground Railroad in Boston required the collective efforts of Black and White women. Each group used their unique position in society as dictated by their gender and race to support their singular cause. As the 'Boston Evening Transcript' recalled, “Frequently it became too hazardous to board fugitives among their own people…Under such circumstance safe harborages were found without expense among the white abolitionists. One such refuge was in the house of George S. Hillard at 62 Pinckney street.” 

Throughout the 1850s, George’s wife Susan routinely welcomed freedom seekers into her home, using her husband’s political reputation to conceal her work with the Underground Railroad. In October 1850, Susan Hillard learned of the presence of slave catchers in Boston who were searching for freedom seekers William and Ellen Craft. Susan Hillard immediately hastened to a home on Mt. Vernon Street where Ellen was taking upholstery lessons to share the dire news. Susan remembered, “I proposed to Ellen to come and do some work for me, intending not to alarm her. My manner, which I supposed to be indifferent and calm, betrayed me, and she threw herself into my arms, sobbing and weeping…She, however, recovered her composure as soon as we reached the street, and was very firm ever after.”  

Susan Hillard’s work with the Underground Railroad continued throughout the 1850s. William Still from the Philadelphia Vigilance Committee documented that between 1855 and 1858 George and Susan Hillard sheltered five freedom seekers in their Pinckney Street home. One of those freedom seekers was Louisa F. Jones. On May 15, 1858, Jones wrote a letter to William Still, reflecting on her arrival in Boston, saying, “I arrived hear on Thirsday last…since that Time I have been living with Mrs. Hillard…”

stops.significance:
In the summer of 1895, Black clubwomen traveled to Boston to attend the First National Conference of the Colored Women of America. Largely organized by Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and members of the Boston-based Black women’s club, the Women’s Era Club, most of the conference took place in Berkeley Hall. The convention provided a space for club delegates “to talk over not only those things which are of vital importance to us as colored women;” but to also “teach an ignorant and suspicious world that our aims and interests are identical with those of all good aspiring women.” 

On the final day, clubwomen met at the Charles Street Meeting House to form the National Federation of Afro-American Women. Later, this group merged with the National League of Colored Women to form what is now known as the National Association of Colored Women’s Clubs. This conference proved pivotal in shaping the way society viewed Black women and laid out the foundation for the advancement of the Black women’s club movement.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head back down Charles Street in the direction from where you came, cross Pinckney Street to arrive at 103 Charles Street, on the right side of the street. A plaque on the building recognizes the home of Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin.
stops.audioTranscript:
In the 1800s, women across the country organized and participated in women’s clubs. Clubwomen socialized, organized meetings, worked to improve their communities, and advocated for a variety of social and political causes. While some clubs included both Black and White women, Black women found themselves largely excluded from white women’s politics. Black women started forming their own clubs in which they could focus on issues relating to race and gender.  

In the summer of 1895, Black clubwomen traveled to Boston to attend the First National Conference of the Colored Women of America. Largely organized by Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and members of the Boston-based Black women’s club, the Women’s Era Club, most of the conference took place in Berkeley Hall. The convention provided a space for club delegates “to talk over not only those things which are of vital importance to us as colored women;” but, more importantly, to “teach an ignorant and suspicious world that our aims and interests are identical with those of all good aspiring women.” 

On the final day, clubwomen met at the Charles Street Meeting House to officially form the National Federation of Afro-American Women. Later, this group merged with the National League of Colored Women to form what is now known as the National Association of Colored Women’s Clubs. In addition to the formation of a national organization, the conference helped shape the way society viewed Black women and laid out the foundation for the advancement of the Black women’s club movement.

stops.significance:
As a center of activism, Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin’s Charles Street home always brimmed with energy. In the 1890s, she often invited liberal-minded local Black and White leaders and community members to her home for discussion and enrichment.

The home also acted as a frequent meeting place for the Woman’s Era Club, a Black women’s club founded by Josephine Ruffin and other local Black clubwomen in 1893. Through events and activities, the club encouraged the intellectual engagement of its members, addressed needs in the community, and maintained a broad vision for equality and social change. Members advocated for greater civil rights for African Americans, supported women’s suffrage, and stood against racism and discrimination. The club’s vision for a world in which Black women took active roles in bettering their communities extended across the country through the club’s nationally published newspaper, 'The Woman’s Era.'
stops.assetName: Meeting Place of the Woman's Era Club
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Charles Street and turn right up Revere Street. Take an immediate left on West Cedar Street, followed by an immediate right onto Phillips Street. Walk along Phillips Street to 66 Phillips Street. The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House is marked by a plaque. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
As a center of activism, Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin’s Charles Street home always brimmed with energy. In the 1890s, she often invited liberal-minded local Black and White leaders and community members to her home for discussion and enrichment. Then Harvard student W.E.B. DuBois said at Ruffin’s home he and others “met and ate, danced and argued and planned a new world.”  

The home also acted as a frequent meeting place for the Woman’s Era Club, a Black women’s club founded by Josephine Ruffin and other local Black clubwomen in 1893. The club’s first report documented the general sentiments of its members:  

“It cannot but be admitted that we, as a race, have too frequently limited ourselves to this field with the result of contracting our vision, enfeebling our impulses and weakening our powers. We the women of the Women’s Era Club enter the field to work hand in hand with women, generally for humanity and humanity’s interests.” 

Through events and activities, the club encouraged the intellectual engagement of its members, addressed needs in the community, and maintained a broad vision for equality and social change. Members advocated for greater civil rights for Black Americans, supported women’s suffrage, and stood against racism and discrimination. The club’s vision for a world in which Black women took active roles in bettering their communities extended across the country through the club’s nationally published newspaper, 'The Woman’s Era.'

stops.significance: Following her escape from enslavement in 1844, Harriet Hayden and her family moved to their home here at 66 Phillips Street, formerly Southac Street, in 1848. While her husband Lewis became a famed Boston abolitionist, Harriet operated their home as a boardinghouse for freedom seekers. For over a decade, Harriet regularly welcomed freedom seekers, providing food, clothing, shelter, and information. Following Harriet’s death in 1893, 'The Woman’s Journal' published a moving remembrance, “Her bright, cheerful spirit and quaint, original utterances were an unfailing source of comfort and cheer in the darkest hours of the struggle. No history of that time will be complete without the name of Harriet Hayden and a record of the vigorous part she played.” In her will, Harriet left a sum of $5000 to Harvard Medical School for the establishment of a scholarship for Black students. Much as Harriet Hayden empowered freedom seekers throughout her life, this scholarship fund continues to aid Black medical students today.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue two doors down the street to arrive at 62 Phillips Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Following her escape from enslavement in 1844, Harriet Hayden and her family moved to their home here at 66 Phillips Street, formerly Southac Street, in 1848. While her husband Lewis became a famed Boston abolitionist, Harriet operated their home on Phillips Street as a boardinghouse for freedom seekers. For over a decade, Harriet regularly welcomed freedom seekers into their home, providing food, clothing, shelter, and information. Though often overshadowed by her husband Lewis in the historical record, her contemporaries in the abolitionist movement both recognized and respected the importance of her contributions to the Underground Railroad. Following Harriet’s death in 1893, 'The Woman’s Journal' published a moving remembrance, writing, “Her bright, cheerful spirit and quaint, original utterances were an unfailing source of comfort and cheer in the darkest hours of the struggle. No history of that time will be complete without the name of Harriet Hayden and a record of the vigorous part she played.” 

In her will, Harriet left a sum of $5000 to Harvard Medical School for the establishment of a scholarship for Black students. The Boston Journal wrote, “This scholarship is peculiarly noteworthy as it is the only instance of the kind in the United States and probably in the world, where a university has received an endowment from a former slave.” Much as Harriet Hayden empowered and aided freedom seekers throughout her life, the scholarship fund established through her will continues to aid Black medical students today.

stops.significance:
Arianna Sparrow lived a few doors down from her neighbors Lewis and Harriet Hayden. While largely unremembered today, Arianna Sparrow took an active role in the Beacon Hill community, particularly in the women’s suffrage and anti-lynching movements at the end of the 19th century. In the 1880s, she helped organize suffrage events throughout Beacon Hill, and she served as a member of the Executive Committee for the West End Woman Suffrage League, a primarily-Black chapter of the Massachusetts Woman Suffrage Association.  

While a member of the Woman’s Era Club, Arianna Sparrow became involved in the anti-lynching movement. In 1899, Sparrow joined a group of notable Black and White women leaders, many former abolitionists and current suffragists, in calling for a mass meeting to protest against lynching. During this event, which drew over 300 people, leaders condemned the unaddressed violence and vowed to continue the fight for civil rights for Black Americans.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Phillips Street and cross Grove Street. The site of the Twelfth Baptist Church will be on the left side of the road, a building approximately midway down the block. NOTE: This building is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Arianna Sparrow lived a few doors down from her neighbors Harriet and Lewis Hayden. While largely unremembered today, Arianna Sparrow took an active role in the Beacon Hill community, particularly in the women’s suffrage and anti-lynching movements at the end of the 1800s. In the 1880s, she helped organize several suffrage events throughout Beacon Hill, speaking alongside other community leaders to encourage Black women to register to vote in school committee elections and Black men to vote for local politicians who supported women’s suffrage. Sparrow also served as a member of the Executive Committee for the West End Woman Suffrage League, a primarily-Black chapter of the Massachusetts Woman Suffrage Association. Newspaper accounts recorded that she offered to hold a subscription of the nationally recognized suffrage paper 'The Woman’s Journal' at her home here in the heart of Beacon Hill, making it available to all members of the community.  

A member of the active Woman’s Era Club, Arianna Sparrow also became involved in the anti-lynching movement. In 1899, Sparrow joined a group of notable Black and White women leaders, many former abolitionists and current suffragists, in calling for a mass meeting in Boston to protest the lynching crisis sweeping the United States. During this event, which drew over 300 people, leaders condemned the unaddressed violence and vowed to continue the fight for civil rights for Black Americans.

stops.significance: Led by Reverend Leonard Grimes, Twelfth Baptist Church came to be known as the “Fugitive Slave Church” due to many of its members being formerly enslaved. In addition to helping freedom seekers, Twelfth Baptist Church members organized to help support and uplift local Black community members, including Edmonia Lewis. Born around 1844 to an African American father and a Chippewa mother, Lewis moved to Boston in 1864 to pursue a career in art. Inspired by Boston’s abolitionist community, her artwork showcased the courage of leaders such as John Brown and Wendell Phillips. While supported by local abolitionists, Lewis felt limited by her race in the United States as she declared, “The land of liberty had no room for a colored sculptor.” Eventually settling in Rome in 1865, Edmonia Lewis broke through racial and gender barriers and gained international recognition as a sculptor. On a return visit to Boston, Black abolitionist leaders held a reception for her at the Twelfth Baptist Church in December 1869.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Phillips Street until the intersection of Anderson Street. Cross the street and turn right up the hill. About halfway up the block is the former location of Sears Place.
stops.audioTranscript:
Originally located at this site, the Twelfth Baptist Church formed in 1840 out of a division within members of the nearby African Meeting House. Led by Reverend Leonard Grimes, this church came to be known as the “Fugitive Slave Church” due to many of its members being formerly enslaved. In addition to helping freedom seekers start a new life, Twelfth Baptist Church members organized to help support and uplift local Black community members, including Edmonia Lewis. 

Born around 1844 to an African American father and a Chippewa mother, Lewis left Oberlin College and moved to Boston in 1864 to pursue a career in art. Under the mentorship of a local sculptor, Lewis worked on refining her skills by creating medallions before advancing to portrait busts. Inspired by Boston’s abolitionist community, her artwork showcased the courage and nobility of leaders such as John Brown and Wendell Phillips.  

Her bust of Colonel Robert Gould Shaw received high praise and earned her enough money to continue honing her sculpting skills abroad. As a talented and determined artist, local abolitionists including William Lloyd Garrison and Lydia Maria Child offered Lewis encouragement, advice, and support. However, Lewis felt limited by her race in the United States as she declared, “The land of liberty had no room for a colored sculptor.” 

Eventually settling in Rome in 1865, Edmonia Lewis broke through racial and gender barriers and gained international recognition as a sculptor. On a return visit to Boston, Black abolitionist leaders held a reception for her at the Twelfth Baptist Church in December 1869. As a show of appreciation and support, Reverend Grimes, George L. Ruffin, William Craft, and others spoke highly of her and gifted her “a purse of money and a handsome ivory mallet.” Edmonia Lewis’s achievements inspired countless people as she disproved the idea that artistic genius was exclusive to the White race.

stops.significance:
As a Black woman born circa 1812 in Wilmington, North Carolina, Clara Vaught likely began her life enslaved.  

It can be inferred that between 1812 and 1852, Vaught escaped enslavement and ultimately settled in Boston. Living in Beacon Hill, she became a critical piece of the free Black community and Underground Railroad, regularly sheltering freedom seekers in her home. During the 1850s, Francis Jackson, Treasurer of the Boston Vigilance Committee, recorded a series of entries for Vaught, including, “December 8, 1852, Clara Vaught boarding Julia Smith and 2 chil[dren],” “March 1855, Clara Vaught for boarding [George] Mapsin,” and “April 1859, Clara Vaught for boarding James Gaston from Wilmington, N.C.” 

Vaught likely lived at several different addresses in Beacon Hill throughout her life. At the time of her death, the Boston City Directory recorded Vaught as a resident of 3 Sears Place, a street that does not exist today but would have been in this general area.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue up the hill on Anderson Street. Turn left onto Myrtle Street. Continue along the street until you reach 27 Myrtle Street.
stops.audioTranscript:
As a Black woman born circa 1812 in Wilmington, North Carolina, Clara Vaught likely began her life enslaved. However, in December 1852, the Account Book of Francis Jackson, Treasurer of the Boston Vigilance Committee, credited Vaught for boarding three freedom seekers at her home in Boston. 

It can be inferred that between 1812 and 1852, Vaught escaped enslavement and ultimately settled in Boston. Living in Beacon Hill, she became a critical piece of the free Black community and Underground Railroad, regularly sheltering freedom seekers in her home. During the 1850s Jackson’s Account Book recorded a series of entries for Vaught, including, “December 8, 1852, Clara Vaught boarding Julia Smith and 2 chil[dren],” “March 1855, Clara Vaught for boarding [George] Mapsin,” and “April 1859, Clara Vaught for boarding James Gaston from Wilmington, N.C.” These entries demonstrate Vaught’s consistent work as a safe house operator in Boston, providing a place of refuge for freedom seekers in the decade that preceded the American Civil War. 

Vaught likely lived at several different addresses in Beacon Hill throughout her life. At the time of her death, the Boston City Directory recorded Vaught as a resident of 3 Sears Place, a street that does not exist today but would have been in this general area.

stops.significance:
Established in 1860, the Home for Aged Colored Women served as a residential institution providing shelter, food, and other care for elderly Black women who could no longer support themselves. Many residents had been formerly enslaved, while others had been involved in Boston’s abolitionist movement and belonged to organizations such as the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society. 

Local Black women served as Matrons responsible for managing day-to-day activities and chores of the Home. Matron Rachel Smith served in the role for 25 years during which she organized an annual Fair to raise additional funds for the Home. She also connected with local organizations to hold entertainment events such as concerts and readings for the women. 

The Home relocated to this location at 27 Myrtle Street in 1865. As government aid expanded, the Home’s Board determined that a residential institution no longer best served the needs of the community and closed the Home in 1944.
stops.assetName: Site of the Home for Aged Colored Women
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along Myrtle Street to Joy Street, turn left to walk down the hill. A little less than halfway down the hill is the original entrance to the Abiel Smith School on the left, next to Smith Court.
stops.audioTranscript:
By helping to support her elderly former employee, Rosanna Miller, Rebecca Parker Clarke realized a need to care for aging African American women in Boston. After going door to door in the local area, Clarke confirmed her belief by meeting with over 15 destitute Black women. With the support of her son, Reverend James Freeman Clarke, as well as Reverend Leonard A. Grimes and Governor John Andrew, she and community members met to help organize a charity to address this problem.  

Originally established at 65 Southac Street, now Phillips Street, the Home for Aged Colored Women served as a residential institution providing shelter, food, and other care for elderly Black women who could no longer support themselves and relied on charity to survive. The Home served as a refuge for elderly Black women at a time when, according to the 1900 Annual Report,  

“No private institution would receive colored women, and the white paupers in the almshouses would not associate [with] them, so they were obliged to share the quarters assigned to the insane or vicious, or to remain outside, dependent on the precarious charity of an occasional benefactor, or of friends nearly as poor as themselves.” 

In 1860, the Home admitted its first residents including Rosanna Miller. Most women came to the Home through referrals from family, friends, former employers, or church leaders, and some women applied for admission themselves. Located in Beacon Hill, many of the Home’s residents belonged to Boston’s Black community or resided in New England. Many residents had been formerly enslaved and others had been involved in Boston’s abolitionist movement and belonged to organizations such as the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society. 

Local Black women served as Matrons responsible for managing day-to-day activities and chores of the Home. The opinion of highly respected Matrons also helped determine whether an applicant should be admitted, or a resident expelled. Matron Rachel Smith served in the role for 25 years during which she organized an annual Fair to raise additional funds for the Home and connected with local organizations to hold entertainment events such as concerts and readings for the women. 

As building capacity became limited, the Home focused on admitting local women and relocated to this location at 27 Myrtle Street in 1865. Later, the Home began to distribute outside aid to help a greater number of women by granting weekly allowances to help pay for their independent living costs. 

As government aid expanded in the 1900s and women increasingly expressed a desire to sustain themselves, the Home’s Board determined that a residential institution no longer best served the needs of the community and the Home closed in 1944. Today, the Grimes-King Foundation for the Elderly, Inc carries on the legacy of the Home and continues to advocate for elderly Black women in Boston.

stops.significance:
Opened in 1835, the Abiel Smith School became one of the first public schools in Boston for Black schoolchildren. For twenty years, it remained a segregated school until the Massachusetts State Legislature banned segregated schooling in 1855, the result of years of activism by the local Black community. 

Susan Paul remains one of the Smith School’s most well-remembered teachers. In addition to teaching the standard subjects, Susan Paul also instilled within her students a sense of civic engagement. She took them to anti-slavery lectures and established a school choir that raised money for the cause. In 1833, Susan Paul became a life member of the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society, holding leadership positions and assisting in their annual fundraiser, the Anti-Slavery Bazaar. Susan Paul’s life was cut short when she died of tuberculosis at the age of 32 in 1841. In their quarterly meeting, the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society tributed Susan Paul, calling her a “clear-sighted and stead friend.”
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around the corner to enter Smith Court.
stops.audioTranscript:
Opened in 1835, the Abiel Smith School became one of the first public schools in Boston for Black children. For twenty years, it remained a segregated school until the Massachusetts State Legislature banned segregated schooling in 1855, the result of years of activism by the local Black community.  

Susan Paul remains one of the Smith School’s most well-remembered teachers. In addition to teaching the standard subjects, Susan Paul also instilled within her students a sense of civic engagement. She took them to anti-slavery lectures and established a school choir that raised money for the cause of abolition. While a teacher, she wrote 'The Memoir of James Jackson,' which intended to show children how to live a life of character while also making a statement that children of color could become educated and responsible citizens. 

In 1833, Susan Paul became a life member of the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society, holding leadership positions and assisting in their annual fundraiser, the Anti-Slavery Bazaar. Susan Paul’s life was cut short when she died of tuberculosis at the age of 32 in 1841. In their quarterly meeting, the Boston Female Anti-Slavery Society tributed Susan Paul, calling her a “clear-sighted and steady friend” to the cause of abolition.

stops.significance:
During the 1800s, Smith Court served as the heart of Boston’s free Black community. Community members frequented Smith Court as they received an education in the Abiel Smith School and attended church services, lectures, and anti-slavery meetings in the African Meeting House. Smith Court also had deep connections to the Underground Railroad, including one memorable act of resistance. 

In 1847, Mrs. Dorsey, a formerly enslaved woman, lived near Smith Court. One morning, a slave catcher entered Mrs. Dorsey’s home and attempted to arrest her and return her to enslavement. A group of children alerted the neighborhood and activist Nancy Prince led a group of women to Mrs. Dorsey’s rescue. Prince, along with the neighborhood women and children, chased the slave catcher out of Beacon Hill while pelting him with stones. 

The courageous actions of Nancy Prince and the other women and children are just one example of how women worked to empower and protect each other within Boston’s free Black community.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to the African Meeting House on the left-hand side of Smith Court, behind the Abiel Smith School.
stops.audioTranscript:
During the 1800s, Smith Court served as the heart of Boston’s free Black community. Community members, including leading abolitionists and students, frequented Smith Court as they received an education in the Abiel Smith School and attended church services, lectures, and anti-slavery meetings in the African Meeting House. Smith Court also had deep connections to the Underground Railroad, including one memorable act of resistance. 

 In 1847, Mrs. Dorsey, described as “…a woman who, by some means, had succeeded in shaking off oppressions yoke,” lived near Smith Court. During the late morning, the slave catcher Woodfork entered Mrs. Dorsey’s home and attempted to arrest her and return her to enslavement. A group of children alerted the neighborhood and activist Nancy Prince led a group of women to Mrs. Dorsey’s rescue. 

Bostonian Thomas B. Hilton recalled, “Only for an instant did the fiery eyes of Mrs. Prince rest upon the form of the villain…for in the next moment she had grappled with him, and before he could fully recognize his position she, with the assistance of the colored women that had accompanied her, had dragged him to the door and thrust him out of the house.” Prince, along with the neighborhood women and children, chased the slave catcher Woodfork out of Beacon Hill while pelting him with stones. 

Following the incident, Mrs. Dorsey relocated to a different home in Beacon Hill. Woodfork did not return to Boston until after 1850 and the passage of the Federal Fugitive Slave Law. The courageous actions of Nancy Prince and the women and children from her neighborhood are just one example of how women worked to empower and protect each other within Boston’s free Black community.

stops.significance: Built in 1806 by members of the community, the African Meeting House served as an integral space for the spiritual, cultural, educational, and political life of Boston’s free Black community on the north slope of Beacon Hill. Living just around the corner on Joy Street, activist Maria Stewart took to the stage at the African Meeting House in the early 1830s. She condemned slavery against African Americans while also advocating equal rights for all, particularly Black women. Stewart called Black women to action: “Oh, ye daughters of Africa, awake! Awake! Arise! No longer sleep nor slumber, but distinguish yourselves.” Maria Stewart encouraged Black women to engage in activism, believing women deserved a place at the front, alongside men, in the fight for civil rights. Speaking several years before Angelina Grimke’s speech at the Massachusetts State House, Maria Stewart made the first challenging step into the public space of activism, becoming the first woman to speak in public to an audience of men and women.
stops.audioTranscript:
Built in 1806 by members of the community, the African Meeting House served as not only a spiritual center but also as an integral gathering space for the cultural, educational, and political life of Boston’s free Black community on the north slope of Beacon Hill.  

Many impressive community leaders stood in front of audiences at the Meeting House to rally the community on a variety of topics: to support equal school rights, protest the Fugitive Slave Law, call for an end of slavery, recruit soldiers to fight in the Civil War, or to demand equal rights for women.  

Living just around the corner on Joy Street, activist Maria Stewart took to the stage at the African Meeting House in the early 1830s. Already a published writer, Stewart used her writings and speeches to condemn slavery against African Americans while also advocating equal rights for all, and particularly Black women. She asked, “how long shall the fair daughters of Africa be compelled to bury their minds and talents beneath a load of iron pots and kettles?” Stewart also called Black women to action: “Oh, ye daughters of Africa, awake! Awake! Arise! No longer sleep nor slumber, but distinguish yourselves.” Maria Stewart encouraged Black women to engage in activism, believing women deserved a place at the front, alongside men, in the fight for civil rights.  

Speaking several years before Angelina Grimke’s 1838 speech at the Massachusetts State House, Maria Stewart made the first challenging step into the public space of activism, becoming the first woman to speak in public to an audience of men and women. Her actions paved the way for other women to advocate for their own voices to be heard. Women in Beacon Hill followed in her wake, doing the hard work to push for social change and better their communities. Their work rippled beyond this neighborhood to greater Boston and beyond, leaving a legacy that compels us to consider how we can better our communities. 

Thank you for joining the Women of Beacon Hill tour. For more information about the Beacon Hill neighborhood of Boston, please take the Black Heritage Trail audio tour.

images.title: Women of Beacon Hill
